column2: The lore of the sea often reaches into the land -- where mariners gather, in hiring halls and clubs. Some of the meeting places ashore are bleak and temporary refuges where mariners find some respite from long tours at sea.

SCIENTISTS from the far corners of the world are coming to Iceland to study the biggest and most remarkable geographical discovery in four centuries -- a staggeringly huge, globe-girdling range of volcanic mountains beneath the sea called the Mid-Ocean Ridge.

WHITBY, England, Nov. 7 -- Labor disputes over bonuses and working conditions are causing serious delays in the construction of a final link in the West's early warning system against ballistic missiles.

The nation has a right to expect religious groups not to impose their special beliefs on others "by social coercion, by the use of economic pressures, political threats, boycotts or blacklists," a Fund for the Republic report declared yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- Qualified sources in the West German Government said today that Bonn had taken no new initiative with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- The perils of the atomic age, apprehensions about the Soviet Union and contemporary currents of ultra-conservatism have combined to produce a strange organization known as The Minutemen.

SYLVANITE was a jerk-water town along Pickpocket Run, "the griftingest stretch of highway in the West." Every year the Chamber of Commerce staged a western round-up for the suckers, a kaleidoscope of greed to the clang of cash registers.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 11 -- Negotiations that opened here this week could affect the economic and political future of the whole world long after the Berlin crisis has been forgotten.
A new Sunday newspaper called The National Observer will be issued by Dow Jones Co., publishers of The Wall Street Journal, beginning Feb. 4.
In the new Dutch resolution on West New Guinea the United Nations General Assembly has now been formally presented with one of the thorniest issues it will face at the current session.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A supporter of the late Premier Patrice Lumumbo now rules the captured city of Albertville in northern Katanga and is conducting a reign of terror, two Belgians back from the area asserted today.
Joan Baez, the current toast of the urban folk-music world, gave a program with the Greenbriar Boys Saturday night at Town Hall. More than 200 disappointed fans were turned away from the box office.
Nine Californians pay homage to West Coast wines in table settings on Altman's fourth floor.
The Brooklyn Philharmonia is a good professional orchestra and it has never sounded better than it did Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the opening concert of its season.
The entire area of the Wilmington, N.C., reserve shipyard is now under lease to the state of North Carolina.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 12 -- President Kennedy declared tonight that cooperative effort of the Federal and state Governments was the best way to insure an independent education system of the highest quality.
NORBORNE, Mo., Nov. 11 -- "He put us on the map."
A project to improve reading skills by the use of self-teaching textbooks is being developed for junior high school students here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The Security Council will meet tomorrow to try to avert the threat of full-scale civil war in the Congo.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $84,380,558,515. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
Among those who toil for charity there is an epigram that runs: "Name a disease and there's a ball for it."

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Four-year-old Saighton's Swell, owned by Brackenbriar Kennels of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., won his first English springer spaniel open all-age stake today in the twenty-eighth annual Connecticut field trial.
LISBON, Portugal, Monday, Nov. 13 -- The people of Portugal voted yesterday in an election that the regime described as a "magnificent example of serenity."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 12 -- Reliable informants said today that United States Air Force jets were flying reconnaissance missions over South Vietnam to pin-point build-ups and movements of Communist rebel forces and their secret bases.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Neues Deutschland, organ of the ruling Socialist Unity [Communist] party, devoted a 5,000-word article today to questions concerning the Stalinist personality cult as it relates to East Germany.
The Federal Aviation Agency has announced plans for a year-long study of the ability of pilots to detect potential collisions visually.

RICHARD RALSTON HOUGH, head of the Presidential task force whose study in air traffic was released yesterday, is at home on land, in the water and in the air. As an undergraduate at Princeton University, he set two world's swimming records in one week.
CLIFTON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- About 1,000 persons paid homage at a Veterans Day observance today in Memorial Park to twenty-two North Jersey recruits who died in a plane crash in Virginia Wednesday.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 12 -Continuing inflation was termed today the chief threat to prosperity in the real estate field, the area of economy usually thought to be most heavily protected.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -The Boston Celtics defeated the Chicago Packers in a National Basketball Association game tonight, 112 -- 96.

THREE members of the New York City Ballet -- Lois Bewley, Charles Bennett, and Bill Carter -- introduced themselves to New York as choreographers yesterday afternoon in Kaufmann Concert Hall, in a program of chamber dance.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Chancellor Adenauer declared tonight that his new coalition Government would make no changes in West German foreign policy.

The F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company, which reportedly had all but signed the contract for the right to broadcast the New York Mets baseball games next season, apparently has bobbled the ball and allowed Liebmann Breweries to come home with the winning run.
Breaking the game wide open with two swift third-period goals, the New York Rangers continued to move on high last night as they whipped the Chicago Black Hawks once again.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- George Washington Bristow, Chief Justice of the Illinois Supreme Court, died today in the University of Illinois Hospital here where he underwent major surgery to remove an intestinal blockage on Oct. 31. He was 67 years old.
The police suggested yesterday that two men who were shot Saturday in a Brooklyn nightclub, one of them fatally, had tried unsuccessfully to prevent the killing of a third man.
BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -East German border guards fired several shots at three women who escaped to West Berlin early today, the West Berlin police reported.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 12 -- Challenge of Pixiecroft, a 3-year-old cream-colored miniature poodle from Mount Kisco, N.Y., achieved two milestones in his ring career today. He won his first best in show and completed the 15 points necessary for a championship.
A slight, soft-spoken scholar and churchman from Ghana deliberately defied one of his country's most publicized laws here yesterday.
THURMONT, Md., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- President Kennedy flew by helicopter to Camp David in the Catoctin Mountains today for a holiday with family and friends.

Directors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., have voted again to increase the dividend on the company's common stock. This time the board, at a meeting in Culver City, Calif., late Friday, ordered a rise in the quarterly dividend from 40 cents to 50 cents a share.
A new attack on public welfare has come from an unexpected source -- social welfare experts. Their remedy is to "get tough" with the welfare programs, not with the welfare recipients.
Rapidly growing opportunities for trade and investment partnerships by United States and Asian business will be explored this week at the fourteenth annual Far East Conference.

It is a challenging prospect for 1970 that the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (O.E.C.D.) will unveil at its Paris meeting late this week. By that year the twenty free nations belonging to this organization -- including this country and our Western European friends -- aim to be turning out a total output of goods and services 50 per cent above the present level.

" Tell It to Groucho," a new television interview show starring Groucho Marx, has been bought by the Columbia Broadcasting System. Though no decision has been made on its scheduling, it may be presented on Thursdays from 9 to 9:30 P.M. beginning in January.
A former house mother at the dormitory of the State University's Long Island Center at Oyster Bay took issue yesterday with John F. Lee, who was dismissed Friday as president.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Last week's special session of the Legislature provided a vivid demonstration of how the lawmakers can relinquish much of their deliberative role to a strong and purposeful Governor. The legal machinery surrounding a special session, as opposed to a regular session, places almost all of the the key control in the hands of the Governor.
Fell, Meenan Co., a new firm of mortgage brokers, has leased space in 60 East Fortysecond Street through Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., broker. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., is the agent for the building.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -The feed grains met fairly steady selling last week, but other grains and soybeans moved higher.
HONG KONG, Nov. 12 -- Communist China implied today that it was not alone in resisting Russian efforts to ostracize Communist Albania.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Republican women are raising money for the party's 1962 campaign in unusual ways and are having fun doing it. Even Democrats, perhaps unknowingly, are contributing.

A record performance led a record field of eighty-seven starters in yesterday's Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior cross-country championship. Richard Vehlow of New York City Community College set the mark.

A new high in sales for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 was announced over the week-end by the Central Soya Company, Inc., soybean processor and feed producer of Fort Wayne, Ind. Sales for the latest period came to $298,243,743, or 8 per cent over the preceding year's figure of $276,073,360.

Adm. George W. Anderson, Chief of Naval Operations, will be the guest speaker Friday at the sixty-ninth annual banquet of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Four films are Scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
The American-Korean Foundation will honor Lieut. Gen. Chung Hee Park of Korea at a reception Saturday afternoon in the Carnegie Endowment Building, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
The inbound Zim-Israel passenger liner Jerusalem raced hundreds of miles off course yesterday to pick up a seriously injured seaman from the Spanish freighter Conde de Fontanar.

LUPUTA, the Congo, Nov. 12 -- This little ghost town in Kasai Province, about eighteen miles from the Katanga border, shelters several hundred dispirited Congolese soldiers, remnants of the Congolese Army force that invaded Katanga at the end of last month.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 12 -The four-day-old Government of President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy was under pressure today from organized labor and the politically significant student organizations.
Hoping perhaps to restore the physiques of their college days, eighteen married men fetched a football and appeared at 11 A.M. yesterday in Central Park.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 12 (AP) -- The passing and running of Fran Tarkenton and an interception by Dean Derby sparked the Minnesota Vikings to a 28-20 National Football League victory over the Baltimore Colts today.

In the Anglo-Russian Convention of 1907, Russia and Britain agreed to refrain from attempts to dominate Afghanistan. The two nations thus recognized the Afghan kingdom as a buffer state between British India and Imperial Russia.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- The tenure of the Christian Democratic Government headed by Amintore Fanfani was insured until the end of January when the Republican party decided today not to cause a Cabinet crisis at this moment.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 12 -- United States hopes for sending a man into orbit this year apparenty ended today when a flight with a chimpanzee was postponed at least a week.
The Parents Association of St. David's School is planning its sixth annual event for the benefit of the school's building and scholarship fund. It will be a dinner dance at the Plaza on Dec. 4.

Yaffa Yarkoni, a raven-haired Israeli singer, made her Town Hall debut last night. She had her first concert appearance here Nov. 4 at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, but had sung here during the last two years in theatres and night clubs.
OFFENBACH'S "Les Contes d'Hoffmann," now eighty years old, made its reappearance at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night after a two-season absence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Jimmy Brown ran his way into the National Football League record book today as the Cleveland Browns sent the Washington Redskins to a 17-6 defeat.
ALGIERS, Nov. 12 -- A Moslem member of the French Senate was assassinated near here this afternoon in a machine-gun attack. The assailants escaped.
Mayor Wagner will ask the City Council to consider increasing taxicab fares by 10 cents.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -An American export, the cocktail hour before dinner, was accepted today by an international medical researcher as an "unavoidable consequence of advanced civilization."
Joan Sutherland, Australian soprano, will make her Metropolitan debut on Sunday, Nov. 26, in the part for which she has become best known: the title role of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor."

CUERNAVACA, Mexico, Nov. 12 -- When Cortes first tired of the noises of battle, the squeak of obsidian knives on armor, the roar of Aztec conch trumpets and the drum throbs that summoned their plumed warriors, he withdrew to the palace he had built in this agreeable valley.
British European Airways took delivery of the first of three Whitworth Gloster turboprop Argosy freighters last week.

Your lead editorials "Toward Freer Trade" (Nov. 3) and "Trade in a Free World" (Nov. 5) are bewildering. As discourses on the idealistic aims of international trade they should rank high. As practical and realistic solutions to the ever-increasing problem of foreign competition the views endorsed by The Times will surely result in less national security and tragically increased unemployment.
The Greater New York Safety Council has asked for "review and reconsideration" of the City Planning Commission's veto of a municipal parking garage system in midtown Manhattan.

Jewish, Protestant and Roman Catholic religious membership rolls set a record in 1960. But the rate of increase was smaller than in previous years -- 1.9 per cent against a population increase of 1.8 per cent.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 12 -- International issues put up a good performance on the Amsterdam stock exchange last week, helped by some investment buying. Turnover rose to 17,800,000 guilders from 11,900,000 the previous week, while the general stock index rose to 409.7 from 403.7.
GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- Trading was lively on the Swiss stock markets last week and prices moved up to within hailing distance of last summer's record levels.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- A discredited Vyacheslav M. Molotov, who is reported to have been ousted from the Communist party and a Soviet diplomatic post, returned today in quiet obscurity to the nation he once helped to rule.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Kennedy Administration has taken all but the final decision to go to Congress in January with a revolutionary foreign trade program.
The site of the first synagogue in the North American continent was pointed out to members of the American Jewish Historical Society on a walking tour through old New York yesterday.

HAMBURG, Germany, Monday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Social Democrats defeated Chancellor Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union yesterday and won another four years' control of West Germany's largest city. The election was the first since the Sept. 17 national ballot.

The city Health Department offers New Yorkers free tests for diabetes. Dr. Kermit E. Osserman, chairman of the city Diabetes Detection Week Committee, and Dr. Irving Starin, co-chairman and Assistant Commissioner of Health, gave a reminder of the tests yesterday, as Diabetes Detection Week began.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The psychological efect of Wall Street's strength and an encouraging Government assessment of Britain's economic prospects gave a lift to the stock market last week.

DALLAS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -The defense came to the rescue in the final minutes today as the Buffalo Bills turned a 20-point fourth quarter into a 30-20 American Football League victory over the Dallas Texans.
St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square celebrated the 150th anniversary of its establishment as an independent parish yesterday.

Representative William Fitts Ryan, whose Congressional district was eliminated in the new reappointment law, said yesterday he expected to seek re-election next year but was uncertain in which district to make the race.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- "Once you are in television," said Walt Disney, "it's like operating a slaughter house. Nothing must go to waste. You have to figure ways to make glue out of the hoofs."

OTTAWA, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Ambassador has protested to the Canadian Government over an incident that marred the reception here last Tuesday on the forty-fourth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Standard Pressed Steel Company today reported profits for the first nine months of this year were down about 40 per cent from those of the 1960 period.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A return to Bible study for the answer to many pressing problems was urged today by two leading Conservative rabbis. They spoke at the opening of the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America at the Concord Hotel.

Frederick G. Storey, president of the Family Service Association of America, called yesterday for an intensive program to combat family breakdowns, which he termed the nation's "No. 1 social problem."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- The Religious Zionists of America elected Rabbi Mordecai Kirshblum of New York as president today as 600 Jewish Orthodox rabbinic and lay leaders ended their five-day, fifty-second annual convention.
In addition to Richard R. Hough, chairman, the members of the Project Beacon task force on airspace were:
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Communists who have long dominated the 240,000-member Electrical Trades Union suffered a major defeat in a recent election to the policy-making National Executive Committee.
A Brooklyn boy who made good in the Navy will be honored in his home borough next Friday. He is Admiral George W. Anderson, Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations.

Mme. Nonna Gaprindasvili of the Soviet Union retained her lead yesterday in the women's world championship challengers chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia. Eight adjourned games were played off.

What are the uses of a marsh, specifically, the 15,000 acres or so of tidal marsh that belong to the towns of Hempstead and South Oyster Bay? Contrary to the impression held by many people, a marsh is one of the most productive kinds of land.
The Department of Buildings announced yesterday it would take action against the owners of record in thirty-three eases involving properties managed by David B. Solove.
Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru reaffirmed yesterday his policy of nonalignment for India but also asserted that the Soviet Union was "completely wrong" in resuming nuclear tests last September.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The leaders of the anti-segregation demonstration in which hundreds of whites and Negroes took part in Baltimore yesterday met today to plan a similar demonstration on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Peace Corps has recruiting troubles again.

A White House Regional Conference will be held Thursday and Friday in the Commodore, Biltmore and Roosevelt Hotels by 4,000 Federal, state and local officials on domestic problems and policies. The delegates will represent eight states.

GARDENA, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Jimmy Clark, a former marine from Huntington Beach, Calif., today won the $7,500 Gardena Valley open golf tournament for the second straight year. Clark shot a five-under-par 30-36 -- 66 for a 54-hole score of 201.
WAS the slam bid in today's deal a good one? It would have been down two if West had made his most effective opening lead. The slam was made because West's natural lead was favorable to the declarer.

The Government of Trinidad and Tobago has formally taken possession of British West Indian Airways. A check for the purchase price of $1,456,000 was presented to British Overseas Airways Corporation, the former owner, on Nov. 1.
DENVER, Nov. 12 (AP) -Jack Kemp threw scoring passes of 91 and 16 yards today as the unbeaten San Diego Chargers defeated the Broncos, 19 -- 16, for their tenth triumph.

The Scholarship Fund of the Nightingale-Bamford School, 20 East Ninety-second Street, and the Yorkville Youth Council will gain Saturday from the annual Christmas Fair, to be held at the school from 10 A.M. until 5 P.M.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -The Boston Bruins whipped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 3, tonight to gain revenge for a 9-1 National Hockey League loss to the Leafs on the same Boston Garden ice just three weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -Despite recent budget trimming, the National Institutes of Health have about 25 per cent more money to spend this year than the previous year.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Adios Butler, the world champion pacer, who won the final race of his career (the $50,000 National Pacing Derby) at Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night, will be retired at an Adois Butler Night ceremony on Wednesday, Nov. 22.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Governor Rockefeller set in motion today a broad state study of how survivors of a nuclear attack could organize and rebuild.
Foreign exchange market was dull during the past week. Business transacted was mostly routine with prices moving within a narrow range.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Two quick touchdowns early in the third period broke up a close National Football League game today and helped the Detroit Lions to a 45-14 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- Demand for steel was holding firm last week. The mills had not had the wave of protective buying they have been long expecting. However, there was no weakening of demand and most signs pointed to modest gains for this month and December.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A local union in a key Ohio stamping plant voted today against accepting either a new national contract or local-level working agreement recently negotiated with the Chrysler Corporation by the United Automobile Workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A national organization has been created to push for President Kennedy's program of medical care for the aged.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy announced yesterday that he had assigned more than 600 additional members of his force to areas where crime incidence is high. The patrols, including detectives and policewomen, are on duty mainly from 4 P.M. to midnight, when street crime is at a peak.
Tigerishly alert in seizing the fullest advantage from every opportunity, the Giants stormed to a 38 -- 21 victory over the Eagles yesterday before a roaring crowd of 62,800 at Yankee Stadium.
FORTUNATELY, General Electric engineers are content to let most of their 1962 equipment look as familiar as last year's hats.

Cardinal Spellman yesterday called on all Roman Catholics in the New York Archdiocese to support President Kennedy's Thanksgiving proclamation urging Americans to extend their blessings over the world.
The New York City Opera Company ended its fall season in a blaze of glory last night at City Center. The opera was Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," and the performance was perfectly grand.

FEW of the great questions that eternally perplex mankind have troubled more poets, preachers and thinkers than the nature of man itself. "What is man, that Thou are mindful of him?" sang the Psalmist. "For Thou hast made him a little lower than the angels, and hast crowned him with glory and honor."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Gen. Rafael L. Trujillo Jr. proposed today the elimination of his father's name from all public places. He asked that history be allowed to judge the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molinia after "contemporary passions calm down."

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Bart Starr hurled three touchdown passes, one of them to Army-bound Paul Hornung, who scored 19 points today as the Green Bay Packers downed the Chicago Bears, 31 -- 28, in a National Football League game.

THE weather was balmy yesterday. So was the football game. Using methods that were mostly sane but sometimes delightfully daffy, the New York Giants smothered the Philadelphia Eagles with such rude finality at the Yankee Stadium that the National Football League championship pretensions of the home forces must be respected as completely valid.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (UPI) -Bruce MacGregor scored his first two goals of the National Hockey league season in leading the Red Wings to a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Two union officials opposed a private bomb shelter program today on the ground that it was unfair to most Americans and an admission that the nation could not solve the problem of finding lasting peace.
Soviet authorities have ordered the disbanding of the governing council of their nation's only Jewish seminary, leaders of B'nai B'rith were told yesterday.

Twenty-eight foremost spiritual leaders discuss the atomic crisis in "God and the H-Bomb," which will be published tomorrow by Bellmeadows Press in cooperation with Bernard Geis Associates. Among the contributors are Bishop James A. Pike, the Rev. Dr. Harold E. Fey, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, the Rev. Dr. Martin Buber, the Rev. Dr. Paul Tillich, Rabbi Israel Goldstein, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken and Pope Plus XII.

The Anglican Bishop of the Masasi Diocese of Tanganyika said yesterday that he had not succeeded completely in awakening American Christians to the problem of their African brethren during his one-month visit to this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall announced his support today of legislation to establish a Sleeping Bear Dunes National Recreation Area in Benzie and Leelanau counties in Michigan.

Cotton futures prices in the domestic market met with considerable selling pressure last week on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed with sharp net losses. When trading stopped on Friday, active futures contracts were off 25 to 87 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) for the week.
About 1,000 persons attended a rally sponsored by the National Council for Soviet-American Friendship last night at Carnegie Hall.
Good books about mutual funds are uncommon.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Rudy Bukich connected on two touchdown passes to Buddy Dial today and led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 37-7 triumph over the Dallas Cowboys in a National Football League game.
NOT all husbands are homebodies. Not all help with the diapers and the dishes. Some men shun domestic duties and are inaccessible during the major and minor crises that beset every family.
The Brookings Institution urged yesterday an expanded program of Federal aid to higher education.

HOUSTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -The Houston Oilers beat the Boston Patriots, 27 -- 15, today and took the Eastern Division lead from the losers before an American Football League record crowd of 35,649. It was the fourth straight victory for the Oilers since Wally Lemm became head coach four weeks ago.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- The Tax Department estimated today that about 150,000 residents of this state would receive complete state income tax exemption on their military pay as a result of legislation enacted last week.
Governor Rockefeller's adviser on the state's fall-out shelter program said yesterday that shelters were an effective instrument of this nation's foreign policy.

Newly added to Kermit Bloomgarden's agenda is an untitled script by Paul Osborn, who is best known for "On Borrowed Time." Mr. Osborn describes the work as an "off-beat" play. It will be done as soon as a star and a director are lined up.

The hope that millions of television viewers in the New York metropolitan area would soon be able to watch an educational channel for the first time has received a severe, perhaps fatal, blow from the United States Court of Appeals in Washington. The court blocked the sale of Channel 13 in Newark to a new educational group until it hears and decides objections by New Jersey.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Two white co-eds attending previously all-Negro Tougaloo Southern Christian College have found the experience "extremely educational."

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Delegates to the convention of the Negro American Labor Council denounced today the recent censure of A. Philip Randolph, council president, by the top command of the labor federation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A labor spokesman accused Arthur H. Burns, chief economic adviser to former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, today of trying to undermine public confidence in the Labor Department's unemployment figures.
New York is back on the intercollegiate football map.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Abdelkrim Khatib, Morocco's Minister for African Affairs declared today after a visit to Mohammed Ben Bella and four other Algerian rebels being held by the French, that their health was deteriorating rapidly."
KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 12 -- Muhammad Naim, Foreign Minister of Afghanistan, charged today that Pakistan had massed troops and armored units in northern areas adjacent to the Afghan frontier.

On Oct. 30 you published a letter signed by Theodore Draper in which he criticizes the Inter-American Press Association for having conferred on Dr. Jose I. Rivero of Diario de la Marina of Havana the Hero of the Free Press Medal. The criticism was based on Mr. Draper's belief that the newspaper represented the most reactionary classes of Cuban society and was not in agreement with the aspirations of the majority of the island's people.

In his column of Oct. 27 Arthur Krock has misrepresented the facts in his account of the discharge and reinstatement of W.W. Law, the militant Savannah mailman who heads the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in his home city and in Georgia.

CAIRO, Nov. 3 -- All merchant vessels of the United Arab Republic, including those owned by the famous Khedivial Mail Line, have been transferred to state ownership under nationalization decrees recently issued by President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
Cornelia Otis Skinner will present this season's single performance in New York of her monologues as a benefit for the Plays for Living Division of the Family Service Association of America.

CAIRO, Nov. 11 -- The agreement under which the United States will ship surplus food to the United Arab Republic, signed yesterday, finds the Egyptians in exceptional immediate need. The accord also affects long-range policies involving the relationship between the two countries.
" It was almost like last spring when practically all stock prices were moving upward." That is how one dealer summed up last week's trading in the over-the-counter market. He said:

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India arrived at Los Angeles today and almost immediately began a three-hour tour of Disneyland. Mr. Nehru, who flew here from New York for a two-day visit was greeted by Mayor Samuel W. Yorty, who said with a smile, that he understood Mr. Nehru was making his first visit to Southern California so that he could see Disneyland.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 12 -- The Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community had two items on its agenda last Tuesday. These were preparing the community's position for the next day's historic negotiations with Britain, and some presumably minor tariff matters connected with the Geneva negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An unusual scientific workshop will open here tomorrow in an attempt by the United States to lay the basis for international cooperation in the development and use of a global system of weather satellites.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The executive head of the congregational arm of Reform Judaism in the Western Hemisphere asserted tonight that the drive for Federal funds for sectarian schools was "perhaps the most serious challenge to religious freedom ever mounted in American history."

AT this time, or even a little earlier in the fall, almost every home cook here and in England used to be busily at work preparing the plum puddings that would be then aged in a cool, dry place and served at Christmas.

The Play of the Day for the Giants yesterday was conceived by a clubhouse attendant and spectacularly executed by a defensive specialist taking part in his first offensive maneuver in four years of professional football.
WARSAW, Nov. 12 -- The West German Government will pay up to $10,000 in compensation to each of seventy-three Polish women victims of Nazi medical experiments during World War II.
Psychiatry must study society as well as the individual if it is to understand the functions and malfunctions of the human mind, a panel of social scientists said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A new search for ambassadors is under way in Washington.

"' Nontaxable dividends' are not always nontaxable dividends." This word from the Internal Revenue Service should be a source of comfort to those who revel in riddles -- though not necessarily to the stockholder.
The remodeled and refurbished sanctuary and church house of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at Seventy-third Street were dedicated at the morning worship service yesterday.

BEAUMONT, Tex., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Joe Campbell shot a fine five-under-par 66 on the last round today and won the $20,000 Beaumont invitation golf tournament with a total of 277 on the Tyrell Park course.
President Kennedy has ordered an immediate start on a radically revised program to modernize the nation's system of air-traffic control.
TAMALE, Ghana, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The leader of the United party Opposition in Parliament charged today that more than 1,000 Government opponents had been arrested recently by the police.
New York's curfew, which sends professional wrestlers -- heroes and villains alike -- to the exit, is annoying the fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United States deficit in international payments climbed to an annual rate of slightly more than $3,000,000,000 in the third quarter of 1961, the Commerce Department reported today.

A second $100,000,000 issue of revenue bonds to finance the construction of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in lower New York Bay will be placed on the market today by a syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., W.H. Morton Co., Inc. and Allen Co.

Every change in leadership of the Soviet secret police, whose formal name these days is the Committee on State Security, is a major event in Moscow. Stalin ruled Russia by virtue of secret police terror thinly masked by a facade of ideology. After Stalin's death the late Lavrenti P. Beria came close to seizing the reins of power through his command of the secret police.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United States and Britain called upon the Soviet Union today to resume negotiations for a treaty to ban tests of nuclear weapons.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Leroy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said today that the renewal of broadcasting licenses should be more or less automatic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that the first year of the New Frontier had clear implications for improving the future of the nation's farmers.
BALBOA, C.Z., Nov. 13 -- By the end of this month, the Panama Canal channel through four of the eight miles that comprise the Gaillard Cut bottle-neck will have been widened to 500 feet.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Eighty-three members of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, including the United States, voted today for a resolution condemning Portugal for refusing to provide information about Angola and other Portuguese territories overseas.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Kelso came out of Saturday's Washington D.C. International horse race with sprains of front and hind legs and will compete no more this year, his trainer, Carl Hanford, said today.

We applaud the President's promise of Nov. 2 that "no nuclear test in the atmosphere will be undertaken, as the Soviet Union has done, for so-called psychological or political reasons." "A Raisin in the Sun" has been staged by the Central Army Theatre in Moscow, it was reported yesterday by Tass, the official Soviet press agency. Andrei Petrov, who directed the play, which deals with Negro life in Chicago today, is appearing in the cast.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee condemned South Africa tonight for its racial policies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Gen. Chung Hee Park, military chief of the South Korean Government, arrived here today for a ten-day visit in the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The Congolese central Government asked the Security Council today to provide it with effective assistance in the restoration of law and order in Katanga Province and in putting an end to the present "chaotic situation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The United States opened today a ten-day course on space weather stations for forty scientists from thirty nations.

SOME years ago in England a number of angry young men successfully used the various arts as cathartics, and so got a lot of people to share what was bothering them. The results were more dramatic in literature and theatre than in painting.

COLUMBUS, Ind., Nov. 11 (AP) -- All the capital stock of Lok-Products Company, Los Angeles, has been acquired by Arvin Industries, Inc., of this city, Arvin announced today. The financial details were not disclosed.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd. (Inco) had its best quarter this year in the three months ended on Sept. 30, with net earnings at $20,579,000. Net profit for the nine months, however, was adversely affected by "continuing increases in costs for labor and services and reduced deliveries and a lower average selling price for copper," the report explained yesterday.
GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- The chairman of the thirty-nine-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) urged today that the pact be overhauled to meet the new trend toward powerful economic blocs.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 13 -- An increase of 48.5 cents in the Nassau County tax rate was proposed in the 1962 budget made public today. Of this increase, 41 cents would go to the county payroll.

HELP is on the way for the millions of little women in America. These previously forgotten persons, five feet one inch or less, have been trying on the smallest dress in junior departments and looking at the results in a mirror. Perhaps the bodice fitted fairly well, but the hem was always somewhere around the ankle.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 13 -- The Presidium of the Knesset decided today to put before the parliamentary body as matter of urgency the question of the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.
With the election campaign past, a new move has begun among at least some of the city's Democratic Councilmen to increase their salaries from $7,000 a year to $10,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A decision of the New York courts that George Lincoln Rockwell cannot be denied a permit to speak in Union Square was left standing today by the Supreme Court.

After scrapping fifteen sets of blueprints, the designers for the Vivian Beaumont Theatre at Lincoln Center have created a vast, mobile stage that can encompass any production from classical Shakespeare to avant-garde Beckett.

Robert C. Weaver, the Federal Housing Administrator, said yesterday that his agency would crack down on communities that were getting Federal urban renewal and public housing help but that were not moving ahead according to plans submitted to the Government.

New York University, in its third season of varsity soccer, has been selected for a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship playoffs.
Eastern Air Lines proposed yesterday to increase fares 5 to 7 per cent on Jan. 5, except for first-class jet and air-bus or air-shuttle trips.
Rory Calhoun, a grizzled campaigner, made his debut as a light heavyweight against a relatively inexperienced foe at the St. Nicholas Arena last night and met with disaster.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Four years ago, during a car race at Montlhery near here, a driver named Adrien Loens lost control of his Maserati in a tight curve. Ahead lay an escape road. Loens might have stood on his brakes and then attempted to slide and skid his machine around the curve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The intimate sound of chamber music was heard tonight at the White House. Pablo Casals Alexander Schneider and Mieczyslaw Horszowski played Mendelssohn, Schumann and Couperin before a distinguished audience of musicians, diplomats and art patrons.
Policewomen arrested seven men in the city on morals charges last week in an accelerated drive against street crime.

The State of Connecticut is planning the sale of $25,000,000 of bonds maturing serially over twenty years. The issue will come up at public bidding on Dec. 5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A Pennsylvania representative, deploring the lack of a devil's advocate among the Administration's foreign-trade advisers, will take the opposing arguments directly to President Kennedy tomorrow.

Package or tie-in insurance agreements, the system on which every concern working in a construction project must place insurance with the same company, has been criticized recently.

The $6,900,000,000 budget deficit predicted by President Kennedy for the present fiscal year "probably will be more like $8, 000,000,000 by the time the period is over," Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said here yesterday.

The Columbia Daily Spectator, undergraduate newspaper of Columbia College, will become an independent membership corporation in 1962, the editors announced yesterday. This is designed to free the newspaper from financial dependence on Columbia University.
Four Americans of Italian descent were honored yesterday at the Italian Consulate General, 690 Park Avenue.
United States Government securities continued in price retreat yesterday, but major losses did not go beyond 8/32 of a point.

Realty investors headed by Joseph Leigh have bought the Slater Mills property at 468 Totowa Avenue, Paterson, N.J. The tract, which was acquired from the Slater Realty Company through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker, will be converted to an industrial center.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Government today designated all or part of thirty-nine counties as additional depressed areas eligible for special Federal aid.

Venezuela's break in diplomatic relations with Cuba is the most serious psychological and political setback the Castro regime has yet received in Latin America. THIS week it is possible to do your Christmas shopping, enjoy a bit of sightseeing and contribute to charity at one and the same time. It can be accomplished by paying $1 admission to "Les Boutiques de Noel," the annual Christmas sale held for the benefit of Cancer Care Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Additional Federal money to aid Cuban refugees probably will be sought to tide the program over until Congress reconvenes in January.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad said today that by the end of the year twenty-five Allied divisions, almost all combat ready, would be facing Communist military forces in the critical Central European sector.

With these new powers he would be able to negotiate tariff reductions across the board rather than on a mere item-by-item basis.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., opened play in the New South Wales tennis tournament today with a 6-1, 6-3 victory over Joan Mills of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Standard Poor's Corporation of New York City and Commerce Clearing House, Inc., of Chicago disclosed plans today to sell common stock to the public for the first time. The naming of Richard B. Henney as treasurer of the Duke Endowment, a large private philanthropic foundation, was announced yesterday. Mr. Henney, who succeeds the late Randolph H. DuMont, joined Duke in 1953 and had been assistant treasurer since 1955.
