Maass, chairman of the bank, affirmed yesterday. He stated that the bank's directors did not request Mr. Maccaro's resignation during a special meeting of the board last Thursday night.
CHAUSSON'S "Poeme de l'amour et de la mer" was the bright spot of the all-French program that the Little Orchestra Society gave last night at Town Hall.
Two 16,500-ton T-2 tankers flying the United States flag will be converted into self-unloading, 22,000-ton bulk carriers in a project announced yesterday by the Reynolds Metals Company.

Despite their acknowledge paucity of raw talent, the New York Knickerbockers outplayed the Philadelphia Warriors in virtually every department last night while scoring a 124-122 triumph at the Garden.

Many persons have taken tickets for the theatre party to "A Man for All Seasons" at the ANTA Theatre on the evening of Nov. 29, which will benefit Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc. The tickets that remain may be obtained from Mrs. Gillette Boland of 232 East Sixty-second Street.

An analysis of the Soviet government's economic growth and its threat to this country's trade supremacy is presented in "The Cold War Economic Gap," by John P. Hardt, C. Darwin Stolzenbach and Martin J. Kohn. The authors have held government posts in the field of economics, political science and Soviet affairs.
Billings for the AddressographMultigraph Corporation in the quarter ended on Oct. 31 set a record for any first fiscal quarter, the annual meeting was told yesterday in Cleveland
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for nine and twelve months ended on Sept. 30.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Industrials advanced again on the stock market here today, although the blue drips moved irregularly. On balance, changes were of a shilling (14 cents) or less and the market tended to weaken toward the close.
A public offering of $20,000,000 of twenty-year, 4 3/4 per cent debentures of the Macy Credit Corporation was made yesterday by Lehman Brothers, Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates priced at 100.
The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday it would not introduce wiretap evidence in any court "until Congress expressly authorizes the introduction of such evidence."
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Spring Broker, a winner only twice in eighteen previous races this year, moved from last place and won the feature at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The State Department denied today that the United States had intentionally delayed a response to Yugoslavia's request to buy additional surplus wheat here after last summer's bad harvest.
Dr. Harold W. Stoke, president of Queens College, defended the City University's ban on Communist speakers yesterday but differentiated between Soviet and local Communists.

Until all the facts surrounding the controversy over the dismissed president of New York State University's Long Island Center are made public, it is impossible to tell whether the new institution's troubles are routine growing pains or symptoms of a more serious disease. But aside from what may be a local academic tempest, the incident invites a critical examination of the entire State University's progress.
SOUTH POLE STATION, Nov. 12 -- Two men are working in a mine here at the bottom of the world.
A Democratic proposal to increase the salaries of City Councilmen to $10,000 a year, starting Jan. 1, received mixed responses yesterday.
The working control of Reliance Manufacturing Company apparel manufacturing concern changed hands yesterday.

How long is the football actually in play in a regulation college game? To supply an answer to that question a stopwatch was put to use at last Saturday's Harvard-Princeton game. The watch was started with the reception of each kick-off (in conformity with game-timing rules) and with the center snap on each scrimmage play.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- When it was announced yesterday that Dr. Elisabeth Schwarzhaupt had been named Minister of Public Health, thus becoming the first woman to head a West German ministry, she was at a loss to explain why her friends were fussing so much.
Max Pollikoff's Music in Our Time, a contemporary music series, has obtained the funds to carry on its seventh season.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- A United Nations investigation commission said today that "in all probability" Patrice Lumumba and two aides were killed "in the presence of" Moise Tshombe.

The nation's eleven big trunk airlines operated in the red again last month after having reported total profits of $1,348,000 in August. The Air Transport Association reported yesterday a net loss for the eleven major systems totaling $3,681,000 in September.
An hour-long network "inspirational" show has been scheduled for the last day of the year by Columbia Broadcasting System television.

A major portion of the Sanford family's 17 per cent interest in Bigelow-Sanford, Inc., carpet manufacturer, has been acquired by a group headed by Donald D. Harrington, an Amarillo, Tex., business man, it was announced yesterday by Lowell P. Weicker, president of the carpet concern.
Brookfield Farm's Intentionally, voted the best sprinter of 1959, is the high weight under 132 pounds and the even-money favorite in the $23,800 Vosburgh Handicap at Aqueduct today.
For almost an hour yesterday at City College a great teacher spoke before 100 students he could see but dimly and whose applause and laughter were muffled in his ears.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 344,729 tons in the week ended Saturday, compared with 352,866 tons in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the comparable 1960 week the output totaled 325,226 tons.
Family service agencies, often as beset with budget woes as some of the families they counsel, were told yesterday by an economist that they did not know how to get money for their work.

New orders for paperboard reached a record high in the third quarter, some 200 industry executives were told yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Paperboard Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The meeting ends today.
A BRIDGE hand is usually a story and a story should have a moral. The moral of the deal shown is that he who laughs last gets the plus score in bridge.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Eleven Freedom Riders, appealing convictions growing out of a test of segregation at a bus station, pleaded not guilty today at their arraignment. Judge Eugene Carter set their circuit court trial for next Monday.

A leading advertising man hurled some sharp criticisms yesterday at television, radio, magazines, newspapers, advertising agencies, the Federal Trade Commission and the advertising business in general.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The diplomatic muddle of the last week over who proposed what to whom on Berlin, and why, has not been wholly clarified. But the Administration is convinced that the basic situation has not been essentially altered.
ALGIERS, Nov. 14 -- The Secret Army Organization, the outlawed network of European extremists, warned today that it "strikes where it wants, when it wants, whom it wants."

Simone Signoret, who surprised Hollywood by returning to French films after winning the 1959 Academy Award in "Room at the Top," has finally agreed to make another English language appearance -- in support of Sir Laurence Olivier.
Gary Wood, Cornell University's sophomore quarterback, yesterday was named Ivy League back of the week for his performance in the Big Red's victory over Brown last Saturday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 14 -- Troops from Eastern Province have crossed into north Katanga and a small detachment is expected to reach Albertville presently.
The minutes of a hearing in Housing Court yesterday concerning the operations of David B. Solove were ordered sent to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for presentation to a grand jury.
SHAFTSBURY, Vt., Nov. 14 -- The occasional dry crackle of leaves on the side of West Mountain indicated to a visiting ex-Vermonter the possibility of an approaching deer or another deer hunter.
A gazetteer of Manhattan night life could currently list authentic folk music from the highlands of Armenia to the lowlands of Scotland.

As a sound truck blared a tune that warned, "Don't cross in the middle of the block," Traffic Commissioner T.T. Wiley darted in the rain yesterday from the Astor Hotel to open the department's holiday safety campaign.

OF all the chefs who have presided over American kitchens, none enjoyed greater fame than the late Louis Diat. As master of cuisine for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, he lived in an era when most hotel men had never heard of cost control.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Portugal walked out of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committe today after the committe voted to allow two African nationalists from Portuguese Guinea and the Cape Verde Islands to testify before the committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Army today cut its December draft call to 16,000 men, the smallest number since the United States began its military build-up for the Berlin crisis.

GUATEMALA CITY, Nov. 14 -- The C.I.A. has come to be regarded as the physical agent of United States Latin-American policy when that policy is expressed by force. In cruder days this role was reserved for the Marine Corps whose Maj. Gen. Smedley Butler confided in his memoirs: "I helped make Mexico, and especially Tampico, safe for American oil interests in 1914.
The Texas Longhorns, unbeaten in eight games, headed the United Press International major college football ratings yesterday for the second straight week.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- Chancellor Adenauer and his new coalition Cabinet, including West Germany's first woman minister, took the oath of office today in a brief ceremony in the Bundestag, the lower house of Parliament.
City school officials got a glimpse yesterday of the shape of school buildings to come.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that he was "very hopeful" that the Western powers would soon agree on a joint position over Berlin and begin negotiations with the Soviet Union.
The exploitation of performers by the League of New York Theatres and the Dramatists Guild was charged yesterday by the Theatrical Artists' Representatives' Association.
Alfred C. Thompson, a boxer who became the country's No. 1 merchant, was honored yesterday by the National Retail Merchants Association.
Most commodity futures declined yesterday on the New York exchanges, with Maine potatoes leading the way by dipping to new lows for the lives of all contracts on the Mercantile Exchange.

A forty-year leasehold on the Melrose Central Building at 260 East 161st Street, corner of Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Melrose Building Inc. The buyer was Peter K. Feinberg. John J. Reynolds Inc., was the broker. The rentals aggregate $2,500 000.

Five years ago Carroll Shelby, then the top man in American sports car racing, made a prediction. He said: "Inside of five for six years America will produce a world road-racing champion. In the United States, under the Sports Car Club of America and several independent clubs, we have more racing-activity than any other country in the world.
The New York Mets' baseball games may be televised by WNTA-TV if educational interests are unable to complete their purchase of the Station by the contract date of Nov. 27.
Jack I. Straus, chairman of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., made a strong plea yesterday for citizen's support of urban renewal programs.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (Canadian Press) -- Tinto Holdings, Ltd., a subsidiary of Rio Tinto Company of London, England, has offered to purchase all the outstanding shares of Rio Tinto Mining Company of Canada, Ltd., at 95 cents a share.
Pablo Casals the 'cellist, joined nine other leading international figures yesterday in appealing to President Kennedy to abstain from nuclear testing.
THE New York Brass Quintet, a trim, lively set of five musicians, provided some fine horn playing last night at Town Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- William E. Miller, the Republican National Chairman, said today President Kennedy should repudiate a "vicious and vulgar personal attack" on Governor Rockefeller and the Governor's family.

In The Times of Nov. 14 you have a story by Paul Crowell to the effect that the City Council would get the taxi bill this week. Mr. Crowell did a very good job of explaining where the proposed 10-cent increase in taxi fares would go.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Andrew W. Cordier, United Nations Under Secretary for General Assembly Affairs, was commended today for more than fifteen years of "devoted service" to the world organization.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon predicted tonight that the Soviet people's "obsession for peace" and Premier Khrushchev's intelligence would prevent war.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- East and West were deadlocked today in the General Assembly in a contest for one of the six non-permanent seats in the eleven-member Security Council.
" Salome," by Richard Strauss, will be given at the Metropolitan Opera this season after all.
The City Council took the first of a number of vital steps yesterday to make municipal government functions and practices conform with the new City Charter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the nation's money supply increased sharply in October for the second consecutive month, following a five-month period of virtual stability.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Cus D'Amato, Floyd Patterson's manager, charged tonight that Peter Fuller had not lived up to his contract in Patterson's world heavyweight title defense against Tom McNeeley scheduled here Dec. 4.
Fordham University will dedicate its new School of Law buildings in two-day ceremonies beginning Friday. The structures are in Lincoln Square.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 14 -- President Urho Kekkonen reacted tonight to Soviet demands for greater political stability in Finland by ordering Parliamentary elections for Feb. 4 and 5. The balloting had been scheduled for next summer.
Only three games were decid-I ed yesterday in the twelfth round of the women's world championship challengers chess tournament in Vx-ajaeka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company announced yesterday that it had realigned its board of directors and the board's committees because of the recent death of its chairman, John D. Farrington.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14 -- Premier Tancredo Neves outlined today a program designed to help Brazil curb inflation and spur economic development.
FORT RILEY, Kan., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Paul Hornung, the National Football League scoring king since 1959, became Pvt. Hornung today when he checked into the Army base here for a tour of active duty.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, will pass title today to the blockfront on the west side of Eighth Avenue between Fifty-fourth and Fift-fifth Streets. The block includes the old Stillman gymnasium, long a training center for prize-fighters.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A white man facing death for raping a Negro woman and a Negro man facing death for raping a white woman were granted new trials today.

The First Republic Corporation of America, a national realty concern, has contracted to buy the ten-story office building at 315 West Forty-fourth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. The building was occupied until a few years ago by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- Mexico's entry, 'Animas Trujano," starring Japan's celebrated actor, Toshiro Mifune, was selected best picture at the fifth annual San Francisco International Film Festival, which ended tonight. The picture was directed and produced by Ismael Rodriguez.

Events today: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Texas Boys Choir, Town Hall, 8:30; Loewenguth Quartet, French institute, 22 East Sixtieth Street, 8:30; Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, Kaufmann Concert Hall, Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30.

The resignation of Charlie Hurth as general manager of the New York Mets was announced by the club yesterday. A spokesman said the parting had been amicable, but no one knew whether Hurth, whose three-year contract had more than a year to go, had been paid off in full.
Counterfeit $10 bills have flooded New York City in the last two months, the Secret Service announced yesterday.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A will bequeathing a $228,000 estate to the state to promote vocal music and "develop the lungs of children" was upheld today by the Iowa Supreme Court.

The food industry was urged yesterday to take heed of criticisms bf the business. At the same time, however, the industry was exhorted to make greater efforts to explain why many of the criticized practices were vital to the growing industry.

IN the epilogue to "Brecht on Brecht: His Life and His Art," the late German playwright, as personified by Eli Wallach, says of himself that he still lives on and that he is like "the man who takes a brick along to show what his house was like."
HARTFORD, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Rev. Joseph Warren Hutchens of Bridgeport was consecrated Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut today.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 942 persons were injured by automobiles in the city last week. This is a decline of thirty-four from the 976 injured in the like 1960 Week.
BONHAM, Tex., Nov. 14 (AP) -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn weakened today in his struggle with cancer and members of his immediate family gathered at his hospital bedside.
The future of the French superliner Liberte as a harbor-locked floating hotel was assured yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Kennedy appointed James J. Saxon Controller of the Currency today. He succeeds Ray M. Gidney whose approval of several bank mergers has been challenged in court by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Louisiana State University declined an invitation from the Sugar Bowl in New Orleans today. The football team indicated in a vote that it would rather spend New Year's Day in a bowl farther away from home.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had been holding two West German tourists on espionage charges for more than two months.

BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- East Germany changed the name of the industrial city of Stalinstadt today as part of what appeared to be a sweeping campaign to obliterate all references to Stalin from the country's public life.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- An official of the National Park Service urged New Jersey today to buy as much open land now as it possibly can.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- "He [D'Amato] ought to read the contract," was Peter Fuller's comment tonight.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 14 -- Henry T. Adios drew post position No. 3 today for the $145,377 Messenger Stakes pace, harness racing's richest race, on Friday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
The Coast Guard's big white icebreaker Westwind steamed back into New York Harbor yesterday after a five-month tour of duty that took her within 340 miles of the North Pole.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Counsel for Dave Beck, former president of the Teamsters Union, asked the Supreme Court today to reverse his conviction for embezzling union funds.
Directors of the Dictaphone Corporation authorized yesterday the declaration of a 50-cent dividend on the common stock, payable on Dec. 2 to holders of record of Nov. 24.
B'nai B'rith yesterday adopted the largest operating budget in its history, $7,487,000. This is an increase of $470,000 over the current budget.
The General Motors Corporations Cadillac Division is preparing the Cleveland Ordnance plant for production of three models of military tracked vehicles.
Thousands of New Yorkers and visitors waited in line yesterday to view a single picture -- Rembrandt's masterwork "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer."
The New York Football Giants probably will have the job Sunday of defending against Rudy Bukich and Bobby Layne, in that order, when the Pittsburgh Steelers meet New York at Yankee Stadium.
The White House Regional Conference, which has been in seven cities already, opens a two-day stand here tomorrow.
Two manufacturers of men's shirts and two retailers differed sharply yesterday over the merits of selling to discount stores.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- India scored 255 runs for four wickets by the close of play today in reply to England's first-innings scare of 500 for eight declared. The match was the first of three cricket test matches between the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Following is the text of a communique issued today by President Kennedy and Gen. Chung Hee Park, head of the South Korean Military Government:

TO the British Broadcasting Corporation must go the current season's early honors for superlative drama on the home screen. The B.B.C. production of "Antigone," which was seen last night over Channel 5, is a work of surpassing intensity, beauty and excitement.

The Supreme Court has left standing a decision of our New York courts that George Lincoln Rockwell cannot be denied a permit to speak in Union Square. We applaud this position of the Court, though we have nothing but contempt for Rockwell and the so-called "American Nazi party" which he leads. Free speech is free speech. Denying the right to it in one case, however obnoxious the protagonist, endangers the principle itself.
The Humble Oil and Refining Company plans to acquire the Olin Oil and Gas Corporation in a transaction involving about $67,900,000.

The Flight Engineers International Association announced yesterday its conditional acceptance of the latest report by the Feinsinger Commission in the dispute between airline pilots and flight engineers.
George Lincoln Rockwell said yesterday he was planning a speech in New York as a result of a decision Monday by the United States Supreme Court.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- Delegates representing 104 members and associate members of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization were asked today at the body's eleventh conference to "make a beginning without delay" toward establishing a world food bank along lines similar to proposals by the United States delegation.

Agreement with the Russians "in those areas where we have common interests" is possible if unity can be created and maintained in the Western world, the new British Ambassador to the United States said last night.

The report of the United Nations legal experts that Premier Patrice Lumumba of the Congo was, in all likelihood, murdered by Belgian mercenaries with the responsible association of Premier Moise Tshombe and other high Katangese officials is utterly shocking. It confirms the worst suspicions held at the time. We must expect to see profound and unhappy repercussions in the tragic country of the Congo.
A plan to cut a pedestrian mall flanked by shops and new buildings from Forty-fifth to Fifty-ninth Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas was discloved yesterday.

ROBERT PENN WARREN, teacher, poet and novelist, twice winner of a Pulitzer Prize (once for fiction, once for poetry), is one of the most brilliantly accomplished of contemporary American writers. His command of language is exceptional. His technical dexterity is impressive. His earnest concern with eternal verities does him credit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Kennedy is heading West this week for a variety of reasons. He wants a change from the confining atmosphere and issues of Washington. He wants to help the Democratic National Committee cut its $1,500,000 deficit, and he wants it known that he intends to be the political leader of his party.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Vice President Johnson said tonight that some Americans were "unwitting allies" of Communists because in fighting communism they "would destroy the shield of unity, justice and integrity that has been our great protector through the ages."

Michael H. Prendergast, the beleaguered chairman of the Democratic State Committee, restated yesterday his intention to stay in office until his term ends in the middle of 1962, in spite of efforts by the party's national leadership to replace him.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The game of musical invalid-chairs goes on and on at Army, with the backfield in a continual state of flux.

THE souvenir of the occasion was most appropriate. It was a perpetual-motion clock that Dolph Schayes received in Syracuse last Sunday when he played in his 683d consecutive National Basketball Association game and thereby set an endurance record. Judging by the tireless way this 33-year-old New York University alumnus was performing in Madison Square Garden last night, he can continue indefinitely as the dribbling counterpart of Lou Gehrig, the original Iron Horse.

YESTERDAY was Ladies' Day in the Louvis XVI Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Men were "welcome if accompanied by a lady" at the fourth all-day Woman In vestors Clinic sponsored by the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business Inc.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The Petroleum industry can reduce its costs by $500,000,000 a year by drilling fewer unnecessary wells, an investment banker said here today.
Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., experienced a sharp setback in the quarter and nine months ended on Sept. 30 when losses exceeded $12,000,000 in each period, the, report disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Parents should take oral poliomyelitis vaccine when their children do to counter the risk of a doublecross by hand-me-down polio viruses, an expert warned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Union, after first accepting a United States invitation, has spurned an international scientific meeting designed to lay the basis for cooperative use of a global weather satellite system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A voluntary Government-negotiated system of aluminum trade among nations outside the Soviet bloc was proposed today by the United States aluminum industry to establish an "orderly pattern" of sales and expansion.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The United States has the choice of making the non-Communist world a partnership of trading nations or a battleground of economic rivals, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said here tonight.

There can be little doubt that Indian-American relations have benefited from the visit to this country of the Indian Prime Minister. Americans cannot fail to have been impressed by Mr. Nehru's obviously earnest desire for a peaceful and tolerant world. His patient explanations of controversial Indian views on non-alignment and the cold war probably changed few American minds but may have made the Indian point of view a little more understandable.

Joseph Gallo, the 32-year-old gangland figure on trial on charges of conspiracy and attempted extortion, was remanded to jail yesterday at the end of the court day by General Sessions Judge Joseph A. Sarafite.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- A 46-year-old professor of English at Cornell University was found dead in his car yesterday and his death was ruled a suicide.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, said that he would prefer to wait until next fall before reporting on his own ideas on the national composition of the United Nations staff.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Three Moroccan ministers sent by King Hassan II asked President de Gaulle today to free Mohammed Ben Bella and two other Algerian rebel leaders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The establishment of a Reform Jewish center here to deal with religious, social and political issues was reaffirmed today by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.
The International Business Machines Corporation has heen awarded a $1,960,000 Air Force contract for the production of B-52 bombing navigation systems.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The International Business Machines Corporation withdrew plans today for a world headquarters or other large office building among private estates here.

President Kekkonen's decision to dissolve the Finnish Parliament and call for new elections indicates that a political crisis has arisen in Finland in the wake of last Saturday's Moscow talks between the Finnish and Soviet Foreign Ministers.

In a sharply worded ruling, Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon yesterday ordered Chief Medical Examiner Milton Helpern to change the autopsy report on a shotgun death from "suicidal" to "accidental."

One hundred years ago this month, in the Norwegian town of Froen, a man was born whom many regard as the greatest of modern explorers. The memory of Fridjof Nansen is being honored in many states, by proclamation and otherwise.

SEATTLE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Two married scientists dropped from the University of Washington payroll are in Prague, Czechoslovakia, and have no plans to return, The Seattle Post-Intelligencer reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A proposal for a hemispheric meeting on problems related to Cuba met opposition from Mexico and a cool reception by key South American countries today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- A bus terminal cafeteria manager, Ralph R. Sizemore, was fined $50 today on two counts of permitting Negroes to eat with white patrons in a cafeteria.
ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller came out in strong opposition today to any negotiating or signing of a treaty with the Soviet Union to ban nuclear testing.
The General Dynamics Corporation and the Air Reduction Company pleaded guilty yesterday to contempt of court by having violated a consent decree against price-fixing.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Bill Russell's rebounding and Bob Cousy's playmaking powered the Boston Celtics to a 119-117 victory over the St. Louis Hawks in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The Marine Midland Corporation, the nation's second largest bank holding company, has made a written offer to acquire the Security National Bank of Long Island, Herman H. Maass, chairman of the Huntington, L.I., bank, said last night.
Imports of steel products declined in September, reversing a seven-month-long advance, according to the Department of Commerce.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Selling pressure spread though all the pits in the grain futures market today and nearly all the early gains were wiped out.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Australia's Big Three of tennis -- Rod Laver, Neal Fraser and Roy Emerson -- scored victories today in the second round of the men's singles play in the New South Wales championships.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Kennedy met the head of the South Korean Government today and promised him "all possible economic aid," continued military assistance and, in the event of another Communist attack, more United States troops.
The Board of Education and the State Investigation Commission are planning to work together to stamp out irregularities in the city school administration.

In case investors are worried that the number of new products coming from research laboratories face any danger of a slowdown, John L. Burns, president of the Radio Corporation of America, stressed yesterday the "even more startling" developments ahead.

THIRTIETH birthdays are traditionally distressing, bringing you up short at the end of youth with the prospect of middle age on the next horizon -- a time for stock-taking and looking a bit apprehensively into the mirror each morning.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- The political future of Dr. Hans Kroll, West German Ambassador to the Soviet Union, remained in doubt tonight following a ninety-minute conference between the diplomat and Chancellor Adenauer.
WATERCOLOR paintings of rooms in the homes of socially prominent Americans are on display through Nov. 24 at McMillan, Inc., 148 East Fifty-fifth Street.
In the planning stage more than two years, New York's third and newest stock exchange, the National Stock Exchange, is being prepared for opening day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Walter P. Ruether complained today that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had not solved its internal problems and was "united in name only.'
MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 15 -- Vice President Diosdado Macapagal took a formidable lead over President Carlos P. Garcia today in returns from the Philippine Presidential election.

FOR Lady Ormsby Gore, the willowy brunette wife of Great Britain's newly appointed Ambassador to the United States and mistress of Washington's largest embassy, life on Massachusetts Avenue is anything but serene.

The Gotham Bowl still hasn't found two teams willing to play in the scheduled post-season football game at the Polo Grounds Dec. 9. But Bob Curran, the executive director, is confident there will be a game.
FORD ISLAND, Hawaii, Nov. 12 -- A high-ranking officer of the United States Navy asserted today that this country had not "faced up" to one of the major problems of nuclear age defense.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- William A. Bailey, 27 years old, of Angola, Ind., a graduate student doing research work in civil engineering at Massachusetts Institute of Technology on defense projects, was sentenced to a year in a Federal jail today for refusing induction into the armed forces.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A savage winter storm struck the south-central and southwestern United States today, blocking highways and knocking out power and telephone lines in entire communities.
Contract negotiations are under way between the leaders of more than 6,000 Puerto Rican longshoremen and their employers on a labor agreement that expires at midnight tonight.
Steel production topped the 9,000,000-ton mark in October for the first time in eighteen months, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Stanford physicians reported today that they had virtually eliminated staphylococcus bacteria from nurseries at the Palo Alto-Stanford Hospital for twenty months.

Records fell in the stock market yesterday. Standard Poor's 500-stock composite and 425-stock industrial indexes and Dow. Jones Co.'s thirty-stock industrial average all closed higher than ever before in history going to 71.66, 75.32 and 732.56.
Seven Congolese school principals touring the United States visited a Greenwich Village school yesterday in a quest of ideas for meeting their problems.

Refusing to be stampeded by the Belgrade Conference disappointments, The Times has stated that our aid enabled Yugoslavia to remain independent of the Soviet bloc. It will hence continue to do so. Yugoslavia's independence is more important than the nature of its political system.

The State Commissioner of Education and the chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education disagreed here last night on whether students in the city's municipal colleges should be compelled to pay tuition.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Federal Trade Commission chairman Paul Rand Dixon declared war today on false advertising of worthless fall-out shelters.
The Montreal Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia-Baltimore Stock Exchange yesterday signed an agreement granting mutual trading privileges to their members.
The Vocational Advisory Service will benefit from "Art for Opportunity," a cocktail party to be held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. Ruxton Love, 651 Park Avenue, on Dec. 15.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 60 cents a bale up to 45 cents off yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Flags flew today on all public building and "God Save the Queen" was played this morning on the British Broadcasting Corporation's news programs to mark the thirteenth birthday of Prince Charles.
Red Cross bloodmobiles will call at four places in the city today to receive donations of blood.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The fourth major brush fire in two weeks was controlled today after having burned nine houses and 2,365 acres.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Kennedy has ordered increased efficiency and economy in Federal offices outside Washington.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Argentina advanced to fourth place tonight in the international jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show when Lieut. Eduardo Castaing, riding Merlin, turned in the best time.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 14 -- The Long Island Association, a regional chamber of commerce, today termed the 25 per cent tax-rate increase proposesd in the Nassau County budget "unrealistic and discriminatory against property owners."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy and Mme. Nina Khrushchev appealed today for world peace. To achieve it, however, they recommended the varying proposals of their husbands, the President of the United States and the Premier of the Soviet Union.
AS a comprehensive study of life in East Germany, "Behind the Wall," a thirty-minute telecast on Channel 7 last night, was inadequate and disappointing.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The United Synagogue of America asked the United States today to inquire of the Soviet Union about the reported recent arrest of Jews there.

A MODEL of a nuclear reactor may be seen in an exhibition, "Atomic Energy In Action'' at the Union Carbide Building, 270 Park Avenue. Also on view are displays depicting the evolution of the uranium atom in scientific thought, how it is mined and processed, and its constructive use.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14 -- The United States' investment in higher education for foreign students probably produces better results for the money spent than most programs of direct foreign aid, the American Association of Land Grant Colleges and State Universities was told today.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Billy Mathis, who had to build himself up so he could play fullback for the New York Titans, is in hot pursuit of the ball-carrying championship of the American football league, according to statistics released today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Kennedy said today that more emphasis should be put into the cultural side of American life.

American designers are now showing their spring collections to stores, preceding the openings in Paris and Italy. Spring fashions are not shown in Europe until January and February. General trends of the new designs are described below. The clothes will be in stores by about the first of the year.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Morocco announced tonight that Capt. Henrique Galvao, the Portuguese rebel leader, is being expelled from this Kingdom with six companions who briefly hijacked a Portuguese airliner in flight last Friday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- The district Court of Appeals ruled today that the Los Angeles Superior Court had erred in permitting the Machinists Union to expel two members for advocating passage of Proposition 18, the state "right-to-work" proposal.

On Nov. 3 you published on page 3 a small item from the United Nations which is of such importance that it should be blazoned abroad as a major event in the history of the United Nations and of the cold war. In some ways it is the most significant happening since the war.
A COMPREHENSIVE and often vivid hour-long tour of Spain went its way on Channel 4 last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Over Western objections, the General Assembly's Political Committee adopted today two resolutions outlawing the use of nuclear weapons in war and banning their testing or stockpiling on African territory.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14 -- The East Hudson Parkway Authority received from its engineering experts today a plan to trap toll-dodgers on parkways in Westchester County to obtain $1,800,000 more in annual revenue.

REFRIGERATORS and freezers have greater storage capacity, ovens come with removable doors and air conditioners are specially pre-tested for their cooling capacity. These were the improvements announced when Hotpoint's 1962 line of equipment was introduced at the Savoy-Hilton Hotel yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday authorized the borrowing of $50,000,000 in the bond market on revenue obligations maturing on Nov. 1, 1991.
MANILA, Nov. 14 -- During the campaign the Liberals charged that the Garcia Administration was corrupt and graft-ridden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The National Potato Council avoided today a fight over specific methods for curbing over-production and bolstering prices. It voted instead to leave possible solutions to a national advisory board to be named by the Secretary of Agriculture.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Navy appears to have shifted its emphasis in the last year from submarine construction to the building of guided missile destroyers and larger, more ates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Kennedy told two little visitors today that they were better behaved than his own children.

Mary Martin was honored yesterday by the United Service Organizations, the City of New York, and 600 persons, many of them prominent in the entertainment world, for her performances for the armed services.

The development of a new method of joining thermo-electric materials was announced yesterday by the General Instrument Corporation. The new technique, which involves the use of a special semi-metallic brazing material, opens the way for low-cost, assembly-line production of long-life thermo-electric components, the company said.

The Human Betterment Association of America elected the Rev. Dr. Joseph Fletcher as its president yesterday.
The sharp rise in the Treasury bill rate at Monday's weekly auction touched off corresponding rate increases yesterday in the short-term money market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department, taking a cautious attitude, predicted today that 1962 farm income would remain steady but not necessarily climb above this year's level.
Members and supporters of the American Women's Voluntary Services will attend "Write Me a Murder" Tuesday at the Belasco Theatre.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Two armed men escaped with almost $200,000 worth of uncut diamonds and other jewelry today after having tied up seven persons in a jewelry store.

A changing pattern of rising interest rates for both the short and long term became more visible in the bond market yesterday. United States Government securities continued to move downward in price. To dealers, the continued price retreat confirmed the end of bullish tinges in the bond market, at least for the time being.

Fifth-grade and sixth-grade pupils who were moved out of Public School 119 in Harlem last month so that repair work could be completed have been returned to a freshly painted and reconditioned building.

"OKLAHOMA!" was a wonderful musical production and it had a long run. Oklahoma also was a wonderful football team and it, too, had a long run. In fact, Bud Wilkinson's Sooners hold the national collegiate record of forty-seven consecutive victories, plus another streak of 123 successive scoring games. They ended simultaneously.
City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs proposed yesterday that a separate department of housing be established to deal more effectively with Multiple Dwelling Law violations.

Two well-known conservatives -- Roy M. Cohn and Godfrey P. Schmidt -- said yesterday they had been asked by a rightwing group whether they would consider running against Governor Rockefeller next year.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 15 -- The worsening flood and famine situation in Kenya was described by the Government today as "a grave emergency."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The head of South Korea's military Government met here today with three United States Cabinet members to get advice on the modernization of his army and the development of his country's economy.
With a change in riders from Eric Guerin to the Panamanian, Braulio Baeza, the Jagma Stables' 4-year-old Gyro closed on the outside to take Aqueduct's $23,000 Vosburgh Handicap yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 15 -- Congolese troops loy to Eastern Province have mutinied, and United Nations officials today linked their action to an attempt by Antoine Gizenga to establish control of the Congo in defiance of the central Government.
A leading ticket broker has called upon producers of major hits to restrict theatre parties to not more than four a week.

Yankee Stadium contained a bubbly blend of mud, sweat and cheers yesterday as the New York Giants practiced in a manner suggesting that they loved hard work. Coach Al Sherman called the drill "a very good one," boding ill for the Pittsburgh Steelers when they come to town on Sunday.

The Organization of American States has again postponed -- which is to say, evaded -- a decision to take any action against the Castro regime.
BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Two airliners collided at an intersection of runways while taxiing at Logan International Airport tonight.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has cited a succession of pilot errors as the "probable cause" of a Trans-World Airlines jet accident at New York International Airport May 9, 1960.
President Kennedy will be honored at the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday night, Dec. 5. He will receive the Foundation's annual Gold Medal.
The Singer Manufacturing Company, which has occupied the Singer Building at 149 Broadway since it constructed it in 1908, plans to move to Rockefeller Center about a year from now.
A Boston educational television station, whose studios were destroyed by fire, was the recipient yesterday of $35,000 worth of electronic equipment donated by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Delegates to the biennial convention of the United Synagogue of America today elected George Maislen of Freeport, L.I., president for a two-year term.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Navy said today it was still investigating the death of a Cuban worker at the Guantanamo Bay naval base last month.
A $3,500,000 program for improving the Flushing Bay approaches to the 1964-65 New York World's Fair site was outlined yesterday to the Army Engineers by Robert Moses, president of the fair.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Kennedy named today a twenty-three-member committee of Federal, state and local officials and citizens to help find jobs for nearly a million unemployed youths.
Victor Borge will entertain at the "Health for Peace" dinner at the Astor on Dec. 13. The event will benefit the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital at Denver.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- England had a lead of 237 runs by the close of play today in the cricket test match with India. However, with only one day left, it seemed doubtful the visiting team would be able to force a victory.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Cuban Refugee Center has tried out a program of telling exiles to accept bona fide resettlement offers or lose their relief payments.

TEHRAN, Iran, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has given full support to Iraq's plan to safeguard its "legitimate interests" in its deadlocked talks with the Iraq Petroleum Company.

Production of electric power in the nation totaled 15,520,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with 15,396,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,505,000,000 in the 1960 period.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 UPI) -- Syracuse shot at a blistering pace in the first half tonight en route to a 114-102 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game at Convention Hall.
Oregon sold $20,000,000 of bridge and highway revenue bonds yesterday at competitive bidding.
An appropriation of $50,000 to help pay for recodifying the city's Administrative Code is slated for approval by the Board of Estimate at a special meeting this afternoon.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 15 -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh rested today on their visit to Ghana. Both Ghanaian and British officials appeared to be pleased with the results of the tour on the seventh day of their eleven-day stay here.
Social Security offices here have scheduled a series of late nigh to advise persons 65 and older who remain at work about their rights under Social Security.
A bunch of young buckaroos from out West, who go by the name of Texas Boys Choir, loped into Town Hall last night and succeeded in corralling the hearts of a sizable audience.
The Communist party appeared determined yesterday to defy the deadline of next Sunday set by the Supreme Court for registering as an arm of the Soviet Union. A protracted legal battle was shaping up.
The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare announced here yesterday that legislation was being prepared to modernize the nation's public welfare system.

"Victim," a British-made film dealing with homosexuality, has been refused a seal of approval by the Production Code Administration for showing in American theatres. The decision of the movie industry's self-censoring group is subject to review by the Motion Picture Association of America.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 15 -- A bright red carpet in a classroom of the Great Neck North Senior High Shcool serves two functions these days: It offers a "red-carpet" welcome to students and visitors and protects the floor from the teachers."

The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to earmark a downtown block near City Hall for ultimate expansion of the Manhattan civic center. It scheduled a public hearing Nov. 29 on the map change.
The nation's airlines, striving for new business while their deficits mount, appeared divided yesterday on whether passenger fares should go up or down or remain where they are.

The three teams with the best won-lost records in the National Football League -- the Green Bay Packers, the Philadelphia Eagles and the New York Giants -- hold three of the four top positions in offense, according to official figures released yesterday. Each has a 7-2 record.
A steadily increasing volume of Soviet oil is being shipped from Black Sea ports to Western markets, a British study of open-market tanker chartering shows.

THE Boston Symphony came to town last night, giving its first Carnegie Hall concert of the season. In some respects the event was packed with nostalgia. Charles Munch, the orchestra's musical director, is retiring after this season.

No. 1 in the American Kennel Club stud book is Adonis, an English setter registered in 1878. No. 1,000,000 is Alice Grey Gown, a Shetland sheepdog listed in 1935. It took fifty-seven years to reach that historic A.K.C. figure.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Five former officials of the Liberal party in Nassau County received one-year suspended sentences in County Court today for violation of the state election law.
