CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 15 -- A Dominican radio station reported today that two leading members of the Trujillo family who left the country last month had since returned.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Hepatitis has struck more than 60,000 Americans this year to set a record, public health figures showed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Northeast Airlines notified the Civil Aeronautics Board today that the Hughes Tool Company had withdrawn financial support and that Northeast's credit for fuel and oil would be cut off next Friday.

Stocks made new highs again yesterday. All the leading indicators moved up for the day, although for a time it was doubtful whether they would. A wave of heavy selling hit the market on the New York Stock Exchange in the final forty-five minutes and all but wiped out the morning advances.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 15 -- The Belgian public indicated today that the United Nations report on the death of Patrice Lumumba was an attempt to injure the central Congolese Government, the Katanga regime and Belgium.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- After being elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association tonight, Herman Freydberg suggested a new par for golfers in his county.
All but two or three of the fifty-two mutual savings banks in New York City will begin paying 4 per cent interest on two-year deposits after Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday.
The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday it had made grants totaling $1,816,815 in the three months ended Sept. 30.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A suit was filed today challenging the constitutionality of two new Federal laws. The laws prohibit interstate transportation of wagering paraphernalia and interstate travel or transportation in aid of racketeering enterprises.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Administration-backed proposals to provide health care for the aged through Social Security funds gained support on two fronts here today.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov 15 -- Sponsored by the Fairfield Villages Mount Holyoke Club, a program of ballet to music of Tchaikovsky, will be presented at Stamford High School Sunday afternoon by Ballet Etudes, a school for professional choreography in Norwalk.

A new master will be on the bridge of the Home Lines passenger ship Italia when she returns here Saturday from Nassau, the Bahamas, after the first of forty-six trips to that resort in the 1961-62 sea-Ruffini.
Most commodity futures prices showed small gains in light trading yesterday on the New York exchanges.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The United States said today that the Soviet Union was trying to impose a three-man directorate on the United Nations Committee for the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space.

A painting by Rembrandt was auctioned last night for the highest amount ever paid for any picture at public or private sale -- $2,300,000. The painting, "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer," was purchased in four minutes of bidding by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The grain futures market made a little headway in spots today but losses were fairly general and broad in a rather quiet trade.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- After a dull start, a surge of buying raised prices of most equities on the stock market here today. British Government securities, too, closed firmer, except for some short-term issues.

As a student at the City College and a member of the Executive Committee of the Student Government was particularly pleased to read The Times' editorials of Oct. 28 and Nov. 4 opposing the Administrative Council's ban on Communist speakers at the City University.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The United States and the Soviet Union individually called today for an early resumption of disarmament negotiations. The Soviet Union proposed further that a disarmament treaty be ready by June 1.
The Vulcan Materials Company has purchased for an undisclosed amount of cash all of the capital stock of the privately-owned Kolker Chemical Corporation, Newark, N.J., it was announced yesterday.

Several New York newspapers have recently commented that Finland is the only European country to maintain payments on World War I loans. Your editorial of Oct. 19 makes a similar but not identical comment.
OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Convicts at Sing Sing Prison staged a sitdown strike today to press a demand that time off for good behavior be made mandatory.

The odds are 2 to 1, man to man, that Carlos Ortiz of the Bronx will defeat Paolo Rosi of Rieti, Italy, and the Bronx, in their listed ten-round lightweight fight at Madison Square Garden this Saturday night. Rosi has an opposite belief.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The United Nations General Assembly formally appealed to France today to give imprisoned Algerian rebels status as politica prisoners to end a hunger strike they have carried into the fifteenth day.
The paper industry called yesterday for Government action to assure fair competition for its products in European and other world markets.
The right of the Federal judiciary to intervene in a dispute over the apportionment of legislators here was challenged by New York State yesterday.
Two cast changes enlivened the performance of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.
Though Columbia will meet Pennsylvania Saturday here in one of the Lions' most important games in years, Baker Field probably will not be sold out.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Third-period goals by Bert Olmstead and Ed Shack enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to score a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The Leafs moved into second place in the National Hockey League, a point in back of Montreal.

Col. Solomon Foote Clark of Glen Head, L.I., was killed Tuesday night on the Long Island Expressway near the Queens Boulevard intersection in Elmhurst when he left his automobile to telephone for assistance. He was 69 years old.

The nation's gasoline production dipped to 27,977,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, from 28,116,000 the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year earlier the output was 27,051,000 barrels.

The concentration of theatres and the other facilities planned for the giant Lincoln Center complex will cause a huge influx of people. Even if only a part of the nine stages there are in use at a single time the problem of moving pedestrians, buses, taxicabs and private cars through the maze will be formidable. Existing traffic and transportation facilities will be overtaxed.
Twenty-five office workers, most of them women, were rescued from three stalled elevators yesterday during a seventh-floor fire in the fifty-seven-story office building at 20 Exchange Place.

The visit of West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to Washington next week has exceptionally important possibilities. Bonn at last has a government. Until now it had been possible -and reasonable -- to argue that the Federal Republic could not do anything about the Berlin crisis or the even more important issue of the attitudes to be taken toward East Germany and the broader question of a European settlement.
The Georgia State Highway Authority borrowed $35,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance construction projects.

SEATTLE, Nov. 16 -- President Kennedy declared today that it was "a test of our national maturity" to accept the prospect that negotiations on Berlin and other world problems might not lead to either victory or defeat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The United States recommended tonight that the Organization of American States defer action on a proposal to ease sanctions against the Dominican Republic in view of the return to that country last night of two brothers of the late dictator, Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
The New York World's Fair of 1964-65 has decided to sponsor an exhibition next year at the Seattle fair to give visitors an idea of what they can expect to see at the New York fair.
Three of the city's most active and influential teacher organizations were recommended yesterday as being qualified for a place on the ballot in the forthcoming collective bargaining election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -Both the railroad and trucking industries reported today that movement of freight loadings last week were substantially higher year-to-year and lower on the week-to-week basis because of seasonal factors.

ALGIERS, Nov. 16 -- Terrorists attacked an airline staff car with machine guns in the center of Algiers today and killed a civilian jet pilot. Police sources said that the victim, Pascal Doriano, 30 years old, had been "sentenced to death" by the Secret Army Organization, the outlawed group of European extremists who seek to keep Algeria French.

Several thousand students at Queens College in Flushing remained away from classes yesterday to protest a decision that bans a Communist party official from addressing a student club on the campus. The ban later was extended to the campuses of all city colleges.
Maritime labor has scored a major victory in its drive to organize foreign-flag shipping controlled by American interests.
BONHAM, Tex., Nov. 16 -House Speaker Sam Rayburn died of cancer in his sleep today. He was 79 years old.

Eastern Air Lines has filed to expand its "Air-Bus" service to Boston-Tampa-Miami traffic, effective Dec. 15. The daily flights would be offered in Super Constellations or DC-7B's, both piston-engined airliners, at night coach rates.
OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 16 -Two-thirds of Sing Sing's 1,773 convicts remained on a sitdown strike today as a protest against parole limitations.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the secretary of the late Gabriel Pascal, theatrical producer, was entitled to share in the stage and motion picture profits of "My Fair Lady."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -Chancellor Adenauer said tonight that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should be able to order the use of atomic weapons without the prior authorization of the President of the United States.

The Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America will open a three-day exposition in the Coliseum today at 6:15 P.M. Twenty-five thousand Scouts are expected to take part in the exhibits or demonstrations.
The Board of Education is planning to establish special classrooms in housing developments and use portable school buildings to relieve overcrowding in the city schools.

RICHARD FLORSHEIM continues his increasingly complex geometrical fragmentation of cityscapes in new paintings at the Babcock Gallery, 805 Madison Avenue. He keeps subject matter simple, sticking to the verticals of buildings and the horizontals of skyline, or of wide reflections in water, animating all by a highly mannered manipulation of light.
Judge Irving R. Kaufman told a meeting of lawyers last night that the bar had to share the blame with the courts for failures to institute reforms aimed at eliminating court congestion and delay.
"BELLA," which describes itself ambiguously as "a very musical comedy," opened noisily at the Gramercy Arts Theatre last evening.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The United States proposed tonight that the Congolese Government be provided with "a small but effective air force" to help deal with uprisings.

Mayor Wagner called for increased Federal cooperation on city problems last night. Among other points, he urged a more liberal definition of middle-income families to be aided in housing, and possible subsidies for railroads.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Britain urged the United Nations today to look into Soviet "white colonialism" behind the Iron Curtain with the same intensity it has applied to the remaining dependent territories in Africa and Asia.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 16 --- The memory of Messenger, the Eighteenth Century thoroughbred to whom virtually all present-day standardbreds trace their blood lines, will be honored for the sixth straight year tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

WHEN the glittering Pleiades appeared in the dark skies of Asia Minor on autumn evenings, the Phoenicians believed that the navigation season was over. They resigned themselves to wild weather until April.
Greater stress on practical research in the maritime industory was urged here yesterday by the head of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.
IN recent years Anna Xydis has played with the New York Philharmonic and at Lewisohn Stadium, 'but her program last night at Town Hall was the Greek-born pianist's first New York recital since 1948.
THE deal shown today seems likely to be talked about, not so much because of the play as because of the exchange of conversation after the play.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Philip H. Willkie, son of the 1940 Republican Presidential nominee, today filed a $1,000,000 alienation of affections suit against Mr. and Mrs. F. Peavey Heffelfinger of Wayzata, Minn.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics posted a 127-121 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight despite a 29-point performance by Jack Twyman that put him over the 10,000 mark as a pro.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Mrs. DeWitt Alexandre of Somerset Hills was re-elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the anual meeting held at the Montclair Golf Club today.

Your front-page report on Nov. 8 describing the settlement of the milk strike stated that the anticipated cost of the settlement was $11 per week per man, with ten thousand employes involved. The amount of milk delivered daily is eight million quarts.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- A modern landmark on the Avenue Champs-Elysees, the "Drugstore," was badly damaged today by a bomb explosion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Yale still remains very much of a factor in the race for the Ivy League football championship even though it has no more than a bare mathematical chance of sharing the title it won a year ago.
Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino last night questioned the motives behind the Democratic attacks on the Congressional redistricting bill voted last week by the Republican-controlled Legislature.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Three Federal judges ruled today in favor of twenty-four railroads who seek to upset an Interstate Commerce Commission report that fixed a rate differential of 6 per cent between water carriers and railroads.

HONOLULU, Nov. 16 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union called off its strike threat in Hawaii ports today and conditionally agreed to arbitrate differences with the stevedoring industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -Army authorities expressed confidence today that they would win long-sought approval soon for a major development and production program of Nike Zeus antimissile bases to protect the nation's key cities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Civil Rights Commission reported today that police lawlessness and brutality remained "a serious problem throughout the United States." It recommended corrective action by both Congress and the Kennedy Administration.
CAIRO, Nov. 16 -- Informed sources said here tonight that this week-end's meeting of neutralist leaders was entirely President Nasser's doing.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries have resorted a new high of $54,300,000 for net income in the twelve months ended on Oct. 31. This compared with $53,975,000 in the 1960 period. Share earnings for the period rose to $2.48 from $2.46 a year earlier.
The Catholic Center for the Blind, a home for blind women at 22 East Seventy-first Street, will benefit from a theatre party to the Nov. 28 performance of "A Man for All Seasons" at the ANTA Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States stood firm today in their opposition to any program of general Federal aid to education that failed to help parochial and other private schools.
BOMBAY, India, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- The first cricket test match between England and India ended in a tame draw today after India had aimed to score 295 runs in 4 hours 5 minutes for a victory.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Following are the names of the thirteen Italian members of the United Nations force who were killed Saturday in Kindu by Congolese troops:

Washington has now acted or is preparing to act on most of the steps the United States will take to help beleaguered South Vietnam's fight in the immediate future against Communist attack. Decision on some of the steps preceded the Saigon visit of General Taylor; some will result from this trip.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union startled a number of diplomats here tonight by pleading poverty in an attempt to head off an increase in its payments to the United Nations.
SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 16 -Following are excerpts from President Kennedy's remarks at the University of Washington's anniversary:
LONDON, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- Profits of the Rootes Motors Group, Britain's third largest car manufacturer, fell by 2,952,200 ($8,266,160) for the year ended on July 31, it was announced today.
Following are some of the expressions of tribute and statements of regret at the death yesterday of Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House of Representatives:

Sixty acres of land in North Caldwell, N.J., have been purchased by Samuel Saltz and Alfred Paretti of Englewood Cliffs, builders. They plan to erect forty-six: homes in the $30,000 price class on the tract, which is bounded by Smull, Central and Gould Avenues.
The retirement next fall of Admiral Richard L. Conolly as president of Long Island University was announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -The Defense Ministry charged today that ships of the East German Navy had provoked a "potentially dangerous" incident in the western Baltic by stopping and threatening a West German minesweeper.

Events today: "Lohengrin," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Henri Honegger, cellist, Town Hall, 5:30; East-man Wind Ensemble, Frederick Fennell, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Frank Glazer, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.
Chair-borne quarterbacks are busier than ever this week, passing sure-fire touchdown plays by mail to the New York Giants.
Columbia University announced yesterday that the tuition would be increased in nearly all its departments in the next two academic years.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- Sales of new cars in early November continued at a booming pace that may herald an industry sales record for the fourth quarter.

Without benefit of the cheering thousands who will voice the season's last hurrahs for the football heroes, the equally heroic varsity harriers will make their lonely rounds of hill and dale in full force over the next two week-ends.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 40 cents to $1.25 a bale yesterday.
CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Lee P. Finley refused today to resign as St. Lawrence County Welfare Commissioner and accused a consulting concern of failing to accomplish what it had been hired to do.

IF Gimbels has its way, New York women will stay home for the December holidays, spend January on the various ski slopes and skating rinks, and then go off to some sunnier Southern clime come February.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Eastman Kodak Company voted a wage dividend today estimated at $50,900,000. It will be paid to some 46,000 Kodak employes in the United States or deposited for their benefit in the Eastman Kodak Employees Savings and Investment Plan.

For collectors of gridiron trivia, the University of Oklahoma set its first record of the football season yesterday. At precisely 2:25 P.M. it became the first college eleven ever to be piped into Yankee Stadium by a bosun's mate.

STALL space for eight horses had been promised but the equine population at Roosevelt Raceway that spring was burgeoning with such phenomenal rapidity that Stanley Dancer thought it expedient to make certain he wasn't squeezed out. So he checked first with Walter Gibbons, the racing secretary.
Prices of potato futures again hit new lows for the lives of all contracts in trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -President Kennedy has decided on the measures that the United States is prepared to take to strengthen South Vietnam against attack by Communists.
THE man who happily said good-by yesterday to the most expensive painting in the world began his career as a physicist, but says he was "pitchforked into the art business by chance."

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York defeated Mme. H. Konarkowska of Poland in an eleventh-round game of the women's world chess champion challengers' tournament yesterday, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were up $31,000,000 at $122,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose by $152,000,000 to $628,000,000.

BECAUSE plums and fresh prunes have departed for the season, it is necessary to turn to dried prunes as a substitute. And an excellent one they can be. In addition, dried prunes have potential not possessed by the fresh version.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Italy accused Austria today of having failed to comply with last year's General Assembly resolution on the Italian-Austrian dispute over Alto Adige.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Walter P. Reuther declared today that to survive the labor federation must agree next month on effective machinery to solve its internal disputes.

CHICAGO, Now 16 (AP) -The grain futures market worked over a generally narrow price spread today with a good deal of the volume limited to speculative dealings. Some grains were fairly broad but all declines were small.
BUFFALO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A fifty-five-foot yacht was in serious trouble about sixty miles south west of here on stormy Lake Erie near Long Point, Ont., the Buffalo Coast Guard said tonight.

The downward drift of prices in the market for United States securities petered out yesterday as market professionals continued to adjust trading positions in the wake of the Treasury's $6,963,000,000 refunding.

The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) yesterday designated interest rates of 3 7/8 per cent and 4 3/8 per cent for two issues of debentures to be brought to market next week. The borrowing will total $225,000,000 and will mark the agency's largest borrowing of new cash this year.
The New York Mets have struck it rich, and they are sharing the wealth.
Penn's often altered starting line-up will undergo additional changes for tomorrow's Ivy League football game against Columbia at Baker Field.

The founder of a school for blind and retarded children in Paoli, Pa., and a citizens' group that built an interracial center in Hartford, Conn., received the annual Lane Bryant awards yesterday for distinguished volunteer service.
If anyone still doubts the importance of orchestral musicians to the proper performance of opera, he has only to consider the minor crisis that occurred at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

Antique furniture, silver, jewelry, oil paintings and even a selection of modern fashions will be on view today, tomorrow and Monday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries. All items will be sold there Tuesday at the eighth annual Famous Designers and Artists Auction arranged in behalf of Irvington House.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) -Terry Gray's two goals in thirty-four seconds and Don McKenney's third-period tally gave the last-place Boston Bruins a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight before a crowd of 11,022.
LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Doug Sanders, Dave Marr and Ken Still, all pros, carded 67's today and shared the first-round lead in the $15,000 Cajun Classic open golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Following are excerpts from a report sent here by Dr. Sture C. Linner, head of the United Nations operation in the Congo, on the killing of thirteen Italian airmen in Kindu:
MANILA, Nov. 16 -- Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Ambassador to the United States, will be asked to resign by the newly elected President, Diosdado Macapagal, it has been authoritatively reported here.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 16 -- Speed boats appear to be getting too fast.
The president of a leading advertising agency argued yesterday that the advertising business suffered from a sort of "ten-year itch."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 16 -- Two hundred physicians of the Hadassah Medical Center staged a one-day strike today because they had not received retroactive pay increases due them. The center is at Ein Karem, on the outskirts of Jerusalem.

Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and associates offered to the public yesterday $25,000,000 first mortgage bonds of 4 1/2 per cent series of the Carolina Power and Light Company.
A hockey team without ice. That was the picture yesterday as seventeen members of the New York Rangers reported for an "important" practice at the big Long Island Arena in Commack.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 16 -- Thirteen captured Italian airmen attached to the United Nations force have been murdered by Congolese soldiers.

Because New York City has been slipping a bit in its progress toward cleanliness, Sanitation Commissioner Frank J. Lucia will ask for money to resume six-day-a-week garbage collection in some sections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Nov. 11, were 4 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
Maurice Evans has signed contracts to co-star with Wendy Hiller in Michael Redgrave's adaption of Henry James' "The Aspern Papers," which has been scheduled to open on Broadway Feb. 7.
The rubber industry is diversifying away from tires and also away from rubber. Such moves will enable the industry to exceed national growth rates through 1975, an economist predicted yesterday.

Iain Macleod, who recently was named Leader of the House of Commons and chairman of the Conservative party in Great Britain, has found that he has inherited many problems that a former party leader had faced. That man was the late Neville Chamberlain, Prime Minister from 1937 to 1940, whose efforts to maintain world peace brought him the sobriquet "Man of Munich."
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The stock market turned irregular here today after its upward swing of the last few days.
David Schoenbrun has been named chief correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System's Washington news bureau. He has been chief of the network's Paris bureau since 1947.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -The Navy, buoyed by the "complete success" of its fifth Transit navigational satellite, predicted today it would achieve the world's first practical use of space satellites.

Ambassador Galbraith, in his letter published Nov. 8, for some unusual reason completely missed the point of James Reston's article on bad government in the megalopolis of the Eastern seaboard. Ambassador Galbraith once again had his tongue in cheek, as was the case when, as Professor Galbraith, he suggested we must reduce production to save the Western world ("The Affluent Society").
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- The mayors of New Jersey's six largest cities called today for a convention to revise the state's tax system.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 16 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga described today as "completely false" the report by the United Nations commission that investigated the death of Patrice Lumumba, former Premier of the Congo.
A 37-year-old Brooklyn man was being sought yesterday on a charge of having collected at least $6,000 in welfare payments while operating four businesses.
Stockholders of the Gillette Company approved a three-for-one split of the common stock at a special meeting in Boston yesterday.

James J. Saxon, Controller of the Currency, said yesterday that Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy had assured him that the Department of Justice "will not impinge in any way on the freedom of action of the Controller's office."
OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 16 -The purchase of the former William K. Vanderbilt estate here was recommended today for the permanent Suffolk County campus of Adelphi College.

Production of lumber in the nation rose to 220,891,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday from 218,099,000 board feet in the week before, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago 21,971,000 board feet were produced.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -The president of the United States Savings and Loan League said today the savings and loan industry was having its greatest growth in history.

Erwin S. Wolfson, New York builder and head of a group of Anglo-American investors, has announced plans for an office building and transportation center to be built on air rights over the tracks of the Union Station in Chicago.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 16 -- Prince Boun Oum, Premier of the Right-wing Laotian Government at Vientiane, rejected today an invitation to go to the Plaine des Jarres, an area controlled by Left-wing elements, to continue discussions on the formation of a coalition government.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 16 -- Finland came under new pressure today from the Soviet Union.

The launching of the first Soviet satellite dramatically affected the schools in New York State, according to a state-wide survey made public yesterday by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., state Commissioner of Education.

Hammacher Schlemmer, the housewares store at 145 East Fifty-seventh Street, has had a heavy favorable response and a small, highly indignant reaction to a two-page newspaper advertisement offering fall-out shelters for everyday living.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that agriculture was this country's "strongest deterrent" to the spread of communism.
The Boston Celtics will pit their world championship talents against the New York Knickerbockers tonight in their first Madison Square Garden appearance of the National Basketball Association season.
Heavy rain and a couple of minor accidents combined to cause a massive tie-up on the West Side Highway last evening.

CONSERVATIONISTS, fishermen and some substantial industrial interests are watching with keen interest the progress of a case of stream pollution now in the hands of the Attorney General of Pennsylvania. Its final resolution may set important precedents.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The Labor party charged today that the Conservative Government's bill to restrict immigration from Commonwealth countries was "barefaced, open race discrimination."

The Metropolitan Museum of Art's $2,300,000 acquisition, Rembrandt's "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer," will go on public exhibition tomorrow. It was moved to the museum yesterday under armed guard from the Parke-Bernet Galleries, where it had been purchased at a spectacular auction Wednesday night.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Undefeated Rutgers, shooting for its greatest football season in its ninetythree-year history, decided today not to compete in any postseason bowl games this year.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that four defendants who had been in jail for periods up to a year because they could not raise bail would be paroled unless they got immediate trials. Two of the defendants are youths.

President Kennedy's new committee on youth employment has a mission crucial to the health and security of our industrial society. The frustrations of joblessness, painful at any age, are particularly demoralizing for the youngster who finds himself unneeded and unwanted in his first attempts to become a productive partner in the community.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- Dr. John C. Bugher, an internationally known biophysicist, said today that the decision whether to continue nuclear testing should be based on political considerations rather than on possible health hazards.

Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg last night praised President Kennedy's "day-by-day support and leadership" in opposing discrimination in Federal employment and in jobs performed under Government contracts.

The property formerly occupied by Public School 18 at 121 East Fifty-first Street was sold at auction yesterday for $3,025,000, one of the highest prices ever paid for city-owned realty at a public sale. The upset or minimum price was $1,350,000.

The construction of a Jewish memorial library as an adjunct to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has been proposed by Bernard G. Richards, chairman of the Jewish Information Bureau, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.
