National adoption of New York's Higher Horizons program, which provides unusual educational opportunities for the underprivileged, was advocated yesterday by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -John W. McCormack of Massachusetts will almost certainly be the next Speaker of the House of Representatives, according to the near-unanimous consensus of political experts here.

Investors purchased more than $250,000,000 of mutual fund shares in October, raising the assets of the 161 reporting funds to $21,562,335,000 on Oct. 31. This was announced in the monthly statistics released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Bernard Chenot, French Minister of Justice, asserted tonight that all persons imprisoned in France because of events in North Africa had the status of political captives.

IDEALLY, a woman should have three kinds of stationery. For formal use, such as answering invitations, notes of sympathy or bestowing thanks, a double sheet of heavy white or ivory paper four by five inches that folds from the top is preferable.
Joseph Gallo, 32-year-old gangland figure and juke-box racketeer, was found guilty of attempted extortion and conspiracy yesterday by a jury in General Sessions Court.
AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Texas has become the first state to insure health care for the aged through a private insurance company.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The nations of the Atlantic community agreed today on a ten-year program to achieve a 50 per cent increase in their over-all output.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The necrology of American politics includes the names of several Presidents who were victims of their trade and tariff policies, both protectionist and otherwise, and it is already apparent that by his constructive decision to cooperate with the Common Market President Kennedy has courageously risked a similar fate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The Federal Aviation Agency has discounted a theory that transistor radios and tape recorders can interfere with aerial navigation.
ROME, Nov. 16 -- News of the killing of thirteen Italian airmen in the Congo shocked the nation today.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Journal, picketed by mail-room employes who called the first strike in the newspaper's history, published an edition today with a news section produced on typewriters and photo-engraved.

Readers of The New York Times have helped each year to provide the turkey, stuffing and trimmings that make possible festive holiday dinners for older people at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House. We are appealing once again for contributions, either large or small, so that the lonely men and women living in tenement rooms on Manhattan's East Side may enjoy the spirit and meaning of Thanksgiving and Christmas.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- "Dag Hammarskjold was a man of learning and a poet of the breed for whom books and libraries are necessary delights."
DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -Five of the nation's top industrial executives predicted today that 1962, in effect, would be a year of moderate growth without a boom.
The ponds and lakes in Central Park are getting their annual cleaning.

George D. Widener's Seven Thirty registered a two-length victory over Make Sail of the Cain Hoy Stable in the main event at Aqueduct yesterday. The Widener filly was the favorite with the 22,395 customers, and the lucky ones gleefully accepted the $4.80 that she returned for every $2 ventured.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Five Federal officials today were named recipients of the ninth annual Rockefeller Public Service Award.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16 -- The rejection today of bowl bids by Rutgers University officials conforms with the school's intention to stay out of big-time football.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 16 -- The universities will play an increasing role in the national space program under a new plan to establish space study laboratories at campuses across the country.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov, who was denounced at the recent Communist party congress for his part in Stalin's terrorism, has now been accused of having arrested 3,500 Armenians in a few months in 1937.
The decision of District Attorney Hogan to discontinue the use of wiretap evidence was a difficult but we think correct one.
Treasury and Federal Reserve officials in Washington said yesterday that they had not changed their credit policy from one of monetary ease to a more restrictive policy.
A drive on "calamity howlers" in this country seeking drastic restrictions on imports from Japan was urged yesterday at a concluding session of the fourteenth annual Far East Conference.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange went down yesterday for the second time this month, according to both The New York Times combined average and Standard Poor's composite index.

HARROW-ON-THE-HILL, England, Nov. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill, bent with age but looking fit and cheerful, sang with the boys of Harrow tonight and added one more page to the history of his old school.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Senator Maurine Neuberger underwent surgery today, and a preliminary pathological examination indicated some "low grade malignant changes" a spokesman for the University of Oregon Medical School Hospital announced.

FORT LEE, N.J., Nov. 16 -Philip Arthur Hunt, founder and president of the Philip A. Hunt Company, manufacturing chemists, died yesterday in a car crash on Route 4 a quarter of a mile west of the George Washington Bridge.
MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Communist party hinted today that it had failed to heal its ideological rift with the Chinese Communists over Albania.

The Scholarship Fund of the Yeshiva University Women's Organization will benefit from an evening at the opera on Dec. 2. Joan Sutherland and Jan Peerce will sing leading roles in Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" at the Metropolitan Opera House.
MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Communist party hinted today that it had failed to heal its ideological rift with the Chinese Communists over Albania.

The Scholarship Fund of the Yeshiva University Women's Organization will benefit from an evening at the opera on Dec. 2. Joan Sutherland and Jan Peerce will sing leading roles in Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" at the Metropolitan Opera House.
ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The Ithaca Common Council began making plans today for a possible twelve-month experiment in free bus transportation for this city of 30,000.
BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- British military authorities here sent a strong protest today to the Soviet command over two border incidents yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Fred Zinnemann, the director, urged the American movie industry and the Federal Government today to participate fully in foreign film festivals attended by the Russians.

A GIRL walked proudly across Belgrade's Boulevard Revolucjia toward the University wearing a tight, short skirt that showed her kneecaps and a big, bulky knit sweater. Her blond hair was piled up high in an Italian-style beehive coiffure and her shoes could have come from Milan or Venice.
A girls' high school in India has been unable to obtain an import permit from the Indian Government for movie projector offered by a Brooklyn Masonic lodge.

WITH Thanksgiving less than a week away, even the most modest budget will allow for the traditional turkey on the table in view of the abundant supply and low prices. Two chains are advertising a price of 29 cents a pound for birds eighteen pounds and over.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. had a record net income of $12,676,516 in its fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, an increase of 30 per cent from the $9,594,908 cleared a year earlier, according to the annual report of Joseph R. Vogel, president.

Francois D'Albert, Hungarian-born violinist who made his New York debut three years ago, played a return engagement last night in Judson Hall. He is now president of the Chicago Conservatory College. His pianist was Donald Jenni, a faculty member at DePaul University.
A lower court decision denying citizenship to Myer Klig, Russian-born union official, was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. The matter was sent back for a rehearing.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16 -- Guerrilla warfare against Chinese Communist rule was reported today in northeastern, southeastern and western Tibet.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- President Moktar Ould Daddah of Mauritania urged African leaders today to mend their disputes, forego political rivalries and become a "united Africa."

The American Jewish Congress said yesterday that the recent arrest and imprisonment of Jewish leaders in Moscow and Leningrad "may signal a return to a campaign of anti-Jewish vituperation in the U.S.S.R."
An internal revenue agent was acquitted yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of a charge that he took a $250 bribe to help a taxpayer.

HARTFORD, Iowa, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Rock Island Lines Twin Star Rocket struck a road-maintenance vehicle at a rural crossing near here today. The train's eight passenger cars were derailed, but there were no fatalities.
Mayor Wagner wants a speedy decision on the selection of a successor to Carmine G. De Sapio as leader of the New York County Democratic organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee has begun an investigation into complaints that increasing numbers of soldiers, sailors and airmen are being denied their constitutional rights.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- The United States won the Prix des Nation Class at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show tonight and moved to within 2 points of first-place Canada in international equestrian jumping.
Directors of the Southern California Edison Company proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock and announced plans to issue 1,500,000 new shares of the common.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 16 -The Ceylonese Government has lodged a "strong protest" with the Governments of the United States and Britain against "indiscriminate sales of rubber" from their stockpiles, "which tend to disrupt rubber markets unduly and depress prices to uneconomic levels."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board said today that thirty-four witnesses were scheduled to testify at its Dec. 7 hearing on a plan to consolidate the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and six upstate New York banks.
John McLaughry, a patient man, delivered a brief lecture yesterday in Providence. He'll have to wait until tomorrow afternoon to learn how well his oratory was heeded.

A program designed to take some of the guesswork out of the teaching of psychiatry and psychoanalysis has been started at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company could charge its large electrical consumers $18,000,000 a year more provided it charged its small consumers $8,000,000 a year less.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Industrial production regained in October what it lost in September, and a little bit more, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. In broad terms, the total was the same in October as the record set two months earlier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -The Union of American Hebrew Congregations sharply indicted today right wing groups such as the John Birch Society. It accused them of operating under the guise of anti-communism and "weakening America by stirring division and hysteria."
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Yola Ramirez of Mexico was defeated today before rain again interrupted the New South Wales tennis championships.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- American Motors Corporation today cut its quarterly cash dividend from 30 cents a share to 20 cents but declared an extra stock dividend of 2 per cent. The cash dividend is payable on Dec. 20 and the stock dividend on Dec. 27, both to stockholders of record of Nov. 28.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- The Republican state chairman said today that New York's voters showed a decided preference for Republican candidates in last week's election "in choosing their government closest to home."

He was christened with a longer and more romantic name, but if you spoke of Mr. Sam any time these past few years everybody on Capitol Hill knew to whom you were referring. Since 1940, except for the short time when the Republicans controlled the chamber which he never regarded as "the lower house," he was Mr. Speaker or Speaker Rayburn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -Gen. Chung Hee Park marked the six-month anniversary of his junta's seizure of power in South Korea by telling the National Press Club here today that he did not like military governments "any more than you Americans."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 16 -- A meeting of the big three of the nonaligned nations -- President Tito of Yugoslavia, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic -- has been scheduled for Cairo this week-end.
A plane that went down with eleven men aboard on drifting ice far out in the Arctic Ocean has been found. All hands are apparently in good health.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 17 -- President Kennedy declared tonight that the nation should regard with pride the "heavy burden" of preserving freedom in the world.
The Boy Scouts appeared last night to be prepared for anything as they opened a three-day exposition at the Coliseum.
THREE enterprising alumni of Yale have embarked on a project that is likely to stir considerable interest among devotees of modern Danish design and cause criticism in the furniture industry.

Chancellor Adenauer has again brought up the suggestion of giving nuclear weapons to NATO. Evidently the Chancellor will talk to President Kennedy about this on his forthcoming visit to Washington as he talked to President Eisenhower last year.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The state today announced a program designed to take the worst teen-age troublemakers out of the public schools and to try to salvage them for constructive jobs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the Pentagon had "no present plans" to call to active duty any additional large numbers of men from the Reserve forces, including the National Guard.

A state legislative hearing was told here yesterday that the high cost of health plans had been due, in large measure, to unnecessary surgery and the construction of more facilities than were needed -- ofen by institutions run for profit.

COLOR television's potential in the field of art, something long assumed but infrequently demonstrated, was excitingly apparent in last night's distinctive and unusual documentary undertaking, "Vincent Van Gogh: A Self-portrait," on Channel 4.

The visit to the United States of Gen. Chung Hee Park, who arrived yesterday from Washington for a week-end in New York, is reinforcing the generally favorable impression his new army regime in Korea has created among Americans in recent months, after initial misgivings.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 17 -- The Justice party announced yesterday that it had agreed to join a coalition with the Republican People's party under Premier Ismet Inonu.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- The State League of Municipalities ended its four-day annual conference today with a plea for a state-wide survey of fall-out shelter needs and for a convention to revise the state's tax system.
RECIFE, Brazil, Nov. 12 -- Landowners are pushing Brazil toward revolution, Francisco Juliao, a Leftist often described as Brazil's Fidel Castro, contends.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Two grand jury indictments against former Chief of Police Bernard C. Brannon, charging perjury and wilful misconduct in office, were dismissed today by Circuit Judge John H. Lucas.
Governor and Mrs. Rockefeller announced last night that they had agreed on a separation in preparation for a divorce.
An improvisatory element is being introduced to jazz at the Jazz Gallery, 80 St. Marks Place.
The United States will issue a commemorative stamp in honor of Dag Hammarskjold, late Secretary-General of the United Nations, on United Nations Day, Oct. 24, 1962.
Abraham A. Ribicoff predicted yesterday that Congress would enact at its next session a bill providing a multimillion-dollar program for new medical schools and scholarships.

C.L. Sulzberger has brought cold reason and the element of patriotism to the fall-out shelter issue. It is high time someone did. What the Administration has been trying weakly to say Mr. Sulzberger has expressed concisely in The Times of Nov. 6: "The question of building fall-out shelters is one of national necessity, not individual preference."

The schoolboy football season goes into its next-to-last act today. With the traditional Thanksgiving Day wind-up games still on tap, only fifty-two contests are listed -- about one-third of the normal Saturday card.

Andre Porumbeanu was sentenced to thirty days in jail and fined $250 for contempt yesterday in Girls Term Court in Brooklyn. He was charged with ignoring a court order forbidding him to associate with Gamble Benedict, the heiress whom he later married.
Oklahoma and Army ran through their final workouts yesterday in preparation for today's meeting at Yankee Stadium at 2 P.M.
New York hasn't had it so good in college football in years.
JAKARTA, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Chaerul Saleh, Indonesian Minister of Development, said today oil negotiations between the Indonesian Government and foreign companies would resume Nov. 21.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Belgium told the Security Council today that she was categorically opposed to the secession of Katanga Province from the Congo and was doing everything possible toward its return.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Police Commissioner L.B. Sullivan took issue today with Civil Rights Commission charges that Montgomery officers were lax during racial violence last May.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- A state-wide organization representing twenty-nine Protestant denominations protested to the University of California today over its sponsorship of a symposium on "Alcohol and Civilization."

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Tales of Hoffmann" at 2 P.M. and "La Boheme" at 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Paul Paray, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Raymond Guy Wilson, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Composers Forum, Donnell Library, 20 West Fifty-third Street, 8:30 P.M.; Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, Hunter College Assembly Hall, 8:30 P.M.

It is a good many years since Goethe remarked to an intimate friend, "The dear good people don't know how long it takes to learn to read. I've been at it eighty years and can't say yet that I've reached the goal."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 17 -The nation's public transport strike went into the third day today. By late afternoon the appearance of Ciudad Ttmjillo's central and side streets seemed to indicate that a government effort to break the strike was having some success.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 17 -- Dr. Alan B. DuMont of Montclair, N.J., television inventor and former national predicted-log champion, today moved closer to the center of pleasure boat matters.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 17 -- The United Nations moved quickly today to seal off the Kindu area in an effort to seize Congolese troops who murdered thirteen Italian airmen attached to the United Nation's force.

Trans World Airlines has filed a complaint with the Civil Aeronautics Board charging that Continental Airlines' proposed 25 per cent reduction in jet coach fares would cost the nation's airlines $180,000,000 a year in lost revenues.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The annual luncheon-fashion show of the Westchester chapter of the National Cystic Fibrosis Foundation will raise funds for research in the disease. The fete will be held on Nov. 28 in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel in New York.
In a routine meeting, stockholders of the Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, voted approval yesterday of a proposal to acquire the Peconic Bank of Sag Harbor, through merger.
WARWICK, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A 91-year-old scholar of ancient Greece reported to the world a major archaeological discovery in the citadel of Mycenae. The only trouble was it was all a hoax.
Don Appell, who wrote the book for the musical hit, "Milk and Honey," is back from a three-week visit in Spain with ideas for two other musicals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets averaged 0.2 per cent higher during the week ended last Tuesday, reaching 118.7 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Installment credit delinquencies increased in September, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday on the basis of its monthly survey of almost 300 banks across the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Lakers broke a 116-116 deadlock in the final 4 minutes 10 seconds tonight to score their sixth straight victory by defeating the Philadelphia Warriors, 125 -- 121, at Convention Hall.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
HONG KONG, Nov. 17 -- An advance party of an Albanian economic delegation arrived in Peiping today.
BOSTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Boston Patriots rallied tonight when an Oakland fourth-quarter punt bounced off the goal posts and defeated the Raiders, 20 -- 17, in an American Football League game.

JACKSON, MISS., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal panel ruled today that Negroes seeking desegregation of Mississippi travel facilities in Federal courts must first seek recourse through state courts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Ed Lubanski, the 1958 champion from Detroit, shattered a six-hour-old record to take the lead after the first qualifying round of six games in the fifth annual world invitation bowling tournament.

MANILA, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Gary Player of South Africa today carded a 5-under-par 65 to beat Arnold Palmer and the Philippines' two outstanding golfers on the first day of Manila competition in the Player-Palmer series.
Fred J. Thompson, a 60-year-old alcoholic drifter, was convicted of first-degree murder and kidnapping yesterday in the rape-slaying of 4-year-old Edith Kiecorius last Feb. 22.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy took a slight tumble while riding this afternoon with the Piedmont foxhounds near Middleburg, Va.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Tulane rallied tonight for a 17-14 victory over Vanderbilt. It was the Green Wave's first football triumph in the Southeastern Conference this season.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Four Republican Representatives who call themselves "Paul Reveres" criticized the Kennedy Administration today for "indecision and ineptness."
Mayor Wagner has invited school and civic leaders in the city and the suburbs to a meeting Monday at City Hall in a campaign to seek increased state aid for education.

The football Giants' outlook for tomorrow's game here against the Pittsburgh Steelers took on a brighter tinge yesterday with the addition of two effectives to Coach Allie Sherman's riddled backfield corps.
Eleven Japanese religious leaders of various faiths arrived here yesterday to find ways "to cooperate with American religious leaders for permanent world peace."

Michael J. Quill warned yesterday that 8,000 members of the Transport Workers Union would strike the city's seven privately owned bus lines if no agreement is reached before their present two-year contract expires Nov. 30.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 17 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad ended 127 years of passenger service into and out of the Exchange Place Terminal here today.
Christmas may not yet be in the air, but in most of the stores and shopping centers in the metropolitan area it already is very much in view.
Twenty-five Indiana farm boys and girls paid a return visit to their New York friends yesterday.
A check for $875,000 was handed over yesterday by representatives of the National Gallery of Art in payment for Fragonard's "La Liseuse."
OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Convicts in Sing Sing Prison ended today a sit-down strike that protested state parole rules.
The New York Rangers, still seeking their first decision over the Montreal Canadiens, will face the Habitants on the Madison Square Garden rink this afternoon.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 17 -- A Columbia University professor voiced concern today over an anti-Communist rally that is to be held here tomorrow.
The appointment of Thomas B. Parish as local rent administrator for Brooklyn was announced yesterday by State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman.

At least four international airlines have protested United States Air Force pressure on American Express Company offices in Europe to give preference to American-flag carriers when booking space for military personnel.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The Atlantis community stressed today that the 50 per cent rise in economic output it hopes to achieve in this decade would help poorer nations as well.
Columbia, seeking to clinch at least a tie for the Ivy League football championship, will end its home season today with a game against Pennsylvania starting at 1:30 P.M.

The phrase Darkest Africa could have been fittingly applied this week to Kindu in Kivu Province in the Republic of the Congo, where thirteen Italian airmen flying peaceful errands for the U.N. were butchered by drunken soldiers of the Congolese Army. Nearly a hundred U.N. soldiers have been killed since the U.N. went into the Congo last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk declared today that the wall dividing Berlin "certainly ought not be a permanent feature." [Question 7, Page 6.]

SOME philosophical speculations were opened by the performance of Chopin's F minor Piano Concerto yesterday afternoon by the New York Philharmonic under Paul Paray. Fou Ts'Ong, the Chinese pianist, was the soloist.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Villanova University today accepted an invitation to play in the Dec. 30 Sun Bowl football game at El Paso, Tex. An opponent will be named within the next ten days.
Contributing a characteristic front-running performance, Gustave Ring's 3-year-old colt Gus won the $10,000 feature purse at Aqueduct yesterday.
Laurel Miller, mezzo-soprano, made an excellent impression last night in her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.
MERIDEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Frank Kowalski, Representative at Large since 1959, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.
Henri Honegger, a Swiss 'cellist who last performed here last year in April, gave a recital in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. He is a distant relative of the late composer Arthur Honegger.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Sweden and five other neutrals proposed today that the United Nations explore the possibility of forming a "nonnuclear club." Its members would be nonatomic powers ready to pledge not to manufacture or acquire nuclear weapons or allow them to be stored on their soil.

A 5 per cent income tax on the broadcasting industry to subsidize live theatre was proposed yesterday to a House of Representatives subcommittee investigating economic conditions among performing artists.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Reliable sources said tonight that the United States, Britain and France would seek a new status for all Berlin, and not simply the Western sector, in any negotiations with the Soviet Union.

IN "Stephen Watts Kearny: Soldier of the West,"* 1794-1848, Dwight L. Clarke makes a valuable contribution to the dramatic story of this country's expansion from sea to sea. Without men like Kearny the United States might have been a somewhat smaller nation. And, doubtless, less troubled by the perils and responsibilities of world power.
NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Off Broadway by twenty-five miles, in a cozy Nyack theatre that was once a church, a group of witty suburbanites last night satirized with originality some tired, old topics.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison shot a four-under-par 68 today for a 72-hole score of 273 and victory in the national seniors open golf championship.

The transmission of pornographic films, magazines, books and circulars through the mail here has increased from 300 to 500 per cent during the last year, Postmaster Robert K. Christenberry said yesterday.

Trumpeter Jonah Jones made the radio scene last night in a bouncy, breezy hour of taped jazz and popular music. This was the first in a series of "music spectaculars" that radio station WNEW will present once or twice a month.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union announced today that two young West German tourists had been arrested and would be tried on charges of having spied for the United States. The statement by the Soviet Foreign Ministry which was delivered to the West German Embassy here said Walter Naumann, 27 years old, and Peter Sonntag, 22, had admitted having "collected-information of an intelligence character."
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 17 -- Adios Don, a son of Adios and, until now, also a son of adversity, paced off with the Messenger Stakes, the world's richest harness race, tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The nation's chief economist reported today that unemployment should drop from the present 6.8 per cent to 5.5 per cent of the working force next year.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union wants Finland to send a delegation to Moscow "as soon as possible" for mutual defense talks. Such discussions were said by the Russians to be "exceedingly unavoidable."
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Three Moroccan Ministers returned home tonight without an agreement that would end the hunger strike of five members of the Algerian rebel Government who are prisoners in France.

The Oakland County Twelve Towns Drainage District, Mich., announced plans yesterday to borrow $33,675,000 in the bond market. Bids on the issue will be received on Dec. 6. The bonds will come due serially from 1963 to 1992.

THANKSGIVING is one holiday when the dinner table and all its accouterments reign supreme. For the hostess bent on creating a lovely setting the many intriguing table appointments at Carole Stupell should be an inspiration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Directors of the Unitarian Fellowship for Social Justice criticized today a statement by the United States Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church reaffirming their opposition to any Federal aid to education that does not include parochial schools.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Grain futures prices stuck to a downward course all day on the Board of Trade and closed with most contracts off major fractions to more than a cent a bushel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dean Rusk:
SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica, Nov. 15 -- At the far end of a 1,000-foot tunnel under the snow here lies one of the keys to the accurate spotting of earthquakes throughout the world.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Rose Bowl game today was threatened with a boycott by Negro college students if Alabama is invited to play in the New Year's day classic.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk called upon the International Control Commission in Vietnam today to look into the "determined and ruthless" campaign by the Communists to overthrow the Government of South Vietnam.
Major structural defects have been found in the concrete foundation piles recently put in for a new $30,000,000 passenger terminal at La Guardia Airport, the Port Authority said yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The trouble-ridden St. Louis Hawks dismissed Coach Paul Seymour today. The former National Basketball Association guard said it was a result of resentment by seasoned players "because of my wanting rookie Cleo Hill to be a starter."
Two singers made their Metropolitan debuts in last night's performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin."
The Kaiser Industries Corporation had higher revenues in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, but operating results were sharply below the year-ago levels, the company reported.
TONIGHT, at the Shamrock Hotel in Houston, Tex, the play-offs will begin to decide the personnel of the six-man team that will next represent this continent in play for the world championship.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 17 -- In a broad attack on Government housing programs, the National Association of Real Estate Boards urged cutbacks today in half a dozen areas of Federal activity.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -- Dr. Hans Kroll, West German Ambassador to Moscow, suggested to Premier Khrushchev during their talk in the Kremlin Nov. 9 that a "grand reconciliation" should be arranged between their countries.
Protestant and Eastern Orthodox churches over the country will begin their eighth annual Thanksgiving appeal tomorrow to aid the needy in thirty-five countries overseas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- A change to 2 or 3 per cent from 12 per cent in the tax reserve allowed the savings and loan industry would result in a reduction of $5,000,000,000 in the gross national product of the United States, Joseph P. McMurray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank, said today.

ALGIERS, Nov. 17 -- Plastiqueurs, those who wage the terror with plastic bombs, are keeping ahead of the glass cutters in this convulsed city. A dozen explosions a night of the putty-like, high-power charges are nothing exceptional, and the least that they do is shatter the windows of a hun dred homes and offices.

MERCER, Wis., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- A Wisconsin Representative said today the Pentagon had "betrayed and demoralized" the state's thirty-second National Guard Division in Federal service at Fort Lewis Wash.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The president of the United States Savings and Loan League charged commercial banks today "with an attitude of hypocrisy" in their campaign to change tax laws on savings associations.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Iowa dethroned Michigan State as Big Ten cross-country champion today on a soggy four-mile course at Washington Park.
New issues of fixed-interest securities valued at $162,685,000 are expected to reach the market next week.
The White House concert of Pablo Casals will be broadcast to the nation next week on radio.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- A New York physician called today for a more enlightened attitude on the part of public health officials toword the use of drugs in treating the mentally ill.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense, expressed regret today that Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker had resigned from the Army after a controvery over his troop indoctrination program.
Gen. Chung Hee Park, head of the military junta that seized power in Korea last May said here yesterday that any further American aid would be used for the benefit of the Korean People.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The West German police have arrested a former Soviet agent in connection with the mysterious death of the legendary Stefan Bandera, anti-Soviet guerrilla leader from the Ukraine.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, called today for a wider listing by publicly held companies on the regional stock exchange of the The Securities Exchange Act There is no reason, said Mr. Funston, "why corporations large enough and important enough to have 300 shareowners should be reluctant or find it inconvenient to provide in their reports and proxies the information investors need to arrive at sound conclusions."
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Ed Stone, managing editor of The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, was elected president today of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, who was a key figure in the Administration of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, announced today his candidacy for Governor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The economy resumed its recovery in October. Each day brings new evidence that the slight setback in September was just a pause.

DALLAS, Nov. 17 -- The heads of Jewish welfare funds and federations in this country were told today that $165,000,000 must be raised next year to meet pressing needs of Jews the world over. Special emphasis was placed on the new immigration to Israel and on domestic requirements.

FOR all its many qualities, abstract or semi-abstract art does not lend itself with much success to the pictorial expounding of doctrine, Christian, Marxist or whatever it may be. Hence the extreme difficulty for an artist working in the modern style who wishes to concern himself with religious content and with the expression of religious feeling.

Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains rose 3.2 per cent in October from the 1960 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. For the first ten months of 1961, sales increased 3.6 per cent from the comparable 1960 level.
Prices of most commodity futures rose yesterday on the New York exchanges.

The American News Company has purchased the vending machine business of Roy Peterson, Portsmouth, N.H., owner of the Denco Vending Corporation and the William E. Dennett Company. The sale price was not disclosed.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 -- Crimson Satan, the winner of the $301,365 Garden State Stakes, was the 3-5 overnight favorite among the seven 2-year-old colts who will contest tomorrow's $116,920 Pimlico Futurity at the Maryland Jockey Club course.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dropped 20 cents to $1 a bale yesterday.
LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Doug Sanders carded a four-under-par 67 today to take a one-stroke lead at the halfway point of the $15,000 Cajun golf tournament.
I feel impelled to thank you for your excellent articles on reading published Oct. 27 and 31.

North American newsprint production aggregated 783,697 tons last month, the highest for any month on record, according to the Newsprint Service Bureau. October output was 1 per cent higher above the 1960 level, the trade association said.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday the New York City police force was not included in a Civil Rights Commission report that said police lawlessness and brutality remained "a serious problem throughout the United States."

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- La Salle's cross-country team, defeated by St. Joseph's earlier this season, upset its Philadelphia rival today to win the cross-country championship of the Middle Atlantic Conference.
MIAMI, BEACH, Fla., Nov. 17 -- Strong opposition was expressed today to Federal action that would cut $5,300,000 from the budget of the National Institute of Mental Health.

The J.C. Penney Company, department store chain, has leased two floors in 383 Seventh Avenue at Thirty-first Street from the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The lease is for five years and eleven months, starting Feb. 1, 1962.

Anent your editorial of Oct. 4 on possible help to Ghana on the Volta Dam project and your publication of Wilton S. Dillon's letter of Oct. 6: Fortunately this is still a free country and both you and Mr. Dillon are entitled to your viewpoints -presumably self-pleasing -- and to express them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara ordered stricter regulations today for the air transportation of military personnel in this country.
A policewoman demanded in Supreme Court yesterday the right to earn sergeant's chevrons. She told Justice Jacob Markowitz she had been denied the chance because of her sex.

Even with one of their sparkplugs missing, the New York Knickerbockers generated enough momentum to post a praiseworthy challenge to the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden last night. The Celtics eventually registered a 104-100 triumph after trailing most of the way.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Superior Court Judge Alva Loiselle ordered the voting machines and all election material impounded today pending an investigation of the mayoralty election at West Haven on Nov. 7.
One of the city's larger managing agents, L.J. Phillips-Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., was reprimanded in Housing Court yesterday for allowing 121 violations to accumulate at one of its properties.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews announced yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Louis Finkelstein, president of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, would give its annual Morgenstern Award Lecture in Washington on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Frank N. Piasecki, an aeronautical engineer, has invented an aircraft that combines two helicopters and a balloon. The merged vehicle is designed to transport heavy loads over mountains and jungles.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The International Court of Justice may be asked for an advisory opinion on how to resolve the United Nations' financial crisis.
The Kennedy Administration pledged yesterday that it would "never stop working" until a bill was passed to provide medical care for the aged under Social Security.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., Nov. 17 -- The Methodist Council of Bishops warned last night "against the folly of a panic program for bomb shelters."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Army Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors recommended today construction of two huge dams at a total cost to the Federal Government of more than $170,000,000.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 17 -- When Carl Trumbull Hayden was a freshman Senator from Arizona in 1927 he once startled his colleagues by speaking for hours against certain aspects of the Boulder (Hoover) Dam proposal.

Carlos Ortiz and Paolo Rosi, ranking contenders for the lightweight title held by Joe Brown, will meet in a scheduled ten-round fight at Madison Square Garden tonight. A title shot hinges upon the outcome.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Government's bill to limit immigration from countries of the British Commonwealth is meeting strong opposition from Conservatives.
For a few minutes last night the impression seemed to be abroad that Bobby Kennedy was Boss Man in Washington.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The new Soviet approach to Finland has reinforced an opinion among Western observers here that Moscow has decided to give more weight to military considerations in the formulation of foreign policy.

ANTIGUA, Guatemala, Nov. 17 -The visitor to this charming former capital of Spanish captains-general is reminded of how strangely history may seek to repeat itself. Once, from Antigua's stone streets and low, pastel-tinted houses, small groups of conquistadors in armor rode across volcanic passes and into green plumed jungles to vanquish vast reaches between the Pacific and the Caribbean.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Increased selling of industrials, thought to be mainly profit taking, depressed share prices on the stock exchange here today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 17 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma has decided to call a meeting of Laos' three princes here from Nov. 24, through Nov. 27, the Pathet Lao radio said today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 16 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk invited South Vietnam today to establish its own "permanent control team" here to investigate charges that Vietnamese Communist guerrillas were operating from bases in Cambodia.
The Horace Mann School opened its seventy-fifth anniversary celebration last night with the dedication of a new auditorium at the campus in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Ghana, Tunisia and Yugoslavia prepared an attack today upon the Dutch plan of self-determination for the inhabitants of Netherlands New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that it was the strength of the United States and its allies that was enabling the non-aligned nations to speak to speak out openly. [Question 11, Page 6.]
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Private housing starts increased by 4 per cent in October to an annual rate of 1,442,000 the Census Bureau reported today.
AKRON, N.Y., Nov. 17 (UPI) -- New York's reservation Indians were given assurance today that hereafter they would have some voice in legislation affecting them.
The Transit Authority was accused by a major civic group at City Hall yesterday of causing a "transportation morass."

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Saturday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- An Atlas-Agena rocket blasted off today in an effort to hurl a Ranger II satellite deep into space from an orbiting launch platform. Its purpose: to test techniques for lofting vehicles to the moon and beyond.
Firmness reappeared in the high-grade bond market yesterday.
A spokesman for the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday it would have no comment before Monday on changes in electric rates proposed Thursday by the Public Service Commission.
TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- James Elder of Aurora, Ont., tonight won the individual championship class at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show.
MIAMI, Nov. 17 -- A sailing-yacht captain who survived a sinking that apparently claimed five lives killed himself today, twenty-four hours after the only other known survivor was found.
PANAMA, Nov. 17 -- By unanimous vote the National Assembly has called for the scrapping of existing treaties with the United States regarding the Panama Canal and the Canal Zone.

A syndicate organized by Sidney J. Ungar, president of the Jarc Realty and Management Corporation, and Robert I. Minsky, an officer of the Kraham Realty Corporation, has bought a garden apartment development in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, for $800,000 in cash over mortgages of $2,383,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today set oral argument for Nov. 29 on a question of continued emergency financial assistance to Northeast Airlines, Inc.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A 69 per cent majority of Lutheran Free Church congregations have voted in favor of merger talks with the American Lutheran Church, it was announced today.

Rembrandt's "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer" is indisputably a masterpiece by one of the great artists of the world; but its sale at auction to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for $2,300,000 produces mixed sensations in uneasy balance. Pleasure of course that the picture remains in this country. Pleasure for New Yorkers that it goes to the Metropolitan.

Mme. Nonna Gaprindasvili of the Soviet Union defeated Frau Fridl Rinder of West Germany in a thirteenth-round game in the women's world chess challengers' tournament in Vrnjacka Banja, according to reports from Yugoslavia.
MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union rejected tonight charges in the West that Soviet Jews were being subjected to a campaign of anti-Semitism.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- India accused South Africa today of having forcibly evicted hundreds of Indian residents from their homes and businesses as a part of the country's policy of apartheid, or racial separation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg told warring labor unions today to make peace and get busy with the organizing job that he said they had been neglecting to the detriment of the nation.

The appointment of Sean P. Keating, Mayor Wagner's patronage chief, as regional director of the Post Office Department was announced yesterday. It was the first Federal patronage in which the Mayor had made a recommendation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- A sixteen-member advisory board for a memorial fund in honor of Dag Hammarskjold was announced here today by the United Nations Correspondents Association. A $100,000 Dag Hammarskjold Scholarship Fund is being raised to provide scholarships at American universities for young journalists from Africa, Asia or Latin America.

Shares in retail concerns, in food and financing companies, rubbers and some other recession-resistant issues performed well in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but most of the cyclical groups were irregular or down.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Federal Judge Pierson M. Hall will begin impaneling a special grand jury on Monday to deal with matters that apparently will have considerable bearing on the motion picture and television industries.
The nation should not overlook the earthly geographic realities at a time when much attention is focused on outer space, a high-ranking naval officer said last night.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 17 -- A Minuteman missile sprang from an underground pit today and streaked 3,000 miles, scoring a major success in the United States drive for efficiency in pushbutton warfare.

This is an addendum to your perceptive editorial of Nov. 11 on the delaying-to-death of a visa for British Member of Parliament Konni Zilliacus. As editor of The National Guardian, to whose annual dinner in New York on Nov. 10 Mr. Zilliacus had been invited as principal speaker, it fell to me to relate to an audience of 700 persons the incredible story of our Government's obtuseness.
WARSAW, Nov. 14 -- The Polish legal profession, bending under relentless official pressure, is committed to a purge of its erring members.
Several hundred persons gathered at the steps of Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday afternoon for the homecoming ceremony for Admiral George W. Anderson Jr., Chief of Naval Operations.
C.L. Sulzberger's Nov. 6 article, "Why This Nation Needs Shelters," is hardly the result of the "calm consideration" for which he pleads.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Princeton's defense will face a challenge tomorrow when Yale's hard-running football team invades Palmer Stadium for an Ivy League and Big Three game. Princeton is a slight favorite.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The striking mail-room employes of The Milwaukee Journal failed to obtain a labor-council sanction today that might have kept other union members from crossing their picket line.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- Flags flew at half-staff throughout Italy today as three days of official mourning began in honor of thirteen Italian airmen who were massacred by mutinous Congolese soldier last Saturday.

Under attack as a result of court action taken by the Department of Justice's antitrust division, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company defended its September merger yesterday by filing five supporting affidavits in Federal court in Manhattan.

The Roman Catholic Bishops have now given notice that they intend to continue their fight against any Federal aid-to-education bill that would provide funds only for public schools. They have reaffirmed their opinion that such aid "discriminates against children attending nonpublic schools."
Aluminium, Ltd., has been informed that the Government of Guinea will take over a substidiary company's assets in Guinea on Nov. 23, the Canadian concern announced in Montreal.

The auto producers, already optimistic about their prospects next year, heard some cheerful news yesterday. In Washington, the Federal Reserve Board said that a survey showed that Americans planned in October to buy more cars than they did when questioned back in July.

An exhibition of craft objects from Peru will be on display on Lord Taylor's ninth floor beginning Monday. A group of Quechua Indians will demonstrate how these object are made in the small mountain villages of their native land The Peruvian merchandise will include pre-Columbian artifacts nineteenth-century paintings occasional furniture and accessories, and contemporary objects.
ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Reports of poliomyelitis in the United States are continuing to decline from the mid-September peak, the Public Health Service reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Owners of $970 million of Series F and G savings bonds which mature next year were invited today to exchange them for new bonds paying more interest.

A day-by-day account of Civil War events as reported in The Washington Star is given in "Mirror of War," which will be issued Nov. 28 by Prentice-Hall. The volume tells of the battles and also about social, cultural and business events.

Although the fact was not stressed, Frank Glazer's recital in Town Hall last night was little less than a month after the twenty-fifth anniversary of his New York debut, given in the same auditorium on Oct 20, 1936.
The Eastman Wind Ensemble came to town last night with a bright Carnegie Hall pipe and hornfest.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- The Republican National Chairman, Representative William E. Miller, said today the West should have "kicked down" the Communists' wall in Berlin "brick by brick as they built it."

Dr. Aubre de L. Maynard has been appointed Harlem Hospital's first paid full-time director of surgery. His salary will be $25,000 a year. He has held a similar post since Nov. 4, 1952, on an unpaid basis.
HONOLULU, Nov. 17 -- The man to see in Honolulu is Jack Hall.

IN D.W. Brogan's review of Dorothy Dunnett's "The Game of Kings," he employs the adjective "uxorious" to describe Henry VIII. It is greatly to be doubted whether Catherine of Aragon and Anne of Cleves, who were divorced, or Anne Boleyn and Catherine Howard, who were executed, considered Henry an excessively doting, fond or submissive husband.

IN the shadowy world of boxing, populated by operators and those operated on, Peter Davenport Fuller, the proper Bostonian turned fight manager, is known variously as "a rich wiseguy," "that sap from Harvard," "the blueblood manager," "the Freud of boxing" and "a smooth-talking monkey who thinks he knows the game 'cause he once won a few lousy amateur fights."

LONDON -- Wales is pridefully different from the rest of Britain, and Pembrokeshire is pridefully different from the rest of Wales. A sturdy land that is wild in many parts and rugged and remote along its pocked coastline, Pembrokeshire is often called the "Little England Beyond Wales."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 18 -- The Government will defend in Parliament next week a proposal that a linguistic frontier be drawn across Belgium to quiet the Flemish-Walloon dispute.
MADRID, Nov. 18 -- The death Monday of Anthony V. Drexel Biddle, United States Ambassador to Spain, has underlined the need for a basic review of American-Spanish relations.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Oil output in the Middle East is still rising. In the first nine months of this year the gain was 8.6 percent over the comparable 1960 level. Production from the region was about the same as global output prior to the war.

THE following interview with Dr. Bourbon B. Branchwater, the peripatetic professor of political cynicism, was recorded after his return this week from an unofficial reconnaissance of Richard M. Nixon:
An engineer and his wife, a high school teacher, were arraigned in Federal Court yesterday on charges of conspiring to extort $30,000 from a 70-year-old physician.

DALLAS, Nov. 18 -- The head of the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds appealed to all levels of government -- city, and Federal -- to undertake basic revisions of the welfare policies "to get people off relief by rehabilitating them for productive employment."
A plan to clear disturbed minds and "reload" them with healthy ideas has been propounded for the consideration of psychiatrists by a philosophy professor.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Gov. J. Millard Tawes described Matthew A. Henson, co-discoverer of the North Pole, today as "a great Marylander, a great American, a great human being."
MARRAKECH, Morocco, Nov. 18 -- Three Moroccan ministers reported to King Hassan II today that their mission to Paris to obtain the release of Algerian nationalist leaders had failed.

When Northeastern University in Boston announced last week that it expects to complete a $40 million development program by 1970, the co-operative education idea entered a new phase. Under the cooperative plan students spend alternate periods of equal length studying on campus and working full-time at regularly paying jobs in business and industry.
Stevedores, who lash cargo in holds and on deck, seldom become part of a mariner's story about storms at sea.
EGYPTIANS, from long-gowned fellahin of the Cairo streets to sleek ministers of state, these days are seeing a radically changed Gamal Abdel Nasser. The President of Egypt is grim.

Professional hockey will go to Princeton, N.J., on Nov. 29 when the New York Rangers play the Providence Reds at the Baker Rink of Princeton University. The game will benefit the New Jersey Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Indiana rallied in the fourth quarter on a 38-yard field goal by Luke George and an insurance touchdown in beating West Virginia, 17 -- 9, today in a rugged football game.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Washington's fleet Charlie Mitchell stunned the University of California at Los Angeles with a 90-yard touchdown run on the opening kick-off and Bill Siler floored the Bruins with a 25-yard scoring dash in the fourth period to give the Huskies a 17-13 triumph today.

BOSTON -- As the nights begin to lengthen and autumn gusts alternately bring tantalizing blankets of warm air from inland and chili sheets of fog from off-shore, Boston regains a special aura that is the stamp of its venerability.

We live in a historic generation in which we cannot see the end of our troubles or solutions for our problems. History is painful. It requires the kind of philosophy, calmness and endurance that President Kennedy described in his thoughtful speech at the University of Washington.
GRDELICA, Yugoslavia, Nov. 16 -- For the first time motorists can now drive almost all the way from Western Europe to Greece on modern paved roads.
MADRID, Nov. 15 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Don Juan de Bourbon, claimant to the Spanish throne, are seriously split over the future of the Pretender's 23-year-old son, Prince Juan Carlos.

WHAT this country needs is a Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Conservatives inflicted by such books as "Revolt on the Campus." There is a clear and present danger that extremists of the right will give conservatism a bad name, just as the extremists on the left managed to hurt so respectable an American label as Progressive.
The use of man-made fibers has increased considerably in the last twelve years in the industrial and home-furnishings fields, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported last week.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Trinity College scored the first five times it had the ball today and defeated a stubborn Wesleyan eleven, 42 -- 14, before 6,500 homecoming fans.
PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The hunger strike of five Algerian rebel ministers and of several thousand of their fellow Algerian prisoners was in its eighteenth day today with no sign of a break.
An Australian psychiatrist told an international meeting on hypnosis here yesterday of using the hypnotic trance for its own sake.

HONOLULU, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The trustees of the Wallace R. Farrington Estate announced today that they had sold majority interest in The Honolulu Star-Bulletin, Hawaii's largest newspaper, and its subsidiaries to a group of Honolulu business men.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 18 -- Turkey's military junta is considering the possibility of having to write off as a failure its effort to return the rule of the country to civilian hands.

THE discarded beer can by the highway is clear evidence of abundance, waste and sloppiness. It is a distinctly American phenomenon -- one that has led John Kouwenhoven, Professor of English at Barnard, to wonder about other local phenomena, with a view to discovering whether they have anything in common, and if so, what and why.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 (AP) -- new word, "resegregation," turned up today in reference to racial problems in Southern schools.
ONE of the easiest ways a home owner can find to increase his present living space is to finish a room in his basement. The project, though sizable, can be completed in weekly stages.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Seton Hall High's cross-country team had no difficulty in capturing the Catholic School Division championship today in the forty-first annual New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association meet at Warinanco Park.

A number of Cleveland business indicators have taken a favorable turn in the last few weeks. Auto sales have displayed increasing strength and department store sales have been brisk. Steel output has regained part of its October. setback.
BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Baldwin High finished its first season under Coach Joe Scannella today with 27-6 victory over Freeport. Scannella formerly assisted at Cornell.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- The Florida State Supreme Court, by unanimous decision of its five judges, has validated a bond issue of $160,000,000 for a 156-mile extension of the Sunshine State Parkway, the Florida toll turnpike.

SAN FRANCISCO -- One of the last of the United States' great natural seashore areas lies, still unspoiled, just fifty miles north of downtown San Francisco. It is Point Reyes, a triangular peninsula of the Marin County coast that thrusts its granite headlands twenty miles into the Pacific.
PIMLICO, Md., Nov. 18 -- Off last among the seven 2-year-old colts in today's $116,920 Pimlico Futurity, Crimson Satan, the 3-10 favorite, crossed the wire a galloping five-length winner.
HARTFORD, Nov. 18 -- Control of the Republican party machinery in Connecticut was captured this week by the forces of John Alsop of Avon, who is seeking the party's 1962 nomination for Governor.

IN the justly admired and generally well-done Landmark series of biographies and histories, Leonora Hornblow's "Cleopatra" falls somewhat under par for the course. It will do, but it disappoints, considering the possibilities.

If one were to judge by the days, November would be hurrying us into winter, for daylight's span is shortening now toward the solstice, only a month or so away. But the long nights keep time itself in balance. The nights linger, and the stars, even as the sun seems to cut cross-lots in its haste.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Michigan State managed to convert more fumbles into touchdowns than Northwestern did today as the ninth-ranked Spartans scored a 21-13 Big Ten football victory.

WAYNE, N.J., Nov. 18 -- With four finishers in the first ten places, Glassboro State captured the District 21 National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics and New Jersey College Athletic Conference cross-country championships today on the Paterson State course.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Eight hundred persons attended an all-day anti-Communist rally at the Greenwich High School today.
Urban renewal projects here are aimed at pushing Puerto Ricans, Negroes and other minority groups out of Manhattan, a conference on housing problems was told yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J. -- This winter resort in the heart of the Jersey pine-tree country will officially open its 1961-62 season on Thanksgiving Day with emphasis on several new all weather swimming pools, additional ice-skating facilities and improved driving and walking lanes around Lake Carasaljo.

LAS CRUCES, N.M. -- Many small villages, founded by Spaniards generations ago, bask today in New Mexico's sun. They may be seen in nearly every section of the state, but are most heavily concentrated in the Rio Grande Valley.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Lance Alworth led Arkansas to a 21-7 victory over Southern Methodist University today and pulled the Razorbacks into a tie with Texas for the Southwest Conference lead.

THE legend of J.D. Salinger continues to revolve like a souped-up dervish, and at the moment is whirling around London. Travelers from this side have been carrying over copies of "Franny and Zooey," the book is being widely discussed -- but at the moment there's no English edition.

RENO, Nev. Nov. 18 -- Speedboat owners, drivers and badge-wearing officials had three meetings today at the annual convention of the American Power Boat Association and wound up with the elections for 1962.

HOUSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Passes by Randall Kerbow, a 193-pound junior, enabled Rice to move quickly for a pair of second-period touchdowns today as the Owls defeated Texas A. and M., 21 -- 7, in a Southwest Conference game.

City College won the ninth annual Collegiate Track Conference championship at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

I WISH to express my appreciaation of Richard Edes Harrison's excellent review and analysis of the "Life Pictorial Atlas of the World." I considered buying this on its pre-publication offer as I have wanted a new and modern one for some time and am glad to have deferred decision.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Bob Klein's 72-yard touchdown run on the game's second play helped send third-ranked Ohio State to a 22-12 victory over Oregon before 82,073 fans today.

SINCE Rudyard Kipling wrote "Captains Courageous" more than sixty years ago, the hardy fishermen of New England have received little literary attention. Now, Mary Ellen Chase, New England novelist and the author of two earlier books of maritime history for young people, gives that neglected breed its due.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer will hold three and possibly four long meetings here next week to seek a way of approaching the Soviet Union with an agreed Western bargaining position to resolve the Berlin dispute.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The French theatre, with hundreds of years of tradition behind it, is at the full tide of another season once again.

Department stord sales in the Federal Reserve district for the week ended Nov. 11 showed an increase of 2 per cent from the 1960 level. The largest gain was reported in the San Diego area. Governor Rockefeller, rather than Mrs. Rockefeller, took the initiative toward ending their thirty-one-year marriage, it was disclosed yesterday by an authoritative source. Mrs. Rockefeller was said to have agreed to the separation reluctantly.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 18 -- A 41-yard field goal by Joe Perkowski, after time officially had expired, gave Notre Dame a 17-15 victory over the Syracuse eleven today.

The Columbia-Pennsylvania football game at Baker Field yesterday turned out the way it had figured to turn out -- a runaway victory for the home side. Clearly superior in virtually every phase of the game, Columbia overran its less-talented Ivy League rival and triumphed easily, 37 -- 6.

IF an irate father had not put the slot on Willie Daniel a year ago, the Pittsburgh Steelers would be a lot weaker in their defensive backfield for their game with the New York Giants at the Yankee Stadium this afternoon. But the punch rearranged Willie's thinking and both he and the Steelers have profited by it.

The eighth annual Winter Antiques Show will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, Jan. 19 through Jan. 25, for the benefit of the East Side House Settlement and its affiliates, Stepney Camp in Botsford, Conn., the Winifred Wheeler Nursery School and the Mill Brook Center.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Jim Traficant, a quarterback, came off the bench today to direct Pittsburgh to a winning touchdown and Fred Cox set a school field-goal record in a 10-9 victory today over Southern California.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Wisconsin's passes enabled it to score a 55-7 victory over Illinois today.

Internal warfare in labor again threatens to break up the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Walter P. Reuther and his associates in the industrial unions have warned that the federation cannot survive if the federation fails to work out a peace formula at its convention in Miami Beach next month. The response of the craft unions in the building trades has been to reject the Reuther group's ideas for arbitrating jurisdictional wrangles.

Polylad showed a great liking for a "good" Aqueduct track yesterday and won the twenty-third running of the Gallant Fox Handicap by three-quarters of a length. The 5-year-old son of Polynesian finished in front of Peter Fuller's' Hillsborough in the mile and five-eighths test.

Yesterday at its opening convention session in Denver, the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults started what is to be an all-out effort to eliminate architectural barriers that make many buildings inaccessible to handicapped people.

CEDAR KEY, Fla. -- Quite possibly the only incorporated city along the entire Florida waterfront that does not have or want an organized Chamber of Commerce is Cedar Key. "We like to think of Cedar Key," says Mrs. Bessie Gibbs, owner and operator of a hotel here, "as just about the last outpost of seclusion, of peace and quiet and privacy.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 18 -- Gen. Rafael L. Trujillo Jr. has resigned as chief of the Dominican Republic's armed forces and sailed for Europe on his yacht, the Government announced tonight.

There "has to be a change" in the New York State Democratic leadership, Mayor Wagner said last week, and "I'm glad to do it." That statement demonstrated how the elections of a fortnight ago had transformed him from a beleaguered candidate -- fighting the Republicans, the Democratic "regulars" in city and state, and public concern about minor scandals in his administration -- into the kingfish among New York Democrats.

Another hint that the nation's high-school reforms are making the traditional college freshman year obsolete comes from Yale University, with a report that the regular freshman mathematics course has been scrapped.

THE Middle Ages have been called the Age of Faith and the Age of Chivalry, but to Christine Price these years between 1000 and 1500 were also the Age of Craftsmen. In a smoothly written, profusely illustrated book, Miss Price, an English-born writer and artist now living in this country, gives a fine account of the work of medieval craftsmen in wood, cloth, metal, stone and other materials.

F the beginning deer hunter keeps one thing foremost in mind, he will be a long way on the road to success. That thought is, simply, that he is an amateur engaged in a non-competitive sport that can be rewarding and pleasurable even if no game is bagged.

FORT COLLINS, Colo., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Jim Cromartie engineered two long scoring drives and plunged for the touchdowns that capped them today as New Mexico handed Colorado State University its sixteenth straight football loss, 20 -- 8.

TO take a person like Catherine de Medici, the "merchant's daughter" who became Queen of France and mother of three kings, and to make a book about her which will interest young readers is something of an achievement.

The New York Rangers will be out to prove they're better than Toronto's coach, Punch Imlach, thinks they are when the Blues take on his Maple Leafs tonight in a National Hockey League game on the Madison Square Garden ice. The game will start at 7 o'clock.

JOHN CALVIN, it must be admitted, is a natural for the historical novelist. A towering figure in his own day, he is in some parts of the world still a dominating feature of the moral landscape. The showing and sale of about 500 works of art at the Decorative Arts Center at 305 East Sixty-third Street from Dec. 7 through Dec. 22 will benefit The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

With winter in the offing and the social and business pressures of the holiday season mounting steadily, this is the time of year when the thoughts of many Madison Avenue executives begin to wander. A battle royal is shaping up over oil.
SUBURBIA is caught in the middle of a ballet boom, and eager and not-too-eager girls, with a helpful push from mama's ego, are trekking to weekly or daily ballet lessons in greater numbers than ever.

A single two-stage Air Force rocket launched two Navy satellites into orbit at Cape Canaveral last Wednesday. One was part of the Navy's program to have in operation by late 1962 a network of satellites to provide a global, all-weather navigational system for ships and planes that will be far more precise than any navigational method now being used.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13 -- shrine commemorating 300,000 persons murdered by the Nazis in Lithuania will rise in a suburb of Tel Aviv.

HOUSTON, Nov. 18 -- Sixteen contract bridge pairs started play here tonight at the Shamrock Hilton Hotel in a five-day contest to determine the North American six-man team for the 1962 world championship.

A WHOLE year of nature is portrayed in this tale of a pond in the wilderness. It begins amid snow and ice, with the pond creatures forced to the very limit of their endurance in the struggle to survive. Then silently and without fuss spring comes to the pond, to awaken incalculable numbers of denizens asleep in earth and water and wood.

More than a hundred years ago, a few industrial school pupils in New York City sat down to free lunches. Today, more than 14,000,000 American children are fed school lunches that cost them only a small amount -- or even cost nothing if they cannot afford to pay.

BONHAM, Tex., Nov. 18 -- House Speaker Sam Rayburn was buried today in the rich Texas earth that nurtured him. Funeral services were held in the First Baptist Church he had helped to build. President Kennedy and former Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and Harry S. Truman were in the front row with the Speaker's long-time friend, Vice President Johnson.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Visitors who have wintered here in the past may have trouble this year recognizing some of the surrounding landscape. New developments in the phosphate mining industry are bringing about drastic changes in the local scenery, and it is generally agreed that these are changes for the better.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 17 -- Ghanaian officials are waiting or the Kennedy Administration to decide whether United States bid on a large scale will be made available for the construction of a huge hydroelectric object on the Volta River.

Most retailers are hoping that a fair break in the weather will pull business up to the figures predicted for it earlier in the year. But fall is fast slipping away and only a sustained period of cool weather will succeed in preventing excessive markdowns.
POINT ARGUELLO, Calif., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A rocket carried a capsule of living material high into space today, but the capsule parachuted into the Pacific off course and was apparently lost.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Ronnie Bull of Baylor scored two touchdowns today despite a back injury that has hampered him all season as the Bears whipped the Air Force Academy eleven, 31 -- 7, before 22,000 fans.

AS the author of "Gideon," the hit dramatization of Old Testament source material, now at the Plymouth Theatre, Paddy Chayefsky is a playright whose head definitely is not in the clouds. Last week, Mr. Chayefsky, feet on the ground, divulged that he, in association with Dr, Tyrone Guthrie (director of "Gideon") and Arthur Cantor (co-producer with Fred Coe) are planning to produce independently a film version of his earlier successful play, "The Tenth Man."

Carlos Ortiz survived a 2-count knockdown in the ninth round and went on to score a unanimous decision over his Bronx rival, Paolo Rosi, in a ten-round lightweight fight at Madison Square Garden last night.

The anxiety of free men everywhere regarding Finland's future has been sharply increased by recent developments. Now Moscow practically orders that a Finnish delegation be sent to the Soviet capital "as soon as possible" to engage in military consultations regarding an alleged West German threat.

True, the southerners must rely on artificial snow, but ski experts say the slopes will be first-rate during the winter months.

McCormack of Massachusetts will be elected Speaker of the House of Representatives without a real contest arises not because he is the choice of President Kennedy and the consistent supporters of the Administration's programs in that branch of the Congress. TWO American sopranos made their Metropolitan Opera debuts in successive weeks last month, both in the same role (Fiordiligi in Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte"). Both flew to Europe within hours after their performances to honor commitments with opera companies abroad.

Nonagricultural employment in Illinois climbed 31,100 in September, the State Employmeat Service reported. At the beginning of the final quarter of the year employment rolls stood at 3,435,200, compared with 3,404,100 at the end of August.

The Dec. 14 performance of "Man for All Seasons" at the ANTA Theatre will benefit the Federation des Alliances Francaises in the United States. The organization was founded in France in 1902 to further French-American friendship.

President Kennedy has spent most of his time since inauguration coping with a succession of foreign crises -- Cuba, Berlin, Laos, nuclear testing, the Congo.
