BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- The East German Communist press has ended a two-day silence in its campaign of defending Walter Ulbricht, head of the regime, against accusations linking him to the Stalinist cult of personality.

QUEEN VICTORIA'S favorite Prime Minister, the novelist Benjamin Disraeli, thus apostrophized her: "We authors, Ma'am." For she had published her "Leaves From a Journal of Our Life in the Highlands," in 1868, and its sequel in 1883.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 18 -- A second joint legislative conference committee was unable this week to agree on a solitary district standing in the way of Congressional reapportionment.

A chance to recapture the lead in the Eastern Division of the American Football League will be presented to the Titans of New York today. The second-place Titans will oppose the division-leading Houston Oilers at Jeppersen Stadium in Houston.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The new West German Foreign Minister, Dr. Gerhard Schroeder, said today that the Communist wall dividing Berlin was "a grave obstacle to negotiations" between the Soviet bloc and the West on the city.

The First International Conference on Measles Immunization, held in Washington last week under the auspices of the United States Public Health Service, heard reports that the vaccine against measles had provided immunity for 96 per cent of 10,000 inoculated children.

NEWS background, observations, interviews and anecdotal tidbits are the ingredients of a savory souffle prepared with a light touch and Served in five-minute portions forty-seven times each week by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

IN reviewing "Hidden Channels of the Mind" by Louisa E. Rhine, Gerald Heard informs his readers that J.B. Rhine set up a Parapsychology Laboratory at Duke University a number of years ago, and began to produce statistical evidence in connection with extra-sensory perception.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Sandy Stephens became the first Minnesota back since Paul Giel to gain more than 1,000 yards as he guided the Gophers to a 10-7 victory over Purdue today in a Big Ten Conference game.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- A new educational project on the east side of San Francisco Bay is emerging as a dramatic symbol of California's population growth.

EVER since it began, the oil industry has irresistibly attracted the attention of crusading social critics. Robert Engler has brought this literature up to date with his account of how the industry reacted to such post-war events as the tideland controversy, the Mossadegh crisis and natural gas regulation. His book fits the tradition; it is .full of rip-roaring episodes, with bold actions on stage and subtle manipulations behind the scenes.
The Angola rebellion is not over, and the nationalist forces are regrouping for a new offensive within a "few weeks," an Angolan nationalist declared here yesterday.

ONE of the elegant new stores on Terazije, Belgrade's Fifth Avenue, is a spacious and well-appointed bookstore that would do credit to Rue de l'Opera and Oxford Street. It boasts one of the longest book shop windows in Europe.

ROBERT BOLT'S "A Man For All Seasons," which opens Wednesday at the ANTA Theatre, is concerned with Sir Thomas More's relations with his sovereign, Henry VIII, and with the spiritual trials and physical sufferings from that relationship.

MONTREAL -- The establishment of a Ministry of Tourism for the Province of Quebec looms as a strong possibility in the wake of a series of hearings in which an arm of the Government has been taking stock of the assets and liabilities of the province's tourist industry.
Britain expects to play host to a record number of visitors from the United States next year, Sir William Mabane, chairman of the British Travel Association, said here last week.
WARSAW, Nov. 17 -- The Roman Catholic Church has won at least a temporary victory in its struggle to keep Government hands off religious education in Poland.
BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Boston College defeated its cross-town rival, Boston University, 10 -- 7, today on a fourth-period field goal by Lou Kirouac and the brilliant play of Harry (The Horse) Crump.

CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A fumble, recovered in the end zone by Harrison Woodruff, a freshman end, enabled Lebanon Valley to score a 15-14 victory over Pennsylvania Military College today and gain the Southern Division title in the Middle Atlantic Conference.

HARRISON, N. Y., Nov. 18-Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Adams Kagel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Todd Kagel, to David Burrall Barnum of the Air. Force. He is the son of Mrs. Norval D. Jennings of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Capt. Burrall Barnum of the Army Air Forces.

A thoughtful, if monotoned account of American progressivism as seen through the activities of Emerson, Theodore Parker, Henry George, Edward Bel!amy, Henry Demarest Lloyd, Thorstein Veblen, and two men Mr. Aaron calls "pseudoprogressives," Theodore Roosevelt and Brooks Adnm.

The New York Giants play the Pittsburgh Steelers in a rematch at Yankee Stadium today. The game will start at 2:05 P.M. A New York victory will greatly enhance the team's chances of winning the Eastern Conference title in the National League race.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Steve Nagy, a 48-year-old bowler from Los Angeles, stole the scoring spotlight today as he rolled the third 300 game in the five-year history of the world invitation tournament.

Society orchestras and their leaders no longer are regarded by society as "just hired hands." Meyer Davis, Lester Lanin, Emil Coleman and Ben Cutler have become as integral a part of social life as members of society.

THE bravery and dignity of the Danish people in rescuing their countrymen of the Jewish faith from the invading Nazis were related yesterday morning in a remarkable little documentary film of both compassion and excitement.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The hunger strike by about 4,000 Algerian rebels in French prisons ended tonight after nineteen days.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company moved its midtown office over the week-end from the Postal Life Building on the southeast corner of Forty-Third Street and Fifth Avenue to its newly rebuilt quarters on the Southwest corner of Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue.
A number of account changes -- some official and some rumored -- were in the wind over the week-end.

DALLAS, Nov. 19 -- Jewish community leaders recommended today an intensive study of whether the increasing number of Jewish all-day schools should be supported by Jewish welfare funds and federations.

Members of the New York Auxiliary of the Blue Ridge School of St. George, Va., will hold their fall luncheon meeting at the Junior League clubhouse today. Arrangements will be made for the fifty-third annual dinner dance, to be held in the ballroom of the Pierre on Jan. 26.

Bobby Ramsen, who could have joined his father's demolition business, is building a name in show business. A fresh, bright comic, Mr. Ramsen is now at the Copacabana, tearing apart the boom in credit cards.

Y.A. Tittle, calling the Giants' seventh play of the third quarter yesterday, signaled for a pass adding, " 'A' back shoot." As the Giants came out of the huddle, Alex Webster, the "A" back for the play, told Tittle he would also go downfield after shooting.

Few subjects have aroused so much concern in recent years as the so-called missile gap -- that is, the belief that the Soviet Union was gaining a militarily significant lead over this country in the number of intercontinental ballistic missiles. Yesterday this newspaper reported that the majority opinion in our armed forces and intelligence services is that the missile gap which now exists is the reverse of that feared previously.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany arrived here this evening for three days of intensive talks with President Kennedy.

IT'S always a pleasure to watch a professional baseball player swing, even when he misses. PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- Steel users were starting to talk in more definite terms about inventory plans last week.

The letter published Nov. 13 from Robert T. Stevens, chairman of the board of one of the nation's, largest textile companies, is welcome because it focuses attention on the basic issue of American foreign trade policy. Cooperative apartments for middle-income families in four city-built developments are proving harder to sell than had been expected. The sluggish demand is a surprise because most of the middle-income cooperatives put up by unions and private builders, with low-interest loans and tax concessions under the Mitchell-Lama Act, have been oversubscribed long before the first shovel of earth was turned.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Premier Khrushchev was reported today to have warned cotton growers that they would be made to wear short pants "even in winter" if they were not men enough to meet his increased output goals.
SAN DIEGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Jack Kemp passed the San Diego Chargers to a 24-14 victory over the Dallas Texans in an American Football League game today.
What better way to honor the memory of Serge Koussevitsky than with a concert of contemporary music.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 19 -- As United States warships patrolled off the coast, the chief remaining members of the Trujillo family tonight left the country they had ruled for thirty years.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers scored 28 points in the second period today on the passing of Bart Starr for a 35-17 National Football League victory over the Los Angeles Rams.
TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- The United States rallied last night and won team honors in the international equestrian jumping competition of the Royal Winter Fair.

Aluminum industry officials expect that their new proposal for a voluntary, Government-negotiated system of aluminum trade among free world nations will prompt a reaction in Washington circles before January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- From the moment of President Kennedy's election, roughly 365 days ago, a falling out between his Administration and the Federal Reserve Board has been predicted. It has not occurred.

Trading in the over-the-counter market got off to a fast start last week, but slowed considerably on Thursday and Friday. Prices turned irregular toward the end of the week as volume contracted, but, even so, on average industrial issues scored another net gain.
THE gray-haired Norwegian diplomat who sought in Moscow yesterday to ease Soviet pressure on Finland is a leader of a party that long used a broken gun as its emblem.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Three Federal judges today ordered John Fraiser, Leflore County attorney, and S.M. Courtney of Greenwood, Greyhound bus manager, to abandon offorts to enforce bus terminal segregation at Greenwood.

William S. Morris Co., Wall Street bond house, following its belief that the electronic computer is a tool that allows small companies to compete favorably with large concerns, installed a computer of its own yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- "Trick or Treat for UNICEF," which collected $36 in 1956, is expected to realize more than $2,000,000 from this year's Halloween collections.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Administration is planning to double the civilian space budget in the next fiscal year.
SMITHTOWN, L.I., Nov. 20 -- A seventy-five-foot Norway spruce will be cut down this week from its lonely stand above the rolling hills of the Nissequogue River Valley.
The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company has revived its plans to re-enter the intercoastal shipping field with fast, large container ships.
Business slowed in the high-grade bond market yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20, (AP) -- Bill Pace of Kansas City took a commanding lead today in qualifying rounds of the fifth annual World's Invitational bowling tournament in McCormack Place.

BROCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Rutgers defeated Brockport State, 3 -- 1, today in the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate soccer tournament before a crowd of 2,500. Herb Schmidt, a center forward, scored twice for the winners.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Kennedy met for a half-hour today with a group of business men who will form the nucleus of a drive in support of his foreign trade program next year.
Cotton futures fell 30 cents to $1.95 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

" FASHION isn't merely putting something on a body -- it's a way of life," says Polaire Weissman, a small blond and blue-eyed woman who occupies a distinctive position on the sidelines of the world of style.

Kelvin Scott of Trinidad, British West Indies, boxed with the loose-jointed grace of a muscular marionette in taking a split decision from Vince Shomo of New York last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.

ALTHOUGH traditional Thanksgiving dishes are largely the same, they need not be static in taste. A touch of dried marjoram provides an excellent nuance in creamed onions; whipped white potatoes take on a different dimension in flavor when combined with celery root or knob celery.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Supreme Court upheld as constitutional today a Florida law making jury duty voluntary for women while it was compulsory for men.

THE peoples choice at Christmas knows no common denominator. The best-seller lists at some of New York's stores disclose only that most shoppers fall for inexpensive gimmicks or turn to lingerie for women and ties for men when all else fails.
Cocoa, potato and Brazilian coffee futures were just active enough to draw attention to themselves in an otherwise dull trading day yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- United States immigration authorities said today that two brothers of Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo Molina, the late Dominican dictator, had been admitted to the United States "temporarily."
The disappearance of a 200-pound safe on wheels was reported yesterday by the Amtorg Trading Corporation, Soviet commercial agents here a 355 Lexington Avenue.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- If all goes well, Jack Brabham, the world champion race driver in 1959 and 60, will race a car in the Grand Prix season that he has designed and built himself. To win the world championship in his own car has been Brabham's dream since he came to England from Australia in 1955.
New traffic bottlenecks to plague motorists will be pointed up this week as four major highway improvements get under way to serve the 1964-65 World's Fair in Queens.

Andre Porumbeanu was admitted to $10,000 bail yesterday in Brooklyn by the Appellate Division pending an appeal from a thirty-day Jail sentence. The sentence was handed down Friday by Magistrate Peter M. Horn in Girls Term Court, Brooklyn.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 20 -- Queen Elizabeth II concluded her eleven-day state visit to Ghana today.
HONOLULU, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller had planned to go to New Guinea via Tokyo, but Pan American World Airways announced here that he would charter the jet instead.
Tension between India and Communist China has increased sharply with the publication of the Indian note charging Peiping with "further aggression."
OYSTER BAY, L.I. Nov. 20 -- Dr. Thomas Hale Hamilton, president of the State University, termed his first meeting with the faculty of the Long Island Center here today as "constructive."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The United States would have a manpower shortage instead of unemployment if it had a more liberal tax depreciation write-off for business, Senator Barry Goldwater said here today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Michael Rockefeller's letters to a former Harvard room-mate indicate he was fascinated with New Guinea.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A former governor of the Federal Reserve Board said today that the deficit in the United States balance of payments had made discipline in economic and fiscal policies a must.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 20 -- A mood of celebration here at the departure of leading members of the Trujillo family was dampened tonight by reports of the murder of six members of the Opposition Saturday.

The eight-player trade between the St. Louis Hawks and the Chicago Packers last Sunday was suspended yesterday by Maurice Podoloff, the president of the National Basketball Association, pending approval by the league's board of governors.
Improvements in the program of state aid to education were recommended yesterday by a special study group appointed by the State Education Department.

CAIRO, Nov. 20 -- The leaders of the United Arab Republic, Yugoslavia and India affirmed today their determination to "concentrate their best efforts on preserving peace." They said this would be the "vital objective of their respective foreign policies and their collective efforts."

Operations of the Coca-Cola Company for the three and nine months ended on Sept. 30 resulted in the highest dollar sales and earnings in its seventy-five-year history, Lee Talley, president and chairman, reported yesterday.
CUSTOM-MADE furnishings in the finest woods may be found in Manhattan in a sawdust-strewn loft.

To help familiarize youngsters and adults with the countries involved in the United Nations, a new game has been devised by Parker Brothers in cooperation with the U.N. Called "United Nations Flag Game," its playing board is laid out with the flags of each country in accurate geographic location.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee approved unanimously today a resolution on decentralizing the economic and social work of the United Nations and strengthening its regional economic commissions.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20 -- India has accused Communist China of "further aggression" along their frontier.
The new president of the Propeller Club of the United States has proposed a radical overhaul of the structure and administration of the organization.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The arrival here today of the two Trujillo brothers and their party of twenty-seven apparently brought to a close the thirty-year reign of the Trujillos over the Dominican Republic.
PROVIDENCE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson floored Al Hauser four times tonight and scored a sixth-round technical knockout at the Rhode Island Auditorium.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Dr. J. Boendermaker, Deputy Governor General of Dutch New Guinea, said today that Michael Rockefeller was seeking head-hunter relics when he disappeared.

The Allied Chemical Corporation, one of the nation's largest chemical makers, announced yesterday that it planned to merge with the Union Texas Natural Gas Corporation of Houston, Tex., a major producer of natural gas and liquid petroleum gas.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Canada urged today the convocation of a conference of Commonwealth Prime Ministers before Britain finally decided whether to join the European Economic Community.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The European Economic Community is about to confront the United States with a new tariff proposal. It would involve semiautomatic reductions by both sides on key groups of items.

The ballroom of the Sheraton-East will be turned into an "Aruba Casino" on Dec. 4 for a dinner dance arranged in behalf of United Cerebral Palsy. Gov. F.J.C. Beaujon of Aruba, Netherlands West Indies, has been announced as a sponsor of the event.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- Thousands of West Berlin university students and other youths tried last night to storm the barriers that divide the city, but were driven back by truncheon-wielding West Berlin police units.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 20 -- The Government warned Western oil companies today that it was taking steps to make arrangements to replace their supply of refined petroleum products.
Undefeated and untied Alabama moved past Texas yesterday and gained the No. 1 berth in the United Press International weekly college football ratings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today denied a hearing to Salvatore Agron, a Puerto Rican boy facing execution in New York for the slaying of two 16-year-old boys at a darkened playground on the West Side of Manhattan.

WARREN, Ohio, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Three city councilmen, among seven persons indicted in an alleged shakedown of contractors on sewer projects, pleaded guilty in Trumbull County Common Pleas Court today. All were removed from office.
Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder, the Syracuse football coach, questioned yesterday the legality of the field goal that resulted in a 17-15 defeat by Notre Dame Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews declared here today that world conflicts were having the effect of drawing closer together the different religious faiths.
ALGIERS, Nov. 20 -- A sharp attack by an official of the French Government on the Algerian Provisional Government in Tunis caused speculation here that peace talks might be delayed.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- President Cemal Gursel announced today a new post-election coalition Cabinet. Ismet Inonu, who is 77 years old, is Premier and Selim Sarper continues as Foreign Minister.
JANE SEYMOUR'S song recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall had taste and style.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- The Western Allies have more men under arms than the Communist nations have and are at least the equal of the Communists in most key weapons, including missiles, the Institute of Strategic Studies estimated in a report published here today.

A NEW apron design by Marti Huber could be an ornament in the kitchen when holiday meals are prepared. The apron is gathered on a band with ties running through the material just below the bust. When pulled, they create a drawstring effect and an Empire waistline.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- The search for Michael Rockefeller was concentrated on the swampy southwest coast of New Guinea today after a rescued companion had reported last seeing him swimming from their capsized raft toward shore, fifteen miles away.

Net income of Federated Department Stores, Inc., rose 8.6 per cent and sales 6.2 per cent in the first three quarters of 1961, it was reported yesterday. The interim earnings statement was made by Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, and Ralph Lazarus, president.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- A group of British investors has successfully bid for a tract of city-owned land downtown. A spokesman said that a $20,000,000 office building would be erected.

Eight new warrants were issued in Housing Court yesterday for the arrest of Mrs. Richard A. Grubel, making a total of twenty-three warrants out for her. Fifteen warrants were issued for her last week.
The public, and even the press, has understandably confused two U.N. General Assembly resolutions, both dealing with nuclear weapons tests and both passed during the week of Nov. 5.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Wheat, corn and oats futures prices were on the firm end of a teetering trade today, while rye and soybeans came under steady pressure and turned weak.
The Echo satellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, ten times between today and Monday evening, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in Washington yesterday.

A five-story apartment house at 665 East 179th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by clients of Elihu A. Novick, lawyer. The plot is 50 by 100 feet. The building has twenty-five apartments and is assessed at $54,000. Braff Braff, attorneys, represented the seller.
Thanksgiving Day will be observed here and throughout the nation Thursday with the traditional mixture of festivity and solemnity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Eric Ambler, who has mastered the art of instilling terror with words in such novels as "Journey Into Fear" and "The Mask of Dimitrios," is despondent about what television is doing to melodramas' best friend, the villain.

ROCHELLE PARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank of New York, said here tonight that private interests must continue to work for the solution of public problems, whether they involve the entire metropolitan area or a segment of it.
LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- A United Nations search plane found six survivors today near the wreck of a United Nations aircraft in Tanganyika.
Ossie Davis, author and co-star of "Purlie Victorious," is working on two new dramas. One is about Negro actresses. The other deals with the emerging African nations.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20 -- The Russian Orthodox Church in the Soviet Union, the largest of all Eastern Orthodox bodies, was admitted today to full membership in the World Council of Churches.

Undeterred by the worst weather in the fifty-three-year history of the event, Cornell's remarkable Stephan Machooka scored as scheduled yesterday in the varsity cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- An $875,000 portrait, described as the finest by Fragonard, will go on display tomorrow in the National Gallery of Art.
Democratic legislative leaders have decided to treat Mayor Wagner rather than Michael H. Prendergast, the state chairman, as their party's real leader in the state.

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dean M. Kelly, director of the Department of Religious Liberty of the National Council of Churches, took issue today with a recent reassertion by Roman Catholic bishops that public funds should be used for parochial schools.

The noted Mexican artist David Alfaro Siqueiros, at 64, is seriously ill and languishing in Lecumberri jail in Mexico City, a victim of political persecution. Along with him are twenty-six other political prisoners, mainly railroad workers, who along with Siqueiros incurred official displeasure in organizing a Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners when 5,000 railroad workers were jailed during a strike in 1959.
While silk-clad bodies vibrated and diamonds shimmered to the music of the Twist last night in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the museum's director, James J. Rorimer, shook with dismay.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Whiteface Mountain presents two faces to the public. One is the well-known northeast side, criss-crossed with ski trails and lifts now lightly dusted with snow and giving promise of a good ski season.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Bertrand Russell, chairman of the antinuclear Committee of 100, announced plans today for a major demonstration Dec. 9 against United States Air Force bases in Britain.
The Golden Triangle Stable's Humane Leader stepped nimbly through the slop at Aqueduct yesterday and won the one-mile feature race. Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Dr. Miller was second.
The Grace Line will try to ease the Friday afternoon rush hour on the Chelsea waterfront by staggering its sailings.
Stockholders of E.J. Korvette, Inc., New York, department store chain, approved at their annual meeting a three-for-one split of the common stock. The split will be effective Dec. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Continental Air Lines called opponents of proposed jet economy service reactionary today and asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for a "full and fair trial."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The United States proposed today that the United Nations help the Congolese central Government reorganize, retrain and develop its armed forces "for the tasks which confront it."
Henry L. McCarthy, former City Welfare Commissioner, has resigned as executive director of the Community Council of Greater New York because of ill health.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy has under consideration proposed changes in oil import limits, a House investigating subcommittee was told today.
DALLAS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The American Football League admitted tonight that it had held a draft prior to the official date -- Dec. 2.

GARY, Ind., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Three "gentlemanly" bandits masquerading as a policeman and two prisoners talked their way into a bank manager's home, held the family captive for twelve hours and then robbed a branch bank of $80,000 today.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The new Agency for International Development made its first loan today, a $50,000,000 advance to Brazil for essential imports and to help stabilize that country's economy.
HONOLULU, Nov. 20 -- Governor Rockefeller, gray with fatigue and accumulated tensions, paused here today en route to New Guinea, where he will spur the search for his youngest son, Michael.
The Asmat art that was being sought in New Guinea by Michael Rockefeller is among the most dramatic products of primtive peoples.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer of West Germany talked privately today in an effort to dispel the "crisis of confidence" between their Governments over the Berlin problem.

Scholars, educators and leaders from many professions gathered last night at the Astor Hotel to pay tribute to Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick, one of the founders of progressive education in the United States.

The Public Service Commission ruled yesterday that requests of a water-supply company for rate increases totaling $286,500 a year were excessive. The company operates plants in Queens, Nassau, Rockland and Wayne Counties.
ESSEN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- The House of Krupp celebrated its 150th anniversary today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Perhaps the United States would not need to reach the moon first or ever, and the current rush toward the prairie dog safety concept of underground shelters would abate, if our official thinking on the collective security of the non-Communist world were totally reappraised.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Deputy Commissioner James B. Cash Jr. of the Federal Housing Administration said tonight he was dismissed from his job today because of a columnist's report that he lost $7,000 in a card game at a builders' convention.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- A five-point program to achieve full employment was proposed today by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 (UPI). -- Mrs. Elizabeth R. Smith, Treasurer of the United States, said today she might resign and help Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California campaign for re-election next year.

BRUCKNER is a religion, and you have it or you don't. His music deals in visions, at great length, in variations on the common chord. Bruckner once had a dream of Beethoven (he had one of Wagner, too, but that dissipated) and it haunted all his waking years.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in the month to Nov. 15 to 3,159,225 shares, or 27,452 shares from the level of Oct. 13, when the revised figure was 3,131,773 shares. In mid-November, 1960, the figure was 4,135,870 shares.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The United States chided the Soviet Union today for trying to plead poverty in an attempt to head off any increase in Moscow's share of the United Nations budget.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Two Republican councilmen called on City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell today to end his week-long speaking tour advertising this city's controversial new welfare plan.
Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino was accused yesterday of a "betrayal of public trust" in supporting the passage of fall-out shelter legislation at the recent special session of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company has received preliminary approval from the Federal Reserve Board to establish two international corporations, the bank announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Office of Civil Defense confirmed officially today that the Government had abandoned evacuation as a protective measure for cities under nuclear assault.

LEONARDO DA VINCI held a number of different worlds successfully inside his head, and he was perhaps the last person for whom this was possible. After him, specialization insulated fields of knowledge from each other with melancholy success.

Walter (Mickey) Sullivan resigned yesterday as football coach at Wagner College. Sullivan, the president of a Manhattan business that employs more than 500 persons, said business pressure had forced him to quit.

It was necessary for me to reach someone in Stamford, Conn., yesterday while I was away from my desk. First, I dialed New York Information 411 to ask how I could find the number. I was told "Dial area code plus 555 plus 1212."

CARL SANDBURG, going on 84 and busier as writer, performer and Presidential visitor than when he was 74, is the subject of a couple of November books by admirers. One is Norman Corwin, scenarist and director, who first began to adapt Sandburg's writings for radio nearly a quarter of a century ago; the other is Harry Golden, the "Only in America" journalist, who is a fellow North Carolinian.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Treasury's shortest-term bill rate rose again on today's sale of the regular weekly issues, to its highest level since early March. The average discount rate on the new issue of ninety-one-day bills was 2.537 per cent, compared with 2.516 per cent at last week's sale.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The annual Christmas fair and bazaar of the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help will open Wednesday evening and continue all day Friday and Saturday. Mrs. Fred Lichtenberg is chairman for the event, which will be held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Elementary School here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The United States declared today that a new society based on racial harmony would "inevitably appear" in South Africa.

While the crisis seems to be ending satisfactorily, it is unfortunate that the situation in the Dominican Republic, where a Trujillo coup was averted last week-end should have reached such a dangerous stage.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -- Improved schools in big cities are the most pressing social need, Abraham A. Ribicoff said today.

The Consolidated Edison Company filed proposals with the state last night for rate changes that would raise the electric bills of the big consumers and reduce them for small ones. It recommended that the new rates go into effect Dec. 20.
Two banks were robbed in the city yesterday -- one in Brooklyn before the morning rush hour and the other in Manhattan during the noon hour. A third attempt, also in Manhattan, failed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr. flashes a happy smile in official birthday pictures released today by the White House.
The holiday turkeys that grace the tables of America in these latter days seldom approach the gigantic birds that many a middle-aged and younger citizen can well recall.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Nov. 20 -- Premier Cyrille Adoula is being criticized in some political quarters for his speech attacking the mutinous soldiers who massacred thirteen Italian airmen in Kindu Nov. 11.
WARSAW, Nov. 20 -- Miss Ursula Discher, the mistress of Irvine Scarbeck, who was convicted of giving United States secrets to Poland, has returned to Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Angelo Inciso, a Chicago union official convicted of causing a local to accept $420.267 from twenty-two employers at various times from 1952 to 1956.

Today's new film is "Loss of Innocence," an adaptation of Rumer Godden's novel "The Greengage Summer," at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, near Seventh Avenue, and the Sixty-eighth Street Playhouse, at Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities requested Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy today to prosecute Maurice H. Klein, former personnel director of the National Security Agency, for alleged perjury and other criminal offenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Kerr-McGee Oil Industries, Inc., said today that six of its officers and directors apparently made forbidden profits of more than $227,000 through dealings in the company's stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- India asked the United Nations tonight to press the United States and the Soviet Union to present an agreed proposal for disarmament negotiations to the General Assembly before the end of this session next month.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 20 -- The first step was taken by Westchester officials today toward granting increases averaging 8 per cent for the 3,600 county employes, except members of the Board of Supervisors.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- Norway's Foreign Minister, Dr. Halvard M. Lange, sought today to ease Soviet pressure on Finland for military cooperation.

Net earnings of Minerals Chemicals Philipp Corporation for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $6,648,100, against $6,211,500 in the 1960 period. The earnings were equal to $1.27 and $1.18 a share in the respective periods.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- The Legislature today approved a bill that would make the deduction and other provisions of the commuter income tax conform with those in the New York income tax law. Gov. Robert B. Meyner is expected to sign it.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Ben Kerner, the owner of the St. Louis Hawks, dipped into the ranks of his thirteen former coaches today and picked Andrew (Fuzzy) Levane to coach the slumping Hawks for the balance of the National Basketball Association season.
THE untamed West -- of Australia, not the United States -- is the setting of last night's new action-adventure half hour called "Whiplash," offered as a local presentation by WNBC-TV.
THERE must be a lesson in a disaster like the witless, tasteless "'Toinette," an alleged musical comedy, which was allowed into the Theatre Marquee last night.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- France announced tonight that Mohammed Ben Bella, Vice Premier of the Algerian rebels' Provisional Government, and four Ministers of State imprisoned with him had ended their fast in a compromise worked out with representatives of the King of Morocco.

Events today: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Philadelphia Orchestra, Hans Schmidt-Isserstedt, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Helen Lightner, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; National Association for American Composers and Conductors concert, Paul Price, conductor, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Gabriel Banat, violinist, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:15.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The American Anthropological Association has strongly disputed recent statements that Negroes are biologically and mentally inferior to the white race.

Sylvia Plath, the Boston-born poet now living in England, has received a fellowship from the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust to enable her to finish her first novel. Miss Plath's poems and short stories have appeared in periodicals in this country and in England.
THERE are two things about "A Summer to Remember" that are generally regarded as incompatible: (1) the new Soviet film is beautiful; (2) it represents socialist realism.

The prison sentences of two men implicated in an alleged attempt to fix a court decision were reduced yesterday. Federal Judge Leo F. Rayfiel, who had given the original sentences, acted in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

The Great Western Financial Corporation, Los Angeles, has become the first savings and loan holding company in the nation with total assets in excess of $1,000,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Warren Lee Pierson, chairman.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 20 -- A 4-by-7-foot glass panel fell into an empty classroom today at the new Hillspoint Road Elementary School. Parents flooded the school office with calls demanding the school be closed.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday increased sales for the quarter, nine and twelve months ended on Oct. 31. Earnings for the nine months exceeded profits a year earlier, while those for the quarter and twelve months almost equaled the 1960 figures, according to the report by Bruce A. Gimbel, president of the large department store chain.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- An Army Reserve general protested Government call-ups today. He contended that the "crisis is over," and argued that ready reservists activated because of it should be released as soon as draftees could be trained.

Mayor Wagner favors proposals to build a $3,000,000 Executive Building in City Hall Park and a $4,521,000 parking garage under Bryant Park. This was disclosed yesterday in a report to the Board of Estimate from Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
A service center for small appliances was opened yesterday by the General Electric Company in a corridor half-way between Grand Central Terminal's main concourse and the subway shuttle.
DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Industry sources estimated today that dealer inventories of new cars have risen to about 700,000 units including slightly more than 100,000 leftover 1961 models.

The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will defer payment next May 1 of the interest on its 4 1/2 per cent convertible income bonds as well as omit dividend payment in 1962 on its non-cumulative $4 preferred stock and common stock. Interest on the bonds is fully cumulative.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Prices of many industrial share leaders fell Sharply on the stock market here today, lowering The Financial Times industrial shares index 4 points to 301.4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to review an order prohibiting six major distributors of old movies from block booking sales or licensing of their films for television showing.

Plans are afoot to bring representatives of most of the tennis-playing nations to the United States next summer for the national amateur championships. If carried out, Forest Hills may rival Wimbledon in the international scope of the entry.

The court reorganization amendment approved on Election Day goes far to assure more effective machinery for dispensing justice. But it did not even attempt to deal with a situation that is fully as important and in need of change as court structure and administration: the way in which judges are chosen.

The New York City Housing Authority plans to borrow $12,175,000 on temporary loan notes on Nov. 28 to finance four state-aided developments -- the Jonathan Williams Houses and Fort Greene Houses in Brooklyn, the Stephen Wise Houses in Manhattan, and the Arthur H. Murphy Houses in the Bronx.
Fourteen persons were hospitalized last night after a smoky fire broke out on a Long Island Rail Road train in a tunnel under the East River.

The election of Joseph Ross as president and a director of Davidson Brothers, Inc., operator of the Federal Department Stores and Hoffritz for Cutlery, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Ross, formerly corporate vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., succeeds Joseph H. Davidson, who has been named vice chairman.

Early this fall the magazine world was surprised by the almost simultaneous emergence of two major new show business publications. One was called Show and its founder was Huntington Hartford, noted art patron.
" Heresy in Red," a thirty-minute telecast about communism in Yugoslavia, will be shown over the American Broadcasting Company network next Tuesday at 10:30 P.M.

Earnings of the Detroit Edison Company are expected to equal about $2.80 a share this year, compared with $2.68 a share in calendar 1960, Walker L. Cisler, president, told a stockholders informational meeting yesterday in Detriot.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Eight student integrationists returned to the Anne Arundel County Jail today to resume their hunger strike after a Magistrate's Court appearance at which they requested jury trials.

Lee Higginson Corporation and associates are offering today $10,000,000 of 6 1/2 per cent convertible subordinated debentures of Transcontinental Investing Corporation. The debentures are priced at 100 and will mature in 1981.
The Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday it was introducing a new structural steel systems in an apartment house project to test whether they could reduce the cost of residential construction.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 20 -- A Canadian-American pair led the field of sixteeen pairs in the American Contract Bridge League's contest here to pick the next international team to represent North America for the world championship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy contributed today to a drive to raise funds for a permanent endowment of the Sam Rayburn Library at Bonham, Tex.
Decentralization of administration has been recommended to the Board of Education by a committee of top school officials.
A moist mixture of snow and rain fell on the city yesterday bringing the first sizable snowflakes since eary spring.

Maryland has accepted a bid to play in the Gator Bowl at Jacksonville, Fla., Dec. 30 -- provided it wins its final game -- and Louisiana State University has received an informal invitation to meet the Big Night Conference representative in the Orange Bowl.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 20 (AP) -- A member of a dance troupe from India, which has encountered segregation practices in the South, said today, "We wouldn't insult people if they visited our country regardless of their race."
Aircrafts were strong as a group yesterday in an otherwise flat and tasteless session of the New York Stock Exchange. Prices closed virtually unchanged.

The condition of anxiety impels men to act. Any action is more tolerable than paralyzing helplessness in the face of undefined and overwhelming catastrophe. We live in a world in which the threat of final catastrophe is thumped into us with each heartbeat, and the feeling of impotence irresistibly mounts.
Bowling is all a matter of the "right" approach -- placing the ball far to the right at the start, that is.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Supreme Court will decide later this term whether a witness in a state legislative inquiry may be forced to answer questions based on eavesdropping of his talks in a prison consultation room.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 20 -- An 11-year-old girl, the only survivor of the ketch Bluebelle, has indicated that other passengers were murdered by the captain.
ROME, Nov. 20 -- The Italian Government will demand greater security for its air force personnel flying in the Congo for the United Nations.

The United Federation of Teachers urged the city's teachers yesterday not to take part in a state-sponsored survey of school conditions here. It charged that the survey could result in a "complete whitewash" of the situation.

HERMAN GODES, Latvian-born pianist who made his debut here in 1953, gave his fourth New York recital last night at Town Hall. The composers he threw light on were Chopin, Debussy, Prokofieff, Schumann and David Burge.

Americans whose names appeared on the bows and sterns of the wartime-built Liberty ships are being honored throughout the country. Instead of going into the scrap yards with the rest of the shrinking fleet of Libertys, the plates bearing their names are being removed from the hulls and placed prominently in town halls and other edifices as permanent memorials.
Columbia University's basketball fortunes, which have been ebbing since the departure of sharp-shooting Chet Forte six years ago, seem destined to remain at low tide for another season.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Eleven Freedom Riders were convicted on appeal today on charges growing out of a bus depot lunch counter incident here last May.

There is an ebb-tide evidently at work in the matter of industrial price increases. This was indicated yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland in its latest monthly review. It comments that the "inflationary waves" accompanying each of the post World War II recoveries "have tended to become more moderate."

Once the news came through that he was missing at sea off the coast of New Guinea it would not have mattered too much who the young man was. Any nation that had ships and planes in that area and in those waters would have brought in all available help to try to find him and bring him safe to land. Yet the eyes of the world are on this distressing drama.
Steel production eased slightly last week.

The philanthropies of the Women's Guild of the Central Presbyterian Church will be helped by the proceeds of the group's tenth annual Christmas Bazaar. The bazaar will be given in the parish house adjoining the church at Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street on Nov. 29 and 30.
The 227,000 stockholders of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will receive an early Christmas present this year.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- Premier Khrushchev has set this price for the removal of the Communist-built wall through Berlin: a "general understanding" between West and East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- An inter-American investigating committee is to fly to the Dominican Republic early tomorrow to survey the situation there, considered here to be uncertain and dangerous.

With the Thanksgiving turkey yet to be roasted, a very international group of children received a foretaste of the next season, Christmas. The occasion was a visit to Christmas Village, U.S.A., at Stern's department store on Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Department of the Interior's proposed revisions in the import control program for crude and unfinished oils were turned over to the White House staff today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The United Nations approved by acclamation today a resolution urging the United States and the Soviet Union to work out immediately a formula for a body to negotiate general and complete disarmament.
FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Nov. 21 -- The wife of a New York banker was killed today and her husband was slightly injured when their automobile was in collision with a state police patrol car near here.

Trading in the shares of Unilever, N.V., a Netherlands company, and Unilever, Ltd., a British company, will begin on Dec. 12, on the New York Stock Exchange. Lever Brothers Company, a subsidiary of both companies, made the announcement yesterday in New York, adding that approval had just been received from the exchange.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 344,952 tons in the week ended Saturday, compared with 344,729 tons in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the 1960 week, output totaled 309,245 tons.
It is definite that Floyd Patterson and Sonny Liston will meet in a title match next spring if each wins his next bout, Tom Bolan, the boxing promoter, said yesterday.
Directors of the Commercial Bank of North America, whose head office is in Manhattan, and the Board of the Peoples National Bank of Brooklyn approved yesterday a plan to merge.

In basketball the best laid plans go for naught if one player fails to hit the hoop with ten seconds left or if a teammate steps out of bounds with the ball three seconds later. The New York Knickerbockers were guilty on both counts at the Garden last night.
There are twenty-seven shopping days left before Christmas, and department stores here will extend their selling hours to accommodate the expected crowds of shoppers.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange recommended yesterday increases in membership dues and initiation fees as part of a program to help defray the cost of a proposed new site for the exchange.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 -- Capt. Henrique Galvao, who has been involved in the seizures of a Portuguese ocean liner and an airliner in attempts to stir revolt against the Portuguese Government, grounded a French airliner here tonight as he tried to force Brazil to grant him refuge.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 21 -- A wild demonstration by joyful crowds shouting "Liberty! Liberty!" greeted the return here today of the principal leaders of the opposition to the former Trujillo dictatorship.

"What Price Coexistence?" an appraisal by Sir John Slessor of Western political and military strategy, will be published Friday by Praeger. Sir John, a Marshal of the British Air Force and a former Chief of the Air Staff, discusses the problems now facing the free world and relates the crucial issue of arms control to global strategy.

CUDDEBACKVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Sheriff Ernest Schoonmaker of Orange County and two hunting companions were found dead today in a three-room mountain cabin filled with deadly coal gas from a kitchen stove.
Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, announced yesterday the election of two of its partners as officers of other concerns.

MACY'S 35th annual Thanksgiving day parade will begin at 9:15 A.M. at Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street. The balloons will include Bullwinkle, the world's largest moose, who will be wearing a nineteen-foot grin; Popeye; the Dragon, and Gorgeous Gobbler.

IT was five years ago that Antonin Novotny, as First Secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party, began the public downgrading of his country's first Communist President, the late Klement Gottwald. M. Novotny declared that his party colleagues had sinned by crediting the Czech leader, who died in 1953, with "merits that belonged to the party and to the masses."
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 -- The Cross Westchester Expressway's directional signs, which have led many motorists onto wrong exits, will be corrected.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union served notice tonight that it would veto any proposal dealing with any phase of the Congo problem except "the colonialist intervention in Katanga."

TINKER BELL was dying. Peter Pan turned to the audience and said it was because so few people now believed in fairies. Would everyone who believed in them please wave his handkerchief and save her life? It was during one of Maude Adams' farewell tours and I was sitting in a theatre for the first time in my life.

GENEVA, Nov. 21 -- David A. Morse announced today his resignation as Director General of the 101-nation International Labor- Organization. Mr. Morse said he wanted "to resume the duties and responsibilities of normal citizenship" in the United States.

The resignation of David A. Morse as director general of the International Labor Organization deprives that important agency of a leader whose activities have benefited millions of workers in every part of the world. The imaginative programs of technical assistance he has initiated to help underdeveloped countries raise the productivity of their industries and farms has brought great advances in mankind's oldest war -- against poverty and despair.
The Southern Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $46,239,401 for the twelve months ended Oct. 31, compared with $45,997,216 a year earlier.

The American Football League's admitted secret draft of college players, held two weeks in advance of the announced scheduled date, Dec. 2, yesterday brought from Alvin (Pete) Rozelle, the commissioner of the rival National Football League, a thinly-veiled threat of possible retaliatory measures.

Sales of Royal portable typewriters for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 were the highest in any three-month period in the history of the Royal McBee Corporation, Allan A. Ryan, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel here.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Nationalization of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad has been listed among six possible courses of action for the line.
The Russian Nobility Association of America, Inc., will benefit from a gala dansant Sunday in the Carnaval Room of the Sherry-Netherland.

The Socialist party charged yesterday that Vice Admiral Robert Goldthwaite, commander of the Western Sea Frontier, was conducting "a virtual one-man crusade for right-wing extremism from coast to coast."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- V.K. Krishna Menon, who has irritated -- even angered -- United States authorities by his behavior as India's delegate to the United Nations, paid an extraordinary call today on President Kennedy.

J. Jay Frankel, the importer responsible for such successful Russian films as "Ballad of a Soldier" and the current "A Summer to Remember," is about to enter the distribution field with a series of new Soviet releases.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 21 -- A group of excited young football players from this North Shore area will invade the South tomorrow to participate in the annual Turkey Bowl game on Thanksgiving Day at Elizabeth City, N.C.

Elizabeth Bergner has requested to be withdrawn from "First Love," the Samuel Taylor drama now playing in Boston, because of ill health. Roger L. Stevens and Frederick Brisson have granted Miss Bergner's wish.

The State Division of Licenses has announced that it had found Martin Price of 81 Middle Road, Eastchester, N.Y., guilty of "untrustworthiness to act as a real estate broker." The bureau said it had revoked the real estate broker's licenses of three concerns for which he was representative broker.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain, although playing with a pulled neck muscle, led the Philadelphia Warriors to a 125-118 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Exchanges between Italy and Austria in the debate over Alto Adige took a sharper tone here today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Dr. Walter Kaufmann, associate Professor of Philosophy at Princeton University, has received one of the two Leo Baeck Prizes for 1961 from the General Council of Jews in Germany, it was announced here today.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved a City Council bill that would bar open fires on land within the city limits.

A woman landlord was arrested yesterday after four of her tenants testified in Housing Court that she had shut off their water gas and electricity and taken down the building's front door to harass them.
Cotton futures moved 40 cents a bale off to $1.20 up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Eddie Arcaro made his final trip of the season to Aqueduct yesterday, but not to ride. He visited the track to get ready for a tour of the Orient and a trip to Australia.
Notre Dame was not entitled under the rules to the extra play on which it kicked the field goal that defeated Syracuse, 17 -- 15, last Saturday in the season's most controversial football game.

WHEN Buff Donelli first assumed the monumental task of giving more bite to the Columbia Lions, he operated on the theory that his mission would be simplified if he could awaken a feeling of pride in his players -- pride in themselves, in their team, in their school and in their accomplishments.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors held its first concert of the season last night at Carnegie Recital Hall and had the excellent Manhattan Percussion Ensemble for a lively guest.

Since the Treasury bill rate moved up again at the regular weekly auction on Monday, there was no question yesterday whether or not commercial paper rates would follow. The only question was who would lead the way.
United States Government obligations scored fair-size price advances all along the line yesterday in a high-grade bond market that was marked otherwise by cautiousness of the dealers.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,018 personswere hurt by cars here last week. This was an increase of 151 compared with 1960.
OAKDALE, L.I., Nov. 21 -- Idle Hour, the former summer estate here of the late William K. Vanderbilt, will be the permanent campus for Adelphi Suffolk College.
The New York Rangers, unbeaten in their last five games meet the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden tonight.

A "sound salon" that sells stereophonic music systems costing $500 to $5,000 in setting of original paintings, custom-made furniture and deep carpeting was unveiled in Queens yesterday by a discount-store chain.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands-New Guinea, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Missionaries joined rescue parties combing the treacherous jungle marshes of the southwestern New Guinea coast yesterday in hope that Michael Rockefeller would be found alive.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) -- A floating museum, filled with Hudson Valley historical objects and paintings, sank in a dock here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Chemical company earnings next year are expected to be 15 to 20 per cent higher than this year, an executive of an industrial research company predicted yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Walter Tuohy, president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, told directors today the carrier was hopeful the Interstate Commerce Commission would approve the line's merger with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company "in the first half of next year."
President Kennedy has given the go-ahead signal to a campaign in support of his foreign trade program for 1962.

DAYTON, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Firemen battled early today to save the main headquarters command building of the Air Force Logistics Command from a blaze that razed a two-story annex to the three-story masonry structure.
The trustees of the New Haven Railroad announced plans yesterday to raise all commuter fares 10 per cent, effective Jan. 1.

The ketch Bluebelle, and her only survivor -- eleven year old Terry Jo -- have added another grisly chapter to the sanguinary history of the Spanish Main. To most Americans the Caribbean is a wind-flecked, sun-kissed sea of pleasure and romance; but the foundering of Bluebelle and the tale of horror unfolded from a hospital bed in Florida should recall its dark yesterdays.

The New York State Teachers Association urged the Board of Regents yesterday to concentrate on improving essay questions for examinations instead of attempting to develop "completely objective" tests.
Bill King, Dartmouth's versatile quarterback, engineered a last-quarter, 15-point scoring spree that gave the Big Green eleven a 15-14 victory over Cornell last Saturday.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- With buyers cautious, prices of both industrial shares and British Government stocks drifted lower in the stock market here today.
The Board of Higher Education denied a request last night by The National Review, a right-wing publication, for permission to present its forum series in Hunter College Auditorium.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 21 -- That General de Gaulle will be seventy-one tomorrow would be of no more significance than an occasion of protocol and esteem were it not for one awesome fact. This fact is simply that the pattern of France's imminent relationships not only with Algeria but with its own self and with the world depend upon the continued influence of his personality.

Leontyne Price sang but one performance of "Madama Butterfly" with the Metropolitan Opera last season. Illness delayed her appearance in the Puccini opera this season until last night. So this was only the second time that she had sung the part of Cio-Cio-San here.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov 21 (AP) -- Jay Mukerjea of India joined three Australian stars in the semi-finals of the South Australian tennis championship when he upset sixth-seeded Ken Fletcher, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Women Strike for Peace movement was born one hot morning last September in the quiet garden of a Georgetown home.
The 1961 international speed weeks scheduled for Nassau in the Bahamas have attracted the largest entry in the history of the eight-year-old racing classics.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 -- A Southern Association of Intelligence Agents has been established by state law enforcement officers to exchange information on "subversion" and other problems.

The City Council shelved yesterday a proposal by its minority leader, Stanley M. Isaacs, to outlaw the solicitiation or acceptance of campaign contributions by public officials or city employes from anyone having business dealings with the city.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor and builder, has contracted to buy the two-story office building with five stores at 47 North Village Avenue, Rockville Centre, L.I. John Kestenleffel is the seller.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 21 -- Four days of intensive search by air and on the ground along the border between Cambodia and South Vietnam have failed to show any evidence of Communist guerrilla bases.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The British Government is prepared to send a diplomatic team to Geneva next week to listen to anything new the Soviet Union has to say on a treaty to ban nuclear tests, officials said tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- Federal officials declared here today that all across the land there was unmistakably heavy support for medical and hospital care for the aged under the Social Security program.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The French Communist party has begun, tardily and apparently with some reluctance the de-Stalinization drive demanded by Moscow.
MIAMI, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The $2 daily-double ticket, the shining hope of all horse players hoping to get rich, will cost $3 at Tropical Park this season, the track announced today.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 21 -- A United States team of experts is expected here shortly to study conversion of the $500,000,000 United States military base complex in Morocco to peacetime uses.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion Ladewig, the 1957 and 1960 champion from Grand Rapids, Mich., led sixteen women into the finals of the world invitation bowling tournament tonight with a near-record total of 5,090 for twenty-four games.

When the Justice Department moved to enjoin the McComb police from interfering with bus company efforts to comply with the Interstate Commerce Commission ruling against segregation, lawyers said the case would affect law enforcement officers throughout Mississippi.
BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- The East German Communists said today that they had fortified their border wall in the center of Berlin with anti-tank barriers to preclude an outbreak of nuclear war.

ABOARD the U.S.S. GLACIER, off Antarctica, Nov. 20 -- The mighty Glacier, the Navy's largest, most powerful icebreaker, has smashed and cut her way to within seven and one half miles of her first destination on the Antarctic mainland.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- Yale and Harvard, fountainheads of American football, play for the seventy-eighth time here Saturday before an assemblage expected to exceed 60,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 21 -- Contaminated fuel and failure to use an emergency fuel valve were suggested today as contributing factors in the Nov. 8 crash of a nonscheduled airliner ferrying Army recruits to camp.

As New Yorkers prepare for family reunions and holiday festivity tomorrow, President Kennedy yesterday issued his first Thanksgiving proclamation, urging thoughts for persons "to whom hunger is no stranger."
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Britain will have to make her choice -- the Commonwealth or Europe -- at the outset of her negotiations for entry into the European Economic Community.
Mohawk Airlines defended yesterday its bid to operate the services of Northeast Airlines, should Northeast go out of business.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The Latvian nationalists ousted from high party and Government positions two years ago were reported today to be standing by their policies.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 21 -- Power revenues of the Tennessee Valley Authority for the three months ended on Sept. 30 were $58,688,000, representing an increase of $1,290,000 from those of the 1960 period, the T.V.A.'s quarterly report said.
Henry Fonda's next television special has been set for Tuesday, Feb. 6, on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Five of eight games in the fifteenth round of the world women's chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja were decided yesterday, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
The State of Ohio borrowed $30,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of major highways.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- The Department of Justice announced its opposition to rival Western railroad merger plans today at the completion of prolonged hearings over the future of the Western Pacific Railroad Company.
PERHAPS "Old-Fashioned Thanksgiving," presented on Channel 7 last night, was overstuffed with performers.
Special police details were assigned to four radio stations here last night to protect all or one of them against a possible seizure by Puerto Rican nationalists.
An organization set up here to get private investors to buy and improve slum tenements called yesterday for the resignation of one of its directors, David B. Solove.
GATHERED from California and Hawaii is a collection of resort clothes at Stern's that is sure to put thoughts of winter far away.

BIAK, Netherlands New Guinea, Wednesday, Nov. 22 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York reached this Dutch island off the northwest coast of New Guinea early today and was told by Dutch officials that extensive searching had revealed no trace of his missing son, Michael.

A 4 per cent across-the-board wage increase has been obtained by 500 licensed deck and engineer officers of American Export Lines, Edward J. Farr, secretary-treasurer of the Brotherhood of Marine Officers, announced yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 19 -- The fate of Colombia's involved political system appears to hang in the balance as the present legislative and Presidential election campaigns gain in intensity and bitterness.
The regional incidence of goiter, long attributed to lack of iodine in drinking water, has now been cited as being of infectious origin.

Helen Lightner, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, has been singing here for almost twelve years. Always she has been praised for taste and style, and those two qualities were again noteworthy on this occasion.
A $377,000 demolition contract has been let to clear the way for the completion of Brooklyn Bridge improvements and the expansion of the Manhattan Civic Center in the City Hall area.
Representative John H. Ray of Staten Island announced yesterday that he would not be a candidate for re-election when his present term expires at the end of next year.

The liquor industry has generated a considerable amount of gossip along Madison Avenue in recent weeks. Several major companies were reported to be looking for new agencies to handle their advertising. And, since the liquor industry is a prodigious spender on advertising, these reports have stirred great excitement.

Securities worth "several million dollars" and $68,000 in cash were found in the East Side town house of the late Mrs. Katherine Geddes Benedict during a recent inventory by state tax-appraisal clerks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Republicans have very little to be thankful for this year. The major elections in New York, New Jersey and Texas were a disappointment to them, and Governor Nelson Rockefeller's impending divorce is a far more serious blow than they are willing to admit.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Coast Guard, pursuing its investigation of the apparent mass killings aboard the ketch Bluebelle, dug deeper today into the strange career of its skipper.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 21 -- A waterfront strike was averted last night when the Puerto Rico Steamship Association and the International Longshoremen's Association reached agreement on a three-year contract.
The Transit Authority said yesterday it would try out lighter weight wheel assemblies under subway cars to see if it could save money on the original cost of equipment and operating it.
BEAUNE, France, Nov. 20 -- The 1961 Burgundy vintage will be the most expensive ever.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note, delivered today to the United States and Britain, accepting their invitation to resume negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear tests:
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 -- The Indian Communist party strongly assailed Communist China today for what India has charged is "further aggression" along her frontier.

New York University's basketball team has a new look this season. In contrast to past years, when almost the entire roster was made up of local talent, this year's group has a geographical representation that would do justice to an Ivy League unit.

The Metropolitan Opera Production Fund will benefit from the Sunday performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The event is being sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, and Mrs. Cecil M. Singer is benefit chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A self-styled "hillbilly scholar" from New Hampshire told a House subcommittee on un-American activities today that "I always regarded Stalin as an outstanding humanist."

WHAT Shaw imagined in "Androcles and the Lion," Slawomir Mrozek evidently experienced in the very act of writing "The Policemen." In combining these two works for its first production in its new location on East Seventy-fourth Street, the Phoenix Theatre last night arranged a natural companionship.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- The Central Committee of the Czechoslovak Communist party has ordered the destruction of the colossal monument to Stalin that dominates Prague. It has also ordered the renaming of all streets and enterprises that bear the late dictator's name.

There is no doubt that stocks, like people, can exert great charm on occasion, and this week and last American Telephone and Telegraph was winning many investors. In three of the last five trading sessions, the stock set historic highs, yesterday reaching a peak of 134 3/8. It closed at 134 184, up 3 1/8.
Six school construction employes pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of having accepted gifts and gratuities from contractors doing business with the Board of Education.

Louis Goldfarb has contracted to buy the four-story building at 273 First Avenue, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, from an affiliate company of Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc. The property, which is opposite Stuyvesant Town, contains a store and three vacant apartments.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 -- Charges of "misrepresentation" and "socialism" marked a verbal exchange in Town Hall here today between two doctors and Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- United States officials were surprised today by the Soviet acceptance of the proposal to resume nuclear-test negotiations, but they welcomed it.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- The Public Service Commission refused today to accept the Consolidated Edison Company's plan for a readjustment of its rates without further public hearings.
MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- A crop failure this year in the virgin lands of the Soviet Republic of Kazakhstan became a question of semantics today.

HANS SCHMIDT-ISSERSTEDT, known to American audiences only by reputation as head of the Hamburg Radio Orchestra, and also by a handful of phonograph records, was seen in the flesh for the first time in New York.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The Cunard Steamship Company's application to establish an international air service between Britain and the United States was denied today by the Minister of Aviation.
LIKE many of Washington's foreign residents, Frau Wilfried Platzer, despite her decidedly European tastes, has come to depend upon several distinctly American institutions.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Indonesia reopened talks today with five foreign oil companies aimed at converting the present 50-50 profits split to a 60-40 percentage in Indonesia's favor.
The triumphal visit of Queen Elizabeth to Ghana was in the best British tradition. It was also shrewd politics, which is likewise a good British tradition.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union accepted today the United States-British proposal to reconvene the Geneva conference on a treaty to end tests of nuclear weapons. The three-power talks will reopen next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Kennedy will grant his first exclusive interview to a Soviet news correspondent Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The security director of the National Security Agency has resigned at the request of the Defense Department, the Department announced today.

MADRID, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco and Portugal's President, Rear Admiral Americo de Deus Rodrigues Tomas, exchanged vows tonight to stand side by side in the defense of the Iberian peninsula against any attacks from outside.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Kennedy today ordered the Tariff Commission to investigate imports of cotton products -- everything from yarn and thread to cloth and clothing -- and to advise him whether added duty was necessary.
Most commodity futures prices showed small to moderate gains yesterday in generally light and dull trading on the New York exchanges.

The governors of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., appreciate the able and conscientious way in which the City Planning Commission, under the chairmanship of the Hon. James Felt, is fulfilling its purpose. Since Mr. Felt was a leader in real estate and, indeed, was a governor of our board when Mayor Wagner appointed him, we are especially proud of the contribution he is making.

DALLAS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The most interesting thing about team statistics in the American Football League is not the big yardage run up by Houston in leading the passing. It's the number of passes caught by San Diego in setting defensive records.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Foreign Minister Erich H. Louw of South Africa said today that his Government would invite three past Presidents of the General Assembly to visit South-West Africa and report on conditions there.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Speakers in the. General Assembly debate on colonialism discussed today five draft resolutions. The resolutions seek to implement last December's Assembly declaration on the granting of independence to colonial territories.

Those who still find it hard to believe that the National League will have a ball club in New York next year can rest comfortably. The New York Mets yesterday announced their 1962 spring training schedule.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation and the Chemetron Corporation, manufacturers of carbon dioxide used in rocket fuels, food refrigeration, and many commodities, pleaded no defense in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of criminal contempt.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Izzat el-Nuss will lead a new transitional Syrian Cabinet following the resignation last night of Premier Mamoun Kuzbari and four Cabinet Ministers, the Government announced today.

After long secret preparations to carry out a series of nuclear tests in the atmosphere while "negotiating" in Geneva on a treaty to ban nuclear testing, Soviet Russia has now started a move, unmatched in hypocrisy and brazen effrontery, to prevent the United States and Britain from carrying out any further nuclear tests of our own.

Three men and a woman were arrested last night in two raids in Brooklyn, where the police said they recovered large quantities of stolen goods and uncovered an arsenal that had been cached for use against the Gallo gang.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 21 -- Premier Theo Lefevre pleaded today with Flemish and Walloon citizens of Belgium to put aside their Dutch-French cultural conflict and to unite in building their common future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Cuba requested today an urgent meeting of the Council of the Organization of American States as well as of the Security Council on her charge of military intervention in the Dominican Republic by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg directed workers who have been on crippling strike at the nuclear testing site in Mercury, Nev., for two days to return to their jobs and "remain at work."
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 21 -- A three-judge Federal court declared unconstitutional today three Mississippi laws requiring segregation in transportation stations.
