UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Security Council arranged a meeting tomorrow to take up charges made by Cuba today that the United States was guilty of "aggression" against the Dominican Republic.
Stocks opened with a strong forward push yesterday, but the force soon went out of the drive and prices closed moderately lower on average.

HOUSTON, Nov. 21 -- The Canadian-American pair of Eric Murray of Toronto and Charles Coon of Boston retained the lead at the two-thirds point of the American Contract Bridge League's contest here to select an international team.

IF words are what you are buying in the theatre then the double bill at the Midway, which opened last night, is one of the biggest bargains in town. There are plenty of words in John Mortimer's two one-act plays, "What Shall We Tell Caroline?"
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Army officials expect to resume in January the program in which volunteers are accepted directly into the reserve forces after six months of active duty.
Irving M. Engel announced yesterday he was resigning as chairman of the New York Committee for Democratic Voters, the central organization of the Democratic reform movement in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued at the State Department today on the Soviet agreement to resume negotiations for a treaty to ban nuclear tests:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- Rodman S. Reed Jr., vice chairman of Marsteller, Inc., an advertising agency, was killed last night in a collision between his automobile and a street car. He was 57 years old. No one else was injured in the crash.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- Two West German students from Heidelberg University are to go on trial here tomorrow on charges of having spied for the United States. Foreign newsmen have been invited to attend the proceedings.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) declared yesterday a special dividend of one share of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) stock for every sixty shares of Indiana Standard held. In addition, the regular quarterly cash dividend of 35 cents a share was voted.

A Roman Catholic priest who aroused a controversy by declaring that a man had a moral right to protect his family's fallout shelter from invasion, by force, if necessary, said yesterday that he would not apologize for his view.

The police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Waterfront Commission yesterday investigated the disappearance of seventeen bales of woolen material, valued at $29,243, from Pier 84 at the foot of West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A special committee has been appointed to acquire works of eighteenth and nineteenth-century American artists for the White House.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation announced yesterday the purchase of 150,000 shares of common stock in Granco Products, Inc., maker of FM radio receivers. A year ago, Emerson and Granco entered into an agreement whereby Emerson received a five-year option to purchase 540,000 shares of Granco common stock, which would be a controlling interest.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- An American pilot for the missionary Aviation Fellowship, Betty Green, flew low yesterday over the crocodile-infested swamp areas where Michael Rockefeller might have landed. She used a missionary-owned Cessna light plane to make the unsuccessful search.

AMONG the lesser-known prizes available to New Yorkers are mussels, known in France as the poor man's oyster. Throughout the winter months they are relatively plentiful at first-class fish markets here and the cost is relatively low.

Stockholders of several of the country's largest banks received good news from board meetings yesterday -- extra dividend declarations. Directors of the third largest bank, First National City of New York, yesterday recommended a 2 per cent stock dividend for their shareholders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The State Department described as "regrettable" today snubs administered in Southern cities to members of a touring dance team from India. The department said that apologies had been offered the troupe.
A pony-tailed young mother with an ingenuous air and a misty voice is, surprisingly, the leader of a group of New York women organized against war, nuclear tests and fall-out shelters.
The Board of Education last night appointed Charles F. Preusse, former City Administrator, as a consultant for four months.
A new reduced rate "no frills" passenger service between Miami and northern East Coast cities was proposed yesterday by Riddle Airlines.
PARIS, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- An early resumption of Algerian peace talks was forecast tonight with Mohammed Ben Bella, the insurgent leader who is now held by the French, participating as a free man.

WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Some two miles along the main trail leading around the back of Whiteface Mountain there is hunting of a high and distinguished order being done. The hunter has a faultless technique and his execution is perfect.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 21 -- The new $750,000 Hillspoint Road Elementary School was closed today to permit the completion of work on the elimination of alleged safety hazards.
WARSAW, Nov. 21 -- Poland has been buying substantial quantities of wheat abroad, presumably to cover shortages caused by a suspension of United States shipments.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Selling pressure slackened considerably in the grain futures trade today and prices rebounded broadly in all commodities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 ( AP ) -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's Thanksgiving proclamation, issued today:

MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Florida State Racing Commission today reaffirmed its rule banning the use of the controversial drug Butazolidin and horsemen threatened not to enter their thoroughbreds for the Tropical Park opening on Thursday.

HONOLULU, Nov. 21 -- In Honolulu, a sort of supermarket of tropical delights, opinion is pretty evenly divided as to whether things are just too good to be true, so watch out, or whether things will just get better and better and better, for ever and ever.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 21 (UPI) -- A Titan rocket was fired 5,000 miles tonight in a successful test of a special nose cone.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A group of Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews stood in the shady rose garden of the White House today and shook hands with President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Leroy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, reappointed today eight members of its Freedom of Information Committee and appointed four new members.
GENEVA, Nov. 21 -- The seven nations of the European Free Trade Association agreed here to speed up their schedule for cutting tariffs in their trade with each other.
The election of Frank C. Ross, vice president of the Ridgewood Savings Bank, Queens, N.Y., as president of the Savings Bank Life Insurance Council was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer agreed today that there should be negotiations with the Soviet Union on Berlin, but that the extent and terms of these negotiations should be precisely defined in advance.

Sales and earnings of the Singer Manufacturing Company set records for the three and nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to figures announced yesterday by Milton C. Lightner, chairman, and Donald P. Kircher, president.
I was glad to see your Nov. 19 editorial "Moscow's Finnish Crisis." Your last sentence is no overstatement: "The weather ahead looks dark indeed" for the Finns.

Unbeaten Alabama was picked yesterday as the No. 1 college football team of the nation by The Associated Press' panel of sports writers and broadcasters in the wake of Texas' defeat by Texas Christian.
The Gotham Bowl made a bid yesterday to bring about a rematch of Syracuse and Notre Dame at the Polo Grounds on Dec. 9.

The election of R.T. Parfet Jr. as president and general manager of the Upjohn Company, 75-year-old pharmaceutical manufacturer with headquarters in Kalamazoo, Mich., was announced yesterday. The change will be effective Jan. 1.

Robert F. Wagner as Mayor has often and justly been criticized for lack of leadership in solving the problems of New York City. But his Nov. 7 election victory seems to have removed any self-doubts as to his leadership capacity.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 21 (UPI) -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said today that he had abandoned plans to speak at a conservative political rally in Garden City, L.I., on Nov. 30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- One of the tools of the Immigration and Naturalization Service is a confidential "back check" file. This system keeps tabs on the whereabouts of recent immigrants to the United States, filed under their point of origin.
Green Bay's Bart Start, the passer, and Cleveland's Jimmy Brown, the rusher, seem to get better and better as the National Football League season progresses into its final month.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Richie Guerin and Johnny Green led a spirited New York attack tonight as the Knicks downed the Syracuse Nationals, 110 -- 109, in a National Basketball Association contest at Boston Garden.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, NOV. 22 (UPI) -- The Interior Minister of the Congo was reported today to have cited "negligence" by the United Nations as one of the reasons for the recent massacre of thirteen Italian airmen.
Dr. Margaret Mead. the anthropologist, posed this question yesterday: Is school necessary?

HOUSTON, Nov. 22 -- The bridge team that will represent North America in the next world championship tournament wil consist of Eric Murray of Toronto and Charles Coon of Boston; G. Robert Nail and Mervin Key of Houston, Lewis Mathe of Los Angeles and Ron Vanderporten of Oakland, Calif.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Ceylon asked today that the smaller countries be given an equal voice with East and West in disarmament talks.

IN "Assembly,"* John O'Hara's new collection of short stories, the reader encounters three groups of characters: (1) The country club yet middle-class set, multi-married and adultery-prone: (2) the "plain" people, made more ordinary, who are adultery-minded; (3) the theatre-movie crowd, just prone.

The eight-story and penthouse office building at 139 Centre Street, southwest corner of Walker Street, has been bought by Fischer-Landis, realty investors. Containing 90,000 square feet of space, the building was occupied until recently by the Navy.
Dr. W.E.B. DuBois, one of he nation's best-known Negro historians and sociologists, has joined the Communist party at the age of 93, the party announced yesterday.
The Federal Maritime Commission will hold a hearing in Washington on Dec. 12 to rule on whether steamship conferences have the right to ban or limit brokerage paid to freight forwarders.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In many varying ways and by many raucous voices we are being told that this is a time for leadership -- a time in which the President has failed us by faltering indecision.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- President Kennedy urged the Civil Rights Commission today to compile a record of progress in the last century on assuring equal rights for all citizens.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A series of tornadoes in Texas today killed a woman, injured nine persons, and caused widespread damage.

Donohue Co., insurance brokers, have leased most of the eighteenth floor at 15 William though Charles L. Goldenberg and Ira M. Koerner, assistant vice presidents of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent for the building.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 23 -- Both Japanese Government officials and cotton goods manufacturers have expressed strong dissatisfaction over the step taken by President Kennedy asking the United States Tariff Commission's opinion on the advisability of imposing an additional tax on cotton product imports.

MIDLAND, Tex., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Westbrook Pegler, the columnist, married Maud Towart of Cannes, France, today in St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. T.J. Kennedy performed the ceremony, which was witnessed by about sixty persons.
First National Stores, Inc., will pay some $20,000,000 for the New York division of Safeway Stores, Inc., which it acquired Oct. 7.

WARSAW, Nov. 22 - Wladyslaw Gomulka delivered a stinging attack on Albania today, denouncing her Communist leaders as "trouble-makers" whose anti-Soviet arrogance threatened the unity of the Socialist camp.

FULTONVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- A University of Buffalo student was killed and three were injured late today when their car rolled over in a ditch along the New York Thruway, four miles west of here.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge H.H. Grooms granted a motion today to quash service in seven libel suits against The New York Times. The suits stemmed from articles alleging a climate of racial terror.
Thanksgiving Day, a holiday compounded of faith, hope and festivity, dawns today with the promise of plenty and a remembrance of the less fortunate.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Coach Ben Schwartzwalder of Syracuse University was selected by the Mayor of Chicago today for a special sportsmanship award because of his conduct in last Saturday's controversial football game with Notre Dame.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 22 -- By midnight of Nov. 30, when the 1961 harness-racing season ends, some 5,000,000 fans will have poured about $400,000,000 into the pari-mutuel machines at the two local raceways, Yonkers and Roosevelt.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The proposal to merge the colony of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya was endorsed today by the British Government and Tengku Abdul Rahman, Prime Minister of the Federation.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 22 (AP) -- About 3,000 employes of the Carrier Corporation rejected today continued representation by the United Steelworkers Union. Instead, they placed their confidence in the Sheet Metal Workers Union by a margin of 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Kennedy announced today the creation of a Freedom From Hunger Foundation to work with the United Nations in an effort "to eliminate hunger and malnutrition from the earth."

Count Risque of the Grandview Stables was overlooked by the crowd of 19,165 players at Aqueduct yesterday. As a result, the son of Count of Honor slipped along on the rail in the closing phase to seize the victory by a length and three-quarters over the heavily favored Kid From Spain.
Four pedestrians were struck by an automobile yesterday and were injured -- two critically -- at a busy intersection in Jamaica, Queens.
ROME, Nov. 22 -- The second International Conference on Political War of the Soviets called on anti-Communist organizations today to unite and wage an ideological and political war against Moscow.
Sales of the nation's electric utilities for the first three quarters of 1961 rose by 4.7 per cent in energy volume and 5.3 per cent in dollar volume from the levels of the 1960 period.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 22 -- A letter that Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd of South Africa was reported to have sent to one of that country's leading Jewish lawyers has been widely interpreted here as an attempt to put pressure on Israel by threatening South Africa's Jewish community.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 22 -- The Illinois Legislature approved a Congressional reapportionment plan today despite protests that the Chicago suburbs were being unfairly represented.

With tomorrow the first day for issuance of notices of intention to deliver on December cocoa and Brazilian coffee contracts, trading yesterday in those commodities was up and prices off. All exchanges here are dosed today, in observance of the Thanksgiving holiday.
Cotton futures moved 75 cents a bale up to 70 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Princeton has so often been one of the best football teams in the Ivy group over the past decade that its success is taken for granted.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 15:
DALLAS, Nov. 22 AP) -- Joe Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, early today canceled the secret draft of the A.F.L.

MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Thursday, Nov. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller reached this administrative capital of the southern region of Netherlands New Guinea today and reconnoitered by air the desolate swampy coast where his son Michael is missing.
The copying of men's clothing styles by women -- which some men believe got its start when Eve took a fancy to Adam's choice of fig leaves -- is picking up new momentum in the shirt industry.

CHICAGO, Nov, 22 (AP) -- The E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and Christiana Securities Company filed a memorandum in United States District Court today objecting to some provisions of the Government's proposals for du Pont's divesting itself of stock it holds in General Motors Corporation.
Word has reached here of the rescue last Friday of eleven men stranded on an ice floe when their plane was forced down in the Arctic Ocean.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Dorland and Mr. and Mrs. William G. Costin will entertain guests Wednesday at the Dorland home at 755 Park Avenue.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- East German workers and border guards put in extra shifts today to install new fortifications along the wall that divides Berlin. A new barbed-wire fence was raised along a 200-yard stretch on the bank of the Spree River.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Coach John Bateman of Rutgers is looking for a four-leaf clover. He believes that a little luck along with good football may win for his team against Columbia in their important clash here on Saturday.
ORONO, Me., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The University of Maine completed an unbeaten season and won the Yankee Conference championship today by defeating the University of Massachusetts, 10 -- 7, today.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 22 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen began today a two-day journey to Novosibirsk to plead Finland's case with Premier Khrushchev.
POINT ARGUELLO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- America's first secretly launched satellite soared aloft today from the naval missile station here. It probably was a Samos reconnaissance model.

The Northrop Corporation showed a 20 per cent increase in sales in its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 29, but earnings were little changed from a year earlier. Directors, however, voted yesterday to increase the quarterly dividend 25 per cent.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Apparently it has not yet occurred to the liberal element of the East that it has been embarked for some years now on a campaign to destroy the freedom of assembly of the First Amendment.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22 (AP) -- New Jersey has worked out the method that 150,000 of its citizens are to use in paying the new commuter income tax. It will require no cash, just the taxpayer's signature.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- The United States appeared today to have settled amicably a problem with India over sugar shipments.
Financing in the form of three mortgage loans amounting to $7,165,000 has been announced on three new apartment buildings in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Pentagon issued instructions to the military departments today emphasizing the right of reservists to win deferments and exemptions from active duty for reasons of family hardship.

Lincoln Was the "Thankfullest" Lincoln by weight of evidence was the thankfullest President, though Franklin D. Roosevelt with his twelve successive Novembers in office issued the greatest number of Thanksgiving proclamations.
A flurry of year-end dividends, including extras, increases and stock distributions, announced yesterday promised a Christmas bonus for thousands of stockholders.

AFTER being prodded for years to adopt the Italian or the British look in his clothing, the American man can take satisfaction from the fact that he seems to have created some fashion impact of his own.
DETROIT, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The Thanksgiving holiday will cut this week's car production to 125,910 units, down 18.4 per cent from last week's 154,366 units, Automotive News said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Abraham B. Magil of New York, a former foreign editor of The Daily Worker, the Communist newspaper, refused today to say whether he would support the United States if it were attacked by the Soviet Union.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Julian Harvey, captain of the death ship Bluebelle, showed no remorse when he told a rescuing tanker crew of the sinking that took five lives, it was reported today.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 22 -- President Joaquin Balaguer told an observation team of the Organization of American States today that his Government was in control of the tense Dominican situation and had the support of the armed forces.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 22 -- Jomo Kenyatta, African nationalist leader, provided an example today of how swiftly times are changing in Africa.
President Kennedy will "star" in a half-hour telecast about football on the American Broadcasting Company network Tuesday, Dec. 5.

There are many reasons for not being thankful today. There always have been such reasons. Those who sat down to the first American Thanksgiving feast more than three centuries ago had to remember those who had died of hunger and disease in the preceding winter. Lincoln's Thanksgiving Proclamations came in the sad days of a Civil War when there had been victories but also many thousands of battle deaths.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The police said tonight that the body of Louis M. Vidal Jr., missing New York business man, had been found in a crude grave. He had been shot at least four times in the head.
Loans totaling $26,500,000 were extended yesterday in Washington to Ethiopia, India and Pakistan.
Paterson, N.J., borrowed $3,217,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Ministry announced today that the Royal Dutch Navy search for Michael Rockefeller has been abandoned after four days as useless. Other searched continue.
MIAMI, Nov. 22 (AP) -- "We will race," Saul Silberman, president of Tropical Park, said late today on the eve of the scheduled start of Florida's thirty-second winter horse racing season.

" BACKLANE CENTER," a somber survey of Jewish stress and strain in suburbia, opened true to the traditions of Yiddish melodrama at the Folksbiene Playhouse last night. It will be given Saturday nights and twice on Sundays.
The Long Island Rail Road has sold its station and 1,400 feet of right-of-way in Bayside, Queens, for a real estate development above the tracks of its Port Washington branch.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today concluded its public hearings on the reopened trans-Pacific route ease. It gave attorneys until Dec. 18 to file briefs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Syracuse University today accepted an invitation to be the host team in the Liberty Bowl football game here Dec. 16.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Presidents of the United States in the past have included foreign press correspondents in the very few exclusive interviews they have given, and these rare journalistic items have been published in full and generally reprinted.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 -- The President of the Los Angeles County Medical Association today branded as "socialism" the entire Social Security system. He charged the Administration with trying to socialize medicine.
The Yankees have their Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris, and Fordham's basketball team will also have a pair of formidable M. and M. boys this season, Jim Manhardt and Bob Melvin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The broadcasting of horserace information useful to illegal bookmakers could result in the loss of a station's license, the Federal Communications Commission reminded radio and television interests today.

A young myth was tacitly but vigorously exploded by the New York Football Giants yesterday. Their many-faceted workout at Yankee Stadium constituted pragmatic denial of the popular conception that they need only to throttle Jimmy Brown in order to beat the favored Brown eleven in Cleveland on Sunday.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Nov. 22 -- The Floral Park Indians, a group of youngsters who participate in the Long Island Midget Football League, will play two games in Massachusetts this Saturday and partake of New England hospitality.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Delta Air Lines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to operate nonstop jet flights between New York and Miami during the winter tourist season.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Mr. Carlino and Mr. Dallago jointly declared tonight that there was no impropriety in the relationship between Mr. Carlino and the company.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Dr. James Van Allen and seven University of Iowa physicists have taken issue with Dr. Willard F. Libby's nationally syndicated series of articles on how to survive atomic attack. They call it "extremely dangerous."
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- The World Council Churches is mounting a full-scale attack on the word "proselytism'' and all that it connotes.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Neues Deutschland, East Germany's main Communist newspaper, removed a long article today in praise of Walter Ulbricht, the East German party's leader, after its appearance in the first edition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to let Continental Air Lines put in effect its proposed jet economy service. It plans a complete investigation first.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board asked local service airlines today to re-examine their route structures and propose elimination of weak points.
Mme. Nonna Gaprindasvili clinched first place in the women's world challengers' chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja yesterday, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Defense Department ruled today that reservists who had finished their military obligations and asked exemption from active duty must resign.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21 -- Thirteen years after the Arab-Israeli war, neither Arabs nor Israelis have officially conceded a single point that might lead to a formal solution of the Arab refugee problem. Despite this, the stagnation of United Nations Relief and Works Agency camps has been relieved in recent months by a few flickers of hopefulness.

Chancellor Adenauer came to Washington at a time when a new era must begin for West Germany. A watershed has been reached. The Federal Republic is no longer a defeated power, no longer a passive participant in European affairs, no longer safely controlled and led by the towering, domineering figure of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
Oil producers and refiners increased their operations last week, while inventories of major products declined slightly, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Republican leaders in Long Beach, L.I., have moved to have the election of a Democrat to the City Council voided. They contend that, contrary to the state Constitution, he had not resigned as city Judge before the campaign.

Last night, on the eve of Thanskgiving, fifty-one provisional members of the Junior League of New York were honored at the league's thirteenth annual Debutante Ball at the Plaza. Proceeds of the fete will go to the organization's welfare trust fund.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced yesterday that an affiliated company had completed a major oil discovery in the Persian Gulf off the coast of Iran.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Don Ellis, a 33-year-old professional from Houston, used a perfect 300 game tonight to protect his lead in the finals of the fifth annual world invitation bowling tournament at McCormick Place.
BOURNE, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Navy submarine chaser and an American Refining Company tanker collided at the eastern end of the Cape Cod Canal early today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A cotton advisory committee recommended today that the Department of Agriculture seek changes in the present cotton control program for 1963 and subsequent years.
The New York Titans will seek to improve on their won-lost record of 5 -- 5 today in an American Football League game with the Buffalo Bills at the Polo Grounds. Kick-off time is 11 A.M.
Duke Ellington and his orchestra have appeared here so rarely in recent years that it was a particular pleasure to hear them at Town Hall last night.
HONOLULU, Nov. 21 -- In Hawaii, tourism and sugar cane are year-round industries and so is politics.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will try to convince President de Gaulle at their meeting this week-end that the time to negotiate with the Soviet Union is now.
Two large commercial banks in Canada have reported record growth for the 1961 fiscal year ended on Oct. 31.
IN "A Man for All Seasons" Robert Bolt has written a play that is luminous with intelligence and steely with conviction.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- Two West German university students pleaded guilty today to charges of spying for the United States. They told a Soviet military court that they had accepted an assignment from alleged United States agents only because they wished to fulfill a dream of visiting the Soviet Union.
Dave Hoppmann, Iowa State back today nursed an injured ankle and a slim lead in the race for major college football's total offense championship.

THE voters have had their say. As is the case in every election, the will of the voters is final. The announcement was made yesterday that Frank Robinson of the Cincinnati Reds had joined Roger Maris of the Yankees as the most valuable player in his league. Robbie won easily, which is as it should have been.
LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The faculty of Washington and Lee University has criticized its trustees for disapproving a possible speaking bid to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Government's plan for the establishment of a national economic development council suffered a setback today when the Trades Union Congress resolved to put off a decision on whether to join.
Sears, Roebuck Co. announced yesterday record sales and earnings for the first nine months of its fiscal year and record dividends for its full fiscal year.
The New York Rangers extended their unbeaten string to six games and regained first prize in the National Hockey League by blanking the Detroit Red Wings, 4 -- 0, at Madison Square Garden last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- There were signs today of a new era in relations between two of Asia's most populous countries, India and Japan. Much closer economic cooperation, if not greater rapport on international affairs, between the two countries was expected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The United States must ease its trade restrictions and work closely with other free nations if it hopes to preserve Western civilization, a Congressional study paper advised today.
Two firemen were killed last night as a five-alarm fire burned in the sub-basement of the Times Tower. Smoke poured through the building and into Times Square for hours.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The New Jersey State Department of Health today endorsed and adopted as its own a policy of the American Public Health Association on birth control.
United States Government obligations of intermediate and long term extended Tuesday's price gains yesterday. Otherwise the high-grade bonds marked time.

ALONG with the joys of the approaching holiday season, there often lurks some apprehension on the part of many a hostess in anticipation of unexpected guests, including small children, who must be made welcome and served quickly prepared snacks or impromptu meals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- President Kennedy received today the University of Notre Dame's Laetare Medal as the outstanding American Roman Catholic layman of 1961.
While many of the stock price-earnings ratios are healthier than they were a year ago, many investors wonder, "How high is high for stocks?"
BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- King Saud of Saudi Arabia arrived today by let plane to undergo surgical and medical tests at Peter Bent Brigham Hospilal.

Classes were dismissed early at Riverdale Country Day School yesterday, and a fine, sunny autumn afternoon beckoned. But instead of going out for basketball or other sports, a team of sixty-four boys spent the first part of their Thanksgiving holiday earning money to bring an African student to their school next year.

Men hid from their dogs and only women and children were allowed to compete at an unusual field trial in Fairfield, Conn., last Sunday. The event was the sixth of its kind conducted by the Nutmeg Field Trial Club.

Voters in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx will undoubtedly be proud to learn that their Representative, Charles A. Buckley, kept this year his secure grip on first place in Congressional inactivity. No member of the House was absent more often when issues were brought up for roll call.
A real estate syndicator whose operations have been suspended by the state was fined $150 in Housing Court yesterday. He had been fined $325 in ten building cases last week.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Halvard M. Lange, Foreign Minister of Norway, who has had blunt talks with Soviet leaders, reaffirmed today the loyalty of his nation with the Atlantic alliance.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22 -- The chief flight engineer of the nonscheduled airline whose plane crashed Nov. 8 while transporting Army recruits today discounted the idea that the two right-side engines had stopped because their tanks had run out of gasoline.

Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino acknowledged last night that he had received fees, both as a director and as a lawyer, from Lancer Industries, Inc. The concern has a wholly owned subsidiary, Lancer Survival Corporation, that says it is the largest manufacturer of glass fiber bomb and fall-out shelters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The State Department announced today the appointment of William J. Tonesk, a 55-year-old career diplomat, as deputy chief of protocol.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Civil War Centennial Commission was called on today to assemble Dec. 4 to pick a new chairman.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 22 -- A rare Buddhist painting, portraying the Green Dolma, highest ranking goddess of the Tibetan religion, has been presented to the Yale University Library.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board moved today to test whether a union may fine members who produce more than the union has set as a quota.

Production of electric power climbed for the sixth straight week, reaching 15,678,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compared with 15,520,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 14,435,000,000 kilowatt hours in the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Justice Department filed suit today to prevent state officials from blocking desegregation of bus and railroad facilities in Alexandria, La.

GRANDMOTHERS are mothers who have time. Time for a toddler to dawdle through his lunch. Time for a 3-year-old who answers the telephone. Time to linger in front of a toy store window or a zoo pond while the sea lions cavort.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- In 1932 John D. Rockefeller Jr. gave a seventy-two-bell carillon to the University of Chicago as a memorial to his mother, Laura Spelman Rockefeller.
A suit to block the sale of an East Side luxury apartment house to the Soviet Government was started in Supreme Court yesterday by the buyer of a cooperative apartment in the building.

A maritime labor and management group has asked the Governors of fourteen Eastern states not to subsidize the railroads in a "predatory rate-cutting campaign which has already nearly eliminated the nation's domestic merchant marine."
MCMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 21 -- Bacteria left in Antarctica by the historic expeditions of Scott and Shackleton have been found still alive after nearly half a century.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press) -- Final plans for the fifty-one story Victoria Square project have just been submitted to city authorities and construction is expected to begin in January, a spokesman for the Place Victoria-St. Jacques Company said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- The most grateful American movie workers this Thanksgiving are probably in Rome, which seems to have become the great magnet for American-made or American-financed movies.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 22 -- A pair of Long Island collegiate football rivals, with identical records of 6 -- 2, will meet tomorrow when Hofstra plays host to C.W. Post College of Brookville.

The Maidman Playhouse, an intimate showcase with a seating capacity of 199 at 416 West Forty-second Street, has been leased for a year, beginning Dec. 4, to Burritt Productions Inc. John Wulp, playwright-director-designer-magazine editor, is the president of the group.
The Philips Electronics and Pharmaceutical Industries Corporation is expanding its activities in the chemical field.

Max J. Rubin returned yesterday to Morris High School in the Bronx and stood on the same stage where he once urged classmates to participate in the student government and to root for the school's football team.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Swing will retire Jan. 1 after almost eight years as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The National Grange declared today that increased farmer bargaining power was a basic requirement for a sound farm program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued today by President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer:
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 22 -- A meeting of conservatives scheduled here next week has been canceled by its sponsors because Joseph McD. Mitchell, the City Manager of Newburgh, has refused to speak.
EVEN at Thanksgiving, some women tend to panic about Christmas. The secret of bringing off the Yuletide without a slip and being able to enjoy it, too, lies in organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A Department of Defense official told the House Small Business subcommittee today that compliance with Government oil import regulations had cost the military a "demonstrable" $20,000,000 since April 1959.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- A new "quick-firing" Atlas missile hurled a nose cone and a 500-pound package of simulated atomic fuel cores 5,000 miles through space today in a spectacular test success.
Robert Levinson was co-broker with William C. Walker Sons, Inc., in the recent purchase by Louis Goldfarb of the building at 273 First Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Though dead almost ten years, Stalin has again stirred the world. His final desanctification by his expulsion from the Lenin Mausoleum has been the object of world-wide comment. But in the excitement of seeking the practical implications of Chairman Khrushchev's move one significant phase of the issue has escaped notice.
Housing experts said yesterday that a major housing problem in the city was to get nonwhite families who were improving their income to move to middle-income housing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Cyprus, Indonesia and India proposed today that Italy and Austria designate a third party to help them find a means of settling their dispute over the province of Alto Adige.
Frank Robinson, crack outfielder of the Cincinnati Reds, yesterday was named the winner of the National League's most valuable player award for 1961 and with that there can be very little quarrel.
Aircrafts, rubbers and electronics were weak on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. But tobaccos and nonferous metals mostly rose, and the market averages closed with modest losses.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A strike against the seven private bus lines here on Dec. 1 appears "inevitable," a union leader said yesterday after meeting with company officials at the City Labor Department.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 22 -- The Ceylonese Government plans to introduce a sliding scale of export duties for rubber next Sunday.

The Teachers Union, which has been banned from all official dealings with the Board of Education since 1950, will be recognized as bargaining agent for all teachers if it wins the collective bargaining election next month.

THE Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra ended its third American tour with a concert last night in Carnegie Hall, this time playing under the direction of Karl Boehm. He had taken over the leadership of the distinguished ensemble for its last two weeks in this country for Herbert von Karajan, the regular conductor, who was heard here with the orchestra in two earlier programs.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Prices continued to decline in the stock market here today.

The Indian Communist party's statement assailing Communist China's territorial encroachments against India has a significance going far beyond the immediate issue. By publicly indicating that they believe Communist China is guilty of aggression against India, the Indian Communists have laid themselves open to the charge from Peiping that they are putting Indian national interests ahead of the international solidarity of the world Communist movement.
Seymour Gang, former confidential secretary to Charles J. Bensley, a member of the recently deposed Board of Education, was clared of possible perjury yesterday by a New York County grand jury.

LONDON, Nov. 22, -- Britain's industrial production showed a marked drop in September, the latest month for which figures are available, but the Government is confident that it will soon show an improvement.
Wall Street's so-called "Levy Committee" is about to begin direct questioning of members of the American Stock Exchange and other interested parties on the exchange's organization and procedures.

MADRID, Nov. 22 -- Rear Admiral Americo de Deus Rodrigues Tomas, the President of Portugal, is on a four-day state visit to Spain at a time when Portugal believes herself increasingly abandoned by her Western Allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, principally by the United States.

BARNEGAT, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Members of the Daughters of the American Revolution have been urged by the society's National Defense Committee not to buy Christmas cards sold by the United Nations Children's Fund.
Drivers and helpers employed by 450 private sanitation companies will vote tomorrow night on whether to empower their union to call a strike at midnight Nov. 30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer have hammered out a negotiating position on Berlin and agreed on additional military steps to back up this position.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 -- A former 16,300-deadweight-ton tanker sailed out of the Bethlehem Steel Company's yards today as jumbo-class vessel of 25,000 deadweight-tons.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Liquidation for the Thanksgiving holiday quickly canceled moderate gains in grain futures prices in the final minutes today and left the market mostly weak.

There are Republicans in the South -- to be exact, they cast 24 per cent of the vote in thirteen Southern states in the last Congressional elections. They are not increasing by leaps and bounds -- in 1952 the percentage was 20 -- but they give grounds for the hope that a two-party system may finally develop.
Justice Jacob Markowitz of the State Supreme Court refused yesterday to compel arbitration in a jurisdictional dispute involving two unions and The New York Times.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Cuba asked the Security Council today to condemn the United States as an aggressor and to demand the withdrawal of its forces now stationed off the coast of the Dominican Republic.
The Sanitation Department was to have opened bids yesterday for contracts to help it remove snow during any heavy snowfalls this winter -- but by the 5 P.M. deadline, no bids had been received.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Rod Laver and John Shepherd today earned the right to meet the powerful Australian doubles team of Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson in the final of the South Australian tennis championship.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 22 -- If a horse is like an elephant, Adios Butler will never forget the occasion of his formal retirement.
The Duro-Test Corporation is considering a stock split in connection with a possible bond issue to finance expansion, Walter H. Simpson, president, announced at the annual meeting yesterday.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 22 -- President Kennedy came home tonight to celebrate a Thanksgiving 340 years and forty miles removed from the original.
CLARKSDALE, Miss., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Mayor W.S. Kincade has refused to back down on a decision prohibiting two Negro bands from taking part in the Christmas parade Dec. 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Council of the Organization of American States heard in silence tonight Cuban charges of United States "armed intervention" in the Dominican Republic and the reply that this accusation was "a new low of irrelevance, hypocrisy and slander."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 -- The Yugoslavs are convinced that there will be no early truce in the current struggle for position between the Soviet Union and Communist China.
STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 23 -- President de Gaulle exhorted France's professional soldiers to unity today and asked them to dispel illusions about the chances of keeping Algeria French.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -- The better-red than-dead school was taken sharply to task here today by a leading American churchman.
TWENTY-THREE enamels by Doris Hall are currently on display in the window and showroom of Maslow Freen, 146 East Fifty-sixth Street.

The cheery Thanksgiving tidings from Michael J. Quill are that two million bus riders may have to do their Christmas shopping without buses after present union contracts on the private transit lines expire Nov. 30. Since Mr. Quill holds the championship for threatening strikes that do not occur, there is reason to hope that this disruption of normal riding will not actually materialize to mar the holiday season.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd has told South Africa's large Jewish community that his Government has never been anti-Semitic and that he wants no anti-Semitism in his ruling Nationalist party.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Hunter's Rock, a Maryland-bred 3-year-old owned by Mrs. Henry Obre of Monkton, Md., defeated older rivals with a late bid in the $30,550 Dixie Handicap at Pimlico today.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex. Nov. 23 (AP) -- Eldon Moritz place-kicking and the running of Jack Collins, Jim Saxton; Mike Cotten, Jerry Cook and Tommy Ford crushed Texas A. and M., 25 -- 0, today and sent the University of Texas football team into the Cotton Bowl.
NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 23 -- A healthy survivor of the blight that struck the New England textile industry a generation ago has embarked on a recruitment program to insure its economic future.
BELGRADE, Nov. 23 -- The United States informed Yugoslavia today that it was again ready to negotiate the sale of surplus American foodstuffs to President Tito's independent Communist regime.

Robert D. Thomas has been named sales of the manager trade sales division of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company. C.J. McCrory, former manager of truck tire sales, has succeeded Mr. Thomas as tire sales manager.
NEWARK, Nov. 23 -- The Barringer High School eleven made a tremendous fourth-period effort and gained a 7-7 tie with East Orange before 12,000 spectators at Schools Stadium today.
City Councilman Stanley Isaacs is quite right in referring to the proposed 10-cent rise in taxicab fares as "scandalous."
Americans at home and abroad savored the joys -- and the flavors -- of Thanksgiving Day yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Noranda Mines, Ltd., announced today it had arranged to purchase 600,000 shares of the outstanding stock of Placer Development, Ltd., for $15,000,000, or $25 a share.

An increasing number of New York youngsters, who formerly reserved Saturday afternoons for the neighborhood movie, are now devoting that time to the gentle art of judo. One of Japan's most successful exports, judo is the classic art of turning the strength of the strong against itself.
Because Johnny Bookman displayed the fastest fingers since Louie The Dip, the New York Titans preserved a 21-14 victory over the Buffalo Bills at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

ALBANY, Novv. 23 -- Keith S. McHugh, New York State Commerce Commissioner, reported today that the state's record of labor stability in the fifteen years through 1960 was one of the most important aspects of its climate for business growth. He made his report in the November issue of Business in New York State, a bi-monthly publication of the State Commerce Department.
ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Nov. 23 -- The Elizabeth City's Boys Club romped to a 4-5-0 victory in midget football's Turkey Bowl game here with a Locust Valley, L.I., Boys Club team.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An Air Force transport plane carrying ten men crashed and burned near Whitehorse today. The Air Force said five men were reported dead, two were missing and three were injured.

Kurt Steiner, a former member of the French Foreign Legion, won the fifty-first Coney Island handicap walking race yesterday. He covered the ten-and-a-half-mile course through Brooklyn streets in 1 hour 55 minutes 4 seconds.

BRASILIA, Brazil, Nov. 23 -- Announcement of the formal renewal of relations between Brazil and the Soviet Union caused an uproar in the Chamber of Deputies and immediate trouble for the Government today.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said last night that Mayor Wagner had asked him to become Deputy Mayor.
BOSTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Coach Doug Harvey's long scoring shot with eighteen seconds remaining gave the New York Rangers a 4-3 comeback victory tonight over the last-place Boston Bruins.
A porter attempting to rescue some cleaning women on the upper floors of the Times Tower was the third casualty of a fire that billowed smoke over Times Square for several hours Wednesday night.
The two biggest oil tankers in the world have become bigger.
The American Jewish Congress said yesterday that twenty-one states had passed anti-discrimination laws this year -- more than in any other year.
MIAMI, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Terry Jo Duperrault knew for certain today that her family did not survive the mysterious sinking of the yacht Bluebelle.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Two teen-agers were jailed here today on charges of stealing an airplane.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Hofstra, one of the perennial terrors of the small-college football set, completed another glowing season today by trouncing C.W. Post College of Brookville, L.I., 24 -- 6.

AFTER the almost mandatory overindulgence of the Thanksgiving repast, it seems doubtful that housewives be going on any extended grocery-shopping sprees this weekend. Perhaps for this reason things are generally quiet local food markets, with little evidence of the usual banner headlines advertising supermarket "specials."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee unanimously called today for further Italian-Austrian negotiations over the Italian border province of Alto Adige, which the Austrians call South Tyrol.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 23 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has announced that since 1937 tax payments by T.V.A. and the retail distributors or T.V.A. electricity, to state and local governments, have increased "at a faster pace, percentagewise, than similar payments by private power companies throughout the nation."

Men and women students from at least seven Eastern colleges paraded in front of the White House yesterday in a silent fast and vigil to protest the resumption of nuclear weapons testing. They were a small but earnest symbol of a small but active ferment on college campuses across the land.

Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel in a cablegram yesterday hailed the American labor movement, "which brought strength and encouragement" to Histadrut, Israel's labor federation, and to the development "of our country as a whole."

THE high-hatted, red-coated man who whipped the Macy parade line into proper order and gave the signal that started it yesterday, Edward Armitage Hill, began life as a proper Bostonian. He is still quite dignified and reserved, and so reticent that many in his social circle don't know that he directs the parade, and most of the paraders know him only as a very efficient organizer who demands precise timing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The diplomatic equivalent of a battlefield promotion is being planned for Allan Charles Stewart of Arizona, now counselor of the United States Embassy in Venezuela. He will become the ambassador there.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The brilliant passing of two quarterbacks, Beau Carter and Jon Anabo, helped Fresno State College upset Bowling Green University, 36 -- 6 in the Mercy Bowl football game before 33,145 fans today.
Velocity of demand deposits rose to new peaks in October, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Overlook Hospital situated on the highest point in Union County, has adopted a nautical method for proclaiming its motto far and wide.
At least eight of those killed in yesterday's plane crash in Brazil lived in the New York area or had close ties here.
HONOLULU, Nov. 23 -- Five years of labor peace on the waterfront seemed assured in Hawaii today.
A prisoner ate $83 in a Brooklyn station house yesterday. When he finished, a patrolman gave him a glass of water to wash it down.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Earl Stoudt, an all-Southern Conference halfback, ended his college football career by scoring four touchdowns today as he led Richmond's Spiders to a 36-18 victory over William and Mary's Indians.
TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 -- Huddled in a corner of a mud-walled, dirt-floored hut in the village of Kutyan in southeast Iran were two women and three or four children.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A meeting of the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Use of Outer Space has been set for 10:30 A.M. Monday in the face of a Soviet threat to boycott the group.

Suburban residents and businesses will be asked to contribute at least $1,500,000 toward the $30,000,000 that the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts still needs to reach its fund-raising goal of $102,000,000.
New York University is using Federal funds to try to develop a "mathematical yardstick" to measure the usefulness of public housing and other projects in reducing juvenile delinquency.
FOR the umpteenth time in 3,000 years, Greece has been discovered again. But the gladness of her hospitable citizens and their friends is tempered with apprehension.

WHEN Paul Brown, the resident genius of the Cleveland Browns, was coaching at Ohio State almost two decades ago, his beardless wonders of the wartime years were involved in a free-scoring game with the still unshaven youths from Illinois. They were tied at 26 -- 26 when the Buckeyes went through with the final play of the afternoon, a plunge that was smothered at the line of scrimmage.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Within its borders Tanganyika harbors the two extremes of terrain on the entire African continent. They range from the permanent ice-cap that tops Mount Kilimanjaro, at 19,340 feet, to the bed of Lake Tanganyika, second deepest of the world's inland seas.

MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen of Finland arrived in the Siberian city of Novosibirsk today to confer with Premier Khrushchev on the Soviet demand for military consultations between their countries.

A national organization of home improvement contractors is planning to set up ethical standards to govern the promotion and sale of family fall-out shelters. The organization is the National Established Repair, Service, Improvement Contractors Association, known as Nersica.

This year's virgin lands grain harvest in Kazakhstan was "wrecked," Premier Khrushchev has charged. His choice of words was ominous. At the height of Stalin's power in the Nineteen Thirties "wreckers" were put on trial and shot, or sometimes shot without the formality of trial. Is Premier Khrushchev thinking of emulating his repudiated master and exacting blood sacrifices for the debacle of declining grain production in Kazakhstan for the last three years?
New York City's school reform is heading for dangerous waters.
Retailers who advertise toys at prices below the usual advertised ones don't always have enough stock to justify their ads, the Better Business Bureau warned consumers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Qualified sources said today that the United States would support an increased and invigorated military build-up of the Atlantic alliance in Europe.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 23 -- A 4-year-old girl with a sensitive nose and strong teeth saved her family from possible death here early today.
People said prayers of thanks in churches and synagogues here yesterday, and at some services the thanks-giving crossed religious lines.
HAVANA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Cuban Government, backing down in the face of an international complaint, withdrew today restrictions that it had imposed four weeks ago on the right of diplomatic asylum.

Production of lumber in the nation dipped to 219,132,000 board feet last week from 220,891,000 board feet the week before, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago, output came to 213,309,000 board feet.
MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Stock Exchange announced today fifteen issues would be removed from trading on the exchange at the close of business tomorrow.

The NAFI Corporation had profitable operations in the third quarter in contrast to a loss a year ago. The diversified company's nine-month results well exceeded those of last year, according to the report issued yesterday by John G. Bannister, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Now that the Pentagon authorities have taken steps to emphasize the right of reservists involuntarily called to active military duty to enter pleas for deferment on the ground that their service would inflict "extreme personal or community hardship," the way has been cleared for a test of the basic purposes of the call-up.

MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Friday, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- Australian helicopters stood by today to search New Guinea swamps for Michael Rockefeller, but hope of finding him alive has been virtually abandoned.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 23 -- By coincidence the three pairs that won places on the new international team last night have the same ideal geographical distribution that the American Contract Bridge League, tried to achieve in former years when it selected the teams arbitrarily.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The National Council of Teachers of English called today for an all-out fight against a wave of "book burnings" throughout the nation.

Events today: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Josef Krips, conductor, Shura Cherkassky, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale, duo-pianists, Town Hall, 8:30.
The Rogers Peet Company, which operates a chain of five men's clothing stores, is acquiring H. Harris, New York custom tailoring establishment. The purchase price was not disclosed.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 23 -- An Argentine Comet jetliner bound for New York plunged into a eucalyptus plantation early today shortly after taking off. All fifty-two persons aboard were killed.
The New York Knickerbockers and the Los Angeles Lakers will meet for the first time this season tonight in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Red Kelly scored three goals to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at the Chicago Stadium.

A difference of opinion is agitating the League of New York Theatres and the Dramatists Guild. It hinges on the contention of the guild that its members are entitled to their royalties on the remission of the 5 per cent city tax on tickets to Broadway shows.

AN eminent group of both artists and sitters is assembled in the exhibition "Official Portraits of Yesterday and Today," at Portraits, Inc., 136 East Fifty-seventh Street. It starts at the top with Boldini's portrait of Whistler, a wonderful image of the aging wit and dandy, a mixture of pathos and panache.
MOSCOW, Nov 23 -- A high Soviet tribunal sentenced two West German students today to twelve years' imprisonment on espionage charges.
PARIS, Nov. 23 -- If there were ghosts walking anywhere in Paris today, they were over at Harry's New York Bar.

FEW intellectual achievements of this century are more interesting or more significant than the discoveries of the archaeologists that have done so much to increase our knowledge of ancient and prehistoric eras. "In the dark backward" when written records were few or nonexistent the epochal events that rocked the world of our remote ancestors were just as important to the long story of the human race as those which convulse mankind today.

HOLLANDIA, New Guinea, Friday, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Royal Dutch Navy today rejoined the hunt for Michael Rockefeller. But Governor Rockefeller was reported to have abandoned in Merauke his personal search for his son.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 23 -- President Kennedy said today he was giving a recess appointment to Bernard L. Boutin of Laconia, N.H., as administrator of the General Services Administration.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Ray Westendorp of Cornell and Tim Burns of the Buffalo State Athletic Club broke the course records today in winning the fiftieth annual road races.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics Association notified Mrs. Constance Wolf of Blue Bell, Pa., today that her Texas-to-Oklahoma balloon flight this week set fifteen women's world records.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Richard Cardinal Cushing called on historians today to broaden the scope of their teaching in an effort to end petty nationalism in the Americas.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 23 -- President Kennedy relaxed with his family this Thanksgiving Day. The high point was dinner at 6 for thirty-three, or as many of the group as had reached turkey-dining age.

The nation's business, scientific and governmental organizations "waste" some $1,250,000,000 a year in duplicating the research and development work already completed by other groups. But because of the enormous bulk of written material that must be investigated to determine if a problem has already been solved, it is often cheaper and faster just to often it over again.

IN the last few hours of Thanksgiving Day, the American Savoyards served up "The Vagabond King" at the Jan Hus House. The Savoyards have given us moments to be thankful for, but this is not one of them.
A proposal for an industry-wide arbitrator to direct labor-management grievance machinery has been made by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A spokesman for aluminum importers said today that the aluminum industry's recent proposal for international agreement on the volume of aluminum trade was "a device designed to eliminate the only effective price competition on aluminum products in the American market."

ERIE, Pa., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Joe De None of Geneva College passed for one touchdown and scored another today to lead the East to a 21-12 victory over the West in the fourth annual Gem Bowl all-star football game before 3,500 rain-soaked fans at Erie Stadium.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser, on the come-back trail following a knee operation, blasted his way into the men's final of the South Australian tennis championships today by beating the Wimbledon champion, Rod Laver, 7 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

Joe Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, vehemently criticized Harry Wismer here yesterday and indicated that he would attempt to oust the president of the New York Titans from the league.

Lawrence Fertig Co. and Lennen Newell, Inc., will form a new affiliation as of Jan. 1. The Fertig agency will bring into the affiliation some $8,000,000 in billings from National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. The announcement confirms a report that appeared in this column early this week.
MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Third-period goals by Phil Goyette and Claude Provost tonight earned the Montreal Canadiens a hard-fought 5-3 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
The International Business Machines Corporation has announced the appointment of two of its executives to additional responsibilities.

I read with great interest the Nov. 15 letter of my old friend Prof. Frank Tannenbaum in which he asserts that the voting in the U.N. General Assembly on the resolution for a moratorium on nuclear testing, without controls, "means that on a basic question of policy in the cold war the great powers are isolated from the vast majority of mankind on both moral and political grounds."
"Biography of a Bookie Joint," the story of national crime into specifics and in general, will be televised by "C.B.S. Reports" next Thursday.
IN the Nineteen Twenties Willa Cather's sober fiction was overwhelmed by the showmanship of Sinclair Lewis and Ernest Hemingway.
The New York City Office of Civil Defense has embarked on a policy of "aggressive evaluation" of its job in view of "the complex survival requirements imposed by the H-bomb and missile era."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- High-ranking officials said today that they believed East-West negotiations on Berlin would start early next year as a result of the talks in Washington this week between President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- President Kennedy was accused today of having made the same kind of charge for which he had criticized "extremists."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 23 -- A Defense Ministry spokesman said tonight that the Dutch Government had "gladly accepted" an offer of the United States Navy to put an aircraft carrier, patrol planes and other vessels into the search for Governor Rockefeller's missing son, Michael.

Assemblyman Mark Lane charged last night that, despite statements to the contrary, Lancer Industries, Inc., stood to gain under the fall-out shelter bill passed by the Legislature in a special session early this month.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Ray Bluth defeated his St. Louis doubles partner, Dick Weber, and the defending champion, Don Carter, today as he maintained his lead in the fifth annual world invitation bowling tournament.

The struggle, underground, between the Allied and enemy intelligence services during World War II is the subject of "Burn After Reading," which Walker will issue on Dec. 7. The author is Ladislas Farago, former Chief of Research and Planning in the United States Navy's Special Warfare Branch, who collaborated with Admiral Ellis M. Zacharias in "Behind Closed Doors."

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The British Government refused today to bar further nuclear tests or refrain from supporting tests by others, presumably the United States, pending conclusion of a test-ban treaty with the Soviet Union.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Six New York University students began fasting and picketing outside the Governor's mansion here today. They were protesting racial segregation in Maryland, where segregated restaurants have been under heavy fire in recent weeks.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- Soviet military authorities detained the United States Army's West Berlin-Frankfurt train for almost fifteen hours today on the border between West and East Germany. The train and the eighty Americans aboard were allowed to proceed only after a 20-year-old East German was taken from the train and turned over to Soviet officials.

Oil Royalty, the home-bred filly owned by Max Gluck, pleased the long-shot players and the Darby Dan Farm's Primonetta disappointed the favorite fanciers in the $28,500 Firenze Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics scored 11 straight points early in the third quarter tonight and then coasted to a 119-106 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors before 8,125. The Celtics trailed, 59 -- 55, at half-time.
The residents of Greenwich Village have won another skirmish in their battle to keep motor vehicles out of Washington Square Park.

Most thoughtful analysts of the current wiretapping chaos will fully concur, I believe, in your editorial statement of Nov. 17: "If the Federal prohibition on tapping is to be relaxed at all, it is extremely important to retain controls of the kind Senator Thomas J. Dodd proposes, at the very least."

Twenty years ago, the Dana Perfume Corporation ran a reproduction of a painting called "The Kreutzer Sonata" in an advertisement for its Tabu perfume. The painting was a romantic affair showing a man holding a violin and passionately kissing a young woman in front of a piano.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The fall registered in Britain's industrial production in September, and the setback to the Government wage "pause" policy by the pay award in the nationalized electricity industry continued to dominate the stock market here today.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Washington and Lee rallied for a 33-20 victory, over Washington University of St. Louis today and gained its first all-winning season since 1914.

THE more leather comes into fashion, the better business will be for Marjorie Lehmann. She and her husband are owners of Leathercraft Process of America, where a woman may call and find out what to do when she has spilled egg on her new suede suit; whether she can dye a leather coat, or if her twenty-five-year-old alligator bag is worth having revamped along 1961 lines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- George Meany, announced today that he had invited six business leaders to the labor federation's national convention starting Dec. 7 in Miami Beach.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The English legal profession disciplined a leading practitioner for professional misconduct today.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Ken Reeder, a halfback, who had caught twenty-four passes this year, threw one today for a touchdown that enabled the Virginia Military Institute Cadets to gain a 6-0 victory over Virginia Tech in rain.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower last night urged officers of the armed services to shun partisan politics.
A Brooklyn lawyer interested in sandlot football yesterday offered 20,000 free admissions for a football game to the city's youth groups.
The Bohemia Stable's Kelso was named the horse of the year yesterday for the second consecutive year in the twenty-fifth annual poll conducted by Triangle Publications, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Many sculptors are indignant because Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall wants to move another statue out of town.
GHARDAIA, Algeria, Nov. 23 -- A new belt of barbed-wire defenses around this oasis shows that the Algerian drama is engulfing the Sahara.
AS the heavy pre-season traffic rolled down the New York State Thruway Wednesday night, a good many city-bound cars sported the evidence of successful hunts.
BAUMHOLDER, Germany, Nov. 23 -- Like millions of other Americans, the officers and men of the Third Armored Cavalry Regiment took time out today to commemorate Thanksgiving Day.
MANCHESTER, Conn., Nov. 23 (AP) -- John J. Kelley won the Manchester five-mile road race today, beating 137 other male entrants and three women who ran unofficially.

MERCURY, Nev., Nov. 23 (UPI) -- The battleground of union jurisdictional fights that virtually halted the nation's nuclear testing program for three days shifted today from picket lines to a national board.
What with unpacking, getting ready for his appearance in a parade and later preparing for dinner with friends, Casey Stengel had a busy day yesterday.

Having already earned his spurs in the Wagnerian wing of the Metropolitan Opera, Sandor Konya staked out a claim in the Italian wing last night. He sang the role of Dick Johnson in the season's fourth performance of Puccini's "La Fanciulla del West."

An Icelandic physician has found an association between stomach cancer and the consumption of smoked salmon, mutton and trout, according to a report in today's Journal of the American Medical Association.
Most people believe that where there's smoke, there's fire. Firemen know it isn't so.
HONOLULU, Nov. 21 -- Business men in the islands of Hawaii are worrying about signs of trouble in three of the state's chief industries -- sugar, pineapple and tourism.

Two milestones are being reached at St. John's University this season. Joe Lapchick is entering his fiftieth year as a basketball player and coach and the Redmen will unveil their new $4,000,000 athletic plant.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Ava Song, in front from the quarter, had little in the way of serious competition tonight in the first-division final of the Fall Series Class A Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

Joseph F. Carlino has shown the bad judgment of getting his private business as a lawyer in Nassau County mixed up with his public business as Speaker of the New York State Assembly. There is just enough of the appearance, if not the substance, of conflict of interest to raise a question in the public mind.
Latter-day Richard Henry Danas are spending two years before the mast on a training ship that has become the pride of the Swedish merchant marine.

MIAMI, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Gordian Knot, a 30-1 shot, outran Pundit in the stretch and scored a head victory in the $12,100 Hurricane Handicap as Tropical Park opened Florida's winter racing season today.
Increased office leasing by a Manhattan real estate concern in October and November is regarded as an indication that the business recession is over.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In the Kennedy-Adenauer conversations, the President and the Chancellor talked for over thirteen hours, much of it alone. Accordingly, the vaguely worded communique, the official briefings and even the official indiscretions may not tell the whole story.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- St. Louis University defeated Rutgers, 6 -- 1, and West Chester beat Bridgeport, 2 -- 0, today in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate soccer championship.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers mounted two touchdown drives in the rain and mud today and took firm command of the National Football League's Western Division lead with a 17-9 victory over the Detroit Lions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A plan aimed at helping young men who are rejected for military service because of poor health was announced today by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
The Gotham Ball was held last night at the Plaza.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 23 -- The Congolese soldiers who murdered thirteen Italian airmen have apparently left Kindu, where the massacre occurred, and headed for Katanga Province.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Carmine Diadamo, a substitute quarterback, scored twice and directed Colgate to a 30-6 football victory over Brown today. The Bruins concluded their worst season ever, losing all nine games.

INCLUDED matter-of-factly in any number of dishes throughout the year, among them rice and tapioca puddings and custard pudding and pie, nutmeg really comes into its own during the winter holiday season.
Fourteen foreign students, specializing in social work, learned here yesterday how a major American philanthropic organization administers social welfare.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Bruce Kidd of Toronto showed a liking for a hilly course and sloshed through the mud in 32 minutes 2.6 seconds today to win the Amateur Athletic Union's national 10,000-meter cross-country championship.
SEATTLE, Nov. 23 -- A worldwide program of entertainment, with 704 performances packed into a six-month period, has been drafted for the Century 21 Exposition opening here next April 21.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- In 1939 some faculty members at the University of California at Los Angeles decided that listening to chamber-music records at one another's homes periodically was no substitute for live music. So every so often they paid a group of musicians to play chamber music in one of the larger homes.
MALVERNE, L.I., Nov. 23 -- The Philadelphia No. 1 team defeated New Atlantic, 2 -- 1, today as play opened in the United States Field Hockey Association's national tournament.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Diplomatic sources predicted today that Prime Minister Macmillan would try to overcome French resistance to Britain's entry into the European Economic Community in his talks with President de Gaulle this week-end.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 23 -- Mobs sacked homes and stores of members of the family of the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina today. The armed forces occupied the capital to stop the looting.
The "Tree of Life" gift wrapping paper introduced last year by the United States Committee for Refugees is now available through the committee and at bookstores.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of "subordinating" the International Atomic Energy Agency to serve American "political and military interests."
DELAWARE CITY, Del., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The forty-five-foot power yacht Duchess hit a jetty in the Delaware River tonight and partially sank in shallow water about six miles south.
Clinton defeated Monroe, 19 -- 6, yesterday and earned the right to meet Brooklyn Tech for the Public Schools Athletic League football championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The Soviet Union contended today that there was evidence that "colonialists' agents" had been responsible for the recent killing of thirteen Italian airmen in the Congo.
Delighted youngsters -- and their elders -- from New York and vicinity began their celebration of Thanksgiving yesterday by jamming the sidewalks to watch Macy's annual parade.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, called yesterday for a "frontal attack" on racial discrimination in labor unions.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Claude (Butch Harmon Jr. made two second-half touchdowns today to load New Rochelle High to a 14-0 victory over Iona Prep at McKenna Field before 12,000.
The "Tree of Life" gift wrapping paper introduced last year by the United States Committee for Refugees is now available through the committee and at bookstores.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Robbers re-enacting a television movie entitled "The Perfect Hold-Up," seized jewelry valued at $1,000,000 from a fashionable shop today and fired upon onlookers with a submachine gun. The police seized the gang and the loot in half an hour.
Yesterday might just as well have been an extension of the Thanksgiving Day holiday so far as the high-grade bond market was concerned.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 24 -- The Town Board announced today that it had approved the application of a builder to construct five garden apartment units here.
