NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Rutgers and Columbia have been gridiron opponents since 1870, when they began intercollegiate football's second oldest rivalry, but it is doubtful whether any of their meetings meant as much as their thirty-fourth encounter tomorrow.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- Japan said today that she hoped that the question of discrimination against her under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade would be settled at next week's session here of trade ministers.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, said yesterday that he did not believe there was any "real prospect for reorganizing the bankrupt company unless (a) its passenger service is abandoned or (b) its passenger service is subsidized."
FOR some mysterious reason, Josef Krips never conducted the New York Philharmonic at one of its regular concerts before this week.
Poland, like any other country that has been exposed to the television virus, is finding that the medium rapidly grows to epidemic proportions.
MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 24 -- Hundreds of natives searched through 150 miles of swampy jungle shore today for some trace of Michael Rockefeller.

FROM any standpoint -- technique, musicianship, program-making -- last night's Town Hall concert by Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale deserves a place among the exhilarating events of the musical season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The chief financial officer of the Hughes Tool Company, said today that possible futher financial needs of Trans World Airlines might limit Hughes Tool's ability to give further help to Northeast Airlines.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy was ordered in Supreme Court yesterday to reinstate the hack license of a cabby who had a fight with an airport guard last spring.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Twelve more leading defense contractors have agreed to sign White House "plans for progress" designed to give Negroes and other minorities equal access to jobs and promotions.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 22 -- The Congo, moving from one crisis to another, has a new one in Stanleyville, where a flood has robbed the city of electricity and water services and has caused concern here, particularly among United Nations officials.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24 -- The largest crowd to attend a collegiate football game in the East this fall is expected for the seventy-eighth meeting of Yale and Harvard in the Yale Bowl tomorrow. The kick-off will be at 1:30 P.M.

The verbal scrimmage between Joe Foss, the commissioner of the American Football League, and Harry Wismer, the president of the New York Titans, continued yesterday, with both sides trying to play offense.
The Bates Manufacturing Company of West Orange, N.J., manufacturer of office accessories, has bought the one-story building at 1 Central Avenue in that city.
Stocks ended an uneventful week yesterday with a small gain. Steels, aircrafts, electronics and tobaccos were firm and no major group showed general weakness.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Ray Bluth of St. Louis built a lead of almost 6 Petersen points today in the fifth annual world invitation bowling tournament before a crowd of 2,600.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 24 -- The Kennedy Administration was reported today to have decided on a civil defense policy that would emphasize community fall-out shelters over shelters for individual families.
Active dealing in cocoa futures was a feature of commodities trading on the New York exchanges yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Labor party leader, severely criticized the Government today following reports that the United States had obtained a copy of a confidential document giving Britain's position in her negotiations for membership in the Common Market.
TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Japan has sent a petition to the United States Administration not to impose a surcharge on cotton textile imports.

A GAY and impish joy came to television last night. The presentation of Tyrone Guthrie's production of "H.M.S. Pinafore" was one of the most delightful specials that TV has known in this or earlier seasons.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons, who used to play out of Fort Wayne, returned tonight and beat the St. Louis Hawks, 142 -- 135, in a National Basketball Association game before 5,140 fans.

The United States and the United Nations have been backing the Leopoldville Government's attempts to force Katanga into a centralized union run from Leopoldville. If we could put Humpty Dumpty together again it would be fine. We ought to stop trying.

The gloomy Dr. Malthus predicted over a century and a half ago that population would inevitably outrun the food supply, and that therefore it would be impossible in the long run to improve the lot of mankind. What we have clearly today is not a sharp decrease in the world's food supply per capita, but an increase crippled by poor distribution, plus a rapidly approaching crisis of population expansion.

The "African Carnival 1961" last night opened a series of seven performances over the week-end at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the African Research Foundation.
Golden ribbons held together the garlands of yellow chrysanthemums and smilax that adorned the Plaza's Grand Ballroom for the first of this season's Junior Assemblies last night.

I am repeatedly amazed to read in the American press that ex-President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico is still "vastly popular" here, as C.L. Sulzberger wrote in The Times on Nov. 13 -- an opinion echoed in your editorial next day. As one who has resided in Mexico continuously for the past six years and writes constantly about the country, I have been unable to discover the "vast popularity" your distinguished reporter found.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 24 -- The possibility of an early settlement of Laotian political troubles faded today with the collapse of efforts to arrange a meeting in Vientiane of the Princes who lead the three rival factions.

"Operation Hanukkah," staged by the National Jewish Welfare Board, will take next weekend's Festival of Lights to members of the faith who are in the armed forces.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 24 -- New Jersey's Governor-elect Richard J. Hughes will discuss a possible diplomatic appointment for Gov. Robert B. Meyner at a meeting with President Kennedy next Wednesday. Mr. Hughes succeeds Mr. Meyner in January.
ERNIE KOVACS went into orbit on Channel 7 last night and, as usual, he made the avant-garde German moviemakers of yesteryear look rather stodgy.
MIAMI, Nov. 24 (AP) -- George Mira and Bill Miller sparked the University of Miami football team to a 10-6 victory over Northwestern tonight before 46,282 fans in the Orange Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Both the railroad and trucking industries reported today increases in freight loadings last week above the 1960 levels. However, rail carloadings were below the level of the preceding week, while truck loadings were unchanged on the week-to-week basis.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 24 -- President Kennedy announced today five appointments to the advisory board of the Commodity Credit Corporation. Those selected are:

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Roy Emerson and Neale Fraser, the Wimbledon doubles champions, won the South Australian doubles title today by defeating Rod Laver and Jim Shepherd, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 24 -- Irvin Paul, owned by Charles King of Hamilton, Ohio, and Abraham Wilsker of Yonkers, scored a length-and-a-quarter victory over Stormy Dream tonight in the mile-and-a-quarter Long Island Handicap pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway.
Highway deaths continued to climb yesterday as the Thanksgiving week-end reached the halfway point.
Football historians will delve into antiquity if Rutgers and Harvard should be returned winners today on the last full program of the intercollegiate season.

It seems to me that your editorial of Nov. 18 under the heading "That $2 Million Rembrandt" contains an unjust reproach. A people which has an unparalleled record for contributing to charities, research and sharing its resources with the under-privileged all over the world hardly deserves to be accused in bookkeeping terms for using its wealth to acquire a cultural treasure which is free for everyone to enjoy.
GEORGETOWN, Colo., Nov. 24 (AP) -- An avalanche roared down a ski slope late today and killed a University of Colorado student.
A woman landlord, accused by her tenants and city aides or using a fire as an excuse to force the tenants to move, asked yesterday that her case be transferred from Housing Court to Special Sessions.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Heinrich von Brentano told the Parliamentary group of the Christian Democratic Union today that its unity was essential to safeguard the fundamental principles of West Germany's foreign policy.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- The General Assembly, acting over the protests of the United States, adopted two resolutions today opposing the use of nuclear weapons.

Fire Department officials were still trying yesterday to determine the cause of the smoky fire in the Times Tower that took the lives of two firemen and a porter Wednesday night. All three were aspyhyxiated while attempting to rescue others.
TRENTON, Nov. 24 -- Mr. Hughes' efforts to obtain a diplomatic post for Governor Meyner will be watched with interest by political leaders and observers here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- The Security Council authorized the Acting Secretary General tonight to use force if necessary to arrest "mercenaries" and other foreign military and political advisers serving the Katanga provincial government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A mathematician has patented for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., New York, important principles of a rocket guidance system that has already operated without a failure in more than sixty firings. The entertainment committee of the Harvard Club of New York has moved firmly to defend the good name of Yale.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had a police guard tonight as he spoke at a civil rights meeting at the Murat Theatre here.
YONKERS, Nov. 24 -- This city is having so much trouble finding homes for families displaced by slum clearance that it may buy two old tenements to house some of them.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of the United States lost, but Lisa Lane, also of the United States, gained two draws yesterday in the women's world challengers chess tournament at Vrnjacka Banja, according to a report from Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The population of the United States will reach 185,000,000 at 3 P.M. Thursday, the Census Bureau estimated today.
The world's first commercial ship powered by an atomic reactor, the Savannah, is expected to undergo her first fuel loading some time next week, it was reported yesterday.
Two New Jersey longshore union officials are expected to be sentenced for contempt on Wednesday, the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor said here yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 24 -- John F. English, the 35-year-old Nassau County Democratic leader, said today he would prefer to continue in the post rather than become the new state party chairman.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- Passenger car production in the United States this week was the highest for any Thanksgiving week since 1955, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A $4,100 tax-fraud case against William Hendrick, former captain of waiters at New York's Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, has been dismissed, according to United States Tax Court records.
Italy has "issued an ultimatum" to the United States after being rebuffed in her efforts to obtain Los Angeles landing rights for Alitalia, the Italian airlines.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Warren Giles, the president of the National Baseball League, said today he was opposed to legalizing the "spitball." He called it a "freak pitch that never had its place in baseball."

There are fifteen bright, new Kelly Green uniforms hanging in Manhattan College's equipment room today, but there are only ten varsity players to fill them. That's the chief problem confronting Coach Ken Norton as he prepares for another rugged basketball schedule.

Tiny one-celled organisms that resemble fossil algae but are different from any organisms known to have lived on the surface of the earth have been found in meteorites by two Hungarian scientists working here.

The program at Aqueduct yesterday was a delight to the players who recognized "mud" form. Of the nine races, six were taken by horses who were proved performers over sloppy tracks and who went to the post as favorites.
DALLAS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- United States District Judge Joe Estes ruled against the Government today in its antitrust suit against Ling-Temco Electronics, Inc., and Chance Vought Corporation.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 24 -- Some men retire into a leisurely life, but Olavi Uuno Viktor Honka, 67 years old, ended a career as a civil servant by becoming a candidate for the Presidency of Finland.

THE most costly of wines and the one most desired as the festive season approaches is Champagne. An ancient inland sea, a fickle climate and a seventeenth-century process of wine-making that is extraordinarily complex and time-consuming have combined to make this the aristocrat of wines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States Court of Appeals here decided today to reconsider its order blocking the sale of WNTA-TV, Channel 13 in Newark, to a New York educational group.
Terence Young, the British director, left for London yesterday after discussing plans for two forthcoming projects, the first of which sounds highly in keeping with his record of adventure films.

The "Big E" is back again! To veterans of World War II this is the big news of the day in Hampton Roads. A new Enterprise, largest ship ever built, and the first and perhaps the last nuclear power carrier in any navy, joins the Navy list today, nine weeks ahead of schedule.
The largest weekly loss on record hit the United States stock of monetary gold during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
Despite a heavy rain, the New York Giants engaged in a spirited workout yesterday in preparation for their important National Football League game with the Browns in Cleveland tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson celebrated his twenty-fifth birthday with 31 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals rallied to defeat the Syracuse Nationals, 127 -- 125, in a National Basketball Association game.
The American Stock Exchange believes apparently that its members have not been sufficiently alert about informing it when other exchanges take disciplinary action against them or their firms.
Memorial services for a Lutheran minister will be held tomorrow in a Brooklyn church where he had been scheduled to preach the day's sermon.

Riddle Airlines, Inc., operated in the black for its first fiscal quarter, ended on Sept. 30. Robert M. Hewitt, president, reported yesterday. Profits amounted to $1,041,443 on gross operating revenues of $8,730,396. Comparative figures for the year before are not available.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 24 -- I once mentioned in these columns the political theorem of my wife which she calls the Extreme Center and in which she advocates, like Lewis Carroll's Red Queen, knocking off the head of everyone to the right or left of her.
Dan Ferris, "Mr. Amateur Sports" in the United States for a half century, said yesterday he was retiring completely. He is 72 years old.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A glorious era is coming to an end for this sea-faring nation, which one could boast that Britannia ruled the waves.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Notre Dame will make a formal request to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Rules Committee for an official word whether the Irish beat Syracuse fair and square on a disputed "extra play" field goal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today it had seized a drug it said was being promoted falsely to athletic coaches as an aid to physical endurance.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- River Rage, a 3-year-old gelding owned and bred by Mrs. Daniel Shea of Hyde, Md., scored by three lengths today in the $4,500 Public Relations Council Purse at Pimlico.

HOUSTON, Nov. 24 -- The thirty-second annual fall national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League begins here tomorrow and will continue through Sunday, Dec. 3.

BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, President Kennedy's personal representative in West Berlin, said today that United States Army authorities had no choice about surrendering an East German refugee to Soviet officials yesterday.
A form of mental deficiency is being prevented by infant-screening programs in several states and in Britain, according to reports in a medical journal out today.

An investment banking group headed by the First National Bank of Chicago won award of $1,500,000 of Wilmington, Del., general obligation bonds at competitive bidding yesterday. The group bid 100.6001 with a 3.40 per cent coupon for the bonds, which mature from 1962 to 1986, setting a net interest cost to the borrower of 3.3538 per cent.
HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 24 -- Olavi Honka withdrew today as President Kekkonen's rival in the Presidential elections of early next year. He abandoned the race "in the national interest."

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The serious problem of what to do about Europe's three neutrals in the new economic alignment that would follow Britain's entry into the European Economic Community is expected to break into the open next year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Princeton will be aiming for its first share of the Ivy League football title since 1957 when it entertains Dartmouth tomorrow.

The man who offered 20,000 free seats to city youth groups for a sandlot football game on Randalls Island was deluged with telephone calls yesterday. As a result, he offered 3,000 more tickets to youth organizations.

An assistant district attorney who had a forty-five-minute clash with a General Sessions judge was directed yesterday to appear in court Monday for questioning on why he should not be cited for contempt.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- A leader of the major Dominican Opposition party denied today Cuban charges of United States aggression against the Dominican Republic.
A Democratic State committeeman sought a court order yesterday compelling Michael H. Prendergast, the state chairman, to produce records of the party's receipts and expenditures.
Cotton futures closed $2.05 a bale lower on the December contract to 45 cents off to $1.25 up on the others yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A Labor Department statistical survey reported today a continuing decline in union membership in the United States.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Alpha Portland Cement Company said today that it had offered to buy the Texas Portland Cement Company of Beaumont for bonds and cash.

James A. Hagerty was a great political reporter. He was trusted by news source and reader alike to present an honest, informed, balanced, unbiased account of the facts. He served The Times for thirty-four years, and on retiring in 1954 left the enduring memory of a standard of fairness, thoroughness and integrity that was an example to all newspaper men.
JERICHO, Jordan, Nov. 12 -- Here in the bleak shadow of the Mount of Temptation, on the arid side of the Jordan Valley, are scattered the mud huts of 82,000 Palestine refugees.

Ingrid Bergman, who has not appeared on Broadway since "Joan of Lorraine" (1946), may replace Elizabeth Bergner in "First Love," the Samuel Taylor play scheduled to open here Dec. 18.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Officers of the nation's biggest corporation gave more than 95 per cent of their political contributions in 1960 to Republican candidates, the political wing of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Thirteen African states proposed tonight that Indonesia and the Netherlands sit down together again and try to reach agreement on the future status of Netherlands New Guinea.

Mayor Wagner assured seven strike-threatened private bus lines yesterday that the city would treat them "fairly and properly" if they negotiated a "fair and reasonable" settlement with the Transport Workers Union.

Raymond McAfee, a baritone who has sung many oratorio performances in the Midwest, moved to New York recently to become minister of music at the Calvary Baptist Church. Last night he essayed his first recital here, in Carnegie Recital Hall, with the excellent collaboration of Paul Liljestrand at the piano.
MALVERNE, L.I., Nov. 24 -- Philadelphia, Northeast and Great Lakes remained undefeated today in the United States Field Hockey Association's four-day national tournament.

Although less than a year old, the coin-operated dry cleaning machine industry is already a young giant in the automatic vending field.

Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino, who has come under fire because of his connection with a fall-out shelter manufacturing company, was defended yesterday by Representative Frank J. Becker, Nassau Republican.

Moscow's decision to postpone indefinitely joint military consultations with Finland against an alleged menace from West Germany is clearly a reprieve for Finland. In retrospect it is apparent that the whole episode -- which aroused so many fears in the West and in Finland -- was primarily a propaganda maneuver aimed at pillorying West Germany before world public opinion.
WARSAW, Nov. 25 -- Poland's economic planners, conceding that wages and consumer income got a bit out of hand this year, have decreed a year of belt-tightening in 1962.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens, getting two goals from Marcel Bonin, tonight blanked the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 0, and took over first place in the National Hockey League game.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Mixing a variable V with a cockeyed T, Dartmouth rushed past Princeton to a 24-6 triumph at Palmer Stadium today, depriving the favored Tigers of a fractional share of the Ivy League football title.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The engagement of Miss Polly Patchen Lauterbach to George Albert Keyworth 2d has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mls. Carl William Lauterbach of Rochester.

For the Grosvenor Debutante Ball last night, the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was transformed into a bower of flowers. Yellow and white chrysanthemums decorated the ballroom boxes, pilasters and stage for the annual event, a benefit for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Three buildings were destroyed today and a fourth was damaged in the second $1,000,000 fire at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in four days. A base spokesman said officials were checking the possibility of arson.

ONE cannot underestimate the daring and imagination that have gone into the conception of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Nor can one fail to applaud the tenacity and devotion that are transforming a bold dream into the reality of steel and stone and electronic marvels.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Agua Caliente tribe is enjoying unusual prosperity today because of an act of Congress passed two years ago.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 25 -- Asia's two leading political powers, India and Communist China, have been brought into intensified conflict by the current turmoil in Southeast Asia. Each of these giants is trying to demonstrate to the smaller nations in this area which system is the better, communism or democracy.
CAIRO, Nov. 25 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser promised his countrymen tonight that a new "popular" Government he envisioned would achieve social justice for Egypt's millions.
VIENNA, Nov. 25 -- Austrians are beginning to feel uneasy about their country's security as they watch Moscow put political pressure on Finland. Both countries have treaties making them neutral.

While three groups of students demonstrated against nuclear warfare and the civil defense program here yesterday two physicists told New Yorkers that fall-out shelters would be useless near target areas.

At any rate, Anthony Bailey, a British New Yorker, has caught the frazzled temper of the Glass Age in a delightful comic novel tinged with just the measure of bitterness the situation demands.
Yama Bahama of Bimini, B.W.I., survived a late-round assault by Farid Salim of Argentina last night to win a majority decision in their ten-round middleweight fight at Madison Square Garden.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 21 -- The entrance of Dr. Alfonso Lopez Michelson and his Liberal Revolutionary Movement into next May's Presidential election becomes more of a certainty daily.

TO tourists who visit Curacao in the West Indies, it is a "paradise." But to Matthew, it is only lonely, hot and tedious. When he receives a dinghy for his twelfth birthday, his narrow world expands. Now he can escape boredom and sail to a deserted island the natives swear is haunted: "Whoever set foot on it would sink to the ground and disappear forever."

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Life has become difficult for the comparatively few men who conduct international economic affairs for the governments of Western Europe. Too many negotiations are going on in too many places, almost all at once, and each affecting all the others.

AFTER thirty-five years of broadcasting, the grand old dinosaur of American radio. "Grand Ole Opry," is as boisterously alive as ever. The show began on Nashville's Station WSM on Nov. 28, 1925, and aside from time off for a few Fireside Chats by the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, has an uninterrupted record of Saturday nights that span a whole era.

THE New York City Ballet, which opens its winter season at the City Center on Dec. 5, has found that its major new work has grown to the proportions of a full-evening ballet. This is George Balanchine's choreographic creation based on the Mendelssohn music for "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and utilizing other Mendelssohn compositions in related style as well.

A DEEPLY ambiguous drama was played on the American stage of Presidential politics between 1952 and 1960. As the intellectual-moral lines are retraced in this book by Stuart Gerry Brown of Syracuse University, Adlai Stevenson becomes the drama's hero-protagonist.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- The Peter Bent Brigham Hospital reorganibed its out-patient clinic this week. The aim was to recapture the concept of the family physician.
WHAT Hitler failed to achieve in one of the fiercest of modern military assaults, Nikita Khrushchev has now accomplished with a swift stroke of the pen. Stalingrad is no more.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Nov. 250 -- The Bedford Hills Community House again will be the scene of the annual Greens Day Party and tea on Dec. 21, Since 1947, this volunteer project for the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco has become a tradition here.
MAPLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 25 -- This town again will observe the Christmas season with special programs and street decorations based on the works of Charles Dickens.

The Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship and the Frank J. Marshall Trophy will be held at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street, beginning on Dec. 17. It will continue for eleven rounds through Jan. 4.

Eight young women made their debuts last night at the third annual Doric Debutante Cotillion in the Metropolitan Club. The event was sponsored by the Women's Architectural Auxiliary, New York Chapter, American Institute of Architects.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 -California Democrats and Republicans will hold significant meetings next week-end. The primary consideration of each party will be unity for victory in 1962.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J. -Several of New Jersey's early American taverns and inns, which lined the colonial turnpikes between New York, Philadelphia, Albany and the west, are receiving a new lease on life through restoration as operating inns or as museums, and at least one of them still greets the winter time guest with the traditional cup of hot mulled cider served before a roaring fire.

A parabolic dish eight feet in diameter, capable of focusing 6,000 degrees of solar heat on test objects and materials, has been developed by Goodyear Aircraft Corporation's Arizona division to test materials for space vehicles.
The bustling new Argentine automobile manufacturing and assembling industry will turn out a record of about 60,000 passenger cars this year.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- In two final minutes of whirlwind football, Syracuse downed Boston College, 28 to 13, today.

Christmas wares are on sale again at the Green Box, the outlet for the Rehabilitation Workshop of Mount Sinai Hospital.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 25 -Frank Iannicelli and Charles Jones of the Downtown Athletic Club reached the semi-finals of the pro-amateur squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York will hold its sixty-seventh annual meeting Wednesday evening in its auditorium at 122 East Fifty-eighth Street.

KINGS POINT, L.I. Nov. 2 -The twelfth annual North Shore Hospital Ball to aid the institution's medical residents training program took place tonight in the giant drill hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy on Manhasset Bay.

AN apparent step-up in the design and production of Japanese cameras and other photographic equipment is reflected in the exhibits to be displayed at the eighth annual Japan Camera Show. The show opens on Thursday at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue.

Prohibiting the use of alcohol or other depressants before driving "may well prove to be the only workable solution to the problem of alcohol and accidents on the road," a British scientist says.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- As a sort of postlude to its season, the Lyric Opera of Chicago presented a world premiere last night. Vittorio Giannini's "The Harvest," given under the auspices of the Ford Foundation's program for the promotion of American opera, will have three more performances this week and will close the season Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A lawyers' committee suggested today the Federal Aviation Agency speed up its enforcement procedures by concentrating on major violations of air safety.

Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg last night lauded the United States and Israel for true adherence to the principles of humanitarianism. Each seeks "freedom not only for itself but for all of the countries of the world," he said.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Walter Ulbricht, head of the East German Government, indicated in a speech published today that the Communists intended to intensify their pressure on the Allied position in Berlin.

A program of Italian and Spanish songs and arias was offered at Carnegie Recital Hall last night by Arturo Di Rocca, a Latin-American tenor who had last sung in this city in February, 1960. Vincente Grisolia was the accompanist.
MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 26 -- The Dutch district commissioner denied here today that the buying of skulls by Michael Rockefeller had stirred a revival of headhunting.

Further evidence that the answer to cancer -- not necessarily its cause, but perhaps the means to cure it -- may lie in the body's immune mechanisms has come from research at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

A man was killed and seven other persons were injured yesterday when a station wagon mounted a sidewalk at St. Mark's Place and Avenue A on the East Side, struck pedestrians, smashed a fire hydrant and then hit a car that rammed a third car.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Fowler Hamilton, chief of the United States foreign aid program, said today it would be a "chancy proposition" for the United States to try to buy the friendship of other nations with foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A consulting economist told Congress today that a "rather small' Federal aid program could meet the readjustment problems of domestic industries affected by a liberalized foreign-trade policy.
Three days of Prayer for religious vocations will be observed in the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese Dec. 5 through Dec. 7.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 26 -- An official statement from Portugal's Department of National Defense said today that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India had planned an attack on the Portuguese island of Angediva, south of Goa.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 26 -- President Kennedy announced today the replacement of Chester Bowles as Under Secretary of State.
Over-the-counter stock prices moved irregularly higher last week, with some dealers reporting it one of the busiest weeks of the year.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Ukrainian Nationals, leading in the American Soccer League, defeated the Galicia Honduras eleven, 1 -- 0, at Houston Field today. Atillo Galassini made the goal.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- Demand for steel appears to have strengthened last week despite some confusion as to the degree of improvement and the extent to which it was backed by actual orders. However, it was becoming increasingly clear that January would see a sharp rise in shipments.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 26 -- The National Merit Scholarship Corporation named a psychologist today to conduct a study of talented students.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Bertil Bjorklund will start series of experiments in few weeks with a vaccine against cancer.
Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower not only got Eliot Ness but also vanquished an entire episode of "The Untouchables" on a television station in Augusta, Ga., last Thursday night.
Hayes Industries, Inc., reported over the week-end an increase of about 89 per cent in earnings on a sales gain of 13 per cent for its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31.
DALLAS, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Abner Haynes scored five touchdowns today as the Dallas Texans snapped a six-game American Football League losing streak with a 43-11 victory over the Oakland Raiders.
The "missile gap," like the "bomber gap" before it, is now being consigned to the limbo of synthetic issues, where it always belonged.
BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Former Gov. Goodwin J. Knight of California may have infectious hepatitis, a disease that could keep him out of the 1962 Republican primary race for Governor.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Don Carter of St. Louis won the $48,000 world invitation bowling tournament today for the third straight year and the fourth time in the tourney's five-year history.
George Katz, who last played the piano here in 1956, was back late yesterday afternoon with a substantial Carnegie Hall program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A compromise Executive Order to bar discrimination in Federally aided housing has been submitted to President Kennedy.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 26 -- President Kennedy announced today the appointment of Dr. Edmond Hutchinson of New York as regional administrator for Africa in the State Department's new Agency for International Development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Trinidad conference between Adlai E. Stevenson and President Arturo Frondizi may lead to wider South American suport of proposals for an inter-American defense establishment.
GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- The United States and British negotiators said today they would take a wait-and-see attitude at the resumption Tuesday of talks with the Soviet Union on a nuclear-test ban.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Some Eagle fans among the 60,127 persons at Franklin Field today roundly booed Sonny Jurgensen when he was introduced just before the game with the Dallas Cowboys. In the next sixty minutes, however, Jurgensen passed for all five Philadelphia touchdowns as the Eagles romped to a 35-13 decision over the Cowboys.
Elisabeth Schwarzkopf sang so magnificently Saturday night at Hunter college that it seems a pity to have to register any complaints. Still a demurrer or two must be entered.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Billy Wade tossed a 55-yard touchdown pass to Willie Galimore with two minutes to play today, enabling the Chicago Bears to score a 28-24 National Football League victory over the Los Angeles Rams.
A drop in union membership was attributed yesterday to a variety of causes including management opposition, changing occupational and industrial patterns, anti-labor legislation and labor scandal.
The second annual Christmas Boutique for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club will be held in the clubhouse auditorium, 301 East Fifty-second Street, on Dec. 4.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has bought the four-story store and tenement building on a plot 44 by 75 feet at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The parcel was sold by Edward Menden through the Kreisel Company, broker.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 26 -- One of the glummer aftermaths of World War I was the White Russian fugitive found as taxi driver in Paris, doorman in Berlin or Istanbul restaurateur. World War II produced a new wave of emigration to New York, Mexico and Hong Kong.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 26 -- Three Northern Ireland constables were injured today when their patrol car was wrecked by a land mine at Crossmaglen in County Armagh.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 26 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe told the people of Kantaga today to gird for war.
James L. Hicks, the executive editor of The Amsterdam News, told yesterday how he had rediscovered religion while cowering on the floor of a barn in Mississippi.

If it is true, as the poet Abram Joseph Ryan put it, that "a land without memories is a land without history," it may also be true that a city without respect for its historic landmarks is a city that denies itself comforting memories.

THERE is a man in Manhattan who travels 100,000 miles each year to purchase eggs. He is Ura Fridman, a caviar expert who commutes between New York and Teheran to sample and purchase sturgeon roe, one of the most sought-after and expensive delicacies on earth.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 26 -- It will cost municipal governments more to borrow money in the bond market next year than in that just past, according to the predictions made here today at the opening session of the Investment Bankers Association's annual convention.

THE deep thinkers in the big leagues are about to succumb to the spirit of self-sacrifice and spend the next week or so in Florida, bravely risking sunstroke for the betterman of their sport. As a prelude to this noble gesture, they took a vote yesterday on the question of restoring legality to a pitch that has been outlawed for four decades, the spitball.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 26 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen suggested tonight that opposition leaders who had incurred the hatred of the Soviet Union should withdraw into private life for the good of Finland.

PRINCESS LEE RADZIWILL, Mrs. John F. Kennedy's diminutive younger sister, was in town for a few days not long ago to shop and visit with friends. While she was here, she also dispelled a few notions about life as it is lived by the aristocracy.

I wish to commend your editorial of Nov. 16 on "Lincoln Center Traffic." As one of the first residents of the redeveloped Lincoln Center complex, I have been very concerned with this problem, which is fraught with potential hazards to present and future residents of this area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Kennedy's first major reorganization of his Administration today was primarily personal. It indicated no basic differences over foreign policy, but was basically a readjustment of personalities to correct hurried political appointments made a year ago, to strengthen the State Department and to bring it closer to the White House.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 4 -- 1, and advanced into fourth place in the National Hockey League.
IN its earliest days. The Texas Boys Choir was not greeted with unrestrained enthusiasm by the fathers of Denton, Tex. Many feared that the training would turn their sons into sissies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Corporate profits continued to rise in the third quarter of the year in the wake of a rapid advance in production during the spring and summer, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ALONG around 10:30 last night at the Metropolitan Opera there was a tiny pause and then the audience went wild. Joan Sutherland had just finished the first half of the "Lucia" Mad Scene, topping it with a perfectly placed high E flat.

MURRAY LOUIS and his dance company appeared at the Henry Street Playhouse on Friday and Saturday evenings and Sunday afternoons in the premiere of his latest work, "Signal," and the repetition of an earlier one, "Journal."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The South African Jewish Board of Deputies said in a statement today that Prime Minister Hendrik F. Verwoerd had "appealed to all to keep South Africa free from anti-Semitism, as in fact it has been for more than a decade."

A successor to Carmine G. De Sapio as Democratic leader of New York County is due to be chosen within the next ten days. All indications are that he will have only a small fraction of the authority his predecessors have exercised and, in political stature, will be only a pale shadow of others who have occupied the post.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The grain futures market held to a mostly higher trend last week and in some instances more than recovered the setbacks of a week ago.
IT MAY have been the male who went through the university, but it is the female who has adopted it.

It was a new year and there were new Challengers but Peter McArdle, representing the New York Athletic Club, won again yesterday in the fourth annual nine-mile cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
Alabama and Rutgers headed the list of seventeen unbeaten and untied major college football teams yesterday.
LONDON, Now 26 -- The talks between Prime Minister Macmillan and President de Gaulle have restored harmony to British and French policies on Berlin, reliable sources reported tonight.
Doug Harvey, the player-coach of the New York Rangers, said before his team's game with Montreal last night that "if you don't skate with the Canadiens, they'll get you in a pocket and murder you."

The swift termination of a crippling strike at a Nevada nuclear test site indicates that resolute action by union leaders who are willing to lead is a dependable safeguard against rank-and-file irresponsibility.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced yesterday that he was resigning as an adviser to the New York Committee for Democratic Voters, spearhead for nearly three years of the drive for reform within the Democratic party.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Lou Michaels kicked his third field goal of the game with thirteen seconds remaining today and led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 30-27 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in a National Football League game.
The ashes of a group of Jews who perished in the Nazi concentration camp of Auschwitz were buried yesterday at a special monument in the United Hebrew Cemetery on Staten Island.

Ben Lucien Burman traveled more than 50,000 miles in North America for his new book. "It's a Big Continent," to be published by McGraw-Hill in January. His journey was made by car, Jeep, flatboat, Florida airboat, speedboat, spongeboat, commercial airliners, one-engine planes guided by bush-pilots and Eskimo canoe.
Augustin Castellon, the great flamenco guitarist from Pamplona, Spain, who calls himself Sabicas, gave a Town Hall concert Saturday night that merits a resounding "Ole!"

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 26 -- A man, his wife and their three sons were found stabbed to death in their home here early this morning. The police started a hunt for a brother-in-law who is a fugitive from a mental hospital.

Trading in cotton futures ranged widely on the New York Cotton Exchange last week. At the close of business on Friday some prices were off as much as $2.15 a bale while others showed gain of up to 60 cents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Pentagon is preparing a major policy directive to assure high moral standards in the operations of subsidized private nonprofit corporations that do vital military research and development work.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Gay Brewer Jr. shot a six-under-par 66 today for a four-round total of 275 and the $2,000 top prize in the third annual Mobile open golf tournament.
Is the memory of an automatic data processing machine too short to satisfy the needs of the Internal Revenue Service?
Trans World Airlines is not planning to seek financial assistance from the Hughes Tool Company, Charles W. Tillinghast Jr., president of T.W.A., said yesterday.

SEATTLE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Army investigators have made soldiers of the Thirty-second Division afraid to talk or write to their Congressmen, Representative Alvin E. O'Konski, Republican of Wisconsin, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Administration's proposed across-the-board increase in postal rates has a "very good chance" of passage in the next Congressional session, Postmaster General J. Edward Day said today.
Edward Albee is about to come forth with his first full-length drama, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?"
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $84,403,605,759. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
Central Park yesterday was a dazzling scene of incongruity. There were skiers on the slopes, tennis players on the courts, skaters on the pond and sun-bathers in the meadows.

MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 26 -- A wisp of smoke rising from the jungles of New Guinea's southern coast was spotted by the crew of a search plane today, reviving hopes that Michael Rockefeller is alive.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Nature lovers on a field trip along the Hackensack River here today learned more about wildlife that has disappeared in recent years than about wildlife that remains.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, former chief economic adviser to President Dwight D. Eisenhower, has upheld the integrity of the Labor Department's statistics. In doing so, he rebutted a criticism of him by Stanley H. Ruttenberg, research director of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- For the first time, an open communion service celebrated in accordance with the Anglican rite was offered here this morning under the aegis of the World Council of Churches.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson arrived here by plane today and conferred with President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina. Mr. Stevenson, chief United States representative at the United Nations, said on his arrival that the United States placed the greatest reliance on the Organization of American States.
The Sudan may soon be noted as a country where it is harder to avoid an education than to obtain one.
The "pioneer area" of modern society stretches from southern New Hampshire to northern Virginia, and from the Atlantic to the Appalachian foothills, according to a study released today.
CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 26 -- United States Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, one of the most influential Republicans in the nation, died at his home here today. He was 63 years old.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 26 -- A spokesman for the Rightwing Government here said today there was a very good chance that the Princes who head Laos' three political factions would meet in Vientiane on Tuesday.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 26 -- A five-member observation group from the Organization of American States returned to Washington today. The observers are expected to recommend that the O.A.S. take steps toward ending diplomatic and economic sanctions against the Dominican Republic.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Uncertainty about general economic trends and pessimistic forecasts on business profits brought a sharp reversal in the stock market last week.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- -Cabinet-rank ministers from thirty-seven countries will gather in Geneva tomorrow to tackle the three toughest problems in world trade.
THE Metropolitan Opera's production of Offenbach's "La Perichole," which returned to the repertory on Saturday night after an absence of three seasons, manages to be entertaining in spite of itself.

Magistrate John B. Lee invoked a rarely used section of the Code of Criminal Procedure yesterday to deny bail to six youths and a woman charged with assaulting a policeman in the Bronx Saturday night.
HELSINKI, Nov. 26 (AP) -- President Kekkonen assured the Finnish nation and the world tonight that the Soviet Union had recognized Finland's present policy of neutrality.

HOUSTON, Nov. 26 -- Mrs. Dorothy Hayden of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., paired with Mrs. Helen Portugal of Los Angeles, won the national women's pair championship as the opening events of the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here were concluded today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- John Brodie's passing and J.D. Smith's running led the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 38-28 victory over the Minnesota Vikings today in a National Football League game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The maneuvering for position in next years fight over foreign trade legislation is fast and furious already, and bound to become more so.
