The Community Church of New York, one of the pioneers in the social action concept of religion, yesterday marked its 135th anniversary.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 26 -- Ruling circles in South Vietnam appear to have hardened their resistance to the governmental reforms reported to have been demanded by the United States as part of a joint effort to defeat communism here.

An open letter on freedom in Ghana appearing as a paid advertisement in The Times on Nov. 19 purports to be signed by the League of Ghana Patriots and the Ghana Students Union of U.S.A. and Canada. Its object was to attack the views expressed by a refugee fellow-countryman, Dr. K.A. Busia.

Charges have been made that the 1961 rent control law contained a "sleeper amendment" dealing with use of current instead of 1954 equalization rates for determination of property valuation. The legislative record is to the contrary.

SEVILLE, Spain, Nov. 26 (AP) -- United States Air Force and Navy units joined Spanish authorities in rescue operations today as flood waters spilled from rain-swollen rivers and swept through low-lying sections of this city. At least two persons were drowned and 10,000 left homeless. Unofficial reports put the death toll at four.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Following are sketches of the men involved in changes made by President Kennedy in the White House and State Department foreign policy staffs today:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- McLain Street, named for the Mount Kisco (N.Y.) thoroughfare on which he lives, became the open jumper champion of the Boulder Brook Club Horse Show for the third time in a row tonight.
AGRA, India, Nov. 26 -- A party that professes a fervent belief in private enterprise completed plans here this week-end to fight the political colossus led by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The State Department is investigating complaints that Soviet trawlers fishing on the Georges Bank off New England are violating an international treaty and the United States may complain to Moscow, Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Mass., said today.
Among Madison Avenue agencies, Lawrence Fertig Co. has always been something of an anomaly.

The Citizens' Committee for Children of New York wishes to congratulate you on your excellent editorial "Reorganizing Public Welfare" which appeared in The Times of Nov. 16. You very rightly point out the overriding importance of administering public welfare in such a way as to "foster self-reliance through greater stress on rehabilitating those already on relief and preventing others from becoming dependent."

CARLSBAD, N.M., Nov. 26 -- Foreign observers got their first look today at a 1,000-foot-long tunnel being prepared for the United States' first underground nuclear explosion in the search for peaceful uses of atomic energy.
HOUSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Houston Oilers, scoring 2 points in the fourth quarter registered their sixth straight American Football League victory by defeating the Denver Broncos, 45 -- 14, today.

Three men and a 13-year-old boy drifted helplessly to sea in an old cabin cruiser off Fire Island Saturday. After twenty two hours, a Danish freighter came to their rescue, but the leaking little boat foundered, and the boy drowned.
Shareholders in mutual funds are showing increased interest in putting their investments on a regular basis.
ALGIERS, Nov. 26 -- At least fifteen persons have been killed and more than ninety injured in violence involving Europeans and Moslems in Algeria since yesterday morning.
It's been a long time between 1869 and 1961.
New York's dockers worked 2,500,000 fewer hours in the contract year ended Sept. 30, as compared with the preceding year, the New York Shipping Association said yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 -- Shaky on defense and stalled on the ground in the first half, the Giants pulled themselves together after the intermission and walloped the favored Cleveland Browns, 37 -- 21, today before a stunned crowd of 80,455 at Cleveland Stadium.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Two Negro students, one a Baptist minister, tried unsuccessfully to worship today in two Augusta white churches.

THE Symphony of the Air, greatly assisted by Van Cliburn, last night got its Seven-concert Beethoven cycle at Carnegie Hall off to a good start. At the same time the orchestra announced that next season it would be giving twenty-five programs at Carnegie, and that it would be taking these concerts to the suburbs, repeating each of them in five different communities.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Nov. 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy took a ride after church today, to watch his wife and other Kennedys ice skating.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Royals scored a 117-102 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight in a National Basketball Association game. Oscar Robertson led the Royals with 24 points.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 26 -- The move to bring back the spitball, for which there was considerable agitation the past year, came to a swift end today.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26 -- The first Israeli trade mission ever to visit Canada has disclosed that it is in the market for Canadian made heavy machinery and equipment.
BOSTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into a tie for first place in the National Hockey League with the Montreal Canadiens tonight by beating the Boston Bruins, 4-1.

James Yoghourtjian, a young American classical guitarist, made his recital debut late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall. The program included short places by composers from the sixteenth century to the present day.

Intergovernmental cooperation in fighting crime would ordinarily be most welcome. But there is a disquieting element in the formation of a Southern Association of Intelligence Agents, representing police officials of nine Southern states. A Georgia official says the new organization would be particularly interested in ferreting out "subversion," significantly adding that "there are a lot of organizations besides the Communist party that are subversive."

New roles for two new singers are included in the Metropolitan Opera's plans for its seventh week, beginning next, Monday. Galina Vishnevskaya, the Russian soprano who made her Met debut in "Aida" some weeks ago, will sing her first Cio-Cio-San with the company in Tuesday night's "Madama Butterfly."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- During a recent visit to Berlin, John A. McCone, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, thought for a moment he was about to fall victim to the "cold war."
TASHKENT, U.S.S.R., Nov. 19 -- The Soviet Union is easily outdistancing all of its neighbors, with the possible exception of Communist China, in the race for Asian industrial and social leadership.

The questionnaires to be distributed by the State Education Department among New York City's teachers make strange reading. If they are indicative of the state's survey of the city's schools, the outlook for any useful contribution by Albany to local reform efforts is dim.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Lenny Moore's long runs sparked the Baltimore Colts to a 27-6 National Football League victory over the Washington Redskins today before 41,062 fans.
HAVANA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- President Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado declared today that "political power is now in the hands of the working class" in Cuba.

The appointment of Dr. Bernard Berelson as director of the communication research program of the Population Council, Inc., effective Jan. 1, was announced yesterday. Dr. Berelson, director of the Bureau of Applied Social Research and Professor of Sociology at Columbia University, is resigning the directorship and taking a leave of absence from the faculty.
WARSAW, Nov. 26 -- Prof. Leopold Infeld, a noted Polish scientist, said this week-end that citizens of Communist countries must be granted more and more freedom.
The General Battery and Ceramic Corporation announced yesterday its acquisition of 200, 000 common shares of the Shoup Voting Machine Corporation from Shoup's chairman, Lewis M. Schott.

Washington's urgent new program for assisting South Vietnam is now well advanced. New weapons, more specialists and more money are being funneled into a crash effort to save the young republic from Communist conquest. Still lacking, however, is the basic requisite for success -- government reform in Saigon.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 27 -- The outstanding demand of the nation's investment bankers for a new national transportation policy received another airing here today at the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association.

Lee Higginson Corporation and associates yesterday offered 171,038 common shares of Binney Smith, Inc., on behalf of selling stockholders at $19 a share. Binney Smith makes wax crayons, water colors, chalk, modeling clay, finger paints and paste.
The Thoroughbred Racing Associations, meeting in annual convention here yesterday, were warned that they must continue to improve their breed of horse-player.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 27 -- The lower house of the Congolese Parliament voted unanimously today to resume diplomatic relations with Belgium.
Two former contestants on a rigged television quiz show pleaded guilty to perjury yesterday. Special Sessions Justice Thomas I. Rohan, after censuring them, suspended sentence in each case.

MIAMI, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- A second questioning of Terry Jo Duperrault, lone survivor of the sinking of the yacht Bluebelle, has made her original story of possible murder on the high seas "more convincing", a Coast Guard spokesman said today.

The sudden and essentially unexplained meeting between Ambassador Adlai Stevenson and President Frondizi of Argentina in Trinidad served to pinpoint again the big problem that little Cuba presents to the hemispheric nations.
Steel production declined slightly again last week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Enthusiastic Christmas shoppers will push December retail sales to near-record volume, Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- One of the largest unions began a conference on international trade today in response to membership pressures for protection against "unfair" competition from abroad.

The Echo I satellite passed south of the city at 7:54 P.M. yesterday, morning southeast about 18 degrees above the horizon. It will be visible, weather permitting, eight more times between today and Monday evening, Dec. 4, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in Washington yesterday.

The outside world does not know what Premier Khrushchev said to Finnish President Kekkonen in their conversation at Novosibirsk. We do know that Mr. Kekkonen came home with an assurance that he would not have to humiliate himself now by having military talks, with the Russians -- that is, by ordering his military advisers to listen while the Russians told them what to do.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Sweden appealed to the United Nations today to halt the spread of nuclear weapons to reduce the risk of an accidental nuclear war.

Warren Rich, pianist from Pittsfield, Mass., made his New York debut last night at Town Hail. He proved to be a well-schooled and conscientious performer, but there was little evidence of much inner fire.
The fifth annual dinner dance of the Manhattan-Bronx Chapter of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America will be held in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane Friday.

In recent years advertising agencies have found it necessary to provide their clients with an increasingly wide spectrum of services. Instead of just devising ads -- the traditional function of the advertising agency -- modern agencies have been called upon to provide advice on packaging, brand names, merchandising techniques, test marketing, publicity and numerous other questions.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The United Steelworkers of America said today that it was asking some 2,900 companies to join in an effort to "stamp out the evils of discrimination in employment, wherever it may exist."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The creation of a special committee of anti-Castro leaders to help screen security risks among Cuban refugees was disclosed today by the Justice Department.

Ground is being cleared for the first major office building to be built in St. Louis in about thirty years. A twenty-story building will rise at the northeast corner of Sixth and Olive Streets in the downtown area.

Dore Schary's plans for his next theatrical venture are moving apace. Between rehearsals of "Something About a Soldier," the Ernest Kinoy play he is staging and co-producing with the Theatre Guild. Mr. Schary said yesterday that he had completed the outline of "For Special Occasions."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets remained unchanged at 118.9 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended Tuesday, Nov. 21, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Kennedy announced today the appointment of Chester Bowles as his special representative and adviser on African, Asian and Latin-American affairs.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 27 -Russell R. Kirby's Milford Hanover, the favorite, scored a half-length victory over Hal Sampson in the one-mile Staten Island Handicap pace at Roosevelt Raceway last night. The attendance was 18,438.

Two studies of the Twenty-second Congress of the Communist party of the Soviet Union are planned for publication early next year. One will be "Russia Enters the 1960's," edited by Harry Schwartz of The New York Times editorial board.

A Bethlehem Steel Corporation subsidiary announced yesterday that it had submitted a plan for the consideration of Chilean authorities calling for the investment of about $9,000,000 in new facilities at two iron mines in Chile.

DENVER, Nov. 27 -- Through the use of radio-controlled pellets of medication implanted in the human body, medical science has achieved a degree of technological control of behavior, the American Medical Association's annual clinical meeting was told here today.
Dale Hall, the Army football coach, made an effort yesterday to spike what he called "Navy propaganda."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet proposal for an agreement to ban nuclear testing, announced today, was viewed skeptically by United States officials as another maneuver to obtain an indefinite, uncontrolled moratorium on such tests.

THE failure of Sean O'Casey's "Red Roses for Me" on Broadway six years ago was a miscarriage of justice. The appreciative revival that opened last night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre is a chance for restitution.

PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea, Tuesday, Nov. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller headed for home today after Dutch authorities all but abandoned hope of finding his son Michael, feared lost at sea ten days ago.

PIRIMAPOEN, Netherlands New Guinea, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller, his face drawn and downcast as the first really hopeful clue to the fate of his son faded, flew to this jungle search camp yesterday.
A small box that can raise a loud and shrill voice for safety was demonstrated by the Coast Guard yesterday.

Adlai E. Stevenson and President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina both professed satisfaction yesterday with their conference in Trinidad. They made their remarks in separate interviews at New York International Airport.
The bond market weakened yesterday in professional trading.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- A 200-acre stand of giant redwood trees has been proposed as a memorial to Dag Hammarskjold.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkokwitz and about thirty-five other Republicans who sought public office in the Nov. 7 municipal election agreed yesterday that a party position must be taken on all city issues.
The Lydian Chamber Ensemble gave a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

LAST week the House of Krupp celebrated -- and that's an apt word -- its 150th anniversary. The gross profits of $1,250,000,000 for this year are expected to be even higher than when the Krupp industrialists made the munitions that fed the Third Reich's guns of war. Of course, labor was a little easier to handle then: Krupp used thousands of slave laborers.
The New York County Medical Society voted last night against permitting patients with medical insurance but without their own doctors to choose hospital resident physicians to treat them.
AMERICAN women are said to go along with the herd and follow the current fashion trends, but there is evidence to the contrary.

LEXINGTON, Mass., Nov. 27 -- A high-flying object that could be the packet of copper hairs that was sent into orbit in an effort to form a communications belt around the earth has been picked up by radar.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Some non-psychiatric explanations for the traditionally morose appearance of comedians were offered today by Bob Newhart.
ALGIERS, Nov. 27 -- The French Army sent armored cars into the center of Oran today to halt attacks on Moslems ascribed to European youths.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 27 -- A Venezuelan airliner was hijacked in the air today by five armed students who forced the pilot to circle Caracas while they dropped anti-Government leaflets on the city.

TAMPA, Nov. 27 -- The major league trading mart, still a bit dormant to now, received a shot in the arm tonight. The White Sox traded Orestes (Minnie) Minoso, their Cuban outfield star, to the Cardinals for Joe Cunningham, a first baseman-outfielder.
The Metropolitan Opera has announced the dates of two cycles of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen," the first at

GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- Semyon K. Tsarapkin of the Soviet Union said on his arrival here tonight that he would "try to find a basis for agreement" at the nuclear test-ban conference on the basis of Moscow's new plan for ending all tests.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Dale Story of Oregon State ran the four miles barefoot in 32-degree temperature and won the National Collegiate cross-country meet today. His time was 19 minutes 46.6 seconds.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- France accused the United Arab Republic today of having fabricated charges of espionage and assassination plots against four French aides.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Chancellor Adenauer will come to Paris for consultations with President de Gaulle Dec. 9, it was announced today.

After his considerable service to the cause of Democratic reform, undertaken at the age of fourscore years, Herbert H. Lehman is resigning as adviser to the New York Committee for Democratic Voters. He cites with justified pride the accomplishments attained in three years. Carmine G. De Sapio is through as Tammany leader. Michael H. Prendergast, state Democratic chairman, is left withering on the vine.

IF movies of the old-time heavyweight champions prove nothing else, they would seem to indicate beyond even a reasonable doubt that the most superlative craftsman of them all was Jack Johnson. A rare opportunity for inspection was given at the Advertising Club yesterday when Sam Himmell gave a luncheon for Harry Hershfield and members of the Boxing Writers Association.

Irv (Spinner) Spencer, a defenseman, and Pat Hannigan and Vic Hadfield, two forwards, will see more action than usual tomorrow night when the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League play the Providence Reds of the American Hockey League in a benefit exhibition game at Princeton University's Hobey Baker Rink.
The new supercarrier Constellation will sail with a constant pictorial reminder of her glorious past -- an oil painting of her namesake, which was launched in 1797.
NORWALK Conn. Nov. 27 -Superintendent of Schools Harry A. Becker has asked teachers not to start discussions on nuclear war in class.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Henri Thomas, poet, critic, translator and novelist, won the Femina Prize to day for his novel, "The Promontory."
DENVER, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Speaking to the medical association's fifteenth annual clinical meeting, a physician said exercise would be a life-saver for the space man on long trips.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 27 -- A field of 300 master mixed pairs entered the second of three rounds in the American Contract Bridge League national tournament here tonight.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- In six-day bicycle racing there is a frenzy of activity in the hours just before and just after midnight. Racers sprint for prizes and points. The crowds, which have spilled out of theatres and nightclubs, scream their heads off.
Maine potato futures prices fell to new lows for the life of the contract yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

JERUALEM, Nov. 27 -- The Israeli Knesset (Parliament) approved by a large majority today the position taken by Israel in the United Nations in favor of sanctions against the Union of South Africa for its policies of racial separation.

The recent increase in credit extensions by the Inter-American Development Bank to Latin American nations is being considered by some international bankers as added evidence of the new direction the Kennedy Administration has taken in foreign aid.
Although City College has an edge in basket ball background over New York's other municipal colleges -- Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens -- the four are now turning out teams that are about on a par.

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Dave Charnley of England, the lightweight champion of Europe and the British Empire, knocked out L.C. Morgan of Youngstown, Ohio, and Los Angeles in the third round of a scheduled ten-rounder tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Diplomats decided tonight not to decide on the best way to try to hire more person from more countries for the United Nations staff.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 27 -- Government circles here have "informally" discussed a recent public statement by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's chief of state, that he would welcome an investigation of charges that Vietnamese Communist guerrillas were operating from Cambodian bases.
ON the blackboard in the higgledy-piggledy office of the Living Theatre, the Avenue of the Americas and Fourteenth Street, the most declamatory word is STRIKE!
A 21-year-old New York post-debutante is engaged to marry the heir-apparent to the throne of a tiny Himalayan country, it was announced here yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 27 -Eugene H. Nickerson, the Nassau County Executive-elect, said today he did not want $10,000 more a year in his new job, as has been proposed in the 1962 county budget.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Saudi Arabia accused Britain today of having perpetrated "a new set of aggressions against Oman" in the last six weeks.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Federated Department Stores, Inc., and Rike's Department Stores, its Dayton, Ohio, affiliate, were charged today with violating Federal laws prohibiting monopoly and restraint of trade.

Contracts awarded last month for construction throughout the country totaled $3,290,716,000, a decline of 1 per cent from the total of $3,319,145,000 for October, 1960. However, there was an 8 per cent gain in residential building over October, 1960.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Industrial share prices rallied after a dull start in the stock market here today. Net movements generally were small and upward.
Prices of cotton futures moved $1 a bale up to 25 cents off yesterday. July cotton showed the best gain, followed by December.
ROME, Nov. 27 -- Excavators have unearthed ruins of the Ludus Magnus, the most important of four gymnasiums in which gladiators were trained to fight in the circuses of Imperial Rome.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock, markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
GENEVA, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- George Hees, Canadian Trade and Commerce Minister, expressed alarm here today lest massive emergent international economic blocs led to world trade restrictions.

A 12,000-pound Christmas tree eighty-five feet high was lifted into place yesterday at Rockefeller Plaza. It is the tallest to stand there in at least a decade and possibly the heaviest since 1933, when the first giant tree was put up at the site.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- The United States proposed today a first step toward insuring that the exploration of space would be used for the betterment of man, not for his destruction.
The Humble Oil and Refining Company has opened a consolidated automotive repair center in Buffalo, N.Y., to enable Esso dealers in the area to offer a wider range of repair services.

George C. Sherman Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I., yesterday was re-elected chairman of the United States Polo Association at the association's seventy-first annual meeting, held at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Tuesday, Nov. 28 -- A united opposition front called a general strike today in support of an ultimatum to President Joaquin Balaguer that he resign in favor of a provisional government.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Police and private investigators have stepped up their hunt for the gang that has been drugging top racehorses.
Three more school construction employes admitted yesterday that they had accepted gifts from contractors doing business with the city school system.
CARROTS are one of the oldest vegetables known to man and they are available almost universally. They are plentiful locally twelve months a year.

An investment banking group headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday was awarded $4,000,000 of Seattle municipal improvement bonds, due from 1964 to 1982. The group bid 100.0099 with a variety of coupons, establishing a net interest cost to the borrower of 3.3477 per cent.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to file in advance of the 1962 Legislature a bill to authorize the Transit Authority to issue bonds to finance the purchase of new subway cars.

TODAY was a bread-and-butter day. The strict round of duty was rarely transcended into pleasure. However, the moments, if minor, were, I suppose, there -- though rather muffled like a spring bird singing under a top hat.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the International City Managers Association said today that Joseph McD. Mitchell, city manager of Newburgh, N.Y., had been censured for political activity, not for his controversial welfare program.

Charles Cogen, president of the United Federation of Teachers (A.F.L.-C.I.O.), which seeks to become sole bargaining agent in New York City's public schools, has reasserted vehemently the teachers' "right to strike." There is "no question" about this right, he says. He declares that the Condon-Wadlin Law, which since 1947 has forbidden strikes of governmental employes in New York State, is "unconstitutional."
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Prime Minister Macmillan appealed to industry and labor tonight to establish economic "interdependence" and to help the Government enforce a policy of wage restraint.
Stocks fell slightly yesterday on average in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. But it was far from a weak market, as many selected issues posted good gains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Barring unforeseen new obstacles, television Channel 13 in Newark will soon become the New York metropolitan area's first educational TV station.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- An angry crowd of mothers could not prevent a school bus from crossing an old bridge today, but removed their youngsters before it crossed.
Unbeaten and untied Alabama held a slight lead over once-tied Ohio State yesterday in the national college football poll of sports writers and broadcasters conducted by The Associated Press.

MERAUKE, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 27 -- Michael Rockefeller made possibly a fatal mistake in relying on an outboard motor instead of native paddlers to get him down a ten-mile coastal stretch of the Arafura Sea, a fellow anthropologist, Roger Gardner of Harvard University, said today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet Union proposed today an immediate ban, without international controls, on the testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, in space and under water.
The three leading city teacher organizations submitted documentary "proof" yesterday of their eligibility to appear on the ballot for the forthcoming collective-bargaining election.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 27 -- A three-judge Federal court directed officials of McComb, Miss., today to remove racially discriminatory signs at a bus terminal.
DUBLIN, Nov. 27 -- Talks opened here today between United States and Irish Government representatives on a revision of the United States-Irish air agreement.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 27 -- A French military bayonet that may have been used to kill a family of five here was found during a search of the victims' house, the police said tonight.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 27 -- President Tito called today on the 1,000,000 members of the Yugoslav Communist party to become better Communists or face explusion from the party.
A charitable foundation was told in Housing Court yesterday that it should display more charity to the tenants in an apartment house it owns.
Following is the text of a Soviet Government statement on the resumption of talks for a nuclear ban test, as made public yesterday by Tass, Soviet press agency:
Four major football bowls last night lined up opponents for their post-season games.
MANY single women are old-fashioned romantics who refuse to be stampeded into marriage for the sake of marriage.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 27 -- The Societe Generale de Belgique, the principal financing company behind the development of the Congo when it was a Belgian colony, will name a new management team tomorrow that will concentrate its efforts more in Europe than in Africa.
TRADITION runs deep in Poland, judging by the display of the nation's folk art that opens today at the Brooklyn Museum.
The City Planning Commission yesterday released a copy of a resolution that said the International Longshoremen's Association supported the controversial West Village urban renewal program.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- An agreement giving the United Nations force and civilian officials in the Congo full freedom of movement throughout Congolese territory was signed today by Acting Secretary General U Thant and the Congolese Foreign Minister, Justin Bomboko.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 27 -Members of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors laid the groundwork today for pay increases for themselves totaling $62,400 a year.
Jackie Kelly, a 20-year-old miniature of the late Sam Langford in appearance, if not in punching power, won the eight-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
CAIRO, Nov. 27 -- A confession attributed to a member of a French mission who is under arrest here deeply involved the Swiss Embassy today in a smuggling charge.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- Thousands of telephone workers stayed off the job today in the Bay Area in a strike called last week-end.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The grain futures market closed today under slowly mounting selling pressure and with nearly all contracts showing declines.

NAGPUR, India, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- The Marylebone Cricket Club of England built a commanding lead today, by the close of play on the second day of a three-day match against an Indian Central Zone team.
A Christmas loan from the Louvre to the Brooklyn Museum -- a small and jewel-toned painting by two Flemish seventeenth-century artist -- will be placed on exhibition Dec. 12.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 27 -- The international trust of the Swedish financier Axel Wenner-Gren will continue despite the death of its founder, it was revealed here today.

THOSE who believe that the Christmas season does not begin until after Thanksgiving can now start into high gear for yuletide shopping. Before making the big plunge, a woman has two choices: To try to buy everything in a large department store or to shop away from the crowds in a small boutique.
The Armenian General Benevolent Union will hold its annual dinner dance in the Grand Ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel on Saturday. The guest of honor will be Lucine Amara, Metropolitan Opera soprano.

Henry O. Leichter, a Democratic state committeeman, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to order Michael H. Prendergast, state chairman of the party, to throw open the committee's financial records.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, Nov. 27 -- The verdict in the trial of Adolf Eichmann will be delivered beginning Dec. 11, it was announced today.
El Al Israel Airlines is "hustling for business," Col. Shlomo Lahat, executive vice president, said yesterday.

Grandmaster Boris Spassky, the leader in the Soviet Union's national chess championship tournament being played in Baku, defeated Grandmaster Lev Polugayevsky after five hours of tense struggle, in the eighth round, according to reports from Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
Directors of American Machine and Metals, Inc., whose new name, Ametek, Inc., will become effective on Friday, increased the annual dividend rate yesterday for the twelfth consecutive year.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which includes Lord Taylor in its chain of thirty-four retail stores, attained record sales in the quarter and nine months ended Oct. 28. This was reflected in earnings higher than in 1960, Robert J. McKim, chairman, reported yesterday.

Manufacturers of chemical processing equipment rolled out several million dollars' worth of their latest wares yesterday as the twenty-eighth Exposition of Chemical Industries opened at the New York Coliseum.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 -- The Department of Justice moved here today to require the Ford Motor Company to divest itself of assets of the Electric Autolite Company that were acquired last spring for $28,000,000.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- New car sales in the middle third of November set a record for the period, it was reported today.

JIMMY SLOHM, age 9, of New Rochelle, N.Y., weighs a hefty 76 pounds with his pockets full of fishing sinkers, and standing in wet boots. He plans to be an outdoors writer, but then young men his age are excitably prone to selecting exotic jobs.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The public information officer of Wisconsin's Thirty-second National Guard Division denied today charges by Representative Alvin E. O'Konski that the Army had tried to "muzzle" the men.
The Municipal Art Society asked the city yesterday to postpone any plan to build a new city executive office building on the site of the old City Court structure just north of City Hall.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 27 -- The Supreme Court of Virginia held today that the state must maintain free public schools for all children. The opinion was given in a case that did not directly involve segregation. But it appeared to be a favorable omen for Negroes suing to reopen the public schools of Prince Edward County, which closed the schools two years ago to avoid integration.

The Football Giants emerged yesterday from their grand victory over the Cleveland Browns with one slightly injured player (battle-inflicted), one slightly injured owner (self-inflicted), a glowing tribute from their coach and a revised sign in their locker room.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Andy Pilney, under fire from disgruntled alumni and fans, resigned today as head football coach at Tulane after eight seasons, only two of them successful
Willie Naulls, the high scoring forward, will be back in the lineup tonight when the New York Knickerbockers face the Cincinnati Royals in the second game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.
POINT MUGU, Calif. Nov. 27 (AP) -- The first target rocket for the Nike Zeus antimissile missile was tested successfully Nov. 15 on Kwajalein Atoll in the Southwest Pacific, the Army disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart Udall struck another blow today at some of Washington monuments and memorials.
In an advertisement in The New York Times today, J.I. Rodale, who produced and wrote the book for "Toinette," criticizes drama critics of the city's daily newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced today the seizure here Friday of nutri-bio vitamin and mineral tablets and three othr products of the Nutri-Bio Corporation. The agency charges that the products were promoted by false and misleading labeling claims.
In a realistic approach to amateur-vs.-professional problems in college bowling, a faculty advisor of the Eastern Intercollegiate Bowling Conference, said:
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The Soviet Union's proposal to bring France into the nuclear test-ban talks was not expected to be greeted with favor by the British.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- The shareholders of the Cosmopolitan Insurance Company overwhelmingly approved today the sale of 150,000 authorized, but unissued shares, of capital stock to an investor group headed by George H. White, the secretary of Brunswick Corporation, for $4 a share.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- The West Berlin Government was reported today to have put out feelers to officials in East Berlin about the possibility of opening visa offices at the intra-city border to permit West Berliners to enter East Berlin.

"In October, things really took off," said a staid business executive to a staid group of Boston security analysts yesterday. R. Russell Pippin, treasurer of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., was speaking about his company's sales, which he estimated at $184,000,000, a record for any month.
Two brothers believed to have been connected with the numbers racket were slain last night in a small pizza-and-spaghetti shop they operated in Yorkville.

I read with interest your Nov. 20 editorial concerning cooperative apartments in our city developments, and the strange fact that despite the shortage in housing which still persists there seems to be a very sluggish demand in connection with the city cooperatives.

As Commissioner of Immigration to succeed Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Swing, President Kennedy has chosen career officer in the Immigration Service with extensive investigative experience. Raymond F. Farrell, an associate commissioner for the last three years, is a 55-year-old lawyer who was with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other agencies before joining the service in 1941.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Nov. 28 -- The General Assembly established late last night a special committee of seventeen members to check up on compliance with a year-old resolution calling for "immediate steps" to grant independence to the colonial peoples of the world.

Frozen steaks given as Christmas presents to city officials cost a construction company an $881,900 municipal contract, a court ruling disclosed yesterday. The story came to light in a decision by Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon.
Delegates to the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' twentieth annual convention visited Aqueduct yesterday. They were there primarily to see what made the new I.B.M. RAMAC 305 Computer tick.
Democrats and Republicans ended the recent city campaign with deficits exceeding $300,000 each.
The point of view expressed by Ed Ryan in his letter published Nov. 16 is an example of a threat to freedom of thought and inquiry which seems to require constant opposition.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 27 -- Vainoe Leskinen, a leading Social Democrat who is disliked by Soviet officials, shrugged off today President Urho K. Kekkonen's suggestion that he quit politics in the national interest.
A SYMPHONIC suite entitled "The Broadcaster," by Robert Maxwell, the harpist and composer of "Ebb Tide," had its world premiere last night over television station WTIC-TV in Hartford, Conn.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Edward Heath, Deputy Foreign Secretary, told a noisy House of Commons today that he greatly deplored the "breach" in secrecy arrangements he had made for Britain's negotiations for Common Market membership.

Judge Charles Marks told an assistant district attorney yesterday in General Sessions Court that he would consider whether his conduct last week had been "so disorderly," "contemptuous" or "insolent" as to constitute contempt of court.
Four high school athletes with above-average grades -- all from middle-class homes in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn -- were accused as thieves yesterday in Adolescent Court.
GENEVA, Nov. 27 -- The great industrial nations of the world set in motion today a new plan that could ultimately lead to the near elimination of tariffs on industrial products.

A message of "praise for your piety and your charity" from Pope John XXIII was brought to Roman Catholics in the United States yesterday by Cardinal Amleto Cicognani, Papal Secretary of State and former Apostolic Delegate in Washington.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Merwyn Gold, a Cleveland man wanted by United States authorities for income tax evasion, was found yesterday at an apartment in a fashionable section.

DENVER, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- The president of the American Medical Association said today the King-Anderson bill for medical care to the aged was "one of the most destructive proposals affecting the Federal-state relationship ever introduced in Congress."

Walter Lippmann, who usually appears on one television program each summer for the Columbia Broadcasting System, will make an additional appearance this year. The New York Herald Tribune columnist will discuss political issues and world affairs in a telecast on Thursday, Dec. 14, from 10 to 10:30 P.M.

A reduction in operating expenses helped the New York Central Railroad lift its net income last mouth to $4,810,574 from $215,444 in the same month a year ago. The road trimmed its expenses in October to $43,200,932 from $46,931,253 in October, 1960.
A temporary employe arrested yesterday in a men's clothing factory in Brooklyn was accused of killing two men whose bodies were found last month in an abandoned quarry in Elmira, N.Y.

The appointment of Louis F. Polk Jr. as vice president in charge of financial affairs for General Mills, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Polk, with the company since November 1960, will continue as controller.
DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- American Motors Corporation today set up a wholly-owned subsidiary to handle overseas operations of its automotive and appliance divisions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Frank Josef Strauss, West German Minister of Defense, advocated tonight "the gradual establishment of an Atlantic common market."

Giovanni Buitoni, a 70-year-old pasta manufacturer with a sense of humor and a host of friends, last night achieved a long-standing ambition -- to sing a love duet with operatic soprano Licia Albanese.

THE appointment of George Wildman Ball to the position of Under Secretary of State was a case of promoting a man when his back was turned. When the announcement was made of his succession to Chester Bowles' responsibilities, Mr. Ball was -- and still is -- in Geneva repre senting the United States at a meeting of trade ministers, part of a session of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

Sales of the Tennessee Corporation rose to $71,791,200 for the first nine months of this year from $68,851,200 for the 1960 period, but earnings declined, E.H. Westlake, chairman and president of the chemicals and minerals producer, reported yesterday.
Mayor Wagner was reported yesterday to have raised objections to the two leading candidates to succeed Carmine G. De Sapio as New York County Democratic leader.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The purposes of President Kennedy's vigorous reorganization of the Department of State seem clearly revealed by the focal points of the changes. One purpose is to strengthen and more firmly join the ties between Secretary Rusk and his Subordinates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Treasury bill rates rose sharply again on today's sales of the regular weekly issues, to their highest levels in twelve months.
The United States Committee of the World Federation for Mental Health has arranged a dinner for Dec. 12 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Some ladles married to United States Navy men of the Sixth Fleet live on the shores of the Mediterranean, which is patrolled by men-of-war manned by their husbands, and some of these wives are unhappy.

Former Deputy City Treasurer Philip H. Gilsten, dismissed by Mayor Wagner, will be questioned under oath today about the printing and distributing of primary campaign literature purporting to show that the Mayor was backed by Communist sympathizers.
The election of M. Frank Bloomenstiel as vice chairman of Bull Lines, Inc., was announced yesterday by Manuel Kulukundis, chairman of the board and executive officer of the company.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- Representatives of four Western states discussed fail-out shelters today at a civil defense meeting at the Fairmount Hotel.

The election of George Champion and B. Earl Puekett as directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was annotmced yesterday by Philip D. Reed, chairman.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin criticized today the reported agreement between President Kennedy and Chancellor Adenauer that the Western allies should seek to limit negotiations with the Russians to the Berlin problem alone.
New York may not be the most advantageous area for a potential investor in apartment real estate, according to a local realty man.
The official word yesterday on efforts to avert a strike Friday against New York's seven private bus lines was "no progress."
Joseph Green, a 31-year-old gambler, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to bribing a College basketball player to keep his team's points down in intercollegiate games.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 27 -- President Kwame Nkrumah opened a United States trade fair here today with a statement that Ghana subscribed to a "policy of positive neutralism and nonalignment" and was "against any forms of discrimination in economic matters."
MADRID, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Eastman Philharmonia Orchestra, on a European tour under auspices of the State Department, scored a big success tonight in its first appearance in Spain.
The Federal Aviation Agency has placed a $4,654,660 order with the Chrysler Corporation for twenty mobile lounges to handle airline passengers at Washington's Dulles International Airport.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 28 -- The Government expelled two British correspondents today but formally rescinded a similar expulsion order against an American newsman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- rose one-tenth of 1 per cent in October to a record, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Kennedy told the Soviet people today that they could live in peace and plenty if their Government halted its efforts to promote conspiratorial communism throughout the world.

Franz Josef Strauss, West German Minister of Defense, agreed yesterday that the Berlin dispute should be "assigned" to the United Nations if projected East-West talks provided a "negative" result. Herr Strauss said, however, that he doubted that a United Nations resolution would have any effect on Soviet actions or intentions.

Fire in an oxygen tent at City Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens, yesterday severely burned a man already critically ill of heart disease.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Greece has jumped within a year from tenth to sixth place in the listing of the world's leading mark time nations, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Americans were asked today to help collect toys for Cuban refugee children.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The United States denounced today a new Soviet proposal for a prohibition on tests of nuclear weapons without international inspection.
Five more persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week than in the same period in 1960, when 1,002 were injured, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Elmer E. Metz was named executive director of the Federal Maritime Commission in an announcement of organizational and staff changes made yesterday by Thomas E. Stakem, commission chairman.

THE winter months are big ones for the white turnip, for it is in heavy supply October through February. This is particularly fortuitous, since the vegetable is a wonderful ingredient for cold weather stews.

DAN FERRIS will be attending his fifty-fourth -- and last -- convention of the Amateur Athletic Union at Washington this week. A career of unselfish devotion to amateur sports will reach a voluntary end because the cherubic-faced honorary secretary of the A.A.U. has announced his retirement. Four years ago he tried to quit and was given honorary status, a supposed sinecure.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Further declines in corn and soybean futures dropped some contracts to their lowest levels of the season again today on the Board of Trade.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- Observers, commenting on publication by Izvestia of an interview given by President Kennedy to its chief editor, Aleksei I. Adzhubei, said tonight that the President's remarks would give the Soviet people considerable new information and stimulate some independent thinking.

FORT LEWIS, Wash., Nov 28 (AP) -- As a general and a Wisconsin Republican Congressman waged a war of words today over the Thirty-second Infantry Division, Senator William Proxmire arrived on the scene unannounced.

The Pacific Finance Corp. led the way yesterday in adjusting interest rates upward on commercial paper placed directly with investors. The move followed a rise in the average ninety-one-day Treasury bill rate yesterday to a twelvemonth high of 2.606 per cent.

The P.A.L. Ball was held last night in the Sheraton-East in an autumnal setting of feather trees in shades of pink to deep red. The fete, a benefit for the Police Athletic League, was held in the hotel's ballroom.
AFTER two years of hammering away at the building industry, exhorting it to upgrade styling, the National Design Center has driven another nail home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In his dealings with the press, President Kennedy has broken every rule in the book and got away with it.
ALGIERS, Nov. 28 -- Former Gen. Raoul Salan, reputed leader of the outlawed Rightist Secret Army Organization, was reported today to have slipped through a police dragnet.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee called today for increased technical assistance to developing nations over the next decade.
Ohio State capped a long climb by gaining the No. 1 spot yesterday in the United Press International weekly major college football ratings.
THERE is a distinct suspicion that the hum of electronics may replace the voice of the turtle in the outdoors.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 -- The tenth annual international golf championship and Canada Cup tourney will be played here on the Jockey Club Course Nov. 8-11, 1962, it was announced today.

The directors of the Cascades Plywood Corporation, Portland, Ore., have approved an offer to merge the company with the United States Plywood Corporation through an exchange of stock valued at about $20,000,000.
A bill to increase City Councilmen's salaries from $7,000 a year to $10,000 was introduced into the Council yesterday.

The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission renewed yesterday an appeal he made late last summer to have the nation's railroads receive Federal assistance in their operation of passenger trains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Kennedy started action today that would break the Democratic party's tie to silver.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- A dozen central and western New York county Democratic chairmen have voted to ask Michael H. Prendergast for his resignation as state chairman.
The eleventh annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic was held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The Congress of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine opened tonight with greetings from President Kennedy. A personal representative of Pope John XXIII was among 12,000 Catholics at the religious education session.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 26 -- Explosive tensions are building up in Ghana.
Another of the seven organizations listed by the City Planning Commission as supporting the proposed West Village project declared its opposition yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Chester Bowles said tonight that in his new job he would be working with President Kennedy "in an area of the most crucial importance to the future of our country."
Eighteen special trains, nine of them from the New York area, will carry approximately 16 per cent of the 102,000 Army-Navy game fans directly to Philadelphia Stadium on Saturday morning.

MANILA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller flew homeward tonight, convinced after his week-long search of the New Guinea jungle that only by "an outside chance, a miracle" would his son be found alive.

The stock market continued mixed yesterday. For the ninth consecutive trading session, prices churned and failed to move in a definite pattern. The end result was a minor loss on average on the New York Stock Exchange.

Make Sail, the Cain Hoy Stable's stakes-winning filly, made her last start yesterday. It was not a fond farewell, for the 13-10 favorite finished third at Aqueduct. She trailed Nicholas A. Martini's Pepper Patch and Mrs. Henry H. Hecht's Barnesville Miss in the $10,000 My Dear Handicap.
Alan Jay Lerner, the Broadway lyricist, has agreed to serve as an executive producer of the special television shows or the National Broadcasting Company.
There has been another shake-up in the top management of the General Dynamics Corporation.

BUKHARA, U.S.S.R., Nov. 18 -- The discovery of one of the world's largest known natural gas fields is rapidly transforming ancient Bukhara into something like an East Texas boom town. Soon the ancient 203-foot Tower of Death, a minaret from which criminals were thrown until 1871, may be one of the few landmarks recalling Bukhara's ancient role as a leading center of Central Asian culture and the Moslem faith.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Following is the transcript of an interview with President Kennedy by Aleksei I. Adzhubei, editor of Izvestia, as made public by the White House:
Customers who visited a new restaurant here yesterday found the waiters, waitresses, cooks and cashiers replaced by $15,000 worth of silent but effective vending machines.

William Haven (Bill) King, the versatile Dartmouth quarterback, was named the Ivy League back of the week yesterday for the second week in succession. King, who gained the honor the first time by sparking a victorious last-quarter rally over Cornell, gave an even more stirring performance against Princeton last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The State Department charged today that a Soviet agent in West Germany, posing as an American, had used romance as a lure in an effort to recruit an American woman employe of the United States armed forces there as a spy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board established today a one-year no-picketing rule in cases where it finds unions engaged in unlawful picketing after losing elections for employe bargaining rights.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- President Kennedy awarded the Harmon International Trophy for Aviators today to three test pilots of the X-15 rocket plane.
Mayor Wagner said last night the choice of a new New York County Democratic leader would be "not just a changing of the guard -- the substitution of one man for another."
A memoir by the poet-lecturer Evelyn Ames of a marriage and a way of life will be published Jan. 23 by Houghton Mifflin called "Daughter of the House."
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated today that India might eventually use force to try to wrest disputed border areas from Chinese control.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's gross revenues rose last month to $11,316,732, or $462,792 above the $10,853,940 reported for October, 1960.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 28 -- The commander of the more than 300 United States military advisers in Laos warned them today against publicly criticizing United States policy in that country or American diplomats responsible for the policy.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- The United States Army announced today that a motorized rifle company of the Third Infantry Division would travel to Berlin tomorrow along the autobahn across 110 miles of East German territory.
Expenditures in the recent city campaign exceeded $2,200,000 and may have reached $2,500,000, it appeared yesterday on the basis of reports on file with the Board of Elections.
McCOMB, Miss., Nov. 28 -- City officials said today they would cease to enforce segregation in rail and bus terminals tomorrow under terms of a Federal Court injunction.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation had record sales in the second fiscal quarter ended on Oct. 31, on slightly higher earnings than in the 1960 period. Half-year sales also climbed, but earnings failed to reach the year-earlier level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Kennedy said today that the publication in the Soviet Union of his two-hour interview with the editor of Izvestia was "a marked step forward in American-Soviet understanding."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A committee of Roman Catholic bishops suggested today that the motion-picture industry was inviting the mandatory classification of films as fit or unfit for viewing by young people.
A reconciliation appeared in the offing yesterday between Mayor Wagner and State Controller Arthur Levitt, who fought each other so bitterly in the primary for the Democratic mayoral nomination.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 -- Wayne Hardin threw oil on troubled waters today in the psychological warfare between the Navy football coach and Dale Hall, his counterpart at West Point.
A fire in a New York Central train and a subway power failure delayed New Yorkers during the rush hour yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Walter Ulbricht, East German Communist chief, charged in a recent speech that Lavrenti P. Beria, the Soviet secret police head executed in 1953, had actively opposed the building of a Communist system in East Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The General Assembly condemned South Africa's policy of racial segregation tonight after a minority of members weakened two draft resolutions demanding punitive sanctions.

The signs point to a vital decision by President de Gaulle very soon in the Algerian conflict. They do so for the simple reason that there must be a solution. The present state of affairs is close to intolerable and it is highly dangerous.
CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Signaled by almost incessant snow flurries, which only by rugged local standards failed to qualify as a full-blown storm, winter began settling in on the North Country today.

Ernie Davis, Syracuse University's star halfback, yesterday was named the winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as the outstanding collegiate football player in the country. The award is sponsored by the Downtown Athletic Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Army wants its mess halls to seem more like home, and so it has decided to feed its soldiers from dinnerware instead of divided trays.
Carry Back, who captured the Kentucky Derby and Preakness this year with sensational finishes, won the 3-year-old title of 1961 yesterday without a dissenting vote.

Former Deputy City Treasurer Philip H. Gilsten was questioned for three hours yesterday by John G. Bonomi, a special Assistant Attorney General, about the printing and distribution of campaign material purporting to show that Mayor Wagner was backed by Communist sympathizers.

The head of the World Zionist Organization called on American Zionists last night to assume a major role in overcoming what he described as the "over-organized chaos" and "bureaucratization" of American Jewish life.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 28 -- Before heading home today, Governor Rockefeller defended his son Michael's anthropological work on this jungle island and the youth's decision to attempt a perilous sea trip by raft with only an outboard motor for propulsion.
An Ardsley, N.Y., ensign, last seen alive on the West Coast on Nov. 17, has been found dead, "apparently from drowning," the Coast Guard announced yesterday.

The Putnam Growth Fund announced yesterday that the share value of its assets increased by 51 per cent for year ended on Oct. 31. Purchases of new shares aggregated $132,800,000, up 345 per cent from those of the preceding year.
TORONTO, Nov. 28 -- Tom McNeeley had a semblance of a workout today in preparation for his fight with Floyd Patterson on Monday for the latter's world heavyweight championship.

The appointment of two new vice presidents was announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation. The new officers are J.B. Copper and W.P. Jones, it was announced by W.L. Lohrentz, administrative vice president for personnel services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Kennedy will visit the Organization of American States tomorrow to emphasize his deep interest in Latin American affairs and especially in the Alliance for Progress programs for the Western Hemisphere's basic development.
The $120,000,000 complex of new and expanded roads for the World's Fair should be completed at least ninety days before the exhibition opens on April 22, 1964, officials reported yesterday.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation seized six men last night in a raid on a Brooklyn numbers bank -- the first arrests under a new Federal law forbidding the interstate transportation of gambling devices.

A committee of Boston educators who registered a protest on Nov. 10 against plans for nuclear bomb shelters have received more than 1,000 letters commenting on the protest, a member of the committee said yesterday. The protest was in an advertisement and a news article in The New York Times.

There is a possibility that the National Football League championship game will be played as late as Jan. 7. If either the Eastern or Western Conference ends in a three-way tie for first place -- and it could happen -- the title game will be staged on that date.

DETROIT, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- W. Nicholas Kerbawy, ousted as general manager of the Detroit Pistons' professional basketball team, today filed a $5,000,000 damage suit against Fred Zoliner, the owner of the National Basketball Association club.

The taxpayer containing six stores and an A. P. supermarket at 183-15 Horace Harding Expressway in Fresh Meadow, Queens, has been sold by Robert Goelet. It was bought by Morris Rokowsky, a realty investor, through Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., broker.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- As Army's football team engaged in a rugged practice today, Dale Hall predicted that the cadets would beat Navy in their traditional game at Philadelphia on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Administration plans for a Regular Army with sixteen combat divisions instead of the present fourteen were made known at the Pentagon today.

WARSAW, Nov. 28 -- Pravda, principal organ of the Soviet Communist party, has censored large sections of a speech by Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist chief, on the recent twenty-second Soviet party congress.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- For the third time this fall, France's economic life was badly crippled today by a strike in the public services.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Atlantic Refining Company announced today that it had developed a process to remove metal contaminants from catalysts used in refining oil. It said the process would ad at least $1,000,000 a year to Atlantic profits.

If this country's tariffs are to be reduced, as President Kennedy proposes, should some form of governmental compensation be made to domestic industries that might be injured by such reductions; and, if so, in what form?

State Industrial Commissioner Martin P. Catherwood reported yesterday that total unemployment in New York State had dropped to 4.9 per cent last month, the first time it had fallen below 5 per cent since October, 1960.

Warren Christopher, whose letter appeared Nov. 20, takes issue with my letter published Nov. 13. My letter dealt with a basic theme of Under Secretary of State Ball's recent speech on foreign trade which was interpreted by The Times as follows: "Most of the potential sufferers [of his plan, if implemented are relatively low-wage industries, and he [Ball] hints that they may have to consider themselves expendable in the interest of our general trade survival."

JOHN BERRY'S "Flight of White Crows"* resembles an iceberg in one respect. Part of it is bright, cheerful, shiny and attractive; but most of it seems like a sinister shadow, dark, menacing and mysterious, extending downward into unknown depths. Without question the queerest book that has crossed my path this year, it is amusing in spots, well written for the most part, ambiguously symbolical, and all too often totally mystifying.

Secretary of State Dean Rusk outlined last night four "possible areas of negotiation" with the Soviet Union where "the raw edges of our basic conflict in objectives may be to a degree dulled" and World War III averted.
A Brazilian investment fund has contracted to buy the Nassau Manor Shopping Center on Nassau Road, Uniondale, L.I., from Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The General Assembly unanimously asked the United States and the Soviet Union today to set up a body to negotiate on general and complete disarmament.
HELSINKI, Nov. 28 -- Finland's trade with the Soviet Union will increase by 25 per cent, or the equivalent of $69,300,000, next year, it was officially announced today.
Renewed buying came into the market yesterday for over-the-counter corporate debt obligations.

The Federal Maritime Commission announced yesterday approval of a proposal under which control of the nation's fourth largest subsidized shipping company would be acquired by the country's leading independent ship operator.
The Housing and Redevelopment Board has designated the entire area of the controversial Cadman Plaza Title I site in Brooklyn Heights for full taxpaying cooperative housing.

The State Investigation Commission shunted to the Legislature yesterday the responsibility of deciding whether Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino's acceptance of fees from Lancer Industries, Inc., involved a conflict of interest.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 28 -- This South Carolina capital city honored two of its residents today on what it designated "Maude and Jimmy Byrnes Day."

The latest Soviet proposal for a ban on atomic bomb tests is a polite invitation to Britain and the United States to let themselves be mouse-trapped. Come right in and see how neatly the spring snaps.
The City Planning Commission rejected yesterday a proposal by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame for a 746-car parking garage under Bryant Park.

THE new president of New York University says that he got into higher education almost by accident. But James McNaughton Hester is quick to add that "if I weren't suspectible, I wouldn't have done it."
VIENNA, Nov. 28 -- Police headquarters in Vienna reported today that nine shots were fired at the Parliament building from an automobile shortly after midnight.

The Middletown Sports Car Club will conduct a winter regularity run on Sunday, starting and finishing at Club 211 on Route 211 just outside of Middletown, N.Y. Registration will begin at noon and the first car is scheduled to start at 1:01 P.M.
More than 1,100 calls complaining about lack of heat came into special Board of Health telephones in the twenty-four hours ended at 3 P.M. yesterday, according to a board spokesman.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- Despite pleas by the leader of Italian communism, the Secretariat of the Italian Communist party has published criticism of the party for not having protested against the "harshness of the revolutionary process in the Soviet Union."
DAVID BAR-ILLAN, the Israeli pianist who only a short time ago appeared as soloist with the Berlin Philharmonic, returned to Carnegie Hall last night with a rather austere Beethoven-Schubert program.

The Board of Estimate gave unanimous approval yesterday to Mayor Wagner's promise of assistance to the seven private bus lines here if they reached a "fair and reasonable" agreement with the Transport Workers Union.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Shareholders of the Philco Corporation voted better than forty to one today in favor of selling the company to the Ford Motor Company.

CONSUELO CRESPI has given New Yorkers who frequent smart restaurants and parties a preview of the longer skirts that are expected to be shown by Paris designers in their spring collections in January.
The sale of television station WNTA-TV to an educational group collapsed last night.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, denounced President Kennedy today for his recent criticism of Right-Wing extremists.

A 37-year-old welfare recipient was denounced yesterday as "a top-flight chiseler" by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz, in Kings County Court. He was being arraigned on a charge having received illegally $6,059 in relief payments over seventeen-month period.

The H.R. Weissberg Corporation, a national realty investing company, has taken title to the Fontainebleau Motor Hotel in New Orleans and the Rio Motor Hotel in Fort Worth, Tex. Both buildings were completed recently.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov 28 -- Mr. Childs, owned by Judith and Irving Tropp of Jackson Heights, Queens, scored a two-length victory over Evergreen Jean in the Class A final of the Fall Pacing Series before 14,351 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 332,276 tons in the holiday week ended Saturday. This figure compared with 344,952 tons the preceding week and 270,596 tons in the 1960 week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
The creation of an over-all, or supreme, commander for United States commands all over the world is recommended in a secret report recently submitted to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara.

JOSEPH SCHUSTER plays the 'cello in a direct, musically vivid style that seizes the listener's attention from the first note and never lets it go. This was the case, once again, with the distinguished artist's recital in Town Hall last night. Since he had brilliant partnership at the piano from Edward Mattos, the evening was a continual pleasure.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 90 cents a bale off to 15 cents up yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 -- The investigation that the Securities and Exchange Commission is about to make on the public securities markets will not be a "flamboyant anti-Wall Street publicity venture," the head of the Federal agency pledged here today.
The Board of Superintendents of the city school system has denied official approval to the controversial film "Operation Abolition."

At least forty-seven of the fifty-two New York City mutual savings banks will begin paying 4 per cent interest on two year deposits on Jan. 1, Oren Root, State Superintendent of Banks reported yesterday.
HONG KONG, Nov. 28 -- Communist China acknowledged today that a dispute existed within the Communist bloc.

" The law is a sort of hocus-pocus science" -- Charles Macklin (eighteenth century playwright). The law is also a tool for those who use its tax provisions to advantage as they buy or sell stocks before the year draws to a close.

I feel that a correction should be offered to the conclusions of Emmett Davis in his letter published Nov. 21 concerning an experience with automated telephone services. Mr. Davis complains that he would have to dial a total of twenty-three digits in order to complete one long-distance telephone call.

YORK, Pa., Nov. 28 -- An executive of the Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company here has accused the State Department of advocating circumvention of the Buy American Act to help foreign nations at the expense of the United States economy.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Nine Negro players of the San Diego Chargers of the American Football League today were considering a request that they refuse to play in Houston on Sunday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -- Sylvia Sidney, the Broadway and Hollywood actress, sued for $350,000 damages today on the complaint that she had been "demoted" to the status of the leader of a harmonica band.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Following are highlights of President Kennedy's replies to questions amt comments by Aleksei I. Adzhubei, editor of Izvestia:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Ohio State University faculty council voted today to reject a bid to play in the Rose Bowl football game at Pasadena New Year's Day.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- French officials said today that the status of diplomats everywhere had been challenged by the action of the United Arab Republic in arresting four members of a French mission in Cairo.
John Hay Whitney, publisher of The New York Herald Tribune, won a round yesterday in his two-year battle against a garage opposite his town house at 163 East Sixty-third Street.

Most advertising agencies strive mightily to establish a distinctive personality that sets them apart from rival agencies. There is one agency, however, that has no problem on this score. It is, in all likelihood, the most unusual agency in the nation.
The domestic price of lead moved up by one-quarter of a cent a pound yesterday, reversing a downward trend defined by a two-step reduction earlier this month.

TRENTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The State Highway Department got a new Federal go-ahead today for its alignment of Route 78 through Hillside and the Weequahic section of Newark, ending a two-year holdup for the cross-state freeway.

Dr. James McNaughton Hester, 37-year-old dean of the New York University Graduate School of Arts and Science, has been elected president of the university. He will be the youngest president in the university's 130-year history.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Following are excerpts from a report made public today by a subcommittee on the situation in Angola:

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 28 -- The Dominican Republic was in the grip of a general strike today, called by a united opposition front to back demands that President Joaquin Balaguer give way to a provisional governing junta.
A breach has developed between airline and military officials who have been working to combine their interests in a single design for a new air freighter.
OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Jane Walkup Parham of Dearborn, Mich., former wife of Henry J. Kaiser Jr., filed suit yesterday for $2,500,000 from Mr. Kaiser's estate.
Brooklyn has become almost a desert town for the sports fan.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan declared today he would be happy to press for a summit conference at a suitable time.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The president of Xavier University proposed tonight that professional football subsidize college football.
Silver producers received the news yesterday that President Kennedy had halted sales of nonmonetary silver to industry with undisguised glee. Silver users received it with shocked surprise.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People attacked the movie industry today. It charged widespread discrimination in employment and grossly unfair portrayals of the Negro's role on the contemporary scene.

MADISON, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Expensive interior alterations on utility buildings on the 180-acre former Twombly Estate, now the Florham-Madison Campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University, have turned them into useful academic buildings.
The embattled owners of Greenwich Village coffeehouses won a major point yesterday in their fight to escape some of the restrictions imposed by the city on cabarets.
Marlene Dietrich's favorite film, "The Devil Is a Woman," is playing a revival engagement at the New Yorker Theatre, and Miss Dietrich wants the world to know about it.
Screen Gems, Inc., television film production and distribution concern, reported a rise in profits at its first public stockholders' meeting yesterday.

NAGPUR, India, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Needing 65 runs in twenty minutes after a surprise declaration by Central Zone of India on the last day of their match, the Marylebone Cricket Club of England failed by 7 runs today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 28 (AP) -- One of the members of the jury that failed to reach all verdict in the Freedom Rider bus burning trial four weeks ago was arrested today perjury charge.
The New York Times announced yesterday that Thomas E. Mullaney, who has been assistant financial and business editor since 1952, has been named news editor in Los Angeles of its new Western Edition.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The General Assembly elected the twenty-five members of the International Law Commission today.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Three of Britain's independent airlines were granted licenses today to operate flight on internal and Continental routes some of which are now flown by British European Airways.
The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company borrowed $30,000,000 in the public capital market yesterday through the sale at competitive bidding of thirty-year first mortgage bonds.
Most commodity futures markets were rather quiet yesterday, and small price changes were the general rule.

In Canada yesterday the Bank of Canada was reportedly in market to a certain degree to support the recently declining Canadian dollar. In New York, the Canadian dollar was quoted as low as 96.031 cents yesterday, the lowest since October, 1951, but it firmed to close at 96.093.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- President Kennedy made a surprise helicopter trip today to Central Intelligence Agency headquarters at Langley, Va., to present a National Security Medal to the agency's outgoing director, Allen W. Dulles.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 28 -- The final of three sessions of the national masters mixed pair contest was played here tonight in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament.

The Cook County, Ill., Forest Preserve District sold yesterday $2,000,000 of bonds, due from 1964 to 1973, to the First National Bank of Chicago. The bank bid 100.652 with a 2 7/8 per cent coupon, setting a net interest cost to the district of 2.7746 per cent.
SUBSTANTIAL effects of American aid to Yugoslavia were demonstrated during an informative telecast on Channel 7 last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Katangese troops dragged two senior United Nations officials away from a dinner party in Elisabethville tonight and beat them severely, it was reported here.
ROME, Nov. 28 -- Feminism suffered a setback in Italy today when the High Constitutional Court upheld a law that punishes adultery of the wife more severely than adultery of the husband.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 28 -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the only real debate in the next session of Congress would be over foreign trade.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- A United Nations inquiry committee said today that the situation in Portuguese Angola was deteriorating. Only drastic reforms will end the simmering conflict in the West African territory, the committee said.
Paul Shyre is planning a Eugene O'Neill repertory company designed along the lines once drawn by the dramatist himself.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Zenith Radio Corporation increased its quarterly dividend and declared extra dividends today. Directors declared a quarterly of 20 cents a share payable on Dec. 29 to stockholders of record of Dec. 8. This is equivalent to 60 cents a share on the old stock.
A man attempted to rob two branches of the same bank yesterday but failed both times.

Members of the Junior Committee of the American French Foundation are working on plans for a theatre party at the American premiere of the motion picture "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" at Henry Miller's Theatre on Dec. 18.
