If sheer effort and dogged determination were worth points in the National Basketball Association, the New York Knickerbockers probably would be way out front instead of way behind in the standing. Also, they would have won last night's game at Madison Square Garden instead of bowing to the Cincinnati Royals by 131 -- 117.
MERINGUE toppings for pies are often a cause of concern, but if a few simple rules are followed they should present no problem.

While the coaches of other metropolitan area schoolboy football teams were relaxing in the tranquility of completed schedules, two were busy yesterday preparing for the most important contest of the season.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 28 -- In planning the Alliance for Progress by which it hopes to achieve gradual social and economic revolution in Latin America, Washington hopes about one-third of the vast new capital funds injected into this continent will be supplied by United States industry.
DENVER, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Jonas Salk said today there were bright hopes for a single vaccine to protect against ten to 100 virus diseases.
GENEVA, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- The United States called today for "a more serious effort to provide assistance to the export industries of the less-developed countries."
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 121 -- 111, despite the 49-point scoring of Elgin Bayor, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

The American Express Company announced yesterday the election of three executives of its overseas banking department as vice presidents of the American Express Company, Inc., the foreign operations subsidiary.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Notre Dame today demanded a full hearing and ruling by the National Collegiate Athletic Association's rules committee into disputed officiating that gave the Irish a controversial 17-15 victory over Syracuse Nov. 18.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- The Security Council ended today its consideration of Cuban charges of United States aggression against the Dominican Republic without taking action.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The United Steelworkers of America asked Congress today to abolish tax advantages enjoyed by the steel industry's overseas subsidiaries.
TORONTO, Nov. 29 (UPI) -The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Montreal Canadiens played a 2-2 tie tonight and remained deadlocked for first place in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Kennedy Administration has tentatively decided to present a broad new foreign trade program to Congress in January. It will be a package of wide tariff-cutting authority combined with Federal aid for industries, workers and communities hurt by imports.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The president of the N.C.A.A. said today that if Notre Dame still wanted a review of its controversial victory over Syracuse he was certain the N.C.A.A. would try to comply.
A group fighting for control of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company accused its directors yesterday of having courted favor with City Hall and the Transit Workers Union at the stockholders' expense.
Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said yesterday that since 1957, Negroes had been assured of equal employment opportunities on the waterfront.
BRASILIA, Nov. 29 -- The Chamber of Deputies passed today a bill to curb drastically foreign investments, foreign banking here and money sent abroad.
Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The Air Force today announced an insignie for "pilot-astronauts," and established fifty miles above the earth as the point at which astronautics begin.
MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Nassau County's proposed record budget for 1962 was attacked at public hearings here today before the Board of Supervisors.

The Taylor Wine Company and Great Western Producers, Inc., announced yesterday that they had completed an agreement for the transfer of Great Western's winery and Scotch whisky import division to Taylor for 300,000 shares of Taylor common stock.

REFRESHMENTS were awaiting the Giants when they filed aboard their chartered plane in the Cleveland airport late Sunday afternoon after administering a soul-satisfying trouncing to the Browns, 37 to 21. Orders had been issued to the stewardesses. Nothing was to be served to club officials, newspaper men and hangers-on until after the heroes had had their fill.
The Baltimore Colts may not have much to show in the victory column but they've taken over first place in team defense in the National Football League.
PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- Two American newsmen traveling with Governor Rockefeller unwittingly bought two native women, a Dutch official reported today.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- A snow storm blanketed upstate New York and northern New England today with drifts up to five feet deep. A cold snap hit southern New England.
ALGIERS, Nov. 29 -- At least nine Moslems and a European were killed in communal clashes in Oran today. The number of injured was given as thirty-one, including four Europeans.
HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 30 -- The air search for Michael Rockefeller, missing in the Arafura Sea, was called off today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest industrial concern, was accused today of anti-Negro discrimination.
Prices of United States Government securities closed practically unchanged yesterday after a rumor wiped out early gains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Congress will be asked in January for a broadened civil defense program with the emphasis on group fall-out shelters, President Kennedy said today.
TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner called on New Jersey's 523 municipal court judges today to support a move to consolidate their courts into twenty-one at the county level.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Kennedy expressed the hope today that reservists called to active duty in the recent military build-up would be released before their twelve-month obligation expired.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Battle lines were being sharply drawn tonight for the impending struggle over baseball's controversial bonus problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A House subcommittee on Un-American Activities, investigating communism among radio engineers, got a string of fifth Amendment pleas today from Leonard Lazar, identified by committee counsel as an employe of the American Broadcasting company.

The Department of Justice has given the green light to the plans of four large Florida banks to form a bank holding company, it was learned yesterday. If approved by the Federal Reserve Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission, the holding company will have total assets of $671,000,000 and capital funds of more than $52,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, raised today the possibility of a $200,000,000 United Nations bond issue to meet the growing deficits incurred by the United Nations forces in the Congo and in the Gaza Strip.

An unusual sort of opera was staged last night at Carnegie Hall. Its musical score was very much in the American idiom; its libretto was casual and folksy. Most of the recitatives were delivered by a radio announcer and there wasn't a coloratura or a basso in the house.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., realty operators, have resold the vacant five-story dwelling at 209 East Eighty-third Street, which they bought two months ago. The house has been purchased by a client of Arthur D. Emil, lawyer.

David Sackson, violinist; George Koutzen, 'cellist, and John Wummer, flutist, took turns at Judson Hall last night in playing a sonata by Bach. Joseph Wolman played the cembalo parts on the piano for all three. The program ended with the Trio Sonata from Bach's "Musical Offering."
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The Treasury announced tonight that Britain was repaying an additional 50,000,000 ($140,000,000) of the $1,500,000,000 she borrowed from the International Monetary Fund in August.
It will be a curious legacy Governor Meyner leaves the State of New Jersey if the legal cloud he has raised kills the proposal for an educational television channel.
Drivers and helpers last night voted to strike against the private carting industry when their present contract expires at midnight tonight.
A Louisiana shipyard signed contracts yesterday with two New Orleans-based lines for the construction of six large dry-cargo vessels at a total cost of $48,648,000.

DENVER, Nov. 29 -- Dr. Peter Marshall Murray of New York City, the only Negro member of the governing body for the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, paid tribute to the association for easing racial tensions as he retired from the house here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said tonight that the Federal Bureau of Investigation would make a complete investigation of today's outbreak of violence at McComb, Miss. His statement follows:

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 29 -- The general strike called by a united opposition front to back demands for the resignation of President Joaquin Balaguer continued today despite efforts by the Government to break it.
A former president of a small upstate bank who allegedly concealed the embezzlement of $50,000 over twenty years by not taking a day off was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury.
The Boston Fund recorded quarter-end highs in net assets and share value for the period ended on Oct. 31, according to the quarterly report released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A group of American and Soviet women urged their Governments today to lessen world tensions by resolving the German crisis by negotiations and by admitting Communist China to the United Nations.

As a Catholic I find I'm in agreement with your editorial "School Aid: Action Plan." The irrelevant religious issue torpedoed the school-aid bill in the last session of Congress largely by the action of the Catholic Church, which is now bringing its "big guns" (its Bishops) to bear on the next session, either to rule or ruin the bill.

" The Murderers," an account of the battle against narcotics gangs by Harry J. Anslinger and Will Oursler, had been scheduled for publication this month. However, it will be issued Jan. 4 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy.
Meredith Willson will adapt the 1947 movie "Miracle on 34th Street" into a Broadway musical. He is writing the book, music and lyrics for the show, which is scheduled to open here in May, 1963.

THE interesting fact that emerges, unsaid, from "The Muckrakers,"* is that all but one of the magazines where these articles originally appeared have disappeared from the newsstands. McClure's, Collier's, Everybody's, American, Hampton's, Appeal to Reason and The Independent are gone. Cosmopolitan is still around, but it is one of the used-to-be publications, now addressed to the young marrieds or unmarrieds or whatever the panacea is called this month.

TAKING the children home to grandmother's house for the holidays may involve flying across half or all of a continent. Particularly since the advent of jet aircraft, distance is less of a drawback to uniting families than it used to be.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
Your Nov. 18 editorial deserves the immediate attention of all groups who support Federal aid to education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Kennedy was wide of the mark today when he commented that W. Averell Harriman, newly appointed Assistant Secretary of State, had probably held as many important jobs as any American except John Quincy Adams.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Following are the main points from President Kennedy's news conference today:
Mayor Wagner accused the Public Service Commission yesterday of "fattening the profits" of the Consolidated Edison Company and demanded that the P.S.C. be reorganized or abolished.
CHICAGO, Nov 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Administration has decided to open negotiations with Yugoslavia for the sale of some of our surplus food stocks, a move which presages continuation of the aid program to that country. Widely publicized United States resentment at the Yugoslav position at last September's Belgrade conference of nonaligned nations had appeared to threaten the continuation of our help, a prospect particularly disturbing to the Yugoslavs because of this year's drought-reduced grain production.

The end of the New York horse racing season probably means that this area's dog shows will see no more of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Hunt of Miami Springs, Fla., for a while. Hunt is a horse trainer by vocation and a dog follower by avocation.
Stocks milled around yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and closed with a small loss on average.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company increased its sales and profits in the final quarter of the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, according to the results reported yesterday in the preliminary annual statement.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Phil David Fine, Deputy Administrator of the Small Business Administration, said here today that there were not ten people in the United States who were capable of running a small business investment company.
WHO said that "Sunday in New York" was naughty? Some morning newspapers are more lurid.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 -- The Government closed the Caracas headquarters of the Communist party and the Movement of the Revolutionary Left today in the wake of a series of disorders organized by students.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A visit to Venezuela and Colombia in December is tentatively planned by President Kennedy. The White House said tonight a final decision on the trip would be made next week.

Production of electric power dipped to 15,330,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the holiday week ended Saturday, ending a six-week advance, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. This figure compares with 15,678,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 13,884,000,000 kilowatt-hours a year ago.
The Committee of French-American Wives has arranged a Christmas bazaar and cocktail party for Dec. 8 in the Palm Room of Longchamps, Manhattan House.
Joseph M. Mazer, an idustrialist, was the guest of honor last night at the first Annual Award Dinner of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, held at the Pierre Hotel.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 29 -- One Indian soldier of the United Nations Congo force was killed and another was missing as violence continued today after an attack on two high United Nations officials by Katanga troops.

HOUSTON, Nov. 29 -- New Yorkers won both the men's and womens master's team contests after three sessions of play in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Shamrock Hilton Hotel here today.

THE best place to find Polish foods in New York is in the vicinity of St. Mark's Place and First Avenue. In a physical sense, it bears little resemblance to Old Warsaw, yet there is probably no greater concentration of Polish-style gastronomy in the United States.

Just as the New York Football Giants had suspected, Paul Hornung will be on the receiving end of a long pass from the Army this week-end. He will carry it from Fort Riley, Kan., to Milwaukee, where he will try to score for the Green Bay Packers in Sunday's big game with the Giants.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Considering that three decades ago there wasn't a basketball team on suburban Long Island representing a four-year college, the sport has made amazing strides in Nassau County.
GREENWOOD, Miss., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Mississippi Citizens Council leader said today that several Southern communities were forming "minutemen" organizations to meet integration attempts.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Anxiety in both the Conservative and Labor parties over the effects of Britain's projected entry into the European Common Market erupted in the House of Commons today.
EASTBOURNE, England, Nov. 29 -- British business men began today an intensive, three-day exploration of the possibilities and best methods of increasing their exports to Continental Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A lawyer for Howard Hughes said today that the Hughes Tool Company was ready to advance financial aid to Northeast Airlines, provided the way was cleared for Hughes Tool to acquire control of the line. Mr. Hughes owns Hughes Tool.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Kennedy indicated today that he had some second thoughts about his past criticism of Government officials for the loss of China to the Communists.
Dr. Clarence Cottam, a conservationist who has been an outspoken critic of Federal pesticide-spraying programs, received the National Audubon Society's ninth Audubon Medal last night.

All ski instructors are handsome, rugged and talented musicians (with an accordion); all girl skiers are pretty and dance as gracefully on skis as Ginger Rogers does on her feet, and a Ski Dek, a moving slope that provides a fabulous, new world of indoor sport, is a barrel of fun.
Lehigh University's football team, which captured seven of its nine games this season, yesterday was named the winner of the Lambert Cup, emblematic of Eastern small-college supremacy.
NEWARK, Nov. 29 -- Officials of the Regional Plan Association today took a look into the future of the northern New Jersey area and predicted a population growth of 3,000,000 by 1985.
GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- Most of the major trading nations of the world moved tonight toward unanimous approval of a three-part decision aimed at attacking the three worst bottlenecks in trade.
More than half of the Kings County Republican Committee's campaign fund was handed out as cash payments to district captains and poll watchers on the Saturday before the election last Nov. 7.
GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- The United States and Britain assailed the Soviet Union today for proposing another uncontrolled moratorium on nuclear testing.
A small rubbish fire in the Times Square subway station was discovered yesterday before 5 A.M. and quickly extinguished.
Governor Rockefeller ended his long journey home last night, tired and drawn.

The price of silver jumped on the New York and London markets yesterday in the wake of President Kennedy's order halting sales of non-monetary silver to industry. Stocks of silver producers were bid up sharply on New York and regional stock exchanges.
Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., advertising agency, has leased five floors in the Pan Am Building under construction on a site at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal on the north.

Facing another deadline tonight, the Communist party of the U.S.A. reaffirmed yesterday that its officers "decline to sign or supply the information called for" in a Federal form for registering as an arm of the Soviet Union.

WITH the twinkle that rarely dies from his green eyes, the Marine chosen yesterday as the country's first man to try orbital flight in space once put it this way when asked why he had volunteered for astronaut duty: "I figured it would probably be the nearest I'd ever get to heaven."

POTSDAM, N.Y., Nov. 29 -While what local weather commentators described as snow "flurries" were whitening the frosty air outside, Clarkson Tech's unbeaten hockey squad took the ice today for its final hard workout before week-end home games against Yale and Loyola University of Montreal.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- French economic life returned to normal today after yesterday's crippling strikes in the public services. But the conflict between the Government and its employes remained as sharp as ever.

The board of directors of the Wheeling Steel Corporation reduced the quarterly dividend by 25 cents a share yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents on the common stock. It is payable on Jan. 2 to stockholders of record of Dec. 8 and compares with 75 cents a share disbursed in previous quarters.
The city's pier development program was attacked yesterday by State Senator Ernest I. Hatfield. The Poughkeepsie Republican is chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Docks in New York City.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) lent a total of $48,400,000 yesterday, continuing its financial assistance to highway construction in Japan and farm development in Kenya.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- President Kennedy said at his news conference today that there could be no real lessening of East-West tensions until there was a "negotiated and mutually satisfactory agreement in regard to Berlin and Germany."

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- Six church leaders, including a Methodist layman from New York, were named today to head the World Council of Churches until its next assembly in 1967 or 1968. Their election tomorrow is regarded as a certainty.
Unbeaten and untied Alabama can clinch the triple crown of defense when it meets Auburn in its season finale this Saturday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Gen. Robert R. Neyland and the National Collegiate Athletic Association ruled officially today that Notre Dame's controversial 17-15 football victory over Syracuse on Nov. 18 was made on an illegal play.
The apprehension of a man described by the city as one of its most-wanted slum landlords was turned over to the police yesterday.
BARTOW, Fla., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The second murder-plot trial of former Judge Joseph A. Peel Jr. ended today when he changed his plea to no defense and was sentenced to life imprisonment.
The Estonian-born violinist Evi Liivak gave her first New York recital in almost eight years last night at Town Hall. Her accompanist was her husband, Richard Anschuetz.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- President Kennedy looked on today as John A. McCone, Los Angeles industrialist, was sworn in as director of the Central Intelligence Agency at a White House ceremony.

Governor Rockefeller will announce soon a revised policy for processing grievances for the state's 110,000 employes, the Joint Legislative Committee on Industrial and Labor Conditions was told yesterday.
A limited revival of the city's long-dormant towaway program and increased powers for the meter maid corps were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
With merger almost desperately on its mind, the New York Central Railroad Company evidently cannot decide just which way to turn.

In her Nov. 22 letter Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, chairman of the Communist Party of the U.S.A. and self-styled defender of our Constitution and Bill of Rights, appeals for your support in her present predicament. She compares her situation to the return of Molotov to a hostile Moscow.

On the penultimate day of racing in this state, when the less hardy declined to battle the cold and the more frugal decided to save their dollars until the horses return next March, 22,410 die-hard improvers of the breed turned out at Aqueduct yesterday.

Brooklyn Tech's Engineers, coupling an adequate offense with a stout defense, defeated DeWitt Clinton, 13 -- 2, and retained the Public Schools Athletic League football title yesterday before 8,000 at Downning Stadium on Randalls Island.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The price of silver on the London market rose today to its highest point in more than forty years.
Cocoa futures dominated trading for the third consecutive day on the commodity exchanges here yesterday.
I have read with great interest and complete agreement your Nov. 7 editorial "Combat Troops to Vietnam?"
Edward N. Costikyan, East Side district leader, received substantial support yesterday as a compromise choice to succeed Carmine G. De Sapio as New York County Democratic leader.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- A United States Army convoy or one company reached West Berlin without incident today after a "motor march" across the 110 miles of East German territory between the city and West Germany.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 29 -- Chancellor Adenauer pledged today West Germany's readiness to assume the sacrifices and risks involved in defending what President Kennedy has described as the Western Allies' three vital interests in Berlin.

Events today: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic Preview Concert, Josef Krips, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Composers' Showcase, Music of Revueltas and Riegger, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Two officials of the International Longshoremen's Association were sentenced to thirty-day terms in jail today and fined $50 each for refusing to obey a court order that they answer questions put to them by the Bi-state Waterfront Commission.
The nation's output of crude petroleum and refined products increased again last week as inventories of major products showed moderate seasonal changes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 29 -- All Syrian political factions except Communists and organized supporters of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic will run candidates on Friday in an election whose campaign has been one of the freest the Middle East has seen in years.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad declared today a dividend of 25 cents a share on the 13,167,154 shares outstanding.

Your Nov. 20 editorial regarding the choice of a successor to the late Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn emphasizes the importance of choosing a strong man for that job. It will not be easy to find anyone with the stature of Mr. Rayburn, who was admired and respected by all who knew him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- George Meany suspended today the Cleveland Federation of Labor and appointed a trustee to conduct its affairs.

Valerian S. Zorin, the Soviet Representative to the United Nations, and the envoys of the Ukraine and Bulgaria stalked out of the Astor Hotel ballroom last night during a speech by Vice President Johnson detailing Western successes in the "cold war."
TORONTO, Nov. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Lake Ontario Portland Cement Company, Ltd., had an estimated net profit of $900,000 in the year ended
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Administration is planning to lift one of its travel curbs on some Communist diplomats and correspondents at the United Nations.

Gilbert W. Fitzhugh has been appointed executive vice president and George P. Jenkins financial vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday by Frederic W. Ecker, chairman. Both will assume their new posts on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Representative Charles S. Joelson, Democrat of New Jersey, said today that he had asked Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Starr Jr. to investigate off-duty hazing of recruits by fellow soldiers.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Apmat, an Australian-bred gelding, and Irvin Paul comprise the entry that is favored at 7-5 to produce the winner in tomorrow night's $25,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. The Nassau will be the highlight of the final evening of harness racing in New York this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- President N.J. Barack of the Amateur Athletic Union said today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association was engaged in "a grab for power" that could wreck amateur athletics in the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UPI) -Bobby Hull of the Black Hawks scored a goal in each period tonight as the Chicagoans gained a 7-4 victory over the Boston Bruins. It was the Hawks' highest score of the season.
PERRY COMO and his company took time off last night and were replaced by an attraction entitled "We The People -- 1961" on Channel 4.

A WIG or even a wardrobe of them is becoming as important to a woman as a wardrobe of clothes. Once relegated to theatrical circles, the wig is now popular with many women who sit on the far side of the footlights.
As a project architect on a New York City Housing Authority commission for my employer I feel qualified to shed additional light on your editorial of Nov. 20 "A Housing Puzzle."

WARSAW, Nov. 29 -- Informed sources said today that Jerzy Kornacki, a Marxist novelist whose arrest two months ago caused a sensation in Polish intellectual circles, has been ordered to stand secret trial.

THE Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, the world-traveling evangelist, was the subject of a television portrait last night on the network of the National Broadcasting Company. It was a personality profile of considerable interest if not too much dimension.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Army's football team and coaching staff are being subjected to greater pressure than usual to win Saturday's game with Navy.

American policy in Laos has often suffered from conflicting action by agents of different branches of the United States Government. In Vientiane the embassy at times has pursued one program, Pentagon men another and Central Intelligence operatives still another.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- United States and Soviet delegates told the United Nations today that their Governments had begun working on the formation of a body to negotiate for world disarmament.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The grain futures market showed little change today. Prices again shifted within small fractions of preceding closes in quiet trading on the Board of Trade.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The proposed Administration program would be more effective than criticism in relieving the welfare situation, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said today.
Hope of averting a strike on seven private bus lines at midnight tonight ebbed yesterday after a City Hall meeting of negotiators, Mayor Wagner and other city officials.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved $1.20 a bale off to 15 cents up yesterday. Near December was the weakest month.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 29 -The leader of 3,500,000 craft unionists assailed Walter P. Reuther today as "treacherous and vindictive" and accused him of trying to "kidnap" the jurisdiction of the building trades unions.
A $5,662,000 offer by the Union Bag-Camp Paper Corporation to purchase Doeskin Products, Inc., was rejected yesterday by Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri.
The city Labor Department said last night the three major teacher organizations that had been recommended for inclusion on the collective bargaining ballot had qualified for the election.

In recent months, many important Madison Avenue figures have become increasingly blunt in expressing their distrust for President Kennedy's New Frontier. Several agency presidents have accused leading Administration officials of having a bias against advertising and of failing to understand the economic role of their industry.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 -- It's difficult for any other sport to attract attention here on the eve of the Grey Cup football championship. The world heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Tom McNeeley is to be held here Monday night, but its allure has been dimmed by the football game, which will be held Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A Congressional study of how to keep the capital from strangling itself with Federal agencies and their personnel started today.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- The Democratic legislative leaders predicted today that the 1962 Legislature would redraw the state's Senate and Assembly District lines to continue and even augment the Republicans' "undeserved majorities."
Otto Preminger's hectic race to open "Advise and Consent" before Christmas to qualify for this year's movie awards has been halted abruptly by the New York County Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A woman reporter's assault on masculine exclusiveness at the National Press Club won sympathy from President Kennedy today.

Hugh A. Grant's Airmans Guide, overcoming ailments at 2 and 3 years of age that would have sidelined many a horse, was named the 1961 handicap champion in the filly-and-mare division yesterday by the Thoroughbred Racing Association board of selection.
DENVER, Nov. 29 -- The possibility that a common disease called rheumatoid arthritis might be caused by a virus was raised here today at the American Medical Association's clinical meeting.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Foreign Minister of Communist China, indicated in Peiping tonight that Albania could continue to count on Chinese support in her dispute with Moscow.
The warmth with which President Kennedy reacted at his press conference to grumblings and complaints from mobilized Guardsmen and Reservists is not only understandable but justified.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 29 -- A male chimpanzee named Enos flew two 17,500-mile-an-hour orbits around the earth today.

Aaron Wagman, a 28-year-old gambler described by the District Attorney's office as "one of the big fixers" in the college basketball scandal, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to thirty-eight counts of conspiracy and bribery of players.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 29 -- New Jersey farmers, having experienced three years of moderate increases in farm income, can expect slightly lower cash receipts in 1962, according to a Rutgers University expert.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Shares of companies engaged in silver mining were outstandingly firm in the stock market here today. Strong speculative buying came in the wake of the announcement by the United States that it is to end its stockpile sales of silver, and on the resultant rise in the price of silver bullion.
It will be Baylor University of Waco, Tex., against Utah State's undefeated football team in New York's first Gotham Bowl game at the Polo Grounds on Dec. 9.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- President Kennedy's interview with the editor of Izvestia received high praise in Western Europe today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Dr. Willard F. Libby said tonight that the Geneva nuclear test ban conference became a "meaningless, hopeless" road to stalemate six months after it began three years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Britain denied today Arab charges of aggression against a separatist movement in the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman in the southeast of the Arabian Peninsula.
An apartment house owner sued in Supreme Court yesterday to bar the city from carrying out the Tompkins Square urban renewal project.
Public cooperation is helping to reduce the number of attacks on policemen making arrests, Deputy Police Commissioner James F. Walsh said yesterday.
A Federal census every five years, instead of every ten, was advocated yesterday by Mayor Wagner and other officials at a Congressional hearing.
DENVER, Nov. 29 (AP) -An eye specialist discounted today most of the beliefs about eyes, which he said mothers had been laying down as law to their children.

Two collectors of primitive art are sharing a museum spotlight. Both are trustees of the Museum of Primitive Art, where their show is being held, and both are publicly exhibiting some of their prize pieces for the first time.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Cassius Clay stopped Willi Besmanoff at 1:05 of the seventh round tonight for his tenth consecutive victory since turning professional.

CAIRO, Nov. 29 -- Cairo newspapers said today that investigations by security police into French "spy ring" arrests could lead to formal indictments of "criminal complicity with intent to overthrow the regime" of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

A motor hotel consisting of an eleven-story building and a seventeen-story one is planned at 426-40 West Fifty-seventh Street and 423-37 West Fifty-sixth Street, a site running through the block between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

In twenty-five years -- less two months -- as fiscal agent for the Federal Home Loan Bank System, Everett Smith has sold $14,008,250,000 of the system's bonds. This amounts to about $10,000,000 a week.

Two city agencies urged the City Planning Commission yesterday to expedite approval of the $100,000,000 industrial development of the Washington Street wholesale fruit and vegetable market area on the Lower West Side.

MONTREAL, Nov. 29 (Canadian Press) -- St. Lawrence Seaway officials said today the waterway probably would have to remain open three or four days past the scheduled closing to clear all the outbound vessels from the Great Lakes.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- President Kennedy's interview with Aleksei I. Adzhubei, editor of the Government newspaper Izvestia, was read with great interest in Moscow today. Ordinary Muscovites seemed to think that publication of the interview was a good idea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Gov.-elect Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey said today he believed there would be an appointment by the Kennedy Administration for Robert B. Meyner, his predecessor.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- An odd and rather suspect stranger came here yesterday, wearing a wig and a period costume.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League defeated the Providence Reds, 3 -- 1, tonight in an exhibition game for the benefit of the New Jersey Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

Members of the board of trustees of the Samaritan Home for the Aged are completing arrangements for a theatre party on Tuesday. They have chosen the performance that evening of "A Man for All Seasons" at the ANTA Theatre in place of the originally scheduled "A Cook for Mr. General," which closed recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 22:

HAVANA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro promised last night that death sentences would be imposed within forty-eighty hours on prisoners taken in any new invasion or counter-revolutionary plot against his regime.
McCOMB, Miss., Nov. 29 -- A mob of cursing whites, shouting "Kill 'em! Kill 'em!" set upon five Negro Freedom Riders today and drove them from the Greyhound bus station.

In the most belligerent statement he has made so far, Prime Minister Nehru announces that India is strengthening its military position in a dozen places along the disputed Indian-Chinese border not only to prevent further Chinese Communist incursions but to prepare "effective action to recover the lost territories" seized by Chinese Communist troops.

ADMIRERS of John D. MacDonald's brass-knuckled yarns of crime and sex will find two of his characteristics bolstering but not redeeming "Man-Trap," a second-rate melodrama that opened yesterday on the circuits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today that the Air Force would buy one commercial Boeing 707 turbofan jet plane, costing close to $5,000,000, for President Kennedy's use.
Strong demand for a $25,000,000 issue of bonds of the Kingdom of Belgium to be offered today on a 5.70 per cent yield basis pushed the price to a premium in trading yesterday on a when-issued basis.
Mississippi sold two issues of bonds totaling $11,855,000 yesterday to an investment banking group headed by the First National City Bank of New York.

A luxury apartment building, a ten-story motel and an office building are being planned for the area north of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets.
IF there is a home designer or craftsman working within the boundaries of California, Elizabeth F.G. Hanson has no intention of letting him remain anonymous.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals struck early and beat the Cincinnati Royals, 136 -- 122, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

There seems no longer any possibility of a basic settlement of the bus dispute before the strike deadline at midnight tonight. The only way to keep the buses running is apparently to extend the old contract, with a guarantee that any improvements eventually agreed on will be paid retroactively by the private lines, which will presumably be helped out of their hole by the city.

The Cerro Corporation, one of two of the world's largest silver producers, will benefit from the increased price of the metal, Robert T. Koenig, president, told shareholders at a special shareholder meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Fresh from his latest triumph, the masterly use he made of the opportunity given him by the Government newspaper of the Soviet Union to inform literate Russian people directly of the Kremlin's responsibility for the existing tensions in international affairs, President Kennedy today felt obliged by a news conference question to deal with a somewhat less important situation.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 -- Shimon Peres, Israel's Deputy Minister of Defense, said in the Knesset today that Israel had received assurances from the Fabrique Nationale in Belgium that it had not supplied submachine guns of Israeli design to Portugal.

Mayor Wagner and Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, participated in the formal dedication yesterday of station WUHF. The experimental ultrahigh-frequency station began operating here a few weeks ago on Channel 31.
DENVER, Nov. 29 (UPI) -The A.M.A. wound up a policy meeting today with an attack on a surgeon's group and a pledge of renewed struggle against Government medical proposals.
ANNAPOLIS, Mr., Nov. 29 -It took Wayne Hardin a year to become fully indoctrinated in Navy football after he had joined the coaching staff here.
BERLIN, Friday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The United States Army began a new movement of troops along West Berlin's Autobahn lifeline today despite a Soviet warning of "dangerous consequences."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced action today aimed at making it illegal to adulterate peanut butter with ingredients not derived from peanuts, other than salt and sweeteners.
The case of an 18-year-old youth who had been in jail for more than a year on an automobile theft charge finally has been dismissed.

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- The less developed nations of Asia and Latin America, supported by the United States, failed today in an effort to persuade the European Economic Community to give up its special preferential tariff arrangements for the tropical products of its African associates.
A GIFTED and humane storyteller, Morris L. West, has turned to the stage with notable results. In "Daughter of Silence," fashioned from his own novel, he has produced a richly satisfying drama.

Events today: "Turnadot," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Josef Krips, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Claire Kroyt, viola and viola d'amore player, and Miron Kroyt, pianist and harpsichordist, Town Hall, 5:30; Galina Vishnevskaya, soprano, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; Beveridge Webster, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Hugh Gaitskell, Labor party leader, made important changes today in the top posts of his shadow Cabinet, which would rule in the event of a Laborite electoral victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Construction activity picked up slightly in November because of strength in home building, the Commerce Department said today.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Passenger car production this week will be the highest in almost two years, Automotive News reported today.
The ancient Jewish festival of Hanukkah, symbolizing the quest for religious freedom over the centuries, starts at sundown tomorrow. It will be observed for eight days.

The Housing and Redevelopment Board announced yesterday that a contract would be signed Monday for the construction of a middle-income cooperative for 431 families at Riverside Drive West and 158th Street.

THERE are few birds more delicious than a duck. And the plump young specimens at local markets are not only tender and succulent, but also generally quite inexpensive. Although 49 cents a pound is the most frequent price supermarket specials for the holiday season often bring the cost down to about 39 cents a pound.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- Premier Khrushchev was reported today to have ridiculed a theory held in the West, that an increasingly educated Soviet society might in the future reject communism as a way of life.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Curtis Harry Bingham of Los Angeles is the new president of the Investment Bankers Association of America because his trade associates believed it was necessary to keep the management of the influential trade group in the hands of a conscientious and energetic executive deeply rooted in the securities business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary of of the Treasury Douglas Dillon warned Latin America today that "the hope of the hemisphere can be betrayed if we assume that the Alliance for Progress is no more than a loan program."
Macy's Herald Square is offering instant information to harried Christmas shoppers in need of store directions or in doubt about where to buy a specific item of merchandise.

HOUSTON, Nov. 30 -- Play continued tonight in the principal masters' team contest of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament here. The fifty-six teams in the contest began play last night, and the championship will be decided in two sessions tomorrow.
The Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem will benefit from the only joint concert here this season of violinist Yehudi Menuhin and his sister, Hephzibah Menuhin, the pianist, at Town Hall Thursday.

SEATTLE, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire said today that "many things are wrong" in the call-up and training of Wisconsin's Thirty-second Infantry Division, but that the Army was making a sincere effort to rectify them.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -- A group of United States Senators indicated here today that the Alliance for Progress program was still not off the ground as far as Latin-American action was concerned.
Vice President Johnson said yesterday that he saw "no reason to protect the Communists from the truth."
The Procter Gamble Company put Madison Avenue in a lather yesterday by announcing a series of account shifts for its detergent products.
A theatre party has been arranged by friends of Hamilton-Madison House at the Dec. 15 performance of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." The play is at the 46th Street Theatre.

Your editorial policy on New Jersey's only VHF TV station, Channel 13, has consistently overlooked essential elements that reflect the total support of governmental, business, educational, labor, agricultural and citizen groups in New Jersey's fight to retain its only allocated VHF television station.
WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 30 -- At Roosevelt Raceway tonight 28,022 students of pickmanship watched Stormy Dream win the $25,000 Nassau Pace and wagered a near-record $2,706,275 on the nine-race program.

Verdi's comic opera "Falstaff," the first of four Showcase Productions this season by A.G.M.A. (the American Guild of Musical Artists), will take place at Hunter College Playhouse at 7:30 P.M. on Sunday, Dec. 10.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Carl Kaysen, former Harvard economics professor, was named today to replace Walt W. Rostow as the President's Deputy Special Assistant for National Security Affairs.
AMONG the many problems facing parents and teachers is the high incidence of teen-age smoking. Until recently smoking was treated solely as a discipline problem.
The price of zinc is heading upward today for the first time since last January.
ALGIERS, Nov. 30 -- The bombing this morning of five cafes in the center of Algiers frequented by European Rightists was interpreted as a warning to the Secret Army Organization.

SARDINIAN handcrafts that reflect a renaissance of ancient art are making their New York debut today. A long way from their natural habitat off the west coast of Italy, these one-of-a-kind items make a colorful splash on Altman's fifth floor between the carpet and housewares departments.

An $8,950-a-year electrical inspector, forty-one years in his department, was dismissed yesterday by Armand D'Angelo, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. The inspector had been carged with accepting $80 in graft.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 30 -- The recent sale of a Rembrandt to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for $2,300,000 appeared to have a side effect today at Hofstra College's Walt Whitman Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The United States wiped out today special travel restrictions that sharply limited the movement in New York of some newsmen and nondiplomatic personnel from Communist countries at the United Nations.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The era of wild and lavish spending for untried baseball talent is expected to end within a matter of hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today the award of a $65,000,000 contract to General Dynamics Corporation and then said a short time later that the award had been delayed. An Air Force spokesman said a delay in the award was caused by a fire at the Wright-Patterson (Ohio) Air Force Base that resulted, he said, in a loss of some records.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- George Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation, is considering a bid for the Michigan governorship.

Four near-by New Jersey college basketball teams will have something extra to shoot for this season. Seton Hall, St. Peter's, Upsala and Fairleigh Dickinson have banded with Rider College of Trenton and will play under the aegis of the Garden State Intercollegiate League.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 -- An Atlas booster rocket for the next Project Mercury flight -- probably the nation's first attempt to put a man in orbit -- was flown here during the night.
The Holland-America Line yesterday named John Reurs Jr. to the post of passenger traffic manager.

JULIE HARRIS was television's ranking figure last night. Her performance in "Victoria Regina," impeccably revived under the auspices of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame," was a work of flowing ecstasy and poingnancy, possibly the finest of her many contributions to theatre on television.
THE inducement to buy antiques is constantly present in New York. They beckon in shop windows and tempt in friends' homes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Defense Department has undertaken a nation-wide campaign in behalf of National Guardsmen and other reservists to protect them against job discrimination and price and rent cheating.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 -- The San Francisco Symphony Orchestra has opened its fiftieth anniversary season without a contract.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- George Cabot Lodge of Beverly, Mass., formally announced today his candidacy for the Republican nomination for United States Senator in 1962.

Jan de Hartog's "The Fourposter," the two-character comedy covering thirty-five years in the married life of one couple, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Saturday, Jan. 13, from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M.
The Long Island Rail Road reported yesterday a net income of $419,359 for October. This compared with the $56,866 cleared in October, 1960.
The value of bonds called for redemption in November before maturity was far below the preceding month's level but more than double the amount called in November, 1960.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- A California housewife has given $1,000, the amount it would have cost her family to build a fall-out shelter, to the United Nations. She described her act as a pledge of her faith that the world organization offers the best protection and hope for man's survival.

A strike against the privately owned bus lines by Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union has been averted, or at least delayed. This is good news for the public, and for business, which would have been hurt in the Christmas shopping season. But the terms of amnesty only postpone a facing-up to the basic fiscal problems of local mass transportation.
WOODSTOCK, Ill., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The will of John D. Hertz, leaving half of his estate to his widow, was accepted for probate today in the McHenry County Court.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The International Association of Great Lakes Ports has made plans to fight new dual-rate legislation on foreign shipping.

Christmas shoppers wishing to buy J.D. Salinger's best seller "Franny and Zooey" may now buy it for $4 on Fifth Avenue, for $3.20 just off Fifth, for $3 along Forty-second Street, for $2.89 at Sam Goody's on Third Avenue and for $2.79 at most big department stores and discount houses.

KEARNY, N.J., Nov. 30 -- A 79-year-old widow was found dead here today, lying bound and gagged in her kitchen. Her apartment had been ransacked, but many hundreds of dollars tucked away in various places had been overlooked.
Communist party headquarters said yesterday the party had cut its national leadership to three officers, but their identity was withheld.
In line with the increased interest in survival rations on the part of the public and the New York State Department of Health, the National Biscuit Company has developed a survival cracker.

Production of lumber in the nation fell to 174,596,000 board feet in the holiday week ended last Saturday from 219,132,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- The World Council of Churches elected today a six-man presidium that will guide its destinies for the next six or seven years.

What went wrong with the Nineteen Sixties? A leading economist, Dr. Marcus Nadler, Professor of Finance at the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University, asks this question, and then proceeds to explain why the decade that began as the "golden Sixties" now looks quite tarnished.

THE "show" in Composers' Showcase is not a misnomer. The series that Charles Schwartz directs at the Museum of Modern Art always presents contemporary music with a flair, and last night's concert, devoted to Silvestre Revueltas and Wallingford Riegger was no exception.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 30 -- Dr. Mamoun Kuzbari charged today that supporters of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic were responsible for two bomb blasts in Damascus last night. The explosions injured three persons.

Dinner and a showing of the closed-circuit telecast of the Floyd Patterson-Tom McNeeley fight in Toronto and the Sonny Liston-Albert Westphal fight in Philadelphia will be given at the Four Seasons Restaurant Monday night.

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- The United States and British delegation leaders will abandon tomorrow the talks here with the Soviet Union on a treaty to prohibit nuclear tests to return to other duties at the United Nations General Assembly.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 30 -- Slashing criticism of United States policies in South Vietnam and of the conduct of Americans here is continuing this week in the Government controlled Saigon press.
WHATEVER alternative may have been found to a Thanksgiving turkey, chances are it was not fish. Fish prices languished last week from lack of demand, but they jumped back up again this week.
THE keen interest of America's youngsters in space flight was demonstrated vividly last night during a special one-hour telecast over WOR-TV (Channel 9).

United Nations officials in the Congo have found it necessary to warn President Tshombe of Katanga that if his truculent talk continues it may lead to violence, the end of which cannot be foreseen. But what is the position of the U.N. troops in the whole Congo, spread out in a territory about one-fourth as large as the entire fifty United States?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Officials of twelve additional leading defense contractors signed White House "plans for progress" today, pledging special efforts to give Negroes equal access to jobs and promotions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Federal Power Commission's new area method of regulating natural gas rates was upheld today by the Court of Appeals here.
Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said last night that "a blanket of silence has fallen on the entire Jewish community" in the Soviet Union.
GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Threatened with the closing of the plant, union workers at the American Can Company's machine shops here voted today to accept a pay cut of 25 cents an hour.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A new director of President Kennedy's Food for Peace Citizens' Council was named today after the resignation of the two co-chairman.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg said here today that the Kennedy Administration had no intention of seeking wage and price controls.
A score of young mothers, some carrying children in their arms or pushing them in carriages, picketed in Times Square last night against nuclear annihilation while rush-hour throngs hurtled by.
A City Council committee was told yesterday that the tax on meals was stifling the restaurant business and making it hard for hotels to attract convention business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The railroad and trucking industries reported today that freight loadings increased last week from the 1960 levels. Loadings in both industries, however, were substantially below the levels of the preceding week because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Experts on the German problem from Washington, London, Paris and Bonn will meet in the French capital during the first week of December before a Western foreign ministers' meeting, informed sources said today.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Nov. 30 -- President Sukarno said today that the "decisive moment'' for the "liberation" of Netherlands New Guinea was at hand. He said he would call on "all progressive forces and friends" for help in wresting the territory from the Dutch.
The United States Information Agency is starting its most ambitious television project: a twenty-six-week video course in English designed to be shown by stations the world over.
Stock prices registered a modest gain on average last month on the New York Stock Exchange.
A proposal for a 2,500-family middle-income cooperative project in the downtown area known as "Hell's Hundred Acres" was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday.
Two linen supply corporations in the metropolitan area, eight member corporations and six individuals were fined a total of $319,000 yesterday by Chief Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- India appeared today to be preparing to force Portugal to give up at least some of her territory on the Indian west coast soon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board deferred until further notice today the deadline it had set for Howard R. Hughes to dispose of his stock in Atlas Corporation.
BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- A West Berlin court sentenced Horst Eitner, a 36-year-old double agent, today to three years' imprisonment for treasonable relations with the Soviet secret service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- A public health report disclosed today that a slight amount of radioactivity escaped into the atmosphere after one of the recent underground weapon tests in Nevada.
TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- The proposed East-West Freeway, which would bisect Essex County, will pass under, rather than over, the Garden State Parkway in East Orange.

TWO of the world's most civilized musicians, the flutist Jean Pierre Rampal and the harpsichordist and pianist Robert Veyron-Lacroix, performed last night in New York's most civilized music room. Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- A three-way row has blown up involving the Canadian and United States Governments and the Provincial Government of British Columbia over the proposed development of the Columbia River for power and irrigation.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 -- Walter Reuther placed the blame for jurisdictional disputes within the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on the building trade unions today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association, seeking more power over amateur sports, threatened today to boycott the Amateur Athletic Union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union certified world records today in eight track and field and nineteen swimming events. They now will be submitted for international recognition.
President Kennedy's use of "finalize" in his news conference Wednesday was defended yesterday by Dr. Philip B. Gove, editor in chief of the Merriam-Webster dictionaries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States will not collaborate with Communist countries in aiding under-developed areas until Moscow stops promoting "wars of national liberation," a Presidential adviser said today.
ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- A major study of commuting habits on Long Island will be started tomorrow by the State Public Works Department.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- An implication by a Right-Wing Deputy that the French Government planned to hand over Algeria to a Communist-oriented rebel regime almost led to blows today in the National Assembly.

Virgil Thomson, the composer, critic and conductor, will be honored on his sixty-fifth birthday with a Town Hall concert on Monday evening, Dec. 18. Chamber music and works for piano and for voice and piano, composed by Mr. Thomson since 1924, will be performed.
A free-trade agreement between United States and Venezuelan shipping interests that was announced yesterday is expected to create "a new climate" for expanded trade between the two countries.

The largest number of copper futures contracts to be traded this year changed hands yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. In all, 720 contracts were traded and prices rose by 14 to 21 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration announced today a temporary curtailment of its lending program because of a shortage of funds.
McCOMB, Miss., Nov. 30 -- City officials asserted today that they would maintain peace and enforce compliance with a Federal Court order desegregating bus and rail terminals.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Bernie Geoffrion of the Canadiens and Bert Olmstead of the Toronto Maple Leafs scored the goals tonight in a 1-1 tie that left the clubs deadlocked for first place in the National Hockey League.

THE New York Times, like the ferry ride to Staten Island, costs only 5 cents. When incorporated into a collage, however, The Times costs much more. At the Stone Gallery, 18 East Eighty-second Street, Jay Milder is showing large collages in which this newspaper figures prominently.
Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, has defended the go-it-alone fund drives of the big national health agencies against proponents of joint campaigns.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The state's highest court divided 4 -- 3 today in upholding a lower court decision that the widow of Glenn Miller, the orchestra leader, had no property rights in a style of music described as "the Glenn Miller sound."
Donnis Butcher, a 6-foot inch backcourt performer from Pikeville College, Ky., will make his first start as a New York Knickerbocker tonight.

Stand-ins for the Green Bay Packers romped about Yankee Stadium yesterday in lively reconstruction of the T-formation plays that have produced the highest point total in the National Football League this season.
TRENTON, Nov. 30 -- Governor-elect Richard J. Hughes said today he planned to appoint a bipartisan committee to study New Jersey's entire tax structure.
CAIRO, Friday, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Four French officials arrested here on charges of espionage will stand trial in open court here next week, the newspaper At Ahram reported today.

Electric utility companies in New York State are sponsoring a program to develop atomic fuel elements suitable for high-performance power reactors, the president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Kennedy are planning an early Christmas party for several hundred White House staff members and their families. It will be on Dec. 13, and the guests will receive "a special Christmas remembrance from the Kennedy's," Mrs. Kennedy's press secretary said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A plywood manufacturer pictured the State Department today as working against the interests of the industry through its trade policies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The respected voice of John J. McCloy, special disarmament adviser to President Kennedy, has now been added to others of comparable experience in international affairs that have noted the rapid deterioration of the United Nations.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Amid talk of labor disunity and dissensions, two former adversaries in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today that they were merging.
ROME, Nov. 30 -- Premier Khrushchev sent a personal message of congratulations and good wishes to Pope John XXIII on his 80th birthday last Saturday.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 30 -- The Central American group of five allied countries and Panama have declared a "united front" against the spread of Premier Fidel Castros revolutionary movement from Cuba.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Nov. 30 -- The Dutch have been heartened by what they consider the opposition of a majority of members of the United Nations to Indonesian designs on Netherlands New Guinea.

Business loans at the fourteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York rose $14,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with a rise of $94,000,000 in the 1960 week.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Tuition at Princeton University's Graduate School will increase $200 next fall to $1,450 a year, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of the university, announced today.
WILTON, Conn., Nov. 30 -- A high school mathematics teacher and a group of students here have been criticized as pro-Communist for citing alleged inaccuracies in the film "Operation Abolition."

New York's longest and most successful season of thoroughbred racing, 220 days -- 221, if the Adjacent Hunts meet is included, and there's no reason why it shouldn't be -- of action on the dirt, the turf and over the hurdles terminated yesterday at Aqueduct.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- Master Tara Sigh of the Sikhs prepared today for a period of penitence for having broken a pledge by ending his recent forty-eight-day fast.
J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman of the city's Housing and Redevelopment Board, attacked yesterday what he called "a lunatic fringe" that rejects city planning for urban renewal.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Red Wings beat Boston, 3 -- 1, tonight, snapping a three-game losing streak and sending the Bruins to their sixth straight loss in the National Hockey League. Howie Glover scored two goals for Detroit.

The Maritime Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has invited seven of the top executives of shipping management to address its fourth biennial convention.

The General Electric Company, the Langley Jones Company and the Allen Photography Company have leased space in Midtown Plaza, an office and shopping center in downtown Syracuse, N.Y. Anthony Bersani, president of the Bersani Construction Company of Syracuse, one of the owners, said the development was now more than a third rented.

Your Nov. 24 editorial made the point that the Germany of today differs from the Germany of the Nineteen Thirties and Nineteen Forties, in that the Germans have entered into fellowship with the democratic nations of the West. But you overlook a number of facts which cannot so lightly be waved off.
WARSAW, Nov. 30 -- Jacob D. Beam quietly ended today a tour of four years and four months as United States Ambassador to Poland.

The Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation, which bought the property at the northeast corner of Broad and Commerce Streets, Newark, last July from the National Newark and Essex Banking Company, has announced plans for its improvement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Army's top commanders, here for conferences with Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr., called today on their Commanders in Chief.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 30 -- Negotiations between the Government and the Opposition to end one-party rule in the Dominican Republic collapsed today after the armed forces insisted on 'the formation of a provisional governing junta to be headed by President Joaquin Balaguer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The average prices received for important products by farmers in mid-November as compared with mid-October and the mid-November parity prices follow:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The Political Committee approved today a resolution calling for an international agreement to halt the spread of nuclear weapons to countries that do not have them.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Italian composer Girgio Cambissa of Milan was awarded the $2,000 first prize tonight in the Queen Mother Elisabeth of Belgium Composition Contest for Chamber Music.
AN astonishing bit of local crime reportage unfolded on Channel 2's "C.B.S. Reports" last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The lifting of all inter-American sanctions against the Dominican Republic is expected to be recommended tomorrow by a special committee of the Organization of American States.

Dorothy Cothran, a young soprano from Chicago who has had considerable experience in opera and concert, made her first appearance in New York last night giving a Town Hall recital. Her accompanist was Frederick Schauwecker.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- One hundred and eighty-seven Mexican youngsters scattered throughout Michigan today for a two-month visit to agricultural and industrial centers.
HAVING let the genie out of the bottle, Premier Khrushchev will never get it back.

Many Wall Streeters were cheered by the speech on Tuesday of William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before the Investment Bankers Association assuring them that the S.E.C. is "not anti-Wall Street."

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Nov. 30 -- When Brian Urquhart arrived in secessionist Katanga Province for the first time three days ago, the first thing he wanted to know was whether it was safe for United Nations personnel in Elisabethville.

FOOTBALL'S sure-fire spectacular, the Army-Navy game, will attract some 100,000 incipient pneumonia victims to the great concrete igloo in the Philadelphia arctic wastelands on the morrow. The wind will howl. The crowd will howl -- and then take nutritious gulps of anti-freeze mixture to ward off the biting cold. This is what is known as fun.

FOR a dozen years Matthew Guinan, as president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, has been near but not quite in the center of the strikes and threats of strikes involving several million bus and subway riders.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals set a precedent today that it said could result in the reversal of many criminal convictions. The convictions that might be affected are those where evidence presented by the state was seized in violation of the United States Constitution.

'Le Passage du Rhin," the French World War II drama that defeated "Rocco and His Brothers" for the grand prize at the 1960 Venice Film Festival, will be seen here early next year, under the title "Tomorrow Is My Turn."
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Midwestern sociology professor conceded in Federal Court today that he talked with no white citizens while here last year to study race relations.
The State Workmen's Compensation Board was assailed yesterday for assertedly depriving many claimants of a fair hearing.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A late burst of buying whirled most commodity prices around on the Board of Trade today and sent them sharply higher.

FISHERMEN possessed of a properly devious turn of mind -- and that, naturally, would include every good angler -- are reminded that now is the time for lifting of spirits in a way that will prove most beneficial to themselves. That means acquisition of new equipment, or more accurately, insuring such acquisition.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A stockholder filed a $237,500,000 suit today against the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its domestic affiliate.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 30 -- Southerners were urged today to carry out a program for higher education tailored to the needs of a changing region.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Gov. Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina today challenged a Department of the Interior action canceling a large Government contract with a St. Louis fur company that is moving to Greenville, S.C.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The population of the United States, as measured on the "census clock" in the Commerce Department lobby, reached 185,000,000 at 3:01 P.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Crime continued to increase in urban and rural areas during the first nine months of this year.
Four Iranians were accused yesterday of operating a rags-to-riches scheme -- shipping $40,000 worth of rags to Iran in the guise of $1,500,000 worth of fine textiles.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- At least three firemen were injured today fighting a four-alarm fire beneath a pier on castle island on the tip of south Boston at the harbor mouth.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Department store sales in the nation for week ended Saturday, Nov. 25, were 6 per cent above the year-earlier level.
BOMBAY, Nov. 30 -- Tension over the reported military build-up in the Portuguese enclave of Goa continued to mount today.
Faulty home heating systems are often responsible for accidental deaths, according to the New York State Department of Health.

Over a month ago the Administrative Council of the City University issued its ban against Communist speakers on the college campuses. Almost simultaneously Queens College barred a representative of the extremist Negro movement of the Black Muslims and Hunter College denied the use of its auditorium to the National Review, a Right-Wing publication.
After several days of indecisiveness, there was no tion yesterday about the tion of the stock market went down.

PEIPING, Friday, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao said today world peace could be achieved "only when the imperialist system and the capitalist system are wiped from the face of the earth."
TORONTO, Nov. 30 -- Floyd Patterson ended active training today for the defense of his world heavyweight championship against Tom McNeeley on Monday night.

The Mayor and Chief of Police of McComb, Miss., had assured the Federal Department of Justice that they would comply with a desegregation order recently issued by a Federal court. Before the police chief arrived on the scene a small but vicious white mob had beaten up three young Negro men and two Negro girls who had taken the desegregation order seriously.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of California declared yesterday a 5 per cent common stock dividend, payable on Jan. 99 to holders of record of Dec. 11. No stock dividend was distributed a year earlier. The company previously declared a quarterly cash dividend of 50 cents, payable on Dec. 8.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union, in an open split with the United Arab Republic, vetoed the admission of Kuwait to the United Nations today.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation had a loss of $11,544,007 from operations for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 30. This included a special write-off of $9,200,000 in connection with theatrical and television inventories.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
The city was accused yesterday of having violated its agreement to permit artists to live and work in loft studios.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- The nation's railroads are in for their worst year since 1935, but a merger of the many carriers into a network of ten or twelve systems would enable the failing industry to save $1,000,000,000 a year, financial experts said here today.
Kelso, the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' American champion in 1960, retained the title this year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer yesterday rejected the plea for a Queens letter carrier who contended he had been denied appointment to the Police Department because of "the so-called sins of my relatives."

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the week ended on Wednesday increased by $11,000,000 to $101,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose by $72,000,000 to $670,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Japanese Embassy accused President Kennedy today of inconsistency in his apparent endorsement of a plan to raise cotton textile tariffs while calling for a liberal trade policy.

The May Department Stores Company reported yesterday record sales for the three and nine months ended on Oct. 3. Third-quarter earnings increased, but nine-month profits were below those for the 1960 period.

Margaret Webster has been signed to direct Michael Redgrave's London play, "The Aspern Papers," based on the story by Henry James. She will arrive from London on Monday to prepare for rehearsals starting Dec. 16.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would fight before the 1962 session of the Legislature to regain the city's power to require the dating of all milk and cream sold here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- Western delegates expressed confidence tonight that they would defeat a Soviet attempt to expel Nationalist China from the General Assembly and hand over China's seat to the Communist Government in Peiping.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges said tonight the barriers to economic success for American Negroes must be removed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Defense Department expressed satisfaction today with the efforts of France to help ease the United States' financial burden in maintaining large forces in western Europe.

The wholesale commodity price index rose Wednesday -- for the sixth consecutive day -- to 83.6 from 83.5 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 83.4 on Nov. 25, 1960.
Two Chicago banks made closely competitive bids yesterday for $2,475,000 of bonds of the Tazewell County, Ill., High School District 303, due from 1963 to 1980.

The Graham-Paige Corporation reported yesterday that stockholders' equity was $2.70 a share on Sept. 30, compared with $1.56 a share a year earlier. It was noted that the value was 9 cents a share on Dec. 31, 1949, a short time after the concern became an investment company.

A troupe of fourteen American, British and Canadian actors has been spending the last six weeks trying to learn the Chinese method of acting from two directors whose English vocabulary does not extend much beyond "Thank you."
A walkout of garbage collectors who serve the city's restaurants and other businesses was averted early today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- In his conversation with the editor of the Soviet newspaper Izvestia, President Kennedy made two statements which need clarification.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Maj. Arch Roberts, former public information officer for Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, defended General Walker's "pro-blue" troop education program tonight and denied it was linked with the militantly conservative John Birch Society.

President Kennedy handled the ticklish question of intervention in Latin America well when he was asked at his press conference on Wednesday about the United States Navy's role in the Dominican crisis. He pointed out that we want to see the Dominicans set up "the kind of government which will permit the Dominican people to control their own destiny."
