The Transport Workers Union and the seven private bus companies agreed last night to extend their contracts to midnight, Dec. 31. This averted a strike of 8,000 drivers and mechanics that had been scheduled for 12:01 A.M. today.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- The West German Government has agreed to buy $700,000,000 worth of arms and military supplies in the United States this year and a similar amount in 1962.

Fanelli Homes, Inc., of Teaneck, has bought seven acres of land on Schraelenburg Road in Haworth, N.J., for improvement with fifteen homes in the $30,000 price category. The land was sold by Charles Pavarini of Haworth through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- It had been snowing in Troy, too. But not as hard as in Canton and Potsdam. Nor was Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute as firm as St. Lawrence and Clarkson Tech were in the other Tri-State League centers in the belief that it had a championship hockey team in the making.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prices eased a little in quiet trading in the stock market today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Administration officials are thinking of temporarily recalling the United States Ambassador to South Vietnam if President Ngo Dinh Diem continues to resist urgent suggestions for democratic reforms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said today he foresaw no material effect on the retail price of silver articles as a result of the ending of Treasury sales of silver.

Political speculation was touched off yesterday by the disclosure that President Kennedy had invited Representative Charles A. Buckley and Mrs. Buckley, as well as the Mayor and Mrs. Wagner, to be his guests at tomorrow's Army-Navy football game in Philadelphia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Kennedy Administration said today it favored the removal of some government activities from the nation's capital. But it made no specific commitments.
The nation's airlines will report a net loss before taxes of about $40,000,000 this year, William J. Hogan, financial vice president of American Airlines, Inc., estimated yesterday.
Flotations of new bonds and stocks rose in November from the levels of October and a year earlier.

MANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30 -- It had been rather quiet here belong the Severn during the week of the Army-Navy football game, but tonight the brigade of more than 3,800 midshipmen gave the team a roaring send-off to Saturday's duty-second service classic in Philadelphia.

Your Nov. 23 editorial states that Bronx Congressman Charles A. Buckley had the worst absentee record in the last session of Congress, and the session before that too. Your editorial also states that voters in Mr. Buckley's district "will undoubtedly be proud" to learn of Mr. Buckley's dismal record.

MIAMI, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox completed their-third trade of the minor league baseball meetings tonight. They sent two pitchers, Billy Pierce and Don Larsen, to the San Francisco Giants for two pitchers, Ed Fischer and Dom Zanni; a first baseman-outfielder, Bob Farley, and a player to be named later.
A permanent committee of architects and engineers has been established by the Board of Education to make recommendations on the construction and design of schools.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Vulko Chervenkov, Bulgarian Deputy Premier and former strong man during the Stalinist period, has been expelled from the Communist party's Politiburo for his actions during that time, the Bulgarian Press Agency reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The prices that farmers received for crops and livestock fell nearly 1 per cent in the month ended Nov. 15, the Department Agriculture reported today.
Cotton futures closed unchanged to 95 cents a bale off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Northeast Airlines announced yesterday it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to authorize increased fares effective Jan. 5. The airline sought an increase in jet day-coach fares from the present 75 per cent of first class to 83 1/3 per cent.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The debate in the House of Commons was suddenly interrupted today when Sir Winston Churchill walked slowly in and took his usual seat on the Conservative side.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Abraham A. Ribicoff, said here today that he might recommend Federal payments to the states for work relief projects.

TITLES mean nothing to Sue Russell. Although she has been named International Secretary of the Year in a contest held by the National Secretaries Association, a non-profit organization that aims to elevate secretarial standards to professional level, Miss Russell prefers to identify herself as "just a secretary."

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator J. Strom Thurmond said last night that it was determined at a meeting in Moscow almost a year ago that something had to be done to stop anti-Communist talks by United States military leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Udall said today that this country might have to develop other hydroelectric sites in the Pacific Northwest if Canada did not ratify the Columbia River treaty.
The eleven major domestic airlines agreed yesterday to impose a penalty of as much as $50 on ticket holders who fail to use their reservations.

FOR a refreshing skin tonic in theatrical surroundings women can try the red and gilt entrusted salon at 26 East Fifty-ninth Street, recently opened by Ginger Blair. Miss Blair, who had a salon on West Seventy-second Street for ten years, offers a quick facial with her own formula creams followed by a complete make up free of charge.
William E. Miller, the Republican national chairman, confessed here yesterday that he did not know who was head of the Republican party. He suggested there might not be one at all.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The influence of Madison Avenue struck with full impact at West Point today. The cadets in gray, who regularly march rigidly in formation when not pursuing the sciences, suddenly became advertising and publicity men for twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Post Office Department said today a new plan of setting up once-a-day mail deliveries and breaking up delivery routes would be tried on a nation-vide basis for the first time this holiday season.
DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Pope John's highest emissary said today that Protestant missionaries to dominantly Catholic nations "can expect oppression in some instances."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets remained unchanged at 118.8 per cent of their 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 1 -Keshava Deva Malaviya, Minister for Mines and Oil, accused Western oil companies today of being "secretive" and uncooperative with the Indian Government.
FOR the current week, at least, the television industry seems determined to make the Federal Communications Commission eat its words about a "vast wasteland"; moreover, it is succeeding.

Anyone suggesting repeal of a city tax, or part of a tax, should be prepared to propose a substitute source of revenue. This is the irreproachable principle stated by Mayor Wagner in commenting on City Council bills that would reduce the rate or base of the city tax on restaurant and hotel meals, including liquor. One of these proposals would reduce city revenue from this tax by $13,000,000, another by $7,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Acting Secretary General U Thant seems to be in full accord with President Kennedy: "Finalize" is a fine word to describe plans about to reach a final stage.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Five hundred homeowners here will put away their garbage cans on Tuesday to take part in a sixty-day test of a weatherproof refuse bag.

Whether or not there was any conflict of interest in Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino's support of fall-out shelter legislation while a member of the board of directors of a company in the shelter-construction business will be examined soon by his colleagues in the Assembly Committee on Ethics and Guidance. The State Investigation Commission bowed out of any inquiry "at this time," doubtless pleased that somebody else had jurisdiction over this political hot potato.
A utility union representing 21,000 of the 25,000 employes of the Consolidated Edison Company voted last night to go on strike.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Classes at the Hall Elementary School on Pixlee Place were cancelled today, after youthful vandals had caused extensive damage in the building during the night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Vice President Johnson today described the status of Negroes employed by the Federal Government as "very unsatisfactory."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson denounced Communist today and said that its admission to the United Nations would give the organization's "seal of approval" to an attack on Taiwan by the Peiping Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Thirteen airlines and the Federal Aviation Agency are feuding over the $4,600,000 worth of airport "mobile lounges" that the agency has purchased for the new Dulles International Airport near Washington.
HOPE springs eternal. Of 100 women who are divorced by the age of 30, ninety-eight will remarry. Of 100 men who are divorced by the same age, ninety-nine will remarry.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Darlene Hard, of Montebello, Calif., already in the women's singles final, today reached the finals of the women's doubles and the mixed doubles at the Western Australian tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The writer of a book on racial matters said today that scientists who believed there was a basic inequality between whites and Negroes were being muzzled by universities and scientific organizations.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A funeral service was held today for Axel Wenner-Gren, Sweden's noted industrialist who died last Friday of cancer at the age of 80.
HONG KONG, Dec. 1 -- Communist China indicated today that it felt the Communist-bloc dispute centering on Albania should be solved through meetings and discussions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Kennedy asked two Cabinet members today to determine what role the Federal Government should assume in the field of mental illness.
Charles W. Tucker Jr., who will be the field judge at the Army-Navy game today, took time yesterday to present an autographed football to an injured schoolboy player at Lenox Hill Hospital.

The Moorestown, N.J., School District sold $2,425,000 of bonds yesterday to an investment banking group headed by the National State Bank of Newark and Stroud Co. as joint managers. The bonds are due from 1963 to 1987.

Materials used to decorate the Terrace Room of the Plaza last night for the Toy Ball will be given to the beneficiary, the Retarded Infants Service at 50 West Fifty-seventh Street, along with the proceeds of the ball.

The American West African Freight Conference has lowered the rate on flour being shipped from United States Atlantic and Gulf ports and Canadian ports west of Montreal to Ghana and Nigeria. The decrease, from $28 a ton to $20 a long ton, will be in effect this month.
Beveridge Webster gave a recital last night at Town Hall that had all the fine characteristics of his musical gifts and piano personality.

FORTUNATELY, Galina Vislmevskaya included the Mussorgsky "Songs and Dances of Death" on her program last night in Carnegie Hall. This incomparable work is one of the titanic conceptions of the entire song literature: searing, powerful, bitter, yet full of humanity and compassion.
MIAMI, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Coast Guard today turned over the investigation of the sinking of the ketch Bluebelle to the United States district attorney's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic law professor described as bad legislation today an old Connecticut law that makes criminal the practice of artificial birth control or the dissemination of information about it.
ALGIERS, Dec. 1 -- A qualified source said today that secret talks "on a technical level" between France and the rebel Algerian Provisional Government were believed to be in an advanced stage.

A dispatch by Harrison E. Salisbury in the Nov. 16 issue of your esteemed paper says: "The center of contention between the two countries (Pakistan and Afghanistan) is an Afghan demand for self-determination for Pathan tribesmen who live on both sides of the Afghan-Pakistani border."
RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The police here have begun to study scientific hypnosis as a weapon in their fight on crime.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California has prepared a new narration for "Operation Abolition," a film report by the House Committee on Un-American Activities about the San Francisco City Hall student riot in May, 1960.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -Fairly heavy selling held the grain futures market under steady pressure today and losses ran to a cent or more a bushel in wheat, corn and rye.
TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan returned today from an intricate political reconnaissance mission in Asia.
UNITED NATIONS, N,Y., Dec. 1 -- Portugal assailed today a United Nations inquiry committee's report on Angola as "prejudiced" and based on "hearsay" evidence.

Spurred by early Christmas buying, sales of the major department stores in the metropolitan area last month rose by 10 per cent above the November, 1960, level. This was indicated by a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.
The Assembly's Committee on Ethics and Guidance will meet next Thursday to consider conflict-of-interest charges made against Speaker Joseph F. Carlino, Republican of Long Beach, L.I.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Fraternities are private associations of men seeking out other men who are congenial and as such must resist those who would reshape them from whatever motives, the National Interfraternity Conference was told today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union charged today that a United States foreign policy aim of creating a "world community" was a new form of imperialism.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 1 -Syrians asserted their independence at the polls today.
TORONTO, Dec. 1 -- The usually conservative Floyd Patterson came out in favor of gambling today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov of the Soviet Union called today on Secretary of State Dean Rusk to deliver a copy of Moscow's already rejected proposal for an uninspected ban on nuclear testing.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 1 -- President Sukarno's statement that he would soon order Indonesian military forces to "liberate" Netherlands New Guinea was received calmly today by the Dutch Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Amateur Athletic Union chose Ralph Boston today as the American male track and field athlete who had turned in the outstanding performance of the year.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 1 -New York teams led after the first two sessions of the masters' team contest in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here, with the two final sessions to be played today.
The directors of the Ekco Products Company voted a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. They also increased the cash dividend on the stock by 10 per cent.
After fifty years as basketball nomads, the St. John's Redmen opened their season last night in a sumptuous new tepee that no one would ever think of giving back to the Indians.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- An income tax case involving the sale of wine by a Roman Catholic order has been resolved by the order's payment of nearly $4,000,000, a Government lawyer said today.

Awards for the construction and design of buildings completed in Queens in 1961 will be made at the forty-ninth annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of Queens on Dec. 5 at the Commodore Hotel. Governor Rockefeller and John T. Clancy, Queens Borough President, are scheduled to speak.

Speculative holdings over-hanging the market evidently cast a shadow on silver in the London market yesterday, and dampened the buying. The price for spot silver was down to the equivalent of 98 cents an ounce, well below the high of $1.02 reached on Wednesday, but still above the 93-cent price touched earlier this week.
City teachers have been advised they do not have to answer questions in a state-sponsored questionnaire that call for an evaluation of their principals, supervisors and the general administration.

PUCON, Chile, Dec. 1 -- In the unlikely event that Senator Barry Goldwater should ever run against Adlai Stevenson for President of the United States he could count on the moral support of anglers in this.
GRADUATE nurses in good standing were given an evening off each week for "courting purposes" back in what some people remember as "the good old days."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Labor Department painted a somewhat brighter employment picture today for the months ahead in announcing that eight more industrial centers had been taken off the list of areas with "substantial" unemployment.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -West Germany has undertaken to study the possibility of renegotiating with West Berlin the political, legal and economic ties between the city and the Federal Republic.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Following are excerpts from the questions and answers at a news conference held today by U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The sixty-second Army-Navy extravaganza comes into the Philadelphia Stadium tomorrow -- and it will set a high in extravagance for a regularly scheduled college football game.
McCOMB, Miss., Dec. 1 -- The police held back angry white mobs twice today while six Freedom Riders achieved the first court-ordered desegregation in Mississippi's modern history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The billions being spent on foreign aid will be wasted unless the nation adjusts its trade policies to the newly developing patterns and somehow stabilizes world commodity prices, Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today.

Three landlords with extensive holdings in East Harlem were fined a total of $2,550 in Housing Court yesterday. They also received stiff jail sentences, which were suspended pending a show of good faith.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Enos, the chimpanzee, arrived back at this rocket base today for a series of tests aimed at determining how a human astronaut would fare when he attempted to match the animal's orbital flight around the earth.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- No diplomat or politician in this capital can really say why it happened, but a measurable easing of relations between the Soviet Union and the Western allies over Berlin is discernible here.

The stockholders of the Newmont Mining Corporation, at a meeting tentatively set for February, will be asked to authorize a new class of preferred stock for use in an exchange offer for the bulk of the Magma Copper Company's common shares, Newmont officials said yesterday.

THE cond in a Series of five f'.,ns p'esented by the Archi. :tural. Iague of New York ?rid the Museum of Modem Art will be presented Thin.sday, Dec. 7, at 8:30 P. M., in the museum . auditorium. The topic will be "How Money Designs the' City:"

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Postmaster General J. Edward Day said tonight that rightwing extremists were a force that the Democratic party must oppose with all its volunteer strength and all its national power.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The powerful Building and Construction Trades Department called unanimously today for the early return of the exiled Teamsters Union to the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
A joint recital of songs, arias and piano works was presented in Carnegie Recital Hall last night by James Stathis, baritone, and Eva Gezina, pianist. The audience was large and friendly.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The Comedie Francaise -- France's state-supported theatre group that seems to thrive on temperament and trouble -- has, for the moment two directors.
PANAMA, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- The United States Panama Canal Company announced today that it spent nearly $6,000,000 more than it took in during the fiscal year ended last June 30.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced yesterday that two loans aggregating $25,000,000 have been made to South Africa for the improvement and expansion of electric facilities and railways.
Mayor Wagner declared last night that authority over the direction of Democratic party affairs must be shifted from the organizational leaders to elected public officials.
LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 30 -- Thirty-three years under the firm hand of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar have not quelled the ingrained Portuguese delight in musical comedy effects.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller will return to his official duties as the state's Chief Executive tomorrow.
MIAMI, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Racehorse owners and trainers attacked Florida's ban of a controversial drug, Butazolidin, today, but the State Racing Commission refused to rescind its stand.

IN that lyrical world where the champagne bubbles out of countless magnums, violinists float from table to table in a cloud of Blue Danubian gaiety and the caviar is spooned out of great silver tureens, there is certainly a place for the goose, or, more exactly, for the goose's liver.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Holy Cross and Boston College wind up their football season in the fifty-eighth game of the annual Jesuit school rivalry tomorrow.
BETTY CAROL, who is both mistress and master designer of the Mam'selle dress house, is like many little women. When she was younger, she was a size 9. Now, she is a size 5.

STUTTGART, Germany, Dec. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Garrison H. Davidson, commanding general of the United States Seventh Army, expressed satisfaction today with the cooperation between his troops and elements of the West German Army serving in his command area.

AT this time of year one-man shows largely give way to group shows with a special eye to the Christmas-spirited collector. Should the latter be interested in old master drawings he will have difficulty coming to final decisions when faced with the excellent selection of English water-colors and drawings, eighteenth to twentieth century, at the Davis Gallery, 231 East Sixtieth Street.

THE newest holiday department to appear at Altman's is the Christmas-at-Home Shop on the fifth floor. This festive corner differs from the Trimthe-Tree Shop on the eighth floor in that it has decorations to be used throughout the house from -- Bedroom to kitchen.
How long can a defendant be held in jail awaiting trial?
A psychiatrist, a Talmudic scholar and a Protestant theologian, all leaders in their fields, will be the chief speakers Wednesday at an all-day symposium on Religion and Mental Health.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Kennedy will divide his time between Army and Navy at the big game in Philadelphia tomorrow, and also between two New York political adversaries.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- After a survey of export trends from 1954 through 1960, the Treasury said today that Britain's exports of manufactured goods had risen much more slowly than those of the rest of the world.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 1 -- President Frondizi's latest extended trip abroad, this time a month-long journey to Canada and across Europe to Asia, points up Argentina's economic dilemma. The President emphasizes that Argentina must find new markets for its exports, especially in Asia.
Of the many talents of professional football players, one of the most unusual is that of Ray Wietecha. On every play, the New York Giants' offensive center passes "blind."

Wendell Phillips, one of the most eloquent, determined, perceptive and influential radicals of the Abolitionist Era, is the subject of a biography by Irving H. Bartlett that Beacon Press will publish on Jan. 12. Titled "Wendell Phillips: Brahmin Radical," it is based on material gathered from voluminous private papers hitherto not available and gives a new insight into the divided temper of the North during the Civil War period.
You are to be congratulated on your editorial of Nov. 15 in which you raise very important questions about the development of State University.
HAVANA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro sang the praises of Lenin tonight and proclaimed, "I absolutely believe in Marxism."
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Three leading Soviet journalists took issue last night with some of the points made by President Kennedy in his interview with the editor of Izvestia, Aleksei I. Adzhubei.

The Noonan Plaza Apartments, a group of eight buildings occupying the blockfront on East 168th Street between Ogden and Nelson Avenues, the Bronx, has been purchased by Gilbert Ancowitz and his associates, Abraham Bisgaier, Albert Bronstein and Charles Kenney.
GENEVA, Dec. 1. -- Britain and the Soviet Union are appealing to the Princes who head the three rival political factions in Laos to speed their negotiations for a coalition government.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1 -- Winter closing operations on the St. Lawrence River section of the Seaway, between Kingston and Montreal, began today, with about twenty-five vessels still on the waterway as a result of snowstorms, which halted navigation.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- An alien Woman's entries in a newspaper crossword puzzle contest led to her arrest today on charges that she threatened in a letter to kill Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 cents a bale off to 55 cents up yesterday.

As this year's General Assembly debate on the seating of Communist China proceeds, the prospects are that at the end of a protracted period of embittered speech-making the Peiping regime will once more be barred from the United Nations. The United States, Nationalist China and other opponents of Communist China plan to block Peiping by getting the Assembly to rule that the question of seating the Chinese Communist regime is a substantive matter.

The forthcoming filming of two major works, Tennessee Williams' "Period of Adjustment" and William L. Shirer's "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich," should find George Roy Hill, the young television and stage director, well-established in the film firmament.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec, 1 (UPI) -- Don Schwall, the Boston Red Sox pitcher who won fifteen games despite missing the first five weeks of the 1961 season, today was named the American League Rookie of the Year.

Wellington Equity Fund wound up its fiscal year with net assets of $80,419,304, equal to $17.13 a share, on Oct. 31. These were new highs and the share value represented a gain of 43.6 per cent over the year-ago level, according to the annual report, which was released yesterday.
The bond market tended to move downward yesterday after a firm beginning. The exception was the corporate sector of the market where prices rose 1/8 to 1/4 on the day.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Alabama, will take on Auburn, a traditional foe, here tomorrow with hopes of winning its first national championship, completing its first unbeaten and untied season in sixteen years and plans for a Sugar Bowl battle with Arkansas on New Year's Day.

Although "No Strings" is getting close to its Broadway opening date, the question of whether it will be able to displace "My Fair Lady" at the Mark Hellinger Theatre on March 1 still remains a moot point.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Following are excerpts from remarks in the General Assembly today by Valerian A. Zorin of the Soviet Union, Dr. Tingfu F. Tsiang of Nationalist China and Adlai E. Stevenson of the United States on the question of the representation of China:
A large number of instruction sheets for filing New York State "short form" income-tax returns will be printed in Spanish this year.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 1 -- New street disorders agitated this capital today as the general strike in support of Opposition demands for the resignation of President Joaquin Balaguer weakened.
Small colleges frequently produce giant-sized doses of enthusiasm when their athletic teams take to the field. In the metropolitan area, Iona, Wagner and Yeshiva rate A-plus in this department.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Rumania was elected to a seat on the Security Council today with the understanding that she would share the two-year term with the Philippines.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 1 -Baseball's major league club owners, marking time for their joint session before Commissioner Ford C. Frick tomorrow, today got themselves involved in an unexpected hassle concerning the playing of a second all-star game.
The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway reported yesterday a $4,292,000 net income for November, the best showing for any month of the year and up from $3,319,000 in the same month of 1960.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Movie producers and actors took to Congress today their argument over whether too many American movies are being made abroad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Special dividend checks totaling more than $29,500,000 are being distributed to more than 400,000 veterans of the Korean conflict, the Veterans Administration said today.
The private carting industry will ask the city soon for permission to raise rates and for a review of other regulations, a spokesman said yesterday.

" PEACE will be the greatest discovery of our time," Dr. Hans Albrecht Bethe was reported to have said over lunch about four years ago. Remarks that he made yesterday when he received the Enrico Fermi Award in White House ceremonies indicate that the feel ing persists in the mind of the man who has made many great discoveries himself.
AN illustrated essay with a forceful point of view, "America in Space," blasted off on Channel 5 last night.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 29 -- Although the two figures around whom the Dominican Republic's political crisis has crystalized are starkly contrasting, each has been shaped by the thirty-one-year dictatorship of the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
Basketball heroes abounded at Madison Square Garden last night, and for a change most of them wore the livery of the New York Knickerbockers.

Instead of fighting for Federal aid to the public schools, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, has chosen to try to kill such aid. In a Congressional election year he prefers to creep into the fray under such safe banners as aid to colleges only for science and technology.

Kurt Adler led Puccini's "Turandot" at the Metropolitan Opera last night for the first time, giving one of the best performances of his tenure there. He was in full command of what was happening musically in the orchestra pit and on-stage.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain's biggest real estate corporation and one of her biggest retail trade corporations have agreed to join forces for real estate development.
College basketball, shaken by scandals twice in the past decade, begins another Madison Square Garden season tonight hoping to regain the confidence of a watchful, waiting public.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- Svetozar Vukmanovic-Tempo, head of the Yugoslav Trade Union Federation and a member of the Politburo of the Yugoslav Communist party, left by air today for Moscow to attend the fifth congress of the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.
The official tabulation of the Nov. 7 mayoral election shows that Mayor Wagner defeated Louis J. Lefkowitz, his Republican opponent, by a margin of 401,730 votes.

The United Artists Corporation showed an increase in its earnings for the first nine months this year, according to the report issued yesterday by Robert S. Benjamin, chairman of the motion picture company.
Buses will soon start making trial runs over the new ramps being installed at the Port Authority Bus Terminal as part of the $20,500,000 expansion of the the depot.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 1 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province left today for Brazzaville on his way to Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Dr. Hans A. Bethe, a German-born scientist who pioneered in the development of the atom bomb and then in the search for nuclear disarmament, was honored here today. From President Kennedy he received the Enrico Fermi award for his contributions to the peaceful and military applications of atomic energy.
YONKERS, Dec. 1 -- Gus Hall, secretary general of the Communist party in the United States, was stopped while driving a new car here today and given three summonses for motor vehicle violations.
Utah State, because it was the first to accept an invitation, was designated yesterday as the home team in the Gotham Bowl at the Polo Grounds a week from today.
Two gigantic rivals in the merchandising industry, Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co., are squaring off to compete in still another field travel.

Cold war and explosive situations at hypersensitive political boundaries loom large in the news, but they are not so new in the experience of military leaders. Forty-five years ago an American general distinguished himself by putting down a disgruntled Mexican revolutionist who resorted to international banditry, all the time carefully maintaining a precarious balance between a large-scale police action and a genuine hot war.
Stocks advanced smartly yesterday and scored the first gain on average in a week. Trading continued to be active.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- An eventful week ended with investors uncertain and disinclined to enter into fresh commitments. Nevertheless, the downward drift produced by week-end selling was more than reversed in late trading, mainly on the strength of a few individual issues.

The Plymouth Oil Company, Pittsburgh, is about to begin negotiations for the cash sale of substantially all of its assets to the Ohio Oil Company, Findlay, Ohio. Formal negotiations "will begin immediately," Paul G. Benedum Sr., president of Plymouth, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The chief of the Federal civil defense program said today that people with back yards and basement should build fall-out shelters if they had the means to do so.
The Lighthouse Ball took place last night at the Waldorf-Astoria in a glittering holiday setting.
The public has been finding it difficult to unearth servicemen who are willing to install converters on television sets in order to receive programs on Channel 31.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1 -Joey L. (Jake) McCandless today was appointed head basketball coach at Princeton.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The United States expressed its concern today over the renewed political crisis in the Dominican Republic.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- A Federal court jury today acquitted Montgomery police officials of charges they violated the civil rights of a sociology professor and his students by arresting them for participating in an integrated luncheon.

WHITING, Ind., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Federal investigators charged two brothers today with having embezzled up to a million dollars from a savings and loan association where one was board chairman and the other was secretary-treasurer.

Despite Soviet propaganda distortions, President Kennedy's interview with Premier Khrushchev's son-in-law and special emissary, Aleksei Adzhubei, has served a highly useful purpose. Winning praise throughout the West, it has helped consolidate Western opinion. It has penetrated the Iron Curtain and has not only presented to a wider Russian public a full exposition of the American standpoint but has also brought home to it the grave responsibility of the Soviet rulers for existing world tensions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The president of the National Guard Association said today that the complaints of a few individuals were "casting a shadow upon the patriotism and spirited response" of reservists called to active duty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The pilot of the airliner in which seventy-four Army recruits died near Richmond, Va., on Nov. 8 failed three flight tests early in his career, Federal Aviation Agency records showed today.

I read with horror and revulsion The Times report of Nov. 21 of the 150th anniversary of the House of Krupp. Horror at the praise heaped upon this industrial monster by the current leaders of Germany, headed by President Luebke and Vice Chancellor Erhard, and revulsion over the words of former President Heuss that "nothing sinful" should be seen in the manufacture of arms in the past.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Gay Brewer Jr. shot an eight-under-par 64 today for a three-stroke lead at the halfway mark of the $20,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- A Federal court jury today acquitted Montgomery police officials of charges they violated the civil rights of a sociology professor and his students by arresting them for participating in an integrated luncheon.

WHITING, Ind., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Federal investigators charged two brothers today with having embezzled up to a million dollars from a savings and loan association where one was board chairman and the other was secretary-treasurer.

Despite Soviet propaganda distortions, President Kennedy's interview with Premier Khrushchev's son-in-law and special emissary, Aleksei Adzhubei, has served a highly useful purpose. Winning praise throughout the West, it has helped consolidate Western opinion. It has penetrated the Iron Curtain and has not only presented to a wider Russian public a full exposition of the American standpoint but has also brought home to it the grave responsibility of the Soviet rulers for existing world tensions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The president of the National Guard Association said today that the complaints of a few individuals were "casting a shadow upon the patriotism and spirited response" of reservists called to active duty.
KANPUR, India, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- India scored 209 runs for three wickets on a dead pitch today as the second cricket test match against England opened.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- After a two-year legal battle, the state's highest court has ruled that the foster parents of a 4-year-old boy are better qualified to rear him than his 18-year-old natural mother.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, said today he would have a plan drafted by next week to deal with the Congo situation. He said the Congo crisis was the most important problem facing the United Nations.

FOR a composer whose music is still controversial, still invites violent dissent and fanatical love, Bruckner is doing well at Carnegie Hall this season. Two of his symphonies have already been played there by visiting orchestras, the Eighth was presented yesterday afternoon by the New York Philharmonic, and the Ninth is scheduled by Leonard Bernstein for a later date.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- A section of a United States motorized infantry company that drove to West Germany this morning was delayed by Soviet officers at a control point outside Berlin.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (AP) -- President Kennedy suffers "political delusions" if he believes the Soviet Union is trying to communize the world, the Soviet newspaper Literatura i Zhizn said today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- State Representative Robert A. Taft, son of the late Republican Senate leader, said today he would attempt to enter national politics next year by running for Representative at large from Ohio.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The word "spirit" was used tonight by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to describe his new public welfare program.
The long-term use of insulin therapy has raised "serious problems" both for many diabetic patients and their physicians, a diabetologist reported yesterday.
Prof. David F. Cavers of the Harvard Law School told a disarmament conference at Columbia University yesterday that a disarmament treaty would make it easier to solve other world problems peacefully.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Government authorized the nation's 13,100 commercial banks today to pay higher interest rates on savings deposits.
An active week looms in the market for new capital as major issues valued at $198,168,000 are slated for offering.

DALLAS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The American Football League will hold its second draft tomorrow. Oakland's lowly Raiders will get the first choice and are expected to grab at Roman Gabriel, North Carolina State's passing quarterback.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Bobby Allen, a 17-year-old Kart champion from Miami Springs, Fla., won the 100-lap Grand Prix today to capture the Sir Victor Sassoon Trophy and $500 in prize money for the second straight year.

More than 3,500 women marched in front of the United Nations headquarters yesterday in a protest against nuclear testing. They carried balloons on which the word: "pure milk, not poison," had been printed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The National Steel Corporation has discovered that the judicious use of a tiny bit of columbium can add as much as 50 per cent to the strength of steel. According to the company, this means that industry can turn out lighter products, saving on steel and manufacturing costs and shipping charges.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 1 -- A novel fall-out shelter is to be installed at the home of David Marvin on Sleepy Hollow Road.
The National Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered a union-representation election between Dec. 15 and Jan. 30 on seventeen Honduran-flag ships operated by a United Fruit Company subsidiary.
A rumor, bruited about in Wall Street for the last month, became a fact yesterday.
New York glittered like a Christmas tree yesterday with the addition of holiday lighting displays.
Cocoa futures trading continued at a brisk pace yesterday. Most other commodity markets, including copper which had been extremely active the day before, were quiet.
The Transport Workers Union, the city's seven private bus lines and the Transit Authority worked yesterday to set up a schedule of contract negotiating sessions, starting next week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Theatre Communications Group has set out to do something about difficulties that waste talent and hobble the development of the American theatre.
Cigar smokers in this country soon may find it harder to buy their favorite imported Havana cigar.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- All signs pointed this week to the brewing of the final climactic storm in Algeria.
Bird lovers are reporting an ornithological bonanza in Central Park these days.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- President Kennedy sat hatless among 101,000 spectators today and watched Navy beat Army, 13 -- 7, in the celebrated inter-service football rivalry.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Mack Cochran, a 155-pound quarterback from Pearl River (Miss.) Junior College, threw two touchdown passes and gained 192 yards today to lead the East to a 20-8 victory over the West in the sixth Shrine Junior College All-Star football game.
College basketball (1961-62 edition) made its debut at Madison Square Garden last night to a mixed reaction.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Greentree Stable's Eurasia, closing with a rush under a fine ride by Herbie Hinojosa, won the $11,950 City of Miami Handicap at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 9,261.

THE one-lamp movie bar photoflood appears to be making some headway in competition with the two-lamp and four-lamp conventional units. A favored source in this class is the General Electric Uniflood, which is incorporated in the Acme Lite Q-Beam Mov-E-Lite, which costs $22.95.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika. MAN must "live for human beings, and not this damned color * * *. A man's color is no sin * * *. Africans, equally as much as Europeans, must realize the falsity of any color bar * * *. You cannot base a constitution on wrong."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Herman Kenin, head of the American Federation of Musicians, called today for a Government ban against the use of foreign music recordings as background for United States television shows.

ONCE upon a time ski area operators, having cleared the stumps and rocks from their slopes and oiled up the rope tow machinery, had to sit around and wait for winter to come and to bring with it enough snow to make skiing possible.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Southern Methodist threw away a 20-point lead today and then stormed back in the closing seconds to tie Texas Christian, 28 -- 28.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y. -- More vacationists than ever are expected to participate in winter sports in the Catskills this season. This optimism is based on the fact that local resort operators are providing more types of winter sports facilities than ever before.
The Christmas season got off to a flying start last week at department stores in the metropolitan area.

Automobile sales continued to spearhead Cleveland business activity. Daily average sales of 317 were at a long-time peak in the week ended Nov. 25. The sales total exceeded that of the corresponding holiday week last year by 200 units. Department store trade is also showing increasing signs of vigor even after allowance for seasonal influence.
Methods of improving the reporting and presentation of local news will be discussed at a two-week seminar for city editors that opens tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University.
LIMA, PERU Attention in Lima, one of the oldest cities in the Americas, was focused last week on Peru's oldest problem -- physical disability.

THE Metropolitan has been described, not with reason, as an Italian opera house. Actually most members of the musical and technical staff are Central European, and the lingua franca backstage is German, not Italian.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 1 -- An air force major stood in front of the Presidential palace and watched a crowd of demonstrators marching away behind a Dominican flag.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 2 -- Duke spotted Notre Dame 7 points and roared back with a devastating passing attack to crush the Fighting Irish, 37 -- 13, today before a crowd of 35,000.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- In an organized attempt to recapture its architectural heritage, Old San Juan is moving backward at an unprecedented rate of reconstruction. Since the Government-aided restoration program got under way four years ago, twenty-five buildings have been completely restored. Another fifteen restorations are now in progress.

Of all our winter birds, only two are known as snowbirds, and both are as true to the weather as the barometer. Just now our only snowbird is the junco, the genial slate-gray dooryard bird that comes south ahead of the snow. But when winter really arrives, with a biting wind and swirling snow, our midwinter snowbirds, the snow buntings, will seem to come on the very wings of the storm.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- While national attention has been focused on fall-out shelters, health officials have been quietly stockpiling $200,000,000 worth of portable hospitals and medical supplies.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- It has been many years now since the first snow train chugged up along the Housatonic River and eventually pulled up in a cloud of steam at the Bousquets slopes, just a mile or so from the heart of this busy Berkshire city.

MERIDA, Mexico -- My wife and I walked down a path that was walled so thickly with jungle growth that we could not see a thing beyond the rustling underbrush. At the end of the path, we emerged into a clearing studded with tree-covered hills.

" AIRY, fairy Lillian," "the Toast of Broadway," "the Queen of Beauty" -- these are a few of the expressions of homage that were lavished upon a girl who, born 100 years ago tomorrow, became an American legend -- Lillian Russell. Christened Helen Louise Leonard in Clinton, Iowa, she eventually migrated to New York to become an opera singer.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Three years ago yesterday fire swept Our Lady of the Angels Roman Catholic School in Chicago, costing the lives of ninety-two children and three nuns.
Negligees and robes with graceful feminine ways raise waistlines to a new high.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- What are the best fresh-water fishing spots in Florida? That question has baffled many a visiting angler confronted with the extravagant claims of innumerable chambers of commerce up and down the Sunshine State.

Under a new grant of $380,000 from the Fund for the Advancement of Education a group of public schools and the University of Pittsburgh will get a chance to test a dream of long-range educational planning. They will develop and test an educational program that begins in kindergarten and continues through graduate school.
Mayor Wagner has demanded the resignations of 400 employes in the highest-paying city jobs by noon of Dec. 15. The jobs are generally referred to as patronage appointments.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 29 -- Christmas trees were on sale today in the marketplace in front of the Presidential Palace, for next Sunday is Little Christmas, the usually happy start of the Yule season. But this year there is a tinge of uneasiness here.
The United States could disarm without brining on a major depression, a conference at Columbia University was told yesterday.
A former professional football player, champion at the low hurdles and physics instructor is scoring big sales gains for a San Diego, Calif., electronics manufacturing company.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti -- This Negro Republic is in some ways the most rewarding place the American tourist can visit in the Caribbean. It can also be in other ways the most frustrating.

THE publication last month of two provocative books -- "Tomorrow's Illiterates: The State of Reading Instruction Today" (Little Brown Co.) and "What Ivan Knows That Johnny Doesn't" (Random House) -- has rekindled a long-smoldering controversy: Are American children learning to read as well as they could and should? If not, whose fault is it and what's to be done?

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Laurance S. Rockefeller one of Governor Rockefeller's four brothers, was admitted to Medical Center Hospital tonight shortly after dinning with the Governor at the Executive Mansion.

Marriages are planned and made not only in heaven in June, but all year round, everywhere. The Bridal Council and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare have been studying the figures on how many marriages take place, what the outlook is and what such happy events mean to business generally.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 2 -- Five hundred and fifty-six delegates from thirty-five nations gathered at Petropolis today for the World Moral Re-Armament Assembly.
DALLAS, Dec. 2 -- Buffalo picked Ernie Davis of Syracuse, the Heisman Trophy winner, in the American Football League draft today over the protest of New York.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Gene Fullmer, the National Boxing Association's world middleweight champion, will defend his title against Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba, 24-year-old world welterweight champion, in a fifteen-round bout next Saturday night.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A Swedish C-46 transport plane with four men aboard is missing in the vicinity of Luluabourg and feared to have crashed a United Nations spokesman said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 2 -- Navy kept a secret today and then let some 101,000 persons in on it just before the game with Army began.

IT WOULD seem that all that could be done with our most ubiquitous game animal, the rabbit, would be to hunt it, jug it, eat it or give it away at Easter. Not so. As reported in Engineering Outlook, a publication of the University of Illinois, scientists there have wired up some wild rabbits.

THE 132-year-old Rochester Institute of Technology, which includes one of the country's leading departments of photography, has acquired a 1,000-acre campus site in the town of Henrietta, N.Y. Its present site in downtown Rochester consists of thirteen acres.

United States Lines seamen will play Santa Claus, St. Nicholas, Pere Noel and other foreign equivalents of Kris Kringle to orphans in twenty-six ports in Europe, Asia and the Far East during the two-week period preceding Christmas.
HOUSTON, Tex. -- Alphonse Moyse Jr., publisher and editor of Bridge World magazine, hailed this writer during the course of the sixteen-day bridge tournament that ends here today.

WILMINGTON, N.Y. -In a move that has caused quite a flurry among the old-timers in the skiing industry, the Whiteface Mountain ski area in the northern Adirondacks has installed equipment to manufacture its own snow.

The electronics industry expects to finish 1961 by passing the $10,000,000,000 mark for the first time, thus setting a new factory sales record, despite a slow start. And 1962 will be even better, according to the Electronic Industries Association.
Keen competition marks the play in the twenty-ninth Soviet Union championship tournament at the Dzerjinsky Club in Baku.

GEOFFREY Bibby has set himself what would appear an almost impossible task. Taking as his canvas the period between 2,000 and 1,000 B.C., he has attempted to draw a composite picture showing what was going on throughout most of the inhabited globe at the same time.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The Syracuse Nationals took an early lead today and had an easy time beating the Chicago Packers, 132 -- 118, in a nationally televised contest of the National Basketball Association.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- British wildlife conservationists are faced with a paradoxical situation threatening the future of a rare animal, the white rhinoceros.

Before the turn of the century a child had to be an orphan of "respectable" parents to gain admission to the Leake and Watts Children's Homo. The main building of the institution accommodated some 500 children in dormitories.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A territorial trust assumed by the United States in the Pacific Ocean after World War II is complicating the Administration's task in deciding whether to conduct nuclear tests in the atmosphere.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -The scheduled Government inquiry into the securities business -- the first of its scope in thirty years -- is likely to unfold in an atmosphere wholly unlike that which brought the Securities and Exchange Commission into being in the Nineteen Thirties.

AUTOMATION now plays host to diners on the Southern Pacific's San Joaquin Daylight, which operates between Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. The road has replaced a coffee shop car with one containing an array of self-service vending machines.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Quakers and their neighbors across the United States, Canada and Mexico have given more than $60,000 to the United Nations.

UP to the present time there has been no full-lenght biography of Alexander Wilson, the "Father of American Ornithology," who died in Philadelphia in 1813 at the age of 47. During the nearly 150 years since his death the biographical accounts that have appeared have been thin and rather perfunctory.

ONE of the few vehicle free areas in Florida this winter will be the Lincoln Road Mall in Miami Beach, which is strictly for pedestrians. The intrastate roads, however, and the major tourist routes leading into the Sunshine State, will carry a record-breaking number of vehicles during the coming season.
The tragedies an alcoholic can create in a family have led to a rapid spread of weekly discussion groups in and around New York City for relatives, friends and children of alcoholics.

Fortunes of 1,700 Liberian investors, in partnership with their Government and United States associates, will ride the high seas this week as an iron-ore carrier plows out of the Free Port of Monrovia for Liverpool.

WHEN Van Cliburn won the first International Tchaikovsky Piano Contest in Moscow in 1958, the Russians behaved like generous losers. Apparently, though, they are taking the greatest precautions to see that it does not happen again.

Two organizations dedicated to the humane treatment of animals will benefit from a theatre party to "First Love" at the Morosco Theatre on Dec. 15. They are Friends of Animals, Inc., of 510 Madison Avenue and the Animal Welfare Institute at 22 East Seventeenth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- In 1932, nearly 84 per cent of the residents of the island of Tristan da Cunha in the South Atlantic were free of tooth decay. In less than thirty years, the level of decay has risen sharply to that usually encountered in sophisticated societies, apparently in direct relation to the rise in imported food, particularly flour and sugar.
FOR the holiday season, Broadway is offering a limited selection of tickets to the big hits and a big selection of tickets to the limited hits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Five months after Congress approved them, the Administration's mass transit and open-spaces programs have yet to progress past the "out" boxes of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
ATHENS, Dec. 2 -- The Center Union party led by former Premier George Papandreou decided today to boycott the opening of the new Greek Parliament Monday.

ONCE upon a time Broadway's play titles were short, easy to remember, sometimes easy to dismiss, and always a simple matter to post in big block letters on any theatre marquee. The title (if not the substance) of E.E. Cummings' once avant-garde "Him" was immediately assimilable in its stark, no-nonsense brevity, and even the comparatively wordy "My Fair Lady" boasted a certain lilting economy.

PART-TIME writers like F.D. Ommanney, a British fisheries expert by trade, occasionally give professional reporters a lesson in their craft. Mr. Ommanney's new book, "Eastern Windows," is a delight when he confines himself to exotic subjects with which he is more familiar than are many, if not most, journalists who roam the same scenes.

IT is a rare day when a kind word for germs makes headlines. But such an occasion arose recently with a report that the United States Navy is planning to test a potentially revolutionary kind of power source -- a "biological battery" which uses bacteria to generate electricity.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The former head of United Nations operations in Katanga Province in the Congo charged today that he had resigned because of a campaign of pressure against him by Britain and France.

Gene Roberts Jr.'s article "Negro Education -- For What?" (Nov. 19) calls attention to an important aspect of the problem of the Negro's acceptance as an American -the fact that while his educational opportunities have improved, his job opportunities have not kept pace.
The Loyal League Philanthropies, Inc., will give its annual dinner for the benefit of underprivileged children on Dec. 16 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
An exchange of art works and music between high school students in this country and abroad will be fostered by the International Arts Institute, a new nonprofit organization.
New York University's total expenses and appropriations for the 1960-61 fiscal year reached a record high of $69,328,585, the school's annual financial report said today.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 2 -Kay Wonderlic, national chairman of a group called the Students Committee for Accurate National Representation, said this week she had started a campaign against the National Student Association.
OTTAWA, Dec. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The Supreme Court of Canada will decide early next year whether an American company can sue the Government of Cuba in a Canadian court.
DENVER, Dec. 2 -- The American Medical Association took a lighthearted look at American habits this week. It concluded that many customs were here to stay and that moderation was the best policy.

THERE has been a growing trend in recent years to establish skiing centers at points close to large cities, including New York. If nothing else, this enables city dwellers who also are skiing devotees to partake of the sport without the need of making a long automobile trip, often in bad weather.

A CENTURY ago Greece began issuing stamps with a seven-stamp series produced by one of the great engraver-designers of all time, Albert Barre of France. The seven stamps were of one design, Hermes, the Greek god, son of Zeus and Maia, daughter of Atlas.

Mayor Wagner was challenged yesterday by Michael H. Prendergast to let the state's Democratic voters decide whether Mr. Prendergast should be ousted as state Democratic chairman. Mr. Prendergast, whose removal has been demanded by the Mayor, called for changes in the party's rules to permit the direct election of all state party officers in next year's primary.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The Mamaroneck Frostbite Association defeated the Sea Cliff Yacht Club, 4-1, in their second annual inter-fleet team match sailed today in a virtual calm. The competition was held in Dyer dinghies.
A lunge at the tape by Richard Dugan, the anchor man, won the distance medley for Power Memorial High last night in the twelfth annual Catholic High Schools track and field relay carnival.

ALGIERS, Dec. 2 -- The French Administration disclosed today that it had smashed an underground ring of deserters from a first-rank state police unit. The group was said to have joined the Secret Army Organization and to have taken arms, ammunition and other equipment.

The Belock Instrument Corporation of College Point, Queens, announced last week that it would supply a radar stabilization platform for use on weather ships on the North Atlantic that supply data for trans-Atlantic flights.

AN obscure Jaghatai chieftain from the foothills of Ferghana, who called himself "The Tiger" but whose real name was Zahir-ad-din Muhammad, did more to change the destiny of India than any man of his time.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- One of four American Methodist missionaries, freed and deported from Portugal today after having been imprisoned in Angola and at Lisbon, arrived in London tonight. His three colleagues were put aboard a plane in Lisbon for New York.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Frankie Carbo, reputed underworld boxing boss, lost his bid for a new trial today and was sentenced to twenty-five years in prison for trying to cut in on earnings of a former welterweight boxing champion, Don Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Council of the Organization of American States is expected to decide by a large majority Monday that there is a pressing need for a conference of the hemisphere's foreign ministers on Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The big news in the world today is not what the politicians and statesmen are saying but what the people are doing.
BOLOGNA, Italy, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Communist-ruled Bologna decided today to retain the name of its Stalingrad Street.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Bridgeport Socialists are considering changing the party's name because of the association of the name Socialist with Communist in the press.
JOHN FRASER, a 28-year-old English actor, made his first trip to the United States last month and immediately went into rehearsal for an important television assignment.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The nation's public welfare workers are still more concerned about the people who need welfare assistance than about those who criticize it.

THE night of Dec. 3, 1960 -- precisely one year ago -- was a night of no particular moment in the history of mankind, except to a handful of theatrical practitioners and myself. For us it was an opening night, that nerve-mangling, do-or-die, boom-or-bust night in the life of every play, which by consequence always seems to those embroiled an hour of eternal and Biblical significance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Wilson Wade, professor of religion at Dartmouth College, suggests that jazz would fill churches.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The horse doping gang struck at another race favorite today hours after detectives had said the net was closing in on the ring.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 2 -"Christmas Preview," the annual tour of New Canaan homes specially decorated for the event, will be held on Tuesday from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M. Civic projects sponsored by the New Canaan Garden Center will benefit from the proceeds.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Charlie Burns' second-period goal proved the deciding score in a 3-1 Boston victory tonight over New York in a National Hockey League game.

DECIDUOUS shrubs ordered for fall planting often are delivered bare-root, wrapped with loose straw or sometimes with moss. It is not always possible to plant them in their permanent place the same day they arrive.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Eddie Machen broke the nineteen-fight winning streak of Doug Jones of New York in a ten-round bout at Miami Beach Convention Hall tonight.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Holy Cross was too strong too early for Boston College today and easily gained a 38-26 triumph before 24,000 fans at Fitton Field.
SANTA MARIA, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Richard M. Nixon declared tonight that "second-rate" Democrats must be voted out of office in California.
When he made his New York debut last year in Town Hall, George Pappa-Stavrou played a formidable trio of contemporary American piano sonatas.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain's gypsies are suffering from neglect and intolerance and the conditions under which they live are among the worst in the world, a member of Parliament charged today.

WARSAW, Dec. 2 -- A senior member of the Polish Commumunist party has called upon "our Soviet comrades" to demonstrate that the excesses of the personality cult are not inherent and inevitable in the Communist system.

Traffic moving through the Chicago area ports for the 1961 season through September totaled 462,375 tons of exports and 173,185 tons of imports, the Association of Commerce and Industry reported. In the same period last year traffic totaled 519,558 tons of exports and 147,389 of imports.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., Dec. 2 -- Negroes are conducting here an orderly attack on racial barriers.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 2 -- Delegates to the third assembly of the World Council of Churches voted overwhelmingly tonight to strengthen the Trinitarian concept in the council's basic requirement for membership.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Two hundred photographs depicting the heritage, beauty people and progress of Bergen County will be displayed in France next summer by invitation of a group of French students at the Sorbonne.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Adlai E. Stevenson told President Kennedy today that he was thinking of running for the Senate in Illinois next year.
GHARDAIA, Algeria, Nov. 23 -- An isolated Jewish community in this oasis is apprehensive about the spread of the Algerian conflict into the Sahara.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- A Communist youth newspaper said today it was "an American tragedy" that "half a world had been mobilized" in a futile search for Michael Rockefeller, "a millionaire's son."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 2 -- Alabama, the nation's No. 1 college football team, stormed past Auburn, 34 -- 0, today and completed an unbeaten and untied season. Immediately after the game, Alabama accepted a bid to play in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on New Year's Day.
A luncheon and bridge party will be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Sixty-sixth Street, on Tuesday for the benefit of the Manhattanville Community Centers.

WHEN the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra makes its first American tour next year, under the direction of Eugene Mravinsky, it is a safe bet that they will play the three popular Tchaikovsky symphonies.
The fiftieth annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases will be officially opened next Sunday as the holiday season approaches.
In one classroom and three makeshift laboratories in a second-floor walk-up above a bar on Broadway at 168th Street, forty-two students from twenty-two nations are learning to combat malnutrition.

Last week's events made it clear that Premier Khrushchev is engaged in a major peace offensive. There had been signs of this earlier, but the decisive proof was provided by Izvestia's publication of President Kennedy's views on world issues and by the news of Premier Khrushchev's birthday greetings to Pope John XXIII.

TORONTO, Dec. 2 (UPI) -Kenny Ploen ran 19 yards for the winning touchdown today to give the Winnipeg Blue Bombers the Canadian professional football title. They scored a 21-14 overtime victory over the Hamilton Tiger-Cats and won the Grey Cup.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Sparked by the passing and running of its quarterback, Ray Farris, North Carolina routed Virginia; 24 -- 0, today in the sixty-sixth game of their football rivalry.

WITHOUT too much being said about it or anybody working up a sweat over a matter that can best be settled with the application of patience, skill and sense, more and more foreign-language pictures are being shown around the country today with dubbed English dialogue on them.

The Margit Bokor Memorial Fund for Cancer Research at Columbia University will benefit from the seventh annual Vienna Opera Ball to be held Feb. 9 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fund is named for the soprano of the Vienna State Opera who died of cancer.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- Here in spacious Convention Hall, where annually a Miss America is crowned, college football, indoors and under lights, returned tonight after twenty-two years and it was the favored Mariners of the United States Merchant Marine Academy who got crowned.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla. -- The towns of Winter Haven, Dundee, Lake Alfred and Haines City form a small rectangle, roughly four miles wide and seven miles long, in what is almost the exact geographical center of the Florida peninsula. They lie equally distant from Jacksonville and Miami and from Melbourne on the east coast and Tampa on the west.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 3 -2, tonight in a National Hockey League game that enabled them to maintain a firstplace tie with Toronto.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 2 -- Charlie Ufford of the Harvard Club led the way into the semifinal round of the thirtieth Gold Racquets invitation squash racquets tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.
BARROW, Alaska, Dec. 2 -- Eskimos of Alaska are organizing to protect their aboriginal hunting and fishing rights.

DALLAS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Bill Meek, who had one winning campaign in five seasons at Southern Methodist University, was removed as head football coach tonight.

The Bacardi Trophy series, which was a leading fixture of winter Star Class sailing in Cuba until that country's political turmoil ended the competition, will be revived in Miami on Feb. 2, 3 and 4. Not only will the event be in Florida for the first time, but the trophy also will be on a different basis.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 2 -- The United Nations force captured thirty-two Katangese soldiers in a clash today at the Elisabethville Airport.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The Jennie Clarkson Home here will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at "Subways Are for Sleeping," on Jan. 5.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Henry Cooper, who would like to be world champion but can't get a fight with Floyd Patterson, expects to knock out Zora Folley in the second round here Tuesday. After that, maybe Patterson will have to give him a fight.

NO matter how much you may say in a general article, book or lecture on snakes, people always want to know more about the "giant snakes." Now at last we can refer our inquirers to a book that tells the whole truth and nothing but the truth about these big reptiles.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 2 -Eight young women will be honored at the second annual Montclair Cotillion, to be held on Dec. 22 at the Montclair Golf Club. The debutantes, all daughters or granddaughters of club members, will be honored also by their parents at dinner parties preceding the ball.

Last week's warning by the Engineering Manpower Commission that the engineering shortage will get worse in the next four to six years has met with mixed response. To most manpower experts, including those of the Scientific Manpower Commission, the predictions appeared like a gloomy but accurate picture of things to come.

MOST of this nation's rocket-and-missile history has been made at Cape Canaveral -- and more is in the making. The already huge complex is about to be enlarged to five times its present size to do the great testing jobs of today and tomorrow for two purposes: continued development of military weapons and the peaceful exploration of space. It is doing some of these jobs now.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Nov. 22 -- Gen. Humberto Delgado, an exiled leader of the Portuguese opposition, appealed today to his country's army to halt its war against the Angolan rebels and work with him to establish a democratic regime.

AMERICAN recording companies are seldom noted for their enterprise in the field of chamber music. Aside from the large Budapest Quartet repertory on Columbia and the growing number of disks by the Juilliard Quartet on Columbia and later, R.C.A. Victor, most domestic companies have confined their chamber issues to recordings made abroad.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 2 -- The New Zealand Government has canceled a program announced early this year to double the rate of assisted immigration.

THE red star in the corner of the frame that means "sold" in an exhibition is the biggest thing that can happen to an artist unless he is a more bizarre personality than good artists usually are. Because it means money, the red star means food and shelter for most artists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy will name William Edwards Stevenson, former president of Oberlin College in Ohio, Ambassador to the Philippines, informed sources said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers were selected today to meet the University of California at Los Angeles Bruins in the Rose Bowl, a move that may pave the way for renewal of the bowl pact between the Big Ten and Big Five conference. A. Sulka Co., purveyor of neckties to presidents and potentates, is busy these days supplying them to the American masses -- or at least to those among the masses who can afford to pay $6.50 to $15 for a tie.

Judge Simon Rifkind's letter in The Times of Nov. 26 was excellent -- as far as it went. Of course, it is desirable to broaden the base of political contributions, but unless there is some control of political spending we are well on our way up a never-ending spiral of increasing campaign costs.

For his first movie since "Room at the Top," British director Jack Clayton has turned to Henry James' classic ghost story, "The Turn of the Screw." Working from a screenplay by William Archibald and Truman Capote, Clayton shot the film in England with Deborah Kerr as the governess who believes ghosts are threatening the lives of the two children in her charge.

TWO leading German manufacturers have placed on the American market portable electronic flash units in both amateur and professional or advanced amateur classes. Mecablitz offers the professional Model 502, with a choice of wet-cell (lead acid) or nickel cadmium battery power, at $149.50 and $169.50, respectively, and a total of up to 400 flashes per charge on the low output setting.

THIS is a letter of sympathy to certain bewildered readers. I have in mind that minority who make a fairly wide sampling of the various critical reactions to new books. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company began shutting down its supermarkets in the Philadelphia area this afternoon as the result of a strike by 1,000 butchers.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Barnesville Miss won the $15,000 added Gallorette Stakes at Pimlico today, defeating Colony Flyer by a head.

HOUSTON, Dec. 2 -- Butch Blume scored two touchdowns and kicked 27 and 33 yard field goals today to guide the Rice Owls to a 26-14 victory over Baylor and gain the host spot in the Bluebonned Bowl on Dec. 16.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Harvard, teeming with skilled manpower, is bracketed with Clarkson Tech as the Eastern hockey squad most likely to succeed in 1961-62.
SUMMIT, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Eight college freshmen from Summit will be honored by their parents at a dinner dance at the Beacon Hill Club here on Dec. 22.

OXFORD, Miss. -- The thousands of tourists who annually make the seventy-five-mile journey south from Memphis, Tenn., to this small town in northern Mississippi come here for more than just a glimpse of the magnolia-scented charm of the Old South.

VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- Prof. Claus Schedl of the University of Graz has published several papers on chronological problems of the Old Testament in which he asserts that erroneous decipherings of ancient manuscripts have prevented a proper understanding of historical accounts in the Bible.
Tom O'Connor, a junior fullback from Chicopee Falls, Mass., has been elected captain of Columbia's 1962 football team. He succeeds William Campbell, a senior.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 2 -- George Meany looked back today at six years of labor unity and found just one reason for dissatisfaction -- the failure of big unions to organize the unorganized.

GEN. LUCIUS DUBIGNON CLAY, a West Point career officer, Class of 1918, saw the city of Berlin for the first time on June 5, 1945. He had come to help arrange with the Russians for the entry of American troops, and his mind was full of the fearful tasks ahead in settling the "German problem."
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Leo Szilard has announced the establishment of a Council for Abolishing War that could spend $25,000,000 a year lobbying for peace.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The parents and relatives of ten Rye debutantes have arranged a dinner dance for the young women at the Apawamis Club on New Year's Eve.

FLEXIBLE electric heating cables can be used by homeowners in many different ways to protect against damage caused by winter freeze-ups. Economical to install and operate, these heating cables will prevent freezing of exposed water pipes and waste lines and will stop formation of ice dams along the roof edges and in gutters and downspouts.

BRITAIN is not going "soft" on communism; nor is she going back on NATO. Any reports to the contrary can be dismissed out of hand. She will play her part in the great alliance; but she needs to know what that part is and what the alliance is for. She is in a questioning mood; and she has every reason to be, seeing that her own future as a habitable land is at stake.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- For many years, Florida depended on the lures of the sun, sea and sand, plus fishing, horse racing and the chance to acquire a mid-winter tan, as sufficient inducement to draw a big flock of winter visitors.
