Through the years, one of the greatest lures of Madison Avenue has been its glamorous wages. In the eyes of many ambitious young men, the advertising business seemed like a fast-moving gravy train offering a quick ride to wealth and success.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Dec. 1 -- Scientists of the United States Army Signal Corps have developed a system for synchronizing high-precision atomic clocks down to millionths of a second on a global scale.

HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- Premier Fidel Castro said today that he was forming a "united party of Cuba's Socialist revolution," a monolithic organization like the Soviet Communist party with restricted membership.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- The winter sports picture in Pennsylvania suddenly is coming to life again. With skiing, among other winter sports, dormant in the Keystone State for many years, those who were partial to these activities had to look to areas such as New York State and New England.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Planners were told this week that the goals of urban America must relate to human interests and needs as much as to wood and stone, monumental buildings, huge parking lots and refurbished homes.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 28 -- Indications are that the coalition Liberal-Country Party Government, headed by Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies, will again be returned at the Australian Federal elections Dec. 9.
VENICE, Dec. 1 -- Three years of painstaking work in the Basilica of Saint Mark here has eliminated the danger of collapse of the pillars supporting the apse and main dome.

EUSTACE MULLINS is, I fear disingenuous when he refers in a recent letter to the Editor to the fact that Ezra Pound told him I was working on a biography which was "nearly completed" and that he, Mullins, "decided to put in another year of research, and get to some things that [Norman] might overlook.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Probably not since the end of World War II had the cause of disarmament looked so bleak as it did this week with the virtual collapse of the test bar talks in Geneva.

PORT ELIZABETH, Bequia, B.W.I. -- Ever since the first intrusion on its privacy nearly 300 years ago, this tiny Caribbean island has resented waves of visitors. Now, however, it has begun to relax its isolationism, but only to a modified degree.

DALLAS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns used two recovered fumbles and a pass interception for three first-period touchdowns today and went on to a 38-17 victory over the Dallas Cowboys in the National Football League.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Dec. 3 -- A reservist recalled to active duty was given two weeks' restriction and extra duty today for having written a complaining letter to the Boston Herald.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, devoted an entire edition to the subject of peace today, declaring there is "an actual possibility of excluding world war from the life of human society."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Kennedy Administration is preparing for a new assault on United States tax policy next year, its 1961 assault having stalled.
BERLIN, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Stares and friendly waves from Russian soldiers and German citizens greeted a United States Congressional group touring behind the Communist wall in East Berlin today.

Burton B. Turkus and Dr. Donald F. Shaughnessy have been appointed aribtrators of York Shipping Association and the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association's Atlantic and Gulf dry cargo, tanker and collier agreements.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 -- Steel officials were starting to talk in bullish terms about their market outlook last week.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Prototype sports cars up to four liters in engine size will be invited to race at Sebring, Fla., and at three other major world sports car races next year, Alec Ulmann, the promoter of the Sebring race, said today.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- Swiss bankers are partly amused and partly annoyed by the aura of mystery and even evil that is attached in some foreign eyes to the famous matter of "numbered accounts."

TORONTO, Dec. 3 -- Floyd Patterson, the soft-speaking and hard-punching heavyweight champion of the world, will risk his crown tomorrow night against Tom McNeeley, the voluble and wild-swinging aspirant from Arlington, Mass.
Financial history will be made this week, but the eleven big New York commercial banks who will help make it would just as soon have been spared the honor.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 3 -- Crude oil and gas flowed strongly in a well at Moonie, Queensland, during a seventy-four-minute test today.
Ernie Davis will play pro football next year -- for the New York Titans, Buffalo Bills, Washington Redskins, Timbuktu Terrors or anyone.

In a letter published Nov. 10 yet another Arab representative repeated the allegation that Israel Arabs "are not given access to civil courts under ordinary circumstances but are subject instead to courts-martial."
MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The Soviet Union warned Denmark today that her military cooperation with West Germany within the North Atlantic alliance "complicated the situation of Denmark's neutral neighbors."
HONG KONG, Dec. 3 -Communist China has turned its attention to the question of who discovered America.

ALGIERS, Dec. 3 -- Moderate Frenchmen in Algeria believe that President de Gaulle has gained ground in the fight against the Secret Army Organization, which is battling against his program for Algerian independence.
College football has come to the end of the season with Alabama and Ohio State on top. The final polls of the coaches and writers will choose between them for the national champion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Detroit Lion touchdown and conversion kick in the final twenty-two seconds pinned a 16-15 loss today on Chicago However, Roger Leclerc of the Bears equaled a twenty-five-year-old National Football League record of five field goals.

A group of investors headed by Alvin M. Greenstein has taken title to the Gotham Hotel, southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. It was sold recently by Webb Knapp, Inc. The seller leased back the hotel for twenty-one years plus sixteen renewal options and will continue to operate it through the Zeckendorf Hotels Corporation.

Events today: "La Fanciulla del West," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Michael Rogers, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Murray Taylor, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

The director of worship of the United Lutheran Church in America proposed yesterday that the denomination's churches "cancel all plans for Christmas services this year" to protest the "orgy of commercialism" that has swallowed the religious significance of Christmas.

Curacao's importance as a transshipment and bunkering center in the Caribbean area is expected to increase steadily as a result of new facilities installed in Willemstad, according to a report issued by S.G.M. Rozendal, the island's Commissioner for Economic Affairs.

Two operas will be revived during the Metropolitan Opera's eighth week, which begins next Monday. Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" will be presented Tuesday night after a season's lapse, and Wagner's "Das Rheingold" will be heard Saturday afternoon for the first time since 1957.
Last night's Town Hall recital of Hyman Bress was a frustrating affair. It was so good it ought to have been better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk agreed today that establishing some major United Nations offices in West Berlin would be a good idea. But he opposed shifting the main United Nations headquarters from New York.
Plans are being made to bring "Rich and Famous," starring Anne Bancroft, to Broadway in March.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 3 -- Mediation of New York's next transit crisis will begin here Wednesday, 1,400 miles from the scene of the dispute.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The British believe the ending of Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien's mission in Katanga Province has removed an obstacle to new negotiations for a peaceful settlement in the Congo.
The World Confederation of General Zionists adopted a "Declaration of Basic Principles" last night that called for "world-wide Jewish unity" with Israel as its spiritual center.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Legislation requiring youthful drinkers to show identification cards in taverns will be filed tomorrow by State Senator Edward J. Speno, Republican of East Meadow, L.I.
Edwin A. Walker declared yesterday that he would carry on his patriotic work without affiliating with any group or individual.

KANPUR, India, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Leg-break bowling by Subhas Gupte and Chandrakant Borde, who between them, captured all eight English wickets to fall today, helped India gain a strong position on the third day of the second cricket test match.

Under pressure of heavy selling the British pound sterling and Canadian dollar turned weak in the foreign exchange market last week. Continental currencies, on the other hand, showed a strong undertone.

HOUSTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- George Blanda passed for four touchdowns and kicked three conversions and two field goals today as the Houston Oilers sent the San Diego Chargers to a 33-13 loss, their first setback in twelve games.

A floor in the new Pfizer Building, 235 East Forty-second Street, has been leased by the People's Planning Corporation of America, underwriter of shares and programs for the People's Security Corporation mutual fund and A.S. Karasick Co., manager of fund.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand Nov. 25 -- Insects were frequent long-distance passengers on the trans-Pacific airways eons before man took to the skies, a current study suggests.
GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- The Swiss stock markets were very active last week, with the big Swiss commercial banks once again the favorites of investors.
Roman Catholics over the world observed yesterday the beginning of their church's new ecclesiastical year, the First Sunday of Advent.

American labor is showing an enlightened sense of the benefits its members will share with the nation and the free world if President Kennedy's program for the lowering of tariff walls and the expansion of international trade is adopted.

DENVER, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Boston Patriots struck on a 51-yard touchdown aerial and set up another score on a 59-yard runback of a pass interception in a whirlwind fourth quarter today to beat the Broncos, 28-24.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 3 -- Jasper McLevy, Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport from 1933 to 1957, today led old-line party members in opposing a change in the party's name.

A resolution on social drinking adopted by the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. has caused confusion in the denomination, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in a sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The Polish folk dance company called Mazowsze, which closed a three-week engagement at the City Center yesterday with a box-office total of $200,000, will be booked by S. Hurok for an additional seven performances in the metropolitan area during Christmas week.

The chief complaint against Bluegrass music -- lack of subtlety -- was rebutted convincingly at a concert Saturday night by Flatt and Scruggs and the Foggy Mountain Boys. It was the second of two concerts Saturday by the six-man string band at the Ethical Culture Society Auditorium with Jack Elliott, singer and guitarist.

Adlai E. Stevenson was a good enough campaigner to take the Governorship of Illinois by a wide margin in 1948 and a great enough political figure to appeal to the nation's Democrats as Presidential timber in 1952 and 1956. The wise men think he could be nominated and elected Senator from Illinois next year to take the place of that wily Republican veteran, Everett McKinley Dirksen.

THIS Friday, to celebrate the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, the A. Veniero bakery, 342 East Eleventh Street, will bake a special pastry called the immacolata. It is a rich and flavorful concoction, the small pastry shell filled with a mixture of sour cherries, raisins, figs, chocolate and chopped nuts.

IT can never be said that Elizabeth Arden has not kept up with the jet age. With beauty passports and travelers checks, she is carving out her own international empire with colonies in twenty-seven countries. Each offers the same treatment, whether it be in London, Lima or San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Government, which has developed into a multi-billion-dollar patron of research and development in industry and universities, is facing what Administration officials regard as a serious crisis in its own scientific ranks.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq threatened tonight to start a war unless Britain kept out of the Persian Gulf Sheikdom of Kuwait, the Baghdad radio reported.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of comment today by Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, on President Kennedy's interview with Aleksei I. Adzhubei, the paper's editor, Nov. 25, as transmitted in English by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

Ever since his first recital here in 1956, Paul Harelson has devoted considerable time and effort to new works. Yesterday afternoon the young New York pianist gave another recital at Carnegie Recital Hall, and his program again included contemporary music.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Francis Patrick Kennedy, 20 years old, jumped off the Golden Gate Bridge today and survived. He is the second person to live through such a leap.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Frank Haxell, former general secretary of the Electrical Trades Union, has resigned from the Communist party, according to a party statement tonight.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy said yesterday there would be no mass transfers in the department this Christmas season. His predecessor, Stephen P. Kennedy, had made such transfers to reduce the number of gifts to policemen.

Algernon D. Black, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, said here yesterday that the United States' unwillingness "to recognize Communist China reflects a certain blindness on our part."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The American economy will climb to new levels of prosperity in 1962 but some of its most serious problems will persist, the United States Chamber of Commerce forecast today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Army is reviving the famous World War I poster of Uncle Sam pointing sternly at the viewer with the legend, "I Want You."
Governor-elect Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey said yesterday that he would meet soon with Governor Rockefeller in hopes of settling major issues between their states.

In many ways cities resemble people. They are born, they come to maturity and they die. Some cities thrive and prosper while others never seem to rise from the kind of morass in which so many people stumble through their lives.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has postponed a telecast of "Noah and the Flood," an hour-long dance drama that Igor Stravinsky, the composer, and George Balanchine, the choreographer, were commissioned to create.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals rallies in the second half and with Sa Etcheverry and John Dav Crow setting the pace defeated the Washington Redskins 38 -- 24, today. The defeat spoiled the Redskins' bid for their first National Football League victory in twenty-two games.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., Dec. 13 -- President Kennedy's recent effort to explain to reservists why they are in uniform again appears to have made the same impression a peashooter makes on a tank.

DEEP in the heart of our second largest state a wound must be bleeding. Nobody enjoys being criticized, analyzed and held up for amused inspection. What we all want is affection and admiration. But Texans, according to John Bainbridge, author of "The Super-Americans,"* are far more sensitive to unenthusiastic comments than the rest of us.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills beat the Oakland Raiders, 26 -- 21, today in an American Football League game at Candlestick Park.

Over-the-counter securities showed more consistent strength last week than listed issues. While stocks on the New York Stock Exchange lost ground on average on every day but one -Friday -- prices in the over-thecounter market fluctuated up and down and ended Friday on a stronger note.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 1 -- 0, tonight on Don Marshall's first-period goal. It was their fourth National Hockey League victory of the season over the Hawks.
The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Inc., appointed Mrs. Naomi Thomas Gray of New York as its field director yesterday.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Hugh McElhenny of Minnesota passed the 10,000-yard mark today in total career yardage as the Vikings beat the Los Angeles Rams, 42 -- 21, in a National Football League game.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association ranked Hugh Curry of Orlando, Fla., as the top 13-years-and-under boy tennis player in the country yesterday and Richard Stockton of Garden City, L.I., as the No. 1 boy in the 11-years-and-under division.
Communist China's industrial production declined significantly this year from the record levels of 1960, Western diplomatic sources say.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., Dec. 3 -Railroad stations without railroads have become collectors items in the suburbs.

The revolutionary Cuban Government has now been placed squarely and officially "on the path to communism." Premier Fidel Castro in announcing this during one of his interminable television speeches stated his firm personal belief in Marxism-Leninism. The new monolithic Communist-type party which he announced on July 26 is apparently ready to be set up.

Charges of assaulting a policeman were brought yesterday against a man who twice previously had been arrested for similar offenses. The incident occurred on West Eighty-fourth Street -- a neighborhood notorious for its crime record.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 3 -- Stirling Moss of England won the Nassau Tourist Trophy race today as the eighth annual International Speed Week of the Bahamas rolled into high gear.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Prospects for mass transportation to New Jersey's newly acquired portion of Sandy Hook were described as very encouraging today by the head of the State Division of Resource Development.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- British defense planning, it was reliably reported tonight, is still being based on global strategic concepts despite pressure from the Allies for greater troop strength in Europe.
MASSENA, N.Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway closed officially for the season last midnight after a two-day delay because of bad weather and a late rush in grain traffic.

THE woman whose husband "hates" her in black or will not let her make a fashion move without consulting him has only herself to blame. Husbands should be trained early in marriage to respect their wives' independence in certain realms, namely, fashion and home furnishings.

IN a book on the subject, Miss Sophia Delza explains that T'ai Chi Ch'uan is an ancient Chinese system of exercises having as its aim good physical, mental and emotional health. All she had to cope with there were ideas and the written word.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- A platoon of United States infantrymen moved up tonight to the Communist border wall that divides Berlin shortly after East German soldiers and laborers began narrowing the gaps in the barrier at the seven crossing points.

Iran presents almost a laboratory specimen of a feudal society, improbably persisting into the middle of the twentieth century and suddenly overtaken by the surging birth of a tumultuous middle class.

The chairman of the board of a leading show business corporation, who rose to the top without really trying, would like to resign. The age of the organization man notwithstanding none of his colleagues want the job.
"OLD Oliver," a prominent McComb, Miss., banker and business man once said, "is dynamite himself."

ELISABETHVILLE, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A United Nations spokesman said today that fire from a Katanga strongpoint north of here near Nyunzu hit one United Nations plane and wounded an Irish officer, Capt. Roger Morlay.

A CAPACITY and vociferous audience was on hand for the Metropolitan Opera's second performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" Saturday night. Sufficient standees to fill all available space in the opera house had already collected in line by soon after sunrise; therefore the management placed standing - room tickets on sale at 10:30 A.M., instead of the usual 7:30 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Amateur Athletic Union completed its reorganization today by naming Navy Capt. Stephen N. Archer as full-time secretary.
HONG KONG, Dec. 3 -- Commentary in Peiping's Jenmin Jih Pao today denounced the "unjust attitude" of the Indian and Canadian delegates on the International Control Commission in Vietnam.

The National Lead Company has announced that a new engineering study will be undertaken on the smelting of titanium ore, called ilmenite, from the Tellnes mine of the company's Norwegian subsidiary, Titania A/S, near Hauge i Dalane, Norway.

Members of the Manhattan Women's Committee of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will be entertained tomorrow at a tea, to be given by Mrs. John A. Morris, chairman of the committee, at her home, 4 East Seventy-second Street.
Mrs. J. Raymond Jones, wife of the Harlem Democratic leader, will be sworn in as Collector of Customs for the Virgin Islands in a Washington ceremony next Monday.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $84,678,693,-091. They consist o Treasury securities as follows:

From the reports recently filed with the Board of Elections it is now clear that campaign expenditures on behalf of Mayor Wagner and his two top running mates amounted to three times their combined salaries for the next four years.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The stock market settled back last week to a period of slow trading and little change in price levels.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 3 -- Pile-driving Jim Taylor hammered into the Giant line for a fourth-quarter touchdown today that clinched the National Football League's Western Conference title for Green Bay.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The Public Health Service reported today that slightly more than half the aged persons checked in a two-year survey were covered by hospitalization insurance.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Gay Brewer Jr. of Crystal River, Fla., capped an eventful week today by winning the $20,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament by four strokes.
STRATFORD, Conn., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The American Shakespeare Festival announced today that Helen Hayes and Maurice Evans would appear here together during the 1962 festival season.
A major reorganization of the local school boards has been proposed by a special committee of the Board of Education.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Despite the absence of Bob Cousy, the Boston Celtics routed the Cincinnati Royals tonight, 119 -- 96, in a National Basketball Association game.
The Hall of Issues -- a spontaneous forum of unspoken opinions -- drew hundreds of sight-seers to its opening yesterday at 241 Thompson Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -Charles (Sonny) Liston, who is so pure these days he almost floats, will meet Albert Westphal, a master baker from Hamburg, Germany, in the other heavyweight fight tomorrow night.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Dec. 3 -The body of a young man and a girl were found in a flaming automobile parked on a lonely road near here early today.
The New York Titans contained the feared running of Abner Haynes, received a good performance from Al Dorow and went on to a 28-7 triumph over the Dallas Texans yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The battle is joined for the post of Democratic majority leader of the House, but the hottest fight may yet develop for the little-known job of party whip.

Nick Chaknis, leader of a rank-and-file group, was chosen president of Local 707 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters yesterday in a closely contested contest. He defeated Vincent Doyle, president of the local since its formation eleven years ago, by a vote of 1,095 to 1,018.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 3 -The keys and ownership certificate of a new synagogue, built on the site where the oldest synagogue in Germany stood until the Nazis destroyed it in 1938, were handed over today to the Jewish community of the Rhine town of Worms.
The state is intensifying its efforts to help Negroes get into job apprenticeship programs. The program is being conducted through private conversations with unions and employers.

Three Methodist missionaries who had been held three months in Angolan and Portuguese jails arrived here by air yesterday after having been deported from Lisbon. They attributed their release to pressure put on the Portuguese Government by thousands of letters from American church people.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The state's role in medical education and recruitment for medicine and allied fields will be studied by a special three-member committee appointed today by Governor Rockefeller and Chancellor Edgard W. Couper of the State Board of Regents.

The American Institute of Chemical Engineers opened its fifty-fourth annual meeting here yesterday, with representatives of four recipient nations explaining how technical assistance programs can be made more effective.

I wish to clarify the Borough of Manhattan's policy in making street repairs at night for the benefit of your correspondent Florence L. Gitterman. In business and commercial areas, to preclude the loss of thousands of dollars and in order to avoid impossible congestion, the borough has undertaken nighttime street repairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The latest stalemate in the negotiations in Geneva for a ban on nuclear tests has come just in time for the American delegate, Arthur Dean, to keep conveniently an important engagement.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was marked by an easing of near delivery prices, but the more distant positions showed relative steadiness last week.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Eagles turned three pass interceptions into touchdowns and Tim Brown scored on a 66-yard punt return to defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers today, 35 -- 24. The National Football League game was capped by a free-swinging fight in the last minute.
A reported shift of a key liquor account and another move by an important United States agency into the French market were in the wind over the weekend.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- The United Nations warned today that it was prepared to use force to restore order in Katanga Province.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- The least vocal of the 1,000 delegates and observers at the Third Assembly here of the World Council of Churches is a group of five Roman Catholic priests. They are the first of their faith to attend a major meeting of the council as observers for the Vatican.
Alabama's unbeaten eleven has been chosen to receive the McArthur Bowl award here tomorrow night at the fourth annual dinner of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Two manuscripts of the late Dr. Walter Damrosch have been acquired by the Library of Congress, which described them as historically important.
The Rev. Harvey W. Noordsy was inducted yesterday as minister in charge of the West End Collegiate Church, West End Avenue at Seventy Seventh Street.

In a bruising contest that reminded older fans of Ching Johnson and others of by-gone days who fought to keep New York at the top in the National Hockey League, the Rangers whipped the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, last night at Madison Square Garden.

Statistics indicate that Tokyo and London are larger cities than New York. But perhaps the biggest city that now exists or ever has existed is the one described in a current Twentieth Century Fund report: it extends 500 miles from Boston to Washington and includes about 38 million persons.

Ellen Douglas, whose short story "On the Lake" caused a bit of comment when it appeared in a recent issue of The New Yorker, is the winner of the 1961 Houghton Mifflin-Esquire Fellowship, amounting to $7,500.
Mayor Wagner has sent Governor Rockefeller a program under which the city would get $261,219,000 in increased state aid and new revenues from taxes in 1962.

Tax Commissioner Mortimer M. Caplin expressed concern last week that business men might be overly optimistic regarding possible adjustments in "Bulletin F," the basic schedule for depreciation under the tax law.
The head of the National Conference of Christians and Jews last night assailed those extremist groups who identify themselves as "conservative and patriots" and who foster "distrust among neighbors."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 -- One of the world's current, major and almost universal problems might be called metropolomania, the big city madness. Cities grow larger, denuding the countryside of population; and cities also grow richer, producing an unhealthy contrast with rural areas that too frequently grow poorer.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 3 -Minnesota, which must lose a United States Representative as a result of the 1960 census, moved closer to Congressional redistricting Saturday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- The Soviet Government newspaper, Izvestia, accused President Kennedy today of pursuing a "big stick" policy by suggesting that the autobahn through East Germany to West Berlin be placed under international control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The United States should be willing to devalue the dollar if necessary to stem the continuing outflow of gold, rather than impose more restrictions on imports, a Columbia University professor said today.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 3 -- The appointment of Dr. Gilbert Horton Mudge as dean of the Dartmouth Medical School was announced today. Dr. Mudge, Professor of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics and Associate Dean of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, will assume his new post next June 1.

WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 3 -Senator Jacob K. Javits said today the United States should "set some minimum conditions under which our foreign aid would be effective, and if the conditions are not met, withhold the aid."
Three pedestrians were killed in two traffic accidents last night. One of the deaths was caused by a hit-and-run driver.

In a Nov. 22 article by Clayton Knowles you name me as listed among "extreme Right-Wing lecturers" who speak at the National War College. I am curious just what the definition of "extreme Right-Wing" is as of today, since it seems to shift day by day.

WELDON SPRING, Mo., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Armforth's Micklewood Dan, owned by the Armforth Kennel of Chicago, and handled by Steve Studnicki of Mokena, Ill., won the English Springer Spaniel National Championship Stake today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A major spilt in the Organization of American States is expected tomorrow when the organization votes on whether to hold a special foreign ministers' conference to review threats posed by Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce predicted today that new construction would set a $60,000,000,000 record in 1962, with revived residential building leading the advance.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 3 -The masters' pair contest in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament here entered the last two of four sessions today with New York and Philadelphia players leading the field of 304 pairs.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The grain futures market was idle or drifted generally lower last week.
A campaign to raise $200,000 to defray the cost of next summer's free performances at the New York Shakespeare Festival is under way.
SANTA MARIA, Calif., Dec. 3 -- California Republicans faced a major question today: How far to the right must the party go in the 1962 state election?
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 3 -Nearly complete election results indicated tonight that Dr. Mamoun Kuzbari and other moderate Right Wingers would control the new Syrian Parliament.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman's three goals, including two in the final two minutes, enabled the Detroit Red Wings to score a 3-1 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs. The victory snapped the Leafs' six-game undefeated streak.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that a low-yield nuclear device had been tested underground in the Nevada desert.
McCOMB, Miss., Dec. 3 -- A Federal District judge has issued a temporary ban against further tests of bus terminal desegregation here by the Congress of Racial Equality.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 3 -- James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that the return of his union to the labor federation was inevitable.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 3 -- The Opposition National Civic Union requested tonight the "urgent presence" here of an observation team of the Organization of American States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Submission of international disputes to binding arbitration to reduce the danger of nuclear war was urged today by the Federation of American Scientists.
A Quaker leader urged parishioners yesterday at St. George's Protestant Church to abhor ingratitude that is marked by both self-absorbtion and self-pity.

The training programs for engineers who will operate the world's first nuclear-power commercial vessel, the Savannah, was disclosed last week by two Professors of Nuclear Engineering at the Merchant Marine Academy.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 3 -- Leaders of the ruling parties attacked today the idea that the present unitary state should be changed into a Flemish-Walloon federation.
The city's two most powerful traffic reform groups urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to override the City Planning Commission's rejection of a parking garage under Bryant Park.

IN the art world, Tenth Street means the block or 60 east of Fourth Avenue with some adjacent spots spraying off the main stem. Additionally it means the habitat of strugglers without uptown gallery connections who show, sometimes by cooperative arrangement, in unpretentious quarters with ohemian overtones.
A three-year study of Roman Catholic parochial schools will be undertaken by the University of Notre Dame under a $350,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation.
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- This city, in many ways one of the world's most civilized, has experienced about 200 bombings since the first of the year.

Your Nov. 18 editorial states, "It is of no use to argue that the former Belgian colony is an artificial structure and not a nation. It is as much a nation as early medieval Britain, Italy, Germany or France was." The implication seems to be that the modern Congo is in much the same state as medieval Europe and that, therefore, we can hopefully expect it to develop in the same way.
The Transit Authority's annual report, submitted yesterday to Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller, showed that the profits of its bus lines were counterbalancing losses on the subway.
A three-year study of Roman Catholic parochial schools will be undertaken by the University of Notre Dame under a $350,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation.
PARIS, Dec. 3 -- This city, in many ways one of the world's most civilized, has experienced about 200 bombings since the first of the year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Sweden appealed today for the immediate admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Supreme Court today invited the states to bring to the court their growing conflicts over abandoned property.

A Molotov cocktail was thrown at the window of a West Side synagogue last night. The crude bomb, a jar of flammable liquid with a smoldering wick, broke the window but fell back to the pavement and failed to explode.
As one who knows and has watched the outstanding work of Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, majority leader for many years, I cannot agree with your editorial of Nov. 20.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Dea's First recorded the highest straight price of the Pimlico meeting when she returned $233.60 after winning the ninth race on today's program.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 4 -- The members of the Westchester Board of Supervisors were compared to thieves at a public hearing today for proposing to increase their county pay 30 to 60 per cent on Jan. 1.

Plans to consolidate General Battery and Ceramic Corporation of Reading, Pa., Filtors, Inc., of Port Washington, L.I., and the Shoup Voting Machine Corporation of New York into a single company were announced yesterday by the principals.

It wasn't meant to be, but the extra added attraction to last night's Floyd Patterson-Tom McNeeley heavyweight title bout turned out to be a slapstick short subject, with dialogue to match, as it unfolded on closed-circuit television.
I want to take exception to your editorial of Nov. 28 on teachers' strikes, in which you criticize my remarks on a recent radio program.
AT its golden anniversary luncheon tomorrow, the Broadway Association will present its gold medal to Richard Rodgers -- "For the Greatest Achievement for the Advancement of Broadway."
The Washington, the third of four 14.370-ton cargo ships under construction for the States Steamship Company of San Francisco in Virginia, will be launched at Newport News on Dec. 15.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4 -Dan Terpack today was elected captain of Princeton's 1962 football team.

Mikhail Tal, the former world champion, suffered his first defeat in the Soviet chess championship at Baku yesterday in a twelfth-round match against David Bronstein, a Moscow grandmaster, according to a dispatch from Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
McCOMB, Miss., Dec. 4 (AP) -- A city judge imposed a thirty-day sentence and a $100 fine on an oil worker today for his attack on a newspaper editor here.
Stocks dipped on average yesterday in brisk trading. However, the easing was not general. The market was an irregular affair, with steel and some motor and oil issues showing the greatest strength.
President Kennedy flies here today to accept the fifth Gold Medal Award of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame at a dinner tonight in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that on Jan. 1 it would begin to pay 3 1/2 per cent on regular savings deposits and 4 per cent on savings deposits of one year or more. It has been paying 3 per cent.

As I was born in Russia and have lived more than eleven years in this country, I think I can appreciate the interview President Kennedy granted to Aleksei Adzhubei, the editor of Izvestia, both from the Russian and the American points of view.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -A statement by Her Majesty's Forestry Commission that for certain purposes an American oak tree, Quercus rubra, was superior to the British oak, Quercus robur, has upset the tree lovers of Britain.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Once week-end buying orders had been completed the stock market became irregular here today, and in some share groups prices turned dull.
The long and bitter contest over the United States Travel Service account ended last night with three big agencies splitting the prize.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -Most corn futures contracts slumped to their lowest levels of the season today on the Board of Trade and pulled some oats contracts to within a cent or so of their season laws.

An employe of Jack Dempsey's restaurant was held up yesterday on Broadway by three men who seized an attache case containing week-end receipts of $6,500. One of the men was captured, and the case was recovered intact.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- The United States presented to the United Nations today a detailed program for world cooperation in the peaceful use of space.
Richie Guerin, who has been averaging 30 points a game, is a doubtful starter for the New York Knickerbockers' contest tonight against the Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether it is constitutional to say a daily prayer in New York public schools.

The life and adventures of a social worker in the slums of New York are told by Bernice Offenberg in "The Angel of Hell's Kitchen." Bernard Geis Associates will issue it Jan. 15. Miss Offenberg spent ten years as a caseworker with the city Welfare Department.

The names of the 104 young women to be presented at the twenty-sixth Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 21 have been announced by Mrs. Eugene W. Ong and Mrs. Sherman Pratt, co-chairmen for the event.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- The flaming courage of Tom McNeeley made an exciting drama of his fight with Floyd Patterson in the Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. But the champion chopped him down with the methodical precision of a butcher going to work on an obstreperous steer.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., Dec. 4 -The Puritans took the custom of bundling pretty much in their stride 300 years ago, but the early courting practice has been termed too racy even for study now by high school seniors here.

Eighty per cent of the nation's total rubber requirements will be filled by synthetic rubber five years from now, a chemical products specialist from the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company predicted yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers at the Commodore Hotel.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that his third-term administration would have "fresh blood in areas where it is needed."

There were indications yesterday that many television stations affiliated with the American Broadcasting Company canceled "Bus Stop" on Sunday night because they believed the savage story of a psychotic teen-age killer would offend many viewers.
The political axe that Mayor Wagner suspended over the head of Joseph T. Sharkey during the Democratic primary campaign appears about to fall.

Tenants of the apartment house at 180 Riverside Drive are considering turning it into a cooperative. The thirteen-story-and-penthouse structure is on the corner of Ninetieth Street. It has eighty-four apartments ranging in size from five to eleven rooms.

IN a New York supermarket this week, one customer wheeled a well-filled pushcart to the vegetable counter and gazed with rapt puzzlement at one of the greens. It had a solid root end and its leaves were somewhat feathery.

PARIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Canadian economic upturn is expected to continue despite efforts to reduce imports of capital from abroad, according to a report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
For the last forty-seven days, a picture by the French master Henri Matisse has been hanging in the Museum of Modern Art -- upside down.
A "piece of tin" worth 300 times its weight in gold will be in the spotlight today when the City Council holds a public hearing on a taxicab rate increase.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 4 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors adopted today a modified county budget for 1962. The changes will call for a tax increase of 29.8 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation, which is 18.7 cents lower than the rate originally proposed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A bank in suburban Silver Spring, Md., was the first in the United States today to adopt higher interest rates on savings and time deposits.

Columbia and Harvard, co-champions of the Ivy League this year, placed nine men yesterday on the coaches' all-star football team. The surprising Lions got five spots, while Harvard was honored with four. Dartmouth and Princeton filled out the eleven-man squad.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 4 -- Khaled el-Azm and Dr. Namoun Kuzbara, leading aspirants respectively for the posts of President and Premier of Syria, emerged triumphant in the Parliamentary election returns from Damascus today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty-niners, disappointed over their 20-17 loss to the Colts at Baltimore Sunday, were growling today.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Transport Minister Leon Balcer said today that Canada's world air policy was aimed at providing a "single front" for Trans-Canada Air Lines and Canadian Pacific Airlines in dealings with other countries.

State investigators have been riding milk trucks in an investigation of "the sour milk problem," Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday told an advisory committee of consumer group representatives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The State Department categorically denied today a report by Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, that it "has prepared a paper" calling for United States nuclear weapons to be turned over to the United Nations.

The Amalgamated Sugar Company reported yesterday a slight drop in sales and earnings for the year ended on Sept. 30. Sales of the Ogden, Utah, company fell to $61,716,142 from $61,969,585 in 1960, while net earnings dropped to $3,561,400 from $3,988,703.

Trans World Airlines announced yesterday its fifty-five navigators had agreed to the gradual elimination of their jobs as a result of the adoption of an electronic navigation device for T.W.A.'s international jets.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Treasury bills rates rose sharply again today on the sale of the regular weekly issues, continuing a trend that began more than a month ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -Charles (Sonny) Liston needed only 118 seconds and one sledgehammer right tonight to knock out Albert Westphal of Germany.
DALLAS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- There were few changes made in the leaders in American Football League statistics last weekend but that didn't go for the records.
TO fill out what has been a not quite-full-length Eugene O'Neill evening at the Mermaid Theatre, Paul Shyre now has added "The Long Voyage Home" as a curtain raiser to "Diff'rent."

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., charged yesterday in a suit filed in Federal Court here that some of its secret chemical processes had been stolen by two companies. The suit alleged that du Pont experts who had knowledge of the process were spirited away by the two companies.

CHRISTMAS has come to Creative Gifts, a tiny shop that wraps women's presents in shocking pink paper with mauve ribbon and silver bells and men's presents in dark brown paper with gold ribbon and bells.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy ordered ten boxes of UNICEF greeting cards today as a symbol of her support of the work of the United Nations Children's Fund.

One of the less nimble feats at the Army-Navy game in Philadelphia was the presence in Mr. Kennedy's box of Charles A. Buckley, the Bronx boss who was thrown for a considerable loss in the recent New York elections. The President's invitation to this De Sapio linebacker had the effect, as Mr. Kennedy must have foreseen, of presenting the weakened Mr. Buekley with a fifth down.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 50 cents a bale yesterday.

Following is a list of the twenty-one electrical manufacturing concerns named as defendants in one or more of the twelve antitrust damage suits filed by a group of forty-four electric utility companies in Federal Court her yesterday:
A theatre party for the benefit of International House will take place at the Feb. 8 performance of "Subways Are for Sleeping."
Led by Bob Melvin's 27 points, the Fordham Rams opened their home basketball season, last night by shearing the Roanoke Rams, 84 -- 45, at the Fordham Gymnasium.
Steel production turned upward last week, hitting its highest level in nearly two months.

Your Nov. 22 editorial "The Testing Trap" asserts that "we have no intention of entering into another voluntary moratorium without at the same time providing for inspection against clandestine cheating."
When you pass a skyscraper being built, does it remind you of your dentist? Well, it could. A new technique for saving and restoring teeth is based on the principle of reinforced concrete.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The State Department is preparing new regulations to bar passports to members of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The three television networks urged the Federal Communications Commission today to retain the present system under which they may take over certain hours of the broadcast day on affiliated stations for network programs.

DAVID PARK was an artist of exceptional honesty and power. Death forces on us a profundity of contemplation, and his premature death, at 49, puts his work into sudden perspective. An exhibition of thirty-three of his pictures opens at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East Seventy-seventh Street, today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 (Canadian Press) -- No legal or mechanical safeguard can be a substitute for common sense in monetary management, G. Arnold Hart, president of the Bank of Montreal, said today at the bank's annual meeting.

ATHENS, Dec. 4 -- King Paul of the Hellenes, in a speech opening Parliament today, said that Greece was loyal to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but that she was also "willing to extend the hand of friendship to all countries prepared to reciprocate this gesture and respect our independence and dignity."

Greg Mather, Navy's field-goal kicker and end; Ernie Davis, Syracuse's star halfback, and Bob Ferguson, the Ohio State fullback, were among twenty-three named yesterday to the East football squad for the annual Shrine charity game.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- New ways to subdivide land were urged upon home builders today as a means of providing more variety in residential styles.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ernie Davis, a Syracuse halfback, today became the first Negro ever drafted by the Washington Redskins, but rumors spread quickly at the twenty-sixth National Football League player draft meeting that he would be traded to the Cleveland Browns.

Events tonight: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "La Sonnambula," in concert form, presented by American Opera Society, 8; Clarion Concerts, Newell Jenkins, conductor, Virginia Babikian, Georgia Davis, Nico Castel, Frank Carroll, Town Hall, 8:30; Marshall Butler, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:45; New York College of Music String Quartet, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- United Nations aid to Arab refugees from Palestine must be continued beyond 1963 if peace is to be kept in the Middle East, Dr. John H. Davis, director of the assistance program, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Council of the Organization of American States voted tonight to hold a conference of the hemisphere's foreign ministers starting Jan. 10 for the study of measures against subversion emanating from Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A weather expert said today that some of the fall-out from the larger Soviet atomic tests this fall might not reach earth until thte spring of 1963.
Jacques Barzun, Dean of Faculties and Provost of Columbia University, has been named an Extraordinary Fellow at Churchill College of Cambridge University in England.
Alex Kroll, all-America center and team captain at Rutgers, signed a professional football contract yesterday with the New York Titans.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Rickey Ortiz, a Puerto Rican welterweight, probably will never forget his twenty-second birthday. He spent ten seconds of it last night on the canvas of St. Nicholas Arena.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Consumer installment debt increased by $184,000,000 in October -- the largest monthly rise since November, 1960.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- A shot at the heavyweight championship of the world may be at stake tomorrow night when Archie Moore and Robert Cleroux meet in the Montreal Forum in a ten-round bout.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 28 -- Australia's huge new radio telescope, dedicated less than a month ago, is already discovering many new sources of radio noise deep in space.

The New York Yankees begin a thirty-game spring training schedule March 10 at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The world champions will play a home-and-home series with every major league club training in Florida and use Fort Lauderdale as a home base.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- London's theatres are enjoying record runs, a survey by The Daily Telegraph indicates. The average West End production has been playing for fifteen months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A spokesman for the coal industry praised President Kennedy today for delaying until mid-1962 a decision on changing the mandatory oil import control program.

A selective service that is too selective, and a universal military training and service act that is far from universal are responsible for some of the current complaints from recently mobilized reservists and guardsmen.

Consider the sharply different positions which might be occupied by three outstandingly able scientists, all engaged in the Government's project to send a man to the moon but each working for a different immediate employer.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- In a savage brawl that produced nine knockdowns, Floyd Patterson retained his world heavyweight championship by knocking out Tom McNeeley tonight. The fight ended at 2:51 of the fourth round with McNeeley on the floor after having taken the full count of 10.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 4 -- The Indian Government was accused in Parliament today of having let the nation down by its attitude toward Communist China.
Mayor Wagner issued orders yesterday for the prompt construction of a fifteen-and-one-quarter-mile tunnel for the city's expanding water system. The project would cost $180,000,000.
A hope that Israel's population would increase by a million by 1970 and by "still another million in the decade to follow" was expressed last night by Mrs. Golda Meir, Israel's Foreign Minister.

Dollar bonds of the Belgian Congo emerged from default yesterday with the delivery of $787,500 to make payment of interest due on April 1 and Oct. 1 of this year on $15,000,000 of bonds sold in the United States market in 1958.

JAPAN came under the searching eye of the camera last night in a one-hour documentary over Channel 4. A National Broadcasting Company News presentation entitled, "Japan: East is West" was a balanced and fascinating assessment of changes in that nation since the end of World War II.
An effort to open more New York suburbs to Negroes will achieve more formal status at a meeting tonight at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street.

The New York Giants came yesterday angry at losing home to the Green Bay Packers Sunday. Cliff Livingston, a linebacker said, "the boys were so angry they were anxious to take on the Eagles as soon as they got off the plane."

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 4 -President Kennedy, in a message to an international meeting of lawyers here, said today that new rules of law were needed for such "uncharted seas" as arms control and the peaceful use of outer space.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) Allan Nevins, historian, was elected unanimously today chairman of the Civil War Centennial Commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The stately Green Room of the White House now is completely refurnished with American antiques of the classical style of the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
A citizens committee on public welfare has made ten major recommendations for changes in national welfare programs. It was disclosed here yesterday.
The colorful decor of the Sheraton-East's ballroom matched the mood of the guests who gathered there last night in behalf of United Cerebral Palsy of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- The future of a Hollywood tradition will be at stake when the movie "One, Two, Three" opens this month. If it successful at the box office it may end the movie industry's fear of making films that are critical of the Soviet Union.

Erwin S. Wolfson, a major builder of office structures here, said yesterday he intended to begin installing his own electric generating plants in his new buildings to avoid rate increases by the Consolidated Edison Company.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- For the third time in six dates an Internal Revenue Service daily double was paid at Tropical Park -- today's paying $1,965.30 for a $3 ticket.
The Emergency Civil Liberties Committee sought a court order yesterday compelling the Commodore Hotel to accommodate its annual Bill of Rights Dinner on Dec. 15.

Local 6 of the New York Mailers Union and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union were temporarily enjoined yesterday by Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon from striking or engaging in a work stoppage against The New York Times.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The sudden attack of jitters that afflicted European foreign exchange markets at the end of last week abated today.
