Sears, Roebuck Co., one of the nation's largest retailers, expects another record sales year for its fiscal period ending on Jan. 31. It also foresees a further rise in sales next year. That was the essence of remarks made yesterday by Crowdus Baker, president of Sears, in a talk before the Boston Security Analysts Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The conflicting opinions of a Representative and a Senator, both from New York, highlighted an unparalleled public hearing here today on the merger proposal of two New York banks.
A Bronx resident drew the maximum penalty yesterday after having pleaded guilty to defrauding the city Department of Welfare of $14,641 over a period of four years and five months.
The appointment of Harmon H. Goldstone, an architect, as a member of the City Planning Commission was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

THE director of the United Nations Relief and Work Agency for Palestine Refugees, John Herbert Davis, has been described as "a natural diplomat." Calling at a Prime Minister's office or a refugee hut, he has an easy, friendly manner.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Newburgh asked the State Supreme Court today for a quick trial on the merits of its controversial welfare program.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4 (AP) -- John Rudometkin paced Southern California to a 79 -- 77 basketball victory over Kentucky before a crowd of 11,700 tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Premier Michel Debre warned French wage earners today that they must moderate their wage demands lest inflation wreck France's economic progress.

The annual Tobe Award for outstanding service to retailing and distribution will be presented to Robert Lazarus Sr., chairman of F. R. Lazarus Co. of Columbus, Ohio, parent store of the Federated Department Store chain.

The prospect that Britain will continue to operate a military base in Singapore for a long time to come has been considerably improved as a result of talks in London between the Prime Ministers of Britain and the Malayan Federation.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -Most unions will be permitted to file simplified financial reports after Jan. 1. This was announced here today by John L. Holcombe, Federal Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor-Management Reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Kennedy ordered today that all Federal agencies recognize the "legitimate role" of employe organizations in formulating personnel policies and practices of the Government.
TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- The local promotion of the Patterson-McNeeley fight ran into difficulty. It was smothered under the blanket of the Grey Cup final for the Canadian football championship.
TOKYO, Dec. 4 (AP) -Japan protested to the United States today against what it called a threatened increase in tariffs on United States cotton textile imports.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave Northeast Airlines permission to obtain emergency financial aid from the Hughes Tool Company (Toolco).
Martin B. Cohen, who has had a hand in the production of two Broadway musicals ("The Vamp" and "Christine"), will produce a straight play on his own next season.
SOME years ago, when Arlene Einhorn first ventured onto the ski slopes, she looked like a fugitive from a rummage sale.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 4 The stockholders of the Central Railroad of New Jersey adopted a resolution today reaffirming management's position that commuter service should not be continued after next July 1 under the terms of the present contract with the state.

ORAN, Algeria, Dec. 4 -- A murder that apparently represented a "settlement of accounts" caused speculation today that there was a split in the Secret Army Organization in this bulwark of European extremism in Algeria.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- George Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation, predicted today that his company would set a record in net sales in its present fiscal year, which began on Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States must become a trade partner of the European Common Market to hold the West together and to insure its own survival, former Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said today.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Reports of record-breaking November sales came from the auto makers today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 4 -- Communist Hungary hinted today that she might pardon Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, the nation's Roman Catholic primate, who has been in sanctuary in the United States Legation since 1956.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. acknowledged today that certain problems had been encountered in the call-up of reservists and National Guardsmen. But he said that in general the mobilization had gone "exceedingly well."
A three-month penitentiary sentence was imposed yesterday on the first man convicted of conspiracy to bribe a public official as a result of last year's Department of Motor Vehicles scandal.
GENEVA, Dec. 4 -- The major Western and Communist powers moved close to final agreement today on a pact to guarantee the neutrality and independence of Laos.
The highest Christmas tree in town was lighted at dusk yesterday, adding to the city's holiday glitter.

FAIRFIELD, N.C., Dec. 4 -- Canadian geese are great big beautiful birds. But today, to the torment of at least one small group of persons gathered here to acquire a few of the geese for traditional Christmas dinners, they flew high wide and, it must be said, handsomely.
The Akron, Canton and Youngstown Railroad, which now goes neither to Canton nor Youngstown, Ohio, soon may be serving those two cities -- as part of a bigger system.

HOUSTON, Tex., Dec. 4 -Philip Feldesman and Ira Rubin of New York don the national masters' pair championship after a four-session contest, ending early this morning, that concluded the American Contract Bridge League's fall national tournament here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Two moves designed to give high schools more representation in Olympic affairs were rejected today by the United States Olympic Committee.

Correspondents write to you about the impending traffic strangulation when the Lincoln Center development reaches its prescribed population maximum. Others have written about the Grand Central Terminal area.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor scored 50 points tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 131-120 National Basketball Association victory over the Syracuse Nationals before 3,061 fans.

African students in the United States find it harder to make friends among American Negroes than among whites, according to a nation-wide survey made public yesterday by the Institute of International Education.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., a leading discount operator in women's and children's apparel, assumed yesterday control of the A.S. Beck Shoe Corporation, a 241-store coast-to-coast chain with sales of $61,000,000 a year.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- A British-American Chamber of Commerce and a related Trade Center for the Middle West was formally established here today.
HARTFORD, Dec. 4 -- Mrs. Anne Mitchell of Granby, Collector of Customs for Connecticut for the last eight years, was removed today by President Kennedy.
MRS. LOEL GUINNESS has been called "the most elegant woman in the world," and her way of dressing "the ultimate in fashion." Her profile has been likened to that of Nefertiti.

One illogicality in the vast structure of state aid for education that has grown up in New York is the failure to admit that public museums are educational institutions. The present state budget grants nearly $9,000,000 in aid to libraries. But the museums are still forgotten.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today a ruling that the Constitution requires a hearing before students may be expelled from a tax-supported college for misconduct.

Directors of Bankers Trust Company, the sixth largest bank in New York City, yesterday proposed to pay a one-for-nine stock dividend. Stockholders will be asked to authorize an increase in the capital stock at the annual meeting on Jan. 24 to clear the way for the distribution.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga warned today that any new armed intervention by the United Nations in his province could lead to a major conflict.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 4 -- Premier David Ben Gurion left Israel by air today for his first visit to Burma. The trip is expected both to underline the good relations between the two countries and to illustrate the continuing success of Israel's diverse program of assistance to the developing states of Africa and Asia.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Heavyweight boxing's third major bout within twenty-four hours begins at Wembley Pool here about 9:30 tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- President Kennedy created today a new military medal for armed forces personnel who take part in "cold war" operations.
Prices of United States Government securities and other high-grade debt obligations continued to slump yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- United States military policemen halted a Soviet Army sedan for an hour at noon today in the United States sector of Berlin, and then permitted the vehicle to proceed on a tour of the city.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The French expect to be the first to put a supersonic commercial jet transport into service.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien, former head of the United Nations operation in Katanga, accused Britain today of "sabotaging" the organization's program in the Congo.
Enforcement was spotty yesterday as the police resumed limited towaway operations after a three-year hiatus.
The Board of Estimate adopted a record capital budget of $850,257,514 yesterday. It was $34,228,597 highest than the 1962 budget proposed by the City Planning Commission on Nov. 1.
WNTA-TV is to become the metropolitan area's first educational television station under a compromise reached yesterday by Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and a New York group.

The Rev. Dr. Harold A. Bosley, pastor of the First Methodist Church in Evanston, Ill., was reported yesterday to have been offered the pulpit of Christ Church, Methodist, when the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman retires at the end of the year.

A late twelfth-century marble carving will make its debut today in the collection of The Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tyron Park. It also will answer a long-standing art puzzle.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Japan, whose fishing fleets range the globe, in 1960 became the first nation in statistical history to take a catch of more than 6,000,000 metric tons.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 4 -- Officials of Katanga Province agreed tonight to remove roadblocks at key points in the city tomorrow. Crack Indian troops of the United Nations force in the Congo had threatened to break through by force.

The Inter-American Development Bank announced yesterday approval of a loan of $4,120,000 from the Social Progress Trust Fund to improve the water supply system of the city of Salvador and its suburbs in the state of Bahia, Brazil.
Alabama, which rolled over ten straight opponents this season without a defeat, was rewarded with the 1961 college football championship by the United Press International board of coaches yesterday.
TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- On the site where Maple Leaf Gardens now stands, there used to be a gymnasium. It was used primarily by amateur fighters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that the National Labor Relations Board's authority extended to two cruise vessels of the Incres Steamship Company, Ltd., a Liberian corporation.

No one seems to have come forward to answer the question, most certainly a rhetorical one, that was asked some years ago in the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate by George D. Aiken, who represents Vermont in that august body.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -The French Government was reliably reported today to have advised West Germany that it opposes the idea of a new contractual relationship between the Federal Republic and West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear appeals by two members of the American Communications Association convicted of contempt and given jail sentences for refusing to answer questions by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American activities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- President Kennedy extended today the United States ban on imports of Cuban sugar for an additional six months, through next June 30.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Bernard Goldfine and Miss Mildred Paperman, his confidential secretary, pleaded guilty today in Federal court to violation of the rules of probation. Their cases were continued to Jan. 2.

TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- Wherever Floyd Patterson deigns to sit, his perch technically is the heavyweight boxing throne. Tonight the throne was a plain wooden bench in his dressing room at the Maple Leaf Gardens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -President Kennedy announced today that he would meet Prime Minister Macmillan in Bermuda Dec. 21 and 22. It will be their fourth conference since Mr. Kennedy became President last January.
Inflation in Brazil is resulting in "impossible" wage demands by Brazilian longshoremen, shipping men said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today it had decided, on reconsideration, to approve the reorganization of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad. The line operates between New York City and Newark, N.J.

ON the third Saturday of each month during the music season the Concert Artists Guild assembles in the afternoon at Town Hall. Its gatherings have two aims: to provide concert experience for the two artists it selects each month to play for its members, and to reward still further those it feels most worthy.
Forty-four electric utility companies filed a dozen antitrust suits here yesterday against twenty-one electrical manufacturers, seeking triple damages for alleged price-fixing.
Michael L. Radoslovich, director of architecture for the Board of Education, pleaded not guilty to charges of improper conduct at a departmental hearing yesterday.
YONKERS, Dec. 4 -- A smoldering quarrel among Democrats in Yonkers, the largest city in Westchester County, broke into the open today.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Britain hopes that the meeting between President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan in Bermuda this month will establish a basic Western negotiating position for talks with the Soviet Union on Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Since a great many professional politicians are the direct tactical descendant of Joab (see Samuel II, S-27) the suspicion created in their ranks by the endorsement of Adlai E. Stevenson by Mayor Daley of Chicago for Senator from Illinois in 1962 is not unnatural.

WESTMORELAND, Kan., Dec. 4 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall tried to take a walk on a Kansas hill today to see if the area would make a good national park. But an irate rancher told him he was trespassing and ordered the Secretary off his land.

Four parcels of land in the Riverdale area of the Bronx have been purchased by Charles M. Chuckrow, Inc. The properties make an area of 60,000 square feet bounded by Irwin Avenue, West 240th Street, West 238th Street and Waldo Avenue.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -The white Venetian blinds were drawn this afternoon inside the red and white brick house at 5785 Dunlap Street in West Philadelphia, but the place was jumping.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Senegal's chief delegate to the United Nations complained today that two members of his delegation had been discriminated against at a Manhattan nightclub.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose last month by 9,000,000 ($25,200,000).
The chairman of the state legislative committee investigating Blue Cross was accused yesterday by his vice chairman of attributing his own conclusions to the committee.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower returned to his farm here today after a three-week vacation with Mrs. Eisenhower in Georgia. They plan to leave again about Dec. 18 for a winter vacation of more than three months in California.

Dallas County, Tex., received bids yesterday on $5,000,000 of court house bonds due serially from 1963 to 1992. The best bid, submitted by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., was an interest cost of 3.6615 per cent.
Potato and cocoa futures drew most of the attention yesterday in an otherwise dull day on the New York commodity exchange.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Manufacturers often must spend more to have their out-of-state tax returns prepared than they pay in the tax itself, House investigators were told today.

The U.S.S.R. has now delivered a first reply to President Kennedy's "interview" with Premier Khrushchev's son-in-law. There is no response to the President's peaceful overtures. There is only reiteration of the aggressive Russian policies that have plunged the world into crisis.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 4 -- George Meany warned organized labor today that management would try to bring unions under the Federal anti-trust laws.
TORONTO, Dec. 4 -- Empty seats by the acre served as mute but eloquent critics of Canada's first heavyweight championship fight at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

Penn State was declared the winner yesterday of the Lambert Trophy, emblematic of Eastern major-college football supremacy. An eight-man committee of coaches, sportswriters and broadcasters made the selection.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 4 -- Air Force officers and policemen led crowds today in armed attacks against storekeepers and anti-Government elements supporting a general strike whose purpose is to force the resignation of President Joaquin Balaguer.

The average male bowler who competes in one or more leagues probably needs additional practice, some lessons and more competition in order to sharpen up a bit. Currently such a bowler is scoring only about 154 a game, far below the much-talked-about 200 circle in bowling.

ART and life meet head on in a show that opens to the public tomorrow at the Decorative Arts Center, 304 East Sixty-third Street. Sponsored by the quarterly magazine Art in America for the benefit of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, the exhibition has as its theme "The Contemporary Collector's Home".
BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Hugh Cabot 3d, 35 years old, wife of the socially prominent artist, died of an overdose of a drug prescribed for her husband, he reported tonight.
An expansion of the Open Enrollment Program to permit greater latitude in the transfer of pupils across borough lines was announced yesterday by the Board of Education.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- If officials of the Museum of Modern Art in New York feel chagrined because they recently hung a picture by Henri Matisse upside down, they may find consolation in the fact that they have company.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 5 -- The gathering of more than 100 of the world's top sports car drivers here for the eighth annual International Speed Weeks naturally has produced many discussions concerning new machinery and racing trends in general.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 5 -- Soldiers used force again today but failed to break either the political stalemate or the general strike called to demand the resignation of President Joaquin Balaguer.

The State of Connecticut borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of bonds maturing serially over twenty-two years at an interest cost of 3.104 per cent.

The New York Times of Dec. 1 carried a report from Washington that the Government was considering recalling our Ambassador from South Vietnam if President Ngo Dinh Diem continues to ignore suggestions for democratic reforms.
The Communist, Western and neutral powers at the Geneva Conference on Laos have reached a kind of half-way house in their efforts to settle the Laotian war and neutralize the Laotian kingdom.
The Air Line Navigators Association, Local 520, made public yesterday further details of its agreement with Trans World Airlines covering the replacement of navigators by automatic devices.
The rise of the discount store was credited last night with having ended a "bottleneck" between the production capabilities of the children's coat industry and increasing consumer demands.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Federal legislation for a shorter work week with no loss in take-home pay may be necessary unless unemployment is reduced, according to an economic report prepared for the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- The Office of Civil Defense is transferring its headquarters from Battle Creek, Mich., to Washington, where it will be consolidated with the Defense Department.
The Kings County Trust Company, Brooklyn, announced yesterday that it would begin paying 3 1/2 per cent interest on savings deposits, effective Jan. 1.

President Kennedy called last night for broader American participation in sports and other forms of physical activity. "We are underexercised as a nation," he said. "We look instead of play, ride instead of walk."
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The downward drift in prices gathered speed in the stock market here today.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Best Bargain, carrying the silks of Mrs. Violet Stewart of Bangor, Mich., scored a mild upset in the Monkton Purse at Pimlico today, when he returned $23.40 for $2.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5 -- This city has taken title to a ten-acre Pennsylvania Railroad complex including the Exchange Place terminal, a ferryhouse and Pier C. The city bought it from the railroad for $1, a spokesman for the city announced today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- The West German Government will propose seven amendments to France's draft treaty for a European political union when the Common Market foreign ministers meet in Paris at the end of next week.

DALLAS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- When Houston beat San Diego, 33 -- 13, Sunday in the American Football League it not only removed an aura of defensive invincibility surrounding the Raiders but it set a league record in offense.

The State Lottery Control Commission was told yesterday that large bingo interests were waiting for the "right judge" to issue an injunction that would stay a commission order limiting games in a single hall to three days a week.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Du Pont interests urged today that plans for disposing of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co.'s $3,000,000,000 interest in General Motors Corpora tion be held up until Congress acted on special tax legislation.

The scholarship fund of LADO, Inc., will benefit from the organization's annual dinner and concert, to be held in the Grand Ballroom and Fountain Court of the Biltmore on Dec. 17. Nemenoff and Luboshutz, duo-pianists, and Boris Goldowsky, conductor and opera commentator, will participate in the program.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 710 persons were hurt last week in car accidents in the city. This was 198 fewer than a year ago when 908 were injured.
Dresser Industries, Inc., showed a 10 per cent increase in net income, despite a 4 per cent decline in sales for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, the report disclosed yesterday.
Market values of high-grade debt securities gave way again yesterday as the dealers in United States Government securities chose to lighten their positions.

Alabama was named the national collegiate football champion yesterday in the final Associated Press poll of the season. This was a goal set by the Crimson Tide coach, Paul (Bear) Bryant, a master re-builder.

BELLS to sound the alarm whenever a crisis beset the city administration would be welcome indeed to the new Deputy Mayor, Edward Francis Cavanagh Jr., named yesterday. If he could, he would always live within sound of them.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- United States and Soviet delegates conferred privately today on the control of future peaceful uses of outer space, now under debate in the Political Committee here.

THE freshly painted sign over a new produce market at 7306 Third Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn bears the name "Frank's Quality Fruits and Vegetables." In smaller letters beneath is written: "Formerly of the Washington Market."

FASHIONS for rituals tend to be classic. Like the bridal gown, the debutante dress has a style distinction whose subtleties are lost on almost anyone but the wearer and her loved ones. Since the late Thirties, when Brenda Diana Duff Frazier came closer to being a popular pin-up girl than any debutante before or since, the garb for coming-out parties has changed hardly at all.
WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson said tonight that despite frustrations and setbacks "the free world is winning the cold war -- make no mistake about that."
WASHINGTON, Dee. 5 -- President Kennedy has decided to take a goodwill trip to Mexico, probably toward the end of next month.
HOUSTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- A hospitalized 275-pound tackle from a little-known Texas college became the newest pawn today in the player-contract war between the National and American Football Leagues.
TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- United States and Japanese atomic energy specialists predicted today that atomic power would begin to be competitive in price with power from oil and coal within this decade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States and South Vietnam are said to be making progress on an agreement for closer cooperation in the fight against Communist guerrillas.
FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Fort Dix has heard "I want out" before and is not troubled.
Five of the nation's major manufacturers of industrial brazing alloys and eight of their officers were indicted here yesterday on charges of violating the antitrust laws.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Government-backed mortgages, caught in a growing squeeze in the national money market, appeared today to be headed for an even sharper decline than they have been experiencing recently.

The Council of the Organization of American States has split -- although not so badly as expected -- on the vote to hold a meeting of the foreign ministers which will be aimed against Cuba. Colombia introduced the proposal, intended to consider the danger of subversion from Cuba and the threat raised by Cuba's admitted affinity to the Soviet bloc.
The United States Court of Appeals extended yesterday the lawyer-client privilege to include client communications to an expert hired by a defense lawyer.

The Association of Fair Housing Committees was formed last night to obtain integrated housing for Negroes in the metropolitan area. Seventy-five community representatives met at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, to form the association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A Christmas season of new sights, new sounds and another home-away-from-home will begin next week for Mrs. John F. Kennedy.

Supreme Court Justice George Tilzer yesterday dismissed a petition to bar the construction of three religious chapels at New York International Airport, at Idlewild, Queens. The suit was brought by Joseph Lewis, president of the Free-thinkers of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two parachute jumps by a four-man team in Arizona last week set world records, the first ever held by the United States in the field of parachuting, the National Aeronautic Association said today.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 -- Seventy-nine drivers are ready to start at 3 A.M. tomorrow in Argentina's biggest road race -- the 3,200-mile Argentine Highway Grand Prix race, which dates to 1910.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

FAIRFIELD, N.C., Dec. 5 -- There is certain element of faith in goose shooting and after this morning there are at least two shooters who every day will practice hard having faith. They will say over and over, "I will have faith that the geese will fly true and well to my blind and decoys and I will banish impatience and doubts."
SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The Teamsters Union foreclosed today on the General Oglethorpe Hotel Company, a corporation that borrowed $2,400,000 from the union in 1959.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The wartime "E" for excellent was revived by President Kennedy today in the name of exports.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 5 -- A situation bordering on famine appears in prospect for squirrels in the metropolitan area this winter.
Famous couples from well-known operas will be impersonated by committee members at the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds Ball, which will take place in the ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 14.
The Defense Department has decided to continue to use the Port of New York heavily for military shipments and plans no changes now for the Brooklyn Army Terminal.
KANPUR, India, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- After one of its customary second-innings rescue acts, the Marylebone Cricket Club of England now looks certain to save the second test match against India.
Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., was awarded the John Fritz Medal last night.
President Kennedy said yesterday he was "delighted" that Mr. Stevenson would stay on at the United Nations.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg called today for an extended American Merchant Marine "to provide jobs and carry out our international responsibilities."
Trans World Airlines recommended yesterday that it be permitted to increase domestic fares to bring in $11,000,000 more a year.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 5 -- Israel called upon Moscow today to allow Soviets Jews who wish to join their families here to do So.

Mayor Wagner appointed Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. as Deputy Mayor yesterday. Mr. Cavanagh will take office Jan. 1, succeeding Paul R. Screvane, who will become President of the City Council on that day.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Gordie Howe of Detroit, gaining a goal and three assists, jumped five notches in the National Hockey League individual scoring race, according to official weekly statistics released today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Defense officials, now in the final phase of preparing the budget requests for next year, are understood to have agreed upon a $51,000,000,000 appropriations request to Congress.
I must say I sympathize greatly with Emmet Davis who, in his letter of Nov. 21, discourses on his dissatisfaction with the additional dialing one has to do these days.

According to popular legend, Madison Avenue is the home of the nervous stomach, the palpitating heart and the bleeding ulcer It is the place where the health of many an executive is supposedly undermined by a succession of client crises and other pressures.

The appointment of Edward Everett Watts Jr. as general chairman of the Legal Aid Society's 1962 fund campaign was announced yesterday. Mr. Watts is a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Turk, Marsh, Ouchterloney Kelly.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Saudi Arabia challenged today the neutrality of Dr. Joseph E. Johnson, a special United Nations envoy seeking a solution of the Palestine refugee problem.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 5 -- George Meany moved today to heal the breach that has developed between the labor movement and Negroes.

DENVER, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Governors attending the Interstate Oil Compact Commission's annual meeting worked out a compromise settlement today in a dispute over a study of equitable sharing of the domestic crude oil market.
The formation of Turn Toward Peace, an organization to seek alternatives to what it calls "the threat of war as the central thrust of American foreign policy," was announced yesterday.
AN unusual study of an important subject -- youngsters who fail to complete high school training -- was presented in a commendable telecast over Channel 7 last night.

The Nov. 21 editorial in The Times under the head "Politicians and Judgeships" pointed out that the court reorganization amendment, which the voters approved at the recent general election, made no change in the mechanics of choosing the judges of the reorganized courts.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- Twenty-five East Germans took over a commuter train tonight and fled to West Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission was asked today to deny license renewal to a Cincinnati radio station on the ground that it "refuses any expression * * * of the liberal and labor point of view."

Events today: "La Perichole," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Orchestra of America, Richard Korn, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Bach Aria Group, Frank Brieff, conductor, Adele Addison, soprano, Giorgio Tozzi, bass-baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Adolphe Frezin, 'cellist, Arthur Loesser, pianist, Judson Hall, 8:30.
The Missouri Pacific Railroad continues to add to its holdings of securities of the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad.
EVERY now and again the Museum of Modern Art holds special exhibitions devoted to aspects of nineteenth-century art that have a special, and often surprising, relevance to the art of our own time.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Zora Folley of Chandler, Ariz., knocked out Henry Cooper of England with a single punch at 1 minute 8 seconds of the second round at Wembley Pool tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Twenty-six of the twenty-nine permanent members of the Comedie Francaise, France's national repertory theatre, today pronounced themselves in favor of their present administrator, Maurice Escande.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The television-viewing habits of Mrs. Olive Vierbuchen are probably among the most unusual in the country these days. She is alert when the commercials come on, but turns down the sound or leaves the room for coffee when the show begins.

The promoters of a new camera who allegedly misrepresented facts to investors who purchased $300,000 worth of stock have been ordered to show cause why they should not be barred from the securities business in New York State.
Piedmont Airlines, a local-service airline with headquarters in Winston-Salem, S.C., has announced the purchase of seventeen Martin 404 aircraft from Trans World Airlines.

M. JEAN BESSE, a Parisian who is really Swiss and who lives in Rome, is credited with many bridge exploits, both in international tournaments (he plays for Switzerland) and in rubber games in clubs, but he cannot ever have exceeded his play of the East hand in this deal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk believes that a total United States embargo on trade with the Soviet Union would have only trivial effect on Russia and might rebound with substantial disadvantages to the United States.
Cotton futures rose 70 cents to $1.40 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Gold milling has lost some glitter, according to one Colorado operator.
The military problems of the United Nations in the Congo typify the problems that would be faced almost anywhere in the world by an international police force.
Donald J. Hardenbrook, the becoming president of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday forecast "a modest improvement" in the nation's economy next year.
The Maternity Center Association has chosen next Tuesday's performance of "Gideon," starring Fredric March and Douglas Campbell, at the Plymouth Theatre for its annual autumn theatre benefit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy accepted "on indefinite loan" to the White House today a silver water pitcher that once belonged to her great-great-grandmother, Louise Lindsay Bouvier.
Plans for a thirty-acre "air space" campus for the rapidly expanding Bronx Community College to be built over subway storage tracks were disclosed yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Two scientists from the East Orange, N.J., Veterans Administration Hospital reported today evidence they believe shows that lung cancer can be prevented by stopping smoking.

With the opening of the 1962 session of the Legislature only a few weeks away, it was not surprising to read the Nov. 27 letter of Robert S. Fougner, general counsel, Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, in support of retention of the "sleeper amendment" contained in the 1961 rent-control law.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Sean McKeown, United Nations troop commander in the Congo, said today that he agreed with Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien that Britain had hindered United Nations actions in Katanga.
Prices of copper futures rose yesterday on news of new clashes between the United Nations and Katanga Province in the Congo.

PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea, Dec. 5 -- The disappearance of Michael Rockefeller in Netherlands New Guinea is causing Dutch and Australian officials to take a sharper look at the anthropologists, art collectors and missionaries who are coming to New Guinea in increasing numbers.

Mrs. Walter Mahony of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Mrs. Margaret Scott Carrott of Greenwich, Conn., gained the final of the New York State women's squash racquets championship at the Riverdale Yacht Club.

The Western Maryland Railway's directors slashed yesterday the quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from the 45-cent rate that had been in effect since December of 1959. The reduced payment will be distributed on Dec. 29, to holders of record of Dec. 15.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The United States and nine other countries proposed today a drive to raise funds for erecting a permanent United Nations International School building near the United Nations Headquarters.

Don Galluzzi, a New York University sophomore, set a pool record for the 220-yard free-style event last night as the Violet defeated Brooklyn Polytech, 71 to 19, in the Alumni Gymnasium pool in the Bronx.

The phenomenal run of "The Threepenny Opera," which has been residing at the Theatre de Lys since Sept. 20, 1955, ends on Dec. 17. The departure was announced yesterday by Carmen Capalbo, Stanley Chase and Lucille Lortel, producers of the Bertolt Brecht-Kurt Weill-Marc Blitzstein musical.
The Freeport Sulphur Company is weighing the purchase of uranium milling and mining properties at an aggregate cost of about $26,000,000.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Henry Ford 2d, board chairman of the Ford Motor Company, today hinted that George Meany, American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations president, had violated the pledge of secrecy surrounding the discussions of the President's labor-management advisory committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 5 -- Twenty years ago Thursday I learned about Pearl Harbor in a dingy hotel hall at Kuibyshev, then Russia's temporary capital. Moscow was besieged by some fifty Nazi divisions and all foreigners considered worthy of attention had been bundled off to the Volga.

The choice of Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. to be Deputy Mayor is an appointment that is personal, political and in recognition of administrative merit. The Fire Commissioner is one of the oldest and closest friends of Mayor Wagner. He was the Mayor's campaign manager in the recent election. He puts loyalty and service to Wagner in top priority.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- France moved farther away from her Western allies today over the key question of how to finance the United Nations' military operations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Nigeria said today that Taiwan's Chinese Nationalists and the Chinese Communist Government should be represented in the United Nations.

What does a team do to defend against Wilt Chamberlain in a National Basketball Association game? Whatever it is, the New York Knickerbockers failed to do it again last night, so Chamberlain and the Philadelphia Warriors whipped the Knicks, 122-105, before 7,126 fans at Madison Square Garden.
A SCATHING account of the events that led to the Hungarian uprising in 1956 and to its crushing by Soviet arms was unfolded last night at the York Playhouse.

A team of Anglo-American aluminum producers has announced the successful development of a modified aluminum reduction cell that promises both lower production costs and multi-million-dollar savings in new capacity expenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The leaders of amateur sports in the United States put aside differences today and made plans to build a United States team for the 1964 Olympics.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., Dec. 5 -- A bartender was convicted today of violating North Dakota's new anti-discrimination law by charging a Negro airman $5 for a Coca-Cola.

The Curtis Publishing Company, publisher of the Saturday Evening Post, Ladies' Home Journal, Holiday and other publications, had a loss of $11,192,837 from operations in the first nine months of this year. After special credits, the net loss for the period was reported at $1,458,330.

When so good a friend of the United States as Sweden urges the prompt admission of Communist China to the United Nations it is time to look again. Sweden knows all about Communist China; knows its record in Korea; knows its brutal rule at home. Yet Sweden, like many other stanch friends of ours among the democratic nations, wants Communist China in the U.N. Why?
Increased sales of Series H bonds helped lift the value of United States savings bonds in the hands of the public by $127,000,000 last month, the Treasury said yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Cincinnati crushed Miami of Ohio, 63 -- 30, in basketball tonight. The Bearcats held Miami's top scorer, Levern Benson, to 7 points, controlled rebounds, 52 -- 39, and forced Miami into tactical errors.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Leaflets urging Savannah Negroes to move to New York and enjoy the benefits of that state's welfare program are being distributed through several small grocery stores in the city's Negro community, the head of a segregationist organization charged today.
The nation's top monetary authority believes Americans should "give a collective assist to Presidential commitments to balanced budgets whenever they're proffered."
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 5 -- Harvard, the champion, and Princeton, the 1960 winner, each placed three men on the 1961 all-Ivy soccer squad. The team was chosen by the league's eight coaches.

Paperboard production in the nation totaled 331,983 tons in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 332,276 tons in the preceding week and 280,359 tons in the same period last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- A brawny recruit who would not take inoculation shots because they are against his body-building principles was kept in the stockade today pending a decision on his case.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The Hungarian delegation here said today that U Thant, Acting Secretary General, had accepted an invitation from its Government to visit Hungary.

TORONTO, Dec. 5 -- Floyd Patterson is willing to fight Sonny Liston in his next defense of the heavyweight championship. At a news conference today, the titleholder said, "I definitely would like to give Liston a chance."
The former owner of a Harlem tenement described by the city as a "horror house" was sentenced in Housing Court yesterday to twenty days in jail and fined $500 for conditions in the building.

THE New York City Ballet last night opened a nine-week season at the City Center. Since it has been opening seasons here for the last fourteen years, generally more than one in each year, we have all become accustomed to expecting nothing in the nature of a grand gala glittering affair.

Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy appointed seventy-two recruits to the force yesterday, bringing its strength to a new high of 24,418. The budget provides for 24,590 men.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 5 -- The Baltic command, the last unachieved link in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's command structure for Western Europe, was accepted today by the Danish Government. A spokesman for a group of prominent independent film distributors yesterday attacked Hollywood's foreign-language Academy Awards as "meaningless and unfair."

More than twenty-five auxiliaries and affiliated organizations of the Pride of Judea Children's Services, Brooklyn, will have booths at the agency's annual two-day bazaar next Tuesday and Wednesday at the Rollerdrome in Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- Communist China has warned India that it might feel justified in sending troops across what India contends to be her northeastern frontier.

Tribute was paid last night at a Lotos Club dinner to Mrs. Albert D. Lasker, who was described by Robert Moses, president of the 1964-65 World's Fair Corporaton, as "much too smart to go down in history as merely a beautiful woman."

The W. J. Sloane furniture store, a retailing landmark at Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street since 1912, will move nine blocks south next month and take over the present quarters of the Franklin Simon store.

The Soviet-Finnish crisis which began with the Soviet note of Oct. 30 came to a relatively harmless close on Nov. 25. While it lasted, it gave rise to a number of ill-informed, highly dramatized and downright gloomy comments in the American press.
With scarcely a break in stride, President Kennedy moved around obstacles caused by the weather yesterday to get into Manhattan.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 5 -- War dogs from the United States Army are being brought to South Vietnam to hunt Communist guerrillas in underground jungle hide-aways. The vanguard of the prospective canine auxiliary to the South Vietnamese ground forces demonstrated its value in a trial operation last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Average earnings of production workers have risen from $10 to $90 a week in the last fifty years, the Labor Department reported today.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 5 -- The appointment of Dr. Joseph C. Palamountain Jr. as provost of Wesleyan University was announced today.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 5 -- Fighting erupted today in this capital of secessionist Katanga Province between units of the United Nations forces and Katangese soldiers and gendarmes.

William Ernest Hocking, the philosopher, and Edwin Dickinson, the painter, have become members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. Their election was announced yesterday by Douglas Moore, academy president.

Clarion Concerts began its fifth Season last night at Town Hall. Following his custom, Newell Jenkins, the conductor of the series, presented old music that had the effect of seeming new for having been lost.

George Meany says his one real disappointment in the six years since the A.F.L.-C.I.O. were merged has been the failure of big unions to organize the unorganized. He hopes the federation's convention, opening in Florida tomorrow, will do something to "get the larger unions organizing and out of each other's hair."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The office of the South Korean observer to the United Nations denied knowledge today of any plan by South Korea to boycott a United Nations discussion of the Korean question. An unofficial report from Seoul last week said that South Korea would not accept an invitation to the debate if the Communist Government of North Korea attended.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Administration is considering creation of a profit-making, publicly owned corporation to operate a communications satellite system.
Unbeaten in their last nine home games, the New York Rangers will seek to extend their string tonight against the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

Tor Nilsen scored 9 points in the last minute and a half to lead City College to an 82-76 Tri-State Basketball League victory over Long Island University at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, Brooklyn, last night.
Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday the prefiling in Albany of legislation needed to legalize off-track betting on horse races.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- A recently discovered diary of a Hessian soldier who fought in the American Revolution was purchased at auction here today by a New York bookshop for $8,960.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two physicians said today that primary and secondary cases of syphilis increased 200 per cent in the nation in the last five years.

Galina Vishnevskaya, the Soviet soprano who has sung in several performances of "Aida" with the Metropolitan Opera this season, made her only scheduled appearance there last night in the title role of "Madama Butterfly."
ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the state's public schools abandon their present plans to send children home in case of atomic attack.
Four appointments to editorial positions were announced yesterday by The New York Herald Tribune.

A dispute between the New York Telephone Company and the Communication Workers of America over the suspension of a worker was settled yesterday afternoon, thirty minutes before a series of protest meetings scheduled by the union.

Joseph E. O'Grady, a member of the Transit Authority, will have some bad news for Michael J. Quill when they meet today in Bal Harbour, Fla., to discuss contract renewal terms for the Transport Workers Union.
A Queens grand jury yesterday indicted nine persons and four plumbing concerns on charges of having conspired to defraud the Board of Education of $389,609.
Stocks milled around yesterday and closed with a minor loss on average on the New York Stock Exchange.
GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- The Soviet Union put into the record of the nuclear test ban talks here today its threat to continue exploding nuclear weapons as long as the United States carried on tests.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- The world Council of Churches ended its third international assembly today with an appeal to all nations to run "reasonable risks" for peace. It also called on church members everywhere to "go together in the way of Christian unity."

Three former college basketball players pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to conspiring to bribe other basketball players to keep their teams' scores down in intercollegiate contests.

ATHENS, Dec. 5 -- Premier Constantine Caramanlis said tonight that Greece, whose extended and vulnerable borders have been repeatedly violated, has every reason to maintain its position" with the North Atlantic Alliance.
TODAY'S overstuffed kitchen is bound to be stocked with a few more house wares come Christmas morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Supreme Court considered today how far a state may go investigating alleged Communist infiltration of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

Directors of Walter E Heller Co., Chicago commercial finance concern, proposed yesterday a four-for-one split of the common stock. The board also declared the regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share, payable on Jan. 2 to stockholders of record of Dec. 20.
HAMDEN, Conn., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Whether to observe religious holidays in classrooms is concerning school officials in Connecticut.

The efforts to obtain Ernie Davis, the Syracuse halfback voted the year's leading college player, for the New York Titans of the American Football League were continued yesterday by Harry Wismer, the Titan owner.
HERMANN GMEINER has no children, but he plays father to 2,000 youngsters, according to United Press International.
Friday will probably be the last day of programing on Channel 13 until two or three months from now when it will start a new career as an educational television station.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 -- Professional boxing lost another untimely clash of wills with Canadian sports fans today. The result was a unanimous decision to postpone indefinitely tonight's scheduled ten-round bout between Archie Moore and Robert Cleroux at the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States must make some arrangement with the European Common Market or split the non-Communist world and vastly strengthen the Soviet Union and its allies, former Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today.

Can scientific (civilized) man survive? This is the question that Bertrand Russell poses in his forthcoming book, "Has Man a Future." His answer: "No, if present international anarchy persists." In his book Lord Russell reviews national policies, both East and West, in relation to nuclear bombs.
There was doubt yesterday whether Jimmy Patton could start for the Giants against the Eagles in the important National Football League game in Philadelphia next Sunday.
Marshall Butler, who made his debut here in 1950, returned last night to give a piano program at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The practice of publishing point-spreads in newspapers throughout the country was held responsible yesterday for contributing to the increase in basketball gambling. The charge was made at the luncheon of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association in Leone's.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Senate Republican leader today termed Mayor Wagner's program for state financial aid for New York City a "rehash of all his discredited chestnuts."

Gus Hall, leader of the Communist party of the U.S.A., said yesterday that the party was not going underground. The only thing going underground, he said, is that "the Bill of Rights is being buried."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- Chancellor Adenauer returned to his office today after having been confined to his house for nearly two weeks because of the effects of a cold caught when he was in Washington last month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) The Federal Aviation Agency set today a 1967 target date for the first flight of America's supersonic airliner. That is about three years ahead of earlier prospects.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga said today that his secessionist Congolese province was ready for the "supreme sacrifice" if the United Nations persisted in its "aggression."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- National and Eastern Air Lines asked a Federal court today to stay a Civil Aeronautics Board ruling granting Northeast Airlines permission to obtain emergency financial aid from the Hughes Tool Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, ordered the commanders of the United Nations Congo force today to take any air or ground action necessary to restore the United Nations' rights in Elisabethville.
Stocks of savings and loan associations have tripped over high prices and competitive interest rates -- and plummeted in the last seven trading days.

An issue of $50,000,000 of 4 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of The Borden Company is being offered to the public today. Morgan Stanley Co. and associates priced the issue at 98 3/4 to yield 4.45 per cent to maturity.
City Councilmen questioned the taxi industry yesterday as to why it wanted a 10-cent fare increase when only recently it persuaded the city to repeal an "onerous" 10-cent tax on cab rides.
Following is the text of the address by President Kennedy at the National Football Foundation dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:
General Electric Company hopes there may be "a more proper and better route than costly litigation" for settlement of damage suits arising from alleged price fixing.

Your distinguished columnist C.L. Sulzberger observed from Lima in The Times of Nov. 27 that some years ago as a government official had "advocated that while we still held a nuclear weapons monopoly it might be wise to consider preventive war * * *."

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Larry Gilligan won four races at Tropical Park today, including a narrow victory aboard the heavily favored Pundit in the feature. The event was marred by a two-horse spill involving Bill Boland and Buck Thornburg.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Macmillan looked today beyond a negotiated settlement of the Berlin crisis, which "might be much easier than we think" to wider, more fruitful talks with the Soviet Union.

Twelve men successful in business and industry were honored yesterday at the tenth annual meeting of the Free Enterprise Awards Association, Inc., in the Savoy Hilton Hotel. The recipients, all of whom had modest starts in life, were:

THERE were roses and other flowers all over the stage of Carnegie Hall last night, courtesy of the Australian Society of New York. Which leads to the deduction that Australia's most distinguished lady was in the vicinity.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Government affirmed today its determination to put through in substantially the present form its bill to control immigration from other Commonwealth countries.

HARRY MALTBY, 26 years old, chronically plagued by a stomach ulcer called Harriet, was a bitter, cynical and angry young man. For three years he had served as a saboteur for the British Intelligence Service in Occupied France. And now, when he had been out of the hospital only a few days and back in England only a few weeks, that pig-faced major mysteriously called B6 was ordering him to return to France.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville reaffirmed today France's opposition to any negotiations with the Soviet Union on Berlin under present conditions.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has decided to stay on as chief United States representative at the United Nations.
Winds up to seventy miles an hour caused one death, injuries, power failures and property damage in and around the city yesterday.
Columbia made its home debut last night under Jack Rohan, its new basketball coach, at University Hall. But Colgate made the important baskets in the final four minutes and picked up a 75-73 victory.
Joseph T. Sharkey declared yesterday he would fight Mayor Wagner's efforts to depose him as majority leader and vice chairman of the City Council and as Democratic leader of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Arthur H. Dean turned from test ban negotiations with the Russians today and tried his hand at persuading the Supreme Court.

Ann Kiernan, a 26-year-old Mountain Lakes, N.J., woman who shot and killed a psychiatrist's wife last August, was committed to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane at Beacon, N.Y., yesterday.

Ernie Davis, here to receive the Heisman Trophy, did some agile broken-field running yesterday. The Syracuse halfback heard two calls from the nation's top touch-football quarterback and heeded both. But only on the second play did Davis go into a huddle with President Kennedy.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Larry Gilligan continued his winning ways as a rider at Tropical Park with a double today. He won the feature race on Roman Note and the fifth on Palenque II.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Gov. Wesley Powell announced today that he would not appoint himself to the United States Senate seat left vacant by the death of Styles Bridges, Republican. He also said he would not be a candidate for the post in the 1962 primary.
NEWARK, Dec. 6 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today concluded hearings on an application by the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad for a 5-cent intrastate increase in fares.

ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Georgia Court of Appeals yesterday threw out convictions against three segregationists who picketed a meeting addressed by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy last spring at Athens, Ga.

Joseph T. Sharkey came close yesterday to conceding that his continued tenure as vice chairman and majority leader of the City Council was in doubt. However, he showed more confidence in his ability to withstand Mayor Wagner's challenge to his continuation as Democratic leader of Brooklyn.

Looking forward to another 162-game schedule in the second year of the American League's expanded set-up of ten clubs, the world champion Yankees announced yesterday they would open their 1962 championship season on April 10 against the Orioles at the Yankee Stadium.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Twenty-seven machines used to imprint validating stamps on drivers' licenses and vehicle registration forms were stolen last night from the Department of Motor Vehicles office here.
The election of Robert W. Sanders as president of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York was announced yesterday.
CUS D'AMATO must have been weak in geometry as a schoolboy. He doesn't seem to know that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points. He talks in circles and he thinks in circles.
A 15-year-old high school pupil was seized yesterday as he attempted to rob a branch of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank in Brooklyn.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- A Government spokesman indicated today that India was considering military action to wrest the small territory of Goa from Portuguese rule.

The Superior Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of Fulton Industries, Inc., has agreed to acquire the Superior Steel division of the Copperweld Steel Company. The latter's directors approved the sale yesterday.
A suspended school employe who has been accused of shaking down contractors was arrested yesterday by detectives from the Queens District Attorney's office.

Arrangements are being completed for this year's Seven to Eleven Dinner Dance, which will be a Christmas Pearl Gala. It will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Dec. 19 for the benefit of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, New York City Chapter.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Many American business men and bankers in Europe are puzzled by the talk coming out of Washington about the United States and the European Common Market.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- What happens to a producer-director when he is ready to begin shooting his movie and then has to wait a year for his star?
Senator Jacob K. Javits and Representative John V. Lindsay visited Alexander Hamilton's home here yesterday and expressed shock at its decrepit state.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Representatives of drug manufacturers and officials of the Food and Drug Administration joined today to try to work out problems over controversial labeling regulations.
Six scholarships will be awarded by the Inter American Press Association Scholarship Fund to Latin-American students and journalists, the fund announced yesterday.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., had consolidated net earnings of $7,209,000, equal to $5.97 a share, in the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Lawyers for Mississippi Freedom Riders today asked a Supreme Court justice to, stop disorderly conduct prosecutions in Jackson, Miss., until a suit attacking travel segregation could be appealed to the high tribunal.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Paul Hall, head of the Seafarers International Union, accused Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges today of following a course that would destroy the American merchant marine.

Friends of the late Jack Kriendler, co-founder of the "21" Club, gathered last night in the club's Hunt Room to mark the close of the thirteenth annual fund drive in behalf of the Jack Kriendler Memorial Foundation. Their goal was $150,000.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Forty-three reservists recalled to duty Oct. 15 complained today in a letter to The Kansas City Star about their duties at Fort McClellan, Ala.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight after a talk with U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, that "the United States is very pleased with the plans of the Secretary General to bring Katanga under control."

The New York Giants, barely recovered from their bruising battle against Green Bay, began preparations yesterday for their National Football League showdown contest against the Eagles on Sunday at Philadelphia.
MONTREAL, Dec. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The locks of the St. Lawrence Seaway, officially closed, were opened today to let three straggling lake ships get home.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Frank (Pop) Ivy resigned today as the head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals, saying he believed he had not achieved the "desired results" with the injury-riddled National Football League team.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- McGeorge Bundy, special assistant to the President for national security affairs, predicted tonight the growth of a "new Europe."

Thomas Walker of Lumberton, N.J., a breeder and judge of boxers, paid a tribute the other day to those who breed dogs from a sincere desire to improve them. At the same time, he warned against mass producers whose only interest was financial.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The General Assembly s Economic and Financial Committee unanimously approved today the allocation of funds to the United Nations and specialized agencies participating in the expanded program of technical assistance.

OAK PARK, Mich., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Sixty-five physicians, aided by a corps of specialists, gave 668 physical examinations today in a concerted drive to raise the health level of adjoining Royal Oak Township, a predominantly Negro area.

Directors of the General Tire and Rubber Company recommended yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock and an increase in the authorized shares. The board also announced its intention to increase the quarterly dividend rate to 10 cents a share on the new shares in 1962.

" AS they say in the rites, 'many are called but few are chosen,' and these few are in my opinion no others than those who have loved wisdom in the right way." Thus spoke our friend and ancestor Socrates. Winston Churchill was certainly one of the chosen and it may be that he loved wisdom in a way Socrates would have approved.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller today called the Governors of ten other states to a civil defense conference.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., outlined today the steps now being considered for disposing of the concern's 63,000,000 shares of the General Motors Corporation.
SPARTANBURG, S.C., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Two City Councilmen, one of them the Mayor pro tem, were arrested today after the police said they had accepted $10,000 in marked bills from a real estate man.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Congresional attention was focused today on two major problems resulting from the steady stream of Cuban refugees fleeing the Castro regime.

MAYBE Christmas has something to do with it. Anyway it happened yesterday -- one of those better-than-average surprises, at the bottom of a circuit double-bill. The picture is a British suspense drama called "Portrait of a Sinner," with Tony Britton, Nadja Tiller (of "Rosemary") and (supposedly on lend-lease) our own William Bendix.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States' long-held hopes for achieving manned space flight in 1961 -- the same year as the Soviet Union -- vanished today.
The First Boston Corporation and Equitable Securities Corporation are offering to the public today $25,000,000 of 4 5/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of the General Telephone Company of California.
This week and next the final showings of the American spring, 1962, collections which began Oct. 17, will be held. The clothes will be in the stores by the first of the year.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The oiler Kaskaskia rejoined the active Navy fleet here this morning after commissioning exercises at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Labor Department announced today two new job training programs under the Area Redevelopment Act. They involve 200 unemployed persons in Ansonia, Conn., and 100 in Washington County, Pa.

" So that its end may be as its beginning," sang Adele Addison in Town Hall last night in the first concert of the Bach Aria Group's fifteenth season. The words were from Bach's Cantata 41, "Jesu nun sei gepreiset," written for New Year's Day, but they might have served as a listener's wish for the group itself, since this initial event was full of beautiful music.
Signs of firmness reappeared in the high-grade bond market yesterday.
An all-America football team selected in a nationwide poll of writers and broadcasters was named yesterday by United Press International, which called it an "unusually heavy and powerful squad."

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec 6 -- Mike Brandeis, a 6-foot sophomore, scored 42 points to lead C.W. Post to a 108 -- 62 victory over Seton Hall of Paterson tonight. This was the first game of the season for the Post basketball team.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 55 cents a bale off to 20 cents up yesterday, with the near months weakest.

How wonderful it is to have Balanchine's "Ivesiana" back in the repertory of the New York City Ballet on what appears to be a permanent basis. In last night's program at the City Center it was sandwiched between the lovely and nostalgic "Liebeseder Walzer" and that champion steed among war horses, "Swan Lake," but it proceeded to walk away with the evening's honors.
The General Electric Company established a special unit yesterday to handle the anti-trust suits piling up against it.
A vast photographic project of documenting the accrued arts of the nation on color slides had its first public viewing here yesterday.

THE World Bridge Federation's tournament of par hands, played throughout the world in November, is now being judged in Australia, where the committee in charge is situated. Preliminary reports of the scores made by some of the leading players in other countries make it appear that a pair in this region, Roger Stern of New York and Lawrence Rosler of Murray Hill, N.J., may be in line for one of the principal prizes.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Johnny Egan starred as the Detroit Pistons routed the New York Knickerbockers, 133 -- 97, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 6 -- Bill King, all-Ivy quarterback from Richmond, Va., has been elected as Dartmouth's seventieth football captain. He succeeds a fullback, Jim Lemen of Cincinnati.
Mayor Wagner has ordered a "top-to-bottom" study of his office by City Administrator Charles H. Tenney.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- Premier Khrushchev observed today that it would be a very long time before President Kennedy turned Communist.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 6 -- Yale scored its first basketball victory of the season and sent Fordham to its first loss in a 53-50 contest tonight.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., Dec. 6 -- "Incredible mismanagement" in mobilization planning was laid to the Department of the Army today.
An invitation golf tourney with a purse of $100,000 will be staged in the metropolitan district in June.

THE headquarters of a district political club on Van Dam Street has been turned into a trim, tasteful off-Broadway house called the Van Dam Theatre. Would this be the wave of the future, like beating swords into plowshares?
The weekly take-home pay of factory production workers in the metropolitan New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose $2.70 from September to October to a new high.
The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 29:

A syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co., Allen Co., Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., and Leo Oppenheim Co. placed $50,000,000 of revenue bonds of the Grand River Dam Authority, Okla., on the market yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Neale Fraser, the star of the Australian Davis Cup team, was upset tonight by his countryman, Ken Fletcher, in a quarter-final match of the Victorian tennis championships. The score was 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 0.

VIRGIL THOMSON had the best of last night's concert of the Orchestra of America at Carnegie Hall. And this was only fitting, since he turned 65 years old on Nov. 25 and this was one of several birthday tributes being paid the composer this month.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Queen Elizabeth II returned tonight to a near-freezing Britain after a month-long, 10,000-mile journey to tropical West Africa.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Sparked by Jerry Lucas' shooting in the second half, Ohio State scored a 99 -- 79 victory over Pittsburgh tonight in the feature game of a charity double-header at the Civic Auditorium.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics lost a 21-point lead, but hung on for a 103-102 victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Four Communist delegations pressed Soviet bloc demands today in the General Assembly Political Committee for a veto power in decisions on the peaceful uses of outer space.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 6 -- Officials are hopeful that increased efficiency in both civil and military administration under President Ngo Dinh Diem will emerge from measures agreed upon by the South Vietnamese leader and Frederick E. Nolting Jr., the United States Ambassador.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations' top military commander in Katanga is a quiet-mannered Indian officer who recently used music instead of bullets to achieve an objective in the Congo.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A majority of the members of a National Guard company from De Soto, Mo., now on active duty at Fort Knox, Ky., telegraphed The Post-Dispatch today a complaint that their Federal service lacked purpose.
SIDI-BEL-ABBES, Algeria, Dec. 5 -- The French Foreign Legion "will always have a place in the fight against communism," one of its top officers said today.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Although a Transit Labor Board was set up last year to prevent last-minute crises in New York's transit contract negotiations, this year's talks appear certain to go down to the usual New Year's Eve deadline.

ALGIERS, Dec. 6 -- Fifteen alleged Rightist "activists" escaped from prison in Bone, eastern Algeria, today shortly before they were to have been transferred to metropolitan France.
Green Bay's Jim Taylor threatens to take the National Football League's individual rushing title away from Cleveland's Jimmy Brown.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 6 -- Australia and Japan both urged the General Assembly today to treat the question of China's seat in the United Nations as an important matter requiring approval by a two-thirds majority.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The best demand in several days raised wheat futures a cent or more a bushel for some contracts today on the Board of Trade, but corn remained under selling pressure and closed weak.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Ira Levin's "Critic's Choice," the latest American comedy to be brought to London, was warmly received at the Vaudeville Theatre tonight with Ian Carmichael in the part created by Henry Fonda on Broadway, where it ended a six-month run last May.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- State Department specialists on the problems of Berlin and Germany left for Paris today to join in preparations for next week's meeting of Western foreign ministers.

St. John's University opened its fifty-fifth season of intercollegiate basketball competition last night by drubbing George Washington, 79 -- 65. The game was played at Alumni Hall, the new student athletic center on the Hillcrest campus in Jamaica, Queens.

Like a young boy detonating a chain of Chinese firecrackers, the liquor industry of late has been setting off crises up and down Madison Avenue. Accounts have been shifting, rumors have been flying and -- inevitably -- heads have been rolling.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Pennsylvania's basketball team opened its season tonight with a 69 -- 54 victory over Michigan in the second game of a double-header at the Palestra.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 6 -- Ground will be broken Saturday for Yale's new Art and Architecture Building.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The United States Army continued a series of troop movements on the autobahn linking Berlin with the West today while a high East German official declared that North Atlantic Treaty Organization troops had no right of free access to the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Treasury is making special studies of automation in six major industries to help with the planned revision of rates at which all industries are permitted to write off their equipment outlays for tax purposes.

The St. Regis Roof will be the setting on Saturday for the annual luncheon of the Huguenot Society of America. The event will mark the 301st anniversary of the landing of the Huguenots in this country.
Private truckers who had failed earlier to bid on snow removal contracts submitted bids to the Department of Sanitation yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- Leaders in the automobile industry agreed today to install anti-air-pollution devices on all new cars and trucks starting with the 1963-model year next fall.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:

Allan P. Kirby, who lost control of the Alleghany Corporation last spring to the Murchison brothers of Dallas, has been conducting a spirited battle before the Securities and Exchange Commission involving the Murchisons and Alleghany.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Western European Governments, which had anticipated President Kennedy's new trade program, will probably react to the President's proposals with public enthusiasm mixed with some private skepticism.

Northern States Power Company expects to clear about $1.55 a share this year, Allen S. King, president, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts. The big Minnesota utility cleared $1.49 a share in 1960.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 6 -- Twenty-five Algerian nationalist soldiers wounded in action took off from here today for East Germany, where they will undergo medical treatment and rehabilitation at the expense of the East German Government.

Production of electric power in the nation climbed to 15,954,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday. This figure compared with 15,330,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- For the first time in five years, a section of the House of Commons was suspended today. The suspension was called when members became involved in noisy exchanges over the Government's controversial bill to control immigration from Commonwealth countries.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Four persons were killed and five were injured today as Argentina's annual road race started.
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Twenty years ago, the peace of a sleepy Sunday morning in Hawaii was shattered by Japanese bombs falling on Pearl Harbor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- After an apparent show of rivalry that was quickly denied, the Air Force and the Navy pinned astronauts wings on their respective space pioneers in a joint ceremony today.
