CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A New York University dermatologist said today that baldness could be eliminated by a series of small scalp grafts.
The automatic IRT shuttle train between Grand Central and Times Square will be put into experimental passenger service Dec. 15, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- The Soviet Government announced today that it planned to spend one-sixth of next year's budget on defense.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has accepted the post of chairman of the editorial advisory board of the Encyclopedia Americana, according to Vincent E. Sutliff, president of the Americana Corporation.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 6 (AP) -- This is a millionaire's town -- but a wolf was at the door yesterday. The police were forced to shoot him finally.
IN sheets, rolls, quires and reams, Christmas wrappings are in the stores. Judging by the selection of papers at specialty shops, gift packages will be like rainbows in December.

" Mort Sahl at Nine O'Clock" has been withdrawn. Accompanied by several song and dance performers, the comic was to have arrived Dec. 29 at the John Golden Theatre. Material was to have been edited by Herb Sargent and staged by Albert Marre.
KANPUR, India, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Steel-helmeted police riot squads quelled disorders today as India and England drew in the second of their five-match cricket test series.
Bingo games were depicted by state investigators yesterday as more profitable to bingo hall operators than to the charities they were intended to benefit.

While President Kennedy was waning the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday that capitalism and the free enterprise system were on trial, Moscow made public data that gave evidence of the magnitude of the Soviet economic challenge.

FRIBOURG, Switzerland, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Eastman Philharmonia Orchestra of Rochester, N.Y., was warmly praised today for its concert given in the main hall of Fribourg Roman Catholic University last night. It was the only Swiss performance of the group's European tour.

President Kennedy appealed directly and earnestly to industry yesterday to support "new and bold" powers for him to bargain on tariff reductions with Western Europe in broad categories, instead of item by item.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture fallows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that he did not plan to run for the Senate in Connecticut, but that the picture could change.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 6 -- Opposition sources expressed optimism today that a negotiated political settlement would be reached with the Government by tomorrow.

The East Fifty-seventh Building Corporation, Francis J. Kleban, president, has obtained a first mortgage loan of $5,500,000 at 5 3/4 per cent interest on the twenty-story apartment building at 200 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Department of Justice asked today that the Federal District Court in Los Angeles block the proposed merger of two of the four largest movie film processing companies -- the America Corporation of New York, and the Republic Corporation of North Hollywood, Calif.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Dr. George D. O'Brien, an assistant professor of philosophy at Princeton University, has been named assistant Dean of the College.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 6 -- United Nations cannon-firing jets destroyed four Katanga planes, the United Nations command announced today.

It seemed the Gotham Bowl football game would never get off the ground until almost at the eleventh hour Baylor University of Texas was signed as the opponent for unbeaten Utah State. They play Saturday at the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- James M. Gavin, the United States Ambassador to France, advanced the personal view today that a meeting between President Kennedy and President de Gaulle would be desirable but indicated that none was currently projected.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Office of Civil Defense Mobilization will hold fall-out shelter analysis courses for professional architects and engineers at eight colleges and two service schools next spring.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 -- Brazil's cruzeiro hit a new low today in the face of heavy demand for dollars.
Richard Rodgers was honored yesterday by The Broadway Association in recognition of "the greatest achievement for the advancement of Broadway."
The opening round of the Department of Justice anti-merger suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company developed into a stand-off yesterday.
Mayor Wagner appointed Assistant Budget Director William F. Shea as Budget Director yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Some time-honored techniques of home construction were scrutinized today and found to be time wasting and consequently costly in the production of houses.
The Regency style, which has been gaining ascendance in furniture collections this year, takes its inspiration from the English Regency period (1811-1820) and not the French Regence era (1700-1730).
TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Resentment and widespread bitter criticism have flared up suddenly in Japan against the economic policies of the United States.
TOKYO, Dee. 6 (UPI) -- Trade and Industry Minister Eisaku Sato approved today a voluntary plan by Japanese textile manufacturers to curtail production.

New Jersey commuters traveling to New York by way of the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad eventually may be able to transfer to Hudson Tube trains at Harrison, N.J., if a plan presented here yesterday is implemented.
The city filed a proposal yesterday for a constitutional amendment that would permit residents literate in any language in general use throughout the state to qualify as voters.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- President Kennedy's proposal received wide and favorable attention here.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP) -- After a wire-to-wire battle, Mr. Egotist won by a half-length from Tuscany Pomp in the $4,000 Cockeysville Purse, the feature at Pilmico today. Mr. Egotist returned $8.80 for $2 as the third choice in the sixhorse field.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Dec. 6 -Gene Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, tapered off in training today for defense of his world middleweight boxing title against Benny (Kid) Paret in Convention Center Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) An international mediator proposed today that the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate Athletic Union join in a national basketball council and end their long dispute over which group should represent the United States in world competition.

ANDREW ARKIN, a dress manufacturer, put the "Talent Wanted" sign on his Seventh Avenue showroom door this week. Sixty-two designers -- including the young, the old, the employed, the unemployed, design students and even one well-known designer, Jenny Bell -- showed up on Tuesday.
Once again, the stock market failed yesterday to break loose and move in a clear-cut direction. After much churning, stocks ended a shade lower on average on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Kennedy's demand for broad new tariff-cutting powers prompted a sharp exchange of views today between the ranking Democratic and Republican members of the Senate-House Economic subcommittee.
ELISABETHVILLE, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Katangese officials issued a series of victory statements today that were disputed by United Nations officials.
BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- A national television program spotlighting bookmaking in Boston has created a wave of righteous indignation here.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Earl Attlee, the former British Prime Minister was reported to be "very seriously ill" today in Amersham Hospital.

The Commodore Hotel's refusal to accommodate the annual banquet of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee was denounced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich as "indecent and un-American."
DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- "People seem to be in a car-buying mood," Maurice Kastner, general manager of the Weber Chevrolet Company in St. Louis, Mo., said today.

ALTHOUGH jewelry designing is not art in the real sense, the designer must feel that it is or he gets terribly blue. So says Miss Mimi diNiscemi, the bright young jewelry designer whose name is inscribed on the work she does for Brania, the high-fashion costume jewelry house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The brief just filed in the Supreme Court by attorneys for the Glidden Company in the Zdanok case poses both a basic constitutional and very personal issue for all the Justices and the Chief Justice in particular. The combination emphasizes the unusually wide range of the interests involved in this case.

ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Pope John XXIII recalled today that St. Nicholas, popularly known as Santa Claus, was jailed 1,600 years ago as are some present bishops of the Roman Catholic Church in Communist-ruled nations.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The state's revenue from thoroughbred and harness horse racing this year reached a record figure of $98,510,444.27. This was an increase of $2,000,000 over 1960.
PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea, Dec. 5 -- "We need twenty-five more years in New Guinea," said a senior Australian official, "but we aren't going to get it."

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 7 -- Moise Tshombe, president of Katanga Province in the Congo, appealed here yesterday for aid in blocking what he termed the decision of the United States Department of State to furnish the United Nations with "air forces destined to bombard the peaceful Katangese population."
Copper futures prices climbed again yesterday on news from the Congo of continued conflict in Katanga Province, a major producing area. Added to this were reports of labor unrest in Chile.

Earnings of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 showed little change from the results of the year-earlier period, according to a report issued by the company yesterday.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that Cardinal Spellman, as Military Vicar of the Catholics in the armed services, would again visit overseas bases during the Christmas season. This year he will be in Germany and France.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Israel asked countries friendly to both the Arab states and to Israel today to take the lead in seeking a genuine peace settlement in the Middle East.
DENVER, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Interstate Oil Compact Commission called today for a prompt and effective action to reduce and stabilize oil imports at a definite ratio to domestic production.

President Kennedy's speech to the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday was the most spectacular public display of his celebrated head for facts and figures since his television campaign debates with Richard M. Nixon.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Boston College's hockey squad suffered heavy graduation losses. Gone from last year's strong team are Tom (Red) Martin, the first American-trained skater to win All-America rating two years in a row; Billy Daley, who rewrote all the school's scoring records; Jim Logue, a crack goalie, and other mainstays.

DUBLIN, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Disputes concerning Dr. Conor Cruise O'Brien, who resigned as United Nations chief in the Congo's Katanga Province and over the use of Irish troops in the Congo, resulted today in the suspension of three Irish legislators.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Prices declined on a wide front in the stock market here today.

Spokesman for the Navy, Marines and Air Force reported yesterday their branches were ready, willing and able to wage either a big war or a small one in defense of American security. The Army gave a qualified "yes."

THE Christmas rush is on and the merchants are ready for it. Once again, department stores have assembled some of their most appealing merchandise in boutiques and this year the emphasis is on imports, especially those that are one-of-a-kind.
Jackie Cooper, who portrays Navy physician in the "Hennesey" series, will obtain shore leave to enact the role of the husband in a television adaptation of "The Fourposter."

UNDER the best of circumstances Oscar Wilde's novel, "The Picture of Dorian Gray," does not lend itself to persuasive dramatization very readily. And to do it in less than sixty minutes would seem an especially precarious undertaking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating reported today that he "was very much disturbed" by mail he had received complaining of "inadequate health facilities" for military reservists and dependents.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- James M. Skinner, president of the Philco Corporation, said today that he would resign when the concern is taken over by the Ford Motor Company.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The offices of France-Soir, the country's most widely read newspaper, were seriously damaged by an explosive charge today. One staff member was injured.

The city moved yesterday to have the Public Service Commission postpone permission to the Consolidated Edison Company to increase its electric rates $10,361,000 a year. The increase is scheduled to go into effect Dec. 20.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The new budget of the Soviet Union indicates that it, like the United States, is putting about half its annual expenditures into defense activities, Pentagon officials said today.
President Kennedy has endorsed a program sponsored by New York University that enables foreign students to spend holidays at the homes of families in the New York area.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- The state is undertaking a new high priority study of the finances of the bankrupt New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
President Kennedy marshaled his arguments thoroughly yesterday for his new trade-policy objectives, which stressed throughout a fundamental change in the United States' world relationships.

SOMEONE, some day should write an inspired and definitive cookbook on the fish and seafood that is indigenous to America. It would include lobsters from Maine, Olympia oysters from Oregon and Dungeness crab from California.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The United States and Britain may find it necessary to consider negotiation with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question without the presence of France at the council table, well-informed sources suggested today.
A plan for the redevelopment of Newark Airport was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
It was not a bumper crop, but President Kennedy made hay for proposals for freer trade with Europe's Common Market in his talk yesterday before the National Association of Manufactures.
Two major national women's groups adopted a code of action yesterday that emphasized opposition to prejudice, protection of individual liberties and intensified efforts for world peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Several members of the Federal Reserve Board, perhaps a majority, believe that there should be no ceiling on savings deposit interest rates.

The economy will end the year on an upswing, according to the latest report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. It says that "substantial gains during the last two months suggest that the underlying forces of business expansion continue to be strong."

The New York Rangers' unbeaten string on home ice was stopped at nine last night at Madison Square Garden. In a wild National Hockey League game, the New Yorkers were drubbed by the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 to 3.
The election of Thomas McCance as treasurer of the Community Service Society took place yesterday at the annual meeting of the society's board of trustees at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The State Department said today that the United States would provide up to twenty-one additional large transport planes to help the United Nations forces that are under attack by troops of secessionist Kantaga Province in the Congo.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Four newsmen were trapped in various places in Elisabethville during yesterday's fighting between forces of the United Nations and Katanga Province. Four others were in the post office from which all dispatches were sent out.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Scentific batting and wind-tunnel tests at the Armour Research Foundation have determined that there was a 'rabbit' in the 1961 baseball, editors of Popular Mechanics Magazine said today.

ADOLPHE FREZIN had not played his 'cello in New York for seven years before his appearance in Judson Hall last night, and an enthusiastic audience made it quite clear that he had better not stay away that long the next time.

Over the past months I have observed several striking misconceptions of the Democratic reform movement as discussed in the columns of The Times. Your pre-campaign editorial of June 6 deplored the reform movement's opposition to a fusion outside the Democratic party.
A memorial to the nearly 34,000 civilian British seamen who lost their lives in World War II while serving aboard merchant ships and fishing craft was unveiled here yesterday afternoon.
Psychiatrists and clergymen should not disagree because, believer or skeptic, they are both on the "same side," a noted psychiatrist said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., announced today that, barring unexpected developments, it would purchase the Turnstyle Corporation, operator of four discount department stores in the Boston area.

The authority of the police-man's nightstick was expanded here yesterday by a special order that included this blunt command: "Use it!"
The coming session of the Legislature will provide lawmakers in Albany with an outstanding opportunity to reassert New York State's leadership in the rehabilitation of the mentally ill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The mailing of allotment checks to military dependents has been delayed because of the sudden pressure of the Reserve call-up, the Army said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Lawrence J. Mullen, 57 years old, and Joseph Westenberg, 51, Teamster Union officials, were indicted today on charges of demanding and receiving illegal payoffs from trucking companies and conspiracy to use the money to pay the legal expenses of another teamster official.
Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. said yesterday that he hoped to replace recalled Army reservists and National Guard troops with new Regular Army troops "at an early date."

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, told an audience of 1,950 persons tonight that the debate over communism was "the greatest in the world."
A giant line averaging 232 1/2 pounds and one of the most brilliant backfields of recent years mark the 1961 Associated Press all-America football team announced yesterday.

Twenty-three riding days until New Year's Eve, and already Mayor Wagner's much-advertised transit labor peace board has torn up the timetable that was supposed to shield New Yorkers against year-end strike worries in the city-owned subways and buses.

Hunt Foods Industries, Inc., is planning to add a paint business to its widely diversified operations. Officials of the company were reported negotiating to take over W.P. Fuller Co., San Francisco paint manufacturer, whose sales last year exceeded $76,000,000.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will return to the practice of law when his second term expires Jan. 16.

The Board of Estimate appropriated $65,700 yesterday for a rehabilitation center for narcotic addicts in the West Eighty-fourth Street area where the city is now conducting a neighborhood conservation program.

The Federal Maritime Commission yesterday warned ship operators, steamship conferences, terminal operators and other groups subject to the Shipping Act to remember the law when exchanging rate information among themselves.
The National Association of Manufacturers held a day-long seminar yesterday on threats from communism.

There will be two varsity events instead of one at the intercollegiate cross-country championships in Van Cortlandt Park next fall, the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America decided yesterday.
NORWALK, Ohio, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Rockwell Manufacturing Company has announced that it will close its gas regulator division plant here on Feb. 1. About 130 employes would be affected.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Harry Cleverly yawned off and on while discussing Boston University's hockey prospects. The coach wasn't bored or anything like that. His seventeenth Terrier sextet is shaping up quite well.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The directors of the Akron, Canton and Youngstown Railroad Company approved today the sale of all outstanding stock to the Norfolk and Western Railway.
A varmint towboat is "running wild" on the Mississippi. A seamen's union posse has been trying for a week now to corral the runaway critter.

Montgomery Ward Co., the nation's second largest mail order enterprise and the third largest retail merchandiser, increased its sales for the three and nine months ended on Oct. 31 from the levels of the 1960 periods. However, earnings declined in both 1961 periods, the company reported yesterday.
This week and next the final showings of the American spring, 1962, collections, which began in October, will be held The clothes will be in the stores by the first of the year.

As a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, I was disturbed by your Nov. 26 editorial regarding the warning to our members about UNICEF Christmas cards.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today ultra-conservative fanaticism in the United States was under control. But he warned that it "represents a danger to the Republican party."

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The French Socialist party announced today that it would present a motion of censure against the Government, which it said was "incapable of meeting the threats against the Republic."

The development of a radio-controlled crawler tractor was announced yesterday by the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company. The new unit will have its first application in steel mill slag removal work, where the company said, it will increase safety and speed production in open-hearth operations.

Earnings of Armour Co. and its consolidated subsidiary for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28 fell from the level of the preceding year, the company reported yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools accredited fourteen Negro colleges and two Negro junior colleges today.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 7 -- George Meany answered critics of the labor movement today with the flat assertion that it was vigorous and strong.

He told the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations that labor would have to show the same measure of dedication and self-restraint it had displayed in wartime.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The unemployment rate dropped sharply last month in the first significant decline in a year, the Administration reported today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Big Ten today eliminated need as a factor in a new financial aid-to-athletes policy. The conference substituted an academic achievement level that is expected to reduce loses of athletes resulting from failure in studies.

It is an example to sustain with pride, before the nation and the world, as a home of many peoples and the host-city to the United Nations. A drive for $54,700,000 to establish a "Fund for Medical Progress" for New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center was announced last night at dinner commemorating the 190th anniversary of the founding of New York Hospital.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 7 -- Prime Minister Julius K. Nyerere said tonight that an independent Tanganyika would adopt an independent foreign policy out that the Soviet Union would be permitted to establish an embassy here.

AT 59 cents a dozen, 2 cents less than a week ago, large Grade A eggs are a protein bargain. Two fried eggs for breakfast, sunny side up or otherwise, costs a fraction less than a dime this week-end. A souffle, an angel food cake or any other dish that requires a number of eggs could be made now, too, without a strain on the budget.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Standing above the watery tomb that was the scene of Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor twenty years ago, the commander of the Pacific Fleet warned the United States today to keep strong against hostile forces.
PORT MORESBY, Australian New Guinea, Dec. 6 -- Casual visitors to the Australian part of New Guinea are usually impressed by the easy relationship between white settlers and the Papuans.
The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday named Richard H. Paul, a New York lawyer, chief counsel for its investigation of the country's stock markets.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Increased state aid for education and a revision of the method of apportioning seats in the Legislature were recommended today for action in the 1962 session of the Legislature.

Theatre parties to the evening showings of the motion picture "El Cid" at the Warner Theatre on Dec. 19, 20 and 21 will benefit Childville, a non-sectarian, interracial residential treatment center for emotionally disturbed children at 130 Boerum Street in Brooklyn.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 7 -- Four policemen were injured here today after policemen wielding batons charged about 500 Africans who stoned the central police station.

Frederick C. Wood, convicted of slaying two elderly men in a basement apartment in Astoria, was sentenced to death yesterday in Queens County Court. He is to be executed in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison in the week of Jan. 29.

Boutonnieres and bourbon, cummerbunds and a Cadillac were among the seized and unclaimed items sold yesterday at auction by the Bureau of Customs.

High-grade debt securities rose slightly in price in a moderately active market trading session yesterday.

The Board of Estimate yesterday ordered a renegotiation of the city's thirty-year lease of Carnegie Hall to the corporation formed last year to save it from demolition.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- New Jersey Democrats made plans tonight to open a state-wide registration drive in anticipation of the 1962 Congressional campaign.
LEONIA, N.J., Dec. 7 -Members of the Methodist Church here are helping their church by helping a scientific group.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday put some stronger "teeth" in its minimum requirements for listing new stock issues on the exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration cautioned the 75,000 distributors of food suplements of the Nutri-Bio Corporation today that the legality of sales promotion materials used by the company had been challenged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A preliminary analysis of the latest Soviet nuclear test series shows that the Soviet Union may have pulled ahead of the United States in some areas of atomic weapons design, particularly in large-yield warheads for ballistic missiles.

MONTREAL, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored three goals early in the final period and defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 15,086, the largest Forum crowd of the season.
