The North Hempstead and Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District 1 is planning the sale of $2,296,000 of bonds on Dec. 19. The issue will come due serially from 1963 to 1991.

Following is a transcript of President Kennedy's address to the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday in Bal Harbour, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The railroad and trucking industries reported today substantial increases in freight loadings last week from the preceding week and 1960 levels.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- A.P. Herbert (Sir Alan Herbert), author and former member of Parliament, campaigning to have authors paid when their works are borrowed from libraries, announced today he would make every effort to keep public libraries and the British Museum from getting copies of his next book.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 7 -- Gen. Chung Hee Park, head of the South Korean military junta, expressed hope today that the United States would give financial aid to South Korea's five-year plan in addition to the normal aid being received every year.
The controversial plan to widen Fulton Street for most of its half-mile length east of Broadway was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The vote was 16 to 6.

The spirit of the mysterious East last night invaded the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, which was populated by the fashionable from the not-so-mysterious East Side. The occasion was the seventh annual Imperial Ball, which each year has a titled guest of honor.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that Portugal had created a situation in her possessions on the Indian west coast that was becoming increasing "intolerable" to India.
Mayor Wagner has asked J. Raymond Jones, a Harlem Democratic district leader, to serve as a city Democratic coordinator and liaison man with the five Democratic county organizations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Housing starts in 1962 will be between 3 and 4 per cent higher than the expected total of 1,325,000 for 1961 if home builders adhere to their present plans.
Three men involved in recent controversies over speaker bans at the municipal colleges spoke at City College meetings yesterday without objection by the administration.

Events today: "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Josef Krips, conductor, Tossy Spivakovsky, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; Leonid Hambro, pianist, and Stanley Drucker, clarinetist, Town Hall, 5:30; Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:40; New York University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Concert of chamber music, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

On an October day in 1928 Ray Morrison's Southern Methodist Mustangs put on an exhibition of razzle-dazzle football at West Point that "made the hair stand up straight on the heads of 1,200 frantic cadets."

ALBANY, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The plan to put state credit behind $500,000,000 in bonds to finance construction of college buildings was defeated by 161,458 votes, the State Board of Canvassers reported today.

In a letter appearing Nov. 21 Jesse Gordon makes a series of false statements regarding the imprisonment of David Alfaro Siqueiros. He is not "seriously ill and languishing in Lecumberri jail," but instead enjoys certain privileges through which he has continued to paint.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 84.5 on Wednesday from 84.3 on Tuesday. It was the eleventh consecutive daily increase.

LATE in the afternoon on the bloody battlefield of Waterloo the Duke of Wellington was exchanging a few words with the Earl of Uxbridge, commander of the Allied cavalry. Just as Uxbridge was about to ride off to lead in person still another charge, "he was struck by a grapeshot on the right knee which shattered the joint all to pieces."
Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, cautioned the city's teachers yesterday not to accept Christmas gifts of "significant material value" from pupils or their parents.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 7 -- On the third day of fighting here neither side had taken control of Elisabethville.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Eugene F. Gibbons of Valley Stream, L.I., former chief engineer of the New York State Department of Public Works, was named today to become Nassau County Commissioner of Public Works, effective Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, Dec. 2, were 3 per cent above the level of a year earlier. The volume for the year to date was 2 per cent above the 1960 level.

NEWARK, Dec. 7 -- A 14-year-old boy admitted critically stabbing his mother today in their home in the Weequahic section, the police said. He was arrested shortly before midnight after returning with a friend from an automobile trip to Asbury Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Civil Aeronautics Board said today the board would withhold at least until sometime next week legal authority for the Hughes Tool Company to continue emergency financial aid to Northeast Airlines.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- The chairman of the National Broadcasting Company attacked criticism of television by governmental authority today as a "dangerous, mistaken, illiberal doctrine."

Justice Keogh's career in public service began when he was a teacher in public school in Brooklyn, his birthplace... was later assistant district attorney, naval officer, United States Attorney...for last eleven years has been a justice of the State Supreme Court.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 7 -- "It's warmer here today than it was yesterday."

The character and conduct of Communist countries are the subjects of a collection of essays by twenty distinguished contributors. Called "Unity and Contradiction: Major Aspects of Sino-Soviet Relations," the book is scheduled for Feb. 23 publication by Praeger.
Tanganyika, former German colony and then British mandate and U.N. trust territory, becomes independent at midnight tonight.

TORONTO, Dec. 7 -- The tenth season of the Stratford Shakespearean Festival, opening on June 18, will show "Macbeth," "The Tempest" and "The Taming of the Shrew." In addition, Edmond Rostand's "Cyrano de Bergerac" will join the repertory on July 30 for the balance of the season.
BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- Gov. John A. Volpe today called for an investigation of the Boston Police Department by various law enforcement agencies.

The Friday Evenings, a group of post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples, will hold its third cocktail dance of the current season on Sunday, Dec. 17, at the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East.
MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- The Soviet Union complained today of what it termed "hostile actions" against its cultural exhibitions in the United States.

FAIRFIELD, N.C., Dec. 7 -In other parts of the world there are adult delinquents who laugh as they steal children's candy or trip lame old ladies, but down here in the goose-shooting fields they are known as "sky busters."

Now boats will go to the highest bidder. Nearly everything else has been auctioned -farms, furniture, antiques, rugs. So some nautically-minded business men have decided to hold an auction of used cruisers and runabouts Sunday afternoon.

In your Dec. 2 summary of the speech made by the Secretary of State, Dean Rusk, you mention that State Department experts have been trying for months to devise a formula for stabilizing world market prices of commodities and that one of the means considered is international commodity agreements.
The board of directors of S.H. Kress Co. voted to resume dividend payments yesterday, with a declaration of 25 cents a share, payable on Dec. 28 to shareholders of record of Dec. 18.
The blaze of light and color that makes New York a dazzling spectacle at Christmas time flared last night as the 4,000 bulbs on the Rockefeller Center tree went on.

CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Attorney General Maurice J. Murphy Jr. was appointed successor to Senator Styles Bridges today. He indicated he would follow closely the conservatism and strong anti-Communist stands of the late dean of Senate Republicans.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 (AP) -The Clevite Corporation raised its dividend rate today by declaring a 35-cent-a-common-share payment on Dec. 28 to holders of record of Dec. 15. For the last ten quarters the company had paid 30 cents a common share.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today a set of fifteen advertising "do's" and "don'ts" for commercial fall-out shelter builders.

Although pianists and violinists occasionally have been known to conduct their own orchestral accompaniments, it is somewhat less common for a singer to attempt the task. Last night at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, however, Gerard Souzay tried his hand at leading this kind of double life.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -Economic ramifications of the disposal of 63,000,000 shares of General Motors Corporation stock by E.L. du Pont de Nemours Co. were debated today in United States district court.

Business loans by the fourteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York fell by $91,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the year-earlier week, there was a decline of $114,000,000.

PARIS, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- The European Common Market and sixteen African states have agreed on a link under which the African nations will receive advantages at least equal to those guaranteed to Common Market members, a communique announced tonight.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation aggregated $30,875,308,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The grain futures market developed a good deal of firmness today and most of it held to the close, although there were no particularly significant commercial influences.

DR. EDGAR S. BROWN JR.'s disgust with the commercialism of Christmas is widely shared. As director of worship in the United Lutheran Church, he is well within his rights to protest against the commercial opportunism that debases an old festival.

LAST night saw the first premiere of the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center. This was George Balanchine's extended divertissement previously known under the working title of "Raymonda," since its twelve numbers take their music (and style) from the old ballet of that name choreographed by Petipa to the score by Glazunov.

HAND in hand, the Menuhins -- Yehudi and Hephzibah, brother and sister -- came out on the stage of Town Hall last night. They played a benefit concert to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of the Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., reached the semi-finals of the Victorian tennis championships today with a 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3 victory over Mary Reitano of Australia. She also advanced in women's and mixed doubles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Army National Guard units manning air defense batteries around cities will be armed with the Nike Hercules missile starting late next year, the Army said today.
FORT LEWIS, Wash., Dec. 7 -- A group of Wisconsin legislators reported high morale tonight among their state's Guardsmen in the Thirty-second Infantry Division.
ALGIERS, Dec. 7 -- Former Gen. Raoul Salan defied the Government today, announcing that he had "confirmed" nine men in command posts in the Secret Army Organization in Algeria.

The American Motors Corporation will invade Europe next month with its Rambler Classic six-cylinder model. The car will be produced at the Haren, Belgium, plant of Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, France's biggest automobile manufacturer.

Production of lumber in the nation totaled 204,523,000 board feet in the week ended Saturday. This figure compared with 174,596,000 board feet in the holiday week that preceded, according to reports received from regional associations.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Rapidly falling snow brought up to ten inches across southwestern New York today, resulting in at least three deaths.

ALL is well once again with Dorothy Raedler's American Savoyards. Having tripped on "The Vagabond King," they have hurried back to Gilbert and Sullivan. Last night the Savoyards presented "The Gondoliers" at the Jan Hus House.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was rebuked tonight by a leader of the television industry for having described it a "vast wasteland."
The Public Service Commission is expected to act on Consolidated Edison's request for an increase in electric rates next Tuesday. Public hearings were completed yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- The United Nations said today that United States Globemasters would resume flights to United Nations forces in Elisabethville tomorrow morning.

As far as City Hall is concerned, President Kennedy's physical fitness program begins at City Hall. Deputy Mayor Paul R. Screvane gave evidence of this yesterday by performing a one-legged deep-knee bend at a calisthenics ceremony at City Hall.

FIVE experienced tasters, armed with sharp knives, pitchers of ice water and serious intent, nibbled, sniffed and examined twenty-seven fruitcakes recently. Their purpose, in the annual New York Times fruitcake tasting, was to select the best from a generous assortment of the products available in retail stores here at this season.

The transfer of station WNTA-TV (Channel 13) to an educational group, which had been scheduled for today, has been postponed until Wednesday. Both parties said additional time was required to complete "complex legal details."
In estors Stock Fund, Inc., became the fourth member of the mutual funds' "billionaires club." Its assets that day reached $1,023,286,940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A committee of nine members to assist Latin-American Governments in developing economic and social projects under President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress was announced today.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dee. 8 (UPI) -- Authorities today announced the arrest of seven men accused in a $180,000 short-weight swindle at the Anderson elevators in suburban Maumee.
The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company's family of shareholders harbors some vaguely dissatisfied members.

The executive board of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers is recommending to the membership that they refuse to sign contracts for their services after next May unless the society is recognized by the League of New York Theatres.

A panel of New York City business and academic leaders, headed by David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, gave an optimistic report yesterday on the future of the city as the financial and corporate capital of the United States.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 7 -Mrs. Marguerite Stitt Church of Evanston, the state's only Congresswoman, will not run for a seventh term. Her announcement today took Republican leaders by surprise.
The United States economy has not been achieving its potential, according to Dr. Simon Kuznets of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Holden Roberto, Angolan nationalist leader, said today that his liberation movement was willing to negotiate a "stage-by-stage" approach to independence with Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar of Portugal.
Bertrand L. Kohlmann, after being elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association last night, swung at slowpokes on the golf course.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The airlines are debating the question whether mergers will help solve their financial ills.
CLARKSDALE, Miss., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Seven Negroes were arrested today on charges of "withholding trade" from downtown merchants.
HONG KONG, Dec. 7 -- Communist China vehemently attacked India and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today over the border dispute between the two nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- "Malicious, frustrated extremists" are again attacking those in public service when excellence in government is "imperative to the survival of free government," the publisher of The Washington Post and Times Herald declared today.

Pro football's annual verbal skirmish over college draftees appeared on the verge of escalating into a court battle yesterday. The immediate issue involved two linemen who have signed with teams in both the National and American Football Leagues.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Industrial shares prices rallied after a dull start in the stack market here today to close with slightly more rises than falls.
A state Supreme Court justice and a former Federal prosecutor were accused yesterday of taking a $35,000 bribe to fix a case of bankruptcy fraud in Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The drug industry agreed today to some additional Federal regulation, but said that other features in a pending bill would destroy all incentive for the development of new drugs.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7 -- President Kennedy told the national convention of Young Democratic Clubs today to give its attention to the nation's real problems and not to outmoded political slogans.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- A seven-day strike by 1,000 butchers employed by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company ended today when the strikers ratified a new contract providing for an $11-a-week increase in pay.
FORT McCLELLAN, Ala., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Col. William H. Greene, head of the chemical combat troops training here, said today he disputed the published complaints of a Kansas City, Kan., unit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced tonight that it would develop a two-man space craft capable of joining another in orbit.

The shortage of legitimate theatre houses is giving Broadway the appearance of a checkerboard these days. At least six attractions will be involved in house moves within the next few weeks and one play ("A Place Without Twilight") has delayed production activities until a suitable haven is found.

Ed Johnson, a 6-foot-2-inch junior, scored 18 points last night to pace Long Island University to a 62-58 victory over Roanoke College of Virginia at the New York University Alumni Gymnasium in the Bronx.

Feldman, Kramer, Bam, Nessen Cowett, a law firm, has leased a floor in the building at 500 Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street and will move from 12 East Forty-first Street in January. The lease was negotiated by S. Harold Appel of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., broker.
Pleas in seventeen cases involving properties that had been managed by David B. Solove were changed in Housing Court yesterday from guilty to not guilty.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday changes in its pricing policies on aluminum extrusion ingot that had the effect of reducing the price on one key grade by 1.2 cents a pound to 24.3 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Premier Fidel Castro's speech last Saturday in which he declared himself a "Marxist-Leninist until the last day of my life" appears to have caused consternation in the Communist world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The problem of Congressional investigations, which has deeply divided the Supreme Court in recent years, was back before the justices today.

THE deal shown was reported by the victim, or culprit, or both -- the player who was declarer at one spade doubled with the South hand -- and he proposed a belated moral: When playing for a small number of tricks, cash everything in sight as soon as possible.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The smallest Boston Garden crowd of the season -- 7,415 -- saw the Chicago Black Hawks continue unbeaten in four games with the last-place Bruins by winning a National Hockey League game tonight, 5 -- 2.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 7 -- United States Air Force planes that had been carrying United Nations troops and equipment from here to Elisabethville were temporarily grounded today after a Globemaster transport was hit by ground fire.
Thoroughbred racing, enjoying one of its best years, winds up 1961 showing increases over 1960 in attendance, wagering and the states' share of the pari-mutuel handle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The creation of a Common Market for the Western Hemisphere as part of President Kennedy's program of trade liberalization was proposed today by a member of his Senate leadership team.
Michael H. Prendergast charged yesterday that the reform Democratic faction was trying to put the Democratic party under control of the "extreme left."
A new program to save some existing housing from destruction within an area scheduled for redevelopment will be tried by the city.
WASHINGTOn. FOR President Kennedy's distinguished foreign visitors who are here on official or state visits, Blair House, across from the White House, is a refuge -- a home away from home.
All near-by Maine potato futures contracts advanced yesterday, primarily on a rumor concerning a Government-aid program. The rumor became a fact after the close of trading.

State bingo investigators were told yesterday that veterans' groups were persuaded by a judge's secretary to hire a former City Corporation Counsel to contest a State Lottery Control Commission ruling.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation has offered to waive some of its rights under the statute of limitations as a show of good faith to customers who might be filing antitrust suits against it in the next two months.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Billy Farrell of Springfield, N.J.; George Knudson of Toronto and Chico Miantuz of Argentina shared the first-round lead with 65's today in the $20,000 Coral Gables open golf tournament.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 7 -- The Government rejected tonight the Opposition's latest proposal for a political settlement to end the Dominican crisis, which has been aggravated by a ten-day-old general strike.

The excellent Four Seasons Consort returned last night to give the first of two programs it has scheduled in Carnegie Recital Hall. The ensemble includes Eric Leber, recorder player, Lois Wann, oboist, Barbara Mueser, viola da gamba player, and Patricia Livingston, harpsichordist.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 7 -- President Kennedy announced today the appointments of new ambassadors to Mali, Haiti and Syria.
Two teacher organizations yesterday accused each other of injecting religion into the campaign for the collective bargaining agent for the city's 40,000 teachers.

The president of the American Cyanamid Company said yesterday that the chemical industry had reason for optimism in the face of growing world competition as a result of its competitive advantage, experience and patent system.
Cotton futures dropped 85 cents to $2.30 a bale yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -About 1,100 State Department employes have been forced into a giant game of musical chairs that will leave 300 out of work by Jan. 2. It is hoped that this will save enough money to pay for some New Frontier innovations in foreign policy.

The ever-growing role played by mutual funds and other institutional investors in the stock market was dramatized yesterday by the latest "Public Transaction Study" of the New York Stock Exchange. On Sept. 15, the day of the study, institutional activity reached a new high, accounting for more than 26 per cent of the trading that day.
A leading authority on geology said last night that the record preserved within the ocean sediments seemed to extend back either 100,000,000 years or forty-five times that long.
A Brooklyn policeman and four others were arraigned in Magistrates Court yesterday in a recent series of church robberies and the desecration of one church.
New York University will meet Denver and Manhattan College will play Navy tonight in a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.
Additional security measures were taken to protect President Kennedy on his two-day visit here this week because of a reported threat by a pro-Castro Cuban to shoot the President.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The Western Allies began a week-long search in Paris today for unity of approach to the Berlin problem.
TOKYO, Dec. 7 -- The twenty years that have passed since Japan set out on Dec. 7, 1941 to destroy the United States have changed the country into a major ally of her former foe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A Senate subcommittee was told today that children of persons suspected of being members of the Cuban underground had been paraded in front of their parents' prisons in Cuba to extort confessions from the parents.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The advance party of a 1,500-man United States battle group, newly assigned to duty here, rode the East German auto-bahan to West Berlin today without incident.

IF you can't abide theatre in free dramatic forms, don't go near "The Apple." If you detest weird characters in unexpected bursts of rage, passion and grotesque humor, don't bother to visit the Living Theatre for a performance of the new play by Jack Gelber, author of "The Connection."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Congress should forbid the states to tax any income derived from interstate commerce, a spokesman for the garment industry told a House subcommittee today.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System were down $68,000,000 at $33,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements were off $221,000,000 to $498,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A Navy officer charged today that the Navy was "threatened with eclipse by a burgeoning, all powerful Department of Defense."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 7 -- A ruling by the Secretary of State that the name of an established political party cannot be changed led Bridgeport Socialists today to abandon efforts to find a new party name.

Gov.-Elect Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey does not take office until mid-January but some recent statements of intent have already made a favorable impression. He plans to meet soon with Governor Rockefeller of New York, and is reported optimistic on reaching agreement with him on several major issues between the states, such as the proposed World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan, the future of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and commuter income taxes.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner rebuked the Port of New York Authority today for what he said was its failure to inform him of plans to expand Newark Airport before making them public.
ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- An official investigation of conflict-of-interest charges against Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino was begun today by a bipartisan legislative committee.

Although most ski areas will not open officially until next week-end, enthusiasts were hoping to get a head start on the season tomorrow and Sunday. Reports from New England revealed that some of them would not be disappointed.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Earl of Home, Britain's Foreign Secretary, indicated today the Government's concern that United Nations operations in the Congo would last for years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, received tonight a gold medal and $10,000 awarded by an insurance company for contributions to the national health or safety.
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 6 -- Members of the United States Peace Corps in Ghana are confident that their operation is off to a good start, for both Ghana and the United States.
The first shipment by Alco Products, Inc., of Diesel-electric locomotives of a new export design is on its way to India, the company reported yesterday.
Settlement of the strike against the Mississippi Valley Barge Line Company of St. Louis was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- A switch was pulled in a British power station today and English housewives began to cook lunch with electricity possibly generated in the French Alps.

Among the exhibitions reviewed during the week are two big ones that should be on gallery goers' lists. The Museum of Modem Art has gathered a handsome show, "Redon, Moreau and Bresdin," which examines these French symbolists in the context of contemporary art.

ALTHOUGH the holiday season is still several weeks away, visions of sugar plums are already dancing in many small heads. To encourage the spirit of giving and to satisfy the urge to create that is present in every child, it is fun to organize a cooky-making party on a day when outdoor activities are curtailed because of bad weather.

I feel that you have done us a grave injustice in your Nov. 30 editorial on the Reservists. As a Reservist now stationed at Fort Dix, I can honestly say that my feelings are those of 95 per cent of the men of my unit.
Cara Williams and Dick Van Dyke will star with Henry Fonda and Carol Lynley on a Columbia Broadcasting System TV special.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States called on non-Communist nations today to rally to the defense of South Vietnam.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- Gov John A. Volpe asked Police Commissioner Leo J. Sullivan of Boston for his resignation today. He said it was the "first and most essential step" in restoring public confidence in the Police Department.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- A program for using surplus food to spur the economic development of needy lands was laid before the United Nations today.
An all-Australia club team will tour the United States next spring and compete against ten colleges in lacrosse.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Some of the 180-member du Pont family sought to show today that they did not work as a solid bloc in their stock dealings.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The police arrested five officials of the Committee of 100 today in an effort to frustrate tomorrow's mass invasion of United States air bases by demonstrators for nuclear disarmament.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 8 -- Michael J. Quill today threatened a city-wide subway and bus strike in New York next Friday unless the Transit Authority canceled plans to start using a crewless, automatic train on the Grand Central-Times Square shuttle then.

Puerto Rican voters will pass tomorrow upon a constitutional amendment under which Puerto Rico's ability to contract public debt will be gauged by Commonwealth revenues from all sources, rather than assessed valuation of property.

IT is always an unusual experience to hear, and observe, Tossy SpivaRovsky. If for no other reason, there is the way he manipulates the violin. As often as not the neck of the instrument is pointed toward the ceiling, and one wonders how Mr. Spivakovsky gets his bow over the strings.
Reconstruction of the buildings at 41 and 43 East Twenty-second Street has been started for an F.W. Woolworth store, which will occupy the property in February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Pentagon announced today that Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara had approved plans for a tri-service Defense Supply Agency. It will control a $3,200,000,000 inventory of military supplies.
Marijuana smoking among Harlem teen-agers is almost as common as the use of regular cigarettes, a Negro Democratic leader declared yesterday.

It was a specialist's sort of program that Claudio Arrau offered a capacity audience last night at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum. For those who have no problem accepting every note in the romantic piano literature, the evening must have been a sheer delight.

The crucial meeting in Paris today between President de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer will help decide how soon, if at all, there will be negotiations between Soviet Russia and a united West to resolve the continuing crisis over Berlin.
An evening of contemporary and baroque chamber music was presented last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

The current engagement of Duke Ellington and his orchestra at Basin Street East can be classified as a rare event. It is the first time in more than five years that his band has appeared in a New York club.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Donald Campbell said today he expected his new jet-engined car, Bluebird, to be completed within weeks for attempts next year to raise the world land-speed record to "over 400 miles an hour."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Evening Star says selected members of the Kennedy Administration, including several Cabinet officers, have been attending weekly lectures on abstruse subjects.
The New York staff of Tass, the Soviet press agency, says it has beaten President Kennedy to the push-up with its own physical fitness program.
COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Swift Manufacturing Company, a garment, drapery and upholstery manufacturer, announced today it was being sold to Glen Alden Corporation.
The head of the house and next head of the house were having one of those periods of togetherness which are urged by popular psychologists. The time was the conclusion of homework.

In a recent issue certain attorneys advocating repeal of the Connally Reservation assure your readers that this would be "an act, which could expose the United States to no practical risk, yet would put an end to our self-judging attitude toward the court, enable us to utilize it, and advance in a tangible way the cause of international law and order."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, bidding for a sixth crack at the middleweight title, knocked out Willie Greaves in forty-three seconds of the eighth round of a scheduled ten-round bout tonight at the Civic Arena.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board expert on foreign airlines said today Scandinavian Airlines system had ignored United States protests about its service to this country.

Stanley Drucker spent a couple of hours yesterday afternoon fulfilling his duties as solo clarinetist with the New York Philharmonic in a subscription concert in Carnegie Hall and then moved down to Town Hall for a joint concert with Leonid Hambro, pianist, at 5:30.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 8 (AP) -- An Army private who refused to submit to routine inoculations because he said they would be detrimental to his health was found guilty today of disobeying an order. On another charge, that he threatened an officer, a military court declared him not guilty.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge refused today to block the proposed sale of Philco Corporation to Ford Motor Company. Judge John L. Miller turned down a request for a preliminary restraining order, which had been sought as an outgrowth of a dispute between Philco Finance Corporation and Appliance Associates, Inc., of Pittsburgh over supermarket-appliance plans.

IN his religious drama, "This Way to the Tomb," which was given the first of three performances last night by the Union Theological Seminary, Ronald Duncan is taking the point of view that it profits man little if he gains the world but loses his soul.
Stocks rose yesterday as trading picked up a bit.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Benny (Kid) Paret of Cuba, the world welterweight champion, will bid for Gene Fullmer's share of the world middleweight title tomorrow night.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 8 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg assured workers today that there was "plenty of room" for wage increases under the Administration's economic policy.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 8 -- Pedro Rodriguez, a 21-year-old Mexican driver, won the 103.5-mile Governor's Trophy race today as the eighth annual Bahamas International Speed Week entered its final stage.

An extra dividend of 70 cents a share and an increase in the quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share were announced yesterday by the American Enka Corporation, producer of rayon and nylon. The payment will be made Dec. 29 to stockholders of record of Dec. 18.

New York City's record of shameful indifference to the fast-disappearing architectural heritage may be improved in the future if the Mayor acts now to establish a Landmarks Preservation Commission with definite powers and responsibilities. Creation of such a body within the city government has just been recommended to the Mayor by a committee he appointed last spring, headed by Geoffrey Platt.

Daniel V. Wrenn retired yesterday on rounding out fifty-four years of service with the Bureau of Customs -- "fifty-four years and four days, to be exact." And the septuagenarian assistant to the Collector of Customs said he had no regrets about quitting.
UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 8 -- Canada expressed the hope today that some form of action would be taken at this session of the General Assembly on the question of China's seat in the United Nations.

A TEN-MINUTE walk from the main plaza of Mexico City stands the Casa Grande, a block-square tenement between the Street of the Barbers and the Street of the Tinsmiths. One of its rooms is occupied by the family of Jesus Sanchez, first composed of six members, more as grandchildren arrive.
ALGIERS, Dec. 8 -- Violence flared in many parts of Algeria today, causing the death of at least thirty persons.
The new issue market is expected to continue active next week as more than $200,000,000 of fixed-interest securities have been slated for sale.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A special committee of the International Tennis Federation drew up a program today that would scrap the distinction between amateur and professional tennis players and make professional stars eligible for Wimbledon and Davis Cup competition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Doctors and pharmacists were warned this week that triparanol, a drug widely used to prevent heart attacks, could have adverse side effects.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Dec. 8 -- Army Intelligence is investigating the appearance of form letters at this big Army post asking reservists to write complaining letters to their Congressmen and telling them how to do it.

Plans have been announced for the construction of a first-run art film theatre, to be called the Lincoln Art Theatre, on Fifty-seventh Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway. The 600-seat house which is expected to open early next spring, will be the second Manhattan theatre for films of a special nature to be operated by a group headed by Robert Ferman and Meyer Ackerman.
Air traffic in the New York area will flow through a new pattern of circling areas, starting Jan. 11.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Britain decided tonight to supply the United Nations with twenty-four 1,000-pound bombs for use by Indian Canberra bombers against the forces of Katanga province.

IN his original drama entitled "Come Again to Carthage," which was seen last night on "Westinghouse Presents" over Channel 2, Robert Crean has written a work with a theme of spiritual beauty and faith.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 8 -- The Prince Leopold Hospital for Africans here was heavily hit by mortar fire for about ten hours last night and early today. Physicians and nurses at the hospital said United Nations forces had hit the building with thirty to fifty mortar shells.

A dissident group of stockholders of the Firth Carpet Company, including one of the biggest Firth distributors on the West Coast, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission notice of its intention to wage a proxy fight to block the proposed merger of Firth into Mohasco Industries, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk put the United States stanchly behind the Acting Secretary General, U Thant, today in the Congo crisis.

The signing of the first labor contract with a major stevedoring company in the port and the renewal of an agreement covering steamship line clerical personnel were announced here yesterday by Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union.
Argentina and Paraguay received standby authority yesterday to draw additional funds of other countries' currencies from the International Monetary Fund during the next twelve months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The chief of the Continental Army Command said today that the Texas and Wisconsin National Guard divisions that have been centers of controversy "are two of the finest and best prepared in our entire reserve forces."
The American Can Company announced yesterday that it would close a machinery plant in Cincinnati and transfer the work to two other locations where employes had agreed to accept lower pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A Congressional economic study group heard testimony today that Western Europe's mounting trade with the Soviet Union was undermining the economy of the non-Communist world and helping to communize under-developed areas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Soybean futures ran into a burst of selling today on the Board of Trade, and losses ranged to well over a cent a bushel. The grains maintained a rally, however, and finished generally firm to strong.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A record shooting performance by Larry Costello of Syracuse failed to prevent the Boston Celtics from defeating the Nationals, 123 --111, tonight in the National Basketball Association.
The two factions in an intra-union dispute among Consolidated Edison Company employes agreed yesterday in Supreme Court to submit the issues to their national executive board tomorrow in Miami, Fla.

The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission voiced concern last night that support for basic research and education was "still inadequate" in a world contest with the Soviet Union. He implied that industry was lagging in its share.
The H.J. Heinz Company had the best half-year in its ninety-two-year history, with sales and earnings at new records, Henry J. Heinz 2d, chairman, reported yesterday.
City College's swimming team opened its season yesterday by defeating Manhattan, 53 -- 42, at the Beavers' Wingate Pool. The loss was the first for the Jaspers after two victories.
LONG BEAH, L.I., Dec. 9 -- The Long Beach Board of Education announced last night it would not renew the contract of Dr. David G. Salten, the Superintendent of Schools, when it expired on June 30.

The receipt of its largest volume of defense orders in nearly a decade was announced yesterday by the Bell Helicopter Company, a division of the Bell Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of Textron, Inc.
A Federal grand jury that was inadvertently discharged, but continued to work for three days unaware of the order, asked for and finally got pay for the time, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman estimated this country's sugar requirements for 1962 at 9,500,000 tons today. That compared with 9,820,000 tons for 1961.
Two all-America players, Ernie Davis of Syracuse and Alex Kroll of Rutgers, headed the United Press International all-East college football team it was revealed today.
High-grade bond prices were firm yesterday, giving the market its most stable appearance of the week.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Syria and Jordan pressed today Arab demands for a United Nations custodianship over properties left in Israel by Arab refugees who fled during the 1948 Palestine conflict.

Earnings of Wilson Co., and its domestic subsidiaries for the year ended on Oct. 28 were nearly four times greater than those of fiscal 1960, when a strike depressed profits, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
Coach Sammy Baugh drilled the New York Titans two hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday in preparation for their American Football League game with the Houston Oilers here tomorrow.

PALM BEACH, Dec. 8 -- The White House said today that reports of rioting in Caracas had been "slightly exaggerated." Nothing has happened, a spokesman said, to change President and Mrs. Kennedy's plan to visit there Dec. 16.

A defense motion by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to strike from the record affidavits submitted by the Department of Justice in its anti-trust suit against the bank was denied yesterday by Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon.
GIBRALTAR, Dec. 4 -- New Yorkers with parking problems can consider themselves fortunate compared with the 25,000 residents of this British colony, two and one-fourth square miles in size.
Three major cast changes in Verdi's "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera last night did not keep the performance from being exciting dramatically and musically.
One thousand $5 bills were turned loose in Macy's Department store yesterday -- with 1,000 children hanging on for dear life.

THIS week the second edition of an Italian-American bridge match that started in 1957 will begin. But this is a rubber match, generally called a set game, between Tobias Stone and Alvin Roth on the American side and Mario Franco of Milan and his partner or partners on the other side.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The American Communist party pleaded not guilty today to charges of failing to register as an arm of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today fixed the national draft quota for January at 15,000 men, 1,000 fewer than were called this month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices remained unchanged at 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

HARTFORD, Dec. 8 -- Fifteen persons died today when they were trapped by smoke and flames on the ninth floor of the thirteen-story Hartford Hospital. The dead were seven patients, a physician, a nurse, two hospital employes and four visitors.

David Rockefeller observed in a speech the other day that here in New York "we have an extraordinary combination of resources, both human and material," and that "no other city in the world contains the range of skills and talent in depth which our city has." This comment, with which we fully agree, turned our thoughts to politics and government.
A judge's secretary who earns $4,000 a year made $48,000 additional by operating the largest bingo hall in the state a special state investigator was told yesterday.

When Alfonso de Albuquerque sailed into the Arabian Sea and took the city of Goa in the summer of 1510, Portugal was an important colonial power. Her right to Goa was substantially the same as Britain's subsequent right to India -- namely, having the power, she took it. She also took one or two other fragments of India which she still holds, and two little specks of dust which she claims but does not hold.

THE newest shop to appear in Greenwich Village has an aura all its own. For virtually everything on view is of paper. Called Martin Proctor's Papier Malce, the store is at 55 Greenwich Avenue just off Perry Street.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 8 -- United States Air Force transport planes resumed this morning an airlift of United Nations troops and equipment to Elisabethville.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The defense injected alleged violation of the right of freedom of speech today in the trial of two persons accused of violating Connecticut's eighty-two-year-old anti-birth-control law.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- A supplemental deer season will be held in eleven towns in Westchester County Jan. 15-19 and Jan. 22-26, according to a report by the State Conservation Department today.

The deadlock that has developed in the Dominican Republic could not be more unfortunate, but it is understandable. The pattern has unfolded in what can be called classic style. For this reason there should be patience on the part of outsiders, not interference.

The trans-Atlantic airline talks scheduled to open Monday in Bermuda are expected by many in the air-travel industry to result in an agreement on a cut-rate group fare and a year-round excursion fare.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 8 -- The Congolese central Government threatened today to turn elsewhere for help if the United Nations was unable to "restore legality" in secessionist Katanga Province.

THE new president-elect of Teachers College, John Henry Fischer, titled his doctoral dissertation "A Plan for Reviewing and Revising the Program for the Preparation of School Executives at Teachers College, Columbia University."

The five-story office building at 46 and 48 Trinity Place through to 83 and 85 Greenwich Street has been sold by the estate of Benjamin Van Horne Vingut to an investor through the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 8 -Edwin G. Michaelian, County Executive of Westchester, said today he would accept a $3,480 pay increase next year, not the $4,450 recommended by a consulting concern. His present salary is $30,000.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., rang up a record $466,800,056 in sales in the twenty-eight weeks ended on Nov. 11, according to the report yesterday of Louis Stein, president of the retail food chain. This was 6.4 per cent above the $438,795,979 volume for the 1960 period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics board approved today lower air freight rates that American and Trans World Airlines plan to introduce tomorrow.
Continuing cold weather in Vermont, which followed a sizable snow storm, led operators of at least four areas in the Green Mountain State to announce that they would be open today for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- James L. Kempthorne says he has revolutionized the process of spraying insulation on walls and ceilings. His method eliminates, he asserts, the dust that used to choke workmen and drive everybody from the spraying area.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The Government asked the National Assembly today to lift the Parliamentary immunity of Jean-Marie Le Pen, one of its most prominent Right-wing members.

Your otherwise excellent article of Dec. 1 on the book-price war conveys the impression that all authors profit from the practice of discounting. Unfortunately, this is true only of those who write best-sellers. Indeed, the authors of hundreds of other worth-while and important books suffer from the book-price war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's Government-controlled cotton crop would amount to 14,304,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A United States Trotting Association panel of 112 harness racing writers and broadcasters today voted Harlan Dean and Henry T. Adios the nation's best 3-year-old harness horses of 1961.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that the Hughes Tool Company could give Northeast Airlines, Inc., the emergency financial help it needed.
Employes who make mistakes persistently may not be inefficient but may just be trying subconsciously to get even with their bosses, a psychiatrist explained here yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., gained the women's singles final in the Victoria tennis tournament on the windswept courts of Kooyong Stadium today. However, she lost in women's and mixed doubles.

CANBERRA, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Voters began going to the polls early today to elect Australia's twenty-fourth Federal Parliament. Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies' Liberal-Country coalition was regarded as virtually certain of retaining power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The New Haven Railroad received Federal backing for a $7,500,000 loan today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush urged Congress today to refrain from any "piecemeal" revision of Federal patent laws.
Of forty original contestants for the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition, sixteen young pianists have been chosen to appear in the semi-finals.

LAST night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center brougt us two ballets in their first performances of the season. These were "Prodigal Son" (Prokofieff) and "Allegro Brillante" (Tchaikovsky), both choreographed by George Balanchine and both standard pieces in the repertory.
The New York Mets yesterday acquired another slightly aged though still highly capable player they expect to give their club stability when it makes its debut in the National League next year.
The New York Times has acquired a 49 per cent interest in the Gaspesia Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., which will build a newsprint mill in Chandler, Que.
FORT POLK, La., Dec. 7 -- ''It isn't fair" and "we want to go home" are the most common complaints voiced at Fort Polk by recently mobilized reservists and National Guardsmen.
BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- East German workmen erected red-and-white-striped customs barrier gates at the seven crossing points on the border between East and West Berlin today.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Suit will be filed Monday in Federal District Court, Newark, by a group of Negroes here to prevent the construction of a warehouse and executive offices just off Route 4 in Teaneck for the Garcia Corporation, a fishing tackle concern of New York.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Big Ten conference voted today to negotiate with the West Coast's Big Five for a Rose Bowl football contract. The vote was 6 to 4. The Big Ten thus is in the position of approaching the Big Five with hat in hand, making all the overtures for a new pact that heretofore had been made by the West Coast group.

The State Assembly's Committee on Ethics has chosen S. Stanley Kreutzer as counsel to investigate the charges of conflict of interest against Speaker Joseph F. Carlino. A lawyer of stern conscience, Mr. Kreutzer has become something of an authority on ethics in public office. He has been retained in this capacity by both state and city, by the Legislature and the City Council.

A new book by Alex Comfort, called "Darwin and the Naked Lady," will be issued on Jan. 10 by Braziller. It contains seven "discursive essays" on biology and art amid present human bafflement. The author attributes much of the trouble to two poles of human behavior -- "the hard center" (the scientist) and "the soft center" (the poet).
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., is planning its first major retail store acquisition since 1926 in a transaction valued at about $16,300,000.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Reports that Communist Hungary proposed to negotiate with the United States for the freedom of Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty drew severe comment today from Pope John XXIII on the "state of slavery" forced on many Roman Catholic bishops.

A BENEFIT showing of two model apartments will be held next week at 440 East Fifty-seventh Street. The interior decoration of the three and one-half and four and one-half room apartments is by Jay Dorf, who has used French and contemporary furnishings.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- British Government issues had a good day with gains of as much as 7s.6d ($1.05) on the stock exchange here today. The surge followed the favorable terms offered by the Treasury for re-conversion of the 4 1/2 per cent 1962 issue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, made a series of charges tonight against officials of a Belgian-controlled mining concern in the Congo's secessionist Katanga Province.

GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- The United States protectionist policies with respect to farm products have drawn sharp criticism again from member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Exporters of dairy products were the main critics of the import restrictions that the United States maintains to protect its farmers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Following is the offiical transcript of the news conference held today by Secretary of State Dean Rusk:
Justice Jacob Markowitz yesterday ordered a Supreme Court hearing to determine whether a policewoman should be eligible for promotion to sergeant.
New York University's basketball team, reported as being weak on defense in pre-season estimates, demonstrated last night that a strong offense can compensate for such a shortcoming.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, a style-setter in fashion, now has greeting card purchasers rushing for one holiday design sold only by the United Nations Children's Fund.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Dec. 8 -- The departure of Moroccan Jews by plane and ship will continue this month and next, according to reliable sources. Nearly 25,000 of the approximately 180,000 Moroccan Jews are expected to leave the country.
A Christmas sale for the blind is being held at the Shop for the Blind, 78 Chambers Street, at Broadway, weekdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.
We have noted with interest a letter published Nov. 27 concerning our recent advertisement.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Ward's Automotive Reports estimated today that car output in the United States this week would be 162,694 units and said that the industry built its 5,000,000th automobile of 1961 on Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors scored 78 points tonight, breaking the National Basketball Association scoring record, but the Warriors were beaten by the Los Angeles Lakers, 151 -- 147, in a triple-overtime contest before 4,022 at Convention Hall.

As ends go in pro football, Joe Walton of the New York Giants is something of an anomaly. He appears too small to fill a job on the attacking platoon, yet the 5-foot-11-inch wingman regards his lack of height as an asset.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Soviet ended its session today after three days of serious speeches by mechanically approving the Soviet state budget and economic plan for 1962.

AFTER years of disdain and neglect nineteenth century academic artists are suddenly kicking off their tombstones and are being received with approbation by advance guard taste. The "upgrading" of Gustave Moreau at the Museum of Modern Art is only the most conspicuous example of this renewed interest.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- The Republican leader of the State Senate proposed today that the Assembly consider censuring a Democratic member who has attacked Speaker Joseph F. Carlino if the charges were not upheld.

Dr. Robert M. Erdman will be the chief Government witness in the trial of State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh on a conspiracy charge involving a $35,000 bribe, a source close to the case said last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Kennedy Administration is deeply grateful to Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba for swearing fealty to Marxism-Leninism, Secretary of State Dean Rusk indicated today.
Utah State and Baylor will headline the action today in the Gotham Bowl as post-season college football makes its first big splurge, but there are five other bowl games on the schedule.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 8 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak protested today in two cables to U Thant, Acting Secretary General of the United Nations, against what he termed the word organization's war operations" in Katanga.

Events today: "Lucia di Lammermoor," 2 P.M., and Goetterdaemmerung," 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House; New York Philharmonic Josef Krips, conductor, Cargenie Hall, 8:30; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Town Hall, 3.
Universal Bible Sunday will be observed tomorrow in Protestant churches over the country.
MIAMI, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- A man jailed as a suspicious refugee from Cuba was identified today as an escaped mental patient who has been sought in the slaying of a family of five in Mineola, L.I.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Representatives of the United States and the Soviet Union conferred privately again today on the composition of a disarmament negotiating body. They were reported to have made "considerable progress" in clearing up their differences.

A number of Brooklyn Heights residents are trying to get the city to declare their neighborhood officially Old Brooklyn Heights -- a historic preserve similar, in their thinking, to Beacon Hill in Boston.

Most commodity futures traded on the New York exchanges declined yesterday in relatively light trading. Evening-up operations in the spot December deliveries and weekend adjustments dominated the activity.
New York, the entertainment capital of the nation, is finally staging a bowl football game today.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 8 -- The Dominican Republic's political crisis drifted today toward a break between the Government and the main opposition forces. Last-ditch efforts, urged strongly by United States officials here, averted the announcement of an end of negotiations. A mediator kept the talks alive.
For the fifth successive year Mayor Wagner has called on the Legislature to permit the city to assume control of tenements whose owners have refused to correct hazardous conditions.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Saturday, Dec. 9 -- Tanganyika became an independent sovereign state today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 -- Chile and Argentina share a closer resemblance to Western Europe than to most of the largely Indian or Mestizo Spanish-speaking nations to the north. They are highly literate, have temperate climates and relatively no race problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Alf M. Landon urged the non-Communist nations today to mobilize their military, economic and political forces and pool them in "the most powerful bloc the world has ever known."
BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 -- Hunter's Rock, Mrs. Henry Obre's versatile campaigner, will seek to add the Pimlico Cup to his laurels tomorrow at the Maryland Jockey Club course.
The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court refused yesterday to throw out a suit to bar the city from building the proposed Hartford Pavillion in Central Park.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- The French Government expressed today its disapproval of the United Nations' armed intervention in Katanga Province.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Staff members of the House committee responsible for laws dealing with labor-management relations have been told they will be dismissed if they are absent, even because of illness.
Whenever he can find a free evening, the head of a major men's clothing manufacturing company visits a school tucked away in an office building near Gramercy Park.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 80 cents a bale off to 45 cents up yesterday. The near December contract was weakest.
Charles A. Church of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was appointed yesterday as District Director of Internal Revenue for Manhattan. He will have the job of collecting $13,500,000,000 a year in Federal taxes.

TOWSON, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Five New York Negroes, who refused to leave a Maryland restaurant on U.S. 40 when the proprietor would not serve them, were convicted of trespassing and fined $100 each today in Baltimore County Circuit Court.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Liu Chang-sheng, vice president of the Trade Union Federation of Communist China, accused the West today of trying to spread what he described as lies and rumors to disrupt the unity of the Communist bloc.
The Air Force launched a thirty-two-foot rocket equipped with powerful flares early yesterday morning in an effort to locate precisely the Hawaiian Islands.
HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Coal miners and others out of work are going back to school to learn new trades under the Federal Government's pilot retraining program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Two powerful running backs, Ronny Bull of Ray Baylor, and Curtis McClinton of Kansas, are included on the twenty-four-man West squad named for the annual Shrine Football game at Kezar Stadium on Dec. 30.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday approved a report calling for sterner enforcement of more stringent rules affecting the recruiting and subsidization of athletes. This action marked the conclusion of its twenty-fourth annual schedule-making convention.

Bil and Cora Baird and their marionettes will make a fifteen-week tour of India, Afghanistan and Nepal starting next month. The trip is being sponsored by the State Department as part of the United States cultural exchange program.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 8 (AP) -- A mother, her three daughters and a son died today in a pre-dawn fire at their fashionable home in a Wilmington suburb. They were the family of Marshall Stephens, a sales executive of du Pont de Nemours Co.
Dr. John H. Fischer, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, was elected president of the college yesterday. He will assume his new duties July 1 as the sixth head of the college.
Signs of the season were much in evidence yesterday morning as 789 passengers embarked on the Christmas sailing of the Norwegian America liner Bergensfjord.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- The Chinese Communist party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao published today the text of President Kennedy's recent interview with Aleksei I. Adzuhdei, editor of the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia.
The city and the Artist-Tenants Association said yesterday they were pleased with a meeting that had been held to clarify their agreement to permit artists to live and work in lofts.
CARLSBAD, N.M., Dec. 9 -- The United States will attempt tomorrow for the first time to harness an atomic explosion for peaceful uses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A study of the recent Soviet nuclear test series has convinced the Atomic Energy Commission that the balance of nuclear power still favors the United States. The commission said tonight that Soviet scientists had made "substantialprogress" and gained "much useful information" in some fifty nuclear experiments.
The drive of the Museum of Modern Art for $25,000,000 to enlarge its plant and services appeared on the way to realization last week.
TORONTO, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored four second-period goals en route to a 9-2 victory over the Boston Bruins before a crowd of 13,274 tonight.

ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, Dec. 9 -- Sometimes during the terrifying days here there is an eerie feeling that you have seen this whole thing before, that it was not very pleasant the first time and perhaps it is about time they altered the script.

Premier Khrushchev's reference yesterday to nuclear super-bombs hanging over the heads of "imperialist aggressors" like a sword of Damocles recalled President Kennedy's use of a similar figure of speech in an address to the United Nations General Assembly Sept. 25.

THIS comparatively short history of the Russian theatre the only one I know of written directly in English. For all its modesty and because of its lack of dogmatism, it is a valuable book for those who love the stage.

District farmers received $773,468,000 for their tobacco crop through Dec. 2. This was an increase of more than 5 per cent above the sum received a year earlier. The distribution of this huge sum has given the district's economy a big lift. Receipts included sales on the old belt, middle belt, eastern North Carolina, South Carolina and border belts.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 9 -- A Pennsylvania program to develop local specialists to combat juvenile delinquency has been initiated by the State Office for Children and Youths of the Department of Public Welfare.
THE past year may be remembered in jazz annals as the year when John Coltrane, a tenor saxophonist, achieved the top-rank stature that his supporters had for some time felt was inevitable.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Three men with Jewish names have been sentenced in Leningrad to be shot for speculating in gold and foreign currency.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Since last July, three 25-foot fishing boats have slid down the ways into the water off Auki, on the island of Malaita in the Solomons group. Four cargo vessels are yet to be built, each constructed by twenty-four youthful trainees from the region under a program as unusual in character as it is significant for the future.

IN Mark Schorer's life of Sinclair Lewis he mentions an interview with John Marquand which appeared in Time magazine in 1949. The interviewer had referred to certain similarities between the two men as satirists, and Marquand was reported as saying, "I would hesitate to rank myself with Lewis; I don't think I have nearly the same stature.

The schools are forever challenged to teach "values." Publicly, educators often respond with such defensive smokescreens as "citizenship" or "character" education. In private conversation they are more likely to admit that such gimmicks are largely designed to ward off criticism.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Bowling Green and Western Michigan, the No. 1 and 2 teams in the Mid-American Conference, dominated the all-Conference team selected today.
UPPER BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 9 -- Morty Stone, like the perfect politician, is many things to many people.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday voiced publicly his opposition to J. Raymond Jones as the new leader of the New York County Democratic organization, often referred to as Tammany Hall.

Southwestern business was in full swing last week as Christmas shopping gained momentum, and many merchants were beginning to offer cautious hopes that 1961 might be a new record year. Sales were in better volume than a year ago.

THE editor of this volume asked forty distinguished naturalists -- the majority of them bird students -- to "describe one memorable experience about the discovery of a fascinating fact about nature." Thirty-six responded, and the result is a kind of anthology, though each piece was written to be published here for the first time.
Twenty-three hundred persons at a Waldorf-Astoria luncheon yesterday saw and heard a musical version of "Peter Pan" performed by children who will really "never grow up."

First place in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League will be at stake today when the New York Giants play the Philadelphia Eagles at Franklin Field in Philadelphia. Each team has won nine games and lost three.

Mr. Herberg represents an important strain in contemporary religious thinking which has its Protestant counterpart in Neo-Orthodoxy. This "party line" is forever trying to separate the scientific and the personal, the cosmological and the historical, the essential and the existential.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Congressional forces that made a reluctant Navy abandon construction of conventional submarines six years ago, are rallying once again. They are seeking to push the Navy into building a nuclear-powered surface fleet.

SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 4 -- Representatives of the Governments of El Salvador and the United States signed an agreement here today designed to further the health aspects of the Alliance for Progress program.

CONVENT, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Alumni and undergraduates of Yale and their friends from Morris, Essex and Somerset Counties will attend the twenty-fourth annual Yale Ball at the Morris County Golf Club here next Saturday. A buffet dinner will precede the dance.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Directors of the Rochester Transit Corporation announced today that they had approved a tentative agreement that will go before 600 striking bus drivers and mechanics for ratification tomorrow.
What seemed so strange to Mrs. Daniel B. Phelan was that in this country "you would pay an organization so that you could go out and work for nothing."

IF one may talk about an American literary Establishment -- a loaded and dangerous term -- then certainly Delmore Schwartz will have to be included in it. Although only 48, he has been for more than two decades a critic of notable vigor, a poet of great skill and an occasional writer of prose fiction.

Among a number of musical programs in branches of the New York Public Library this week, one tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street, will offer instrumental and vocal works by contemporary American composers.

THE American Broadcasting Company has done a disservice to itself. Its presentation on "Bus Stop" last Sunday of a drama called "A Lion Walks Among Us" was a disgraceful and contemptible flaunting of decency, an indescribably coarse glorification of vulgarity to win an easy rating.
Racist violence in McComb, Miss., was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Israel R. Margolies as "more truly subversive of democracy than any foreign ideology."

Total unemployment in Pennsylvania rose in November for the first time in four months. It was attributed to normal seasonal changes. The number of workers unemployed in mid-November was 374,000, an increase of 19,000 from the preceding month.

UP to the monastery in Bethlehem's brown hills long ago limped a sore-footed lion. Succored by St. Jerome, the lion became devoted to him, stayed on and was given the task of guarding a grazing ass. When the ass disappeared, however, the monks assumed he had eaten his charge and the lion had to perform the ass' duties as penance.

Plans for next year's twelfth annual Animal Kingdom Ball have been announced by Mrs. William Paul Hoffmann, general chairman. The fete, a dinner dance on Jan. 25 to be set in a winter forest decor at the Sheraton-East, will benefit the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
VALLETTA, Malta -- This island's tourist authorities are deep in plans to attract more visitors from Europe and North America in the coming year.

CONGRESSMEN, who backed or blocked various parts of the Administration's program during the first session of the Eighty-seventh Congress, have been away for over three months, mostly taking the pulse of public opinion in their home districts. Now they are returning to their Washington offices, in preparation for the second session of the Eighty-seventh Congress lying straight ahead.

ON Thursday night newsmen and film critics from all over the world will assemble with German brass and bigwigs in West Berlin to witness the world premiere of Stanley Kramer's "Judgment at Nuremberg." They will be in attendance at something more than the gala opening of a film: they will be spectators at another performance of Mr. Kramer's celebrated act of placing his head in the mouth of a lion.
