WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., White House aide and prize-winning Harvard historian, was introduced yesterday to an American Political Science Association meeting as "one-half of the faculty of Hickory Hill University."

Dr. Frank A. Calderone's attempt to save commuters the bother of traveling to Broadway for their entertainment has failed at his Mineola (L.I.) Theatre. The policy, which had been in effect since Sept. 29 at the 1,220-seat house, was cancelled after last night's fifth and final performance by the New York City Opera.
Trading in the over-the counter-market last week was active but erratic and no definite price trend developed.
A three-goal first period, and a defense that refused the right of way combined for a neat 3-2 victory by the Toronto Maple Leafs over the New York Rangers last night.

The statement of J. Clarence Davies, reported in your Dec. 1 issue, that the responsibility of the Housing and Redevelopment Board is to the needs of all the city's residents needs some clarification. It is strongly implied that neighborhood groups opposing any renewal projects of the board also by definition oppose the general welfare and, I suppose, by extension advocate the continuation of squalid housing.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 -- Steel mills reported that demand continued strong last week. For one mill, incoming orders in the last twelve days were the best since early 1959. The backlog of a second mill had nearly doubled in this period.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears packed all their scoring into the fourth quarter and dashed the Cleveland Browns' title hopes today with a 17-14 victory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today that possible injury to United States industry from President Kennedy's proposed new liberal trade policy had been "overstated and exaggerated."

A stagger system of cargo and passenger sailings started by the Grace Line experimentally this month may lead to a considerable improvement in port traffic, Wilfred J. McNeil, president of the line, said yesterday.

A brownstone at 158 East Sixty-fourth Street is the place to find one of the most attractive galleries and gallery owners in town, not to mention some of the best and most reasonably priced works of art, should such be on a Christmas shopper's list.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States endorsed tonight a decision of the United Nations to continue fighting in Katanga to carry out the Security Council orders.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- When the fourteenth Earl of Home, Her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, flew in this afternoon, his arrival received about the same amount of attention as that given a fading film star.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Charlie Conerly's deft and knowing hand guided the New York Giants today to at least a tie for the National Football League's Eastern Conference title.
It is a rare Music Forgotten Remembered Concert that does not have a pleasant surprise or two or four or more. Saturday evening's concert at the Metropolitan Museum was no exception.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Nevada State Athletic Commission, leader of a Western states revolt against the National Boxing Association, voted today to remain in the organization during the term of its president, Dr. Charles P. Larson of Tacoma, Wash. rather than withdraw immediately.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The new Arms Control and Disarmament Agency seems to be off to a bureaucratically slow, financially modest and politically uncertain start.
SAN DIEGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Jack Kemp led the San Diego Chargers to a 28-10 victory over the Buffalo Bills today in an American Football League game.

ARTUR RUBINSTEIN last night concluded his charity marathon at Carnegie Hall. Since this tenth recital, like each of the previous nine, attracted almost 3,000 persons, one can estimate that the pianist's feat raised almost one-eighth of a million dollars for causes close to his heart.

The cloud of steam and dust over the New Mexican desert yesterday, a few miles from Carlsbad, represented an experiment in peaceful progress, not in destruction. It came from an underground explosion only about one-fourth as violent as that over Hiroshima in 1945; and therefore could not compete with the open-air weapons of 100-megaton strength and more of which Mr. Khrushchev has been boasting.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- The Soviet Union has recalled its diplomatic mission from Albania and has ordered the closing of the Albanian Embassy in Moscow, Albanian sources reported today.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 10 -- Dan Gurney of Riverside, Calif., won the classic Nassau Trophy race today for the second year in a row. Driving an English Lotus XIX, he set an average-speed record for the event of 90.796 miles an hour. This bettered his 1960 record of 89.544 m.p.h.
An area inventory of the transport industry's potential value in the event of a national emergency was begun last week for the National Damage Assessment Center in Washington.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Chief United States Delegate, voiced confidence today that Communist China would be barred from admission to the United Nations at this session.
BY reviving Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera, a slight edge may have been taken off the "Ring" cycle, which starts with "Rheingold" next Saturday afternoon.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 10 -- New York City labor leaders promised today to back with money and picket lines the effort of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electricians to shorten the work week.

An assistant professor of English at Fordham University said yesterday that general college education too often "masquerades as liberal education" and produces "the vaguely informed mind rather than insight and perspective."

Billy Cannon staged the biggest one-man show in the two-year history of the American Football League yesterday as the Houston Oilers gained a 48-21 decision over the New York Titans at the Polo Grounds.
THE deal shown is one that fooled every expert who played it, in one of two ways.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Monday, Dec. 11 -- The streets of Jerusalem were wet and empty this morning.
The New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association has started a campaign to keep Vincent A.G. O'Connor in office as Commissioner of Marine and Aviation.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- Five young Somali officers made an unsuccessful attempt last night to seize command of an army unit at Hargeisa and take over local administration, Premier Abdi Rashid Shermarke said tonight.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $84,670,662,091. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 10 -- Joshua Nkomo, the African nationalist leader in Southern Rhodesia, said today that Britain should suspend the Constitution of Southern Rhodesia and called the colony's Prime Minister, Sir Edgar Whitehead, a "dictator."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 10 -- President Joaquin Balaguer announced today that he would not resign before the end of his term next August.

The House of Representatives will be the decisive battleground next year on issues of fundamental importance to national progress. The vulnerability of its members to local pressures is sure to make the House a special concentration point for protectionist efforts to block President Kennedy's challenging program for liberalized foreign trade.
Mayor Wagner's office announced yesterday the reappointment of Dr. Ray E. Trussell as Commissioner of Hospitals, but acceded to his request that he not serve beyond July 1, 1963.
The delegate assembly of the United Parents Associations has called for the abolition of the city's local school boards or their relegation to advisory bodies to the Board of Education.

The nation's farmers may be understating their combined income by substantial amounts leach year, according to an estimate by the Internal Revenue Service. If this is correct, the Government may be losing many millions of dollars in tax revenues.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Ch. Evening Star de Luchar, a Skye terrier, received an early birthday gift today.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Dec. 10 -- King Mahendra restored today the fundamental rights in Nepal that he suspended a year ago.

Opinions may vary on the general "image" presented abroad by the United States. But there seems little doubt that in the area of intensified trade promotion this country has been showing definite professional polish.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 10 -- Members of the Katanga Youth Organization stoned the United States Consulate and the American Methodist mission here today. No one was injured but most of the windows in the consulate were broken.
Nine settlement houses in eight Manhattan and Brooklyn areas will start a three-year project to prevent juvenile delinquency by working with pre-teen-agers who might otherwise drift into youth gangs.
The problem of homosexuality in women is increasing, a psychologist said here yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- An authoritative informant said today that a master defense plan for Katanga Province of the Congo had fallen into United Nations possession. The plan was drawn up by a "general staff" of French mercenaries, the informant said.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, Dec. 10 -- The Government of newly independent Tanganyika is worried lest the terms of financial aid offered by the United States be too strict.

Richard Cardinal Cushing of Boston made a plea over the week-end to keep "modern pagans" from taking Christmas away from Christians. And a columnist for his archdiocesan newspaper asked parishioners this year to "cut Christmas back" to its religious essentials and curtail the current "emotional binge."

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The president of the nation's largest farm organization said today failures of Kennedy Administration programs had caused most farmers to lose any enthusiasm they might have held earlier for Government controls.
Sammy Baugh, the head coach of the Titans, said yesterday: "I wish this guy who blames us coaches would fire us."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- On the wall of an office at the Samuel Goldwyn Studio is an extraordinary device for making movies. It is a large sheet of graph paper with bars of different colors drawn across its sections.
Moore-McCormack Lines has announced that its luxury liners Argentina and Brasil will make twenty-four cruises between February and December, 1962.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 10 -- Belgian university students registered their disapproval of United States policy in support of the United Nations action in the Congo by throwing stones and pieces of metal at the United States Embassy and at Brussels police guards today.
The New York County Democratic organization will begin voting today on rules to reform its procedures.

The cotton futures market started out firmly last week but ended the week in lower ground. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 19 points (25 to 95 cents a bale) lower than a week earlier.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10 -- Yale University announced today the receipt of an anonymous gift of $500,000 to endow a new professorship in honor of Dr. Charles Seymour, historian who served as Yale's president from 1937 until his retirement in 1950.
ALGIERS, Dec. 10 -- A new underground group professing to support President de Gaulle declared today a "clandestine war" on the Secret Army Organization.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Frank S. Giles, head of the state police, said today he had evidence that Boston policemen had received pay-offs.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Monday, Dec. 11 -- Adolf Eichmann was convicted this morning of crimes against the Jewish people, crimes against humanity, war crimes and membership in hostile Nazi organizations.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- Albert John Luthuli of South Africa received the 1960 Nobel Peace Prize in Oslo today and said he was accepting the prize as an honor to the "freedom-loving people" both of his country and the entire African continent.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Earl of Home, the Foreign Secretary, called today for an immediate cease-fire in the Congo.
The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken of Riverside Church urged the nation's leaders yesterday to take "calculated risks" for peace.
GROSSINGER, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Darlene Sechanic of Jersey City and Bob McCarthy of New York won the senior championships at the Tri-State indoor speed-skating meet today.

The fiftieth annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases began officially yesterday, meeting with the same generosity that readers have shown every Christmastime since the fund started in 1912.
British, pound sterling and Canadian dollar showed a firmer undertone in foreign exchange dealings last week. Business turnover was very active at times.

The winter season is now in full swing and socially prominent women are appearing at charity balls wearing their selections from the fall collections. These trends were noted at two recent fetes -- the P.A.L. and Imperial Balls. The simply cut, floor-length gown in an opulent fabric is the overwhelming choice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The facts of life make it necessary that the Administration's "liberal" foreign trade program embrace some concessions to "protectionism."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Bobby Layne threw four touchdown passes and sent the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 30-14 victory over the Washington Redskins before 21,134 fans today.
Richard Dyer of the Salle Csiszar won the George Piller Memorial international saber tournament yesterday at the New York Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that he believed Senator Barry Goldwater could swing the South's 1964 Presidential vote under either party's banner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In the fall of 1956, a letter arrived at the Atomic Energy Commission headquarters here from three scientists at the Livermore Laboratory in California. The letter contained a radical, imaginative and, in the opinion of many at the time, a far-fetched proposal.
Investments in New York apartment property face a bright future, according to one of the city's leading realty investors.
Seaboard World Airlines plans to use only turbine planes on its scheduled trans-Atlantic services starting next month.
DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Dick Lane set up the Lions' first 10 points with a blocked kick and pass interception and Detroit went on to a 13-7 victory over the Minnesota Vikings today.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Ralph Backstrom, the center, scored twice in the third period tonight to give the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 victory over the last-place Boston Bruins.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 10 -- President Kennedy's trip to Venezuela and Colombia will be the first of several Latin-American visits. Their immediate purpose is to help start the nebulous Alliance for Progress by focusing attention on governments willing to qualify for aid by reform programs.

A.M. Sonnabend, Boston financier, is prepared to take an active part in the management of the Firth Carpet Company if a group of dissident stockholders are successful in blocking a proposed merger with Mohasco Industries, Inc., it was learned over the week-end.

American Airlines has recommended reducing the spread between first-class and coach fares on transcontinental flights from $40 to about $25. It also proposed proportionate reductions in the differential for other flights of more than 1,200 miles.

SOMEWHERE in Ontario, well north of Toronto and the thickly populated area but south of the true wilderness of the Subarctic, there is a pond. There is nothing special about this particular pond. The larger animals -- moose, caribou, bear and wolf -- are not to be found upon its shores. It is not a scenic beauty spot.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Army and New York University have devised a new electronic device that counts and measures raindrops.

The unmarried New Yorker, for forty-eight weeks of each year, is self-sufficient and self-supporting. The career girl and the bachelor inhabit a daytime world of deadlines and accounts, an after-hours world of little dinners, two-on-the-aisle and supper later, concerts and lectures when one is in the mood, the corner bistro when one is not.
Although "nobody knows the score" yet on rheumatoid arthritis and related diseases -- as one scientist put it last week -- authorities agree that a "really important discovery" in this field is near.

GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- The Swiss stock markets churned for a good part of last week after having pushed the stock index for domestic issues to a new peak for the week before. Despite the indecision, volume was again at a high level.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- East German Communist authorities confirmed today the fatal shooting of a West Berlin student and the capture of two other youths who were members of underground teams organized to help East Germans escape across the border barriers into West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A big commercial fish catch is indicated for 1961, the Department of the Interior reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Federal Communications Commission played an extraordinary role in the lengthy maneuvers that ended last week, in assuring educational television for the New York metropolitan area.

A theatre party has been arranged for the Dec. 20 evening performance of "Subways Are for Sleeping" at the St. James Theatre. The Cuban Refugee Emergency Appeal of the International Rescue Committee will receive the proceeds.

The New York State Association of Plaintiffs" Trial Lawyers has urged the Government to "denounce'; the Warsaw Convention, a treaty that regulates .airline liability toward passengers in international air transport.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Britons with a sense of history and plenty of cash will be given an opportunity beginning this week to do what their ancestors did more than 100 years ago.

A program of choral music in keeping with the season was offered in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon by the Welch Chorale of St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church, 3025 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. James B. Welch conducted the group of thirty-four singers in an extended group of chansons, motets and mass movements by Orlando di Lasso and a selection of carols from around the world.
Grants for faculty research at the colleges of the City University of New York totaled $808,535 in 1960-61, the Board of Higher Education reported yesterday.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Gene Fullmer, the National Boxing Association middleweight champion, proposed tonight that Paul Pender delay his scheduled rematch with Terry Downes and permit Fullmer to fight the Briton for full possession of the world 160-pound title.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- George Knudson shot a 66 today and won the $20,000 Coral Gables open golf tournament by a stroke.

Two singers, both already known for their work with the New York City Opera, will make their Metropolitan Opera debuts during the company's ninth week, which begins next Monday. John Alexander, tenor, will sing the role of Ferrando in Mozart's "Cosi fan Tutte" on Tuesday.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People stepped into the fight over bargaining representation for the city's 45,000 teachers yesterday. It gave full backing to the American Federation of Teachers and its New York affiliate, the United Federation of Teachers.

Steve Allen announced yesterday he had asked the American Broadcasting Company to release him from his television contract Dec. 31, three months ahead of schedule. The network said it would make "every effort to comply."

Visiting craftsmen from the London theatre yesterday gave their views on "The English Stage -- New Directions?" at a luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk. The symposium was held in The Playbill Restaurant.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 65 cents a bale up to $1 off yesterday, with the far months showing the most weakness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Federal Aviation Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby may face charges of "careless" aircraft operation.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Japan hopes to win sixty-three medals, twenty-five of them gold, at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. This was made known today in a "white paper" released by the Olympic committee for training and strengthening of Japanese athletes.
City Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix acted yesterday to avert a threatened strike of 9,000 New York electrical workers on New Year's Day.
The City University will ask the Legislature for $6,300,000 to begin its doctoral offerings next year, Dr. Mina S. Rees, Dean of Graduate Studies, announced yesterday.

The relationship of the Anglo-Newfoundland Development Company, Ltd., and Price Brothers Company, Ltd., was incorrectly identified in an article in Saturday's editions concerning the acquisition by The New York Times of a 49 per cent interest in the Gaspesia Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., a subsidiary of Anglo-Newfoundland.
The Martin-Marietta Company has received a $12,144,777 Air Force contract for research and development of the Titan II missile program.

HILLSIDE, N.J., Dec. 11 -- The $82.50-a-week cashier of small loan company here fessed today, according to police, that she had been bezzling about $200 a day years. The total, the police came to $185,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Treasury's key short-term bill rate receded in today's sale of the regular weekly issues, after a strong five-week advance. It remained well above the level that prevailed until early November, however, and the Government's financial authorities believe that it should continue in the higher range.
OSLO, Norway, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from a speech by Albert Luthuli, Nobel Peace Prize winner for 1960, at a dinner in his honor here tonight.
The nation's retail stores rang up record sales in November, with a 3 per cent increase from the October level, the Department of Commerce reported yesterday.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 11 -- Albert John Luthuli characterized South Africa today as "a museum piece in our time, a hangover from the dark past of mankind, a relic of an age which everywhere else is dead or dying."
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Vice presidents of two of the nation's largest optical concerns were re-indicted in United States District Court today on price fixing charges.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Two officials of the Ford Motor Company were elected today to head the Philco Corporation as Ford took over control of the Philadelphia electronics concern.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A housewife who served for nine years as a counterspy for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today she thought there was "considerable" Communist infiltration in American churches.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 11 -- Dr. Martin Luther King told organized labor today that it had "not adequately used its great power, its vision and resources to advance Negro rights."
The builders of the Bankers Trust Building rising on the west side of Park Avenue betwen Forty-eighth and Forty- ninth Streets are taking no chances with bad luck.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to look into antitrust law charges by The Tri-City Herald, of Kennewick, Wash., against the Columbia Basin Publishers, The International Typographical Union and others.

General Davidson, who commands the United States Seventh Army in Germany and has a stomach as flat as the parade ground of his West Point, recently let it be known that the corpulent soldier must disappear from his command.

The "night people" may now take advantage of an opportunity to learn how to bowl. Those persons who don't want to sleep, or just can't, now may spend their time acquiring the proper approach, the proper grip and the proper way of making spares.

In reading the provocative editorial "Legislative Ethics" published in The New York Times on Dec. 2, I was reminded of the intelligent and well developed practices on conflicts of interest that prevail in the British House of Commons.
The injection of "sectarian issues" into the teachers' collective bargaining campaign was criticized yesterday by the Catholic Teachers Association of the Diocese of Broooklyn.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 11 -- The restoration of a three and one-half mile strip of storm-ravaged dunes on Fire Island was approved today by the Suffolk Board of Supervisors.

Lloyd's Register of Shipping, universally acclaimed as a purveyor of vital ship information, has informed ship historians and librarians on both sides of the Alantic that "some of our volumes are missing."

Undefeated Billy Daniels of Brooklyn scored a technical knockout over Don Warner of Philadelphia last night at 1 minute 49 seconds of the third round of a scheduled ten-round bout at St. Nicholas Arena.

It should not be assumed that the United Nations cannot make progress without the approval of the Soviet bloc, Richard N. Gardner, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said last night at the Harvard Club.

The Republic Corporation, a diversified industrial concern with headquarters in Los Angeles, announced yesterday the election of Gordon K. Greenfield as president and William Zeckendorf as chairman of the executive committee.

Big stocks took the lead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The two biggest, General Motors and American Telephone and Telegraph, made historic highs and the third, Standard Oil of New Jersey, gained a point in an almost general advance of the more substantial oils.

Saying that he had "no intention of getting involved in calls made by officials," Allie Sherman, the coach of the New York Giants, began to map plans yesterday for the key game with the Cleveland Browns at Yankee Stadium Sunday.

The Dominican situation has reached a point of considerable danger for the unhappy republic and therefore for all of us. The negotiations between the civilian Opposition groups and the armed forces backed by neo-Trujillo elements have broken down. A variation of a military dictatorship led by General Rodriguez Echevarria, using President Balaguer as a helpless figurehead, is now threatened.

Consolidated net income of the Seaboard Finance Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 rose to $6,610,451 from $4,416,616 in the preceding fiscal year, A.E. Weidman, president, disclosed in the annual report released for publication today.
In your News of the Week for Nov. 26 I note that you refer to the President of Nicaragua, Luis A. Somoza, as "dictator."

FARMINGDALE, L.L, Dec. 11 -- Robert Frost says that "poetry is what disappears in translation." Another poet, John Ciardi, lost nothing in translation here today as he read some of his work for a group of poets who happen to be only 8 and 9 years old.
THE melting pot that is America absorbed scores of ethnic groups, which it then disgorged as look-alike, dress-alike, one-tongued Americans.
A man and a youth were wounded in Brooklyn yesterday in what the police described as a new outburst of underworld warfare involving the Gallo gang. The youth was a bystander.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today a decision that the Secretary of Labor can inspect union records under the 1959 labor law even when no violation is indicated.

One of the most disturbing developments in the economy in the last year or so has been the persistent high rate of unemployment. But there are signs that things are improving in this respect. The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, for one, has seen the signs and reports on them in its latest survey, Business Conditions, released yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Fourteen nations have called on the Arab states and Israel to settle their longstanding quarrels, including the Palestine refugee dispute.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Louis Armstrong, the band leader, was named a defendant today in a $11,500,000 damage suit filed by a Las Vegas hotel and Harold Minsky, stage show producer.

Regarding your editorial of Dec. 4 supporting the construction of fallout shelters: I am disturbed that you can reach the conclusion you do on the basis of evidence at hand. Many basic questions are left unanswered by your editorial and by most other public pronouncements on the subject.

As a layman whose knowledge of the necessities of building design is admittedly limited, but whose sense of housing value has been sharpened by the need to find a middle-income apartment in the city, let me support the claim made by the anonymous architect for the New York City Housing Authority in his Nov. 30 letter.
Almost every weekday, as the earth's rotation brings the meridian of Texas into line with the sun, powerful radar signals jab across the intervening space and bounce off the sun's corona.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Stockholders of the Argo Oil Company met again today to vote on the sale of the company to the Atlantic Refining Corporation but recessed because officials lacked a tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service.

UNITED NATION, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee unanimously approved today a resolution calling on the Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space to meet by March 31 to begin discussing world cooperation in that field.
Flint, Mich., announced plans yesterday for the sale of $6,950,000 of sewer bonds due serially from 1963 to 1991.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 11 (AP) -- With Oscar Robertson scoring 32 points and also leading his team in rebounds and assists, the Cincinnati Royals defeated the Chicago Packers, 133 -- 117, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The Berlin crisis caused some panic buying of food and other supplies by shoppers in the Soviet-bloc countries, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe disclosed today.
This week marks the close of showings of American collections for spring. The clothes will be in stores across the country by the first of the year.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 11 -- A $65,000,000 plan to redevelop the Brick Church business district of East Orange will be unfolded to city officials tomorrow at the Suburban Hotel here.
The stories of the Neediest Cases reported on Sunday brought immediate responses yesterday.
Trading in copper futures led the activity on commodity exchanges here yesterday, spurred by news from Katanga Province in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A Presidential emergency board established to avert a pilot strike against Pan American World Airways said today that it could not recommend a settlement because the controversy was too vast.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Terry Downes of Britain said today he was interested in defending his share of the world middleweight title against Gene Fullmer instead of Paul Pender. In Boston, Pender said he wouldn't step aside.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 11 -- Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, the mining company accused of having helped President Moise Tshombe maintain his defiance of the Congolese Government and the United Nations, is the source of approximately $52,000,000 a year to secessionist Katanga Province's government.
A lawyer who had been appointed a receiver to rectify slum conditions in six tenements moved yesterday in Supreme Court to be discharged of his responsibilities.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The flattening of the economic boom in Western Europe was confirmed by new figures today, but there remains little evidence that a recession is setting in.
The Dialogues of Titans, New York's permanent floating rap game, took an intellectual turn last night, moving into the realm of loyalty, ego, character and trust.

AS Christmas is coming and the art is getting thin, a number of shows can perhaps be best dealt with in brief reviews. Apart from Fred Farr's drawings and some of his horses and occasional moments in other exhibitions, I saw nothing that even slightly provoked me to take off and wave my hat.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The National Fire Protection Association reported tonight that fast-burning ceiling tile was the principal reason for the loss of sixteen lives in last Friday's Hartford Hospital fire.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Oil shares and South African gold minings rallied strongly in the stock market here today, but industrials remained indecisive.

An $11,000,000 program to convert the 7,000 Teletypewriter stations in New York State from manual to dial operation has been started by the New York Telephone Company. The conversion will be made by next September.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson, the former world heavyweight champion, will start a comeback Jan. 12 or Feb. 2 here against Joe Bygraves, a former British Empire champion. It will be Johansson's first start since he was knocked out by Floyd Patterson in Miami Beach last March in their third title fight.
DEL SHOFNER and Y.A. Tittle are room-mates. When the Giants assembled for a steak breakfast just before their important game with the Eagles in Philadelphia on Sunday, Shofner looked a mite peaked.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 11 -- Argentine train service was returning to normal today following the end of the forty-two day nation-wide strike.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 11 -The State Department has taken the side of the Soviet Union in its ten-year dispute with Glen Cove over a tax exemption.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Herberto Hinojosa rode three winners at Tropical Park today, including a four-length victory aboard Primon in the feature race.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- West Germany is prepared to accept the elimination of all quotas on wheat imports from other members of the European Economic Community, or Common Market, but will seek the retention of quotas on imports countries outside the Common Market.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Supreme Court unanimously struck down today a non-Communist oath required of all public employes in Florida.
Twelve Columbia College undergraduates have formed a scientific research corporation that already has produced three devices for possible public use.
"The Anvil," a play by Julia Davis, based on the trial of the militant abolitionist, John Brown, will be produced and staged by Charles Wood at an off-Broadway theatre in March or April.
New labor contracts for 200 ship pursers aboard vessels of several of the country's major passenger and dry cargo lines were announced yesterday by the Staff Officers Association of America.

The other day the president of one of the nation's largest corporations rose before an audience of 250 at the Waldorf Astoria's Starlight Roof and, in an atmosphere of deep solemnity, presented a scroll to a cow.

MADRID, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Three Senators among a group of United States Air Force Reserve officers on an active duty tour of Europe today called the three United States air bases in Spain "among the most important we have."
Thirty Morningside residents sued in Supreme Court yesterday to block the sale of the St. Luke's Women's Hospital site to the Consolidated Edison Company for construction of a power plant.

Hoping to bolster a club that has won only eight games in twenty-six National Basketball Association starts, the New York Knickerbockers have purchased Al Butler from the Boston Celtics, the Eastern Division leaders.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 11 -- Down at the Nassau Yacht Haven more than 100 charter fishing boats are riding at anchor. It is 8 in the morning and on every deck the mates and the captains are setting up their gear, taking food and beverages aboard and welcoming their sportsman passengers of the day.

The automated train that has raised the threat of a strike against all subway and bus lines in the city was put through its paces in a press preview yesterday.

Warren Spahn, the indefatigable and practically indestructible southpaw of the Milwaukee Braves, walked off with just about everything in sight in the National League, according to the official pitching averages released yesterday.

A SCANT six years ago in The Netherlands, Magda Boon planned her daughter Krista's first Christmas. Eager to pass on the colorful Central European traditions of her own childhood, Mrs. Boon designed a series of individual, elfin creatures, cut them out of lightweight plywood and painted them in brilliant hues.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 12 -- Portuguese authorities announced tonight that they would evacuate women and children from Goa, which is thought to be threatened with imminent attack from India.
BUFFALO, Dec. 12 -- Mayor-elect Chester Kowal has named Howard E. Finney, a deputy inspector in the New York City Police Department, to become Buffalo's police commissioner Jan. 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- A United States spokesman predicted today that the General Assembly, after taking a Christmas recess, would reconvene Jan. 15.
HAZARD, Ky., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Four miners were caught under falling earth in a truck mine near here today and authorities said it appeared there was no hope any would be found alive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Rev. David Andrews, 37-year-old North Carolina Methodist minister, knelt today in front of the White House, seeking clemency for Morton Sobell, who is in prison.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The North Atlantic treaty forces are in their most vigorous condition in many years on the eve of annual meetings of organization's foreign and defense ministers here. This is largely the result of Premier Khrushchev's pressure on Berlin, qualified sources said.

Opportunity just about wore itself out knocking on the door of the New York Knickerbockers at the Garden last night. The repeated failure of the Knicks to make the proper response led to their fifth straight defeat.
The busy and rugged Gene Fullmer, who owns a portion of the world middleweight championship, was named yesterday to receive the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque as the fighter of the year.
Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, arrived here last night in his new role as matchmaker for the recently formed United World Enterprises, Inc., of Los Angeles.

Stockholders of the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pittsburgh, Pa., will bet asked on Jan. 30 to approve a two and one-half-for-one split of the bank's stock. The plan must be approved also by the Controller of the Currency.
New York City will officially open the Christmas season tomorrow with the lighting of twenty-six trees in various boroughs at 5 P.M., Newbold Morris, Commissioner of Parks, announced yesterday.

The $10,000,000-a-month deficit the United Nations is incurring in dealing with disorders in the former Belgian Congo is forcing the world organization to become a borrower. A plan to raise $200,000,000 to tide the U.N. over the next six months is now under consideration. The money would be raised by the sale of United Nations bonds.
The city administration unexpectedly indicated reluctance yesterday to go all-out for establishing $1.25 or $1.50 an hour as a city minimum wage.
HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -The University of Houston hired Bill Yeoman, Michigan State backfield coach, today as head football coach for the Cougars.
Robert Moses, a nice kind man -- according to 9-year-old Robert Selwyn of Queens -was absentee host yesterday to a group of school children interested in Mr. Moses' World's Fair.
Copper and cocoa futures prices declined in heavy trading here yesterday. Domestic sugar advanced on a good volume.
Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, rolled up new records in sales and earnings from operations.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 12 -- In size, population, wealth and logic Brazil is the most important nation in South America and, by the end of this century, could well be one of the world's major powers. Because of this one might suppose Brazil to be the most eligible country for aid under our Alliance for Progress.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from today's reading of the judgment in the trial of Adolf Eichmann.

Coach Joe Lapchick of St. John's University may not miss Tony Jackson as much as he had expected. Last night his talented Redmen defeated the University of Oklahoma quintet, 68 -- 49, for their second consecutive triumph.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 -West German newspapers were unanimous today in approving the verdict against Adolf Eichmann by an Israeli court yesterday. None of the lengthy editorials devoted to the proceedings in Jerusalem registered surprise over the judges' findings.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations build-up in Elisabethville continued today with the arrival of 216 Swedish troops.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 35 cents a bale off to 30 cents up yesterday.

ATHENS. THE Athenian strode through his marble-floored, glass-walled living room, past the Indian goddess carving, the Byzantine icon and the Italian modern chairs. He drew back the pumpkin-colored draperies.
Fog covered the metropolitan area last night, disrupting air travel and slowing highway traffic.
The world champion Yankees may be faced with a record payroll, one that could go well over $700,000. But their salary troubles with one problem child could be over within a matter of a few hours.
Following is the text of a Soviet note to the United States on charges against Gen. Adolf Heusinger, as made public in English yesterday by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

The trait of hero worship has given rise to a vast and fast-growing industry in this country. Some $500,000,000 is spent each year by advertisers to exploit famous names and faces. Thus, Roger Maris, the New York Yankees' home run hitter, will earn more than $100,000 this year by lending his name to a variety of products.

Contracts are being drawn for William Bendix to star in "General Seeger." He will depict the title role in Ira Levin's drama concerning a major general who is in conflict with his superiors. Mr. Bendix was last seen here toward the end of the run of "Take Me Along" when he went on as Jackie Gleason's replacement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- President Kennedy's week-end trip to Venezuela and Colombia will cover about 6,370 miles by plane, helicopter and auto. The President will make half a dozen speeches.
The third annual Marymount Dance will be held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 29 for the benefit of Marymount Junior College in Arlington, Va.

The Christmas Ball will be held at the Sheraton-East on Dec. 22. Lt is the largest of the three subscription dances held each year under the direction of Mrs. Audrey Winston for post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples.
TWICKENHAM, England, Dec. 12 -- Favored Cambridge broke loose late in the second half and posted a 9-3 Rugby victory over Oxford before 60,000 fans today.
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two hundred and sixty-seven young Negroes were arrested while marching and singing through the downtown area today.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday revoked the license of Herman (Hymie the Mink) Wallman as a manager and second and fined him $5,000 for paying gratuities to a commission boxing judge.

The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France, meeting in Paris, have made a contribution toward a settlement of the Congo problem by agreeing to seek a "united and peaceful Congo." The agreement on a united Congo dashes any hope President Tshombe may have had of obtaining recognition of Katanga as a separate and independent state.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 12 -- Belgium's Foreign Minister, Paul-Henri Spaak, urged today that the United Nations conclude an immediate cease-fire with Katanga authorities and develop a policy of conciliation.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Virtually no security information has appeared in the press since President Kennedy spoke on the subject last April, the White House said today.

The New York Titans signed a player yesterday. During the confusion of the feud between Sammy Baugh, the coach, and Harry Wismer, the owner, the Titan obtained Lawrence McHugh, a 238-pound offense guard.

The New York City Ballet last night opened the second week of its season at the City Center. The program consisted entirely of repetitions from the the previous week. These were "Swan Lake," with Patricia Wilde and Jonathan Wilde, "Interplay," excerpts from the Balanchine-Webern "Episodes," and "Western Symphony."
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Small gains outnumbered falls in most groups in quiet trading on the stock exchange here today.
A Portuguese Government spokesman charged yesterday that four American Methodist missionaries aided "terrorist groups" in Angola seeking to make the Portuguese African province independent.
SANDY HOOK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- Government scientists reported today they had caught 311 sharks between Aug. 13 and Oct. 13 off the Jersey and Long Island coasts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Mrs. John F. Kennedy will appear early next year on a network television program originating from the White House.
Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said yesterday he would not accept an invitation from the City Council of Newburgh to explain his new public welfare program there.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Union protested to Denmark today over the Danish Parliament's accept ance of a North Atlantic Treaty Organization plan for joint military command with West Germany in the Baltic.

Mayor Wagner has given further proof of his determination to serve as the state's real Democratic leader by informing Democratic members of Congress that he is interested in their vote on a new majority leader for the House of Representatives.
ALGIERS, Dec. 12 -- European civilians in an auto fired submachine guns and tossed hand grenades at two men in another car in Algiers today.

" It was a great mistake," Representative Albert Rains Democrat of Alabama, said yesterday in discussing the Federal Reserve Board's recent increase in interest rate ceilings on commercial bank savings deposits.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Union's debt to the United Nations was put today at $41,271,180.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Government and five western oil companies have agreed on some "principal provisions" in talks here on the future of Indonesia's petroleum industry the Government has announced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- The ultra-conservative movement, as represented by the John Birch Society and the Minutemen, constitutes a grave danger to the Republican party, Senator Jacob K. Javits told a luncheon meeting of the Bay Area Republican Alliance today.

The ten-point program of revision of public welfare policy promulgated by Secretary Ribicoff is a good step. He sees it as a "hard-head and compassionate-heart approach," and we can detect in the outline no departure from that spirit. The Secretary is unyielding in his distaste for the inhumane Newburgh code of welfare "reform." He regards the Newburgh approach as "demagogic" and one that will "solve nothing."
Frank Boucher, a former National Hockey League all-star center and twice coach of the New York Rangers, yesterday was selected to receive the Sportsmanship Brotherhood's annual award.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 12 -- James J. Kelly, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was named Nassau County Police Commissioner today. He will assume office Jan. 1.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, youngest brother of the former President, is being vigorously urged by Republican leaders of Maryland to run for the Senate next year.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 12 -- Events leading to the death of a 4-year-old boy in Coram last week are being investigated by the Suffolk County Medical Society.
Directors of National Airlines and of Continental Airlines announced yesterday a plan to merge their systems into a new one that would be called National-Continental Airlines, Inc.

A tally of mail ballots cast by employes of the Consolidated Edison Company on a new contract proposal will be made today following an order issued yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich.

A $15,000,000 contract to design and manage installation of a missile test range on the island of Sardinia has been received by Vitroselenia, an Italian electronics company. The company is jointly owned by the Vitro Corporation of America and Selenia, S.p.A., a Raytheon Company subsidiary.

Any trip by a President (or, as Richard Nixon found in 1958, a Vice President) of the United States to Latin America contains certain risks. President Kennedy's trip to Venezuela and Colombia next Saturday and Sunday has the merit of containing as few foreseeable risks as possible.

Seven hundred thirty faculty members of more than twenty New York institutions of higher learning have joined a Boston academic statement opposing fall-out shelters and urging a "positive program for peace with freedom."

Swift Co., the world's largest meat packer, achieved record sales of $2,488,980,885, in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28, an increase of $46,638,728 from the preceding year's volume. Earnings, however, declined by $6,363,079, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The United States and others may be confronted with a new set of Common Market tariff rates much sooner than expected.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -The major United States airlines are losing $30,000,000 on their operations within the country this year, the Air Transport Association estimated today.
Governor Rockefeller moved last night to spike rumors that he might not run for re-election. He scheduled a top-level Republican conference at Albany to plan campaign strategy for next year.
Hope of averting a strike by 9,000 electricians in the city was lessened yesterday when industry spokesmen repeated their rejection of union contract demands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The first public push for a broader Federal mass transit effort came today as the American Municipal Association and allied groups endorsed a five-year $1,750,000,000 program for submission to Congress next year.
Blyth Co., Inc., placed on the market yesterday common shares of Pacific Lighting Corporation valued at nearly $36,000,000. The offering price for the 600,000 shares was $59.75 each.

Student campaigns to revive football spring up periodically at Fordham, New York University and other colleges that dropped the sport when the financial burden of trying to compete on the "big time" level became too heavy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals upheld by a split decision today a Civil Aeronautics Board ruling that permits Northeast Airlines to obtain emergency financial aid from the Hughes Tool Company.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- The Japanese police were carrying out a nation-wide search today to make sure that they had stamped out a plot by Right-wing fanatics to assassinate the top leaders of the conservative Government.
Fourteen associations representing freight forwarder, railroad and trucking interests have protested proposals by the Post office Department to raise the maximum size and weight of parcel post.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Controller Arthur Levitt challenged Mayor Wagner today to deny him a place on the Democratic state ticket next fall.

ANY composer who writes a symphony around the first eight chapters of Genesis is (a) a brave man and (b) asking for trouble. A cosmic subject needs a cosmic approach, especially when accompanied by the program notes that the composer in this case, Richard Yardumian, has supplied.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 12 -- A formula for ending the civil rights controversy between Negroes and leaders of the merged labor movement fell apart today with each side accusing the other of broken promises.

The C.R.D. Realty Company has bought the former Cornell-Dubilier plant on Hamilton Boulevard in South Plainfield, N.J., for development as an industrial terminal. The deal was for cash. The property consists of eleven buildings with a total of 273,000 square feet of space and thirty acres of land. It is served by the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

Allan P. Kirby has moved one step closer to a proxy contest to recover control of the Alleghany Corporation, the big holding company, which he lost last spring to the Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex.

The stories of The New York Times Neediest Cases have reminded many readers of their own contrasting good fortune. Some were among the 442 contributors who sent in a total of $11,287.46 in gifts to the appeal yesterday.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 12 -- What are they like, the white soldiers fighting in Katanga's army?

HARTFORD, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Officials announced today that a 41-year-old janitor at Hartford Hospital, where a fire Friday caused sixteen deaths, had been committed to a mental institution after questioning.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Fresh Katangese troops moved in from the north today to bolster the Elisabethville garrison fighting United Nations forces.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the United States arrest Gen. Adolf Heusinger of West Germany and hand him over to Moscow for trial as a war criminal.
I am unpleasantly surprised to read your Dec. 3 editorial "Sukarno on a Rampage."

DALLAS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Edwin A. Walker, who resigned from the Army as a major general after a dispute over the way he indoctrinated his troops, said tonight he has never seen an Army with "less purpose and mission" than the United States Army.
BORDEAUX, France, Dec. 12 -- Marie Besnard, a 65-year-old widow originally accused of having killed her mother, father, second husband and ten other persons with arsenic, was acquitted today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12--Argentina's 3,200-mile Grand Prix highway race has become a battle of brothers. Oscar Galvez won the fourth stage of the race today, covering the 542-mile distance from Bariloche in the Andes to Comodoro Rivadavia on the Atlantic Coast in 8 hours 14 minutes 37 seconds.

INDOMITABLE is probably the word for "The Hostage." When the Brendan Behan comedy-drama reluctantly quit Broadway last January because of that "old debbil" stop-clause and for lack of an accommodating haven, there were promises that it would be back.
A survey by the United Parents Associations has found the supply of textbooks in the New York City public schools inadequate and many books seriously outdated.
A landlord who received the maximum fine in a heating case last week received the same in a health case yesterday in Housing Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The State Department dismissed as a "crude and ludicrous propaganda exercise" the Soviet Union's demand today for the arrest of General Heusinger.
RENE DE OBALDIA asks many questions: What is life? What is its purpose? What is its meaning? He also looks at the human condition and finds it absurd.

Three members of the Gallo gang, one of whom was wounded by an unidentified gunman Monday, were booked yesterday on charges of consorting with known criminals. They were booked on the order of Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver.
The City Council bill for a 10-cent increase in taxicab fares appeared yesterday to be doomed for lack of a formal request by Mayor Wagner for its passage.

Three officials of teamster union locals in New Jersey were arrested here yesterday on charges of attempting to extort $10,000 from a West Side metal products distributor with a promise to bring his labor troubles to an end.

CONAKRY, Guinea, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- President Sekou Toure, a Lenin Peace Prize winner, stirred a sensation in this young African nation today with the disclosure that the Communists had tried to overthrow his Government in an abortive plot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A Federal Communications Commission hearing examiner recommended today that a South Carolina radio station lose its license because it broadcast obscene remarks, was generally deficient in programing and carried too many advertisements.
The National Football League has fined officers of the Philadelphia Eagles -- number unspecified -- for comments made about the officiating at last Sunday's game with the New York Giants.
Mayor Wagner continued his advance pressure on Governor Rockefeller and the Republican-controlled Legislature yesterday to grant the city's requests for increased financial aid.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An agreement between the United States and Western Europe for deep cuts in tariff rates is expected to be reached before the end of this month, informed sources said tonight.
Schools and colleges in the state are scheduled to receive forms this week on which to apply for state funds to help pay for fall-out shelters.
New York City borrowed $53,100,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction, the purchase of subway equipment and other public improvements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The European Common Market was praised at a Congressional hearing today as an example for this country to follow in battering down walls between states.
DISCREETLY striped barber pole is in the window, but other than that Christopher Joyce bears little resemblance to the conventional barber shop.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- A small plane is in the top of a sixty-foot treet, deep in the woodlands here, and nobody was quite sure today what to do about it.
Dave Hoppmann of Iowa State moved the football almost a mile, 1,638 yards, and won offense honors among major-college players this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The fall upsurge in the automobile industry helped push the average factory employe's weekly pay to a record last month, the Labor Department reported today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- United States District Judge Walter J. LaBuy today turned down a Government request to issue, on the basis of oral arguments, a final order in the anti-trust case against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Premier Michel Debre denounced United States policy today on the Congo and the United Arab Republic.

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany agreed late last night to try to find out what the recent tough talk on Berlin from Soviet sources means.

Steels and oils were the leaders in a confused session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Most groups were thoroughly irregular. So were the chief market indicators, although all managed to close with gains.

Paperboard production in the nation rose to 338,958 tons in the week ended last Saturday. This figure compared with 331,983 tons in the preceding week and 316,846 tons in the same period of last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
A few simple precautions can help keep holiday accidents from happening. The following suggestions are offered by the Connecticut State Department of Health.
A definite trend toward more conservative surgery for infants with congenital heart defects was reported at a press conference held yesterday by the New York Heart Association, 10 Columbus Circle.

GEN. ADOLF ERNST HEUSINGER, who has been denounced as a war criminal by the Soviet Union, spent four years of World War II in almost daily association with Hitler. But this association, which was as a high staff officer only, did not leave him bearing the Nazi brand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -Caroline Kennedy tried to get an early peek at the White House Christmas tree this morning, but was detoured by special Presidential decree.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Iraq announced today legislation restricting areas of exploitation by foreign oil companies.
Dr. Robert Kaeppeli has been named chairman and Dr. Victor Umbricht has been elected president of the Ciba Corporation, which will be formed on Jan. 1.
BERLIN, Dec. 12 -- East German Communist authorities began last night to delay trailer trucks carrying freight from West Berlin to West Germany.
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 12 -- Organized labor rejected today President Kennedy's plea for voluntary restraint in collective bargaining. It called instead for higher wages and shorter hours.
Electricity rates will be increased by $19,700,000 a year for more than 40,000 major consumers here, including the New York Housing Authority, effective Jan. 23.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two Negroes were sworn in today as members of the White House police force.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 13 -- Joshua Nkomo, president of the National Democratic party, which was banned Saturday, has taken swift action to form a new African nationalist party.

Members of the Metropolitan Ski Jumping Committee, representing the eight active jumping clubs in New Jersey and lower New York, wrote to Governor Rockefeller last night asking for an improved hill and better spectator facilities at Bear Mountain State Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The statement given today by Acting Secretary of State Ball of the reasons why the United States Government will not join in the British Government's request to the United Nations for a cease-fire in Katanga forecloses for the time being the prospect of the "peaceful integration" of the Congo provinces which the Administration still defines as the purpose of the combatant military operation it equips and supports.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy approved today the award of new routes from Buffalo to Toronto for Eastern Air Lines and Mohawk Airlines.
UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The proposed creation of a world food bank to help the hungry and economically backward regions of the world was approved today by seventy-two nations.

It has been Leontyne Price's fortune this seasont at the Metropolitan Opera to be cast in Puccini roles. Last night, however, she returned to the title role in Verdi's "Aida," with the same success she had experienced in it the previous season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Kennedy sent his personal representative to Brussels tonight to resolve remaining issues in negotiations with the European Economic Community for a major lowering of tariff barriers.
Democratic Representatives in Congress from this city agreed yesterday to consult with Mayor Wagner before expressing a preference for majority leader in the House of Representatives.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 13 -- About 560 women and children left Goa for Portugal today in the face of a threatened attack from India.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Cyprus told the General Assembly today that any action on bringing Communist China into the United Nations would require a preliminary stage of negotiations.
CAIRO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Two French women are being detained in Cairo to give evidence in the "French spy ring" trial, which opens Jan. 15, informed sources said today.

Manufacurers Hanover Trust Company and Marine Midland Trust Company of New York announced yesterday interest rate increases on savings deposits, effective Jan. 1, identical with those announced earlier this week by the First National City Bank of New York.

A leading Soviet specialist on air pollution said yesterday that his country had been spared from smog because of the absence of atmospheric "lids" that trap fumes over American and West European cities.
At 3 P.M. just fifty years ago today a band of five men stood at the spot which marked the final point in the geophysical measurement of this spinning globe we live upon.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 13 -- Construction of combat submarines capable of diving to the bottom of the oceans now appears feasible through use of new materials and fabrication techniques, in the opinion of a leading submarine designer.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 13 -- Four days after the close of voting in the Australian national election, the result is still uncertain. It will remain in doubt at least until Monday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- President Kennedy will deliver a traditional Christmas message to the nation from Washington next Wednesday, the White House announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Brooks Hays, former president of the Southern Baptist Convention disclosed here that he paid a call on Pope John XXIII at the Vatican Oct. 23 during a visit to Rome.

The Murchison Brothers of Dallas made arrangements yesterday to sell substantially all of their 17 1/2 per cent holding of the Gulf Life Insurance Company of Jacksonville, Fla., to the American Life Insurance Company of Birmingham, Ala.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- New York University won a battle between unbeaten basketball teams tonight by whipping Iona College, 78 -- 65, at the Westchester County Center before 2,500 fans.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- J. Paul Getty, one of the world's wealthiest men, gave reasons today why he thought he should not be tossed from a balloon to keep it aloft.
Newton L. Minow now sees some greenery in the television "wasteland" he excoriated last May.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Following is a statement read by Acting Secretary of State George W. Ball to newsmen on the United States position on the Congo:
CHICAGO, Dec., 13 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored two goals late in the final period and tied the Boston Bruins, 2-2 tonight.
By action as well as by word Governor Rockefeller continued his efforts yesterday to refute reports that he would not seek re-election and that he might resign before his term ends.

Dr. Alexander Schiff, a physician with the New York State Athletic Commission for thirty-six years, was named the winner yesterday of the New York Boxing Writers' Association's James J. Walker Memorial Plaque "for long and meritorious service to the sport."
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Allied sources said today that West Berlin police units on border patrol along the Communist wall were being equipped with new M-2 carbines to strengthen their firepower.

The ten-point program announced Monday by Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to get people off relief and into useful work was commended yesterday by the National Urban League as "an important first step" toward resolution of a complex and growing problem.
The nation s output of crude oil and condensate rose an average of 199,150 barrels a day in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
MANILA, Dec. 13 -- A joint session of Congress tonight procalimed Diosdado Macapagal as the duly elected President of the Philippines tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy still is swimming and taking muscle-strengthening exercises every day, White House aides said today. His bad back apparently is tremendously better.
Edgar B. Young, the acting president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, has been named executive vice president to handle financing, construction and operational affairs.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Richard Cardinal Cushing and eleven Roman Catholic nuns joined Jewish mourners today at services for Steven Smith, 14 years old, who drowned in a bog after straying from a school for the handicapped.

The long-standing dispute between India and Portugal over Goa has now reached the point of an imminent armed conflict between them. Prime Minister Nehru is massing troops to "liberate" what India considers with justification to be the last colony on it, territory.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The finance ministers of ten of the leading industrial nations agreed today on a $6,000,000,000 plan to strengthen the world monetary system.

The national women's division of the American Jewish Congress is sponsoring a luncheon in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor on Monday as the culmination of a nation-wide fund-raising campaign to aid the Louise Waterman Wise Youth Center in Jerusalem.
After 104 years of service to Yorkville the Central Park Baptist Church has closed its doors for the last time.
MOUNT PROSPECT, Ill., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Deputies evicted today a truck farmer who had balked at accepting a court award of more than $15,700 an acre for land condemned for a school site.

Advertising agencies normally are pleased to land a new account, but employes of one agency, Johnstone, Inc., were particularly jubilant yesterday over a new client. The agency put out a release that proclaimed: "What many a multi-million dollar advertiser can't do, Fasig-Tipton Company has done for Johnstone, Inc.

Parking a car, getting it back and computing the cost takes no more effort than placing a key in a slot, a demonstration at an automated garage showed yesterday. It is not even necessary to turn the key.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- President Kennedy today appointed nine additional members to the Committee on Youth Employment created to consider the plight of almost 1,000,000 youngsters out of school and out of work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board held today that a union might request an employer to discharge a worker who was delinquent in his union dues and that the employer might do so even if the worker subsequently paid his dues.
The price of a key grade of scrap copper went up one-half cent yesterday to 25 1/4 cents a pound.
TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- The first meeting of the United States-Japanese Committee on Scientific Cooperation opened here today to promote smooth contacts between the two countries.
Dick Tiger, a 32-year-old Nigerian middleweight who is regarded as one of the best in the business, is a realist with a twofold purpose.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 13 -- Four United Nations jets dropped bombs and rockets today on the Lido Hotel in this battered capital of secessionist Katanga Province.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Demand by United States buyers for Unilever, Shell and Royal Dutch shares lifted the stock market here today. Gains in these issues were substantial and other American favorites basked in their reflected strength.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, urged by Republican leaders to run for the Senate, said today he had no thought of leaving the Johns Hopkins University.

A union representing employes of the Consolidated Edison Company voted yesterday to accept a new one-year contract. This lifted the threat of a strike that had been voted on Dec. 1 by 5,000 members of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers of America.
