We endorse, with somewhat mixed feelings, salary increases for City Councilmen. But there are other, and greater, injustices in compensation for service in public office. The Mayor, now at $40,000 (plus Gracie Mansion), the Controller at $30,000 and the President of the City Council at $25,000 should be increased substantially. The Borough Presidents, now at $25,000, have long been underpaid, with a salary fixed more than twenty years ago.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The Western European Union unanimously asked the Allies today to avert "nuclear anarchy" among the Atlantic powers.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Labor and student groups have called a fifteen-minute general strike Tuesday to demonstrate opposition to the Secret Army Organization, clandestine Rightwing group that is opposing the regime with terror tactics in France and Algeria.
The election of Morris D. Crawford Jr., as president of the Bowery Savings Bank was announced yesterday by Earl B. Schwulst, chairman, who has been functioning also as president.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Republican National Committee announced today it would hold another round of simultaneous fund-raising dinners connected by closed-circuit television on Feb. 1.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt and eight other Delano heirs failed today in their efforts to prevent sale for commercial purposes of a piece of land in near-by Fairhaven.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Algerian nationalists paid their first formal call at the United States delegation today for a forty-five minute talk with Adlai E. Stevenson.
IF one could name the place where Edgar Berryhill Young has been all his life, and where he wants to remain, it would be "in the wings."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration cautioned today that tops that contain a good, cosmetic, drug or hazardous substance as defined by law are subject to laws that are enforced.
Brooklyn Democratic leaders named a committee of five yesterday to try to dissuade Mayor Wagner from insisting on Joseph T. Sharkey's ouster as majority leader of the City Council.

NORMAN NORELL has gone all out for the full skirt, the cinched waistline and the knee-high hemline. His spring collection bustles arid bounces with clothes that are as breezy as sportswear and so youthful as to sometimes appear almost childlike.

THE celebrated Ernest Ansermet, 78 years old and oak-sturdy, made his first New York appearance since 1958 last night in Carnegie Hall. He directed the Boston Symphony in a program that had several of his specialties.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- It was understood today that the United States had made strong representations to India to avoid the use of force to "liberate" Goa.

HONG KONG, Dec. 13 -- This British colony has asked the British Government to lodge a "strong protest" in Washington against the proposed United States "equalization fee" on imported cotton textiles goods.
November steel production totaled 8.749,000 tons, up from 6,171,940 tons a year before, but below the 9,173,170 tons melted in October, 1961, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
United States Government securities went through another day of sensitive price adustment yesterday to the enlarged interest-payment authority newly commanded by commercial banks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The United States conducted another nuclear weapon test today by setting off an underground explosion at the Nevada proving grounds.
Villanova sparked by Hubie White's 28 points, gained its sixth triumph in a row by beating the Fordham quintet, 69 -- 48, before a crowd of 3,000 last night at the Fordham gymnasium.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, Dec. 13 -- George Ivan Smith, chief United Nations representative in Elisabethville, capital of Katanga Province, indicated today that a systematic effort was being made to secure communication lines between the airport and areas where Katangese troops had strongholds.

Amid the fanfare that has come to be part and parcel of business negotiations involving big-money sports celebrities, Mickey Mantle yesterday became the first member of the world champion Yankees to sign his 1962 contract.
TAKING time off from weightier problems, Channel 7's "Close-Up!" series sat in with a group of lively youngsters last night for what turned out to be a delightful, informal visit.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Packers erased a big deficit in the final period tonight and beat the New York Knickerbockers, 113 -- 112, in a National Basketball Association game.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 13 -- Sparked by Dave Tremaine and Joe Broz, Navy beat Gettysburg 60-53, in basketball today.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- A majority in the fifteen-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization continued today to press for an active approach to negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question, despite French opposition.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- What was intended to be a secret trip to the United Nations ended otherwise today for a Manhasset High School student who was playing hooky. He was the millionth visitor this year to obtain a ticket for a tour of the world organization's headquarters.
The profits of a cooky shop operated by pupils of a third-grade class in a Port Washington, L.I., elementary school were received yesterday by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Two former Communist officials have received Federal warnings that they might be jailed for violating terms of their release from prison if they fail, to register as Communists by Dec. 19 -- or disclaim party membership.

A DOUBLE of an opponent's cue-bid can be very useful in telling one's partner what to lead. In fact, careless failure to double some cue-bids can he read by one's partner as denial of high-card strength in the cue-bid suit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The head of a national distributing company testified today that it was selling its own drugs for up to 90 per cent less than brand-name prices.
HARTFORD, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Property damage in the Hartford Hospital fire that killed sixteen persons last Friday was estimated today at $300,000.
The threat of a city-wide transit strike tomorrow was averted by an arbitrator's decision last night.

Grandma Moses, who died yesterday at the age of 101, was not a very good artist by the standards that prevail today, or, for that matter, by the standards that have always prevailed in art of much consequence.
The largest contribution to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, $1,875, was from employes of the American Tobacco Company. With it came a letter from Paul M. Hahn, president of the company. It said:
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The grain futures marke showed signs today of having fallen into a year-end lull as trade again hit a draggy pace with most prices little changed.

Two employes of the New York City Housing Authority were indicted yesterday by a Bronx County grand jury for allegedly accepting bribes from a contractor. The District Attorney's office said other arrests might fellow in the investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, tonight received the thirteenth annual William Penn Award of the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation, the Administration's sharpest critic on domestic farm policies, declared itself solidly behind President Kennedy today in his request for greater authority liberalize foreign trade.
THE well-designed, machine made dress, a garment that was developed and perfected on Seventh Avenue, is turning up all over Italy these days, thanks to the know-how of such men as Leonard J. Fisher.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Cotton growers and producers of flue-cured tobacco have overwhelmingly approved continuing national marketing quotas and price supports.
The Esso Education Foundation announced grants yesterday of almost $1,900,000 to privately supported institutions. The emphasis was on unrestricted grants.

IN the opinion of Clifton Fadiman, there is a subtle link between wine and art. As if to develop the theory, two leading wine-and-spirits shops in Manhattan now offer the public two catalogues strikingly illustrated with art to announce their liquid wares.

A record increase in investments of assets of domestic life insurance companies was indicated for this year, according to a report presented yesterday at the annual meeting here of the Life Insurance Association of America.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- New Jersey asked New York today to join it in testing the constitutionality of its commuter income tax law.

Production of electric power in the nation rose to 16,084,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Saturday from 15,954,000,000 kilowatt hours in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.

The American Gas Association has leased a floor in the office building being erected by Fisher Brothers at 605 Third Avenue near Fortieth Street. William V. Colovito of H. Clayton Smith Co. was the broker. Galbreath-Ruffin is the agent for the building.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- A 45-year-old unemployed salesman was held today as a suspect in the theft of ten paintings valued at $500,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Union leaders today accused Eastern and National Airlines of plotting the "economic destruction" of Northeast Airlines and demanded a Congressional investigation.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Joe Woltering's 19 points led Adelphi's basketball team to its first victory of the season tonight. The Panthers defeated City College, 64 -- 59, in a Tri-State League game.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Hungary bitterly assailed today United States efforts to discuss "the question of Hungary" at the present session of the General Assembly.
A plan for a 271-acre waterfront park around the southwestern tip of Staten Island at Tottenville was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
GEORGE TOWN, Bahamas, Dec. 13 -- This town of a few hundred persons on the island of Great Exuma lies about 150 miles southeast of Nassau. It is exactly one hour away on a Bahamas Airways DC-3.

New York City borrowed yesterday $40,000,000 on short-term tax anticipation notes at an interest rate of 2 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday. The notes will be dated Dec. 14, 1961, and will come due on May 1, 1962.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 13 -- The Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga, the Belgian-controlled mining company that is the biggest industry in the embattled province of Katanga in the Congo, charged today that "the aim pursued by the troops of the United Nations is complete destruction of the economic potential of Katanga."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A hearing on Norfolk and Western Railway merger plans was recessed today to Jan. 15 after the railroad's president expressed opposition to any order that it merge with Erie-Lackawanna Railroad.
The Rabbinical Court of America, the Orthodox tribunal devoted to resolving family relations and marital problems, said yesterday it had saved 500 marriages in its first year.

The Iraq Petroleum Company and associated companies, the Basrah Petroleum Company and the Mosul Petroleum Company, termed yesterday the efforts of the Iraq Government to restrict their operations in Iraq as "discriminatory" and in violation of existing concessionary agreements.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A decision on how E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., will divest itself of interests in the General Motors Corporation was put off today until after Congress reconvenes in January.
Ross Products, Inc., New York importer of consumer merchandise, reported yesterday sharply higher earnings on little change in sales in the year ended on Aug. 31.

Active trading in cocoa and wool futures yesterday ended with declines in both commodities. The declines were laid to news from abroad. Similar influences helped copper rocovery from its retreat on Tuesday.
WEST POINT. N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Army swept three sports contests today.
A five-alarm fire swept five stores in the Bronx early today. Heavy smoke and flames stubbornly resisted the efforts of 200 firemen using forty pieces of equipment.
The Civil Aeronautics Board is expected to act in the next few days on the controversial issue of domestic airline fares.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The Roman Catholic Order of Alexian Brothers will break a 600-year tradition to permit its local hospital to admit women patients next year.
A group of thirty-three American Negroes -- artists, performers and educators -- departed last night for Lagos, Nigeria, to have a ball with their African counterparts.
Four candidates were chosen last night for the finals of the Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition.

The five-story apartment building occupying a plot 110 by 157 feet at 1326 to 1334 Riverside Drive, near 180th Street, has been sold by the Hensle Construction Company. It contains sixty-three apartments. The property was bought by the Manhattan Fifteen Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $200,000.

BOB HOPE arrived on Channel 4 last night in the first of his specials of the television season. Surrounded by an assortment of attractive girls, a self-conscious group of all-America football players and several guest stars, Mr. Hope offered an hour of mildly amusing entertainment.
TUCKER'S TOWN, Bermuda, Dec. 13 -- Two major changes in the North Atlantic air-fare structure were reported agreed upon today by a committee of eight carriers.

Conformity may not be the spice of life, but it is a way that accountants prefer. Each year the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants undertakes an analysis of 600 annual corporate reports. From this it gleans trends in reporting techniques and comments on what it considers the best methods.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Guatemala is considering breaking relations with Britain in the near future, president Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Cinema, it is often said, is a director's medium. Directorial talent is sufficiently rare, however, to make the advent of a new director of "star quality" an event of great importance in movie production circles, as evidenced by the rise of Jack Clayton.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Following is the text of an aide-memoire given today to U Thant, Acting Secretary General, by Sir Patrick Dean, chief British representative, urging Mr. Thant to seek an immediate cease-fire in Katanga:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Administration abandoned today the widely publicized plans for mounting Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles on trains so they could be moved from one site to another. Officials estimated that the program had cost $108,000,000 so far.

Events tonight: "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic preview concert, Josef Krips, conductor, Wilma Lipp, soprano, Shirley Verret-Carter, mezzo-soprano, Rudolf Petrak, tenor, Norman Farrow, bass-baritone, Felicia Montealegre, narrator, Westminister Choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Romero Family, classical and flamenco, guitarists, Town Hall, 8:30; Martin Sameth, baritone, David Garvey, pianist, Dorothy Renzi, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
A woman landlord who had been sought by the city appeared briefly in Housing Court yesterday and then left before her case was heard.
A physician and three lawyers indicted Tuesday by a Queens grand jury investigating the tow-car racket surrendered yesterday and were held in $1,000 bail each in Queens County Court.
Alumni of New York University yesterday honored Dr. Albert B. Sabin, developer of the live virus polio vaccine. He was graduated from the University's Washington Square College in 1928.

HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Grandma Moses, the spry, indomitable "genuine American primitive" who became one of the country's most famous painters in her late seventies, died here today at the age of 101.
Two men and a youth were convicted of first-degree murder last night in the shooting of a United Parcel Service driver on the East Side on May 17.

A police raid in the Bronx last night uncovered an alleged gambling ring that took in more than $80,000 a day in its operations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Nassau County. Five men were arrested but not booked immediately.

Abraham A. Ribicoff proposed last night that American universities, foundations, medical schools, architects, engineers and manufacturers join the Government in an international Health for Peace program.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13 -- An escaped mental patient was reported tonight to have confessed to the slaying of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gregov, but he denied he had killed the couple's three sons.
Your Nov. 27 editorial "'Subversion' in the South" states that I am pushing for a bill "to let the states wiretap without restraint."

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today what political observers have felt all along -- that he would run for renomination in next year's Democratic primary.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 13 -- Support was voiced here today for a survey of major North Jersey rivers by the Army Corps of Engineers to help reclaim more than 20,000 acres of Meadowland.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Administration is considering opening a second American entry point for Cuban refugees to relieve the overloading of the Miami area, a spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The key word in the Congo situation today was "reconciliation."

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of the officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
Rutgers won a basketball game last night on the Columbia University court. It was the first time this had happened since the schools started their basketball rivalry in the 1914-15 season.
ROME, Dec. 13 -- Pietro Nenni, leader of the Left-wing Socialists, hinted today that his party was prepared to accept membership in the Atlantic alliance if the Government accepted Socialist support.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- India scored 253 runs for three wickets today as the third five-day cricket test match against England began.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United Church of Christ outlined plans today to build retirement centers in ten states for persons over 62 who have incomes as low as $1,800 a year.

Market indicators disagreed yesterday. Standard Poor's 500-stock index was down moderately and more stocks fell than rose. However, The New York Times industrial and combined averages were up, and Dow, Jones Co.'s industrial average showed a gain.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The United States and the Soviet Union presented tonight a joint resolution to set up an eighteen-nation negotiating body to work on general and complete disarmament.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 cents a bale off to 30 cents up yesterday.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Following is the text of the constitutional amendment adopted today by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations for the settlement of internal disputes:
MILL NECK, L.I., Dec. 13 -- The Beaver Dam Winter Sports Club will be the setting on Jan. 27 for a benefit buffet supper and skating party for the Family Service Association of Nassau County.

An appeal by the Teachers Union to postpone the teachers' collective bargaining election here because of allegedly unfair labor practices by the Board of Education was dismissed yesterday by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Commissioner of Education.
A "sit-in" strike at sea aboard the liner Bremen was reported yesterday by passengers debarking here.

In the last Congress Senator Keating of New York was sponsor of a bill to let state and local police tap wires, under court order, without any significant limitation. No record would have had to be made of the wiretapping. The bill did not even exclude from judicial consideration wiretap evidence obtained by unauthorized methods.

The Milwaukee Braves were the National League's top fielding team last season, according to the official averages released yesterday. Compiling a .982 fielding mark, the Braves led the league in total putouts with 4,174, tied the Chicago Cubs in assists with 1,848, and commited the fewest errors, 111.

Delta Air Lines, Inc., which has had to abandon its plans of early last fall to sell a major block of additional stock to help finance its jet aircraft equipment program, has turned to a group of banks and insurance companies to provide the needed capital.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- For the first time in its card-selling history, the United Nations Children's Fund is facing a complete sell-out of its greeting cards by the end of the year.

As far as Broadway is concerned, Sidney Michaels, a film and television writer, has yet to make his playwriting debut. Nevertheless, he says he has hit the jackpot collecting money from options on his scripts.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Max McGee, a Green Bay end, has a cracked rib and it may keep him out of the Packer line-up in the National Football League championship game on Dec. 31.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A Federal District judge denied today the attempt of a Negro to enter the all-white University of Mississippi immediately.

THE latest exhibit to sign up for space at the New York 1964-1965 World's Fair is actually three exhibits. Robert Moses, president of the fair, announced yesterday that three houses and their accompanying gardens will be built by The House of Good Taste, Inc., an organization set up by the American Institute of Approval.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The American Municipal Association endorsed today a broader Government shelter program.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- U Thant, the Acting Secretary General, gave a chilly reception today to a British memorandum calling on him "to secure an immediate ceasefire in Katanga."

According to tradition, bankers are supposed to work bankers' hours. Over the last few days, however, the advertising departments of the leading banks in this area have been on a far more arduous schedule. At some banks, in fact, they've been toiling through the night.
RALEIGH, N.C. Dec. 13 (AP) -- Roman Gabriel, the ace passer of North Carolina State College, today said he would play pro football with the Los Angeles Rams of the National Football League.

A new technique in the plastics industry that was said to permit for the first time the full-scale manufacture of reconstituted nylon from nylon scraps, both fiber and solid, was announced yesterday by the Long Island Plastics Corporation, Lindenhurst.

Anton Rost of Brooklyn, who makes periodic trips to Europe to buy dogs for others, returned from his latest journey with none. He did not buy in Germany because he saw nothing he liked. He did not buy in England, Ireland, Scotland or Wales because what he liked was not for sale.

In its editorial of Dec. 12 endorsing Newton N. Minow's view of the relationship of the Government to television programing The Times supports its position by stating that "no city has more than seven regular television channels, and most areas can see only one or two or three."
The Philadelphia Eagles and the Baltimore Colts need survive only one more week-end and they'll wind up with team statistical honors in the National Football League for 1961.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Temple scored its fourth straight basketball victory tonight by defeating Princeton 65 -- 55, at the Palestra.
Macy's New York signed a lease yesterday to operate a three-floor department store in the planned Westchester Plaza shopping center in New Rochelle.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The United Nations' withdrawal today of its request to Britain to supply bombs to United Nation forces in the Congo has extricated the Conservative Government from a position of political and diplomatic embarrassment.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee overwhelmingly approved today an African-Asian resolution calling for general elections leading to the independence of South-West Africa.

The election of Paul M. Herzog of New York as president of the American Arbitration Association was announced yesterday. The association provides tribunals to arbitrate commercial, labor and other disputes.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 13 -- The labor federation approved overwhelmingly today a broad new plan for the settlement of jurisdictional disputes between affiliates. The formula, the fourth in the six years since the merger of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, was hammered out in a nine-hour session of the federation's Executive Council.
Demand for shares of the British and Dutch concerns that control the vast Unilever interests flooded the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in their second day of trading there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, a leader in the tape industry, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Danville, Ill., on charges of attempting to monopolize and conspiring to restrain and monopolize trade.
Pre-Christmas festivities were in full swing yesterday as many community organizations, business concerns and private groups celebrated.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The Delaware River Basin Commission, set up to administer a $591,000,000 program for the development of the water resources of the Delaware Valley, held its first meeting today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Following is the text of a joint resolution on disarmament offered here today by the United States and the Soviet Union:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Representatives of both North and South Korea were invited today to participate in the debate on Korea.
A painting by Claude Monet was sold last night for $80,000.
College football attendance rose 1.34 per cent in 1961 to record high of 20,677,604.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13 -- A Nassau County Commissioner of Accounts and a Deputy County Executive were appointed today by Eugene H. Nickerson, the Democratic County Executive-elect.

STOLLEN, the delicious German sweet bread that is almost a cake, is becoming a familiar sight in city bakeries at Christmas time. Some are imported, others are made locally, but there is nothing to equal the flavor of a stollen made at home.
The Commonwealth Edison Company awarded $40,000,000 of fifty-year 4 3/4 per cent sinking fund debentures yesterday to the First Boston Corporation and associates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The elimination of ten Reserve divisions is under consideration in the Pentagon as part of a broad study of the structure, size, capabilities, readiness and usefulness of the National Guard and Organized Reserve system.

Robert Patrick Dana of Mount Vernon, Iowa, and Richard Eunkook Kim of Iowa City received cash awards from the Mary Roberts Rhinehart Foundation to help them complete works in progress. Mr. Dana, who received a grant of $1,200, is an assistant professor of English at Cornell College in Mount Vernon.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 13 (AP) -- The builders of a pioneer electronic computer received a scientific prize tonight bequeathed by a canny nineteenth century Scotsman who proposed to limit the awards to $20.

For a good many years United States foreign policy has given great weight to the principle of "self-determination" for other peoples. Now, in justification of our backing United States operations in Katanga, a new and contrary doctrine has begun to emerge, which is partially reflected in your editorial of Dec. 12.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 -- The Venezuelan Government moved several units of its armed forces from the interior to Caracas today as part of its plans to guarantee maximum security during the visit here Saturday of President Kennedy.
Court action was threatened yesterday when the transfer of WNTA-TV (Channel 13) to an educational television group was postponed for the second time in five days.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 13 -- A broadly representative citizens committee appointed by the Stamford Board of Education tonight submitted a detailed plan to end racial, economic and academic segregation in the city's high schools.

THE New York City Ballet, still feeding its standard repertory into the season's schedule at the City Center, last night introduced George Balanchine's youthful and charming little Tchaikovsky "Pas de Deux," composed originally for "Swan Lake" but never actually used in it.

An American Committee for Aid to Katanga Freedom Fighters was organized yesterday. Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Senate's Republican leader, was among eighty-one persons named as sponsors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The United States declared its opposition today to a ceasefire in Katanga until United Nations forces there had achieved their "minimum objectives."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 13 -- The police used rifle fire, bombs and tear gas today to break up a wild Dominican demonstration at the United States Consulate's visa section.
Montgomery Ward Co., retail merchandising chain, reported yesterday that its sales for November and the first ten months of its fiscal year were new highs.
Football practice is a legitimate con game. This became evident yesterday while the New York Giants were plying their trade on the scarred turf at Yankee Stadium.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- "The pendulum of power has swung far from our states toward the Federal Government" because states have failed to meet pressing public needs, former President Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today.
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 13 -- The police arrested 202 Negroes tonight during a demonstration at the City Hall as racial tension mounted in this southwest Georgia city.
WALGROVE SNOOD the literary banker and Kim Carruthers the benevolent bookman were sitting in the taproom of the Debenture Bay Yacht and Crabgrass Club.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 13 -- Israel wants an arrangement with the European economic community, or Common Market, Commerce Minister Pinhas Sapir said today.

THE New York City Ballet, still feeding its standard repertory into the season's schedule at the City Center, last night introduced George Balanchine's youthful and charming little Tchaikovsky "Pas de Deux," composed originally for "Swan Lake" but never actually used in it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The United States declared its opposition today to a ceasefire in Katanga until United Nations forces there had achieved their "minimum objectives."
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 13 -- The police used rifle fire, bombs and tear gas today to break up a wild Dominican demonstration at the United States Consulate's visa section.

The New York City Housing Authority has installed an I.B.M. 1401 electronic computer to handle its accounting system. This is the first computer installed in a housing authority in the United States. Ten months were required to install the unit at 299 Broadway.

Mayor Wagner asked the City Council yesterday to raise the pay of the incoming Board of Estimate. Almost simultaneously, the Council voted $3,000 raises for members of the Council that will take office Jan. 1.
The American Tobacco Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to acquire a 13 per cent interest in Gallaher, Ltd., one of Britain's largest tobacco concerns.

Relief was the keynote at the offices of the Metropolitan Opera late yesterday afternoon -- relief that Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg had finally come through with his figures and relief that the raises granted to the musicians of the orchestra were not higher than they were.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A field goal by Gene Shue and four free throws in the last forty seconds enabled Detroit to score a 107-103 National Basketball Association victory over Cincinnati tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Congress will approve President Kennedy's request for new foreign-trade bargaining tools if he does "a proper selling job" in explaining the need for them, one of his legislative leaders predicted today.
A bill that would enable New York banks to establish statewide branch systems will be pro-filed before the Legislature convenes in January, it was learned yesterday.

Opera was the theme of the entertainment and gold and orange the decor at the fourth annual Spoleto Ball held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. Besides the singers who entertained, there was a parade of committee members dressed as famous couples from operas.
Two major copper companies with properties in Northern Rhodesia announced yesterday that they planned to merge.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Turkeys came in for special mention here today as the American Farm Bureau Federation took a strong stand against restricting production or marketing of the birds "or any other agricultural commodity not now under control."

MANILLA, Dec. 14 (UPI) -The Oriental Boxing Federation hailed today the National Boxing Association's approval of Saturday's world junior lightweight title match between the Filipino champion, Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, and Sergio Caprari of Italy.

Willie Salesky, realty investor, has bought the five-story apartment house at 1280 Walton Avenue, southeast corner of East 169th Street, the Bronx, which he plans to syndicate. The building is on a plot 145 by 125 feet and contains seventy-five apartments and seven stores.
MORE than four centuries after he was beheaded, a man of conscience has become the most impressive character of our theatrical season.
Prices of United States Government securities turned upward yesterday for the first time in a week. Elsewhere in the bond market demand also tended to outstrip supply.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Nazem el Kodsi, a moderate conservative was elected today as Syria's President and immediately began moves to give the country its first Parliamentary-based government since it broke away from the United Arab Republic in September.
THE Christmas baby is an extra-welcome, tax-deductible gift for his parents' Christmas stocking. But from the time he begins to toddle, he often begins to feel short-changed.

SEATTLE, Dec. 10 -- A taxi driver who was born in Greenpoint and emigrated from Brooklyn seventeen years ago without ever having been to the top of the Empire State Building figures 1962 is going to be his year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- An agreement providing pay increases and changes in working rules for stewardesses has been signed between the Air Line Pilots Association and Alaska Airlines. The contract runs until Sept. 30, 1963.
