Frederick Loewe, who said last February that he would take leave of the theatre for from twelve to eighteen months to recover from the arduous task of preparing "Camelot," apparently is returning to work earlier than expected.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Charles Boyer, although an officer of one of Hollywood's most successful television companies, has not made a major television appearance in more than four years, largely because there are few scripts worth the effort.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President and Mrs. Kennedy will leave at noon tomorrow on a two-day visit to Venezuela and Colombia on behalf of the Alliance for Progress.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 -- Sales of new cars fell slightly during the first ten days of December from the preceding period, but were still 4.4 per cent above the 1960 level, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh and three co-defendants in a $35,000 court fix case pleaded not guilty in Federal Court yesterday. The arraignment of a fifth defendant, Dr. Robert M. Erdman, an orthopedic surgeon who is expected to be the Government's principal witness, was put off until today.

MANY American women who are accustomed to traveling abroad alone or in the company of other women seem intimidated by New York City. What particularly concerns them is the prospect of gaining entree to some of the city's famous restaurants and places of entertainment without a male escort.
New York Airways' helicopter services in this area will be sharply curtailed with the elimination of several cargo, mail and passenger flights, it was announced yesterday.

LEAVING the Times Building on West Forty-third Street one afternoon last week I walked a short way with the revered philosopher of the editorial staff. As always, I had a book under my arm and he asked to see it. I showed him "You Only Have to Get Rich Once,"* by Walter K. Gutman, and we agreed that the title, at least, was provocative.
GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- The United Nations Sugar Conference adjourned here tonight but left open the possibility of its being reconvened to resume the deadlocked negotiations on export quotas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Lawyers for the Roman Catholic Church issued an eighty-two-page challenge today to the Kennedy Administration's position on the constitutionality of Federal aid to church-related schools.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 60 cents a bale off yesterday. The December contract was unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Dorothy McCullough Lee, chairman of the Subversive Activities Control Board, said today she planned to return to her former home in Portland, Ore., next August.
In a braze of multi-colored lights and amid the sound of Christmas caroling the city last night officially opened its Christmas season of 1961.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 14 -- Special police units arrested 111 persons today in predawn raids throughout three northeastern provinces bordering Laos. Those arrested were suspected of having been involved in a plot to bring the area under Communist rule.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 14 -- Policemen armed with rifles and percussion and tear-gas bombs were massed downtown today to prevent disorders.
THE winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association will begin today at the Statler-Hilton Hotel and continue through Sunday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) -- The American Football League's first All-Star professional game will be played Jan. 7, the league and the sponsoring San Diego Junior Chamber of Commerce said today.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Britain today called for an open Wimbledon lawn tennis championship -- even if the International Lawn Tennis Federation rejects the idea of mixing amateurs and professionals generally throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Shortages, mistakes and weaknesses, dramatized by complaints of a handful of mobilized National Guardsmen and Reservists, have stimulated a re-examination of the Army's manpower procurement policies, Reserve organization and mobilization procedures.

Concert managers, performers and producers of musical events in the United States and Canada met yesterday at the Plaza Hotel to open the three-day fourteenth annual convention of the International Association of Concert Managers.

If there were an international "wire race" akin to the "missile race," the United States would be far ahead of Russia, according to one steel expert recently returned from an overseas trip that included stops in the Soviet Union.
A new medical library center will be opened near the New York Academy of Medicine next summer to serve New York medical schools and research institutions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The several statements -- prepared, extempore and in reply to news conference questions -- which Secretary of Labor Goldberg made last week during the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention left an inference and produced a judgment, both of which the Secretary has declared erroneous.
The U.S.S. Sabine, a twenty-one-year-old fleet oiler with a record of service unequaled by another ship of her type in World War II, returned to active Navy duty here yesterday.

Sixty-two members of the Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, which acted "The Skin of Our Teeth," "The Glass Menagerie" and "The Miracle Worker" in thirty-nine foreign cities, were honored yesterday by Actors Equity.

A forty-year-old Liberian freighter appeared to be near the end of her seafaring career yesterday in a tangle of liens and attachments. The ship, the 281-foot Sula G, has been lying idle at the foot of Kent Street in Brooklyn for six weeks.

GREELEY, Colo., Dec. 14 -- Twenty children were killed today when a passenger train traveling seventy-nine miles an hour hit a school bus at a rural crossing near here. Thirteen of the seventeen other...
Your editorial of Dec. 14 misconstrues my award. It also shows a lack of understanding of arbitration and collective bargaining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg's statement on "The State of the Performing Arts," which was included in his findings in the Metropolitan Opera dispute:
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 14 -- National Guardsmen were called out today as negotiators sought to resolve a crisis over mass arrests of Negro demonstrators here.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- For the second consecutive month, Britain's trading deficit, the excess of imports over exports and re-exports, has decreased.
Spurred by the tantalizing aroma of legal tender, the New York Giants kept cold noses to the proverbial grindstone for an hour and a half in Yankee Stadium yesterday.

Stocks fell steadily yesterday and closed on the New York Stock Exchange with a substantial loss on average. No major group as a whole resisted the price decline, although various specialties and more volatile issues within groups went against the trend and posted gains.

Restaurant Associates, Inc., operator of a chain of restaurants, including the Four Seasons, Brasserie, La Fonda del Sol and Forum of the Twelve Seasons, has announced plans for three more units in the Pan Am Building, now under construction at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal.
An additional stock on the American Stock Exchange apparently is under scrutiny by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In his survey of "the state of the performing arts" in the United States, Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg has couched his statement in terms that might be compared with a Presidential State of the Union message.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg called today for Government subsidies of all performing arts and urged both business and labor to join in a partnership of financial support of the arts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Kennedy established today a commission headed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to advance the cause of women's rights.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation recovered today nine valuable contemporary paintings stolen from an art collector in the Pittsburgh area last July. They had been left in a near-by motel.

Out of the curious contradictions of the impartial arbitrator's decision that simultaneously averted an illegal, contract-breaking strike of all city transit and stopped the first passenger, operation of an automated train one principle emerges unmistakably: automation of mass transit must proceed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Reserve forces will not again be mobilized for "cold war" crises, Deputy Defense Secretary Roswell L. Gilpatric indicated today.
NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- Five New Jersey contractors were convicted tonight in Superior Court on charges of conspiracy in the submission of bids for a multi-million dollar sewerage program.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting Federal Reserve member banks in New York City rose $88,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
PANGIM, Goa., Dec. 14 -- Jet fighter planes, presumed to be Indian, flew over the heart of Goa today in an apparent show of force against the Portuguese.

The city begins operating today under a new Zoning Resolution, a "blueprint for growth." The comprehensive law replaces the zoning resolution of 1916, which was the first of its kind in the United States.
The landlords received jail sentences and maximum fines in Housing Court yesterday for failing to provide adequate heat in Harlem properties.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, confirmed tonight that two of his top aides were in the Congo to pursue the United Nations' long-range aim of reconciling the dissident leaders there.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Following is the text of a letter from Governor Rockefeller to Mayor Wagner dealing with rent control and Middle income housing it New York City, as released by the Governor's office today:
CONSIDERING the current high popularity of the guitar as a concert instrument, it should stand to reason that a concert offering not one but four guitarists would be just that many times as good.
IT is to television's credit that one can sit down after dark and twist the dial to a concert by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns today entered the picture in the bidding for the most prized collegiate football player, Ernie Davis, by making a deal with the Washington Redskins.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The United States warned tonight that the admission of Communist China would have a disruptive effect on the workings of the United Nations.
Department store sales in New York State and northeastern New Jersey rose 6 per cent in October, compared with September, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- Howard W. Petersen, special assistant to President Kennedy, put forward today a new proposal for settlement of trade differences between the United States and the European Common Market. No details were given.

Despite continued differences on negotiations with the Soviets and on the Congo, the North Atlantic allies meeting in Paris have taken a long stride toward making NATO a fourth atomic power in the West to bolster its defenses and deterrents to war.
Arthur L. Jacobson was admitted to membership on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and thereby hangs a story:
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Schenley Industries, Inc., expects to show slight gains in sales and earnings for its first fiscal quarter, ended on Nov. 30, it was disclosed yesterday at the annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.

Exports and imports of steel-mill products climbed sharply in October from the September levels. However, data issued yesterday in Washington by the Department of Commerce indicated that exports for the first ten months of the year were well below those of the 1960 period.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Big Five Conference today appointed a committee to negotiate with the Big Ten on possible renewal of a Rose Bowl football contract.
Trading in most commodity futures yesterday was generally quiet, with price declines outnumbering increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- For a few moments today a valuable painting spun through the air in front of the House of Representatives. Then, gently, the steel-framed, 12-foot-square fresco was set down and trundled inside.
The North Carolina Society will hold its sixty-fourth annual dinner dance this evening at the St. Regis Roof.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Administration has paved the way for Congressional approval of an international financial plan to protect the dollar and other major currencies.
BERLIN, Dec. 14 -- An audience of Germans and foreigners responded tonight with mixed views to the world premiere of the American film, "Judgment at Nuremberg."

Allan P. Kirby, who was ousted as chairman of the Alleghany Corporation last spring after a bitter proxy contest with the Murchison brothers of Dallas, has no plans at this time to conduct a new proxy contest in an effort to regain control of the big holding company.
Strong political criticism was building up around the country yesterday against the United States' role in support of the United Nations' action against the secessionist Congo province of Katanga.
It's a long way from the streets of Brooklyn to St. Lawrence University's Appleton Arena in Canton, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Several unconfirmed reports relating to grains became significant factors in futures trading here today and brought out a price-firming volume of short covering in corn, oats and rye. Wheat and soybeans were steady to easier.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain and Paul Arizin combined for 75 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to a 136-125 victory over the Syracuse Nationals in the second half of a National Basketball Association double-header.

MIAMI, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Federal judge ruled today that the former heavyweight champion, Ingemar Johansson, owes the United States $1,009,801 in income taxes and directed the Swedish fighter's promoters to pay it.

William Saroyan has written a volume of reminiscences that he calls "Here Comes, There Goes You Know Who." It will be published Jan. 23 by Trident Press and distributed by Simon Schuster. The author, now in his middle age, looks back at his childhood and years in an orphanage and works up to his later tax troubles and obsessive gambling.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- India, sparked by a score of 189 runs not out by Vijay Manjrekar, scored 466 by the close of the home team's first innings today in the third cricket test match against the Marylebone Cricket Club of England.

The Computer Usage Company, which services electronic data processing machines, has leased a floor containing 10,000 square feet of space in 655 Madison Avenue at Sixtieth Street. The company was organized in 1955 and has offices in Los Angeles, Washington and this city at 18 East Forty-first Street, from which it will move early next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Administration proposed today a $700,000,000 civil defense program designed to provide community fall-out shelters for 20,000,000 persons.

Mayor Wagner was reported yesterday to have chosen Debs Meyers to replace Frank D. Doyle as his press relations secretary at $20,000 a year. Mr. Meyers is public relations director for a Chicago industrial concern.

DETROIT, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman scored two goals and Terry Sawchuk recorded his second shutout in three games to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-0 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a National Hockey League game.
More than 300 persons jammed school headquarters last night to present views on the Board of Education's plan to revitalize the city's local school boards.
MIAMI, the Baghdad on the Beach that tends to think Santa is benovolent only if he brings out the sun, is involved these pre-Christmas days in a clash of symbols.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The new $7,000,000 building of the National Library of Medicine was dedicated today to provide "a living fund of knowledge, serving health workers everywhere."

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre Company's presentation of Chekhov's "The Cherry Orchard" opened tonight at the company's London home, the Aldywch Theatre, before an appreciative audience and divided critics.

Events today: "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Joseph Krips, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:15; William Clauson, folk singer, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Kiyozo Na Kayama, singer and samisen player, Carnege Recital Hall, 8:30.

Ski enthusiasts eager to enjoy some pre-holiday sport yesterday found themselves wondering whether a trip to the north country would be worth while. The lack of sufficient new cover on slopes in the Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains served to cool enthusiasm.
Avianca, Colombian National Airlines, has named an official with twenty years of company service as general manager in charge of operations in the United States.

A scheme by "three ex-convicts" to raise $500,000 for the filming of a life of St. Patrick, was described as a "fraud" yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. The state moved in Supreme Court for an order staying any further promotion of the venture, pending a decision on its request for a permanent injunction.

Net income of Stop Shop, Inc., in the sixteen weeks ended on Oct. 21 declined to $880,165, or 32 cents a share, from $1,391,425, or 50 cents a share last year. Sales of the grocery store chain rose to $91,336,918 from $86,884,629 a year earlier.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $5,000,000 to $40,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of require meats rose $49,000,000 to $553,000,000.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 14 -- The Board of Supervisors today voted salary increases totaling $1,440,000 for Westchester County's 3,600 employes. The raises will average 8 per cent.

Bob Ferguson of Ohio State again outdistanced Ernie Davis of Syracuse in their battle for post-season honors when he was named college football's "player of the year" yesterday in a United Press International poll.

BERNARD SHAW'S "The Dark Lady of the Sonnets" replaced "The Policeman" last evening as a curtain-raiser for "Androcles and the Lion" at the Phoenix Theatre. Although the playlet is a trifle, it is an iridescent and stylish one, and it is stylishly acted.

THE international constructivist sculptors showing work at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, are Robert Adams, from England; Coulentianos, from Greece, and Carrel Visser, from the Netherlands.
HALF way through "Signs Along the Cynic Route," Will Holt informs the audience there will be a fifteen-minute intermission, waves a finger and warns, "Remember, you're counted."
The magazine industry was criticized by a prominent advertising executive yesterday for attempting to sell quantity rather than quality circulation.
The Hall of Education at the New York World's Fair, which was originally planned as a $2,000,000 one-story building, will instead be a three-story structure costing $7,000,000.
The Orange County Board of Supervisors was told by its planning committee yesterday that the jet airport proposed for the New York metropolitan area should be built in the county.
New York University and Georgetown, each undefeated in four starts, will put their winning streaks on the line tonight in the college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

THERE are those, primarily indoor types who lament when a fly drowns in their martini, who constantly decry the intrepid sportsmen. They form leagues against honest gentlemen in red jackets who ride out in battalion strength against a fox, sneer at lonely anglers hip-deep in trout streams and shout "Murder, murder,", when a hunter brings down a buck.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mr. O'Konski, reached today by telephone at his office in Mercer, Wis., said that General Van Fleet was "indulging purely in name calling and I don't think it's worthy of a reply."
The City Council yesterday allowed the proposed 10-cent increase in taxicab fares to die quietly in committee.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 15 -- President Kennedy has promised more military assistance to South Vietnam in its fight against the Communists.

A member of the National Mediation Board reported yesterday that the Air Line Pilots Association and Pan American World Airways had agreed to resume neutral fact-finding sessions in their contract dispute.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- A member of Congress who said he had stayed awake at night wondering how to answer students' questions about the nation's need for atomic weapons gave his reply today at Rye High School.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 14 -- United Nations forces threw heavy mortar fire into the center of Elisabethville last night. The area around the post office came under a particularly heavy barrage.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- Darlene Hard of Montebello, Calif., and Margaret Smith of Victoria -- women's singles finalists for the last three weeks on the Australian tour -- advanced into the semi-finals of the New South Wales championships, which resumed today.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The House of Commons rejected tonight a Labor party effort to get it to censure the Government for pursuing what were called "equivocal and vacillating" policies on the Congo.

AVON PARK, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Two teams of professionals tied for the lead with three-under-par 69's today in the first round of the Scotch mixed foursomes golf tournament. The $25,000 competition is staged by Haig and Haig.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities in the nation aggregated $29,094,897,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
DUNEDIN, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Gary Player can don professional golf's money-winning crown this year.

Roger Maris and the Yankees' general manager, Roy Hamey, held what was described as an "amicable salary discussion of about half an hour" in the Yankee offices yesterday. But there was no contract signing.

Sales of the Brown Shoe Company reached a new high in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, but earnings declined from the level of the preceding year, the company announced in the annual report yesterday.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 14 -- Lehigh struck a blow for Eastern wrestling tonight. Coach Gerry Leeman's unbeaten Engineers defeated Oklahoma, one of the West's perennial powers, 17 -- 8, in a tension-packed dual meet.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The American Medical Association urged mankind today to "stop worrying about radioactive fall-out and concentrate on getting ready for Christmas."

The obvious arguments for and against the repeal of the Connally Reservation to our acceptance of the World Court have been repeated over and over again. However, the Dec. 9 letter of Frank E. Holman and Archibald B. Roosevelt advocating retention of the clause contains what appear to be four misleading positions that should be noted.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 14 -- An effort by British diplomats to bring about a phased cease-fire in Elisabethville, capital of Katanga, has been rebuffed by the Katangese government as well as by the United Nations, informed sources reported today.

THE Orchestra San Pietro of Naples, Italy, an ensemble of nineteen handsome young Neapolitans, completed its first North American tour last night. Its sixty-seventh and final concert was given in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Directors of the Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, decided yesterday to invite officials of the Marine Midland Corporation to discuss a proposal whereby Marine Midland would acquire Security National through an exchange of shares.

Production of lumber in the nation rose to 213,829,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday. This figure compared with 204,523,000 board feet in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Friday, Dec. 15 -- Adolf Eichmann was sentenced today to death by hanging for the killing of 6,000,000 Jews.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 14 (AP) -An influenza-like ailment that had hit scattered points in Missouri and Illinois spread to St. Louis today. City schools reported absenteeism ranging up to 30 per cent. Suburban schools have been affected several days.

Two venerable Scottish musical organizations -- the Massed Bands, Pipes, Drums and Dancers of the Scottish Regiments of the Argyll and Sutherland and the Royal Scots Greys -- will make their first American appearance next fall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) Sol A. Dann, Detroit attorney who has clashed with the management of Chrysler Corporation, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he planned to wage a proxy fight to oust Chrysler's present management.

The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved the sale of radio station WMGM by Loew's Theatres, Inc., to the Storer Broadcasting Company. The commission said the $10,950,000 sale price was the highest ever paid for a standard radio station.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed today that the 1962 Legislature let New York City take over rent control from the state next May 1.
Six mathematics books used by gifted Soviet high school students were issued in translation here yesterday for American teen-agers.
Eddie Erdelatz, the former head football coach at the United States Naval Academy, has joined a platoon of applicants for the coaching job at West Point, it was learned yesterday.

Interstate natural gas pipelines paid an average price of 15.44 cents a thousand cubic feet for natural gas purchased in 1960, according to a study released yesterday by H. Zinder Associates, Inc., gas and oil consulting concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A consultant for a House of Representatives select education subcommittee reported today that a "crash" cultural program was "absolutely necessary" if the United States was to "fill the vacuum we have created" and into which the Russians "have plunged with increasing success."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 14 -- New violence erupted here today as extremists continued to press their campaign against President Kennedy's scheduled visit Saturday.
With the immediate threat of a city-wide transit strike having been removed, plans were announced yesterday to resume contract negotiations on Monday in efforts to avert a New Years Day walkout.

Floridians and particularly Miamians are adding a few touches this holiday season to what has become speed boating's part of the Orange Bowl excitement. Before and after the football game Biscayne Bay, Indian Creek and even one of Florida's inland lakes will be the rendezvous of some of the country's top racing drivers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Following are excerpts from a Pentagon statement today outlining the Administration's civil defense proposals:
November was one of the best months in the history of the mutual funds industry, according to statistics issued yesterday by the Investment Company Institute.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- A need of 25,000,000,000 gallons of water a day for homes and business in the state in 1975 was forecast here today at a regional conference of the Legislature's temporary commission on water resources planning.

ELISABETHVILLE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- United Nations planes bombed and strafed a Katangese military concentration on the southern outskirts of Elisabethville today. The return fire of Katanga's troops appeared ineffectual.

NOT many corporation presidents get to their offices the way Mrs. Jean Larkin does. To arrive at her desk on the third floor at Angelo's Fillet House, 107 South Street, she must climb two flights of narrow woden stairs, then a final one that is exactly like the steep ladders leading up from a ship's engine room.
Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today more than $33,000,000 of common stock of companies getting a public market for their stock for the first time.

The site plan for a nine-acre shopping center on Route 9 in Ossining has been approved by the Planning Commission of the Town of Ossining. The project will have 90,000 square feet of store space and parking for about 600 cars.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- Greece celebrated the sixtieth birthday of King Paul today with an engaging mixture of traditional pomp and holiday gaiety.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Tanganyika became the United Nations' 104th member nation today.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Flashy but erratic Whitney Reed is rated the No. 1 tennis player in the nation in rankings released today by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Ada B. Eklof's Vir-Marie won the $4,000 Season's Greetings Purse at Pimlico today and paid $21.40, $9.60 and $6.40 for $2.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Kennedy sought tonight to end the United Nations' conflict with Katanga Province and to bring the leaders of the Congo together to establish a loose federation.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 14 -- The three princes of Laos met for five hours today in the Plaine des Jarres to discuss formation of a coalition government.

The United States monetary gold stock fell $51,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. At $16,925,000,000, the gold stock was down $842,000,000 since the first of the year.

In this day of mass movements it is well to remember that if the individual is not free then the society in which he lives is not free. This is what Bill of Rights Day means, as we celebrate it today.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Foreign Ministry said tonight that Portugal had proposed sending international observers to Goa and that the British Government was in favor of establish ing any such machinery that would be acceptable to both sides.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The University of Miami Hurricanes, 6-point underdogs, arrived today for their Liberty Bowl football game with Syracuse Saturday without their ailing quarterback, George Mira.

The desire of the United States to help emerging Africa catch up with the twentieth century has again been concretely demonstrated by the State Department's pledge of $225,000,000 to assist Nigeria in carrying out its five-year development program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy has an almost entirely new wardrobe for her week-end visit to Puerto Rico and South America with the President.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Business broadened among leading industrials in the stock market here today. Although gains were not large they were fairly numerous.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Kennedy has written to two Asian leaders asking them not to use force to gain territory they regard as parts of their countries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Administration is considering using Christmas Island, a British possession in the central Pacific as a site for atomic tests in the atmosphere.

TANGERINES make their first appearance of the season about the same time that department stores start putting up their Christmas decorations. They disappear from local markets soon after those decorations are taken down.
A program as intelligently chosen as the one Marten Sameth, baritone, sang in Carnegie Recital Hall last night could not fall to be musically attractive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The women of America are a great mystery to manufacturers trying to fathom why they buy one product instead of another, a Senate hearing was told today.
Students at schools and colleges inside and outside New York City are joining in giving to the Neediest Cases.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- Algeria's long-standing demands for independence from France were pressed today by African and Asian countries before the General Assembly's Political Committee.

THE leader of the National Civic Union, the largest of the opposition groups in the Dominican Republic, is a national symbol of the last thirty-one years of passive resistance to the dictatorial regime of the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The British seem more conscious of race problems and race relations these days than at any time since the war.
Construction of a $5,746,000 two-berth pier in Brooklyn was authorized yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Department store sales in the nation for the week ended Saturday, Dec. 9, were 1 per cent above the level of the year-earlier period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- The Federal Power Commission has ordered Humble Oil and Refining Company, Houston, Tex., to show cause why it should not apply for F.P.C. authorization to buy the properties of the Olin Gas Transmission Company, Monroe, La.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The atomic age arived at the icebound continent of Antarctica today, fifty years to the day after Roald Amundsen became the first man to reach the South Pole.
The Board of Education last night gave Deputy Superintendent Joseph R. Weiss the choice of resigning or being dismissed.
The National Arts Club will hold its annual New Year's Eve dance in the gallery of the club at 15 Gramercy Park for the benefit of its scholarship fund.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 84.7 on Wednesday from 84.6 on Tuesday.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Robert S. McNamara, Secretary of Defense, urged the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today to make a major effort to build conventional forces for checking Soviet pressure in Europe.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the statement of Adolf Eichmann in the Jerusalem District Court yesterday. (Transmission of text was delayed):
A vacationing patrolman in civilian clothes was shot dead last night by a liquor-store bandit he had captured.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Justice George J. Beldock was named Presiding Justice of the Second Department of the Appellate Division today by Governor Pockefeller.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Sales and earnings of manufacturing corporations declined slightly in the third quarter of this year from the second quarter level, two Government agencies reported today.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 14 -- Denmark told the Soviet Union today that Denmark alone had the right "to consider in what manner Danish security and defense can best be safeguarded."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Freight loadings last week were substantially above the 1960 levels, but below those of the preceding week of this year, the railroad and trucking industries reported today.

HARDLY an eyebrow was raised when Mickey Mantle signed a Yankee contract the other day for the trifling salary of $85,000 a year. He didn't even have to argue for it. The Bombers handed it over with the unconcern of a grocery clerk tossing out some extra green stamps. What once would have been regarded as a breath-taking venture into high finance has become pennyante stuff.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (UPI) -- George E. Schneider, the Sugar Bowl president, said today that the New Year's Day football game between Alabama and Arkansas "is creating the tightest scramble for tickets and rooms that I can remember."
The State of South Carolina borrowed $6,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.
Shares of the British and Dutch companies that control the world-wide Unilever interests were the first and second most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange again yesterday.
ALGIERS, Dec. 14 -- Frogmen linked to European extremists damaged an American built ship of the French navy in the Algiers harbor early today.
Agents of the Bureau of Internal Revenue carried out a series of raids yesterday in twenty-two cities in a nationwide crackdown against gamblers who failed to buy Federal occupational tax stamps.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- West German newspaper accounts of the Allied conferences in Paris this week have underscored the disunity among the Allies.

When Charles MacPhee unfolded a form letter from the Union Square branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank last night, a slip of paper fluttered out. On it were written these words: "Vault -- starts 84 left 2X (twice) past 84 to 52 right past 8 once second time stop left to 60."

PARIS, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said today that French air space was being denied to the United Nations because "the United Nations has bombed the city of Elisabethville and the French consulate was seriously damaged."

IT used to be a pleasure to ride around America in cramped, ornate and shaking little hotels. You got a wonderful panorama of the country that way, as well as some miscellaneous cinders in your observing eyes.
Nearly 1,000 persons attended the tenth anniversary dinner of the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee last night at the Commodore Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Just about the busiest man around here these days is Adlai E. Stevenson, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States has decided to lend Ghana $133,000,000 for the construction of a huge hydroelectric project on the Volta River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial production rose again in November breaking the record set in August, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Further developments in the automobile and steel industries in December indicate that the rise is continuing.

Installment credit delinquency experience improved significantly in October, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. The report was based on the association's survey of almost 300 banks across the nation.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- The national director said today that the Congress of Racial Equality would start anti-segregation sit-ins across the country, particularly in the Southwest and Midwest, after Jan. 1.
An as yet unnamed giant -- the largest merchantman ever built in this country -- will become waterborne Monday.

Political, educational, religious, governmental and civic representatives assembled in State Supreme Court yesterday to oppose the sale of the site of St. Luke's Women's Hospital to the Consolidated Edison Company.

HARTFORD, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Combustion tests of accoustical ceiling tile from Hartford Hospital, where a fire last Friday took sixteen lives, may have far- reaching effects on state fire safety regulations.
A citizens' group has proposed to the city its own privately financed program for rehabilitating homeless derelicts in the Cooper Square section of the Bowery.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 Jess M. Ritchie's ten-year feud with the Federal Government over his battery additive, ADX2, has quietly run out of juice.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- A rapid increase in the number of Blue Shield members over the age of 65 was announced today.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The United States will begin new diplomatic explorations of the Soviet Union's intentions regarding Berlin early in the new year. It will have the approval of thirteen other members of the Atlantic alliance and the grudging toleration of France under President de Gaulle.
The Coast Guard here yesterday announced changes in radio frequencies, effective Jan. 1, in its Atlantic Merchant Vessel Reporting System. The changes are designed to improve communications.
William Cluson, a singer of folk songs and ballads, who recently completed his third world singing tour, gave a program at Carnegie Hall last night.

The wrestler Antonino Rocca, distinguished for his primitive manners in the ring and his good manners out of it, was invited yesterday to appear before fifty high school students attending a conference of New York City's Commission on Intergroup Relations, at 80 Lafayette Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce forecast today an increase of 17 to 24 per cent in United States automobile production next year. The department's Business and Defense Services Administration said at least 1,000,000 more cars were expected to be built in 1962 than in 1961.
HONG KONG, Dec. 15 -- The diplomatic break between the Soviet Union and Albania was reported without comment today in Peiping's Jenmin Jih Pao.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Presidential emergency board that looked into a threat of a strike by Trans World Airlines pilots recommended today a reduction of jet aircraft crews from four to three persons.
THE winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association continues here today with individual contests divided into three flights for life masters, senior masters, and players of lesser rank.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Darlene Hard, the United States women's champion from Long Beach, Calif., was slated today as the No. 1 player in the United States Lawn Tennis Association rankings for the second straight year.
Net income of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28 dropped to $10,540,625 from $15,302,533 for the preceding year, the textile manufacturing concern reported yesterday.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Kevin Loughery led the St. John's Redmen of Brooklyn to a 64-59 victory over Kansas tonight in the second game of the Sunflower State basketball double-header. In the first-game, Kansas State defeated Marquette, 80 -- 64.

The prorated oil wells in Texas will be permitted to produce on a nine-day schedule in January, or the same rate as in December, the Texas Railroad Commission ruled yesterday. At present the state's permitted production is 2,854,898 barrels a day.
Roger Maris, baseball's home run king, normally reticent and unemotional, appeared deeply moved yesterday when told he had been named The Associated Press' male athlete of the year for 1961.
Some progress was reported yesterday in removing one of the last forseen obstacles to the closing of the sale of Channel 13 for educational television.

The Foreign, Defense and Finance Ministers of the fifteen nations of the North Atlantic Alliance have concluded their latest session in Paris with renewed determination to continue arming, not to wage war, but to wage peace, and to do so from a position of strength.
Early in 1962 there will be quite a bit of shifting away from some of the favorite stocks of 1961. That is the opinion of a leading analyst, Kenneth Ward, of Hayden, Stone Co.
The Department of Justice yesterday unexpectedly called off further cross-examination of defense witnesses in the Government's anti-merger suit against the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
A national legislative conference on the problem of commercialized smut was proposed here yesterday.

JOSEF KRIPS is a formidable technician, and he fully displayed his powers in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. But in the process of leading a smooth, accurate performance with the New York Philharmonic, he somewhat neglected musical values.
The first of the city's "snow streets" -- streets on which motorists will have to move their cars if the city declares an emergency because of a heavy snowfall -- will be designated on Monday.

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934, the following changes in the holdings of the officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies:
PURCHASE, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Tree surgeons removed a small plane today from the top of a sixty-foot tulip tree in dense woodland here.
BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Fred G. Pastore, the Internal Revenue agent credited with sending Bernard Goldfine to jail, resigned today under fire.

Events today: Metropolitan Opera, "Das Rheingold" at 2:30 P.M. and "L'Elisir d'Amore" at 8; Boston Symphony, Ernest Ansermet, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Concert Artists Guild, Town Hall, 2; New York Philharmonic, Joseph Krips, conductor, Felicia Montealegre, narrator, vocal soloists and Westminster Choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Robert Kurka's "The Good Soldier Schweik," Robert De Cormier, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; Theatrum Instrumentorum, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Theodore and the Ted Curson Quartet, Judson Hall, 8:30.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Foreign Minister Golda Meir hinted today that Israel -- under certain conditions -- might be willing to take back some Arab refugees displaced by the 1948 war.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Chicago's Superintendent of Schools, replying to a Federal court suit, asserted today that there was no segregation in the public schools of Chicago.

At a special meeting held in lieu of the annual meeting in Montclair, N.J., yesterday, stockholders of Cinerama, Inc., were told that net income for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 rose to $476,000, or 17 cents a share, from $175,000, or 6 cents a share, for the 1960 period.

Four corporations and four of their officials were fined a total of $186,000 yesterday by Judge Jacob Mishler, in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, for contempt of court growing out of the violation of a consent decree against price fixing in chemicals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two Virginia men today on charges they conspired to misuse national defense information belonging to the Navy Department.
American churchgoers were called upon yesterday to "seek a Christian course of action" in confronting the "ominous" threat of atomic attack.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 15 -- President Kennedy received an enthusiastic welcome from hundreds of thousands in this city today as he started his weekend journey to Latin America.
Frank Robinson, whose whip-like bat helped the Cincinnati Reds to the National League 1961 pennant, was the league's top slugger, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

A pair of prized Arabian horses arrived here by ship from Morocco yesterday as a gift to an American youth who had put meaning into the People-to-People program while living in the North African kingdom.

A final ruling in an old controversy involving a bargaining issue between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association was issued yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.
At a meeting this week in the home of Mrs. Edward M.M. Warburg, members of the executive committee for the Diamond Ball discussed plans for the event arranged for Jan. 31 at the Plaza.
Jail terms were imposed yesterday on three of eight Bronx youths who had pleaded guilty to second-degree manslaughter last October in the fatal beating of a 20-year-old shipping clerk.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Dec. 15 -- Few countries exist where an accurate estimate of the situation and a forecast of the future are more critical to us than Brazil. And few countries exist where it is more difficult to distinguish rumor from reality and premise from promise.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 70 cents a bale off to 15 cents up yesterday, with the near months showing the most weakness.
A bill backed by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. to prohibit smoking in all but certain designated areas of public and voluntary hospitals will be submitted to the City Council Tuesday.
It is exactly a year since two airliners collided over Staten Island killing 134 persons in history's worst air disaster.

With traders evening up for the week-end, most commodity futures prices rose on the New York exchanges yesterday. Adjustments in expiring December deliveries accounted for a good part of the activity in some products.

Buildings Commissioner Peter J. Reidy announced yesterday that the Department of Buildings would not accept plans for construction and alterations on Monday to give the departments personnel time to process the huge volume of applications that were submitted before the new zoning regulations became effective.

KITWE, Northern Rhodesia, Dec. 15 -- Sir Roy Welensky, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland, said today he feared that prolonged guerrilla warfare would follow if the United Nations forces took control of Elisabethville, the capital of the Congo province of Katanga.
HOUSTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- John Hadl, the Kansas quarterback, will play in the Bluebonnet Bowl football game against Rice tomorrow despite a charge that he already has signed a pro contract.
MIAMI, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Two North Carolina industrialists and five other men were rescued today after riding a disabled amphibious plane for thirteen and one-half hours in choppy Bahama Island waters.

IT is "Nutcracker" time again at the City Center. The New York City Ballet last night turned the repertory over, at least for the week-end to its annual presentation of George Balanchine's full-length version of the famous Tchaikovsky Christmas piece for the youngsters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm production this year was 2 per cent below the record 1960 crop but exceeded the levels of all previous years.
A quiet optimism on the part of most of the competitors prevailed yesterday as the pairings for the United States chess championship, were drawn.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 15 -- About the only thing that one can say will certainly happen in Goa tomorrow is that the sun will shine.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 15 -- The nation's first atomic-powered aid to navigation, a seven-ton, electric sea buoy, began flashing its light here this morning.
The state Attorney General's chief prosecutor of slum landlords clashed with his counterpart from the city Corporation Counsel's office yesterday at a hearing in Supreme Court.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 15 -- The New Jersey Public Market Commission adopted a resolution today to float a $15,000,000 bond issue to build a food distribution center in the Hudson County meadows.

One important exhibition among the week's openings will no doubt divert a number of today's shoppers from their Christmas missions. It is the Whitney Museum's "Annual Exhibition of Contemporary American Painting.''
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 15 -- The United States sought here today to promote direct negotiations between President Moise Tshombe of Katanga and Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- The General Assembly rejected today a proposal to seat Communist China in the United Nations. The vote was 48 against the proposal and 37 for it. Nineteen nations abstained.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Speculators shopping around for more comfortable positions twisted the grain futures market into a mixed range today on the Board of Trade.

Ed Johnson scored 20 points last night in pacing Long Island University to a Tri-State League basketball triumph over Hunter College, 69 -- 68, at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn. Hal Mayerson of Hunter scored 29 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A New York physician has invented a method of obtaining internal pictures of the body with sound waves. He expects it to be especially valuable in the diagnosis of brain tumors.
Japan and Hong Kong are understandably indignant at the possibility that they may have to pay a higher tariff on their cotton textile exports to this country.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The West German Government voiced its approval today of the Israeli court's death sentence on Adolf Eichmann and appeared to be relieved that the trial was over.

SEBRING, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Teams led by Ted Kroll and Johnny Pott shared the 36-hole lead at 138 today in the $25,000 Scotch mixed foursome golf tournament. The 72-hole event is being staged by Haig and Haig.

The board of directors of Mead Johnson Co. proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common and preferred stocks. It also announced that it intended to increase the cash dividend on the common stock.
The head of two large American scientific societies has proposed that the effort to understand and, if possible, control the weather be international.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The trade that sent Ernie Davis, Syracuse's all-America halfback, to the Cleveland Browns yesterday actually was made just before the National Football League's Dec. 4 draft, it was learned today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- The General Assembly's Budgetary Committee recommended today an $80,000,000 appropriation to cover the costs of the United Nations military operation in the Congo through next June.

The United Nations General Assembly yesterday again barred Communist China from a seat in the world organization. A vote on the Soviet resolution that called for giving the Chinese Communist regime the seat now occupied by Nationalist China received 37 votes, less than a majority; there were 48 votes against and 19 abstained.
The system of selecting Federal grand juries in the Southern District of New York from voter registration lists was held yesterday to be proper and constitutional.

DURING intermittent duty with this newspaper over the last year, I have reported on some 170 exhibitions. A great many others were allowed to die painlessly without comment. The 170 ranged from the magnificently idiotic to the magnificent.

Recently some academic people in the Boston area expressed in The Times their misgivings about the public attention being given bomb shelters. We share these misgivings. Much of the current discussion of shelters seems to us to encourage an unrealistic hope that the horrors of nuclear war can be significantly mitigated by civil defense measures of the sort used in World War II.

The price of silver advanced again yesterday in New York and London. Handy and Harmon, Inc., leading suppliers of the metal to industrial users in the United States, set a price of $1.04 3/4 an ounce, up 1 1/2 cents from Thursday. The London spot price was fixed at 87 1/4 pence ($1.0218), up 1/4 penny.
DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Henry Hank knocked down Chic Calderwood of Scotland with a flurry of punches to the stomach tonight and went on to score a unanimous decision in their ten-round bout.

VIENNA, Dec. 15 -- The Austrian, Swiss and Swedish Governments proposed today the opening of negotiations for association with the European Economic Community. The proposal was made to Dr. Ludwig Erhard, president of the Community, or Common Market.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Gioacchino Failla, one of the nation's leading experts on radiological measurements, was killed today in an automobile accident in near-by Downers Grove Township.

One of the world's largest simulator laboratories, which has been "flying" aircraft and "firing" missiles before they were built, has been made available to industry for pre-production testing of industrial products and processes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The House Veterans Affairs Committee will review the policy of calling up National Guardsmen and Reserves for "cold war" duty, Representative Olin E. Teague said today.

A COLLECTION of fine Indian jewelry, designed by some of that country's outstanding artisans, will be on sale at Alexander's department stores on Monday. The traditional pieces in 16-karat gold include handmade rings, earrings, necklaces and bracelets, with precious stones worked into the designs.
About 300 city employes in unclassified and exempt Civil Service categories had submitted their resignations by yesterday noon, the deadline specified by Mayor Wagner.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra served notice today it would not play Sunday's scheduled performance of Handel's "Messiah."

WHETHER she is a weather girl, the wife of young Dr. Malone or an operatic singer who is on camera for only five and one-half minutes a season, television's woman performer must pass a rigid fashion inspection before she steps before the camera.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Edward Guillaume, 69-year-old former circus clown was sentenced to fifteen to twenty years in state Prison today in the axe slaying of Gabrielle Nelson, 49, last Oct. 9.

ANYONE who wants to feel a pre-Christmas glow might stop at 793 Lexington Avenue (between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Street), where the window of the Phoenix-Pan American Shop is atwinkle with glittering Mexican Christmas ornaments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- An Army spokesman said today that the backlog of allotment checks that had caused mailing delays earlier this month was relieved today. This means, the spokesman said, that all allotment applications that were filed before Dec. 6 had been acted upon.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector) Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of the death sentence against Adolf Eichmann, read today by Presiding Justice Moshe Landau of a special Israeli court:

The West Milford, N.J. Board of Education sold yesterday $1,550,000 of serial bonds due from 1963 to 1982 to B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc. and associates. The price paid was 100.05 for obligations bearing interest of 4 1/8 per cent. On reoffering, the securities were priced to yield 2.1 to 4.1 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- France closed her skies today to aircraft, presumably including United States Air Force planes, ferrying supplies or men to the United Nations forces fighting in the secessionist Congo province of Katanga.
PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 16 -- Premier Michel Debre and his Government emerged today politically bruised but still in office from the final debate of the National Assembly's present session.

Abhorred by all mankind and cast off by his own people, a cadaverous-looking but still arrogant former Nazi official named Adolf Eichmann has been sentenced by an Israeli court in Jerusalem to die on the gallows for his part in the unparalleled crimes of the Nazi regime.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- The Commerce Department said today that it would use the suggestion that multilingual signs be installed for foreign visitors.

The dominant factor in the new capital market next week is expected to be a $155,000,000 bond offering of the Florida Turnpike Authority. The forty-year obligations are tentatively slated for offering by Dillon, Read Co. and associates.
AN almost story-like quality pervaded "The Peace Corps in Tanganyika," an expertly done hour on Channel 4 last night. The program looked more for the motivation than for the mechanics of the corps.

Where will Mac the Knife and all the others go? Where will that unique band of beggars, thieves, cutthroats and tarts reside? After five memorable years in Greenwich Village, Mac, Polly, Jenny and the rest are leaving.
A back-to-nature movement for monkeys at the Bronx Zoo has apparently proved that they are city slickers.
Officers and unlicensed seamen of two maritime unions yesterday protested the Department of Agriculture's chartering policies by picketing a British flag ship in Lake Charles La.

L.O. Koven Brother, Inc., boilmakers, have sold their Jersey City plant consisting of five buildings with 148,000 square feet of space. The company moved to Dover, N.J., in 1959. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker in the Jersey City sale.

With three Hollywood features already to his credit, after a quiet shift from television, John Frankenheimer, the 30-year-old director, visited town recently to scout locations for a fourth, even as a fifth project enters the blueprint stage.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 15 -- United Nations troops pushed toward the heart of Elisabethville today in a major drive for control of the capital of secessionist Katanga Province.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:

The Times editorial "The Lost Citizen" on Dec. 9 should be reprinted daily. You are right when you say that New York needs interested and active citizens. You are right when you say that New York has first-class talent but doesn't always use it.
GREELEY, Colo., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Manslaughter charges were filed today against Duane Russell Harms, driver of a school bus that carried twenty children to their deaths at a railroad crossing.

One of the Wall Street's oldlest brokerage concerns Henry Clews Co., which dates back to 1877, will be merged on Jan. 1 into another old timer, Abbott, Proctor Paine, whose origin goes back to the Eighteen Eighties, according to plans announced yesterday.

Herman C. Nolen, president of McKesson Robbins, denied in a statement yesterday a Washington report by United Press International that he had endorsed the bill on drugs submitted by Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee. The bill would require drugs to be sold under generic rather than brand names.
HOUSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Rice and Kansas, two football teams that produced winning seasons after shaky starts, meet tomorrow in the third annual Bluebonnet Bowl game.

Joseph R. Weiss, who has been suspended as Deputy Superintendent of Schools on charges of improper conduct, said yesterday he had not decided whether to resign or fight dismissal by the Board of Education.
The executive committee of the New York County Republican organization endorsed yesterday the direct election of district leaders.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- The United States is now trying to soothe some of the political wounds opened in Japan by Washington's plans for an additional tax on imported cotton goods.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 15 -- President Kennedy will arrive in Venezuela tomorrow at a time when Venezuelans are experiencing political strife and economic recession.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Cliff Hagan scored the key points tonight as the St. Louis Hawks beat the New York Knickerbockers, 120 -- 108. The loss was the Knicks' seventh straight in the National Basketball Association.
The deadline for receiving ballots in the union representation election for public school teachers was extended last night to 1 P.M. today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Andover Academy and Taft School will meet tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. in Princeton University's Baker Rink in the final of the Lawrenceville School's fourteenth annual invitation hockey tournament.
A Municipal Court Justice ruled yesterday that a victim of an auto accident is obliged to inform the defendant's insurance company that he is suing for damages.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that his coming budget would include $5,500,000 for a Staten Island research institute on mental retardation and $2,500,000 for three state programs to aid mentally disturbed children and adults.
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 15 -- The threat of more Negro demonstrations mounted tonight as negotiations to resolve a weeklong racial controversy continued, with no agreement in sight.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Dec. 9 -- The flight from Cairo to Khartoum takes just three and a half hours, but the plane puts down, usually in the dead of night, in a different world. The air in December is balmy and the atmosphere is relaxed.

FOR as little as 29 cents, shoppers now can buy four big, juicy Florida grapefruit in many chain and independent stores here. The citrus fruit, which really does grow in bunches like the grape from which it gets its name, is not only a bargain, but also outstanding in quality.
A tribute to fallen buddies of World War II accompanied a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Washington Senators traded an outfielder, Marty Keough, today and another player to be named later to the Cincinnati Reds for a catcher, Bob Schmidt, and a pitcher, Dave Stenhouse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A biscuit made of crushed wheat may be destined in the era of possible nuclear warfare for the notoriety that World War II gave to Spam, the crushed meat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, pledged his support today of legislation, if it is found necessary, to correct what he termed "scandalous packaging practices."

The stock market was a thoroughly scrambled affair yesterday. After moving back and forth, stocks closed off moderately on average on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading volume was the smallest since Nov. 1.
A television repair man pleaded guilty yesterday to failure to answer fifty-one traffic violations, which included eleven summonses for speeding.

An exhibition and sale of ceramics by the students and instructors of Henry Street Settlement House, 265 Henry Street, continues through Friday. Handmade decorative accessories for the home range from $1 to $30.
Producer stocks of refined copper in the United States rose to 77,646 tons at the end of November from 76,785 tons a month earlier, according to data from the Copper Institute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- R. Sargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, today upheld his agency's rule against aiding private missionary organizations.

Organized labor has demonstrated a sense of social responsibility with its promise of expanded help for the country's two million migratory and seasonal farm workers, the most exploited members of the labor force. No group is so much in need of outside aid if its standards are to be brought up from levels disgracefully close to peonage.
Three hold-up suspects were captured in Brooklyn last night as they sat in a car with two victims of a $5,000 robbery.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The stock market quieted down here today after a busy four days. Thick fog may have accounted for the sparse attendance in the exchange and the fall in turnover.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation recovered today three data books valued at $5,000,000 that were stolen from a General Electric Company plant at Rome, Ga., in September.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 15 -Portuguese police units have withdrawn from at least four posts along the Indian frontier and may evacuate others, it was officially made known today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Fulbert Youlou, President of the Congo Republic, the former French Congo, sent a request to the Security Council today for an immediate meeting to discuss a cease-fire in Katanga.

A group of Eastern and Mid-western investors headed by Robert Sealfon, a New York industrialist, has bought 100 per cent of the capital stock of the Hoffman Beverage Company of Newark, N.J., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Pabst Brewing Company.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 15 -- Adolf Eichmann's hopes for a successful appeal from the death sentence given him today were kept alive by the Israeli Special Court's ruling that this sentence was not mandatory.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Yale's sophomore-studded basketball team staved off Brown's second-half rally tonight for a 77-62 victory in its Ivy League opener.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- President Kennedy arranged today for Vice President Johnson to be kept posted "on all matters of importance" while Mr. Kennedy is away on his trip to Latin America.
Billy Pickett of New York, a last-minute substitute for Florentino Fernandez of Cuba, will face the middleweight champion of the British Empire, Dick Tiger, tonight.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pending a probation report, sentences have been deferred for the president and four salesmen of a New York concern who pleaded guilty yesterday to having been involved in an iron ore stock swindle last year.

New York University's unbeaten basketball team established a Madison Square Garden collegiate scoring record last night when it romped to a 122-59 triumph over Syracuse in the opening game of a double-header.

A brisk business was done in high grade corporate and local government bonds in over-the-counter trading yesterday but investors continued to be indifferent to Treasury securities of more than short term.

George M. Weiss yesterday peeled off a few more big bills from the Mets' seemingly limitless bankroll when he purchased Charlie Neal, a slickfielding second baseman, from the Los Angeles Dodgers. As was to be expected, Walter O'Malley's Dodgers drove a sharp bargain.

Herbert Wendt tells the story of the birth and development of races and peoples in a new work called "It Began in Babel." An American edition of it will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Feb. 1. Translated from the German by James Kirkup, it is based on the findings of ethnologists and anthropologists, and of missionaries, explorers and adventurers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded a contract today for development of a 2,500-ton rocket to be used to send a three-man expedition to the moon.

Mayor Wagner pledged New York City's support yesterday to the joint New York-New Jersey-Connecticut effort to solve the metropolitan area's commuter woes and to frame a long-range comprehensive transportation plan for the region.
The Packard-Bell Electronics Corporation, Los Angeles, reported yesterday a net loss of $9,511,162 on sales of $31,887,807 in its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15 -- The police used tear gas today to break up demonstrations by 1,500 Negroes in the main business district of the city. Fifty Negroes were arrested on charges of having been disorderly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission has authorized the importation of a limited amount of natural gas from Canada at a point near Niagara Falls, N.Y.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Some of the Negroes marched to Baton Rouge today from Southern University. Some traveled in buses operated by a Negro company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States applied pressure on President Moise Tshombe of Katanga today to come to terms with the central Government on unification of the Congo.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Ernie Davis held the spotlight today as the football squads of Syracuse and Miami of Florida, wrapped warmly against icy blasts out of the north, completed preparations for tomorrow's Liberty Bowl game.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 15 -- One of the most intriguing experiments the European dance world has seen in several years is in progress here in the subsidized Theatre Royale de la Monnaie.
Pre-holiday air travel was in turmoil yesterday as a result of an abrupt Government suspension of special transcontinental fares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Explorer XII, probably the most prolific scientific satellite yet launched by the United States, has obliged scientists to revise their theories on the composition of one of the radiation belts girdling the earth.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he would speak at political and nonpolitical functions in seven states in the next six months.

The appointment of Rabbi Alan W. Miller as spiritual leader of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism here was announced yesterday by Sandor Hirsch, chairman of the board of trustees of the congregation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Prime Minister Julius K. Nyerere of Tanganyika expressed fears today that his nation's independence might slow efforts to achieve an East African federation.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 15 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province said today that he was willing to meet on neutral ground with Cyrille Adoula, Premier of the Congolese central Government.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- President Kennedy's visit in Venezuela was reported tonight by the Havana radio in details almost totally at variance with the news coming directly out of Caracas.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- This has been a difficult week for the West. In the face of continuing Soviet pressure throughout the world and a slowly deteriorating situation at its focal point, Berlin, the great powers of the Atlantic Alliance found themselves caught in basic disagreements over policies and over the means of carrying them out.

GOOD letters ate like pearls; they are admirable in themselves, but their value is infinitely enhanced when there is a string of them. BRIDGE hands of a certain type sometimes seem to run in streaks, just as do good and bad cards for the rubber bridge player. Last week seems to have been a week for the play known to bridge-players as the coup.
President Kennedy's liberal trade program, which in its broad outlines has had remarkably smooth sailing so far, appears headed for stiff opposition both at home and abroad.
WATERTOWN, N.Y. Dec. 16 -- More than 77,000 National Guardsmen and reservists from the First Army area will undergo training at near-by Camp Drum next summer.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 16 -- President Kennedy arrived in Caracas today and received a cheering welcome. He issued a call for the "elimination of all tyranny" from South America.

John Hay Whitney, former Ambassador to Great Britain, and his sister, Mrs. Charles S. Payson have each contributed $5,000,000 to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Fund for Medical Progress.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 16 -- President Ngo Dinh Dien's Government appeared this week to have taken a firmer grasp of the problem of growing Communist subversion than at any time since the Communist guerrillas opened a new military campaign in South Vietnam nearly a year ago.

IN the year that is fast dying, a last-minute four-disk tribute to the sesquicentennial of Liszt's birth has been offered by Westminster. The most interesting of the disks, which are issued individually, is one planned and made five years ago for this year's anniversary.
The ban on speeches by known Communists on city college campuses was reversed yesterday.
Squadron A and Westchester played to an 8-8 four-period tie and Connecticut defeated Brookville, 9 -- 3 last night in the weekly indoor polo doubleheader at the Squadron A Armory.
NEWTON N. MINOW, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, continues to makes headlines with his controversial exercise of the office of the head of the regulatory agency.

The two-month decline in Cleveland-Lorain steel production halted at the end of November when the index of output showed a nominal one-point increase to 105 (1957-1959 equals 100). As a result of the fairly substantial downturn this fall at Cleveland and Lorain mills, the index of local output has been below the industry-wide average for several weeks.

Fordham's basketball team stopped previously undefeated Connecticut, 85 -- 68, last night before 2,500 at the Fordham Gymnasium. It was the Rams' fourth victory in six games. Connecticut had won four in a row.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 16 -- Israel is holding up the release of Adolf Eichmann's prison memoirs, his assistant defense counsel said today.

WHEN George N. Shuster retired in 1959 after twenty years as president of Hunter College, his colleagues and friends published in tribute to him, a small but notable volume of his essays and addresses, "Education and Moral Wisdom."

ONE of the most remarkable novels I've ever discussed in these pages was "Angry Harvest," published here in 1958. It focused on the relationship between a middle-aged Polish peasant and a young Jewish girl whom he hides from the Germans during the war years.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 -- The No. 1 post position, an acknowledged disadvantage in sprints here this season, was no deterrent to the Jagma Stable's Gyro in the twenty-first running of the City of Coral Gables Handicap today at Tropical Park.

Among the young women who will be honored at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball on Dec. 21 at the Waldorf-Astoria will be the Misses Mary Elizabeth Stewart, Daryl Acheson, Diane Emily Mertens, Edith Fabyan Read, Josephine Marie Christine Bergen and Deborah Saltonstall Pease.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 16 -- Prof. Arne Tiselius, head of the Nobel Foundation, suggested today that scientists themselves might help deter the misuse of science if they would speak out more.

Robert A. Glasser, the New York State harness racing commissioner, confirmed last night reports that his office was considering concurrent spring meetings for Roose velt and Yonkers Raceways.

James Fenner took a position opposed to Federal subsidy for the arts. Mr. Fenner said, in part, "If the Met cannot operate within its income from contributions and ticket sales, why not let it die like any other money-losing operation?"

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Syracuse spotted Miami of Florida a 14-0 lead in the first half of the Liberty Bowl football game today. Then the Orangemen, with Ernie Davis leading the charge, roared back to a 15-14 victory after the intermission.

THE New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has put into effect a reduced-fare plan that is designed to make every day Excursion Day. The big attractions of the new plan are that tickets are valid on any train any day and that the round-trip rate is equivalent to the one-way coach fare, plus 55 cents.

MANILA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Gabriel (Flash) Elorde, fast-punching Filipino southpaw, stopped Sergio Caprari of Italy in 2:22 of the first round tonight and retained his world junior lightweight championship.

Banks are quiet, businesslike places and, through the years, bank advertising also has been quiet and businesslike. The savings banks issued gentle homilies about the virtues of thrift while the big commercial banks emphasized their efficiency and reliability.

A significant step toward world cooperation in the peaceful uses of outer space was taken by the United Nations last week when the 103-member Political Committee of the General Assembly, including Russia, unanimously approved a resolution calling for the internationalization of space and world cooperation in the use of space satellites for the development of weather forecasting and communication.

The entry list for the Westminster Kennel Club dog show in Madison Square Garden closed on Friday with 2,571 dogs in 116 breeds or varieties of breeds. The event will be on Feb. 12 and 13. Poodles and dachshunds led the list with 188 and 158 dogs, respectively.

DANBURY, Conn, Dec. 16 -- A fifteen-mile section of Interstate Route 84, to be known as the Yankee Expressway, was opened here today.

The week-end trip that President Kennedy is making to Venezuela and Colombia is an effort to dramatize the Alliance for Progress plan for Latin America, a plan potentially as important historically as the Good Neighbor policy.

Department store sales in the Federal Reserve district for the week ened Dec. 9 showed an increase of 4 per cent, as compared with the 1960 period. The San Diego area showed the largest gain, while small losses were registered in downtown Los Angeles and Portland.

The countryman realizes that snow nourishes and protects his fields and pastures and even helps to seal and insulate his house and barns against the cruelest bite of winter. The youngster with a sled and the grownup with a pair of skis know the particular satisfaction of a snowclad slope.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Cornell's hockey team beat Yale for the first time in fifty years today when the Big Red scored a 2-1 victory over the visiting Elis.

An advisory group of experts to assist the Government in its role in the development of a commercial supersonic transport plane was named last week.

The South Asian and Far Eastern operations of the Experiment in International Living will be furthered by the proceeds of an invitation benefit on Jan. 30. The performance of the Ceylon National Dancers at the Hunter College Playhouse has been chosen for the event.
