Kirby, who lost control of Alleghany Corporation last spring to the two Murchison brothers of Dallas, Texas, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to hold a broad hearing on a plan to split the stock of Investors Diversified Services, Inc.

CADAQUES is a small fishing village in northeast Spain on the beautiful Costa Brava. Tile-roofed, whitewashed stone houses and buildings of pure folk architecture are terraced up the hills rising from the town's lovely beach. Many people from countries other than Spain make their home there, among these Peter G. Harnden, an American architect who lives and works in Europe, his wife and their four children.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Rancho Rio Honodo's Indian Blood won the $15,000 added San Bruno Handicap today by two and a half lengths from Poland China at Tanforan. The favored Native Diver finished third in the field of seven 2-year-olds and suffered the first defeat of his career.

A GOOD many young people may already have met, courtesy of approved reading lists or their parents' libraries, one of the most famous detectives in fiction, Hercule Poirot. ABOUT this time every year there comes a falling off in the number of recitals and orchestral concerts in our major halls of music. The Christmas season is hard upon us, and the public is less disposed than usual to attend to symphonies, sonatas, and the like.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- Less than eighty airline miles from the sun-drenched Mexican border, skiers are careering down the piney slopes of snow-capped Mount Lemmon. This 9,150-foot pinnacle of the Santa Catalina Mountains, less than an hour's drive from Tucson, boasts of being the southernmost ski center in the United States.

THERE is no better balm for the theatre's fevered brow than a few fine works. Because some admirable productions have graced the first half of the season, Broadway is brighter and more optimistic than in several years.

SARASOTA, Fla. -Some 700 owners of trailers in the greatest of trailer parks, in the heart of this city, once more this year have intensively decorated their premises and streets with religious and festive phases of the Christmas Story, so that Mobile Home Park will be a spectacle attracting, in all probability, 100,000 motorists.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bill Kirvan paced the Navy basketball team to a 70-61 victory over Princeton today.
TORONTO, Dec. 16 -- George Armstrong scored three goals tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs subdued the New York Rangers, 4 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game.

The new 29,250-ton tanker Gulf Supreme -- the final unit in a four-year, $120,000,000 fleet-modernization program of the Gulf Oil Corporation's domestic fleet -- is now nearing the end of the first leg of her initial commercial voyage.
NEWARK, Dec. 16 -- The battle to block the Port of New York Authority's plan for a major jetport in Morris County has been won, its principal opponents said today.

TRENTON, N.J. -- The historic events of this nation's first Christmas can be retraced by visitors as the area celebrates the 185th anniversary of General Washington's famous crossing of the Delaware River on Christmas eve in 1776.
WASHINGTON Dec. 16 -- The Kennedy Administration revealed today safeguards contained in its agreement to lend $133,000,000 for the construction of a hydroelectric project on the Volta River in Ghana.

ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., 264 other Negroes and one white youth were arrested today as they marched on City Hall for a prayer dem onstration. All were jailed. There was no violence, despite the tension aroused by week-long racial controversy and the breakdown of negotiations between white and Negro leaders aimed at restoring this city of 56,000 persons to normal.

IN a brief White House ceremony one day last September, John F. Kennedy signed the bill giving permanent status to the Peace Corps. After praising the "bipartisan effort" behind the bill in Congress, the President grinned slightly, glanced at the restless, well-tailored official to his right, and concluded: "Also, I want to express my esteem for the most effective lobbyist on the Washington scene, Mr. Sargent Shriver."
DALLAS, Dec. 16 -- Hayden Fry, a 32-year-old backfield coach at Arkansas, was hired today to restore Southern Methodist University to national football prominence.

EXPANDED facilities for the Department of Photography at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio, are under construction and will be occupied next September, according to announcement by Clarence H. White Jr., head of the department.

As part of his second program with the Boston Symphony in Carnegie Hall this season, Ernest Ansermet yesterday afternoon conducted a novelty by his Swiss countryman, Frank Martin, called Etudes for String Orchestra.

HAROLD SCHONBERG'S article on the effect of "misplaced scholarship" upon performances of Bach's B minor Mass was refreshing. C.S. LEWIS' experiment in criticism reverses the traditional process employed in judging books. Instead of the critic judging a book to be good or bad and then considering whether it is worth careful reading, he suggests that the critic decide whether the book is good or bad by considering whether it admits of careful reading.

But in this promotion of biggest, the highest or the fastest, one of the greatest pleasures of skiing is being neglected.

The new shelter program of the Kennedy Administration is realistic. It does not attempt to provide protection against all effects of a possible thermonuclear attack, but only against those effects against which protection is feasible -- namely, radioactive fall-out. For this purpose Congress will be asked for an appropriation of $700,000,000, most of which would be used to provide community shelters rather than individual hide-outs.
Archbishop Molloy High of Queens retained Division I honors yesterday in the seventh annual Mount St. Michael Polar Bear Relays on the school's outdoor board track in the Bronx.

WARSAW, Dec. 17 -- After four years of docile acquiesence in its thinking, the intellectual community in Poland is again caught up in a heady cult of freedom.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 17 (AP) -The president of the United States Figure Skating Association and his partner won the veterans dance final today in the North Atlantic States sub-sectional figure skating championship.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 17 -- At least 285 persons, most of them children, were killed and 600 injured today in a fire that swept a circus tent at suburban Niteroi this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Reserve "fillers," drawn from so-called control groups, and specialized non-tactical units, such as Army security agency or civil affairs detachments, provided most of the malcontents in the recent mobilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The principal coffee-growing and coffee-drinking nations of the world published today the proposed terms of a far-reaching international agreement to relieve the chronic distress of economies that are tied to that basic commodity.

The Port of New York tomorrow will greet the only new passenger liner to enter North Atlantic service this year. The liner is the 27,300-ton Empress of Canada, the new flagship of the Canadian Pacific fleet.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Some of the sixty-four Negroes jailed here after anti-segregation demonstrations resumed eating jail meals tonight, the sheriff's office said.
THE annual winter tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association ended at the Statler-Hilton Hotel last night with 212 pairs competing in the second of two sessions of the pair contest.
The construction of a sanctuary to house some of the Dead Sea Scrolls has been started in Jerusalem.
AT Hertz Rent-All, which opens today, virtually everything is for hire but Father Christmas.

A dispute over who should handle the problems of voters in sections of the East Side of Manhattan has arisen between Representatives Alfred E. Santangelo, a Democrat, and John V. Lindsay, a Republican.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec 17 (UPI) -- Heidi Biebl o Germany won the women giant slalom today in the seventh Criterium of the Firs Snow ski meet.
A state appropriation of $500,000 will be sought to match Federal funds to help rehabilitate three historic shrines in the city.

Your editorial page of Dec. 4 presents an interesting study in contrasts. The column by C.L. Sulzberger, generalizing from his current Latin-American trip, advocates a lessening of economic aid for cities -- especially criticizing a slum clearance program as a misallocation of resources -- in order to narrow the gap, and consequent tensions, between rural and urban areas in under-developed countries.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- President Kennedy's interview with Izvestia's editor is still fresh news in the remote areas of the Communist world nearly three weeks after it was published.

THE Giants barely caught the plane for Green Bay and the championship playoff. They almost missed it in the Yankee Stadium gloom yesterday. But they hauled themselves aboard through the back door in a final frantic clamber. To do it they pushed aside the Eager Eagles of Philadelphia, who were holding stand-by tickets.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 17 -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued today by President Kennedy and President Romulo Betancourt after their talks here:

The Teachers Union said yesterday that it would cooperate with the United Federation of Teachers to gain "a $6,000 to $12,000 basic compromise salary scale" in the city schools. Salaries range now from $4,800 to $9,450.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 17 -- A notice of appeal against the judgment and death sentence imposed on Adolf Eichmann, the former Nazi officer convicted of a major role in the killing of 6,000,000 Jews, was filed today in the Jerusalem District Court.

A full day of radio from the services of the British Broadcasting Corporation was carried yesterday over WBAI on the frequency modulation dial. It was an altogether suitable tribute to one of the world's superior sound broadcasting operations, one that still has pursued a rare degree of quality despite the competitive onslaught of television.

Trading in the over-the-counter market was lively last week from a volume standpoint, but the price trend was highly erratic. Most dealers stressed that there was an unusual amount of churning and considerable tax selling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, was asked the other day how the "Soviet trick of getting U.N. membership for Communist satellites," such as Outer Mongolia, could be countered.
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 17 -- A leadership conflict developed today between the two regional organizations in the Negro protest movement here.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 17 -- Thirty-two men were named today the 1962 Rhodes scholars from the United States.

The property at 1420 to 1426 Third Avenue, a plot 104 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Eighty-first Street, has been assembled by the Rawal Realty Corporation, Julius Raynes, president. The plot, which contains three five-story apartment and store buildings, was acquired in two parcels.
MADRID, Dec. 17 -- Alberto Franco Nogueira, Portuguese Foreign Minister, described the Indian invasion of Goa tonight as an example of "international immorality."

The Administrative Council of the City University of New York has wisely withdrawn the ban against Communist speakers on its college campuses. The council was wrong when it imposed the ban in October. Although it tried to justify its action by reference to the opinions of unidentified attorneys, there never was any doubt that the edict was counter to the basic principle of free speech.
What may prove to be the first commercial oil-producing well in Australia has been drilled by the Union Oil Company and associates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Little Dick James' four touchdowns led Washington to a 34-24 victory over the Dallas Cowboys today. The triumph was the Redskins' first in twenty-four games in the National Football League, covering two seasons.
Ten years ago the nation's telephone industry consisted of the giant Bell System and 10,000 independents.
The University of Buffalo, with 10,000 students and a 178-acre campus, is to become a part of the State University of New York, probably on July 1.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 17 -- United Nations forces battled their way into the heart of this secessionist capital tonight. They were reported trying to capture the official residence of Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province.
Jacques Margolies, who has not given a violin program here since 1950, returned yesterday afternoon to play in Carnegie Recital Hall and show, once again, his considerable violin talents.
Until now, Jane Fonda, daughter of Henry Fonda, has appeared in only two Broadway plays, "There Was a Little Girl" and "Invitation to a March." Both were seen last year.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 17 -- The Indian army moved into Goa today and had its first clash with Portuguese troops.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- French high fashion has suffered a severe economic blow that may affect Paris' position as the world capital of haute couture.
Wagner and Offenbach will share the spotlight at the Metropolitan Opera in the final week of 1961.
LISBON, Portugal, Monday, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- The Portugese Government ordered last night the internment of all Indian subjects residing in Portugese overseas territorie.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Portuguese delegates were awaiting instructions tonight on whether to call an urgent meeting of the Security Council on the Indian incursion into the Portuguese enclave of Goa.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Perhaps only agents and mothers notice it, but a film writer's credit is a solemn and sometimes complicated matter. There have been celebrated cases in which, so to speak, pens were beaten into swords, but "Boys' Night Out" provides a more typical example.
In many ways, the distributor is the unsung hero of the mutual funds business. It is up to him to see that the shares of the various funds are made available across the nation for the buying public.

As the House Subcommittee on State Taxation of Interstate Commerce wound up its hearings last week one conclusion was inescapable: Corporations operating in many states will be taxed increasingly as the states seek means of offsetting the rising cost of government.

Scoring often with explosive forehand shots, James Prigoff of the City Athletic Club retained the national squash tennis championship yesterday by defeating Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club on the Harvard club courts.
SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 17 -- The opposition party has conceded defeat in today's national elections, the first uncontrolled elections in El Salvador in thirty years.

Suggestions for the shopping list of gifts to men, 1. Ample jewel case in brown or natural testa calf is suede lined. $59.50 at T. Anthony, 772 Madison. 2. Tickets, album of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." Tickets, $3.45 to $9.60 for April-May; stereo album, $5.98, Liberty Music stores. 3. Collector's item: authenticated letter by G.B. Shaw handsomely framed with sketch, $155.

The biennial convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations made many valuable contributions to labor's unity and vigor. It gave George Meany and his fellow-leaders improved tools for combating some of the difficulties that have stunted union growth.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Margaret Smith completed a sweep of Australian state tennis titles today by winning the women's singles final in the New South Wales championships.
The direct appropriation of lump sums by the city and the state to the city's seven colleges was advocated in a report by the chairman of the Board of Higher Education released yesterday.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 17 (UPI) -- Neale Fraser returned home today from Sydney, where he withdrew from the New South Wales tennis semifinals yesterday while playing Roy Emerson.

The Medical Library Center of New York has bought the eight-story loft and garage building at 5 to 17 East 102d Street. It plans to use large space as a medical library. The building will be connected with the Academy of Medicine.
After two weeks of skirmishing, intersectional contests and the first batch of tournaments, most of the top college basketball teams appear to be living up to advance notices.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- The United States ignored an East German protest today and sent a company of its garrison here along the 110-mile East German autobahn to take part in training exercises in West Germany.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 18 -- A Westchester County budget with expenditures of $61,342,453 for next year was adopted today by the Board of Supervisors after caustic debate. The vote was 34 to 8.
IN Portugal, in contrast with Spain, the bull is never killed in the bull ring. A Portuguese bullfight may thus lack blood and drama, but it demands patience, subtlety and skill.

The city's public school teachers have voted strongly to be represented in collective bargaining by the United Federation of Teachers (A.F.L.-C.I.O.). The impressive majority the federation received over an alliance of old-line professional organizations, coupled with its even more overwhelming rout of Left-Wing rival union, eliminates any doubt that the teachers want a bargaining instrument identified with the main stream of American labor.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The French Government was defied by both the Left and Eight today as crisis over Algeria continued its steady build-up.
DALLAS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Ten records were set in the American Football League this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a lower Federal Court had no power to modify a National Labor Relations Board order if the parties had agreed to it.
The five-hour fire in the Times Tower Nov. 22 that took the lives of two firemen and a porter was caused by careless smoking, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday.
Trading on the National Stock Exchange will begin on Wednesday, March 7. The board thus will become New York's City's third operating securities exchange, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Imperial chemical Industries, the largest industrial group in the British commonwealth, has offered to say control of Courtaulds, Ltd., Britain's leading manufacturer synthetic fibers. It would be the largest merger in British history.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Dec. 18 -- C.W. Post College rallied from a 9-point deficit late in the game to defeat Brooklyn College, 54 -- 51, on its home court tonight. The victory was the fifth straight for the Pioneers.
The Neediest Cases Fund received $20 yesterday as a result of a lovers' quarrel. The episode ended happily for the couple also, with their reconciliation.

I heartily commend you on your recent fine editorial entitled "New York's Low Wages." It is just about time that the responsible press firmly took up the cudgels in this crucial area which has become a disgrace in our city.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Following are the texts of a Western resolution and a resolution presented by the United Arab Republic, Ceylon and Liberia to the Security Council tonight on the Indian-Portuguese dispute:
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Dame Flora Robson, one of England's leading dramatic actresses, fluffed her lines today at the dedication of a new West End Theatre named after the young heir to the throne.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 18 -- Portugal was hopeful tonight that world reaction to India's Aggression against Goa, Diu and Damao had spread so rapidly that the United Nations General Assembly might favor Lisbon in a vote.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Like alchemists seeking the philosopher's stone, moviemakers look for the formula that will transmute base celluloid into box-office gold. Gregory Peck, bemused by the late winter rain, thought he had found it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Supreme Court refused today to order a temporary halt in the prosecution of Freedom Riders in Jackson, Miss.

Martin Lindauer of Munich and Swedish-born Edita Morris recently received awards for thief latest works. Dr. Lindauer, Privatdozent and Oberassistent at the Zoological Institute of the University of Munich, received the Phi Beta Kappa award of $1,000 for "Communication Among Social Bees."
Two theatre benefits are being planned by the Vocational Advisory Service, a counseling service for young people and the physically handicapped.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 18 -- The Dominican public, surprised by yesterday's announcement by President Joaquin Balaguer of the establishment of a provisional government, awaited today the reaction of the National Civic Union, the largest opposition group here.

Events today: "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; McHenry Boatwright, bass-baritone, with the Symphony of the Air, Franz Allers, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; National Association for American Composers and Conductors concert, choral program conducted by Hugh Ross, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The Soviet Union hailed tonight what it described as the drive by India for the "liberation" of the Portuguese territory of Goa.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The Conservative Government's policy of restraint on wage increases won a decisive victory in the House of Commons tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- All Government agencies were directed today to review their personnel policies and operations to make sure there is no discrimination against women.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A.S. Hewitt's Snow Dune set the epace almost all the way today in winning the featured seventh race at Tropical Park before a crowd of 6,944.
The first game to be completed in the second round of the United States chess championship at the Prince George Hotel ended in a draw last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- In their diverse ways, the variables of weather, politics and economics have helped to alter the patterns of rice production, consumption and trade during the last two years.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 16 -- Fifty-five of the several hundred current world records certified by the International Game Fish Association are credited to the Bahama Island area. The list could have been increased to fifty-six this week but for a misunderstanding on the part of one expert angler and the hunger of a group of natives.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The American Football League's commissioner, Joe Foss, said today that three of the eight clubs was "nearly breaking even or in the black" this year.
HAVING found a lovely doll of the Infant Jesus in Europe last year, Helen Hayes was putting together a creche in the front hall of her house in Nyack, N.Y.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller has been warned by his fiscal advisers that the State's spending will rise at least $225,000,000 in the next fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman, never a handy man with a market basket, tried to convince shopping housewives today that food was a bargain.
Christmas trees here are in shorter supply than last year, but are still selling at prices comparable to last year's, dealers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- To the surprise of United States scientists, an underground nuclear explosion earlier this month near Carlsbad, N.M., was detected by seismological observatories as far away as Finland and Japan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Administration is considering a sharp increase in salaries for top-level Government workers to make the Civil Service more competitive with private industry.

Basic similarities among cancer cells, regardless of their type or the ultimate cause of the cancer, are providing a unifying concept of great importance to cancer research, according to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center's first annual report, published yesterday.

SHOULD a violin be on your Christmas list, holiday shopping can be a pleasure. Instead of the usual wrangle-jangle, the rare tone of a Guadagnini may be heard at John Markert's shop, albeit echoed by a tentative scale on a beginner's violin.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A taller Kentucky basketball team dropped Temple from the unbeaten ranks tonight, 78 -- 55, with a convincing second-half demonstration of might.

Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation will expand its research facilities with a multi-million-dollar program at its Graham Laboratory, near Pittsburgh, Avery C. Adams, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday in Pittsburgh.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 18 -- New York University's undefeated basketball team started sluggishly, gained momentum gradually, and then just ran away from Notre Dame for an 81-73 triumph tonight.

The Goodyear International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, announced yesterday it would build its first plant for the production of synthetic rubber outside the United States near Le Havre, France.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Government officials told an agitated Parliament today that India's invasion of Goa had placed Britain "in a most painful position."

Norman Krasna, author of the current comedy, "Sunday in New York," will have another work on Broadway next season called "French Street." It will be produced by David Merrick and Ray Stark in association with Seven Arts Productions.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday.

The story of how a financial manipulator purchased a California steel company with the company's own money was told yesterday in Federal Court.
Holden Roberto, the Angolan rebel leader and President of the Union of Angolan Peoples, announced yesterday that his movement intended to set up a provisional government "within a few months."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Controller of the Currency ordered today a public hearing here on Jan. 5 on the proposed merger of the Bank of Livonia of Livonia, Mich. and the National Bank of Detroit.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Lanny van Eman sank a 15-foot jump shot with three seconds left tonight and gave the Wichita Shockers a 52 -- 51 basketball victory over Cincinnati. The upset ended the Bearcats' 27-game winning streak, the longest in current collegiate circles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration told Congress today that the possible use of Government guarantees to enable small retailers to rent space in shopping centers should be "thoroughly explored."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that she was "shocked and disturbed" by the praise recently given the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain by Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
RENEVO, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Two hunters, made rigid with cold as they slept, were saved recently by the efforts of a country doctor. But they lost their toes.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 18 -- The twenty third annual series of County Assemblies, three dances honoring young women in groups from the age of 16 through college years, will be held at the Longshore Country Club on successive evenings starting Dec. 26, each with a philanthropic purpose.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Governor Rockefeller plans to ask the 1962 Legislature to authorize New York City to resume the dating of milk sold in the city.
Steel production last week was at its highest level since the week ended on April 30, 1960.

Net income of the Atlas Credit Corporation rose to a new high of $1,034,895 in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, Jack L. Wolgin, president reported yesterday. This reflected a sharp rise over the 1960 figure, when the financing and leasing concern cleared $447,043.

The annual report of Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc., for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 disclosed yesterday that sales and earnings were below those of a year before, reflecting competition of discount stores selling drug store merchandise.
CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Mayor Arthur Munson said today he has been informed by General Foods Corporation that the company has dropping plans to build a frozen baby food plant here.
As the heir to Mohandas K. Gandhi, Prime Minister Jawaharial Nehru of India has been widely regarded as a symbol of nonviolence.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Vincent Hallinan, attorney, is challenging the authority of the Roman Catholic Church "to act as an agent of God on earth." The challenge is in a suit he has filed in Superior Court here to set aside a will bequeathing $200,000 to thirty-five Catholic institutions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -Several corn futures contracts sold at their season lows today on the Board of Trade as the market slipped into its broadest general setback of several sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, deplored today what he called high prices, high pressure salesmansship, waste and monopoly in the drug industry. He declared that the situation called for drastic action.

The Christmas window displays at the Abraham Straus store in Brooklyn are literally good enough to eat. As a result, the store is doing a brisk business in the old-fashion candies used in the decorations.

"Tenpin Showcase," an eighteen-minute sixteen-millimeter film showing the 1961 American Bowling Congress tournament, recently was released by the Congress for use by bowling groups and other sports organizations.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A two-for-one stock split was proposed today by the United States Shoe Corporation directors in view of record 1961 sales and profits and an excellent outlook for the coming year.

SHAKESPEAREAN scholars -- and theatre audiences -- well know that "A Midsummer Night's Dream" has never shone quite so brightly in physical performance as on the printed page.

Though it was virtually unknown in New York ten years ago, Berlioz' "L'Enfance du Christ" has since become a traditional part of the city's celebration of Christmas. And last night the forces that brought the work back into such successful circulation again gave the work at Carnegie Hall.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 18 -- India's Defense Minister, V.K. Krishna Menon, named Maj. Gen. F.P. Candeth as Military Governor of Goa today.
J. Edward Lumbard, Chief Judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals here, responded yesterday to a motion for an injunction against a representation election aboard Honduran-flag ships.

The Board of Education has voted an appropriation of $50,000 to present "Julius Caesar" in the junior and senior high schools. The same amount was obtained last year through the Board of Estimate.

Patrons and patronesses have been announced for the ninth annual Ball of the Roses, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Jan. 11.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -Secretary of State Dean Rusk informed B.K. Nehru, the Indian Ambassador, today that the United States "deeply regrets" India's use of force in claiming the three Portuguese colonies on India's west coast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- A feud threatened to erupt between the Washington Redskins and Dallas Cowboys today over seventy-six chickens and ten pounds of chicken feed.

The New York Academy of Medicine, through its nonprofit American Museum of Health, announced plans yesterday for a $3,500,000 Hall of Medicine and Health at the New York World's Fair in 1964 and 1965.
Volume in Maine potato futures soared and prices dipped to new lows yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
New York State is planning the sale of $33,000,000 of housing bonds backed by the full faith and credit of the state, Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday. The sale will take place on Jan. 10.

FOR ALMOST two decades Virgil Thomson sat in seat J-101 in Town Hall, arising about 10:30 P.M. to make his deadline. Last night he sat on the stage, looking like an aged kewpie doll, his face getting redder and redder as tribute after tribute was read to him.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- A Western proposal that the Security Council call for an immediate cease-fire in Goa and other Portuguese possessions was defeated early today by a Soviet veto.
The New York Stock Exchange, which tends to be more sedate than witty, has published this little ditty in the latest issue of The Exchange, its monthly magazine.
Mayor Wagner's Task Force on Youth and Work submitted yesterday the first in a series of reports aimed at increasing employment opportunities and job training for young persons.
Strong gales churned up the North Atlantic yesterday and slowed inbound passenger liners.
Six very excellent vocalists making up the Riverside Chamber Singers, gave a charming and engaging concert of unaccompanied music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Directors of Garrett Corporation yesterday authorized the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed issue of $20,000,000 of 20-year debentures. The aircraft accessories maker plans to use proceeds to pay short-term bank borrowings.

A 280-pound Texas cattle rancher became head coach of the New York Titans yesterday. He is Clyde (Bulldog) Turner, generally regarded as the greatest center in the history of professional football. He was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1960.
A system employing radar may soon be used to measure the true speed of ships at sea.

MOUNTAIN HOME, Idaho, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Electricians returned to work today at a Titan missile-launching project in southwestern Idaho. Their action ended a labor dispute that had slowed work at the vast complex.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- President Sukarno ordered total mobilization of the Indonesian people today to take over Netherlands New Guinea. The President said: "I order the Indonesian people to wreck Dutch efforts to set up a Papuan puppet state."

Stock prices were extremely irregular for most of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but slipped in the final hour. Every major group was ragged, showing nothing that could be interpreted as a concerted movement.

WHEN the snowflakes whirl and entertaining small groups of friends is the the order of the day, it is rewarding to offer something different for their enjoyment. Memories of outdoor barbecues are always pleasant and now, with the aid of any one of a number of readily available appliances, it is possible to serve charcoal-broiled delicacies all year around.

Richard Boone, who stars as Paladin in "Have Gun, Will Travel," will leave the West temporarily to fulfill an assignment in the East. He will appear as the narrator in a dramatized reading of the Stephen Vincent Benet poem, "John Brown's Body," which the Columbia Broadcasting System will televise on Sunday, Jan. 14, from 1:30 to 2:30 P.M.

The F.W. Woolworth Company has leased space in the Eastwood House, on the northwest corner of Seventy-second Street and First Avenue, for a retail store. The building is scheduled to be finished in September, 1962.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that a corporation officer may not be prosecuted under the Sherman Act for antitrust violations alleged to have been committed in carrying out his corporate duties.

To simplify the cleaning of ovens and broilers, avoid filling any baking dish too full so that the contents spill over. If foods should spill, they should be wiped up as soon as the oven cools slightly. Use a mild abrasive where there are baked-on particles.
A merger of the Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company, Cleveland, into the Electronic Specialty Company, Los Angeles, has been agreed to "in principle," the two companies announced yesterday.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation expects 1961 earnings to amount to about $1.10 a share, Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, said at a luncheon meeting of security analysts yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club.

The Aluminum Company of America expects the fourth quarter to be the best of 1961, with further improvement for both Alcoa and the industry sighted for 1962, Lawrence Litchfield Jr., president of Alcoa, said here last night.
BONN, Germany Dec. 18 -Chancellor Adenauer said today that an East-West conference on Berlin was necessary because Berlin could not be left in "uncertainty" about the future.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 18 -- After nine days of doubt and tension, the Government of Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies has won the Federal election held Dec. 9.

New York is a dynamic city without parallel in history. It has grown physically and financially far faster than culturally. Despite the fact that it is the most cosmopolitan location in the country, it is a veritable vacuum of architectural originality and value.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 18 -- The Emperor of Ethiopia said today that he was dedicating the new Haile Selassie I University to serve the cause of peace in "crucial times."
DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- It is estimated that seventeen of the twenty-six makes in production will build at least 100,000 cars this year. Last year fifteen of twenty-four passed the 100,000 mark.

More than 700 faculty members of universities in the New York area appealed to President Kennedy and Governor Rockefeller today to turn the national effort away from fall-out shelters and "forward on a race towards peace."

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- On Saturday at Milan, Italy, before 20,000 fans, half of them French, and before a French television audience estimated at 5,000,000, the French national soccer team was beaten by Bulgaria, 1 -- 0. The loss eliminated the French from the world soccer championship in 1962, when the world's sixteen best teams will fight it out in Chile.
Mayor Wagner returned to City Hall yesterday after a two-week vacation and promised to do his best to avert strikes by transit and electrical workers on New Year's Day.

After taking due note of the gratifying success of President Kennedy's trip to Venezuela and Colombia, it is worth remembering how much remains to be done. There is no rest for those who work in the complex, dynamic and emotional field of Latin-American questions.

Six nations, including the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia and Canada, rate top consideration among the eighteen countries to be represented in the 1962 world amateur hockey championship. The tournament will be held March 8 to March 18 at Colorado Springs.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 18 -- Bob Stowers and Richie Swartz scored 32 points between them in the first half to pace Hofstra to a 76-57 victory over St. Anselm's. Stowers finished the game with 30 points. Swartz had 20.

What finally became of Bakri and Busnach, who began it all? The plastic explosive charge that smashed the front of the Algiers cafe last week; the road mine that sent the civilian bus sky-high; the single deadly shot in the night outside of Guelma -- all stem from Bakri and Busnach.
Let those who think the Giants lucked their way to the National Football League's Eastern title consider an item of news released yesterday.

ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 18 -- An agreement was reached today in this city's racial controversy. It paved the way for the release of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and about 300 other Negroes from prison.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 18 -- President Alberto Lleras Cahargo said today that it was "the great hope" awakened by President Kennedy's inter-American policies that filled the streets of Bogota with cheering epople yesterday.
PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 18 -The Governor General, Brig. Manuel Antonio Vassalo e Silva, declared today that Portuguese troops would do everything in their power to repel the Indian invasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Space experiments have helped establish a direct relationship between magnetic fields around the earth and disturbances on the sun, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 18 -- United States diplomatic efforts to bring about a meeting between Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo and President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province appeared to be proceeding successfully tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Movements in industrial share prices were irregular in the stock market here today. However, the firm undertone was maintained and there were slightly more rises than falls in many groups.
Who and how much to tip are questions that face homeowners and apartment dwellers during the holidays.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Air Force announced today it is planning to close all airspace over the Molucca Islands and around Netherlands New Guinea.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- President Kennedy interrupted today his return from a flying trip to Latin America. He stopped here to rest and care for a heavy cold and an earache.

Theodore L. Bates, the man who founded Ted Bates Co. twenty-one years ago, has decided to reassume the position of chief executive officer, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Bates also will reassume many of the administrative responsibilities he shed six years ago when he became honorary chairman and decided to play a lesser role in the day-to-day workings of his agency.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The Air Force fired a Minuteman missile 3,600 miles today from a concrete-lined hole in the ground.
BORWICK, Pa., Dec. 18 -- President Kennedy had a Christmas message of encouragement delivered today to the school children of this community by a top-ranking member of his Administration.

Representative John V. Lindsay rebutted charges yesterday that the new Seventeenth Congressional District had been gerrymandered by the Republican-controlled Legislature last month to help him when he sought re-election next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Commissioner of Labor Statistics told a Congressional study group today that Federal training, guidance and placement programs, as well as a booming economy, were needed to reduce the nation's unemployment.
Intensified negotiations began yesterday in an attempt to avert strikes by transit and electrical workers here on New Year's Day.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Cudahy Packing Company has reported a loss of $374,496 for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28, compared with a net profit of $810,985 the preceding year. Sales amounted to $324,920,000, compared with $340,920,000 a year earlier.

COME Christmas and tables will be dressed with style and misgiving in holiday linens and lace. Many a hostess already dreads the moment when the red wine will spill and the candlewax plop on a treasured tablecloth.

ONE of the nicest presents for a woman to receive, but one of the most difficult to choose, is a gift of clothing. Individual taste is the stumbling block as the beneficiary's ideas often difer from the benefactor's. The following suggestions, however, are fairly foolproof because they are classic fashions that fit into almost every woman's wardrobe.

With his invasion of Goa Prime Minister Nehru has done irreparable damage to India's good name and to the principles of international morality.
Wilma Rudolph, the Olympic track star, yesterday won The Associated Press' award as female athlete of the year for the second year in a row.
Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich charged yesterday that city authorities had been overzealous in prosecuting a court-appointed manager of slum tenement houses.
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The New York State Court of Claims ruled today that a policeman was legally within his rights in using a nightstick to enforce the law.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- The White House announced today the recess appointment of Henry R. Labouisse as Ambassador to Greece.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Treasury bill rates rose sharply o ntoday's sale of the regular weekly issues. They were at their highest level since mid-October of last year. This week's issue of ninety-one-day bills sold at discount rates averaging 2.670 per cent, compared with 2.579 per cent last Monday.
Danger is growing that the "true identity" of college applicants will be lost because of inadequate reports by the high schools to the colleges, an education official said yesterday.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman accepted today United States Freedom From Hunger Foundation.

The United Nations is more than $100,000,000 in the hole, largely because a number of states, including the Soviet Union, will not pay assessments on the U.N. operations in the Congo or in the Gaza Strip. Eight nations -- including Denmark, Ethiopia, the Netherlands, Norway, Pakistan, Tunisia, Malaya and Yugoslavia -- are proposing a $200,000,000 bond issue to meet the crisis.

KITWE, Northern Rhodesia, Dec. 18 -- A Katangese Government official was killed and two news correspondents were wounded today when the car they were traveling in was hit by bazooka fire as they tried to leave Elisabethville.

The high-grade bond market held yesterday to the checkered pattern of recent trading sessions -- firmness, strength and activity in prime corporate and local government bonds and apathy and heaviness in United States Government securities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today a state court ruling that would permit New York authorities to investigate publication of the book "How I Made $2 Million in the Stock Market."

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 18 -- The New York University and Notre Dame basketball teams will meet Feb. 21, 1963 at Madison Square Garden in a renewal of a game that once was the Garden's leading annual intersectional attraction.
The unsound plea of the American Committee for Aid to Katanga Freedom Fighters contributes nothing to the solution of the political situation in the Congo. Rather it aggravates it.
DENVER, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A labor recruiter has been indicted for having placed New Mexico Indians in "involuntary servitude and peonage."

DALLAS, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- The first American Football League all-star game at San Diego Jan. 7 looms as a virtual replay of the forthcoming championship game Sunday between the Houston Oilers and San Diego Chargers.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Bingo games in Utica and Syracuse before 1958 were part of an interstate operation headed by a former Utica man, a witness testified today at a public hearing here.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 18 (UPI) -- Top-seeded Williams and fourth-ranked Colgate won their first-round games today in the first Christmas invitation hockey tournament at Brown University.
GENEVA, Dec. 18 -- The fourteen-nation conference on Laos unanimously approved today a new appeal to the three rival Laotian political leaders to speed their negotiations for a coalition government.

SINCE a miracle is a rarity, producer-director Frank Capra cannot be faulted for having failed to turn up a wholesale lot in the "Pocketful of Miracles," which was revealed yesterday at the Victoria and Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatres.
ALGIERS, Dec. 18 -- Hopes for an early cease-fire in the Algerian war, now in its eighth year, were voiced in competent quarters today.
Property owners in the retailing area near Washington Square charged yesterday that the city's new zoning law and two proposed amendments to it threatened to limit the growth of Greenwich Village.
The existence of Christian churches in totalitarian Communist states constitutes a real challenge to doctrinaire Marxism the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake said yesterday.

An expanded research and information program on the planning and use of schools and colleges will be undertaken by Educational Facilities Laboratories under a $5,000,000 grant announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

ANYBODY in the mood for one of those grown-up musical fairy tales? A sample of the category opened last night at the Cricket Theatre. It is called "All Kinds of Giants" and it is all about a sort of dotty king whose realm is being terrorized by a giant in the near-by forest.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 -- Three hundred Negroes and a few whites tried to march on the State Office Building today. They were protesting against the mass arrest of anti-segregation demonstrators last week in Baton Rouge.
A SPECIAL gift deserves a special wrapping, according to Tina Grant and Margaret Yakovenko, both of whom are currently busy dreaming up original Christmas packages.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary warned tonight that the situation in the Congo could reach a point at which the Government would have to withdraw its financial support of the United Nations.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers arrived to a red-carpet welcome today for their Rose Bowl game with the University of California at Los Angeles eleven.

FROM now until mid-April, thousands of American women will be at sea. Some will be accompanied by their husbands, but the majority will be hopeful of acquiring one. Most of those will be disappointed but will return to shore sun-tanned, exhilarated and planning to go on another cruise next year.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- The state Education Commissioner ruled today that a Suffolk County school district had to pay for transporting a 14-year-old girl to a parochial school on a route that involves two ferry rides.

A record budget request of $66,902,055 to operate the seven college units of the City University was approved unanimously last night by the Board of Higher Education.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The 1962 edition of the Government book "Your Federal Income Tax" is now available. The price is 40 cents a copy.
The first of the city's new snow streets was posted with a sign yesterday by two commissioners -- in the rain.
Today could be a big news day for six New York banks.
Automation of long distance telephone service has received protracted attention in your distinguished paper. Your editorial comment as well as some of the correspondence were quite entertaining.

"Les Liaisons Dangereuses," a film once banned for export by the French Government, was allowed to open here last night after New York censors approved a "darkened" print of two "objectionable" nude scenes.
Three passengers stepped out of a taxi at Pier 84, North River, yesterday and paid a fare of $337.50. "It was the only way we could get here in time for the sailing," one of them remarked.
Ohio State came within a point of a perfect score yesterday in The Associated Press' first weekly college basketball poll of the season.

AMERICA is an open book that is reviewed constantly by the swarming social critics of our civilization. One of the best of the recent critiques is "The Beer Can by the Highway,"* whose author, John A. Kouwenhoven, brings a vigorous helmsmanship to the whither-are-we-drifting industry.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Duke received iron-man performances from its five starters tonight and stunned West Virginia, 69-65, before an overflow crowd of nearly 7,000 at Mountaineer Field House.

Allie Sherman, the Brooklyn College boy who made good in his first year as coach of the New York Giants, was named National Football League coach of the year in an Associated Press poll yesterday. He immediately distributed the credit to others, and it wasn't just a case of Christmas giving.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 19 -- A suggestion was made in the Belgian Senate today that the United Nations should be held legally accountable for Belgian casualties and damage to Belgian property in Katanga Province in the Congo.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Reliable sources predicted today that the United States and other Western powers would make no further move in the United Nations to oppose India's conquest of Goa and other Portuguese possessions on the Indian subcontinent.

Representative John V. Lindsay was challenged from two quarters yesterday on his denial that a Republican-controlled Legislature had gerrymandered the Seventeenth Congressional District.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Gov. John A. Volpe said today he had hired James D. St. Clair, a lawyer, to prepare ouster proceedings against Boston Police Commissioner Leo J. Sullivan.

The directors of the Mercantile Stores Company, Inc., proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. They also announced their intention to increase cash dividends by 35 cents a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Despite significant worldwide fall-out from the Soviet Union's recent series of nuclear tests, radiation exposures of humans resulting from tests by all nations since 1945 will remain within acceptable health limits, the Government reported today.

Your Dec. 13 editorial on our recommendation of a four-hour day suggested that the logical conclusion of labor pressure for a shorter work week is "a no-hour day and a no-day week." Now I would submit with the utmost seriousness that the no hour day and the no-day week has existed for some time in our society.
Martin Geisler, the author of a booklet titled "How to Set Up and Operate a Paperback Bookshop," said yesterday that he was $170,000 in debt and had 300 creditors.
The appointment of John E. Thilly and Alfred M. Vinton as senior vice presidents of the First National City Bank of New York was announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- U Thant, Acting Secretary General, "urgently appealed" to Indonesia and the Netherlands today to refrain from any actions that would threaten peace and security.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)) -- Most transactions in the grain futures market today were toward evening up commitments in December contracts on which trading ended. Except for a moderate volume of short covering in some commodities trade was dull and prices little changed.

State Senator MacNell Mitchell, chairman of the Senate Committee on New York City Affairs, said yesterday that he was filing in advance of the legislature a bill appropriating $6,300,000 to reimburse New York City for outlays for graduate and professional studies at the new City University.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt denied yesterday that she had sent a telegram to Secretary of State Dean Rusk criticizing him for recently praising the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco in Spain.
USING as his inspiration a momentous historical event, David Karp constructed an excellent television drama, which was shown on Channel 7 last night.
An increase of $300 a year in undergraduate tuition -- from $900 to $1,200 -- was announced yesterday by Yeshiva University.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, 73-year-old father of the President, suffered a stroke at his home in Palm Beach today.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- President Kennedy's first Latin-American visit seems to have gotten the Alliance for Progress off dead center. One may now hope his effort will be followed by gathering diplomatic momentum. But there are immense problems to be surmounted and some of these will here be discussed.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, said today he planned to estabilsh permanent residence here as overseas director of a Miami insurance concern after he retired from Congress in 1964.
FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Two soldiers were killed and a third was injured today when a hand grenade exploded prematurely during a routine training exercise, the Army said.

Efforts are being made by George T. Delacorte to beautify the premises of Central Park's new Shakespeare Festival Theatre. Mr. Delacorte, who is the president of the Dell Publishing Company, confirmed a report that he was discussing plans to install a lighted fountain in the lake adjacent to the amphitheatre.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The United States and Britain made public today a report accusing the Soviet Union of having sabotaged the renewed talks in Geneva on a nuclear-test ban.
TRENTON, Dec. 19 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council appeared tonight to be only weeks away from the legal status it has long sought.
The Police Department is investigating a charge that two radio patrolman dismissed the complaint of a rabbi who had been attacked by hoodlums in Greenwich Village.
The J.C. Penney Company, nation-wide chain of 1,704 department stores, is planning to enter the mail-order business through the proposed acquisition of the General Merchandise Company.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 -- Settlements totaling $980,000 for five children stricken with poliomyelitis after inoculations with polio vaccine were approved today by Superior Judge Richard C. Fildew.

Producing companies are taking a closer look at the consumer fields. An indication of the interest of a major company seeking closer contact with the ultimate consumer came yesterday when officials of the International Nickel Company, Inc., and Sears, Roebuck Co. sat down and explored the impact of metallurgical progress on retail merchandising.
The Federal Government will join the city early next year in a survey to pinpoint all buildings here that are suitable for fall-out shelters, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.

ONE of the deserving books that was crowded out of this space by the thundering herd of autumn publications is a curious, brilliant and yet unsatisfactory novel, "The Night of Trees,"* by Thomas Williams. Judged solely on its demonstration of ability and a talent for fiction, this ambitious, almost pretentious, novel must be given high marks.

IT is a remarkable group of young men that will carry the banner of the New York football Giants into the championship play-off against the Packers at Green Bay a week from Sunday. Professional football seems to attract the highest type athlete anyway. Virtually all are college men and, at the very least, some of that background brushes off on them.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 19 -- An exodus of Moroccan Jews came to a halt today after political parties here attacked the Government for having tolerated "Zionist-inspired" emigration.

THERE is an arresting aggregation of antique and modern books on food in the library of the Hotel Administration School at Cornell University here. It ranges from the food of the ancients to the cuisine of the present day.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Attorneys for The New York Times asked the Alabama Supreme Court today to reverse a $500,000 libel suit judgment.
TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Communist China endorsed India's invasion of Portuguese Goa today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 cents to $1.10 a bale yesterday.

The New York County Medical Society expressed satisfaction in an official publication today over the recent action by the Food and Drug Administration against a book by Dr. Carlton Fredericks, writer and lecturer on nutrition.

Harriman Ripley Co. and Stern Brothers Co. and associates are offering to the public today 130,000 common shares of Russell Stover Candies, Inc., at $24.25 each. The shares being sold resulted from the conversion of $1,300,000 of subordinated convertible notes the company originally held by the three selling stockholders, the State Mutual Life Assurance Company of America, the Value Line Income Fund, Inc., and Central Life Company.
A new television show that will take to the sidewalks of New York to see what viewers think about TV starts Saturday at 3 P.M. on Channel 2.
Fordham's more highly rated basketball team had to stage a late rally to beat Columbia, 67 -- 59, at the Maroon's gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The newly appointed Federal regulator of national banks disapproved today the proposed merger of the First National City Bank of New York and the National Bank of Westchester -- the second largest banks in New York City and suburban Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for the nation's pharmacists complained today that Americans were holding them responsible for all the adverse testimony Senate investigators heard about the drug industry.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Wednesday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A rhesus monkey named Scatback, a radio transmitter and medical instruments implanted in its body, rocketed 600 miles into space last night and landed in the South Atlantic more than 6,000 miles southeast of here.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Dec. 19 -- The Union-Castle Line's 33,500-ton Transvaal Castle, Britain's first "hotel class" liner, docked here today after a two-day shakedown cruise eminently satisfactory to crew and passengers.
MONTREAL, Dec. 19 -- The first steps toward turning the Richelieu River-Lake Champlain-Hudson system into a seaway are about to be taken Prime Minister John Diefenbaker has disclosed.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19 -- Dr. Sal J. Prezioso of Scarsdale was named today as the second highest executive official of Westchester County.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Viscount Linley, the six-and-one-half-week-old son of Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowden, was christened today with Jordan River water at Buckingham Palace.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The State of New York won today a court battle to obtain a permanent injunction against twelve of Newburgh's tightened welfare regulations.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- The Soviet Union has broadened its offensive against West Berlin's ties with West Germany.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain went on another scoring spree tonight with 57 points in a 117-110 National Basketball Association victory by Philadelphia over the Cincinnati Royals.

Many persons entertained at the fourth annual Seven to Eleven Dance, a Christmas Pearl Gala, which was held at the Plaza last night for the benefit of the New York Chapter of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Shares of Imperial Chemical Industries and Courtaulds, the company I.C.I. is bidding for, continued to attract considerable attention in the stock market here today.

PANGIM, Goa, Dec. 19 -- The Indian Army strengthened its hold on Goa today. The first troops entered this capital at 8:45 A.M. local time. They crossed the Mandovi River by barge from Betim, just opposite the capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Dr. Zairin Zain, Indenesian Ambassador, indicated today that his Government would like the United States to offer its good offices in the dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands over Netherlands New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Federal Aviation Agency has suspended the operating certificate of Imperial Airlines in the aftermath of the Nov. 8 plane crash that killed seventy-seven persons.

MAJ. GEN. RAFAEL RAMON RODRIGUEZ ECHAVARRIA, Secretary of State for the Armed Forces, is the man who has emerged from the Dominican political crisis as the mainstay of the Government of President Joaquin Balaguer.
Columbia honored its Ivy League football co-champions last night at Ferris Booth Hall on the campus. More than 300 friends and alumni of Columbia attended.

Allan P. Kirby of Morristown, N.J., won a round yesterday in his battle with the Murchison Brothers of Dallas, Tex., who last spring wrested control of the Alleghany Corporation from Mr. Kirby, its largest stockholder.
The New York Diabetes Association announced yesterday that Dr. Martin G. Goldner, director of medicine of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn, had been elected president for 1962.
The third round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship was fiercely contested yesterday at the Prince George Hotel.
John Alexander made an auspicious Metropolitan debut last night as Ferrando in Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte."

The City Council completed legislative action yesterday on the 1962 capital budget of $765,653,754. This assured the city of a program of new schools, libraries, courthouses, police stations, firehouses and other public improvements slated for the year beginning Jan. 1.
Maine potato futures again dominated trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices hit new lows for the lives of all contracts but January, and the volume again was high.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd said today that he would press for a Senate investigation of United Nations policy in the Congo. TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Grant Meister, an office employe o fthe Simmonds Precision Products Corporation here, leaped off the Tappan Zee Bridge tonight, the state police reported. It was presumed he was killed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Representatives of independent retailers urged Congress today to establish a guarantee system designed to help them rent space in shopping centers and other key sites.
Doug Harvey, the player-coach of the New York Rangers, celebrated his thirty-seventh birthday yesterday by shaking up his lines in an effort to return the team to winning form.

Whitey Ford, who won twenty-five games for the Yankees, may have been baseball's No. 1 pitcher for 1961. Certainly no one questioned his meriting the Cy Young award.
Joe Zuger of Arizona State not only led major-college football players in pass interceptions this season, but also won the individual punting crown for himself and the team title for the Sun Devils.

The merger of the Franklin Simon and Oppenheim Collins specialty store chains into a forty-store Franklin Simon operation in fifteen states was announced yesterday. John Hay Whitney and his sister, Mrs. Charles S. Payson, have generously served the public interest with their gifts of $5,000,000 each to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's Fund for Medical Progress. Mr. Whitney is chairman of the fund, and editor in chief and publisher of The New York Herald Tribune. He was president of the hospital's board of governors from 1949 to 1953.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A campaign for stricter enforcement of football playing rules will be waged by the National Federation of State High School Athletic Associations, which today reported fifteen deaths for the 1961 season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The Hallicrafters Company and France's largest electronics enterprise plan to set up a jointly owned subsidiary in the Chicago area to produce high-power micro-wave tubes and other advanced vacuum devices for military and commercial markets, it was announced here today.
Many readers who feel grateful for their own good fortune were among the donors yesterday to the fiftieth annual appear of The New York Times Neediest Cases.

Edward Ziegler, who has been an executive with the General Electric Supply Company in Richmond, Va., assistant city editor of The Raleigh Times and an editor in the business magazine field at McGraw-Hill, has written a book about a new kind of American "influential" who is assuming more power than is good for him or for the country.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A special commissioner has recommended that the rich coastal strip of Kenya, over which the Sultan of Zanzibar holds nominal sovereignty, should be an integral part of Kenya after independence is achieved.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Twenty-three men asked today an end to the probationary periods to which they were sentenced in February in the Government's price-fixing case against the heavy electrical equipment industry.

Brand, Grumet Seigel, Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have leased 13,000 square feet of space in the office building at 67 Broad Street. The brokers have their main offices at 49 West Thirty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- United States military men in South Vietnam were understood today to be operating in battle areas with South Vietnamese forces that are fighting Communist guerrillas.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- An Air Force transport plane with one of its engines disabled narrowly missed a suburban residential area today and crashed in a muddy field. Seven crewmen died as the plane broke apart on impact.

FREE marionette show, "Alice in Wonderland," is the Christmas gift of the Department of Parks Marionette theatre to the children of New York. The show will be presented at the Hunter College Playhouse, Sixty-eighth Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.
UNTIL the middle of the second act of "Poppa Is Home," which opened at the Gate Theatre last night, Poppa is ahead. He can't walk or talk -- especially, talk.
Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in gross revenues and net income for twelve months ended Nov. 30.

Joe Weatherly of Norfolk, Va., is a 5-foot 7-inch 39-year-old block of granite whose skill with a late-model stock racing car has kept thousands of fans gasping and cheering for the last ten years. He has been chosen in a nation-wide poll as the most popular National Association for Stock Cars driver of 1961.

Robert M. Wopat was elected yesterday to the new post of executive vice president-telephone operations for General Telephone and Electronics Corporation. Mr. Wopat, who is now president of General Telephone Company of Illinois, a subsidiary, will assume his new duties on Jan. 1.
The shipbuilding industry will be given an opportunity in mid-January to bid on construction of six freighters that will be built with Federal subsidy aid.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- A United States proposal urging intensified efforts to resolve the Palestine refugee problem was approved tonight by the General Assembly's Special Political Committee.
The Empress of Canada, flagship of the Canadian Pacific fleet, paid her first visit yesterday to the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Two cows, named Sophie Tucker and Madame Curie, have helped the Government develop what it calls a highly efficient process for removing dangerous quantities of radioactive strontium from milk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges issued a glowing report on the economy today.
PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Officials of Passaic and Clifton asked the New Jersey State Highway Department today to include two bridges in their plates for Route 21.
The Community Service Society yesterday urged the rehabilitation of welfare recipients. It derided as "panaceas" five recent suggestions to reduce the burden of public assistance.

If the late Henry Hadley had lived, he would have been 90 years old today. In commemoration of this anniversary, the National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented a concert of choral music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was the organization's second concert of the season.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Dr. Albert L. Weiner, an osteopathic physician, was convicted of manslaughter tonight in the death of twelve patients who died of serum hepatitis after receiving injections from him.

With Johnny Green performing minor miracles under both hoops, the New York Knickerbockers snapped an eight-game losing streak last night by trouncing the St. Louis Hawks, 128 -- 111, at Madison Square Garden.
HAMILTON, Ohio, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Champion Papers, Inc., is acquiring the Whitaker Paper Company of Cincinnati, the presidents of the two concerns said yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Undefeated Duquesne routed St. Bonaventure, 74 -- 57, tonight. The nationally ranked Dukes posted their sixth basketball victory of the season. The loss was the Bonnies' first after six victories.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru defended today the Indian take-over of the Portuguese enclaves of Goa, Damao and Diu.
ST. MARYS, Pa., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Three St. Marys finance companies are insolvent to the extent of about $3,700,000.

Sales and earnings of the Firestone Tire Rubber Company in the last six months of its fiscal year were the highest for any similar period in its sixty-one-year history, the company reported yesterday. However, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, they were the third largest in the company's history.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 -- The Netherlands Government indicated today it was ready to negotiate with Indonesia on the New Guinea question.
SHREVEPORT, La., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Joe Waggonner, a conservative Democrat and staunch segregationist, won election tonight in a special Congressional election in northwest Louisiana's Fourth District.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Five students from Upsala College, East Orange, were fined $60 each on petit larceny charges in Borough Court here last night.
Negotiators spent two hours yesterday on the contract dispute that threatens to tie up public and private transit here on New Year's Day.

Our association welcomes Secretary Abraham Ribicoff's constructiveness in approaching problem areas in public welfare. As you underscored in your Dec. 13 editorial "Welfare Overhaul" the Ribicoff plan places greater emphasis on rehabilitative measures and faces squarely the need for recruiting additional trained staff workers to put these measures into practice.

THERE is a considerable amount of strong feeling among deer hunters in New Jersey. What aroused them is that there was supposed to be a special "Hunter's Choice," one-day, either-sex deer season today. There will not be.
Columbia students staged a premature holiday celebration last night.

NEWARK, Dec. 19 -- The City of Newark notified the Port of New York Authority today that it would seek to collect back taxes for 1960 and 1961 against buildings leased by the agency to private companies at Port Newark and Newark Airport.
The construction of the Thirtieth Street Expressway and a network of municipal garages to alleviate midtown traffic congestion were called for yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Interior Department opened today a campaign to win approval for a transmission system designed in its main aim to feed Pacific Northwest power to San Francisco and southern California.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The British Government announced today that it planned to introduce a decimal system of currency unless a study showed the difficulties to be overwhelming.

SEVILLE, Spain, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Twenty persons, including eight children, were killed and about 100 were injured today when a light plane hit a high-tension post and crashed into a crowd that had gathered for a "day of blessing."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- Preparations for the prosecution of twenty-six former Nazi officials suspected of mass murders in the Auschwitz concentration camp edged forward today with the start of pretrial investigations by a Frankfurt provincial court.

Paperboard production in the nation rose to 341,752 tons in the week ended last Saturday. This figure compared with 338,958 tons in the preceding week and 300,066 tons in the 1960 period, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 19 -- Dr. Bertil Bjorklund, a Swedish immunologist, began yesterday a long-term program of testing in healthy human volunteers what might turn out to be an anti-cancer vaccine.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A new trans-Atlantic telephone cable, the first link in a projected British Commonwealth circuit, was inaugurated today by Queen Elizabeth and Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada.

Construction will start today on the Bridge apartments, the first middle-income housing project in the state to be built on an "air rights" site, it was announced by James W. Gaynor, State Housing Commissioner.

As negotiations for new transit contracts with labor on the subways and the bus lines move into their final and critical stage, certain fundamental principles stand out as nonbargainable if the public interest in this area is to be protected.

McHENRY BOATWRIGHT, young Georgia bass-baritone, received show-case treatment last night when he was presented at Carnegie Hall. Not only was his program one of the type sung by great stars, but also he had the Symphony of the Air to support him.
WINTER winds bring out the mole in man. Let a blizzard blow and Christmas shoppers disappear below ground.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 19 -- India's take-over of Goa and the other Portuguese enclaves in India confirmed her position as the bulwark of freedom and the bastion of anti-colonialism and anti-imperialism, leaders of five African nationalist movements said in a statement here today.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Mayor Richard P. Dyckman doesn't want a $700 salary increase, even as a Christmas present. He told the City Council this last night when it voted to pay him $1,000 a year.
The Kips Bay dinner dance, for the last nine years an annual spring party, will have a winter theme this year because of its new date, Jan. 17.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 19 -- Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo and President Moise Tshombe of secessionist Katanga Province flew separately to the United Nations air base at Kitona today for talks on the Congo's future.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The first astronomical satellite launched by the United States has sent back word challenging the theory that the universe is in a steady state.
The City Council passed yesterday by a vote of 24 to 1 a bill to give $10,000 raises to Mayor Wagner and his seven colleagues on the incoming Board of Estimate.
Cardinal Spellman left by plane last night for a Christmas visit to American servicemen stationed in Germany and France. It is his eleventh Christmas tour of overseas military bases.

It is discouraging that while efforts are being made to improve housing, beautify the city and reduce crime there is at the same time a constant pressure in the reverse direction. A case in point is the new zoning ordinance which, unless modified, will have the effect of downgrading zoning requirements in the Washington Square-Greenwich Village neighborhood.
Treasury securities more than won back yesterday the slight price losses sustained in Monday's business but the trading was apathetic outside of the short-term area.
WOONSOCKET, R.I., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Woonsocket Spinning Company posted notices yesterday advising its 300 employes that the woolen mill would close, union sources said today.
On Dec. 1 you published an article by Edwin L. Dale on "Swiss Bankers Defend Secrecy" regarding foreign numbered accounts.

GENEVA, Dec. 19 -- Britain and the Soviet Union have told the three political leaders of Laos that their delay in forming a coalition government is preventing the completion of an international agreement to guarantee the neutrality and independence of Laos.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that there was a sharp increase here last week in the number of persons killed and injured in automobile accidents.
An agreement is near for WOR to televise and broadcast games of the New York Mets, the new National League baseball team.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was questioning twenty corporations and 500 broker-dealer concerns about "hot issues" sold to the public during the last two years.
It has been nearly a month since Albert S. Bard, who became 95 years old yesterday, last ripped an advertising poster from a utility pole and threw it into a rubbish basket at Broad and Wall Streets.
ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- The firs step in a state-wide campaign against air pollution was taken today.
Mark Schubart, vice president and dean of the Juilliard School of Music, will be the head of the school until a new president is chosen.
So-called investment-quality stocks were under heavy pressure yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange and the market made a broad retreat, closing at about its low point for the day.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The Urban League charged today that the Chicago Board of Education was budgeting 20 per cent less a pupil for "Negro" schools than for "white" schools.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 19 -- Communist guerrillas have stepped up their attacks on Government forces and civilians. The renewed rebel offensive had been expected with the advance of the rice-harvesting season, which offers the insurgents an opportunity to increase their food supplies at the expense of the Vietnamese farmers.
