BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The City Commission revoked the license of the segregation-troubled restaurant in the Greyhound bus station today. It ordered the restaurant to close at midnight.

The Radice Construction Company, a builder of luxury apartments in New York, New Jersey and Florida, has moved its headquarters from White Plains to 850 Third Avenue, at Fifty-first Street. The new office, with 2,000 square feet of space, was leased through Matthew J. Stacom, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc.
Boris Spassky, a grandmaster from Leningrad, won the Soviet Union chess championship at Baku yesterday, scoring 14 1/2 of a possible 20 points, according to Tass, the official Soviet news agency.
SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 19 -- The triumph of the official National Conciliation party in Sunday's elections for a new Constituent Assembly has created an unusual political situation in El Salvador.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 19 -- The Minnesota House of Representatives passed a Congressional redistricting bill today land sent it to Gov. Elmer L. Andersen, who is expected to sign it.

AT first glance, the Netherlands strikes the visiting American as agreeably familiar territory. In fashions and food, as well as in industrial activity, this prosperous land appears to be different, but only slightly so. Adding to the visitor's feeling of being at home away from home is the certainty that if he loses his way on a city street, a passer-by will point him in the right direction, affably, and probably in English.
Roger Vadim, somewhat daunted by the unfavorable reviews of his French film, "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," left for Tahati last night to take a "holiday from directing" -- but not from film-making.

The State of New Jersey yesterday designated Feb. 6 as the date of sale for issues of bonds totaling $45,000,000. Of the proceeds, $30,000,000 will be used to finance the purchase of land for recreational purposes and $15,000,000 for the construction of state institutions.

IT'S inescapable, but "Not While I'm Eating," an astonishingly inept revue that opened last night at the Madison Avenue Playhouse, brings to mind the old Mother Goose saw about beggars riding "if wishes were horses." A lot of wishful thinking must have gone into this venture, but that, unfortunately, was all. Some talent was needed.

The Federal Maritime Commission said in Washington yesterday that it was about to take a closer look at the lack of uniformity in charges for free time, wharf demurrage and storage for cargoes in Pacific ports.
MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- William Edwards Stevenson has been appointed United States Ambassador to the Philippines, the Foreign office announced today.

The Superior Court of New Jersey has ordered D. Kaltman Co., Inc., metropolitan-area wholesale drug concern, to show cause before the Chancery Division at Hackensack on Friday why it should not reveal its list of stockholders' names to Frank Pinchak, a practicing pharmacist of Paterson, N.J.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Orvil E. Dryfoos of New York was named by President Kennedy today to be a member of the Outdoor Recreation Resources Review Commission.
A zinc mine in Ogdensburg, N.J., has been returned to the active list after forty months on stand-by status.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, Dec. 20 -- Mongi Slim of Tunisia, President of the General Assembly, ruled yesterday that the agenda of the session that is to resume Jan. 15 would not be strictly limited to discussion of the Angola and Ruanda-Urundi questions.
DALLAS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Houston Oilers' claim to be pro football's first 6,000-yard team was upheld today.
New electronic devices with a wide variety of applications were announced yesterday by two major manufacturers.

Mike Ditka, a 1960 all-America end at the University of Pittsburgh, was named rookie of the year in the National Football League yesterday by a committee of sports writers and broadcasters for his work with the Chicago Bears.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The former Tristan da Cunha Islanders, who fled their home in the Atlantic two months ago because of a volcanic eruption, will be resettled permanently on the south coast of England, the Government said today.

AS a wind-up for the year, the Museum of Modern Art has selected a group of recent acquisitions in an exhibition, opening today, for which "Weather Vane" would be the perfect title. Only a fraction of the year's acquisitions are on display, but they tell the direction of the wind no less effectively for all that.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The General Assembly's Budget Committee approved a $200,000,000 bond issue tonight to prevent a financial collapse of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Government forecast today a 1962 winter wheat crop of 944,133,000 bushels. This would represent a reduction of 12 per cent from the 1961 harvest of 1,076,274,000 bushels and would indicate success for the Administration's new program for reducing the wheat surplus.
Airline schedules at the three principal metropolitan airports were upset yesterday by fog.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 19 -- A one-week postponement in the scheduled meeting of foreign ministers of the Americas Jan. 10 will be sought by Colombia, informed sources said today.
WARSAW, Dec. 19 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski has criticized a police raid on a Catholic youth meeting in Poznan as an "unheard of violation of the religious feelings."

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Tony DeMarco knocked out Don Jordan at Boston Garden tonight at 2:40 of the second round of their scheduled ten-round fight. It was Jordan's first knockout-defeat in seventy bouts.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Premier Cyrille Adoula of the Congo has warned the Union Miniere that he will bill it for the money that it has been paying to the Katangese government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Army issued today a pocket-size, twelve-page pamphlet entitled "Why Me?" to National Guard and Army Reservists who have been called to active duty.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Following is the text of the Army's "Why Me?" pamphlet giving questions and answers on the call-up of Army Reserves and National Guardsmen:
The U.S. Time Corporation announced yesterday cancellation of plans for a $5,000,000 watch factory in India, citing the Indian seizure of Goa and other Portuguese enclaves as the reason.
The new Kate Wollman Memorial Rink in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, will be dedicated Friday, Park Commissioner Newbold Morris announced yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- The French Government, the Paris police and thousands of demonstrators, all unanimous in opposition to Right-wing terrorists, collided tonight in street fights in which more than 130 persons were wounded.

An engineer employed by a plumbing concern accused of submitting rigged bids to the Board of Education was arrested for having refused to answer questions by investigators for the State Attorney General.

Charlie Hennigan of the Houston Oilers, Bill Mathis of the New York Titans and Bill Atkins of the Buffalo Bills led the United Press International poll yesterday for the American Football League all-star team.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 19 (UPI) -- The National Foundation announced today that it would raise funds to finance the construction of the Salk Institute for Biological Research. It said it would underwrite any deficit up to $12,000,000 for the institute's first two years of operation.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Villanova University today declared Ron Meyers ineligible for its Sun Bowl football game against Wichita when it learned he had signed with the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for business and labor gave sharply conflicting views today on the cause and cure of the unemployment problem.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The British Government would endorse a meeting between President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev to discuss Berlin and other critical issues, it was reliably reported tonight.
The old political Europe and the new political Europe coexist side-by-side these days here in Brussels.

"Question 7," a propaganda film produced under the auspices of the Lutheran Church, has been voted the best motion picture of 1961 by the committee on exceptional, films of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.
Archie Moore, the co-holder of the light-heavyweight championship, is being sued for $295,000 in a breach of contract action lodged by Feature Sports, Inc.

Events today: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Down Town Glee Club, with Choir Boys of Trinity Church and Choir Boys of St. Paul's Church of Flatbush, George Mead, conductor, Charles Ennis, organist and choirmaster, Carnegie Hall, 8; Canticum Musicum, Muriel Haas, soprano, Doris Cylkowski, Alice Netter and Thaddeus Cylkowski, harpsichordists, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Maria Lopez-Vito, pianist, Kaufmann Concert Hall, Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, 8:30.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- With-trading at a low ebb, prices on the stock market here today moved aimlessly and within narrow limits.

The number of contributors yesterday to The New York Times Neediest Cases was 943, which ranks among the largest figures for a single day since the Fund began in 1912. Since the present appeal opened on Dec. 10, there have been 6,010 donors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A medical executive told a Senate subcommittee today that a New York hospital saved up to $500,000 a year by using drugs without brand names.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- President Sukarno sent a new letter to President Kennedy today as Indonesia continued a military buildup aimed at wresting control of Netherlands New Guinea from the Dutch.

Senator Jacob K. Javits criticized the Kennedy Administration last night for what he termed its failure to support the recent sixteen-nation resolution in the United Nations calling for direct peace negotiations between the Arab countries and Israel.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Joseph P. Kennedy remained in a serious condition tonight as a result of a stroke yesterday.
Potato, cocoa and rubber futures, took the lead in trading volume yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Sessions otherwise were generally dull.

Degrees of darkness are difficult to distinguish with accuracy. From late afternoon until night has fallen the supply of natural light fades slowly through the processes of twilight until lowering visibility gives place to complete darkness.

Vacation and holiday payments for longshoremen in the Port of New York totaled $10,250,995 for the contract year that ended Sept. 30, Alexander P. Chopin, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, reported yesterday.
Bernhard Morris was 100 years old yesterday. He has but one concern -- youth in the atomic age.
DISPLAY experts and party decorators were the first this year to start caroling "Deck the halls with boughs of holly" but by now most of the nation is ready to join in the chorus.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 20 -- In a precedent-setting decision, the Government of Italy has been found guilty by the European Court of Justice of having violated a provision of the treaty establishing the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

SOUTH LONDONDERRY, Vt., Dec. 20 -- SKI SKETCH: The Swiss-born Hans Thorner has been skiing for forty-five years. During that time he has filmed commercial ski movies, performed in them, headed ski schools and operated ski lodges.

TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina said today that President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress program could turn into one of the most important factors in the development of Latin America.
St. John's basketball team routed St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 92 -- 64, last night at Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens.
The Dime Savings Bank of Wililamsburgh yesterday announced the election of Joseph T. Sharkey as chairman and Ray W. Kline as president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Following are excerpts from a speech in Los Angeles yesterday by George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State, outlining United States policy on the Congo:
An experiment started here early last year by the New York Telephone Company has become a boon to Christmas shoppers.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Bermuda's Government House, where President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan are scheduled to meet tomorrow, is on a ridge running along the north shore of this 352-year-old British colony.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Customers were so scarce in the grain futures trade today that the market hardly showed any sign of life except in rye. Nearly all contracts held within small fractional ranges all day, with activity stalled for long periods at a time.
Since Moss Hart took the keenest pleasure in being alive, the news of his death in Palm Springs yesterday is particularly devastating.

The United States Government was ordered yesterday to pay $345,000 to the widow and young daughter of a Pittsburgh business man killed in the 1958 mid-air collision of an airliner and a Maryland Air National Guard jet.
The following two paragraph were inadvertently omitted from my column published Dec. 20 and I would be grateful if you could print them:
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- President Kennedy hailed today what he called the "solution to the political difficulties" of the Dominican Republic.

IT is said that behind every man of note there is a woman, and Santa Claus is no exception. About sixty of the best-groomed men in town who wear red suits and have white beards receive the services of four expert women dressers before they venture out.

Hamilton Fish Armstrong's letter in The Times of Dec. 20 protesting the "downgrading" of West Eight Street and the Sixth Avenue section from Waverly Place to West Tenth Street typifies the attitude of many who may not have read the proposed zoning change.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The British Government is prepared to go beyond exploration and discuss "matters of substance" when East-West talks resume in Moscow, Edward Heath, Lord Privy Seal, told the House of Commons tonight.

In an editorial on Dec. 7 you examined the finances of the Transit Authority and the means used to retain the 15-cent fare. However, you neglected to mention the single most important reason we have been able to retain this fare since 1953.

WHEN Vengalil Krishnan Krishna Menon arrived yesterday at the United Nations in the closing hours before the General Assembly was to recess for Christmas, one delegate remarked: "This may be more than we can stand."

The State Supreme Court has made permanent its prohibition against enforcement of the medieval welfare code through which Newburgh, N.Y., sought to cut relief costs by degrading its needy citizens. It has been clear ever since the "get tough" regulations were promulgated last July that they were inhuman; it is now officially determined, as we suggested at the time, that they were illegal as well.

Miss Rheingold will have a new set of mentors starting in 1962. Foote, Cone Belding, the agency that has nurtured Miss Rheingold for more than a decade, has parted company with Liebmann Breweries, Inc. maker of Rheingold beer.

Richmond, Va., borrowed $7,800,000 in the public market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised on bonds due serially from 1963 to 1982, which were sold at public bidding at an interest cost of 2.939 per cent.
NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Ernie Hefferle resigned today as the Boston College football coach to join the coaching staff at the University of Pittsburgh.

The financing of a 159-mile extension of the Florida Turnpike north from Fort Pierce to Wildwood was effectuated yesterday by the Florida Turnpike Authority by the sale of $157,000,000 of revenue bonds to investment bankers.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Miami policeman, often working on his own time, cracked a tough murder case and found his sister involved.
India's Defense Minister V.K. Krishna Menon, heatedly denied yesterday that India's occupation of Portugal's coastal enclaves in India amounted to aggression.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board asked savings and loan associations today to hold the line on dividends paid to depositors so that they would not have to increase mortgage interest rates when the spring home-building season started.

Events today: "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Handel's "Messiah," presented by the Oratorio Society, T. Charles Lee, conductor, Gail Manners, soprano, Jean Maderia, contralto, Walter Carringer, tenor, John Macurdy, bass, Albert Fuller, harpsichordist, Carnegie Hall, 8; Emilia Conde, pianist and singer, assisted by Moises E. Rodriguez, guitar trio and singers, and Polly, Rogers, dancer, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:15; Program of electronic music directed by David Walker, Art for 1111 Lexington Avenue, 8.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk met in executive session with six members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as criticism of the Administration's support for the United Nations action in the Congo mounted.
KENOSHA, Wis., Dec. 20 -- The McGuffey Reader trial appeared today to be headed for settlement out of court, with the 1879 textbook remaining in the curriculum at the Twin Lakes school.
A 43-year-old woman was struck on the head and robbed early yesterday morning in the elevator of the Stuyvesant Town apartment house where she lives.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 20 -- Dr. Arthur Engel, head of the Royal Medical Board, disclosed today that he had tried in vain to persuade Dr. Bertil Bjorklund to postpone his current cancer vaccine tests.
MUSKEGON, Mich., Dec. 20 (AP) -- There's room for just two more persons in near-by Laketon Township's community fall-out shelter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Grave misgivings that the United Nations can be returned to the peace-making purposes for which it was established have now been expressed among so many and diverse American groups that no longer can U.N. critics be successfully segregated as Right-Wing extremists, conservatives, isolationists, Fascists, pro-colonialists, and so on.

The following reports of ownership and changes in ownership of equity securities listed on the American Stock Exchange have been filed by officers, directors and large stockholders, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The third X-15 rocket ship made its first flight today in a successful test of a new automated control system.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- Annoyance here about United States displeasure with India's seizure of Goa mounted today.
The United Federation of Teachers will ask for $68,000,000 in salary increases when it meets with the Board of Education today for the first time as the bargaining agent for the city's teachers.
The virtues of a bad temper and direct action against nuisances were expounded yesterday to a group of New York's civic leaders by Albert S. Bard, 95-year-old vice chairman of the Citizens Union.

WARSAW, Dec. 20 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski has appealed for a parliamentary investigation of what he termed "illegal" Government acts of discrimination and harassment against the Roman Catholic Church.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Wilt Chamberlain and Paul Arizin helped give the Philadelphia Warriors a 117-102 victory over the Detroit Pistons in the finale of a National Basketball Association double-header tonight.

RIO DE JANIERO Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A former employe of the circus confessed tonight that he set last Sunday's circus fire in suburban Niterol in which 323 persons were killed and about 800 injured, the police said.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20 -- The International Business Machines Corporation announced today it would transfer its permanent headquarters to an office building under construction on a 443-acre woodland tract in Armonk.
Half the twenty-two men named yesterday to the National Football League's all-star team were drawn from the Green Bay Packers and New York Giants, who meet for the league championship on Dec. 31.

The Borough Presidents, despite the certain and considerable lightening of their labors in prospect because of Charter revision, insist on a $10,000 salary increase instead of $5;000. They have thus done their best to discredit the whole city pay rise process.

" I AM deplored for extolling President Eisenhower for the very reasons for which I should reprehend him," Marianne Moore remarks innocently in her golden book of spirit and sense, "A Marianne Moore Reader."*

Doug Harvey got the shooting and all-out play he was seeking and the New York Rangers snapped a three-game losing string by blasting the Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 1, at Madison Square Garden last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The lights of the national Christmas tree flickered on briefly and then went out for ten minutes to mar the lighting ceremony at President's Park at dusk today.

" Masterpiece," a drama about the court trial in Amsterdam of the late Hans Van Meegeren, the most famous art forger of modern times, will be televised on Sunday, Feb. 4, from 10 to 11 P.M. by the National Broadcasting Company.
The election of Herbert R. Silverman as chairman and chief executive officer of James Talcott, Inc., was announced yesterday by the retiring chairman, James Talcott.
Most of the professional bondsmen in Brooklyn refused yesterday to bail out any prisoners because of a dispute with District Attorney Edward S. Silver over refunds on forfeited bonds.

The market for high grade bonds was given pause yesterday by the decision of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to come to market later in the winter to borrow $300,000,000 on new debentures not convertible into common stock.

A revised version of "Brecht on Brecht: His Life and His Art," to be called "Brecht on Brecht," will be produced by Cheryl Crawford on Jan. 3 at the Theatre de Lys, 121 Christopher Street, for a limited engagement.

TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- Governor-elect Richard J. Hughes said today he would demand an expanded commuter rail program by the Port of New York Authority, beyond the acquisition of the Hudson Tubes, as New Jersey's price for ending a deadlock with New York.

Jim Brown of the Cleveland Browns survived a late-season rally by Jim Taylor of the Green Bay Packers and set a National Football League record by taking rushing honors for the fifth consecutive year.

Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the Canticum Musicum presented three Bach concertos -- for one harpsichord in D; for two harpsichords, in C minor; and for three harpsichords, in C. Between the first two came a "Salve Regina" for soprano and strings, by Niccolo Porpora, one of Bach's contemporaries.

The Nissan Motor Company, Ltd., Japan's largest automobile manufacturer, has arranged an $11,000,000 credit through the Export-Import Bank in Washington, Katsuji Kawamata, president and chief executive officer of the company said yesterday.
Public utility stocks were pounded heavily in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, which otherwise was virtually a stand-off.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Circuit Court Judge J. Cullen Ganey revoked today the probationary sentences of twenty-three present and former executives in the nation's heavy electrical equipment industry.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Radio Corporation of America believes it has passed the peak of the high cost of introducing data-processing systems and consequently expects a marked improvement in earnings next year, David Sarnoff, chairman, said yesterday in a year-end statement.

Archie Moore, the light-heavyweight co-champion, was accused in Supreme Court yesterday of setting up a "device by which he seeks, in fraud of his New York creditors, to insulate his New York earnings from their just claims."

Governors of the American Stock Exchange customarily meet every first and third Thursday of the month. Today is the third Thursday, of course, and today's board meeting will be the first since the special meeting of Dec. 11, at which Edward T. McCormick resigned his $75,000-a-year presidency of the exchange.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The activities of the British Information Services in the United States are to be reduced beginning next year, the Foreign Office has announced.
Franklin Plaza, a middle-income cooperative in East Harlem, was dedicated yesterday in a ceremony attended by Mayor Wagner and William Reid, chairman of the city Housing Authority.
FOR those who are contemplating giving an animal as a Christmas gift, the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals offers the following suggestions.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Britain's Department of Scientific and Industrial Research will give grants totaling nearly 1,200,000 ($3,300,000) for two new radio telescopes at Cambridge University Jodrell Bank and other projects, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- The Maurice L. Rothschild Co. group of retail stores in the Chicago area has been sold to Botany Industries, Inc., of New York, it was announced today. Terms of the cash acquisition were not disclosed.
SAYREVILLE, N.J., Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The bodies of two young brothers were found today in a car submerged in the Raritan River near the Victory Bridge here.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Capt. Al Kaemmerlen scored 26 points tonight to lead the Princeton basketball team to an 81-65 victory over Rutgers in Dillon Gymnasium.

Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" received its fifth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Leontyne Price was again the Cio-Cio-San, but this time she had an almost completely different supporting cast.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 20 -- Some high Portuguese officials expressed serious concern today that India might not remain content with annexing Portuguese Goa, Damao and Diu, but may seek to extend her anti-Portuguese campaign to other areas, including Africa.

St. Mark's Place, a rather bizarre street of the avant garde and Russian bath rubbers, was made no less whimsical yesterday by the sight of a llama staring languidly down from a window at pedestrians below.

Former President Herbert Hoover strongly criticized yesterday United States support of the United Nations military operations in Katanga. He said that the people of that secessionist Congo province were seeking freedom from Communist domination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Kennedy-Macmillan conference, opening tomorrow in Bermuda, comes at a difficult time. The President is preoccupied with the illness of his father. The Prime Minister is preoccupied with a series of difficult domestic political controversies over the Common Market, the United Nations and India.
An eighty-foot high suspension building, hung above ground in an architectural sling and supported by eight pylons, will house transportation and travel exhibits at the New York 1964-65 World's Fair.

GENEVA, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The cotton textile subcommittee of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) is bogged down in disagreement over how to draft a long-term agreement on world cotton textile trading, it was learned today.
Many of the city's top appointed officials at the $25,000-salary level will get $5,000 increases early next year, it was reported at City Hall yesterday.

Bear, Stearns Co. and Straus, Blosser McDowell and associates are offering to the public today units of securities in Executive House, Inc. The offering consists of 6 per cent subordinated sinking fund debentures due Oct. 1, 1971, and 400,000 common shares and purchase warrants for an additional 400,000 shares.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Federal judge said today he would continue an order prohibiting the National Labor Relations Board from holding a union election aboard a fleet of Honduran-flag ships.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 20 -- A low cheer went up today among the Green Bay Packers. Elijah Pitts had scored again.

CHRISTMAS wouldn't be quite the same without some version of "Cinderella." This year we can thank the Russians, no less, for an opulent feature-length transcription in color of Sergei Prokofieff's ballet, which opened yesterday at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- The United States declared its readiness today to play a role in the peaceful settlement of the Netherlands-Indonesian dispute over Netherlands New Guinea.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Dec. 21 -- The main part of the sixteenth session of the General Assembly ended early this morning with a condemnation of the failure of the Soviet and Hungarian Governments to heed Assembly resolutions on the situation in Hunfary.

JOHN HATHORN, editor of the magazine Texas Bridge, unfortunately was in the hospital when the most recent national tournament was played in his home town in Texas, but this writer paid a visit to him and was able to swap some tall tales.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Archibald MacLeish, three times winner of a Pulitzer Prize as a poet and playwright, is closing out a twelve-year career of teaching at Harvard College. After devoting the spring term to his own writing, Mr. MacLeish will retire as Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory.
New York University announced yesterday that Dr. Harold O. Voorhis, vice president and secretary of the university, would retire next July 1 after forty-two years with the university.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 20 -- The prominent newspaper Jornal do Brasil, which has been sharply critical of United States policy, reflected a change in Brazilian opinion today after a speech by Ambassador Lincoln Gordon of the United States promoting the Alliance for Progress and replying to attacks on foreign enterprise.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Dec. 21 -- The General Assembly acted on a broad front last night to overcome what is regarded as one of the gravest issues now facing the United Nations -- the imminent threat of bankruptcy.
The nation's inventories of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes, dropped 6,303,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

IN recollections of childhood at Christmas, one of the most compelling evocations is that of stockings hung from the mantel with care. The stockings bulged, not only with toys of a miniature sort, but with clusters of dark raisins, with oranges, tangerines and candy canes.
Sales and earnings of the Dana Corporation for its first fiscal quarter, ended on Nov. 30, rose sharply from the year-earlier level, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Government announced penalty action today against eighteen concerns and individuals for allegedly illegal shipments of aircraft, automotive and other equipment to Cuba by way of Mexico.

THE 17-year-old boy, driving the wagonload of bricks, clucked his horses to a stop alongside the ball field. Soon he was in the game, the delivery forgotten while his father waited in growing impatience. Eventually the father trailed the wagon to the ball field. Should he order his son back on the job or let him play ball?
TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- India's prestige in Japan has dropped sharply, perhaps irreparably, as a result of the invasion of Goa.

The expansion of the national tennis championship tournaments at Forest Hills, Queens, next year from the usual ten days to a full two weeks was announced yesterday by Edward A. Turville of St. Petersburg, Fla.

THE New York City Ballet last night gave the season's first presentation of the Balanchine-Stravinsky "Apollo" and created something in the nature of a miracle. In its principal roles were Jacques d'Amboise, Allegra Kent, Patricia Wilde and Jillana, all of whom have danced the roles many times before, and Robert Irving was once again in charge of the orchestra.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Miss Marina Ann Forstmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius G. Forstmann of Broadfield, Belle Haven, and Miss Marian Elizabeth Beane, daughter of Mrs. Louis B. Stoner of West Hartford and A.C. Beane of Greenwich, were presented here tonight at a supper dance.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Government scientists said today they had succeeded in cracking partly the "genetic code," the key to the reproduction of all living matter.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 20 -- A Christmas tree vender has gone out of business voluntarily here following a complaint by a civic group that his stand was in a residential zone.
Your Dec. 12 editorial on the Congo crisis was most commendable. May I offer some comments in support of this position from a somewhat different vantage point.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Eight members of the Green Bay Packers today were named to the West squad for the National Football League's all-star Pro Bowl game here Jan. 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- An old specter of the political wars has been seen again in Washington -- the specter of the "softness on communism" issue; that haunted this country in the last years of the Truman Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission resumed today a hearing on a request by Consolidated Edison Company for provisional permission to operate an atomic reactor, but then recessed the hearing until Jan. 3.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a rules change to prevent brokers from absconding with the proceeds from sales of new stock.
Three unfinished games were completed last night in the United States chess championship at the Prince George Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Dr. Luther L. Terry, the United States surgeon general, announced today the award of $16,587,135 in grants to thirty-seven institutions in twenty-two states to build medical research facilities.
The works of Sholem Aleichem one of the greatest of Jewish humorists, are about to be moved from New York City to Tel Aviv.

THE frantic Wall Street worker faced with last-minute Christmas shopping need not despair. Although many of the shops in the vicinity do not have the glamour of Fifth Avenue, they do offer -- to say the least -- a variety of gifts, which include everything from electric blenders to live snakes.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 -- A leader of the opposition to Premier Fidel Castro said today that bloody fighting had broken out in the mountains of central Cuba between a guerrilla army and 25,000 of the militia.

The New York Giants went back to work at Yankee Stadium yesterday after a two-day rest. Coach A1 Sherman began preparing his athletes for their Dec. 31 play-off with the Packers at Green Bay, Wis., for the National Football League championship.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- President Kennedy will meet with Prime Minister Macmillan of Britain in Bermuda tomorrow, as scheduled.

HANOVER, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The sale of two trotting stallions to the Soviet Union was reported today by the Hanover Shoe Farms, Inc., the largest standardbred breeding farm in the world. It is believed they are the first American horses to be exported to Russia since before 1917.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts cleared the way today for the construction of a multi-million dollar commercial and business center in the Back Bay district.
The sale of the giant French liner Liberte for use as a floating hotel at the world's fair in Seattle appeared yesterday to be in doubt.
Paul Crowell, City Hall reporter for The New York Times, received a scroll from Mayor Wagner yesterday on the occasion of Mr. Crowell's seventieth birthday.
Allen P. Kirby took another jab yesterday at John D. Murchison, president of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company of which Mr. Kirby is the largest stockholder.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The bells of St. Mary-le-Bow, silent since 1939, rang out today and London prepared to welcome the "first" Cockneys born since the war.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- More than 300 miners voted unanimously today to continue a strike that has halted a $66,000,000 defense project here.

Small industrial cities have their downs and ups these days. Recently, some 250 workers at the Geneva, N.Y., plant of Ekco Products Company were told the plant would be closed unless they took a substantial pay cut, which they rejected.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Moss Hart, Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, stage director and scenario writer, died today of a heart attack. He was 57 years old.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 20 -- President Alberto Lieras Camargo unveiled today a ten-year national economic development plan that will be presented for financing by the Alliance for Progress.
TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- Cells are being made to march through their entire life cycles in step at a research institute here.
A $2,000,000 suit by 809 home owners in Rosedale, Queens, was filed yesterday against the Port Authority as the operator of New York International Airport and the forty airlines that use the field.
The breeding of dogs is a form of self-expression, said Lloyd C. Brackett of Allegan, Mich., at the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club meeting yesterday in Luchow's Restaurant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Federal Trade Commission has called upon the St. Regis Paper Company to produce confidential files at an unusual anti-trust hearing next week.
Princeton's unbeaten swimming team posted its third victory of the season by defeating Columbia, 64 -- 31, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League meet at University Pool last night.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The Government was accused today of harshness in repressing the demonstration staged here last night by Left-wingers against Right-wing subversion.
Winter begins at 9:20 P.M. today.

Divergent trade reaction this week to the proposed international coffee agreement has underscored the size and complexity of the economic and political problems involved in formulating such a plan. The terms of the draft pact, worked out by representatives of the world's leading producer and consumer nations, were made known last Sunday in Washington.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 60 cents a bale off yesterday. Trading was slow. Rallying tendencies were checked by hedging and liquidation. The July contract was unchanged.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Cyril G. Fox resigned today as chairman of Fels Co., because of "complete disagreement" with the present policies of the 59-year-old Philadelphia soap and detergent manufacturing concern.

ROME, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- Fifty-four students of the North American College prostrated themselves today before the altar of St. Peter's Basilica in ceremonies ordaining them as priests of the Roman Catholic Church.

The Supper Dance, a subscription event for debutantes of the last three seasons, will be held Saturday evening at the St. Regis Roof. Proceeds will go to the building fund of Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Douglas Aircraft Company, Santa Monica, Calif., won a $50,000,000 contract today to modify the upper stage of the Saturn rocket for use in manned flights around the moon.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The director of a dental clinic for longshoremen has been dismissed and the clinic closed pending an investigation of discrepancies in its financial records by the Waterfront Commission.
John J. Bergen, who never saw a hockey game until he became president of the New York Rangers two seasons ago, believes college hockey can gain an important position in the New York sports picture.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in the month to last Friday by 236,052 shares to a total of 3,406,805 shares, its highest level since mid-June.

The oldest established athletic event at Madison Square Garden den and one of the oldest in the nation was held at Madison Square Garden yesterday. It was the annual prep school hockey game in which the St. Paul's School of Concord, N.H., has been a protagonist for sixty-six years, thirty-four of them in the Garden.
ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Democratic legislative leaders called today for an increase of "at least 50 per cent" in state aid to cities, towns and villages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Department of Defense has been considering a charge of $1 for each out-patient visit made by the wives and children of servicemen to military hospitals or dispensaries.

I applaud your editorial in the Dec. 14 issue entitled "The Cairo Case." It points up properly the disregard for international custom and usage shown by President Nasser of the United Arab Republic who seized four members of the Commission of French Interest in Egypt.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Thursday, Dec. 21 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga and Premier Cyrille Adoula of the central Government concluded today an agreement to end the secession of Katanga and restore the wealthy province to a unified Congo.

Stockholders of the Cities Service Company, at a special meeting in Dover, Del., yesterday ratified a plan to merge with the Columbian Carbon Company. The latter's shareholders, at a special meeting here, also approved the merger proposal yesterday.

A CRITIC without prejudices is like a dog without a tail. He has nothing to wag. Unfortunately, I have some prejudices to wag today. For Alberto Giacometti usually leaves me unwarmed, and as a rule Dimitri Hadzi's work leaves me cold.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The long Congressional deadlock over proposed postal-rate increases appeared to be breaking today.
Dry weather worked wonders for the Christmas spirit yesterday among shoppers and partygoers. Holiday parties proliferated all over town in hospitals and service centers.
Although the Yankees are commonly associated with power as exploited by their mighty home run sluggers, the world champions were not a club to neglect their defense in 1961.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -- The most complex half-hour scripts in television -- and perhaps the longest -- are for a show without words. The difficulty of preparing these scripts is the reason Ernie Kovacs does them so rarely.

Production of electric power in the nation rose to a record high of 16,695,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday. A week earlier 16,084,000,000 kilowatt-hours were produced, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
The election of Watson K. Blair, Joseph F. Lord and Lewis T. Preston as vice presidents has been announced by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Following is the text of a statement by President Kennedy today on the situation in the Dominican Republic:
LEOPOLDVILLE, Dec. 20 -- Premier Adoula of the central regime and President Tshombe of Katanga conferred steadily today and informed sources reported indications of an acceptable compromise.

President Kennedy meets Prime Minister Macmillan today for the fourth time since he entered the White House eleven months ago. The special relationship between the two English-speaking countries so assiduously cultivated by Winston Churchill is being submerged in the wider Atlantic community; but the United States and Britain remain the two leading powers in that community and constant consultation and agreement between them is crucial.

The nation's leading retail store chains increased their sales in November by 6.3 per cent from the 1960 level, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. Sales for the first eleven months of this year rose 3.8 per cent above the figure for the 1960 period.

During the days of John Dewey, when Teachers College was at the peak of its influence, its faculty was described as "one big unhappy family" because of the internal debates, intellectual disagreements and scholarly feuds.

The property at 167 to 175 East Ninety-sixth Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, has been purchased by a group headed by Charles E. Sigety, former Deputy Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration. The buyers have announced preliminary plans for improving the plot with a fifteen-story building that will contain apartments for elderly persons.
New York's two principal labor disputes moved no nearer a settlement of the principal issues yesterday, with New Year's Eve strike deadlines now only eleven days off.

Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad at a board meeting here yesterday reassigned to the president all top executive responsibility and abolished the title of chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1.

HOW many of us ever bother -- or dare -- to think how fearfully chance can thrust a sudden, shattering, deforming experience into our lives? Jack Garfein has in his new picture, "Something Wild," which came to the Plaza yesterday, and anyone who sees it is not likely to be contemptuous of chance thenceforth.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Villanova scored its eighth straight basketball victory tonight. The Wildcats defeated St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., 64 -- 59, at the Palestra.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 20 (UPI) -- A monkey that survived a 5,000-mile rocket trip 600 miles into space had to be abandoned in the Atlantic today when a radio beacon failed to work.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Army assured Congress today that it would make no drastic changes in the reserve forces without first consulting the appropriate Congressional committees.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- By all the readings on the business horizon in Western Europe as 1961 began to fade into history, prospects appeared favorable for sustained progress well into 1962, the Economic Commission for Europe reported in its Quarterly Bulletin.

American Telephone Telegraph Company yesterday authorized the sale of $300,000,000 of non-convertible bonds at competitive bidding on Feb. 14, 1962. The bonds will mature on Feb. 1, 1994, and will not be redeemable before Feb. 1, 1967.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Nine men were indicted today in Covington, Ky., on charges of conspiring to evade $387,555 in gambling taxes.
The Syracuse Nationals of the National Basketball Association agreed yesterday to allow Dick Barnett to play with the Cleveland Pipers of the rival American Basketball League.
Benjamin J. Davis, a leader of the Communist party, was the center of violence among students at City College yesterday after he gave a speech there.
Questionable administrative practices at the State University Long Island Center at Oyster Bay, including the destruction of official records, were reported yesterday by Controller Arthur Levitt.
The heads of two unions demanding a shorter work week said yesterday that they would not sign new contracts that failed to provide for a cut in hours.
The year-end churning of large blocks of short-term money furnished most of the business in the market for prime debt securities yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A considerably improved trade volume pushed the grain futures market into a broader price range today on the Board of Trade.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21 -- The authorities of suburban niteroi took precautions tonight to prevent a possible lynching of two Brazilians held on charges of having set Sunday's circus tent fire.
The National Labor Relation Board in St. Louis has issued a complaint of unfair labor practices against Federal Barge Lines, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Army said today that its Nike Zeus anti-missile missile had successfully intercepted a missile in flight for the first time.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- It appeared today that the first Cockney to be born in twenty-two years may grow up with a brogue. She was born yesterday to a large Irish family.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- An Internal Revenue Service agent accused of taking a bribe was indicted today in Federal court.

Sir Harold Jeffreys of the University of Cambridge, England, and Prof. Felix A. Vening Meinesz of the University of Utrecht, in the Neherlands, have been selected to share the second $25,000 Vetlesen Prize awarded by Columbia University.
Sales volume on the New York Stock Exchange passed the 1,000,000,000 share mark yesterday for the first time in any year since 1929.

Robert Manning has resigned as Sunday editor of The New York Herald Tribune, the newspaper announced yesterday. Mr. Manning had been Sunday editor for five months, having joined The Herald Tribune in that capacity in late July.
What appears to be the first medical use of a revolutionary optical device called the laser has been reported by Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and the American Optical Company.

The board of directors of the National Steel Corporation proposed a two-for-one split of the company's capital stock yesterday. It also disclosed that the company might sell some 1,500,000 additional shares of the new stock if the split was authorized.
A transfer of jurisdiction over many defendants under 21 years old from the criminal courts to the new state Family Court was proposed yesterday.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 21 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery has offered to intervene in the dispute between Guatemala and Britain over British Honduras, the Guatemalan President, Gen. Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes said today.
EAST LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The University of Minnesota Gophers staged a ninety-minute scrimmage today, and Coach Murray Warmath wasn't a bit impressed.
ALBANY, Ga., Dec. 21 (UPI) -- An economic boycott of white business places has been put into effect by the Negro community in this south Georgia town, the scene of racial demonstrations last week.

WINTER is the season when New Yorkers fall heir to three varieties of cabbage, all boons to good health and degustation. They are the white or green cabbage, the red cabbage and the Savoy. All three abound in Vitamin C.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- In a traditional Christmas action, Governor Rockefeller today reduced the sentences of four convicted murderers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -The Federal Trade Commission rejected today a motion by six drug companies to disqualify the commission chairman, Paul Rand Dixon, from a pending case.

The Hertz Corporation announced yesterday it had negotiated a $40,000,000 twenty-year loan with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Leon C. Greenebaum, chairman of Hertz, said the funds from the new loan would be used to retire outstanding equipment obligations and to carry out an expansion program.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- A new state program designed to give free technical training to qualified welfare recipients to make them more readily employable was announced today by Governor Rockefeller.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Activity on the stock market here remained subdued today and price movements were small and irregular.

The appointment of John J. Carty, a 53-year-old career Civil Service employe, as First Deputy Controller beginning Jan. 1 was announced yesterday by Controller-elect Abraham D. Beame. Mr. Beame is now Director of the Budget.
A holiday outpouring is expected to drain untold thousands from the city by road, rail and air late today -- the last working day before Christmas for many persons.
PROVIDENCE, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics easily defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 122 -- 103, in a National Basketball Association game at Rhode Island Auditorium tonight.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 22 (UPI) -- The flooding Pearl River crested here today at 37.5 feet, a record, as National Guardsmen and convicts battled to hold a levee.
Electric utilities took another beating yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Standard Poor's utility index once again fell more than 1 per cent.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -- The Indian Government offered today to repatriate Portuguese nationals from the territories of Goa, Damao and Diu.
BINH HUNG, Vietnam, Dec. 14 -- When Japan invaded China in 1937 a scholarly young Chinese decided that patriotism and his family's honor required that he enlist in his country's armed forces.
Governors of the American Stock Exchange were advised yesterday to lose no time in selecting a new president to succeed Edward T. McCormick, who resigned that $75,000-a-year post on Dec. 11.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Representative from Long Island has asked President Kennedy to obtain Federal funds to pay a $28,000 local tax bill on the forty-five-room mansion in Glen Cove owned by the Soviet Union.
AGREED: that the Bible ought to be retranslated at intervals to keep the original and the current languages as close as possible.

MONTREAL, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- A Montreal cast-off, Ab McDonald, scored with less than a minute and one-half to play tonight, giving the Chicago Black Hawks a 4 -- 3 victory over the Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.
William Zeckendorf completed arrangements yesterday to bring $43,750,000 worth of capital into his real estate empire, largely through a new partnership with a British realty company.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 20 -- Emperor Haile Selassie said today his great concern at this time, the fourth decade of his reign, was that Ethiopia set African nations "the good example" of economic, political and cultural progress.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 21 -- About 100 men are engaged here in a strange diplomatic operation.

Checking account turnover continued to rise in November, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase from October was 2 per cent in New York City, 3 per cent in six other large money centers, and 1 per cent in 337 other reporting localities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has abandoned his proposal to charge service men's wives and children a $1 fee for each out-patient visit to military hospitals, the Defense Department announced today.
Trading volume in cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange set a new record yesterday. However, the run was downhill.
Bolivia is setting aside money to resume interest payments in 1962 on the nation's twice-defaulted external bonds payable in United States dollars.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 21 -- United Nations headquarters in the Congo denied today that the agreement reached earlier in the day by President Moise Tshombe of Katanga to end the secession of Katanga had to be ratified by provincial authorities.
THE Oratorio Society of New York made its way through Handel's "Messiah" for the 139th time last night.
ALBANY Dec. 21 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the impending appointment of a new Presiding Judge and a speed-up policy for the State Court of Claims.
A six-month extension of the city's contract with the Duncan Parking Meter Maintenance Company was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
Several contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday made their donations in the form of gifts for others.
Fresh details are slowly emerging from reticent Administration sources about the expanded program of American participation in South Vietnam's anti-Communist struggle.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- Premier Khrushchev congratulated Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India today on the seizure of the Portuguese enclaves. He described the Indian action as "fully lawful and justified."
KENOSHA, Wis., Dec. 21 (AP) -- An attempt to reach an out-of-court settlement in the dispute over use of the McGuffey reader in the public elementary school at Twin Lakes broke up today.
Six subsidiaries of the American Electric Power Company of New York filed twelve antitrust suits in Federal Court yesterday against twenty-two manufacturers of electrical equipment.
IF racing is the sport of kings, then skating may be the plebeian pastime. In theory, all a skater needs are a pair of skates and an ice-covered pond.

The Misses Pamela Reed Brooks and Elizabeth Oakley Hutchins were honored last night at a dinner dance given at 1A East Seventy-seventh Street by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. A. Oakley Brooks of 1220 Park Avenue and Edgartown, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Hutchins of 1220 Park Avenue and Cazenovia, N.Y.
ANNISTON, Mo., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The case of eighteen rural Negro children who have been unable to gain admission to a county high school was settled today after Gov. John M. Dalton intervened.

Almost a quarter-ton of sibling rivalry will be added to the 1962 New York Giants. Steve Simms of Rutgers and Bill Triplett of Miami (Ohio) University, two fullbacks whose brothers toil in National Football League beef trusts, signed Giant contracts yesterday for next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Following are excerpts from a statement made by Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, at a news conference here today:

The Board of Education and a negotiating committee for the United Federation of Teachers agreed in an hour-long meeting yesterday to set up operating procedures for collective bargaining as quickly as possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. Congress is expected to set next year a five-year record in the handling of legislation concerned with the nation's transportation systems, Dr. George P. Baker, president of the Transportation Association of America, predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy met with top aides today to plan moves against United States Communists who have defied an order to register as agents of the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The United States welcomed today the agreement between the Premier of the Congo and the President of secessionist Katanga Province to restore the unity of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Administration's review of oil requirements and import quotas will be conducted by a Petroleum Study Committee drawn from seven Cabinet agencies. Only the Post Office, Agriculture and Health Departments are not represented.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- President Sukarno discussed today "implementation" of his two-day-old "command on the liberation" of Netherlands New Guinea, the Foreign Ministry announced.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the largest in the nation, reported yesterday a net profit for November of $4,954,900. It was the sixth successive profitable month and helped cut the 1961 deficit to $2,728,324.
A surprising number of new magazines have made their debut this year, but the two that have attracted the widest attention are Show and Show Business Illustrated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A conference of rabbis who direct Hillel Foundations of B'nai B'rith endorsed today the teaching of religion at state universities "when their purpose is limited to promoting knowledge and understanding and does not seek to indoctrinate or make converts."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 21 UPI) -- Three youths who sponsored strict welfare legislation at a recent young people's assembly demanded today that State Welfare Commissioner Raymond W. Houston retract a charge that they had been influenced by right-wingers.
NICE, France, Dec. 21 -- Four men were convicted here today of the theft of twenty modern art masterpieces from the Colombe d'Or Inn at St. Paul-de-Vence April 1, 1960.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Shoppers at the nation's department stores spent more last week than during any previous six-day shopping period, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

The needy of New York in our time have a place to turn for food, clothing and shelter. Yet something more is needed. To the traveler who had fallen among thieves, the Good Samaritan of the scriptural parable gave not only first aid but the healing touch of personal loving-kindness.

Christmas business at Tiffany Co. is running about 25 per cent above last year's level and earnings for 1961 will be about 40 per cent higher than those of 1960, Walter Hoving, chairman, told shareholders here yesterday.
BONE, Algeria, Dec. 20 -- A jeepload of soldiers precedes and an armored car follows the bus taking passengers from the airport of Bone to the city's center after dark.
North American production of newsprint last month fell slightly from output in November, 1960,but United States newsprint consumption set a record.
Caroline Burke Swann, who co-produced "The Hostage" on Broadway last season, plans to present "The Little Golden Calf" next fall.
Herbert Seidman, the New York State champion, defeated Donald Byrne last night in a fourth-round match of the United States chess championship at the Prince George Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- It was soft music, not a power failure, that dimmed the lights of the national community Christmas tree.
MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- West Germany will participate in next year's world ice hockey championships in the United States whether Communist East Germany takes part or not.
The city is to have a replacement for the bustling, clamorous Fulton Wholesale Fish Market, it was decided yesterday.

OTTAWA, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian economy, responding to rising consumer and government spending, moved ahead strongly in the third quarter. The gross national product expanded 2.7 per cent to an annual rate of $37,364,000,000, from the second-quarter rate of $36,396,000,000, it was reported today by the Bureau of Statistics.
Arbitrator Theodore Kheel's decision in the automated shuttle-train case was a wise one despite your criticisms in your editorials of Dec. 14 and 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Nothing succeeds like success except the success that is enduring. Therefore, even those who deplore the methods employed must concede that the United Nations achieved a success in the Congo when President Tshombe of Katanga signed the pact with Premier Adoula that was described today by the central Congo regime; and that Prime Minister Nehru was successful in aggrandizing Portuguese India.

THE rubber match played by Tobias Stone and Alvin Roth of New York against the Italian pair of Mario Franco of Milan and Serge Montorsi of Rome, played in Milan last week, resulted in a victory for the American pair by 8,300 points.
District Attorney Edward S. Silver warned yesterday that he would ask for grand jury or legislative action in the refusal of Brooklyn bondsmen to provide bail for defendants.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers went through a steaming workout in 11-degree weather today, somewhat less than cheered by word from Paul Hornung that he was getting a six-day leave starting Dec. 27 from Fort Riley, Kan.
A group of reform Democrats held a rump meeting of the executive committee of the New York County Democratic Committee yesterday and voiced unofficial views on three subjects.

Schenley Industries, Inc., showed a slight increase in earnings in the quarter ended on Nov. 30, over those of the corresponding three months last year, the report of Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman and president, disclosed yesterday.

The chairman of a stockholders committee fighting the proposed merger of the Firth Carpet Company with Mohasco Industries, Inc., said yesterday that the group planned to ask A.M. Sonnabend to become chairman of the company if it won a favorable vote at a meeting on Dec. 29.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Etienne Hirsch, a foremost advocate of a United States of Europe, has been replaced in a top post of the European Atomic Energy Community because of President de Gaulle's hostility to the idea of supranationality.
Mrs. Joan Moore, wife of Archie Moore, said yesterday that Feature Sports, Inc., was attempting to "shift the blame" to her husband for cancellation of a 1960 title bout.
ROME, Dec. 21 -- In the fourth Christmas message of his reign, Pope John XXIII tonight urged peace and goodness upon all Christians.
Ten years of boom in West Germany were pinpointed by that government's Federal Economics Ministry yesterday in an annual report.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) plans record capital expenditures next year of $1,200,000,000, M.J. Rathbone, president, said yesterday in a year-end statement. The existing record was set in 1957, when these outlays amounted to $1,131,000,000.
The New York University School of Law won the twelfth national moot court competition last night at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- The reactor of the Savannah, the world's first atom-powered merchant vessel, was started tonight at Camden, N.J.

The Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that "indications point to a renewal of debt-management tinkering in 1962" in the city's finances. It pledged to fight any weakening of present constitutional safeguards.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- Weeb Ewbank, whose coaching fortunes have slumped since his Baltimore Colts won the National Football League championship in 1958 and retained it in 1959, won a vote of confidence today. His three-year contract was renewed.

Production of lumber in the nation eased to 211,334,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday. This figure compared with 213,829,000 board feet produced in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations.

George Meany said last night that labor's role in the national and international spheres would continue to help build a "free democratic society," despite predictions that the merged labor movement would be torn apart by internal strife.

Joseph Gallo, a 32-year-old gangland figure, was sentenced yesterday to serve from seven years and three months to fourteen years and six months in prison on his conviction for conspiracy and attempted extortion.

Streamers in varying shades of pink satin hung from a large central candle-lighted chandelier to form a canopy over the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas ball.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -The Boston Bruins scored three goals in three minutes in the third period tonight for a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings. The Bruins hadn't won in eight games.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Twin Coach Company announced today a top management realignment as a step in a diversification program, which places new emphasis on the aerospace field.
Thousands of Brooklyn and Queens residents were caught in prolonged rush-hour delays on the IRT and IND subways yesterday morning.
WARSAW, Dec. 21 -- the Polish Government has retreated from its attempt to make Roman Catholic religious instruction a branch of public education.

The first issue of a new magazine designed "to provide a common meeting ground for business and the liberal arts" was published yesterday by Pace College.
Pleasure boat shows are scheduled on both sides of the Atlantic early next month. Some industry tycoons, naval architects, boat builders and observers will be able to cover both by plane.
Many bail bondsmen possess the qualities of both soothsayers and touts and, like Diogenes, they are ever in search of honest men.
Secretary of the Navy John B. Connally is leaving office this week after tenure of less than a year to seek the Governorship of Texas.

High-scoring Wilt Chamberlain of the Philadelphia Warriors beat Boston's Bill Russell for the center position on the Eastern Division team that will play the West in the annual National Basketball Association all-star game at St. Louis Jan. 16.

Assemblyman Mark Lane produced an affidavit yesterday saying that Lancer Industries, Inc., which in 1960 was planning to manufacture fall-out shelters, had contended it knew what the New York shelter law would contain eleven months before it was enacted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) -- At least 2,400,000 workers will receive wage increases averaging about 7 cents an hour in 1962 under major collective bargaining contracts, a Labor Department study indicated today.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation's chief executive officer expects to see in 1962 a continuation of the "moderate recovery which began several months ago," unless steel labor negotiations in the first half "create a retardant for the latter half."
National Telefilm Associates, Inc., owner of WNTA-TV, was reported last night to be nearing a settlement with its creditors so the station could be transferred to an educational group.

The directors of the General Aniline and Film Colporatton announced yesterday the election of Dr. Jesse Werner as president, chief executive officer and a director of the eom pany. Dr. Werner, who had been a vice president, succeeds Philip M. Dinkins, who is retiring as president and director on Dee. 31.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Production of new automobiles by U.S. manufacturers this week is expected to drop 10.6 per cent from last week's 165,336 units, Automotive News said today.

A Negro couple may rent a previously refused apartment in Great Neck, L.I., as a result of an agreement obtained yesterday by the State Commission Against Discrimination, the commission reported yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -Warren K. Billings received a Christmas pardon today from Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California.
The Traffic Department made public for holiday motorists yesterday a list of major traffic bottlenecks in the city.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased by $69,000,000 to $109,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Saverio Saridis is one policeman whose lot promises to be a happy one.
Because of international implications, the United States Court of Appeals yesterday stayed representation elections aboad seventeen Honduran-flag vessels.

THOSE who have not yet decided what will be the feature of Christmas dinner will find plenty from which to choose in the stores today and tomorrow. The most obvious choice is turkey, which is being offered at the same incredibly reasonable prices that held for Thanksgiving.

WALTER LIPPMANN'S third television appearance, which took place last night over 'C.B.S. Reports' on Channel 2, again underscored his value to the home medium. Net profits of Walter E. Heller Co., Chicago commercial finance and factoring concern, will reach $5,900,000 this year, Robert I. Livingston, president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday. This would compare with last year's $5,164,743.

ONE of the most nostalgic sounds of Christmas this year is the tinkling of a nineteenthcentury music box. The proposed jet airport for the metropolitan area was the subject of action in three communities yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority said yesterday that it would seek competitive bids on Jan. 4 for $25,000,000 of term bonds. The bonds will be dated Nov. 1, 1961, and will mature on Nov. 1, 1991.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- With an almost audible sigh of relief from the Conservatives, the politicians shut up shop today for the Christmas holidays. The Tories, as they sought the balm of "goodwill toward men," conceded that in recent weeks they had found little of it in the House of Commons.

Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers, who has averaged nearly 38 points a game, yesterday was a unanimous choice for the Western Division squad that will play the East in the National Basketball Association's All-Star game at St. Louis on Jan. 16.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Treasury bill rates declined on today's sales of next week's regular issues.

TOKYO, Dec. 22 (UPI) -- Tickets to the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo will be sold in advance abroad only to those who have hotel reservations.
