The annual report of the State Attorney General's civil rights bureau indicates rising use of the state antitrust law in an effort to suppress racial and religious bigotry. The law originally was enacted to prevent commercial or industrial combinations to restraint trade.

Steel production in 1962 is expected to range between 105,000,000 and 115,000,000 tons, against an estimated 97,000,000 tons for 1961 and 99,300,000 for 1960, Max D. Howell, executive vice-president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said in a year-end stataement.

AMONG the pleasures of the fall television season has been the sturdy conduct of the New York Giants football team, which virtually alone has sustained the cause of the two-hour live drama on the home screen. Conceivably, its admirable behavior holds a lesson for other phases of video.
Oil in commercial quantities has been discovered in Australia. This is expected to give a strong lift to the economy of the Down Under Continent, which has had to import all its oil requirements.

On the first page of The Times (Dec. 17) there appeared two opposing statements. One was by President Kennedy before the largest crowd that ever greeted a President in South America. The other was Secretary of State Rusk in the private chamber of the most hated dictator in the Spanish-speaking world.
The Ukrainian Nationals of the American Soccer League, Kutis of St. Louis and Dukla of Czechoslovakia gained top honors in major competition in 1961.
BIZERTE, Tunisia, Dec. 23 -- The French-held naval base of Bizerte, scene of bitter fighting five months ago, remains to many Tunisians a symbol of national frustration.
The thoroughbreds again raced to record-breaking attendance and betting figures in most of the states in which pari-mutuel wagering is permitted.

SCHOOLGIRLS who are fascinated by pioneer life will find this book a joy to read. Any other child, however, is likely to give up after the first few pages, because this story of a family of settlers in the Oklahoma mountains in the early Nineteen Hundreds is told so leisurely as to discourage any but the most faithful followers of "the olden days."

The political settlement reached in the Dominican Republic between the opposition National Civic Union and the armed forces this week opens the immediate prospect of a truce that the United States can support.
PORT SAID, U.A.R., Dec. 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser served notice tonight that all lands in Egypt held by foreigners would be seized and nationalized.

THE first shall be last and the last shall be first, the old screed runs. So it was in Agustin Anievas' recent experiences in the first Dimitri Mitropoulos International Music Competition. He was the first of the thirty-two pianists in the contest to play in the preliminaries.
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 23 -- A Negro has brought a second suit against an integrated housing development here to permit him to buy one of its houses.
The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency suggested last week that fear of accidents might be keeping many persons from using the airlines.

Alabama was the top college football team of the country in 1961 and Ernie Davis was honored as the player of the year. The Syracuse halfback won the Heisman Trophy in a national poll of writers and broadcasters, the first Negro to receive the award since its inception in 1935.

THIS was the year when man went rocketing into other space for the first time and the world of sports took the hint. It ventured also into hitherto unexplored areas with expanded programs and expanded records that gave booster shots to the athletic astronauts. The Yuri Gagarin of the muscle set was Roger Maris, who soared even higher than Babe Ruth, a guy who once lived in the stratosphere.
Quality and riot price gets the first emphasis when a consumer buys a mattress, the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation reports on the basis of a national survey of consumer buying attitudes.
WASHINGTON -- A series of new bridges and highway connections in the Washington is going to make life easier for tourists visiting the nation's capital -- and for drivers who want to avoid it.

TO commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of New Mexico's statehood, the first tricolor United States stamp of 1962 will feature one of the Southwest's most spectacular sights, the giant outcropping known as Shiprock which rises like a great beacon some 1,400 feet above the high plateau of northwestern New Mexico.
ELISABETHVILLE, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Tension continues to grip this city because of the presence of 30,000 Baluba tribesmen in a refugee camp here.

The first medical use of a revolutionary optical device called the laser was reported last week in a joint announcement by the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and the American Optical Company. The laser, a device that produces an intense and precisely monochromatic beam of coherent light, has been used by eye specialists at the Center to treat a tumor in the blood vessel system of a patient's ret ina.
HOBOKEN, N.J. Dec. 23 -- A new of engineering program for undergraduates that emphasizes the unity of all branches of science and engineering will be developed by Stevens Institute of Technology.

THE Farmer's Almanac, a helpful publication for anyone who wants to know when to prune, plant and harvest crops, also supplies side information for individuals eager to conduct their lives in accordance with the fish and game laws, auto laws, postal laws, and the influences of the stars.
WHEN the Metropolitan Opera was negotiating labor contracts last summer, it counted on spending an additional $1,000,000 in the next three years in the form of raises to its union members.

AS a matter of course, everybody who is interested in the ballet of the Soviet Union (and who is not?) will want to sea the film based on the Bolshoi production of Prokofieff's "Cinderella," if only for the record.

TORONTO, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Murray Oliver scored three goals in one game for the first time tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 7-4 triumph over the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

Sponsored by the Ford Foundation, a vast project "to look at American humanistic scholarship of recent decades" is being carried out at Princeton. Its purpose, described by its director, Richard Schlatter, professor of history at Rutgers University, in the current newsletter of the American Council of Learned Societies is to help "to distinguish the inspired prophets from the fanatical Pied Pipers."

Auto racing in 1961 in the United States became one of the three most attractive professional sports in terms of dollars received for admissions (beaten only by horse racing and baseball), according to chroniclers and statisticians of the three big racing organizations -- the National Association for Stock Cars, the United States Auto Club and the Sports Car Club of America.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System and Desilu Productions plan to make a pilot film for a proposed half-hour weekly television series starring Victor Borge. It is interesting that Mr. Borge, who, like Santa Claus, is accustomed to only one performance a year, is now entertaining the idea of a regular series.

On the vast continents of Africa and Asia, more than three dozen new nations have come into being since the end of World War II. Another dozen, formerly independent in name only, have assumed full nationhood. Still another dozen states expect their independence within the decade.

TO the ancient Druids mistletoe was a plant from heaven. The modern youth looks upon it as a heavenly plant, too -- especially at Christmastime when he finds the girl of his choice beneath a generously berried sprig.

The United Nations is still in existence after another meeting of the General Assembly. Given the state of world affairs, this in itself is an achievement. The Assembly's greatest success was the election of U Thant of Burma as Acting Secretary General in place of the lamented Dag Hammarskjold, killed in an airplane accident while trying to bring peace to the Congo.

The largest merchant ship ever to be built in this country is now alongside an outfitting pier at the Quincy, Mass., yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company. The vessel is the 106,500-ton tanker Manhattan, owned by Manhattan Tankers Company, Inc.

More persons frequented harness-racing tracks and wagered more money in 1961 than in any single previous year. When, however, all was said and done Adios Butler was the one who accomplished the most in and for the standard-bred sport.
FROM the Hess Department Store in Allentown, Pa., comes a new travel suit designed for the male tourist who has almost everything and is carrying it with him and needs a lot of pockets.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- Holiday travelers interested in shaking a gubernatorial hand and looking in on a traditional New Year's reception at Government House, and who do not care what Governor or which state it is, can have a gay time New Year's Day here in Annapolis.

MIAMI BEACH -- The performers, the directors and the angels of that annual wintertime extravaganza known as Miami Beach went through the hectic, nerve-tacking paces of another opening this week-end, and they are now sitting back awaiting what they confidently hope will be favorable reviews from thousands of sunshine-seeking critics.
The Yankees, just before closing shop for the holiday weekend, put in another busy day yesterday getting things ready for 1962.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Larry Pursiful sparked Kentucky to an 80-67 upset for Kansas State in the University of Kentucky invitation basketball tournament final tonight.

This has been an insistent question of U.S. foreign policy: In the effort to achieve world peace, how much reliance shall be put on the United Nations and how much on the strength of the U.S. itself and its North Atlantic Allies?
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 4 -- The Yugoslavs are discovering they have more petroleum than they ever dreamed of.
A rabbi called on Christians yesterday to remember the "Jewishness of Jesus" in their celebration of the Christmas festival.

The United States equestrian team acquired a permanent home for the first time in the ten years of its existence for the most significant development in American horse shows during 1961. It consists of a large stable that includes living quarters at Gladstone, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Rumblings in the business world might suggest that one of the Kennedy Administration's most radical features is its antitrust policy. The Attorney General, Robert F. Kennedy, found it desirable to devote a major speech last month to denying that the Administration is "anti-business."

THE story goes that the early Greek lyric poet, Stesichorus, once wrote a poem about Helen of Troy in which he called her the usual insulting names, adulteress, warmonger, etc. He was then smitten with blindness. He had forgotten that Helen was, after all, divine and quite capable of looking after her reputation.

West Coast shipowners have agreed to wage increases and other benefits that will add 12 per cent to their costs over the next three years, according to a report issued by the Sailors Union of the Pacific.

Ever since Harry Nelson Pillsbury of Boston astounded the chess-playing world by winning the great international tournament of 1895 at Hastings, England, that famous seaside resort has been the mecca for tile world's best players.

"Give me allies to fight," Napoleon is said to have remarked. The Kremlin clearly agrees, for in each of the world's trouble spots the Russians are to be found pressing moves that will undermine or unsettle the Western alliance.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Italy's Davis Cup tennis team showed a slight improvement in practice today, but most experts are predicting a 5-0 sweep for Australia in the challenge round starting Tuesday.

AFTER offering checklists of the year's outstanding crime novels (Dec. 3) and short stories (Dec. 17), I'd like to round off 1961 by calling attention to the surprisingly many excellent volumes of fact-crime -- the best annual crop in a half dozen years or more.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Canada apparently is going to keep the Harmsworth Trophy in speed-boat racing at least another year.

Department store sales in the Federal Reserve district for the week ended Dec. 16, showed an increase of 6 per cent from the 1960 level. Every metropolitan area in the district showed an increase with the exception of the Portland area.
Women who are working in behalf of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will have "Tea With Tins" the afternoon of Jan. 23 at the Pierre.

THIS year, which saw the sale of a Rembrandt masterpiece -- "Aristotle Contemplating the Bust of Homer" -- for a record $2,300,000, has brought a heightening of interest in all the works of this hugely productive Dutch genius. And in the Christmas season that interest fixes particularly on his religious works.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 23 -- After frantic consultation today in the No Man's Land between Israel and Jordan, a Jordanian sergeant left with what appeared to be several thousand dollars worth of Israel's supply of Jordanian money.
Tonight in San Pablo, about fifty miles north of Manila, a Filipino couple will kneel in prayer before a small, homemade creche.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A new strategy is being devised within the Administration to get President Kennedy's stalled tax bill through Congress.
California's eight-oared crew won the championship of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association for the second successive year in 1961.

IN this century, the chronicles of the Negro children in desegregated schools can bring stature or disgrace to the South, for this generation of Negro children is now in the process of becoming what it will be tomorrow. Its leaders, whether we approve or recognize them, are in today's classrooms.
THERE is the glow of the Yule holiday. There is the glow of the family ingathering. There is the glow of happy children.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Favorites found little difficulty today in the first round of the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament.

SHERMAN, Tex., Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Two "Sam Rayburn Democrats," one a State Senator and the other a lawyer with labor support, forced a runoff election next month in a special election held today to fill the Congressional seat of the late House Speaker Rayburn.
"One of our players has offered us a cup to be sort of an international challenge cup."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- The Interior Department moved this week to meet one of the principal reservations made by Pacific Northwest states over a proposed power line linking that region and California.
Visions of sugar plums -- and record quantities of other candies -- are dancing in the heads of consumers this Christmas.

Members of the Production Fund Committee of the New York City Ballet are sponsoring the gala premiere of George Balanchine's full-length ballet based on "A Midsummer Night's Dream." The event will be on Jan. 17 at the City Center.
The new Board of Education will report this week on the steps it has taken to improve school operations and clean up the conditions that led to the removal of the former board.

Emile Griffith, the former welterweight champion of the world, defeated Isaac Logart of Cuba in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 1,042 witnessed the contest, fought at a lively clip and highlighted by some excellent boxing.

An airplane crash near Brussels, that cost the lives of all eighteen members of the United States team bound for the world championships in Prague, cast a pall over the figure-skating world in 1961. As a result, the championships were canceled.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 23 -- Paul Hornung, the National Football League's most valuable player, will get in a full week's practice with the Green Bay Packers before the championship game against the New York Giants here Dec. 31.

As the week ended, bankers were still poking through the wreckage washed ashore after the sinking last Tuesday of the First National City Bank of New York-National Bank of Westchester merger proposal.

AS the handmaiden of science, the Patent Office has placed its seal this year on many inventions vital to the space age -- satellites, rockets, nuclear reactors and machines for the automation of production in factories and of learning in schools. But American inventors have not been preoccupied with defense and industry to the exclusion of all else, as witness these innovations for personal or household use that should contribute much to gracious living.
A Columbia University Professor of Mineralogy has received two samples of sensitive Norwegian clay, as carefully wrapped as two Christmas ornaments, to further his study of mudslides.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- The Soviet Union reacted with skepticism today to the United States-British determination to renew diplomatic exchanges in Moscow on the Berlin dispute.

TORONTO -- Winter is a busy time for vacationists in Canada, especially when the snow comes. There are outdoor sports, for both the participant and the spectator, from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and even close to the sub-Arctic regions.
With the United States the most prominent contributor, swimming's list of world records underwent another drastic revision in 1961. Fifteen men's and thirteen women's marks were broken.

There was little Christmas cheer for investors in the stock market last week as prices declined steadily. The market was unable to sustain several minor attempts to rally, and the feeling among brokers seemd to be that the time for a year-end rally was passing like the old year.

The major electrical appliance industry looks for a 5 per cent increase in total shipments for 1962, according to Joseph F. Miller, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

ART, like nature, has to be distinguished from the systematic study of it which is criticism. It is therefore impossible to "learn literature": one learns about it in a certain way, but what one learns, transitively, is the criticism of literature.
James Sherwin beat Herbert Seidman in the fifth round of the United States chess championship at the Prince George Hotel yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India Dec. 23 -- Many Indians discovered to their surprise late this week that they had a national conscience.

THE lengthy and monumental set of Variations on a Theme of Diabelli that Beethoven constructed on a cheerful little waltz is generally more admired than enjoyed. Concert performances are few and far between, and those who love the work must turn to recordings to satisfy themselves.

MIAMI -- Visitors arriving here by air are sometimes greeted by an unexpected reception committee consisting of small, polite owls. Passengers aboard incoming planes often glimpse the little creatures perched upon runway markers, where they seem to be bowing a welcome to the passing parade.

LAST January a jazz archaeological expedition to New Orleans, sponsored by Riverside Records, turned up and recorded some aging but spirited jazz musicians whose work had been generally ignored by recording companies both in and out of New Orleans.

THE agitation for some form of Federal support of the arts has been quickened by Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg's statesmanlike intercession. His declaration on "the state of the performing arts," which accompanied his arbitration award in the Metropolitan Opera case, had admirable largeness of vision.

THE historian who attempts to write an objective history of the Old South must steer resolutely between the Scylla and Charybdis of Northern and Southern prejudice. Clement Eaton of the University of Kentucky undertook this exacting task and has succeeded in high decree.

ERICK Erikson once suggested that "a nation's identity is derived from the ways in which history has, as it were, counterpointed certain opposite potentialities; the ways in which it lifts this counterpoint to a unique style of civilization, or lets it disintegrate into mere contradiction."
A committee to work for more state aid to the city's public schools has been formed, the Public Education Association announced yesterday.
VIENNA, Dec. 21 -- The Austrian Government is keeping alive a hope that it can talk the Soviet Union out of its Objections to Austria's possible association with the European Economic Community.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- The Government of secessionist Katanga Province will send a parliamentary delegation to Leopoldville, seat of the central Congolese Government, it was announced today.
The China Merchants Steam Navigation Co., Ltd., of Taipei, Taiwan, failed last week to attract a single offer for its Liberty ship, Hai Huang, now trading in Far Eastern waters.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Nearly everything went wrong today before Alex Kroll, Rutgers University's all-America football center, and Phyllis Benford were married by Mayor Kenneth Oka.

Broad surveys of business in the St. Louis area showed a steady expansion with the present rate of activity on a high level although it was not reflected in the statistics of department stores sales. Retail movement of new model automobiles was described as remarkably brisk during the first half of December.

Few Western democracies have ever had as close and nerve-racking an election as the most recent one in Australia. The shifting results ended after nine days of doubts and confusions with Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies' Liberal-Country party coalition seeing its majority of thirty-two reduced to two in the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Air Force has received Administration approval for development of one of its advanced ballistic missiles into a booster capable of hurling multi-ton payloads into orbit.

BECAUSE civilization's girdle is too tight, there is a mass migration to the outdoors, and this was the year it reached a new high. Legions of people discovered the fun of walking through woods, trying to catch fish or pitting skill against the protective talents of animals and game birds.

Activity in pure-bred dogs, on an upward spiral for several years, continued to grow in 1961. The interest was reflected by the fact that for the first time American Kennel Club registrations touched the half-million mark.
Squadron A defeated the Patricians, 11 -- 10, last night in polo at the Squadron A Armory. Russ Drowne scored seven goals and had brilliant backing from Dave Ellis and Dave Rizzo.

An 18 per cent increase in sales from the comparable 1960 level was reported by district department stores for the week ended on Dec. 16. Nearly three-fifths of reporting automobile dealers in major district cities sold more new cars in November than in October, one-fifth sold about the same number as in October, while one-fifth disposed of fewer cars, the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond was advised.
The Caribbean voyage of the Mexican cruise liner Acapulco was canceled yesterday, twenty-six and a half hours after she was scheduled to sail from West Fifty-fifth Street.

Controversies and one major policy change marked the year along the professional golf circuit. Differences among sponsors, players and the Professional Golfers Association surrounded the selection of competitors for two international teams.
Presents are still to be wrapped, many trees still must be trimmed, and there are only 307 shopping days left till next Christmas.
ALTHOUGH the time is not yet ripe for Twentieth Century-Fox to lie down trustingly with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's lion, a seasonal good will prevails tonight in the microcosm that is Hollywood.

Employment in non-agricultural pursuits in Illinois slipped from 3,435,200 in September, to 3,434,000 in October, the State Employment Service reported. The 1,200 decline in the month compared with 900 from October, 1960.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 20 -- Efforts to bring the more than 10,000,000 polyglot people of Malaya, Singapore and the three British territories of North Borneo, Sarawak and Brunei into a federation of Malaya appeared today to be almost certain of success.
FOR THIS WEEK: Add water daily to the tree holder. Turn lights off late in the evening. . . . Keep gift plants cool and moist. . . . Have a very Merry Christmas.

MOST skiers spend as much time reading travel brochures as they do actually skiing, and many can tell you how many lifts, how many miles of downhill runs exist at every major ski station in the Alps. They trade information among themselves, and plan winter vacations which in most cases never come off.
MIAMI, Dec. 23 -- Anti-Castro leaflets were dropped on the city of Matanzas, on the north coast of Cuba, at 2 o'clock last Thursday morning, members of Operation Phantom said here today.

The governors of the American Stock Exchange were urged last week to act quickly to select a new president. The advice same from the special committee that has been looking into the exchange's operations.

IT is a strange time for younger poets, and for some that are, now, not so young. The criticism-dominated Forties and early Fifties carried scores of competent craftsmen into as much recognition as any poets got, and then abandoned them.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The international politics of this melancholy century entered a new and depressing phase this week. The contest between communism and the West is heneeforth to be complicated by militant, physical anti-colonialism exercised by those former colonial territories now strong enough in their nationhood, politically as well as militarily to move against the residual remains of old colonialism in what they consider to be their special spheres of influence.

For years the U.S. role in the United Nations has been under attack from extreme right-wing groups that have accused Washington of subjecting American interests to a "world government." The criticism recently, because of the Kennedy Administration's support for the U.N. action in Katanga, has had a broader base, involving several prominent Republicans and a few Democrats.

A moderation in the weather late in the week ended on Dec. 23, gave retail distribution a big lift but volume still failed to match the 1960 figures. For the last four weeks department store sales in the Federal Reserve district have trailed a year ago, and merchants are doubting now that a gain will prevail for the month.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 -- William C. Partee's Cavalanche and Ogden Phipps' Subtle were the winners of their respective divisions of the City of Miami Beach Stakes today at Tropical Park. A turnout of 9,701, somewhat below expectations, witnessed the feature races, which were for 2-year-olds and at a mile and 70 yards.
FOR many Christians, Epiphany, also known as Twelfth Day or Little Christmas, commemorates the the baptism of Jesus, the visit of the three kings to Bethlehem or the miracle at Cana.

Each National Motor Boat Show that has been coming to New York every January for a half-century picks a theme and slogan for itself. This year's fifty-second annual exposition has adopted "The Wonderful World of Boats."

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- The West Berliners are getting ready for Christmas. They have carried their Christmas trees to the roofs where they can be seen from the other side of the wall dividing Berlin. They have strung lights on everything that is high and visible from a distance, and they have decorated the graves of their dead.
The second and final Junior Assembly of 1961 was held last night in the Plaza. The first took place there Nov. 24.

In speed-boating's wide array of competitive classes, all the way from tiny stock outboards for teenagers to the Unlimited Class creations sometimes costing in excess of $100,000, many proud winners emerged with prizes from the 457 regattas sanctioned this year by the American Power Boat Association.

MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Jean Beliveau and a substitute rookie wing, Bobby Rousseau, scored twice each tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Kennedy has written an assessment of nearly a year in office in which he concludes that his speeches and statements since last January have done much to "get the country moving again" and to replace "complacency" with "awakening."

"GOD makes visible to men His will in events, an obscure text, written in a mysterious language." So wrote Victor Hugo, echoing the conviction of those in the Western world who see divine purpose in apparently random events which occurred in the ancient Near East and which were recalled in the language of the Bible.
Northrup Knox of Buffalo won the amateur court tennis championship of the United States for the fourth time since 1957.

THE news that "Carry On Nurse," a minor, starless British film has earned $2,000,000 in the United States and -- in the words of its proud owner -- still has "by no means exhausted its potential" -- has set producers here pondering on a new idea which is really a very old one.

THIS is an important book, and for any Englishman who was young in the Nineteen Thirties a bitterly painful one. A.L. Rowse tells his own story of the great English political conflict of those years. The English political leaders, most of the Conservative party, the overwhelming majority of serious and responsible opinion, and a good slice of the ordinary public all believed that it was possible to come to terms with nazism.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, President Kennedy's father, improved "considerably" in the last twenty-four hours, it was announced at noon today.
A white and gold decor was arranged last night for the annual Mistletoe Debutante Ball at the Pierre, at which twenty-one young women were presented to society.

I was delighted to read in The Boston Herald for Dec. 13 the story of the Scarsdale, N.Y., school children who are giving up desserts after lunch and sending their dessert money to Washington for President Kennedy to use for the United States Freedom from Hunger Foundation. These boys will be benefited not only in body but in mind and spirit too by such a contribution.

IF my count is correct, this is the nineteenth new English translation of "The Purgatorio" published in the last forty years. Poets love to translate Dante, as an experience and as a test. Yet, as John Ciardi aptly notes "no sane translator can allow himself to dream of success.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 23 -- President Kennedy announced today he would appoint John Moors Cabot of Massachusetts as Ambassador to Poland.
Orders for spring merchandise began to be received in depth last week by resident buying offices here.

A game between the Green Bay Packers and New York Giants at Green Bay, Wis., next Sunday will determine the National Football League championship. The Packers led the Western Conference for the second straight year while the Giants regained the Eastern Conference supremacy they last enjoyed in 1959.
Columbia University's well-balanced fencing team scored the upset of the season yesterday by defeating New York University's National Collegiate champions, 14 -- 13.
The Chicago Black Hawks, third in the National Hockey League's regular season, surprised by winning the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world professional crown, in 1961.
The car and truck renting and leasing industry financially "came of age" last week.
IN classrooms from coast to coast, children are learning French these days from televised courses conducted by a vivacious teacher named Mme. Anne Slack.
OTTAWA, Dec. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Record cargo tonnages moved through the St. Lawrence Seaway during the 1961 navigation season, the Seaway Authority announced this week.
WARSAW, Dec. 23 -- The Polish Parliament approved last night the Government's 1962 economic program and a record high national budget to implement it.
"Why me?" was the keynote of most of the complaints that dissatisfied reservists sent to newspapers and Congressmen after they were called to active duty because of the Berlin crisis.

IT would be bitterly ironical if George William Russell (1867-1935), better known by his pen name of "AE," were to survive only in footnotes to the history of the Irish Literary Revival, for nobody did more than he to discover and encourage his juniors in that movement.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Bill Russell and Sam Jones pulled the Boston Celtics together for a 122-111 victory over the New York Knickerbockers today with a fourth-quarter flurry.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -- The dream of linking more than a dozen major Ruhr cities with an eighty-mile subway system has caught the fancy of West German engineers and architects.
Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union became the first player to regain the world chess title for the second time.

AN extraordinary conglomeration of events made 1961 an amazing year in sports. Thrills, frills, controversy, confusion, and, in spots, frustration followed one another with the bewildering rapidity of an animated cartoon. Attendance and financial figures spiraled into the millions and billions.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- Government sources endorsed today the decision by President Kennedy and Prime Minister Macmillan to seek new contacts with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question.

Three years ago, ten Midwestern colleges (Beloit, Lawrence, Ripon, in Wisconsin; Coe, Grinnell, Cornell, in Iowa; Carleton and St. Olaf, in Minnesota, and Knox and Monmouth, in Illinois) formed the vanguard of the new trend of formal cooperation.

ON Tuesday evening there will be unveiled on Forty-ninth Street the portrait of an enigma. The portrait's title will be "Ross," its subject Lawrence of Arabia, and by coincidence it will open at a theatre named for another tortured individual, Eugene O'Neill.

DURING the holiday season many apartment dwellers become acutely aware that while they may be long on hospitality, they are short on the space in which to dispense it. It is at such a time that good interior planning and designing pay off, as the small apartment on these pages illustrates.

SINCE the early 1890's the Del-Mar-Va Peninsula has furnished the bulk of Christmas holly for the eastern half of the United States. Here, too, is the only place in the world -- Fruitland, Md. -- where holly auctions are held annually.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- A former preacher who left New York to become the first chancellor of California's huge state college system is nearing the end of his first half year on the job.
Senator A.S. Mike Monroney accused the aviation industry last week of neglecting short-haul travel. He was critical of trend toward bigger and fewer airliners.

Although December is usually one of the dullest months of the year for the construction industry, building permit volume has remained relatively brisk. Permits issued during the first two weeks of the month amounted to $2,700,000, largest total for the period since 1957.

IN Chicago where, just seventeen years ago, his first Broadway play, "The Glass Menagerie," had its historic tryout, Tennessee Williams has spent the last month tensely working on the tryout of "The Night of the Iguana," which he calls "my last play for Broadway."

WAGNER'S "Ring" cycle pursued its course yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera with all uncut "Walkuere." This work is not as much of a stranger there as the others in the cycle, and it has been absent for only a season.
IF urban renewal is not to turn into urban devastation, which it shows signs of doing, the officials of New York would be well advised to take a course in the history of the city's architecture.

Many apply for Rhodes Scholarships, but few are chosen. Last week, the thirty-two Americans were picked among over 600 candidates endorsed by their colleges. The scholars-elect represented twenty-six states and twenty institutions.

TENJO, Colombia, Dec. 21 -- "The day the two dump trucks came was the turning point. That's when the people around here began to believe in the Peace Corps," said John Montoya, 19 years old, of Orem, Utah.

Carlino of the Assembly, which is being studied by the Assembly Committee on Ethics and Guidance.

NORTHVILLE, Mich., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The young patients at Northville State Mental Hospital, received a new bus today. It was the result of 2,301,600 Gold Bell trading stamps sent in by people from throughout Michigan and from as far away as California.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 25 -- One of India's most respected political leaders has strongly censured his Government for seizing the small territories of Goa, Damao and Diu from Portugal.
WARSAW, Dec. 25 -- A special Christmas greeting from Pope John XXIII to the Polish faithful was read today to overflow congregations in Roman Catholic churches throughout Poland.
The appointment of Charles J. Colgan as executive vice president and general counsel of United Tanker Corporation has been announced by J. Carter Hammel, chairman of the board.
Many of the daily contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases fund are children who express simply and directly their sympathy with the troubled lives they have read about.

PROFESSIONALLY, Dr. Thomas Park is concerned with flour beetles. Their basic biological processes have fascinated him for years. He has written long articles on their behavior, how environment affects them and how they react to overcrowding, temperature and competition.

AT A time when I was trying to convince the President that dishonoring the treaty with the Senecas is an immoral act, I received a long envelope with "White House" in the upper left-hand corner. Things looked brighter for a few seconds.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- A few days ago two American service teams played a football game in a soccer stadium in Perpignan in southern France.
The protracted hearings on Senator Kefauver's bill to tighten Federal regulation of drugs have shed needed light on the drug industry's strengths and weaknesses.

The Federal Aviation Agency invited aircraft operators and equipment manufacturers yesterday to a meeting in Washington on Feb. 27 to review airborne equipment requirements forecast as a result of the Project Beacon report.
ALEXANDER SCHNEIDER'S musical Christmas Eve at Carnegie Hall was as attractive and joyous as ever.

Hayley Mills, who has arrived from England to attend the premiere tonight at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre of "Ross," the biographical drama starring her father, John Mills, has been named the year's leading English movie star by the British trade publication, The Kine Weekly.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 25 -- Nearly all classes at Smith College will be suspended Jan. 8 through Jan. 26 for an experiment in education designated as "interim session."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Democrats and Republicans are plotting strategy for the thirty-seven Senatorial seats at stake in the 1962 elections.
BERLIN, Dec. 25 -- President Kennedy told West Berliners in a Christmas message today that the beacon of freedom in Berlin "will continue to shine brightly for many years to come."
ROME, Dec. 25 -- Pope John XXIII formally announced today the convocation in 1962 of the Roman Catholic Church's twenty-first Ecumenical Council.

Efforts will be resumed today to avert a threatened New Year's Day strike by 9,000 electricians against 600 contractors. James J. McFadden, deputy for commissioner, said he was hopeful that the spirit of cooperation that has prevailed in the electrical industry in New York City for forty years will teach us to reach a satisfactory settlement in the present abstract negotiations without a work stoppage."
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23 -- The St. Louis University School of Medicine was embroiled this week in one of the most serious policy controversies in its 125-year history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Students from ten universities and colleges picketed the White House again today to protest an expected decision to resume nuclear tests in the atmosphere.
MIAMI, Dec. 25 (UPI) -- Bobby Ply of Baylor passed for three touchdowns and scored a fourth tonight in leading the South to a 35-10 victory over the North in the Shrine all-star football game.
One hundred and fifty puppets will leave for India on Saturday, but none will play flutes for cobras, or sleep on beds of nails, or do anything that may seem trite in New Delhi.
The lull between the Christmas and New Year's holidays normally provides business men with a propitious opportunity to assess the year gone by and to set objectives for the year to come.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Premier Khrushchev has conceded that neither he nor the Communist party is infallible and has demanded that he be told personally when he is wrong.
Wilt Chamberlain's scoring average just keeps climbing.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Fifteen-year-old Pattie Corte will return to a hospital tomorrow because the hundreds of Christmas presents she received today did not include a blizzard.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The chancellor of the International Olympic Committee, Otto Mayer, has complained to the committee's president, Avery Brundage of Chicago, about insufficient cooperation from the organization committee of the 1964 Olympic Games at Tokyo.

HARTFORD, Dec. 26 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will run for the United States Senate if he is nominated at the Democratic state convention in Connecticut in June.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- All grain futures prices yielded to selling pressure and declined today on the Board of Trade, while soybeans were irregular.
MIAMI, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- A cold wave chased the public from Florida beaches today and fur coats were much in evidence in shopping centers.
The Port of New York continued to lose ground in the first six months of 1961 in efforts to maintain its position as the nation's premier foreign trade gateway.
A Bronx police captain was summoned to headquarters yesterday to reply to complaints that he had attempted to shake down merchants during the holiday season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Air Force is awarding a $26,706,000 contract to the Allison Division of the General Motors Corporation, Indianapolis, the office of Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, was informed today.

The scheduled ten-round fight between Sugar Ray Robinson, former world middle-weight champion, and Denny Moyer of Portland, Ore., at Madison Square Garden Jan. 6 was postponed until Feb. 3 yesterday because Robinson had aggravated an old injury to his left hand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Air Force received long-sought permission today for manned orbital flights by its Dyna Soar space glider.
HANDSOMELY armed with a command of the strategy of the theatre, Terence Rattigan has made a bold foray into the life and personality of that enigmatic figure, Lawrence of Arabia.
NEW DELHI, India (AP) -- Although iron ore exports from Goa to Japan were temporarily disrupted by India s capture of the Portuguese enclave, India wants shipments to continue.
ALBANY, Dec, 26 (AP) -- The following skiing conditions were reported today to the State Commerce Department:

THE deal shown today comes from the memory of a distinguished nonagenarian of Princeton, N.J., G.M. Boiling, who has not played bridge since he was a young man in his seventies but who has never relinquished the spirit of the bridge expert.
DENVER, Dec. 26 -- Scientists called today for the establishment of a new science -- that of human survival.
AS anyone who has changed apartments knows, the real way to start redecorating to throw out rather than move the old furnishings.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Revel rallied in the stretch today and scored a two-length victory in the $23,500 Palos Verdes Handicap as Santa Anita opened its fifty-five-day race meeting.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association has begun an investigation of football recruiting at the University of Missouri, university officials disclosed today.

CAIRO, Dec. 26 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser tonight ended the shrunken United Arab Republic's federation with Yemen. The move ended the United Arab States, an organization formed by Yemen's association in March, 1958, with the original United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria, proclaimed the month before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Social Security tax rates go up again, Jan. 1, with the increased revenues helping to meet the cost of benefit changes that became effective under amendments signed into law June 30.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- "We are scrambling a little to get back at the peak of condition," Coach Rip Engle said as his Penn State team arrived today.

THE National Broadcasting Company offered last night one of the most graphic and useful of its series of "White Papers" -- a chilling step by step account of the initial success of Premier Khrushchev toward the neutralization of Europe and the isolation of the United States.

Railroad merger proceedings have been progressing with the speed of a slow freight. In fact, the Interstate Commerce Commission, which has been holding lengthy hearings, has told Congress it would make no final decisions on pending mergers until mid-1962, to give the legislators time to ponder ways of helping the carriers.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- When "The Establishment," a new political cabaret, opened its doors here recently, one London critic asked, "Can English satire draw blood?"
A public offering of $950,000 of Old Empire, Inc., 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 1971, is being made by Laird, Bissell Meeds and R.L. Warren Co. The issue is priced at 100.
NEWARK, Dec. 26 -- the Department of Justice today accused three New Jersey banks of engaging in a conspiracy to make uniform charges for their services.

Miller-Stephenson Chemical Company, Inc., has appointed Dr. Ellsworth G. McClenachan as vice president for research and development. He was also named technical director. He had been a research chemist with the American Cyanamid Company.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 26 -- The "Ode to Joy" was sung in English here tonight to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Japan and the United States have agreed on a payment of about $490,000,000 in settlement of Japan's foreign-aid debt for the period following World War II. The debt involves the cost to the United States of government services, relief and rehabilitation in Japan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The United States and Japan will hold a conference in Tokyo on cultural and educational exchanges the week of Jan. 25, the State Department said today.
ATHENS, Dec. 18 -- From the Acropolis, Athens -- glittering and white under a bright December sun -- sprawls all across the plain and clambers up the lower slopes of the encircling mountains.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- "The year 1962 gives every promise of being an excellent one for business," the chairman of the world's largest manufacturing enterprise said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Montgomery Ward Co. has tux, will mail.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower and his family visited Disneyland today. The former President seemed almost as delighted as his four grandchildren.

Dayton gained an exciting triumph over New York University and Wisconsin upset Providence last night in advancing to the semi-finals of the tenth annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors tossed away a 15-point lead but rallied in the final period tonight and defeated the Syracuse Nationals, 118-111. The game opened a National Basketball Association double-header before a sellout crowd of 13,909.
Transit negotiations to avert a city-wide subway and bus strike New Year's Day entered their customary last-week crisis phase yesterday.
THE Metropolitan Opera's "Lohengrin" has a new Elsa.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 35 cents a bale off on near March to unchanged to 25 cents up yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Villanova's unbeaten basketball team won its ninth straight game tonight as it ended the first round of the Quaker City tournament with a 72-45 victory over Niagara.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The Duchess of Kent is expecting a child this summer, it was announced today. The child will be tenth in line of succession to the throne.
When Perry E. Hall steps down as a general partner in Morgan Stanley Co. on Jan. 1, the active phase of the career of one of Wall Street's most energetic and colorful leaders will pass into history.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has said he would consider assigning a commercial television channel to New Jersey.

TO MOST people functioning quietly in workaday pursuits, the "Call Of The Wild" is something Jack London wrote and Clark Gable made memorable on the screen as he won the day in snowdrifts up to his adenoids. That shows how little they know.

Early-bird customers shopping for next Christmas mingled yesterday with shoppers returning some of this year's holiday gifts. Stores in the city and suburbs were crowded with shoppers, who also took advantage of semi-annual clearances, particularly in clothing. Oddly enough for the day after Christmas, some of the busiest areas at many stores were those selling Christmas cards, decorations, wrappings and even artificial trees -- all at half-price.
HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Communist China and Albania took a major step toward closer economic relations today by forming a joint shipping company.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 26 -- Replying to the accusation that the Federation of Rhodesia has been allowing arms and other war material to cross Northern Rhodesia's border with Katanga, Prime Minister Sir Roy Welensky last night launched a bitter attack on the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins of the National Football League confirmed today that they were getting Bobby Mitchell from the Cleveland Browns as part of the trade that surrendered the Syracuse star, Ernie Davis, to Cleveland.
MIAMI, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The referee today changed the final margin of the South team's victory over the North in the annual Shrine all-star football game in the Orange Bowl last night.

Steel production last week reached the highest point in twenty months.

The official mills of the Sports Car Club of America continue to grind slowly. After a year of experimentation with the confusing "individual" system in rallying, in which the individual gets a score, the National Rally Board of the club has gone back to the more sensible "driver-and-navigator" plan, in which the team gets a score.

The fact that Cincinnati and La Salle won their opening-round games in the tenth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival yesterday afternoon was no surprise. The ease with which they dispatched their opponents, however, left the 13,186 fans with plenty to talk over at dinner.

Walter Sullivan's two recent articles in The Times have thrown sobering light on the increasingly difficult problem scientists face in keeping up with current research findings and with the knowledge they need for their own work. A Teamsters Union official was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting $92,000 in loans in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act. Two vending company executives and three corporations were indicted with him.
TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- Japan is ending 1961 with a drive to expand her markets in Western Europe, which Japanese leaders consider the trade center of the world.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that fifteen persons had been killed in traffic accidents last week and that 1,058 had been injured. SAIGAN, Vietnam, Dec. 26 -- The United States Ambassador, Frederick E. Nolting Jr., will arrive in Washington Jan. 5 for "consultations with various State Department officials."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 26 -- Social and cultural relations between Israel and West Germany are to be regulated by an interministerial committee appointed by the Israeli Cabinet, an informed source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that more than 14,000,000 school children participated this year in the federally sponsored school lunch program. The number of participants is 5 per cent more than last year.

The New York Central Railroad raised its earnings to $2,986,291 last month from $1,027,341 in the 1960 period. This improvement reflected in large part a $1,100,000 increase in gross and $1,778,950 of additional non-transportation revenues.
Van Heflin has been chosen to narrate and appear in a television documentary dedicated to the United States highway from Fort Kent, Me., to Key West, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- The Consumer Price Index and other economic barometers published by the Government will take a new base period in 1962, the Budget Bureau said today.

The Kratter Corporation, a New York real estate investment company, has decided not to go ahead at this time with a proposed public offering of $100,000,000 in debentures. The issue has been in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

EAST LONDON, South Africa, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Jim Clark of Britain drove his Lotus to a South African record today when he defeated his countryman, Stirling Moss, in the eighth Grand Prix of South Africa auto race before a crowd of 60,000.

THERE may be a subtle native meaning for Japanese audiences tucked away in the Japanese film "Odd Obsession," which came to the Carnegie Hall Cinema yesterday. Five New York Giants and eight Green Bay Packers, including Paul Hornung, were chosen yesterday on the United Press International all-National Football League team.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Political analysts for a liberal action group predicted today that Congress would fail to complete action in 1962 on President Kemnedy's new foreign trade program.

Changes in major partnerships in the investment banking firms of Kuhn, Loeb Co., and Morgan Stanley Co., are about to go into effect.

In one of the most unusual transactions since recording companies began taking an interest in Broadway musicals, Capitol Records has won the right to issue the original-cast album of Richard Rodgers' new show, "No Strings."

Negotiations are continuing in Havana for the release of 1,183 prisoners in return for $21,000,000 worth of farm tractors, it was announced here yesterday. The prisoners were captured during last April's unsuccessful invasion of Cuba.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Clyde Usina of West Palm Beach, Fla., was named the head golf professional of the Fairview Country Club today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Settlement of the multimillion-dollar estate of Arthur S. Hickock, former president and founder of the Hickock Oil Company, was announced today after sixteen years of litigation.

A man who allegedly threatened to kill the minister and staff of a midtown church if he were not given $1,000,000 was arrested yesterday. The arrest came after a two-month investigation and as a result of a description of the man issued to city churches.

Christmas holiday traffic deaths soared to 524 for the period from 6 P.M. Friday to midnight Monday, it was reported yesterday. The National Safety Council said it hoped the high toll would lead motorists to drive more carefully over New Year's.

A court hearing yesterday on the sale of the site of St. Luke's Women's Hospital to the Consolidated Edison Company further complicated the proposal after opposition groups had spoken out.
ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Governor Rockefeller will ask the 1962 Legislature to create a State Atomic Research and Development Authority empowered to borrow $30,000,000 for space age projects and programs.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Neale Fraser and Roy Emerson crushed Nicola Pietrangeli and Orlando Sirola of Italy in doubles today, enabling Australia to clinch the Davis Cup for the tenth time in the last twelve years. The scores were 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4.

IN some countries, especially in northern Europe, herring is a staple that appears as the main dinner course several times a week. In this country, herring is predominantly a cocktail snack. It follows that in this month, when so much entertaining is done, sales of herring products are at their peak here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- United States officials said to day that troops of the Congolese National Army would perform "guard duty" only in Katange Province.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor next year. The former Schenectady Mayor thus became the first Democrat to enter the race for the Democratic nomination. Governor Rockefeller announced a year ago that he would run for a second term in 1962.

Desegregation of some public schools in Atlanta, Dallas and Memphis went so peacefully early this fall that several observers noted that the Deep South is very likely and generally accepting the inevitability of racial desegregation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- John B. Payson, reitred banker and business man, was found dead this morning at his home here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The United States balance of payments deficit for the third quarter has been calculated at a rate of just below $3,100,000,000 a year -- up from $1,900,000,000 three months earlier.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- An article published today in Pravda, the principal Communist party newspaper, compares the Communist rift over Albania to that which arose between Lenin and Trotsky in the early Nineteen Twenties.
MA'LULA, Syria, Dec. 21 -- In this village carved out of a mountain-side the people still speak the language of Jesus.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Only eleven of the sixteen seeded players in the boys 18 years-and-under division of the Orange Bowl junior tennis championship survived today's round.
Potato and cocoa futures drew most of the interest yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.

A broad new market has been opened to plastics producers with the acceptance by the Federal Housing Administration of A.B.S. plastics for drainage and vent pipe and drainage fittings for inside use in residential housing.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 -- President Kennedy, summoning five of his principal staff members from Washington, started work today on his State of the Union Message and checked over the new budget he will present to Congress next month.

BABYLON, L.I., Dec. 26 -- This South Shore village is to be the first in Suffolk County in which Long Island Rail Road grade crossings will be eliminated.

TRUNG LAP, Vietnam, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Despite the constant threat of Communist snipers and guerrillas, fifteen United States Army men and their South Vietnamese trainees observed Christmas at this lonely base in the jungle with a midnight mass, a Christmas tree and a turkey dinner.

MADRID, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, his left hand in a plaster cast, returned to his official residence today from the hospital where he was taken after a hunting accident Sunday.

The Cadillac Tower, a forty-story, gold-domed building that is one of the tallest in Detroit, has been acquired by the United Investors Corporation, a publicly owned real estate investment company at 60 East Forty-second Street.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- In a nation-wide broadcast last Saturday President Gamal Abdel Nasser ridiculed Imam Ahmed of Yemen.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 26 -- Bitterness rose sharply today between the Government of King Hassan II and the Left Wing Moroccan Federation of Labor.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Underneath the gleaming parasol of our projected Latin-American Alliance for Progress remain the tawdry problems of what we know as normal diplomacy, the problems of jealousies and territorial claims.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25 (UPI) -- Dave Trager, the owner of the Chicago Packers, said tonight he would pay a $2,500 fine levied against his team by the National Basketball Association's president, Maurice Podoloff, "only under duress."

THE hazardous game of trying to anticipate news developments of the next year was played by some American Broadcasting Company correspondents last night. They were seen and heard during the network's report called, "World Prospects: 1962."
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- A half-million-dollar gift to "promote effective use of the English language" was disclosed today by the University of Chicago.
An unexpected tightening of the money market held the attention of the bond community yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- American Airlines said today that all its Chicago flights would be operating at O'Hare International Airport by early February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Two loans totaling $11,430,000 to help Argentina finance the expansion of electric power facilities and to help defray the cost of an irrigation canal were approved today by the Inter-American Development Bank.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 26 -- The Indian News Service, one of two news agencies that were established in July, announced today that it would cease operations on Sunday.

The Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, has purchased $1,700,000 bonds of the Anaheim, Calif., Unified High School District, due from 1963 to 1982. The 1962 Albany legislative session opens a week from today with plenty of material for lawmaking and no dearth of politics in prospect. THE forty-five-member directorate of the Green Bay Packers was in a state of alarm at the end of the 1958 season. The once proud and mighty Packers were on a toboggan slide, rocketing downhill with such precipitous haste that it looked as if they might hurtle out of the National Football League. They had won only three games in 1957 and scored only one victory a year later, the worst record in the league.

A group of United States companies has received approval for a $136,500,000 steel mill project in Pakistan.
Two persons were suffocated and a man critically burned in a fire early today at the Mayflower Hotel on Central Park West.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 26 -- The Green Bay Packers opened "Championship Week" before an unexpected audience of 500 fans today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board dismissed today an unfair labor practice complaint against the American Broadcasting Company.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Aldo (Buff) Donelli of Columbia was named today as one of eight finalists in the vote of the American Football Coaches Association for the annual coach of the year award.

By all past Soviet standards Premier Khrushchev was uttering subversive doctrine the other day when he admitted that both he and the Communist party are fallible and urged Soviet scientists to speak out when they think the leaders are wrong. The perspectives opened up if this advice were taken to heart by Soviet scientists are really shattering.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- There is a lot of talk in the Western world these days about a marked conservative trend in politics.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Informed sources said today that the United States Government had informed the Dutch that it would not sit in as a third party in any Dutch-Indonesian talks on Netherlands New Guinea, as requested by the Dutch.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- President Kennedy will speak at a Democratic fundraising dinner here Jan. 20 to celebrate the first anniversary of his inauguration.
Increased sales and earnings were reorted yesterday by the American Distilling Company for its fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 the anual report of Russell R. Brown, president, disclosed yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 -- The United States Air Force in Europe said today it had grown into the strongest American air command ever maintained outside the United States in peace time.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (UPI) -- Three astronomers at the California Institute of Technology have found an "odd-ball" star -- so odd it may take a whole new study of high energy nuclear reactions to explain it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- American Export Lines, which is expanding its Mediterranean and other route operations with the acquisition of additional tonnage, will not know what the subsidy position on the acquired tonnage will be until after President Kennedy's budget message goes to Congress next month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Government sought today to forestall higher dividend rates in savings at savings and loan associations by authorizing more flexibility in the way dividends to paid.
TARZANA, Calif., Dec. 26 -- Al Jennings, one of the most feared outlaws in the Southwest frontier days, died here today in bed. He was 98 years old.

Because of a resurgence of contracts for commercial and manufacturing buildings, as well as continued strength in single-family houses, future construction contracts in November were increased to a total of $3,008,215,000.

A member of the committee investigating conflict of interest charges against Assembly Speaker Joseph F. Carlino said yesterday that the committee probably would not take any action in the case before the Legislature convened next Wednesday.

THE political star of Samuel Studdiford Stratton of Schenectady greatly increased in brilliance on Nov. 8, 1960. On that day he won re-election in what was described as a smashing victory, particularly for a Democrat in a traditionally Republican area.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The United States expects to encounter difficulties in negotiations with Portugal for renewal of the treaty that provides Air Force and Navy bases in the Azores.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., announced yesterday that the Government of Colombia had agreed to purchase its properties in that nation for a price not to exceed $25,600,000.

An American edition of a new book by Tibor Mende, "China and Her Shadow," will he published by Coward-McCann on Jan. 22. M. Mende, professor of Political Science at the University of Paris and author of several books on international affairs, has based his book on wide travels in Communist China. He

FOR several months now I have been postponing the pleasure of reading and discussing an attractive little book about India, "Where the Lion Trod," by Gordon Shepherd. Because it is modestly limited in its scope and light and cheerful in its manner it seemed wise to give precedence to other weightier and more ambitious works that were dignifying their publishers' lists.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Britain put 200 servicemen on a twelve-hour alert today because of recent Iraqi statements over Kuwait.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Although Communist Bulgaria is busily de-Stalinizing, there are indications that relations with Albania will continue.
Governors of the American Stock Exchange at a special meeting yesterday approved in principle the reorganization suggestions for the exchange made last week by the so-called Levy committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The City Council here today passed a new motion picture censorship ordinance that would permit the police superintendent and his film censorship unit to ban showings of pictures found to be obscene or otherwise objectionable.

Events today: "L'Elisir d'Amore," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; New York Philharmonic Naumburg Foundation Concert, Werner Torkanowsky, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; John Magnus, bass-baritone, Town Hall, 8:30;
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- President Kennedy promoted Rear Admiral Roy L. Johnson to vice admiral today and approved his assignment as deputy director of Strategic Target Planning.

Grady Clark, president of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., a $3,000,000,000 Minneapolis-based investment company, has issued a statement indicating his regrets at the opposition being expressed to the proposed split of I.D.S. stock.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- One of of the best preserved Etruscan tombs, which was officially opened in the Eighteen Nineties and subsequently lost, has been rediscovered.
Negotiations are in progress for Howard K. Smith to return to television with half-hour weekly program of news analysis over the American Broadcasting Company network.
The city lagged behind private property owners yesterday in removing snow and ice on sidewalks.

PNOMPENH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Cambodia's chief of state, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, opened his nation's Congress yesterday with a fiery speech denouncing "our Thai and South Vietnamese enemies." He called Communist China "the only effective support and real brother" Cambodia can count on.

"The Secret War," a study by Sanche de Gramont of espionage in the "cold war," which Putnam will issue April 9, has been named winner of the Putnam $10,000 Award. In his book the author contends that "both East and West are practicing total espionage as an unadmitted but essential weapon of foreign policy."

Among those who sell dog food, leashes, beds, jewelry and vitamin preparations at dog shows there often is an artist, surrounded by examples of his work. Painters, too, are part of the caravan that travels the show circuit for profit. One of them is Robert C..Hickey of IHallandale, Fla., who would rather paint dogs] than people.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) Assistant Secretary of State W. Averell Harriman has reorganized the State Department's big Far East bureau since taking charge of it this month.

The New York Times has recently published a series of identical full-page advertisements of a publisher named Lyle Stuart promoting the sale of a book by J.J. Arevalo called "The Shark and the Sardines," translated from the Spanish by June Cobb.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- This Government made no protest of the decision of the United Nations. Secretariat to send into Katanga, as reinforcements of the U.N. troops there, about one thousand soldiers oil the Congolese National Army under the command of the Leopoldville regime.
SHIPPINGPORT, Pa., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Shippingport atomic power plant produced its billionth kilowatt-hour of electrical energy last night, a record for a nuclear power generating plant.

Canadians are the "talkingest" people on earth. New York City has more telephones than any other city in the world, with Los Angeles second. London, if the city, county and metropolitan area are included, noses out the West Coast city for second place. Among major cities of the world, Stockholm, Sweden, has more phones -- 62.7 per 100 of population -- than any other.
The fire at the Mayflower Hotel that killed three persons early yesterday was caused by smoking in bed. Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. declared a few hours later.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The Artist, a bay gelding from Cedarledge Farm of North Stamford, Conn., was ridden by Geoffrey Craig of Rye, N.Y., to four blue ribbons and the working hunter championship of the Sunnyfield Farm horse show today.

Remembering a special happiness he felt on the holiday just past, Herman Mertins Jr. of Little Falls, N.J., sent $10 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. He wrote: "I hope this will help to light the faces of some children such as I saw on Christmas morning."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- The Penn-Jersey Transportation Study, a public agency, warned today that lack of integrated planning for a transportation network in Greater Philadelphia would result in continued waste of money and land.
A police captain was suspended last night and ordered to appear before a Bronx grand jury on Wednesday on charges that he had shaken down Bronx merchants and members of the force.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 27 -- The long-awaited meeting of the three principal Laotian political factions to form a coalition government broke down today almost before it got started.

The license of a Long Island real esate broker has been suspended for sixty days because he was found to have served as a broker for the seller of a property while he was president of a holding company that bought the property.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- Italian progress on the Mont Blanc tunnel was temporarily slowed when workers struck an underground stream, it was disclosed today.

Quite understandably, the New York Stock Exchange is never very happy about continuing the listing of securities of bankrupt organizations. So it probably was quite pleased yesterday to announce that it would suspend trading in two bond issues of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, the commuter line that links Manhattan with Hoboken and Jersey City, N.J.
I Young women who are posti debutantes vied with one an-, other last evening for the honort of having worn the most beau-! tiful tiara to the thirteenth all-i !nual Tiara Ball.
THE safety play is understood by most bridge players to apply to any method of playing a single suit so as to win precisely as many tricks as one needs to win.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Queen's University of Kingston, Ont., earned the right to meet Michigan State tomorrow night for the tenth annual Boston Arena invitation Christmas hockey tournament by defeating Boston University, 5 -- 3, tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission approved today the export to the Soviet Union of a small quantity of radioactive steroids for research in metabolism.

Wagner's "Ring" cycle, begainning its second time round last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a repetition of "Das Rheingold," had a couple of new giants in the cast. Ernst Wiemann, who had sung Fafner in the previous performance, switched to the role of Fasolt with no apparent effort, and Gottlob Frick stepped into the role of Fafner, in his debut with the company.

JEAN NICOLET founded Green Bay in 1634. Curly Lambeau founded the Packers in 1919. To the citizenry of that bosky Wisconsin metropolis there is almost unanimity of opinion about which is the more important date. If a vote were held this week, Lambeau would probably win by a landslide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Two high State Department officials suggested tonight that much of the opposition in the United States and in Europe to the United Nations operation in Katanga was caused by the work of a well-financed propaganda machine.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Kentucky's sixth-ranked Wildcats defeated Yale, 79-58, tonight in basketball.
The new Toots Shor's, which the restaurateur affectionately coils "the joint," opened yesterday at 33 West Fifty-second Street -- where he worked thirty years ago as a bouncer.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 27 -- Secessionist Katanga Province sent six legislators today to this capital of the central Government, raising hopes of an important step toward Congolese unity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Brokerage houses were warned today against being greedy in arranging compensation for selling the stocks of unseasoned companies.

A DELFT brick flower holder, a pewter bowl and a Wedgwood mug are only some of the handsome reproductions of eighteenth and nineteenth century pieces now available at attractive prices through Sleepy Hollow Restorations, a non-profit, educational corporation.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday confirmed reports that his office was conducting a securities investigation of Lancer Industries, Inc. The inquiry has been under way for two and a half years.
THE new Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division's Second Department is enthusiastic and painstaking about nearly everything except eating.

THOSE who fail to learn from the past, we are told at intervals, are condemned to repeat it. One way to acquire such useful knowledge is to read James Laver's "Between the Wars,"* a stimulating pastiche of man's follies and grandeurs between 1919 an 1939 -- the years of the long armistice.

CATANZARO, Italy, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Angry relatives and friends of the seventy persons killed in a mountain train wreck smashed and burned a railway station today when they learned of official charges that excessive speed had caused the accident.
DENVER, Dec. 27 -- The possibility that life on earth originated in seeds from another world was ruled out by two scientists at a meeting here today.
Gains outnumbered losses yesterday, on the New York, commodity exchanges, where traditional year-end evening up of positions dominated trading.

James Cox Brady was named chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Racing Association, Inc., at a meeting of the board of trustees here yesterday. George D. Widener remains as honorary chairman.

Since 1790, when Alexander Hamilton established the United States Revenue Marine to discourage smuggling on America's shores, the fleet of what became the United States Coast Guard has expanded from ten oar-propelled boats to more than 400 large ships, cutters, patrol boats and tugs.
MRS. RICHARD RODGERS, wife of the composer, a most engaging Manhattan hostess. A woman with a warm ample and unruffled nature, she has a genuine enthusiasm for fine food.
PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The Belgian Government has expressed grave concern that the European Economic Community may fail to vote by New Year's Eve to pass on to the second stage of the Common Market.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Wilt Chamberlain continued his sensational scoring pace with a 53-point performance tonight as he led the Philadelphia Warriors to a 131-119 victory over the New York Knicks in a National Basketball Association game before 5,526 fans.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway announced yesterday that it cleared $5,587,940 last month and had a $42,503,208 profit in the first eleven months of this year. The November earnings included a $500,000 credit, representing adjustments of Federal income tax for prior periods.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 -- President Kennedy passed his physical examination today with high marks, but did not quite make straight A's.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 20:
THE barometer of "early" American marriages is going up steadily each year. Whether the upward trend foretells a sunny future is open to debate.
The New York Rangers, who had won three straight games while scoring nineteen goals, proved no match for the Montreal Canadiens last night.

The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday it expected to have fifty to seventy-five passenger cars powered by gas turbine engines on the road late in 1963. The engine is essentially an adaptation of the principles of jet propuusion to automotive power.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- An East Berlin court has sentenced two German students and a Swiss bank clerk to prison terms on charges of having run an underground to help East Germans flee to the West, the main Communist newspaper, Neues Deutschland, disclosed today.
The services of one hundred lawyers, title men, accountants and realty specialists and almost as many documents were required to complete the $65,000,000 sale of the Empire State Building yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- The State Education Commissioner today supported the action of the Oceanside, L.I. Board of Education in discharging its Super intendent of Schools, McDonald F. Egdorf.

In the wake of the thumping success the Kingston Trio has enjoyed for the last three years, a rash of young folk-music groups have patterned themselves after the trio's winning formula. Two ensembles, currently appearing at Manhattan clubs, however, have departed from this trend and are pursuing trails of their own.
