WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A Federal grand jury in New Orleans charged a Louisiana State Senator and two other men today with having broken the Federal law against wiretapping.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission getting ready to give the states control over some peaceful nuclear activities, has received many states-rights protests.
A Federal Court jury last night convicted all eleven defendants in a narcotics conspiracy trial. The jurors had deliberated over a two-day period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- (AP) -- Contamination of milk with radioactive iodine stemming from the Soviet Union's nuclear tests this fall has eased throughout the United States, the Public Health Service reported today.
The National Health Council yesterday announced procedures for uniform accounting and reporting by voluntary health agencies. It recommended their adoption by member organizations.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 27 -- The Government of King Hassan II announced today a fiscal reform to increase national investments and decrease the tax burden on the peasantry.

DENVER, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The United States has developed a technique for detecting nuclear explosions far in space, with at least hypothetical possibilities of monitoring detonations at twice the 93,000,000-mile distance of the sun from the earth.
Members of the Transport Workers Union last night authorized a total bus and subway strike on New Year's Day if they do not have a new contract by then.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 27 -- The Government said today that it was taking precautions to maintain essential services that have been threatened by growing labor unrest.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein denied last night that he had offered to mediate the current dispute between Guatemala and British Honduras.

The Bendix Corporation had a net income of $23,968,664 in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, compared with $26,188,471 in the preceding fiscal year, Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, reported yesterday.

The population of midtown Manhattan appeared yesterday to be twice its usual size and half its usual age. On foot and on wheels, out-of-school children and their parents oozed at a glacial pace into the rectangle between Thirty-fourth and Fifty-ninth Streets and Lexington and Eighth Avenues.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that the potential for increases in consumer sales, larger outlays by industry for capital equipment and greater defense expenditures promised better business for the industry in 1962.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Communist party of the Soviet Union warned its members today against losing control over the program of de-Stalinization.

The still tenuous hope for a peaceful and united Congo raised by the agreement between Premier Adoula and President Tshombe to end Katanga's drive for "independence" is acquiring an increasingly solid foundation as a result of several major developments.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru stanchly defended India today against Western criticism of the use of force to wrest the territories of Goa, Damao and Diu from Portugal.

The appointment of Dr. William T. Lhamon as psychiartist in chief of the New York Hospital, as head of the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic and professor and chairman of the Department of Psychiatry of Cornell University Medical College was announced yesterday, effective July 1.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Geoffrey Pollard, a rising Australian with sharp control, beat Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, the United States junior champion, in the Orange Bowl junior tennis tournament today. The scores were 10 -- 8, 8 -- 6.
Two of the season's debutantes were honored at the Mr. Regis last night.
Sears, Roebuck Co. has joined the battle for the mail-order travel dollar against an old rival, Montgomery Ward Co.
The Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival basketball tournament moves into its second phase at Madison Square Garden today with all eight teams seeing action.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 27 (AP) -- long-delayed hearing on an injunction against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opened in state court today and almost at once brought a complaint of invasion of privacy from a Negro lawyer.
MELBOURNE, Thursday, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Vannie Canapele, captain of the Italian Davis Cup team, commented today:
BOSTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- A Federal judge refused today to halt the deportation of a physician who was a member of the Communist party in East Germany.

A prospect for continuing economic recovery was forecast yesterday by thirteen of the country's top business executives who expressed their views on the outlook for 1962 in the annual symposium conducted by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

DENVER, Colo., Dec. 27 -- A "democratic-scientific society" whose potentialities are still little recognized has emerged in the United States in the last twenty years, Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today.

THE church was dark, but spotlighted in the apse, at the head of a long flight of steps, was an angel with a coral robe and golden wings. As the light faded from the angel, voices singing medieval plainsong died away in the unseen sacristy.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The British aircraft carrier Centaur, two frigates and a tank-landing ship speeded today toward the Persian Gulf. They were dispatched as a result of the Government's concern that Iraq might move to seize the Sheikdom of Kuwait.

"La Dolce Vita" has won the Joseph Burstyn Award as best foreign film of the year. The annual awards, given by the International Film Importers and Distributors of America, Inc., also cited "Saturday and Sunday Morning" as the best foreign film in English and "Purple Noon" as the best example of dubbing.

New Jersey's scheduled sale of $42,000,000 of direct state obligations on Feb. 6 will probably mark the state's only borrowing next year on full faith and credit obligations, John A. Kervick, State treasurer, said here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Trade outlook in the grain futures market was mostly bearish today and nearly all contracts closed steady to weak in draggy transactions.

Some of the country's leading economists are showing how they relax in a life busy with teaching, advising, researching and writing: Creations of their leisure are in an arts exhibition at the Commodore Hotel.

In congratulating Winston J. Churchill Jr. of North Wales, Pa., upon the inclusion of his name in the list of Rhodes Scholars appointed from the United States to attend Oxford University, one may note that another Winston Churchill could never have qualified for that honor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Nearly 1,500,000 Negroes left the South during the Nineteen fifties, the Census Bureau said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- The United States and Yugoslavia have reached agreement on the sale of American surplus agricultural goods worth $45,000,000, including transportation costs, to the Tito regime.
The 39-year-old rector of a New Jersey church was found dead yesterday in a West Side hotel room. Detectives said he had apparently taken barbiturates.
SHERBURNE, Vt., Dec. 27 -- When Paul Bousquet was 5 years old, he counted sixty-three busloads of skiiers arriving at his father's rope tow area at Pittsfield, Mass.
The letter in an adjoining column from the United States Inter-American Council raises an important question in respect to the advertising policy of this newspaper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that his department had "taken a number of steps to make the military establishment a more effective servant of American foreign policy."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Construction activity increased by 3 per cent this year to a high of $57,500,000,000, the Commerce Department estimated today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Representative James Roosevelt announced plans today to get an early start in the new Congressional session on a proposed Fair Employment Practices Law.

Mahonlng County, Ohio, sold $2,500,000 of reservoir bonds due from 1963 to 1982, to an investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co. The group bid 100.778 with a 3 3/8 per cent coupon, setting a net interest cost of 3.3048 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 1.80 to 3.50 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The nation's scheduled airlines employed a record 171,610 workers this year, an Air Transport Association survey showed today.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Alexandria Hotel, a stopping place for the rich and famous for more than twenty-five years after its construction in 1905, is scheduled for demolition within a year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission board decided today not to interfere with a 10 per cent increase in interstate commuter fares on the New Haven Railroad, effective Jan. 1.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 27 -- City officials have been invited to attend a luncheon at the Soviet Unions Killenworth estate here, but preparations for the event have proved as confusing as the delicate tax situation involving this city and the Russians.
A demand that the present state aid formula for financing education be scrapped was made yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 27 -- National Theatres and Television, Inc. has reported that its loss for 1961 fiscal year would be about $6,900,000.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Connecticut's that service center for narcotics addicts is to be established here in 1962.

A football team is like a prizefighter. Both must be trained and conned at a pace that will bring them to the peak of mental readiness for championship bouts. This state, perhaps best described as an alert trance, is what the New York Giants are aiming for this week.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Ralph Dupas hooked and jabbed his way to a unanimous ten-round decision over Virgil Akins, a former welterweight champion, tonight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Ambassador Howard P. Jones conferred today with President Sukarno in a new United States effort to avert the possibility of a Dutch-Indonesian war over Netherlands New Guinea.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- French and Tunisian officials resumed talks here tonight to explore the possibilities of settling the dispute over the Bizerte naval and air base.

Stocks moved forward vigorously yesterday in what might be interpreted as a belated but welcome year-end rally. The New York Times combined average rose more than 1 per cent and made the best one-day gain since Aug. 1.

WARSAW, Dec. 27 -- Hendrych Holland was one of the handful of Polish Jews to survive the Nazi occupation of his country. A schoolboy at the outbreak of World War II, he fought in a Left-wing resistance group.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada and six members of his twenty-three-man Cabinet left for Quebec today to confer with Governor General George P. Vanier. Other members of the Cabinet are to meet them there tomorrow for a discussion of Government affairs:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Combining magic, television and children calls for sleight-of-hand showmanship, according to Mark Wilson, probably the nation's leading authority on the subject.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- The Yugoslav Parliament approved tonight a Federal budget calling for the expenditure of the equivalent of $2,115,530,000 and a plan for economic development during 1962.

Allie Sherman, the "kid from Brooklyn" who guided the New York Giants to the Eastern Conference championship in his first season as head coach, yesterday was named the National Football League Coach of the Year by United Press International.
TO the dismay of antiques amateurs, two signs bar the doors to the paradise of shops on Third and Second Avenues in the Fifties. One sign reads "wholesale," the other "only to the trade."
TRENTON, Dec. 27 -- The end of a long-standing legislative impasse between New York and New Jersey appeared imminent tonight.
A 49-year-old manipulator who kited a $10,000 forgery into thefts totaling more than $10,000,000 in fifteen years pleaded guilty to larceny in General Sessions Court yesterday.
Mayor Wagner and four of his associates on the Board of Estimate are to have new $8,800 city-assigned Cadillac limousines for their terms beginning Monday.

Harry Van Arsdale's Dec. 20 letter, in which he attempts to justify a four-hour day for members of Electricians Local 3, shows a blatant disregard of the facts as they pertain today to the New York construction industry.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Unheralded Tom Book pulled St. Louis out of a first-half hole and Gebrge Latinovich steadied the Billikens the rest of the way for an 81-72 victory over Notre Dame tonight.
Conflicting accounts of how four firemen and a civilian were injured in a Harlem street fight early yesterday will be presented to a grand jury.
Cotton futures moved 15 cents bale off on near March to 10 to 95 cents up on the others yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
A salvo of statistics from the steel industry fell yesterday on silent ground, for the moment, in the territory of the United Steelworkers of America.
Primitive tribesmen in the Republic of the Sudan hear so well that scientists are preparing to test whether their hearing approaches that of animals.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Foreign Minister Evariste Kimbe of Katanga Province said here today that the downfall of Katanga would lead to an attempt by Antoine Gizenga to take over the "central power" in the Congo.
The Electric Bond and Share Company has announced the election of Richard Saltonstall and Harold F. Smiddy as directors of the investment concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen said today that Congress would take a good look at United States financial support for the United Nations. However, he said this country could not afford to "shirk its obligation" to the world organization.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Rod Laver and Roy Emerson, holders of all the major amateur tennis titles, awaited professional offers today after having led Australia to her tenth Davis Cup victory in twelve years.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Two teen-agers were in custody today following the early morning shooting of a Madison Township policeman and a sweet-shop owner.
A group of upper West Side residents signed an agreement yesterday withdrawing their objections to the sale of the St. Luke's Women's Hospital site to the Consolidated Edison Company.

A CHILD may never know the pleasure of reading good books if his parents have not cultivated the habit. To the dismay of Phyllis Cerf, whose life revolves around literature, many nonreading parents shower their child with delights, but thoughtlessly overlook the fact that he might treasure some books of his own.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 -- A proposed executive order forbidding racial and religious discrimination in Federally aided housing has been sidetracked temporarily.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Ground was broken today for a $27,000,000 shopping mart, office center and railroad station in the old downtown heart of this suburban city.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is preparing an all-out push for medical care for the aged under Social Security.

A court decision is to settle the booking dispute affecting the continuation of "My Fair Lady" beyond Feb. 24 at the Hellinger. Herman Levin, producer of the Alan Jay Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical, which has been running there since March 15, 1956, has brought the action against Max Stahl and his son, Stanley, owners of the Hellinger.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Prices of industrial shares were generally firm on the stock market here today despite a small volume of business.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Ralph Wells' lay-up shot in the last four seconds of an overtime period gave Northwestern a 64-62 victory over Princeton tonight.
The appellate part of the Court of Special Sessions has reversed a Housing Court conviction of a landlord's representative for failing to register as agent for a tenement.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the appointment of Edward Thompson, an acting judge of the Queens County Court, as Fire Commissioner to succeed Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. next Monday, when Mr. Cavanagh will become Deputy Mayor.
Directors of the Hercules Powder Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting on March 20.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union is pushing a new campaign to sell oil outside the Iron Curtain.

The initial public sale in stock of Camp Chemical Company, Inc. is being made today with the offering of 110,000 shares at $3 a share by Russel Saxe, Inc. and Lederman Co. Proceeds will be used ultimately for expansion.

Yields on United States Treasury short-term discount bills moved up further beyond the 2 3/8 per cent mark yesterday as the money market continued to be held in the grip of unexpected year-end stringency.
In spite of large recent increase in Congressional appropriations for heart-disease research, increased voluntary agency support in this field was urged yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 27 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser's termination of the federation with Yemen is regarded by observers here as a new attempt to stamp his stern brand of socialism as the "be all and end all" of the United Arab Republic's policy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Post Office Department upheld today the dismissal of Jeardine Surrency, a 41-year-old woman clerk who was dismissed last April from the Savannah (Ga.) Post Office.
A nation-wide campaign for a million pounds of blankets to meet appeals from refugees in twenty-five countries was begun yesterday by Church World Service.

Harold Friedman, managing partner in Sutro Brothers Co., has resigned from the brokerage firm effective Jan. 2, it was learned yesterday. Although Mr. Friedman was at the firm's 80 Pine Street office yesterday, he could not be reached for comment.

After seven years of effort President Nasser's dream of a pan-Arab empire uniting with all Africa and the Islamic peoples everywhere in a struggle against the "imperialists" has turned to dust and ashes. He still calls his domain the "United Arab Republic," but with Syria's secession and the break with Yemen it is now confined to Egypt, which is neither united nor (with its predominantly Hamitic population) Arab nor a republic.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Dec. 27 (AP) -- President Joaquin Balaguer decreed today that all property confiscated from Dominicans for political reasons prior to last June 1, must be returned to the former owners.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 27 -- Belgium and the Congo announced today the resumption of diplomatic relations.
The State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday upheld the right of the Board of Education to disqualify two contractors from bidding on school construction work.
A skating party, for the benefit of the World Team Memorial Fund, will start at 12:30 this afternoon at Playland in Rye, N.Y. The event will he staged by the Westchester Figure Skating Club.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Greyhound Corporation approved today the issuance of a new class of preferred convertible stock and an increase in authorized common stock of 2,000,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that the record-matching output of American farms in 1961 accounted for cash marketing receipts of $31,300,000,000 in the first eleven months of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Irvin C. Scarbeck, who was convicted of having given security information to Communist agents in Poland, asked today that his thirty-year prison sentence be reduced.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A United States spokesman voiced concern today over the apparent collapse of the talks of the three Laotian princes. He said the peace in Laos was at stake.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- Jerry Lucas scored 20 points and rebounded with machine-like precision tonight to lead Ohio State's No. 1 ranked team to a 59-49 victory over Washington in the first round of the Los Angeles Basketball Classic.

Thousands of commuters and long-distance travelers were late arriving at Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station yesterday morning. Signal and mechanical troubles delayed the New York Central, New Haven, Long Island and Pennsylvania roads.
The New York Athletic Club and Belmont Abbey of North Carolina gained the final of the Winged Foot club's holiday invitation basketball tournament last night.
The New York Central Railroad yesterday asked the Public Service Commission for permission to make life a little easier -- and cheaper -- for some commuters.

Basic, Inc., Cleveland, Ohio producer of basic granular in brick refractory materials, has registered a proposed offering of $3,500,000 of cumulative convertible preference stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Senator Harris said today that he had no knowledge of the wiretapping and said the indictment was a politically motivated persecution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Representative Victor L. Anfuso, Democrat of Brooklyn, urged Governor Rockefeller today to recommend that the Legislature authorize direct primary elections for Governor and Senator.
IF it weren't for disturbances on the stage and in the pit, "Subways Are for Sleeping" would be.
The New York Athletic Club and Belmont Abbey of North Carolina gained the final of the Winged Foot club's holiday invitation basketball tournament last night.
The New York Central Railroad yesterday asked the Public Service Commission for permission to make life a little easier -- and cheaper -- for some commuters.

Basic, Inc., Cleveland, Ohio producer of basic granular in brick refractory materials, has registered a proposed offering of $3,500,000 of cumulative convertible preference stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Senator Harris said today that he had no knowledge of the wiretapping and said the indictment was a politically motivated persecution.
Federal officials expressed doubt yesterday that the Mexican passenger liner Acapulco would be able to begin regular cruise service between Los Angeles and Acapulco, Mexico, on Jan. 20.
Negotiations to avert a New Year's Day strike of 9,000 construction electricians remained deadlocked yesterday on the union's pivotal demand for a four-hour work day.
The National Sugar Refining Company has sold for $4,000,000 its refinery at Reserve, La., near New Orleans, to the Godchaux Sugar Refining Company.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 27 -The Green Bay Packers had four kickers getting ready today for Sunday's National Football League title game against the New York Giants, but all four are handicapped by old age, lack of practice or injuries.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller's annual message to the Legislature next Wednesday will suggest the possibility of state aid to nursing homes, including private proprietary homes as well as nonprofit institutions.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- British officials believe that a rapid increase in political and economic problems in East Germany has enforced a pause in its progress toward autonomy within the Soviet bloc.
George J. Beldock was indicted yesterday as Presiding justice of the state Supreme Court's Appellate Division, Second Department, at a ceremony in the courthouse, 45 Monroe lace, Brooklyn.
TORONTO, Dec. 27 (UPI) -- The Chicago Blacks Hawks and the Toronto Maple Leafs played a scoreless tie tonight in a National Hockey League game before 13,644 fans.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, will visit the West African nation of Guinea early next month for talks on "various problems of further co-operation between the two countries," the Moscow radio said tonight.
BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- Observers here expressed doubt today that political differences had arisen between the East German regime and Moscow. On the contrary, they said, there is the closest cooperation.
VIENNA, Dec. 27 -- Premier Ion Gheorghe Maurer of Rumania contended yesterday in his annual report that his country's production increased 16 per cent in 1961.

IRKUTSK, U.S.S.R., Dec. 15 -- At 45 or 50 degrees below zero the cold of the Siberian taiga or forest region cuts through heavy clothes, numbing hands, face and body. It can freeze a man to death almost before he realizes what is happening.
The diamond-polishing industry in Israel has emerged from a recent shutdown in apparent good health, and with prospects for future growth more promising than ever.
The economic outlook for next year is for moderate or vigorous expansion following the completion of the present recovery, a group of economists reported yesterday.
Randy Rose of Midwood High School and Jackie Schuman of Wingate High reached the final of the Public School Athletic League indoor singles tennis championship yesterday.

The New York State Banking Board, at a special breakfast meeting yesterday, took action to improve the competitive position of the state's 127 mutual savings banks with reference to commercial banks and savings and loan associations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the department of Agriculture follows:

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that New York voters traditionally expected their Governors to be national and international political figures, and not executives limited strictly to matters of concern to the state.

Activity and strength surged back yesterday into all parts of the high-grade bond market except United States Government Obligations. In the Treasury list trading outside of the short-term area stayed apathetic and prices tended to fall.

A delegation of the National Council of Churches that visited the Soviet Union earlier this month was informed that about 1,500 churches were closed in the country in the last year. Most of the closings were said to have been in western Russia.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- A physical examination as a condition for the issuance or renewal of a driver's license was proposed today by the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles and Traffic Safety.

Today is a sentimental day at the Philadelphia offices of The Saturday Evening Post. Ben Hibbs, editor of the magazine, will empty his desk and vacate the office he has held twenty years. His successor, Robert Fuoss, takes office next week.
PRESIDENT KENNEDY'S recent appointment of a committee to help find jobs for nearly a million unemployed youths has focused national attention on a growing problem.

ON the morning of Feb. 13, 1542, Catherine Howard, fifth wife and Queen Consort of Henry VIII, was beheaded in the courtyard of the Tower of London. Like her first cousin, Anne Boleyn, who was beheaded on the same spot six years earlier, Catherine had not made a success of her marriage to the splendid, gross and brutal tyrant who was King of England.

The fanciest set of figures since the national debt was last published is contained in the first National Survey of Salt Water Angling. It was conducted by the Sandy Hook Marine Laboratory in Cooperation with the Bureau of the Census.

A top official of one of the world's largest copper producing companies said today he was confident that his industry would "continue to provide adequate supplies of metal at stable and reasonable prices to its users."

A feeling of resentment has been growing among Broadway actors over alleged tactics employed by producers to obtain salary cuts from them based on the agreement reached last summer by the League of New York Theaters and the Dramatists' Guild.

AS beautiful, chic and accomplished as Vivien Leigh obviously is (she still looks lovelier than some of the starlets who were in pigtails when she played Blanche DuBois), she cannot do much with the banalities in "The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone," another film based on a story by Tennessee Williams, which came to the Capitol yesterday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 28 -- A seam of clay about a sixteenth to three-eighths of an inch thick underneath the Wheeler Dam navigation lock in Alabama, caused the lock's collapse last June, the Tennessee Valley Authority said today.
IN the wee small hours when diamond-encrusted carriages become pumpkins and Cinderellas lose heir glass slippers, a diminutive French maid tiptoes into a Fifth Avenue salon carrying a feather duster.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- One of the coldest Decembers in years has disrupted activity and spread discomfort throughout Britain. The icy spell has prompted bleak thoughts of January and February.
Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy called on merchants and the public yesterday to do their share in stamping out police shakedowns.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Gustave Ring's Stinson Beach, under a powerful ride by Avelino Gomez, defeated Times Roman by a head in the feature race at Tropical Park today. Creteman was third.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Gambling yielded $6,682,000 in Federal excise taxes on wagering in the last fiscal year.

The Central, Intelligence Agency is the subject of a new book by Andrew Tully. Morrow will publish it Jan. 10 under the title "CIA: The Inside Story." The author attempts to answer a number of questions about a branch of government about which not too much is known.
The Transport Worker Union and the Transit Authority agreed last night on a next two-year contract.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Mrs. Woodrow Wilson died tonight at the stately town house that became her home when she and the World War I President left the White House more than forty years ago. She was 89 years old.
PARIS, Dec. 28 -- President de Gaulle prepared today a New Year's message that his countrymen hope will hold out a promise of imminent peace in Algeria.
Magistrate Anthony E. Maglio yesterday lost his third fight to have the city pay him $35,000 he spent in legal fees during a removal proceeding.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Americans smoked more this year than ever before, the Department of Agriculture said today.
The giant French liner the Liberte is going to the bone yard instead of to Seattle, Wash., as a hotel ship during next year's world's fair there.

A drop of 7,240,000 barrels in the nation's supplies of light fuel oil in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The decline in the home heating fuel was a bit more than seasonal and it reflected the cold weather over most of the country.
Mayor Wagner yesterday dropped Market Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli, who had held his post longer than any other city department head.
A record volume of office building construction was carried out in Manhattan this year according to a compilation by the Real Estate Board of New York.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Government has rejected a recommendation that the Imperial Tobacco Company, Ltd., Britain's largest manufacturer of cigarettes and tobaccos, divest itself of its substantial shareholding in its biggest rival, Gallaher, Ltd.

A State Department official's statement that opposition to the United Nations operation in Katanga had resulted from a well-financed propaganda machine here was ridiculed yesterday by the head of Katanga Information Services.

Events today: "Die Walkuere," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P.M.; Janet Baxter, soprano, Town Hall, 5:30; "The Play of Daniel," presented by the New York Pro Musica, Noah Greenberg, conductor, St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, 3 and 8:30.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one who has spent a good deal of time in West Africa, I am horrified at the irresponsibility of some American conservatives who are trying to exploit the agony of the Congo for their own small, domestic political purposes.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 28 -Prince Souvanna Phouma, head of the neutralist faction among Laos' three political groups, demurred today to a suggestion that he hold individual talks with those who would be in or close to a coalition government.

Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday Ives, Inc., has been appointed managing agent of Gracie Towers, a new twenty-one-story cooperative with 150 apartments at 180 East End Avenue. The building occupies the block-front between Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Streets.

NINETEEN SIXTY-TWO will undoubtedly be the year in which men finally approve of women's fashions. The delicate, fragile, youthful beauty, out of the fashion running for seasons, appears likely to be next year's girl of the moment.
An enormous new pleasure boating undertaking to handle eventually 1,500 boat slips is off to a fine start near Toms River, the seat of Ocean County, N.J.

As the slippery spiraling football sliced a gentle are through the mist in Yankee Stadium yesterday, the intended receiver broke sharply toward the left sideline. Before he could gather it in, however Jim Patton cut across the field from his safety position, leaped out of the mud and made a deft interception.
The Hughes Tool Company yesterday reached an agreement to acquire the 56 per cent controlling interest in Northeast Airlines common stock now held by the Atlas Corporation, an investment company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Subandrio said today that Indonesia was prepared to discuss the possibility of giving the people of Netherlands New Guinea "a great measure of autonomy" if the territory was transferred to Indonesia.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- "Don't have any doubts, Comrade Colonel. Give me this Leontyev and in two weeks he will crack like a nut."
Paul R. Screvane, City Council President-elect, named Charles F. Rodriguez yesterday as $17,500-a-year executive assistant to the Council President. Mr. Rodriguez will take office Monday.

Herbert Seidman, the state champion, won his eighth-round game with George Kramer in the Lessing J. Rosenwald tournament for the United States chess championship at the Prince George Hotel in Manhattan yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Civil Defense Office of the Pentagon ruled today that commercially made fall-out shelters must shield those inside from all but 1/100th of the radiation outside.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one of the leaders in the movement to reform the Democratic party in New York, I write to reply to the letter of my friend Walter D. Binger, which appeared in your issue of Dec. 13.

DETROIT, Dec 28 (AP) -- United States auto plants, which were idle Christmas and also will be closed tomorrow, will build an estimated 103,479 passenger cars this week, Automotive News reported today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy reported today that the Department of Justice "has made important progress in the civil rights field during 1961."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 -- President Kennedy appointed a panel of seven private citizens today to study the Federal civilian salary systems.

A reign of terror in Harlem, in which Government witnesses were threatened, bribed and assaulted, was made known yesterday with the indictment of a major bootlegger, his son and two other men on charges of obstructing justice.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Small but steady buying in the stock market here today gave most sections a firm appearance. Sentiment was helped by yesterday's big rise on Wall Street.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo Dec. 28 (AP) -- A vanguard of Deputies from secessionist Katanga Province took their seats in the Congo National Parliament today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Kennedy plans to ask Congress next month for Governmentauthority to buy up to half of the United Nations' projected $200,000,000 bond issue.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Elizabeth Taylor was named the movies' top moneymaking star today in the thirtieth annual poll of exhibitors by The Motion Picture Herald.

The Pandora's box opened by India's invasion of Goa continues to spew forth its evils upon the world by encouraging more conflicts in the name of the same "anti-colonial" pretexts advanced by Prime Minister Nehru and his Defense Minister Krishna Menon. Their example was promptly welcomed by President Sukarno, who has been proclaiming his intention to "liberate" Dutch New Guinea by force of arms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- A political cheek-up on President Kennedy at the end of the year would probably come out very much like his medical check-up: condition good but could be better.
Plans to expand its airline shuttle service to a third pair of cities, Boston and Washington, were announced yesterday by Eastern Air Lines.

Production of lumber in the nation fell to 195,307,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday. This figure compares with 211,829,000 board feet produced in the preceding week, according to reports received from regional associations.
DETROIT, Dec, 28 -- Sales of new cars in the fourth quarter of 1961 may establish a new record for the industry, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

The Port of New York Authority indicated a willingness yesterday to establish connections between the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, which it intends to acquire and operate, and the other commuter railroads in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Republicans appear to have gained a handful of House seats from the Congressional redistricting completed so far by the state Legislatures.

Los Angeles, Calif., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $14,000,000 in the bond market on Jan. 31. The money will be raised on service revenue obligations to finance harbor development. The bonds will come due serially from 1964 to 1986.

The International Debutante Ball progressed last evening to a setting of red and gold for its seventh annual presentation of young women to local society. Pink and silver had been the ball's traditional colors.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- President Kennedy authorized the Senate Judiciary Committee today to examine tax returns for the years 1950 to 1960.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- Prof. Ludwig Erhard, the West German Minister of Economics, has decided to preside over the meeting of the ministerial council of the European Economic Community opening in Brussels tomorrow.
A high Treasury Department official said yesterday that he expected the United States balance of payments deficit to get worse before it gets better.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An improved commercial and speculative demand strengthened the grain futures market generally today, with corn among the best gainers on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of New York, proposed today that Congress retain the right to veto individual trade agreements while voting broader Presidential authority to reduce tariffs.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28 (UPI) -The Boston Celtics, trailing at half-time, 61 -- 49, rallied to defeat the St. Louis Hawks, 117 -- 109, tonight in a National Basketball Association game. It was St. Louis' sixth straight loss, a record for the club.
TOKYO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- American swimmers were credited with seventeen of twenty-seven world records approved today by the International Amateur Swimming Federation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -A combination of dinner and theatre is being planned for the Garden Court of the Sheraton-Palace Hotel here.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Dec. 28 -- Just when it seemed as if rain in the Manchester Valley might ruin ski-running conditions in this part of Vermont, along came colder weather early this morning to give the entire countryside a new mantle of white.

THE Contract Bridge Forum, published monthly in Los Angeles, is little read by players east of the Mississippi. This is not surprising because it properly devotes most of its space to players and tournaments in the Pacific area, including Hawaii and Alaska.

The University of Wisconsin last night engineered the major upset of the tenth annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament and one of the biggest surprises of this season by whipping the previously unbeaten Dayton Flyers, 105 -- 93, in the semi-finals.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Rod Laver and Roy Emerson said today they had no immediate plans to play professional tennis.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- A new plan that will increase state assistance to local school districts by $96,500,000 a year was made public tonight by a special legislative committee that has been studying the problem for more than a year.
Fewer appeals for new legislation and more cooperation among governmental agencies that enforce consumers laws were urged yesterday by a leader in the field of consumer protection.

Joseph R. Weiss, Deputy Superintendent of Schools, who was ordered by the Board of Education to resign by Dec. 31 or be dismissed, has chosen to resign. The board said yesterday that it had received and accepted a one-sentence letter of resignation dated Dec. 26.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- Edgar Pankey, the father of an American student who is serving a two-year term in an East Berlin prison, has flown here to plead with the East German authorities for his 20-year-old son's release.

Charlie Rosen, a 6-foot-8-inch senior, scored 29 points to set a school record and lead Hunter College to a 74 -- 55 basketball victory over Adelphi last night in the first round of the second annual Long Island College Association's tournament at Queens College's Fitzgerald gym.

A syndicate of New York investors represented by Arthur Fastenberg, lawyer, has bought the industrial plant of the Ludlow Corporation, producer of jute and flax products, in Ludlow and Wilbraham, Mass. Theodore H. Coogan, vice president of Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc., of New York, was the broker.

Sweeping changes in the top echelon of the J.I. Case Company and arrangements for a three-year credit agreement with banks were announced yesterday by the big maker of farm equipment and construction machinery.
HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The nation's first Federal retraining program for the jobless has started slowly because of lack of widespread response from the people it was designed to help.

A shutdown of the city's $1,250,000,000-a-year construction industry at midnight Sunday was viewed by industry spokesmen as a strong possibility yesterday as contract negotiations with electrical workers collapsed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Safe transportation of radioactive materials will be discussed with state and local officials at four meetings sponsored by the Atomic Energy Commission and the Interstate Commerce commission.

The New York Stock Exchange is not committed to any particular site for a new exchange building. Keith Funston, the president, said in a statement yesterday that the exchange would be willing to study any proposal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The medical needs of persons on relief are not being met in some states, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

Because the United States distrusts and dislikes the Government of Communist China, we have consistently refused to "recognize" that Government. There are good reasons for our distrust and our dislike. The Government of Communist China is aggressive abroad and tyrannical at home. There is no basis whatever for confidence or friendship between that Government and our own.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that his agency had helped obtain more convictions and recapture more fugitives in 1961 than last year.

The Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community meets again today in Brussels in a last-ditch effort to reach agreements permitting the Community to pass on to its second stage. This would take it two-thirds of the way toward a complete customs union as a prelude to European political unification. The deadline for such agreements is midnight New Year's Eve.

BORN in Astoria, Queens, in 1900 . . . educated at Bryant High School, Long Island City, and Polytechnic Institute in Brooklyn. . . . Commissioner of Buildings since Oct. 15, 1958 . . . licensed professional engineer, member of Grand Jury Association of New York County and co-chairman of the construction division.
Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose by $107,000,000 to $216,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday that Howard K. Smith would conduct a television program of news "analysis and interpretation" beginning Feb. 14. It will be presented each Wednesday from 7:30 to 8 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A Federal hearing examiner recommended today that the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers be labeled Communist-infiltrated. The decision came almost five years after he had undertaken the case.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Woodrow Wilson Memorial Bridge linking Maryland and Virginia just south of Washington was dedicated today at ceremonies shortened by a biting wind and near-freezing temperatures.
DETROIT, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- A $4,000,000 trade mark infringement law suit is pending in Federal court here against the Mead Johnson Company, makers of Metrecal.
Frank S. Hogan was sworn in as District Attorney of New York County yesterday for his sixth consecutive term. The oath of office was administered by General Sessions Judge Joseph A. Sarafite.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- When he appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee last March as a nominee to head the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, Burke Marshall underwent the usual rough questioning from Southern members.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (UPI) -Claude LaForge's second-period goal in his first appearance in the National Hockey League this season gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-2 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at the Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- An adequate epitome of a ninety-fivepage judicial history and analysis of the present constitutional status of the issue over including parochial schools in the proposed Federal aid to public schools cannot be supplied here because of two limitations -- those of space and this department's lack of legal competence.

Following are the one-way fares that apply now on five major domestic airline routes and the fares as they would apply if the basic fares were increased by 3 per cent as permitted yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board. Round-trip fares are double the one-way fares.
Leading players in professional basketball will be in action tonight at Madison Square Garden.
The Queens County Bar Association has invited leaders of bar associations in the metropolitan area to attend a conference on improving the selection of judges.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Several thousand wives and children of striking miners marched today on the central Government offices in Rodez, capital of the southern department of the Aveyron, in protest against a decision to close coal mines there.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Speaking for one of the "forgotten museums," I would like to say how timely and to the point I felt your editorial of Dec. 5 to be. The museums of this country are experiencing the result of the population explosion and attendant educational expansion.
Business loans by the fourteen weekly reporting member banks in New York rose by $133,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Harlan Cleveland, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, on the projected purchase of United Nations bonds:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Senate Majority Leader Mike Mansfield called today for the United States to re-examine four entire position" in Laos and voiced doubt whether the United States should continue providing the country with aid.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Treasury cautioned British industries today that they would face major test if Britain entered the European Economic Community.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -"Confidence on the part of businessmen and consumers, combined with high levels of personal income and savings, should result in sustained and stable prosperity in 1962," Lynn A. Townsend, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said today in a year-end statement.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- The United Nations made public today a report documenting accusations that Union Miniere du Haut-Katanga had allowed "murderous attacks" on United Nations personnel from its installations in Elisabethville.

Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union defeated Robert G. Wade of New Zealand yesterday in the first round of the thirty-seventh annual Christmas Chess Congress at the Sun Lounge, St. Leonard-on-Sea, according to a report from London.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- Senegal has accused Portuguese forces in Portuguese Guinea of "provocative" acts and has told the United Nations she would defend herself against such actions.
"Giants, Sons of Giants," Joseph Kramm's new play, has advanced its local opening from Jan. 11 to Jan. 6 at the Alvin Theatre. The attraction has been booked into the theatre on an interim basis.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 28 -- A drum and bugle corps may stir the pulses on parade days but at other times -- well, it can just be so much noise.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Christmas shoppers poured a record total of dollars into the cash registers of the nation's department stores last week, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement or Colored People denied today that it has transacted any business in Alabama since it was outlawed in the state by a court injunction five and a half years ago.
BUFFALO, Dec. 28 (AP) -Cornell opened a wide first-half lead tonight and went on to beat Canisius, 75 -- 62, in the first round of the eighth annual Queen City invitation basketball tournament.

Directors of the Consumers Power Company, Michigan, raised the quarterly dividend on the common stock yesterday with the declaration of 70 cents a share, payable on Feb. 20 to holders of record of Jan. 19. Shareholders had been receiving 65 cents quarterly.
RECENT remarks here about Willa Cather resulted in the gift of a letter that she wrote to Katharine Foote Raffy in 1937.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Vice Admiral Edward N. Parker will be deputy director of the new Arms Control and disarmament Agency, competent sources said today. The St' Department declined to confirm or deny the report.
The world's air traffic attained its highest peak this year despite a slackening of its rate of growth, the International Civil Aviation Organization reported yesterday.
The Liberal party demanded yesterday that five conditions be met if the Republican-controlled Legislature transferred jurisdiction over rent control in New York from the state to the city.
Cotton futures moved 20 cents a bale off to 30 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Undefeated and unranked Villanova knocked seventh-ranked Duquesne from the unbeaten ranks tonight with a 78 -- 53 victory in a semi-final game of the Quaker City basketball tournament.

HOLLWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- The true baptism of fire for an actor in the legitimate theatre is not opening night, but the audition for the part. It is unlikely that anyone ever went into the flames with less protection and emerged more happily than did Jack Khruschen, veteran of many character and comedy roles in movies and television.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia County Medical Society announced yesterday it had found no wrongdoing by Dr. Joseph E. Campbell, who had been dismissed as chief Philadelphia pathologist.
The city moved yesterday to end the appraising commissioner system of determining awards in the taking of land for water supply purposes.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 28 -Passenger service on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad between Jersey City and Newark was halted for two hours late this afternoon by the derailment of a Pennsylvania Railroad freight train near here.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Ten persons were injured today when a bus attempting to avoid a skidding car cracked into a bridge guard rail and teetered over a 100-foot embankment for an hour.

Prices moved through, a wide range in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange but closed with almost no change. The high was touched shortly before 11 A.M. Thereafter there was an almost glacial drift downward and the low came at the close.

Max E. Youngstein, former vice president of United Artists, has been appointed executive vice president of Cinerama, Inc., effective Monday. Mr. Youngstein's new post will also include the presidency of Cinemiracle International Pictures, Inc., a recently formed Cinerama subsidiary.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28 -- Argentina reaffirmed today her support of the principle of non-intervention, or "hands off," in relation to Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -The Peace Corps is planning a new college-style center in Puerto Rico to train hundreds of volunteers as community development workers for Latin-American villages.
A 32-year-old Brooklyn-born firebrand named Dave Astor is probably the only practicing night-club comic who can claim Bertrand Russell as a mentor.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The report today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Sol Panoff, managing agent for a building at 68 West Ninety-third Street, was fined $1,000 and given a thirty-day suspended sentence in Housing Court yesterday.

The powerful special investigating committee of the American Stock Exchange has prevailed on Joseph F. Reilly not to stand for re-election as unpaid chairman at the exchange's annual election on Feb. 12.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The tournament favorite, Temple, raced ahead in the final five minutes tonight to beat Minnesota, 70 -- 66, in the opening round of the Hurricane Basketball Classic.
The appointment of Dr. Herbert C. Cave as director of anesthesiology at Harlem Hospital at a salary of $25,000 a year was announced yesterday by Ray E. Trussell, Hospital Commissioner.

Although John Magnus. a bass baritone, is a graduate of the Juilliard School of Music and has made concert appearances in the United States and South America since 1947, he did not give his first New York recital until last night, when he sang in Town Hall.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Jerry Lucas staged a one-man show tonight as he led Ohio State's top-ranked Buckeyes to a 105-84 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles in the Los Angeles Basketball Classic.

FAMILIES that chose a nice inexpensive turkey for Christmas will find hams for New Year just as attractively priced. Or, if ham was the meat favored last Monday, turkey is still in the bargain category for next Monday's holiday.
At the turn of the year the nation's economy is catching its "second wind." The phrase is that of the First National City Bank in its latest survey of business conditions issued yesterday.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 28 -- It was 15 degrees below zero and vapory whisps of smoke from thousands of chimneys traced feathery patterns across a cloudless sky today when a frosty dawn illuminated Title-town, U.S.A.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- A press merger has forced Debrett's and Kelly's, two guides to the upper reaches of British life, into close but hostile fraternity.
Michael J. Sullivan, former Republican leader of Oyster Bay, L.I., was fined $1,000 and placed on probation for two years yesterday by Judge Leo F. Rayfiel in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
Elmer Valo, who spent twenty year's in the major leagues as an outfielder and pinch-hitter, heads a list of five new scouts added yesterday to the staff of the New York Mets.

The election of new officers headed by Amory Houghton, chairman of the executive committee of the Corning Glass Works, was announced yesterday by the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
A snowstorm that threatened to add to the traffic perils of the New Year's week-end, merely brushed by the city yesterday, leaving New Yorkers cold and soggy but relieved.
LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 28 -- At 1 o'clock this rainy afternoon, fifty mothers and as many children converged on City Hall here.
The Ford Foundation is beginning a new assault on slums because it feels that many human problems are not being solved by physical urban renewal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the major domestic airlines today to increase fares by 3 per cent for six months.

TO a fellow who has been privileged to witness virtually every National Football League championship play-off game since 1934, the storehouse of memories is rich and rewarding. They come flooding back to mind unsummoned because this is the eve of another post-season spectacular: Sunday's collision between the New York Giants and the Packers at Green Bay.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, wife of the President, may reconsider plans for a trip to India next month.

A new cargo pooling arrangement agreed to by twelve shipping lines trading from north Mediterranean ports to New York and other Atlantic ports will mean sharing an annual cargo volume of about 360,000 tons worth $19,000,000 in revenues, shipping men said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Justice Department asked a Federal court today to strike down a Louisiana law requiring would-be voters to pass a constitutional interpretation test.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- Iraq protested to the Security Council today against British naval moves in the Persian Gulf area. The complaint charged that Britain was pursuing a "gunboat policy" that threatened Middle Eastern peace and Iraq's security.

DENVER, Dec. 28 -- Some 3,500 years ago the Egyptians were able to write extensive drug manuals free from harmful dosages. But today pharmacologists are beset, more than ever, by the ethical problems raised by their discoveries.
Three groups of statisticians have repudiated charges by a section of business and finance that unemployment statistics are manipulated to make the problem more serious than it really is.
W.T. Grant Company registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering to the public of $35,000,000 of sinking fund debentures due on Jan. 1, 1987.
Rumors played a large part yesterday in causing the nervous cocoa futures market to plunge as much as a cent a pound, the daily limit.

KUMQUATS, those tart, delicious miniatures of the citrus family, deserve higher esteem than they get in this country. Here, their principal reason for being is as fillers for fruit baskets. The kumquat is tiny enough to tuck into the vacuums created when oranges, apples, pears and persimmons are piled in the beribboned gift packages that fancy food shops prepare.

New York University and St. John's regained a bit of their lost basketball glory yesterday by reaching the final of the consolation bracket of the tenth annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden.

"West Side Story" set a precedent yesterday by being voted the best motion picture of the year in the twenty-seventh annual poll of The New York Film Critics. This was the first time a musical had been awarded the group's top prize.

Lou Gehrig, Reggie McNamara and Johnny Blood, iron men of baseball, bicycle riding and football, will be joined in the career longevity records Sunday night when Harry Howell skates onto the Madison Square Garden ice.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's annual news roundup entitled "Years of Crisis" was presented last night before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations. Nine correspondents stationed in different parts of the world answered questions advanced by the moderator, Charles Collingwood, and members of the audience in Illinois.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Historians spoke out forthrightly today on such subjects as the Confederacy and Chinese biography, but many of them hedged in evaluating one of their contemporaries.

The following is a report of ownership and changes of ownership of equity securities listed on the American Stock Exchange filed by officers, directors and large stockholders, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934.
Subway riders on a northbound IND local train yesterday witnessed the struggle and capture of a theft suspect by a detective and a Transit Authority patrolman.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- With several hundred million dollars of annual farm exports at stake, the United States Government was keeping carefully clear today of the crucial farm debate in the European Economic Community, but it had a good idea of where its interests lay.

The Vientiane conference of Laotian princes may yet get back on the tracks after an initial derailment caused when Prince Boun Oum abruptly terminated the talks after a short initial meeting with the princely half-brothers, Souvanna Phouma and Souphanouvong.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, forcefully censured the United Nations tonight for its stand on colonialism and on the use of force by some of its members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The new United States Ambassador to Argentina will be Robert M. McClintock, 52 years old. He is a career diplomat who once was shot at in Lebanon and served in war-wearied Cambodia and other trouble spots.

Alsace de Bagnolet, a team that won twenty-three games and lost two in capturing the French basketball championship, lost the first game of its American to last night. The New York Athletic Club beat the Frenchmen, 103 -- 63, at the Winged Foot Club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Frank B. Ellis, director of the Office of Emergency Planning, is planning to resign soon, informed officials said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (UPI) -Illinois, paced by Bill Burwell, rallied late in the second half tonight and beat Manhattan, 61 -- 56, in the finale of the Chicago Stadium double-header.

NEWARK, Dec. 28 -- The City of Newark was accused today of having acted in "bad faith" in trying to collect taxes on buildings leased by the Port of New York Authority to private companies at Port Newark and Newark Airport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission (F.T.C.) reopened today its investigation into the merger activities of the St. Regis Paper Company of New York City. The commission has been trying to find out since 1956 if the acquisition by St. Regis of several small paper companies tended unlawfully to reduce or stifle competition in the industry.
There is an Eastern Air Lines pilot who perhaps wishes that when Mitchel Air Force Base was closed last June someone had put "gone out of business" signs at the ends of the runways.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Intercity truck tonnage rose 15.4 per cent last week from the level of 1960, the American Trucking Associations reported today.

PRIZES through the years have been getting bigger and bigger; and while no musical prize as yet has matched those of the old quiz shows, where half the universe rode on a single question, some of the recent musical competitions have taken care of their winners in quite respectable fashion.

Assets of the Republic Natural Gas Company were sold to the Socony Mobil Oil Company and four other concerns for $148,500,000 following approval of the transaction by shareholders of Republic at a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday.
Production of electric power the nation eased to 61,630,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended last Saturday, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
BY the time he reaches the second half of his new play, "The Night of the Iguana," Tennessee Williams is writing at the top of his form.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- The Rev. Carlo Boyer, a Jesuit member of the Roman Catholic Church's Secretariat for Christian Unity, said today that Christian unity demanded a Catholic hierarchy with "infallible" and "visible" authority.
OCEAN CITY, N.J. Dec. 28 -- A seal that called at a bay-front house here this morning has its hosts worried: It shows no sign of departing.

John Morrell Co., and its subsidiaries had record sales of $554,700,611 in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28, compared with volume of $511,792,499 the year before. Earnings, however, fell 39 per cent, the annual report of the meat packing concern disclosed yesterday.
Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund write in tribute to its efforts. Yesterday one letter, enclosing $25, read:
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru indicated today that he was greatly disturbed by Western criticism of India's seizure of Goa, Damao and Diu from Portugal by force.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton, the first Democrat to seek the party's Governorship normination for 1962, accused Governor Rockefeller's administration tonight of using a "papa knows best" attitude in legislative matters.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Art Market finished first in the $10,000 Seattle World's Fair Purse on the turf course at Santa Anita today but was disqualified and placed second. Micarlo, who had finished second, was declared the winner, Gawain placed third.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The gloomy events of the past weeks bring a number of emotion to the fore: disappointment a British-French obfuscation of the United Nations' commitment in the Congo; outrage at India's pious invasion of Goa and the ether Portuguese enclaves; and contempt for the Soviet veto of Security Council of forts to achieve a cease-fire and withdrawal of India's forces.
Higher hospital and insurance benefits will go into effect with the new year Monday for local longshore workers and their dependents.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 28 (UPI) -- Elgin Baylor scored 44 points tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers' free-throw accuracy led to a 121-114 victory over the Syracuse Nationals in a National Basketball Association contest.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Representative John Brademas said today that strengthening higher education in Latin America was the key to making President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress effective there.

Donald W. Alexander, administrator of the Federal Maritime Administration, has announced the appointment of Paul N. Pfeiffer as chief hearing examiner of the Federal agency, which is part of the Department of Commerce.

THE arrival on the New Frontier of men with sizable families was heralded by some as an augury of greater efficiency in government. It was reasoned that any man who could keep a wife and five or six children in good running order could easily manage the machinery of state.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The rival coaches shuffled their squads into offensive and defensive units today and went through final polishing-up drills for tomorrow's Blue-Gray football game.

President de Gaulle's year-end broadcast to the French people emphasized by its vagueness that France's major problems were not solved in 1961. He obviously found it impossible to do more than call attention to the fact that for the European Common Market, and on Algeria, Germany and France's internal economy, efforts and negotiations continue.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Bruce Drysdale and Russ Gordon excelled tonight as Temple won the Hurricane Classic basketball tournament by beating last year's winner, Miami (Fla.) 85 -- 67.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System says it never intended to charge that Montgomery County voter registrars were derelict in their duties.
BRIGHTON, Colo., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Robert M. Roberts, 40-year-old former sheriff of Adams County, was sentenced to the state prison today for burglary and conspiracy.
A member of the State Lottery Control Commission resigned this week with some strong comment about the long hours and low pay of those who regulate bingo games in the state.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- A bank book helped the Moscow police capture a gang of four men and a woman who had staged a series of hold-ups here, a Moscow newspaper reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Dr. Samuel Flagg Bemis, president of the American Historical Association, questioned today the validity of an assumption that what might have prevented two world wars could also stave off a third.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, retired, cited tonight the career of Vice President Johnson as an example of Left-Wingers' progress in converting politicians.
DENVER, Dec. 29 -- A scientist reported today that he believed he had found out why people in regions with hard water suffer less cardiovascular disease than those in places where the water is soft.

Paperboard production in the nation fell to 334,531 tons in the week ended last Saturday, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. This figure compared with 341,752 tons in the preceding week and 285,977 tons in the same period last year.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Thirteen skiers of the American Nordic combined and cross - country squad, who trained in this Adirondack Mountain village for the last week, will start racing tomorrow.
An Interstate Commerce Commission appeals board in Washington rejected a plea yesterday to suspend a 10 per cent fare increase that the New Haven Railroad will put into effect Monday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Kuwait declared today that Iraq was threatening world peace and security and poisoning the mind of Iraqi public opinion against "Kuwait's peace-loving nation."

" MADAME APHRODITE," the new off-Broadway musical that opened last night at the Orpheum is about a phony cosmetician who brews her own beauty cream and then dispenses it to gullible members of the feminine sex.

The New York Board of Regents says that unless the pace of building up the State University system is quickened dramatically, "the state will be embarrassed, costs will be higher and many of our youth will be prevented from attaining the education they should have." It urges the Governor and the Legislature to give the university "greater freedom of action" to translate its master plan from blueprint into campus.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Trade in grain futures dragged along almost at a standstill today with prices almost stationary.

The automated subway shuttle between Times Square and Grand Central is finally going to run, but it will carry some supercargo. The Transit Authority has written into its new contract with the Transport Workers Union a guarantee that a union motorman will be aboard the "manless" train on every run during a six-month experimental period.

A handsome stage presence, an unusual program and potentialities as an interpreter made a fairly interesting event out in the New York debut recital of Janet Baxter in Town Hall last yesterday afternoon.

EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Odds-makers across the border in Juarez, Mexico, today rated the speedy and surprising Wichita Shockers a 6-point choice over Villanova in tomorrow's Sun Bowl football game.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Chancellor Adenauer warned West Germans today that 1962 would not be an easy year, but coupled his warning with the assurance that "I am still convinced there will be no war in Europe."

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. (Reuters) -- The Government Ghana announced today major contracts for a vast and power project on the Volt River had been awarded United States, British, Italian Austrian, Japanese and Nigerian firms.

The performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere" at the Metropolitan Opera last night brought into prominence Randolph Symonette, who took over the role of Wotan from the indisposed Otto Edelmann on less than twelve hours' notice.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 29 -- Westchester County officials reported today that they were drafting plans for a $1,000,000 underground office center for use as a fall-out shelter. It would accommodate 200 persons and be stocked with food and other supplies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board was accused today of being so lax in certifying non-scheduled airline operations as to make "effective safety inspection a practical impossibility."

CORTLAND, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A charge that "large financial interests," with investments in State Thruway bonds, were delaying construction of the North-South Expressway south of Syracuse today was denied today.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 -- Adlai E. Stevenson reported to President Kennedy today on the recessed sixteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Lamar Tech beat Middle Tennessee, 21 -- 14, in the Tangerine Bowl football game tonight before a crowd of 6,000 persons who braved near-freezing temperatures.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The retired French liner Liberte may still be available for use as a hotel ship during the Seattle World's Fair next year, it was reported today.
THE finesse is almost the first play a bridge beginner learns, and sometimes he seems to learn it too well.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Peace Corps is reviewing he role of the colleges it has used in the training of its volunteers. There have been nine months of mixed results.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Air Force today chose the Navy's record-breaking F-4H Phantom instead of its own F-105 for use as a tactical reconnaissance fighter.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Three little girls lost their lives today in a smoky fire that apparently started in a sofa of their basement apartment and spread to a Christmas tree.

Most commodities futures traded on the New York exchanges rose yesterday in the abbreviated final session of 1961. All exchanges halted trading during the noon hour and will remain closed until Tuesday morning.

National Airlines, Inc., returned to profitable operations in the six months ended on Dec. 31, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday. Directors of National and Continental Airlines have agreed in principle on a merger, the details of which remain to be worked out.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Salvatore A. Bontempo has resigned as administrator of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

The election of Wesley L. Baker, William S. Clough Jr., John P. McGinnis and Ellis A. Simmons as vice presidents of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has been announced by Henry C. Alexander, chairman.

More concrete steps toward Christian unity were taken during 1961 than in any other recent year, the Rev. Dr. Roswell P. Barnes, executive secretary in the United States for the World Council of Churches, said yesterday.

LUDOWICI, Ga., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Responding to an announcement that the American Automobile Association had cited this town as a speed trap, Mayor J.W. Godfrey said today "we hardly arrest anyone here."
Construction electricians in New York City agreed yesterday to put off their strike, set for New Year's Eve, until next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov of the Soviet Union paid a farewell call on Secretary of State Dean Rusk today. The Russian declared later that he was still optimistic about the future of United States-Soviet relations.

An insurgent group of stockholders in the Firth Carpet Company apparently succeeded yesterday in blocking a proposed merger of Firth into Mohasco Industries, Inc., the nation's largest rug and carpet company.
Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange in 1961 closed generally higher in the heavier trading since 1929.
Mayor Wagner set the stage last night for the removal of Joseph T. Sharkey as Democratic majority leader and vice chairman of the City Council. The move had been expected for several days.
One or more large New York City commercial banks are exploring actively the possibility of acquiring a mutual savings bank through a merger.

A clergyman against whom the city had issued seventeen summonses appeared in Housing Court yesterday and pleaded guilty to fifteen violations of the housing law in a building he manages at 2176 Eighth Avenue.
The New York Knickerbockers arose in their desperation and belabored the high-flying Boston Celtics for a 110-100 National Basketball Association victory at Madison Square Garden last night.
TOKYO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Japan has produced 28,200,000 tons of crude steel this year, or 27.4 per cent more than in the previous year, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation announced today.

Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, the world champion, last night won his second straight game in the premier international tournament at the annual Christmas chess congress in Hastings, England. He beat John Littlewood of England.
Teachers outside New York City will indeed be interested in the significance of the teachers' vote in the city if, as The Times implies, "It will set patterns for school systems elsewhere."

Partners in the big, powerful commission firms rather than stock specialists on the floor of the American Stock Exchange will have the dominant voice reorganizing the exchange's rules and procedures and in picking a new president to succeed Edward T. McCormick, who resigned the $75,000-a-year post earlier this month.

Whatever the immediate effects of the annual New York Film Critics awards on the careers of the recipients, Thursday's balloting found the new prize-winners generally moving full-steam ahead, either before or behind the cameras.
Mayor Wagner signed a bill yesterday giving salary increases to himself and other elected city officials, but not before he had been denounced by eight citizens at a public hearing.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Del Carroll saddled four winners at Tropical Park today, including Will Ye, the 13 -- 10 favorite in the feature.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 29 -- The nine members of Uruguay's executive body, the National Council of Government, are widely divided over what position to take concerning Cuba at the Punta del Este Conference of hemisphere foreign ministers, called for Jan. 22.
The Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $129,943, after fixed charges, including capital and sinking funds, for the first eleven months of this year.

DENVER, Dec. 29 -- Some of those most directly concerned with putting three Americans on the moon by 1970 watched a simulated landing today. It was designed to show what would happen if the moon vehicle should come down on a mountainside.
TEANECK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Fairleigh Dickinson University plans to build a science and research center on thirty acres along the Hackensack River.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 -- President Kennedy announced today that C. Allan Stewart would be the new Ambassador to Venezuela.
Guy A. Beaudine, whose interest in basketball is purely visceral, expects to register his third consecutive Holiday Festival triumph at Madison Square Garden tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- President de Gaulle held out tonight qualified hopes for agreement on an independent Algeria, but, "in any case," he said, the bulk of the French Army engaged in Algeria will be brought home next year.
The unexpected year-end demand for prime corporate and local government bonds was undiminished yesterday as the year's last trading session came to an end.

The last week-end of the old year and the traditionally frenzied approach to the new began last night with the prospect of mostly fair skies here. But it will be cold enough to keep most revelers indoors by the fireside, punch cup or hot jazz hand.
