MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- Diosdado Macapagal, son of a peasant, was inaugurated today as the fifth President of the Philippine Republic.
An overwhelming majority of almost 250 of the country's top economic forecasters expect a high and rising level of business activity in the United States next year.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons defeated the Cincinnati Royals, 131 -- 116, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

NEWARK, Dec. 29 -- The Essex County Tax Board ruled today that the City of Newark could collect taxes for 1960 and 1961 on land and buildings of the Port of New York Authority used by private concerns.
The gifts of children touched by the plight of those less fortunate helped to push The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund over the $500,000 mark yesterday.

OMAHA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Creighton University scored its fifth straight basketball victory tonight, defeating Princeton, 63 -- 54. Paul Silas of Creighton scored 17 points. He was forced to leave the game because of personal fouls almost ten minutes before the end.

" We have never looked for anything spectacular in the way of business whenever New Year's Eve falls on a Sunday and we're glad it does not happen often," a leading Broadway ticket broker said yesterday. His sentiments were echoed by most showmen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Farm product prices rose nearly 1 per cent between mid-November and mid-December, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The department said higher prices for all species of meat animals, commercial broilers, oranges and tobaccos were primarily responsible for the increase.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Yale made more than half its shots from the field tonight and upset Evansville College, 92 -- 83, in the Evansville invitation basketball tournament. Sophomore, Buster Briley, scored 38 points for the losers.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 29 -- This city is trying to sell its City Hall.
Your leading editorial on Dec. 24, "Why U.N. Survives," is interesting and informative, as are most of your editorials. However, it is not convincing. It smacks of the song "Wishing Will Make It So."
New York became the first city in the nation yesterday to require concerns doing business with the city government to pay their workers at least $1.50 an hour.
Paul Hornung, the Green Bay Packers' versatile halfback, yesterday was named the National Football League player of the year in the United Press International poll.

Edmar Mednis had a busy day yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan yesterday as the contestants in the United States chess championship devoted their time to completing previously adjourned games.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 20 -- Historians proclaim Ethiopia to be the ancestral champion of freedom and independence in Africa. They say Ethiopia has known no conquest in 3,000 years except the Italian Fascist occupation of 1936-41.

FOR many, New Year's Eve means a quiet evening at home with the family and perhaps several close friends. But for those who continue to make it "the party of the year," gay hats, streamers, noise-makers and confetti are traditional musts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Alleged "illegal activities" among members of a New York Army Reserve unit are under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Defense Department said tonight.
DENVER, Colo., Dec. 29 -- If the arms race continues, an all-out nuclear war is inevitable, the American Association for the Advancement of Science was told tonight.
A "partial" list of charges against a suspended Bronx captain was made public last night by the Police Department.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 29 -- A state court judge today ordered the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People permanently banished from doing business in Alabama.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Two historians pictured former President Franklin D. Roosevelt today as a man who knew little about organized labor and who stayed in the background on racial matters.

Directors of the Plymouth Oil Company at a meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday approved the sale of substantially all its assets to the Ohio Oil Company for $115,000,000. Paul G. Benedum, president of Plymouth said the gross consideration was subject to certain adjustments to be made at and after the closing of the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight movements for the week ended Dec. 23 were 520,231 cars, or 10.7 per cent above the 1960 level, but 2.4 per cent behind the volume for the preceding week.

TO start the new year with a clean slate, now is a good time to go through household accumulations in closets and get rid of anything that is not in use or likely to be in the coming months. To bring order out of chaos, place articles least likely to be needed on top shelves in legibly labeled boxes (Christmas boxes come in handy for this).

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- A demand that State Democratic Chairman Michael H. Prendergast of Haverstraw fill out his term was made here tonight when the Haverstraw Democratic Town Committee unanimously upheld his record.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Defense Department created a task force today to prepare for possible resumption of atmospheric nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee chairman asked the Defense Department today to investigate complaints by United States soldiers that they had been forced to engage in "combat" duty for a war movie being made by Darryl F. Zanuck.
William K. Malester, president of Cavanagh's Enterprises, said yesterday that Cavanagh's Restaurant at 256 West Twenty-third Street would remain open despite pending bankruptcy proceedings.
SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 29 (AP) -- College football standouts from throughout the nation will play tomorrow in the thirty-seventh annual East-West game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Westinghouse Air Brake Company of Pittsburgh received a patent this week for a computer to control automatically the speed of freight cars being sorted in classification yards. Its decisions are based on reports from radar equipment such as the police use in checking for speeding autos.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Virginia Tech, led by Bucky Keller, raced past Florida, 78 -- 69, tonight and won the Gator Bowl basketball tournament. Vanderbilt defeated Navy, 77 -- 74, in the Consolation game.

An American edition of Pamela Frankau's new book, a work of nonfiction, is planned for February publication by Doubleday. Called "Pen to Paper," it summarizes the author's experiences in her thirty years of writing, describing her methods, tribulations and "beefs."
In the final session of the year, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange were almost directionless yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- President Lopez Mateos of Mexico argues that while Fanklin Roosevelt understood Latin America's problems he never had a program because he didn't get down to the economic base. Like other southern statesmen, Senor Lopez is now optimistic, feeling the Kennedy Administration shows both comprehension for the issues and a approach.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -- Indian troops have begun withdrawing from the former Portuguese territories of Goa, Damao and Diu.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Rockefeller's annual message to the Legislature next Wednesday will urge an expansion in the membership of the State Commission Against Discrimination from five to seven commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga charged today in a message to President Kennedy that the United States Ambassador had interfered in the Congo's internal affairs. The State Department rejected the charge as untrue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Another false bomb threat forced employes of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to evacuate their building today for the second successive day.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The right of a teacher to workmen's compensation because she caught mumps from her pupils was upheld by the Appellate Division here today. The court said the case was "novel and without precedent."

GREEN BAY, Wis., Dec. 29 -- At full strength with the release of Jesse Whittenton and Bill Quinlan from the hospital, the Green Bay Packers whipped through a final forty-five-minute drill today for Sunday's National Football League championship game against the New York Giants.
ELISABETHVILLE, Dec. 29 -- United Nations forces and the Katangese police sent out joint patrols today for the first time in a coordinated effort to curb looting.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, President Kennedy's father, sat up and showed "marked improvement" in the last two days, his physicians reported today.

NEW YEAR'S EVE, supposed to be the jolliest night in the year, strikes a note of gloom in many feminine hearts. An abhorrence of crowds and of forced merriment are two reasons often given for disliking the waning hours of Dec. 31.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, Dec. 29 -- President Moise Tshombe charged today that a new attack had been opened against North Katanga by troops of the central Government with the assistance of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Treasury's ninety-one-day bill rate jumped today to its highest level since the start of the 1960-61 recession. Next week's issue of ninetyone-day bills was sold today at discount rates averaging 2,703 per cent.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Louis J. Fisher, the president of the Amateur Athletic Union, today appointed John B. (Cap) Haralson of Bakersfield, Calif., as chairman of the track and field committee. Fisher said:
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 20 cents a bale up to 80 cents off yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Dec. 29 -- The Rhodesia Herald, which supports the Government of Sir Roy Welensky, accused the United States today of favoring resumption of the war in Katanga to crush President Tshombe.

In a year-end statement yesterday the president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis urged the nation "not to succumb to the feeling that war is inevitable" and to put aside any idea that the search for peace was "synonymous with appeasement."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The American Optical Company and Bausch Lomb, Inc., the country's two biggest makers of eyeglass lenses, were named today as defendants in a civil antitrust action.

ALGIERS, Dec. 29 -- President de Gaulle's broadcast left Algiers outwardly calm but deeply gloomy and touched off violence in Oran.

Perhaps it's none too soon to begin a Save-the-Hudson-Ferries Movement. What with a bridge coming to link bucolic Staten Island with its more urban northeasterly neighbor, and the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad talking about transferring its New York-bound passengers to Hudson Tube trains at Harrison, N.J., instead of bringing them to the Hoboken docks, one of these days there may be two less ferry services across the river.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dee. 29 (AP) -- Georgia Tech was a shaky 3-point favorite today over a grim, hard-working Penn State team on the eve of the seventeenth Gator Bowl football game.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Most industrial shares and Government securities advanced in quiet trading on the stock exchange here today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- British subsidiaries of United States manufacturers are making a "solid and constructive contribution" to Britain's export effort and to her balance of payments, according to the American Chamber of Commerce in London.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 -- United States authorities have barred the Soviet commandant in East Berlin and his chief adviser from entering the American sector of West Berlin.

The Seafarers International Union, which has helped immobilize a British-flag freighter to protest Agriculture Department chartering policies, announced yesterday it would take similar action against other foreign ships.

The second-floor display of toys, tapestries, wood carvings and jewelry is still on view at the Brooklyn Museum. All merchandise is for sale, at prices ranging from 50 cents to $360. Museum hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on weekdays, 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays and holidays.
